title: Hong Kong Surprise: Politics Steady but Economy Falters
description: His hometown is marking the first anniversary of its return to China on July 1, but Loon Wai-ting is in no mood to celebrate. Mr. Loon has spent the year without a job. On a recent sauna-like afternoon, in the teeming neighborhood of Mong Kok, he stood before a government labor office, fruitlessly searching a bulletin board for job listings.

title: THE CHEF
description: MANY years ago, while traveling in Mexico, I was served a stew made with an unusually fragrant chewy corn. It was unlike anything I had ever had before. The complex flavors of the stew -- nutty and bright and most of all big -- came from something that appeared utterly simple.

title: Storm Brings Wind and Hail, And Pair of Weak Tornadoes
description: Two tornadoes touched down in central Long Island early yesterday, toppling trees that damaged dozens of cars and houses and pulling down power lines and traffic signals.

title: Free Agency Opens With a Strong Crop
description: A general manager with a generous checkbook and several holes on his roster could rapidly improve his team when the free-agent signing season begins today. He could acquire goalie Mike Richter, center Doug Gilmour, center Ron Francis, right wing Brett Hull, defenseman Steve Duchesne and defenseman Uwe Krupp.

title: Dance Honors for Brothers Who Could Tap Up a Storm
description: Fayard and Harold Nicholas, the tap dancers who performed professionally as the Nicholas Brothers in movies, Broadway musicals, nightclubs and television shows, received the 1998 Samuel H. Scripps American Dance Festival Award on Monday night in ceremonies at Page Auditorium on the campus of Duke University here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUSEVITSKY, PATRICIA LILY
description: KUSEVITSKY-Patricia Lily. The Officers, Trustees, and Members of The Forest Hills Jewish Center mourn with great sadness the death of Patricia Lily Kusevitsky, mother of our Vice President of Ritual, Valerie Leibler and wife of the world renowned late Cantor David Kusevitsky. Her gentle, dignity and indomitable courage inspired and touched all who knew her, and we mourn her loss as members of her extended family. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to Valerie, and all the members of her family. Rabbi Gerald C. Skolnik Cantor Erno Grosz Carl Seldin Koerner, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIEDA, JOHN J.
description: WIEDA-John J. On June 29, 1998. Beloved husband of Ann. Loving father of Richard, Robert, Stephen, Elizabeth, Lorraine Miles, Diane, John B. and Christopher. Cherished grandfather and greatgrandfather. Reposing at Kennedy Roth Funeral Home, 41-45 58th Street, Woodside, New York, on Wednesday 2:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday 9:45 AM at Saint Sebastian R.C. Church, Woodside.

title: Clinton Tells Of Hopes and Risks On Trade
description: President Clinton told American business leaders today that corruption, environmental neglect, weak financial regulation and restrictive trade practices threaten China's growth and full entry into the global economic system.

title: Signs of Slower Growth Lift Treasury Prices
description: The prices of Treasury bonds climbed yesterday after reports on manufacturing and retail sales suggested that the economy was slowing and that inflation was tame.

title: Franny Murray, 82, Major Figure in Penn's Sports, Dies
description: Franny Murray, who starred in football and basketball for the University of Pennsylvania in the mid-1930's, then became embroiled in a major controversy over his ambitious football program as Penn's athletic director in the early 1950's, died on Sunday at his home in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 82.

title: Clouds Never Lift For Texas Underdog
description: Just when Garry Mauro thought things could not get any worse in his effort to unseat Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, things got worse.

title: Henny Penny Gets the President's Ear
description: Doom threatens. Again. This time it's a giant asteroid (''It's the size of Texas, Mr. President''), and it's the Chrysler Building that becomes New York's most conspicuously flattened landmark (just as ''Deep Impact'' toppled the Statue of Liberty and ''Godzilla'' wrecked the Brooklyn Bridge.) That damage is done by a fake meteor shower during the first part of ''Armageddon.'' The sight, however apocalyptic, isn't as scary as the prospect of raising a generation of Americans on movies like this.

title: BAYARD ADDS CONTRACT DRILLING ASSETS OF TRANSTEXAS
description: Bayard Drilling Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had bought the contract drilling assets of the TransTexas Gas Corporation for $75 million. Bayard, a land-drilling services company, said the companies had also agreed to a three-month alliance under which Bayard will provide TransTexas with as many as 15 rigs for drilling in the South Texas and Gulf Coast regions. Bayard said the deal complemented its existing land-drilling business and gave it a core operating area in South Texas. Bayard, based in Oklahoma City, had 1997 revenues of $55.7 million. TransTexas, a Houston-based natural gas and oil company, had revenues of $657.7 million for the first six months of 1997.

title: Flag Amendment Returns Lost Power; Fundamental Process
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dessert Of Strawberries And Elegance
description: PRECIOUS as they are, strawberries are not often eaten out of hand -- they're delicate, their colors bleed and in most instances, they simply aren't sweet enough. These drawbacks, however minor, have combined to make strawberries the basis for some of the best fruit desserts, from strawberry shortcake to summer pudding.

title: Birth Rate Falls to 40-Year Low Among Unwed Black Women
description: The birth rate for unmarried black women, long a focal point in the debate over the causes of poverty among African-Americans, has reached its lowest point in 40 years, Federal health officials said today.

title: Business Travel; Repairs at Westchester County Airport will be completed next month, ending a series of delays.
description: RUNWAY repairs at Westchester County Airport in White Plains are scheduled to be completed early next month, bringing an end to disruptions that began for travelers in May.

title: 6-Year Sentence Possible For a Fatal Stabbing
description: A man who fatally stabbed a student inside Bayonne High School could serve as few as six years in prison, officials said after he pleaded guilty on Monday to aggravated manslaughter.

title: Oakley-Camby Deal Is Final
description: The Knicks tied up some loose ends yesterday before the National Basketball Association locked out its players at midnight. After the Toronto waived Charles Oakley's physical, the draft-day deal that sent Marcus Camby to the Knicks and Oakley to the Raptors became final.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORTON, WILLIAM S.
description: NORTON-William S. The AllenStevenson School records with great sadness the death of Dr. William S. Norton, an alumnus from the Class of 1926 and father of Thomas Norton, Class of 1958. Dr. Norton served actively as School Physician and on the Board of Allen-Stevenson from 1947-1972, after which time he was elected Trustee Emeritus. To his wife, Priscilla Waters Norton, and his entire family, we offer our deepest sympathy. Ronald S. Rolfe '60, President of the Board David R. Trower, Headmaster

title: Ferraro to Donate Tobacco Fee
description: Moving to quash a potentially damaging campaign issue, Geraldine A. Ferraro has decided to donate to charity the after-tax proceeds of a $20,000 honorarium she received from the tobacco industry last year, her aides said yesterday.

title: Phil Collins Offers Swing Fare
description: Arena shows, Top 10 hits and million-selling albums weren't enough for Phil Collins; he wanted to lead a big band. And now he has one, a brassy 20-piece group that played a sold-out show at Carnegie Hall on Monday night. As midlife diversions go, the Phil Collins Big Band is just the thing for a diligent, meticulous musician who still enjoys the hard work of drumming.

title: Pleading a Case for the Child; Educator Stresses Developmental Needs Over Methods
description: To this day, the winnowing process from his own youth still gnaws at him: how he was able to make it, while so many equally intelligent peers who grew up in less nurturing environments could not.

title: 19 Nations See U.S. As Threat To Cultures
description: Nineteen nations, including America's closest friends, joined forces at a conference here today to protect themselves from what they see as the gravest threats to their collective cultures -- free trade and the United States.

title: Chinese Say Clinton Makes Them Feel More Free, but for How Long?
description: For a week, millions of curious Chinese have sought out a chance to lay eyes on Bill Clinton, on TV or in person, to catch their first glimpse of what wide open democracy looks like.

title: Douglas A. McCrary, 83, Decorated Pilot
description: Douglas A. McCrary, a rancher, community leader and a decorated World War II pilot, died at his home in Calvert, Tex., on June 16. He was 83.

title: Optimism Over Economic Efforts by Japan Bolsters Yen
description: The dollar plummeted more than two and a half yen yesterday -- its biggest loss since the United States and Japan sold dollars two weeks ago -- as traders reacted to signs that Japan was making progress to mend its ailing banking industry.

title: Woman Admits Starving Son Who Died in 1997
description: A 28-year-old woman pleaded guilty in Bronx Supreme Court yesterday to starving and beating her 5-year-old son. The woman, Jocelyn Bennett, sobbed in the courtroom as she confessed to second-degree murder in the March 1997 death of her son, Daytwon.

title: Is It Pasteurized? Juice Labels Will Tell
description: THIS fall's jug of fresh apple cider will look different from the cider jugs of previous years. It will wear a label that warns of the hazards of drinking juice that has not been pasteurized or otherwise treated to destroy potentially harmful bacteria.

title: U.N. Team Says Congo Army Killed Hutu
description: The human rights investigators whom Secretary General Kofi Annan was forced to withdraw from Congo, the former Zaire, in April today accused Congolese soldiers and their allies in the Rwandan Army of killing unarmed Hutu refugees in 1996 and 1997.

title: Venator Settles Case With S.E.C.
description: Venator Group Inc., the former Woolworth Corporation, and four of its former executives have agreed to settle Securities and Exchange Commission charges that they had falsified earnings in the 1993 fiscal year.

title: Liberties; Le Tout Swivet
description: We're all in a new tizzy.

title: Federal Officials Release Report on Discrimination
description: Federal officials said yesterday that they had found no evidence that Teaneck schools discriminate against black or Hispanic students and teachers regarding placement in honors classes, guidance services or hiring.

title: Come, Sit, Don't Beg: Dogs Dine Out in New York
description: FOR dog owners and their pets in search of a dinner out together, New York can be a town without pity. Yet with the city's dog population on the increase, man, dog and restaurant seem to be entering a new era of accommodation.

title: Whitman Cuts $42.8 Million From Budget
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed a new $18.1 billion state budget into law tonight, using her line-item veto power to eliminate $42.8 million in legislative spending, as well as language prohibiting her from turning public employee jobs over to private contractors.

title: Anti-Gay Meanness
description: To the Editor:

title: Commercial Real Estate; Plan Seeks to Clarify Muddled Lower Manhattan
description: As Nieuw Amsterdam was only 22 blocks in extent, one Dutch colonist could easily find another by suggesting a rendezvous at the market field. Do not try that today.

title: Picturing You at Prometheus
description: Dear New York Visitor,

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about plans by the Rockwell International Corporation to spin off its semiconductor division referred incorrectly to the size of that business and misstated the state of the company's overall sales. Automation equipment, not semiconductors, is Rockwell's biggest business. It is the automation business, not the company as a whole, that is experiencing flat sales.

title: Glitches Snarl Malaysia's New Airport
description: SEPANG, Malaysia  Kuala Lumpur's new airport opened Tuesday with glitches in its central computer causing the baggage and check-in systems to shut, bringing chaos to Southeast Asia's biggest airport.

title: Ewing Blames Owners For Game's Labor Woes
description: On the night that the National Basketball Association shut down for business, the Knicks' Patrick Ewing blamed free-spending franchises for the league's contentious labor situation, but offered few solutions for a new agreement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, ELLA M. (NEE MIELZINER)
description: GOLDSTEIN-Ella M. (Nee Mielziner). Of Forest Hills, New York. Born in Cleveland, OH. Beloved wife of the late Jacob Goldstein. Devoted mother of Samuel (Marion), Norman (Rita) and Richard (Eileen). Adoring grandmother of Debra and Joe, Felicia and Bruce, Michael, Melissa and Lawrence, Gabrielle & David. Adoring great grandmother of Jake, Tucker and Jacob. Member of Temple Isaiah and Sisterhood, National Council of Jewish Women, Forest Hills Section, Suburban League Cerebral Palsy and American Jewish Congress. Services Wednesday, July 1st, 1PM Schwartz Brothers Funeral Home, Forest Hills, N.Y.

title: Term-Limit Campaign: Less Bang for the Buck
description: Advocates of term limits have been unusually active this year, pressing candidates in just about every state, especially Congressional candidates, to pledge to serve a limited time in office. Those candidates who have refused have been sharply chastised in costly advertising campaigns, and those who have taken a pledge have been roundly praised.

title: Glimpses of Change in China
description: President Clinton's trip to China has given Americans an extended look at political life in that complex and changing country. Some of what they have witnessed was predictable, including the Chinese Government's effort to clear outspoken dissidents from Mr. Clinton's path. But a good deal was not, like the uncensored broadcast in China of Mr. Clinton's news conference with President Jiang Zemin. The signs of unexpected openness may be the most encouraging development of the Clinton visit.

title: After Decades of Words for Albert, Silence
description: Marv Albert's life is one without work. Nine months after pleading guilty to misdemeanor assault three days into an embarrassing trial, he attends movies; reads voraciously; plays tennis with Kenny, his oldest son, and his brother, Steve; walks his new pugs, Lulu and Ruby, and plans a future with his fiancee, Heather Faulkiner, from their duplex apartment on Columbus Avenue.

title: Insurers Gain While Doctors Lose
description: To the Editor:

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Alabama Governor Wins Runoff in Triumph for the Right
description: In a convincing victory for religious conservatives, Gov. Fob James Jr. won a decisive majority tonight over the businessman Winton Blount 3d in Alabama's Republican primary runoff for governor.

title: Business Group Reaches Agreement to Buy Nets
description: A group of New Jersey businessmen reached an agreement to buy a majority interest in the Nets yesterday, setting the stage for the team to attempt a move out of the Meadowlands Sports Complex and to a proposed site in Newark.

title: Excerpts From Timothy McVeigh Letter
description: Following are excerpts from a letter dated Oct. 20, 1993, and written by Timothy J. McVeigh to his sister Jennifer McVeigh. The idiosyncrasies in spelling and punctuation are Mr. McVeigh's.

title: Holocaust Scholar Quits Museum Job
description: Expressing ''deep regret,'' the United States Holocaust Museum today accepted the resignation of John K. Roth, whose appointment as the head of a new center for Holocaust scholarship ran into severe criticism from some Jewish groups that said he had made inappropriate comments about the Holocaust and that campaigned for his ouster.

title: Japan Jobless Rate Remains at Record High
description: Japan's unemployment rate hovered at a record-high 4.1 percent in May for the second straight month as the nation's deepest recession in a quarter-century prompted companies such as Nissan and Kajima to announce job cuts. A record 2.93 million Japanese were out of work, 490,000 more than in May last year, the Management and Coordination Agency said yesterday. The jobless rate, which had been forecast to rise to 4.2 percent, did not increase, however, because an equal number of Japanese people stopped looking for work.

title: Donations Rise, Ending United Way Slump
description: Reversing years of declining support, United Way of Tri-State will report today that it raised $103 million in the last year, up 4.5 percent over the previous year after adjusting for inflation, the first real increase in this decade.

title: G.M. Workers Expected A Much Better Vacation
description: The way Ryan Garland sees it, the two strikes here that have shut down the General Motors Corporation and put his father out of work are a blessing.

title: Omnicom and Others Win Awards
description: The New York Festivals has named six grand Best of Show winners in its 41st annual international print and radio competition.

title: Differences Over Privacy On the Internet
description: Differences between European nations and the United States over how to protect consumer privacy have led to a clash over technologies endorsed by the world's two leading makers of browsing software for navigating the World Wide Web, the Microsoft Corporation and the Netscape Communications Corporation.

title: Paris Journal; La Ministre? Over the Immortals' Dead Bodies
description: You say ''Madame le ministre,'' I say ''Madame la ministre,'' the French Government decreed on Monday.

title: CARPENTER TECHNOLOGY SELLING TALLEY BUSINESSES
description: The Carpenter Technology Corporation, a maker of specialty metals based in Reading, Pa., said yesterday that it had sold one Talley Industries business and would sell another for undisclosed terms as it focuses on the steelmaking operations of the recently acquired Talley. Carpenter, which had 1997 revenue of $939 million, said it had sold John J. McMullen Associates Inc. in a leveraged buyout and had agreed to sell the Waterbury Companies to Waterbury's management team. The two businesses had combined 1997 revenue of $121 million. John J. McMullen, a naval architecture and marine engineering concern in Arlington, Va., had 1997 revenue of $84 million. Waterbury, of Waterbury, Conn., makes buttons as well as products for odor and pest control. It had sales of $37 million last year.

title: Azgi and Ali's Excellent Adventure
description: The wide-eyed young man with a suitcase is an innocent soul. ''I like hamburger, baseball and Mr. Bob Dylan,'' he announces in an eager-to-please, Indian-accented voice. Soon he reveals, ''I am the first person in my entire family to fly on an airplane'' and pauses before adding, ''I hope no crashing.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IMMEDIATO, DANIEL J.
description: IMMEDIATO-Daniel J. July 1, 1937 to January 28, 1994. Always remembered, never forgotten.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASPER, STANLEY A.
description: KASPER-Stanley A. Born Jan. 9, 1918 in Brooklyn, New York. Passed away June 29, 1998 in The Woodlands, Texas at the age of 80. Stanley was a POW during W.W. II having served with the U.S. Army as a First Lieutenant and was awarded the Purple Heart. He was a Sr. VP of Irving Trust in NY, NY during most of his professional career and after his retirement in 1981 was a financial consultant in the NY and Houston area. He was a member of Sts. Simon & Jude Catholic Church in The Woodlands, TX., and was also an avid golfer. Survived by wife Kathleen Kasper; daughter Mary-Fran Ciavarella; sons and daughters-in-law Richard P. and Pat Kasper, John S. and Theresa Kasper; son Michael Kasper; grandchildren Michael R. Ciavarella, Valerie Kasper, Bradley Kasper; cousin Dorothy Switzer. Funeral mass 10AM Thursday, July 2, 1998 at St. Simon & St. Jude Catholic Church. Interment in the Houston National Cemetery.

title: CBS loves TV; now the network wants viewers to fancy CBS.
description: A LEADING agency has been recruited to help convince viewers that CBS loves TV as much as the next network if not more.

title: Fierce Run on the Rand by Speculators Shocks South Africa
description: Speculators have given the South African rand a nasty shock in the last few days, forcing the nation's central bank to enlist help from the United States and Britain and to raise interest rates sharply to stem the currency's fall.

title: New Pepsi Drink to Use Special Sweetener
description: The Food and Drug Administration approved the use yesterday of an artificial sweetener known as Ace-K in soft drinks. And about an hour later, Pepsico Inc. announced it would be rolling out a new diet cola nationwide by October that will use both Ace-K and aspartame, known to consumers as Nutrasweet or Equal.

title: Creditors Unhappy With Marvel Plan
description: Unsecured creditors and investors expressed their dissatisfaction today as a two-day Federal court hearing on a plan for Marvel Entertainment Group to emerge from bankruptcy protection by combining with Toy Biz Inc.

title: Wary Students Jam CUNY Remedial Classes
description: A month after trustees at the City University of New York voted to phase out remedial courses from their four-year colleges and set higher entrance standards, college officials say they are seeing a big jump in the number of students applying for CUNY's summer remedial courses, hoping to master basic reading, writing and mathematics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAY, AGNES D'ARCY
description: HAY-Agnes D'Arcy. In her 90th year on June 29, 1998 of Setauket, Long Island. Miss Hay was the daughter of the late John B. Hay and Agnes D'Arcy Hay. She was a retired school teacher at the Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn. Funeral Service Friday, July 3, 1998, 1PM at the Caroline Church Setauket, L.I. Interment Caroline Churchyard Cemetery. Funeral information contact the O.B. Davis Funeral Homes, Port Jefferson Station, Long Island.

title: New York's Unguarded Beaches
description: Los Angeles County does not rely on the mystique of its fabled beaches to attract summer lifeguards. It scours swim teams in high schools and colleges on the West Coast, casting its net as far east as Arizona. New York City, once again in the throes of a lifeguard shortage, could take a page from California's book. Four miles of city beach are now closed. Some stretches are shut for environmental reasons, but two and a half miles are closed because there are not enough guards. That is unacceptable in a crowded metropolis, where summer heat and humidity can reach triple digits.

title: Concerns on Rockefeller Center Plans
description: Voicing concern about the face that Rockefeller Center will project to Fifth Avenue and the world, the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission recommended yesterday that the center's owners scale back plans to turn some stone exteriors into virtual walls of glass.

title: Alabama Governor Wins G.O.P. Runoff
description: In a victory for religious conservatives, Gov. Fob James Jr. won a decisive majority last night in a primary runoff for governor. A strong supporter of school prayer, he will face Lieut. Gov. Don Siegelman, who easily won the Democratic nomination four weeks ago.

title: JOHN PAUL MOVES TO STIFLE DISSENT ON HEATED ISSUES
description: In one of his sharpest rebukes to liberal Catholics to date, Pope John Paul II today made changes in canon law aimed at stamping out debate on a wide range of passionately discussed issues, including euthanasia and the ordination of women.

title: Linda Tripp, Who Taped Lewinsky, Goes Before Grand Jury
description: Flanked by her son and daughter, Linda R. Tripp walked into Federal court today to testify before a grand jury, five months after her furtive tape recordings of a confiding friend turned Monica S. Lewinsky into a household name and turned the White House upside down.

title: The Democracy Gap
description: Trade is the central issue in the debate over American policy toward China. Should we extend permanent most-favored-nation status to China? Under what terms should China be permitted to join the World Trade Organization?

title: Some Scientists Are Hopeful Again for an AIDS Cure
description: At the 12th World AIDS Conference, some scientists today expressed cautious but renewed hope of ultimately eliminating H.I.V. from the body and thus curing AIDS.

title: Guided Tours of Sonoma, Napa and Beyond
description: TWO guidebooks designed to make traveling in the California wine country more fun have just been published. They're both good, even though neither one offers help on the single most pressing issue facing the Napa County visitor: How in blazes do you make a left-hand turn coming out of a winery along Route 29?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARK, SAMUEL, D.D.S.
description: BARK-Samuel, D.D.S. On June 30, 1998. Born December 12, 1903. Husband of the late Rebecca (Beatrice) Bark. Father of Peter and Belen Bark, and Terry and Joseph Kochman. Grandfather of David and Michelle Bark, Michael Bark and Bethann Bark, Scott Kochman, Gerald & Shari Kochman, & Larry and Norci Kochman. Great grandfather of Brady Bark, Naomi, Kimberly, Sidney and Isaac Kochman. Services today, July 1, 1:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Shiva will follow at the home of Peter and Belen Bark.

title: Giuliani Endorses Vacco's Re-election Bid
description: Seeking to prove his loyalty to state Republican leaders for the second time in a month, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani embraced the re-election campaign of State Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco yesterday.

title: Cincinnati Enquirer Workers Subpoenaed in Chiquita Case
description: In the wake of an apology by The Cincinnati Enquirer for illegally obtaining voice mail messages used in a scathing expose of Chiquita Brands International Inc., a special prosecutor has issued subpoenas to some of the newspaper's employees.

title: Sports of The Times; Silly Kick Will Haunt England
description: GLENN HODDLE hears the word in Eng land ''vendetta.'' He calls it ''a horrible expression.''

title: Paul van Buren, 74, 'Death of God' Exponent
description: The Rev. Dr. Paul Matthews van Buren, a leading exponent of the ''death of God'' school of theology, died on June 18 at Memorial Hospital in Blue Hill, Me. He was 74 and lived on nearby Little Deer Isle.

title: Cone Isn't Perfect, But He Isn't Bad
description: David Cone walked briskly to the Yankee bullpen last night as the blue tarpaulin was being removed from the field following a rain delay. Cone had not thrown a pitch in almost an hour and wanted to loosen up his right arm. But he stopped on the warning track and gazed up at the videotape replay of David Wells's perfect game that was being shown to the soggy fans at Yankee Stadium. What does it feel like to be perfect?

description: New Look at Stanhope

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNAN, EDWARD, M.D.
description: BRENNAN-Edward, M.D. The Executive Committee, faculty, staff and candidates of the Columbia University Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research, express our deepest sorrow over the death of our esteemed colleague, Edward Brennan, M.D. He brought a profound dedication and quiet authority to his psychoanalytic work. He will be greatly missed by his patients, his students and colleagues, and all of us who benefitted from his warmth, his strength, and his integrity. We extend our sympathy to his wife Alice, his children, Elizabeth, Noel and Alison and his grandchildren, Claire, Molly and Caroline. Robert A. Glick, M.D. Director

title: McVeigh Letters Before Blast Show the Depth of His Anger
description: Previously undisclosed letters by Timothy J. McVeigh to his younger sister before the bombing of the Federal building in Oklahoma City reveal him as deeply frustrated and at one point suicidal over his inability to confide the extent of his anti-Government activities to his family.

title: LIBERTY MUTUAL IN DEAL TO ACQUIRE FLORIDA INSURER
description: The Liberty Mutual Group, the Boston-based property casualty insurer, agreed yesterday to buy Summit Holding Southeast Inc. for $222.4 million, including the assumption of debt. Summit, of Lakeland, Fla., will contribute its 7 percent share of the Florida workers' compensation market to Liberty Mutual, the largest United States provider of such coverage. The deal would give Summit's owners $33 for each of their 5.8 million shares, while redeeming Summit's 1.64 million preferred shares at a cost of about $17 million and transferring $14.3 million of debt to Liberty Mutual. Summit's shares surged $6.125 yesterday, to $31.875.

title: Journal; Hollywood's Mental Block
description: There may not be a writer in America in a more delicate spot than Chris Gerolmo. He is the Hollywood screenwriter (''Mississippi Burning'') and director who had completed the script of ''Laws of Madness,'' the Michael Laudor story, and was prepared to start shooting it when Mr. Laudor, a schizophrenic who became an academic star at Yale, was charged with the brutal stabbing of his pregnant fiancee, Caroline Costello.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLANCY, CLEO GARIS
description: CLANCY-Cleo Garis. Of Key Largo, FL, formerly of Short Hills and Spring Lake, New Jersey, on June 28, 1998. She was born in Newark, New Jersey, on June 30, 1905 the daughter of the late Lillian M. and Howard R. Garis who were authors of numerous children's books including early Tom Swift & Bobbsey Twins books. Howard Garis was also the creator of The Uncle Wiggly stories which he began shortly after the turn of the century & continued to write until his death in 1962. Mrs. Clancy was also preceded in death by her brother, Roger C. Garis. She & the late John J. Clancy were married in 1928. John Clancy practiced law in New Jersey for over fifty years until his death in 1979. He served as a Commissioner of The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and at the time of his death was Chairman of Carteret Savings. Mrs. Clancy was a graduate of St. Vincent's Academy and The Faucett School of Fine Arts, and was herself the author of several children's books. She is survived by her daughter and son-in-law, Carroll and Sheldon Brooks of Key Largo, Florida. Interment will be in Spring Lake, NJ. Contributions in her memory to ORCAT, 100 Anchor Drive, North Key Largo, FL 33037 or The Carmelite Monastery, P.O. Box 785, Flemington, NJ 08822. For information, David Lee Funeral Home, 612-473-5577.

title: Galina Brezhnev, 69, Child Of Longtime Soviet Leader
description: Galina Brezhnev, the high-living daughter of the former Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev whose antics often led to scandal, died today in a Moscow hospital. She was 69.

title: In Napa's Shadow, Sonoma Shines
description: RESIDENTS of Sonoma County will say this much about their neighbor to the east: the Napa Valley is better known and has better restaurants. That said, they wouldn't dream of living there.

title: An Angel Calls Back the Music of Old Havana; From Shining Shoes to Carnegie Hall, and the Stories Along the Way
description: The ''Buena Vista Social Club'' album quietly crept into the marketplace in the fall of 1997. It was an unpretentious record steered by an American musician, Ry Cooder, and made in Havana by 80- and 90-year-olds singing a gentle, pre-revolutionary pop music that had mostly been forgotten.

title: Plea Deal Rescinded, Informer May Face Life
description: Four years ago, Anthony S. Casso, who was depicted by the authorities as one of the Mafia's most notorious leaders, struck a deal with Federal prosecutors. For disclosing mob secrets and testifying against other high-ranking gangsters, he would probably avoid a lifetime prison sentence even though he had participated in 15 murder plots and other violent crimes.

title: Washington Talk; Social Security's Fix And Al Gore's Future
description: If the prospect of trying to fix Social Security gives heartburn to nearly all politicians, it could be downright ulcerating for Vice President Al Gore. His role in any solution to the retirement system's looming financial problems could prove either a tremendous accomplishment or a heavy burden going into the 2000 Presidential race.

title: Jail for Leader And Advisers In Bribery Case At Police Union
description: The former head of the New York City transit police union and top union lawyers and advisers were sentenced to prison yesterday for their roles in a kickback scheme involving millions of dollars in union funds.

title: U.S. Jet Fighter Fires Missile at an Iraqi Antiaircraft Battery
description: An American F-16 fired a missile at an Iraqi antiaircraft battery today because the Iraqi forces had aimed radar at one of four British jets patrolling the ''no flight'' zone over southern Iraq, officials here said.

title: BASEBALL: A Hacker Becomes a Hitter; Sosa Shows Patience at the Plate in His Finest Season
description: Once upon a time, Sammy Sosa was the kind of mad-hatter batter who swung so violently and so indiscriminately that, it was said, he would attack even a white paper cup if it came floating toward home plate.

title: Merrill Creates Telebras Security
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said today that it had created a single security for the 12 companies being spun off from the sale of Telecomunicacoes Brasileiras S.A., known as Telebras, allowing investors a cheaper way of investing in Brazil's national phone system.

title: Clinton Enjoys Radio Stint: No Violence, Drugs or Sex
description: Talk radio is still new in China, so good behavior counts.

title: Best Team Has Zero Starters In Denver
description: The fans who punch the holes in the All-Star ballots were not overly impressed with the individual players on the best team in the major leagues, since the Yankees did not have any starters voted to the American League team yesterday. This was not as shocking as it might sound because the Yankees have exemplified a team concept and do not really have one standout player. They have a handful of stars.

title: U.S. Nuclear Arms' Cost Put at $5.48 Trillion
description: Nuclear weapons have cost the United States at least $5.48 trillion since 1940, and for most of that time neither Congress, the armed services nor the President had a clear idea what was being spent, according to a four-year study sponsored by the Brookings Institution.

title: SUNBEAM REVIEWING EARNINGS AND MAY RESTATE
description: The Sunbeam Corporation, which ousted its chairman, Albert J. Dunlap, last month, said yesterday that it had hired the accounting firm Deloitte & Touche L.L.P. to determine whether its 1997 earnings would have to be restated. Deloitte will review Sunbeam's financial statements, with assistance from the company's regular auditor, Arthur Andersen L.L.P. Sunbeam, the largest United States maker of small appliances, said it might be forced to restate its results for last year and for the first quarter of 1998. The review follows last week's report of an ''informal inquiry'' by the Securities and Exchange Commission into Sunbeam's accounting practices.

title: THE MARKETS: STOCKS -- The Balloon That Refuses To Be Popped; Investors Keep Lifting Stocks Despite Warnings
description: The warnings that the bubble is about to burst have been sounded each quarter for the last few years, but investors in the stock market continue to ignore them. And so far, despite a series of blows lately that were widely expected to take the air out of the balloon, they have been right.

title: Watermelon Drinks: Cool, Sweet, Colorful
description: WATERMELON has an all-American image, one that goes along with hot summer days, picnics at the beach and backyard cookouts. But this does not give enough credit to a fruit that has been refreshing people since ancient times.

title: Critics Fear Shift in Control of Child Clinics
description: The Giuliani administration today will put into place the final pieces of its plan to reorganize the city's network of 39 child health-care clinics, and advocates for the poor are worried that it will harm the quality of services at clinics that serve the city's poorest children.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Searching for Oil, and Maybe Love, in the Snow
description: WHERE THE SEA USED TO BE

title: Expectations Still Soar a Mile High
description: For most players, the All-Star Game provides a respite from the longest regular season among professional team sports. That should be the case for everyone heading to the midseason festivities in Denver next week. Except for Mark McGwire.

title: Tiny Croatia Takes Big Step With Victory
description: Croatia does not occupy much space on the map of Europe, but it is big enough to provide a homeland to one of the planet's better soccer teams. Today, that team advanced to the quarterfinals in its first World Cup with a 1-0 victory over Romania that was more emotional than sensational.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, MARION
description: GOLDBERG - Marion. Beloved wife of Lou. Devoted mother of Barry, Judy, Diane and Edythe. Cherished grandmother of Rachel, Steven, Elyssa, Brooke, Ricky, Brittany and Bradley. Services Wednesday, 11AM, at ''RiversideNassau North Chapel'', 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: Chief of Packard Bell NEC Steps Down
description: Beny Alagem, the chief executive and president of Packard Bell NEC Inc., resigned today, citing fundamental differences with the company's main investor, the NEC Corporation, and Groupe Bull, a minority shareholder.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: Ozzy Osbourne, Settled Survivor

title: Nomura Unit Buying Thorn for $1.63 Billion
description: Future Rentals P.L.C., a new company that was formed by Nomura International P.L.C., agreed yesterday to purchase Thorn P.L.C., the second-biggest rent-to-own appliance business in Britain, for $:980 million ($1.63 billion) in cash. Future Rentals will pay 250 pence a share. Shares of Thorn advanced 19.5 pence yesterday, closing at 230 pence in London, and the company's American depository receipts added $1.75 each, ending at $16 in Nasdaq trading.

title: Bitter Festival Chief Says It's Definite: Shanghai Opera Won't Appear
description: Nigel Redden, the director of the Lincoln Center Festival, announced here tonight that his struggle with local culture authorities over how to produce ''The Peony Pavilion'' had finally ended in failure.

title: Police Concede They Were Caught Off Guard by Size of the Protest
description: New York City police officials acknowledged that they were caught off guard yesterday by a surging crowd of thousands of protesting construction workers who engaged in a running series of violent incidents as overwhelmed police strained to maintain crowd control.

title: About New York; Bidding Wars Make Agency Defend Its Turf
description: THE smiling, silver-haired visage of the Rev. Joseph Fitzpatrick peeks out from a photograph Lizette Tait keeps behind her desk. It reminds her of Father Fitz, a feisty Jesuit and sociologist who founded Neighborhood Youth and Family Services, the nonprofit child welfare agency she directs in the Bronx.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Hong Kong is a graveyard for political prognosticators. Everybody predicted we'd have a bumpy ride politically but the economy would take care of itself. Exactly the opposite has happened.''

title: Insurers Gain While Doctors Lose
description: To the Editor:

title: Take Flight? A Norwegian Would
description: Seventeen years have passed since the Norwegian jazz-fusion guitar hero Terje Rypdal performed in New York, and at his concert at Symphony Space on Saturday night, the closing show of the JVC Jazz Festival, his insularity showed. It's hard to approach his music with the normal concertgoing views: Is it gesturally akin to other improvised music made today? Does the music have a sense of humility, a sense of its place in the world, a human touch? Does it represent some sort of general movement among musicians?

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: WHEAT SURGES. Wheat and soybean prices jumped after the Agriculture Department reported that inventories were smaller than expected. July wheat rose rose 8 cents, or 3 percent, to $2.7625 a bushel.

title: Neighbor Accused of Firing at House of Paroled Rapist
description: A 23-year-old neighbor of a paroled rapist who authorities say was the target of vigilante gunfire two weeks ago was arrested today and accused of firing five bullets into the house where the parolee lived.

title: Belying the Legend of the Crusty Old Salt
description: TEMPTING as it may seem, Dan Cavaluzzi, a towboat captain, does not refer to the weekend sailors who get hung up on sandbars or run out of fuel as jerks, morons or any of the other terms one may use for people who mess up because of their own incompetence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALEF, STEVEN A.
description: GALEF-Steven A. We are all charged with the responsibility to help make the world a better place. Steve Galef aced that course. Steve was a master at finding the prudent, the enhancing and the positive. His integrity, sound judgement and professionalism were his bywords. He was strong, soft, energetic, even paced, compassionate and grounded. Steve served his country and his community with uncommon distinction. The world is a better place for his having walked through it. He will be missed for the remainder of our lives. We are blessed, however, by having touched Steve and, far more, by having been touched by him. Alice and Stanley

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the dismissal of James Fallows as editor of U.S. News & World Report misspelled the given name of a columnist whom Mr. Fallows removed earlier. He is Steven V. Roberts, not Stephen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMEL, ARTHUR JAMES
description: HAMMEL-Arthur James, 71. Of Weston, Florida. Passed away June 29th, 1998. Beloved husband of Harriet. Cherished father of Steven, Susan, Marc, Douglas and Paul. Grandfather of David, Joshua, Victoria, Alexander and Danielle. A Memorial service on Wednesday, July 1, at 4 P.M., at Menorah Gardens, 21100 West Griffin Road, Fort Lauderdale, Florida. 954-434-1531. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The American Heart Association, American Cancer Society or a charity to benefit the homeless.

title: Flag Amendment Returns Lost Power; Protecting Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: French Plan to Buy American Center's Paris Home
description: When the new American Center here was inaugurated by Hillary Rodham Clinton in June 1994, the $41 million building designed by Frank Gehry looked set to become a hothouse of American artistic creativity. Instead, barely 19 months later, the center suspended its activities for lack of funds and its only remaining asset, its ultramodern headquarters in eastern Paris, was put up for sale.

title: Anti-Gay Meanness; Selective Bible Quoting
description: To the Editor:

title: Rap Singer Is Shot In Robbery in Brooklyn
description: A member of the hip hop group Wu-Tang Clan was shot twice and robbed of some gold jewelry yesterday in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Those Distorted Images of Startling Invention
description: Jarring and beautiful in their distortion and richness, selected works by Martha Graham were vibrantly performed at Marymount Manhattan College on Sunday by the young members of the Martha Graham Dance Ensemble. There was also a premiere, ''Apologue,'' by the group's artistic director, Kenneth Topping.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the effect of the Supreme Court's decision to expand the definition of disabilities misidentified the infertility organization for which Deborah Wachenheim is director of government affairs. It is Resolve, not the National Infertility Association.

title: Mongols, Told to Use Surnames Again, Are Trying to Remember
description: KARAKORUM, Mongolia  Sipping a bowl of fermented mare's milk inside his tent on the windswept plains of central Mongolia, D. Shatar proudly tells of the traditions he will pass down to the next generation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMUELS, FRANCES
description: SAMUELS-Frances. Age 91, of Guttenberg, New Jersey. Beloved mother of Audrey & Steve Kurtz, Edward and Janet Samuels, and Judith Kay. Cherished grandmother of five and great-grandmother of two. Graveside services are 1 PM, Thursday, at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Brooklyn, New York.

title: In Book Publishing, Some Editors Still Care; Writers Wanted
description: To the Editor:

title: Turbulent Labor Rally Snarls Midtown
description: More than 20,000 construction workers, protesting the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's use of a nonunion contractor, staged a turbulent rally in midtown Manhattan yesterday that erupted into clashes with the police and paralyzed traffic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE GRUCHY, KENNETH
description: de GRUCHY-Kenneth. Of Ridgewood, NJ on June 30. Husband of Jean and father of Cheryl and Ken, Jr. Formerly with Graybar Electric Inc. and Anixter Bros. Inc.

title: Edward F. Preston, 79, Ex-O.M.B. Executive
description: Edward F. Preston, a former executive with the Office of Management and Budget who helped develop the Senior Executive Service, died on June 8. He was 79 and lived in Alexandria, Va.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about a Serbian assault against rebels in Kosovo Province misstated the assignment of an American Ambassador, Christopher Hill. He is the envoy to Macedonia, not Montenegro. (There is no American ambassador to Montenegro, a part of Yugoslavia.)

title: 3 People Are Slashed In 2 Incidents on Subway
description: Three people were slashed in two seperate incidents on the subway yesterday, the police said.

title: Investors Cool To Hilton Plan; Stock Tumbles
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation announced a long-awaited transaction today that is aimed at enhancing shareholder value. But investors seemed to be focused not on the deal that was done, but on the one that got away -- and that helped cause shares of Hilton to fall in heavy trading.

title: Women and Men Are Set for Races
description: In the 159-year history of the Henley Royal Regatta, preserving rowing tradition rather than initiating change has been a hallmark of the event, the sport's oldest crew race. This week, for the first time, Henley will stage an invitational event for women's eight-oared shells among the United States, the Australian, the Canadian and the British national crews.

title: King's Lawyer Cites An Agreement
description: Don King's defense lawyer said yesterday that the contract at the core of King's Federal wire fraud trial in Manhattan reflected a verbal agreement with the boxer Julio Cesar Chavez and was not the calculated fraud alleged by prosecutors.

title: In Queens, Eye-Opening Curries and Vindaloo
description: LOVERS of Indian food often rant against New York's generic Indian restaurants, where the menus endlessly repeat the same dozen dishes and the food has been denatured for the home delivery market. These restaurants usually offer northern India's meat-based cuisine, which, with its Tandoori grilled meats, curries and rice dishes, is easy for Americans to appreciate.

title: A Small Brazilian Treat, Rich With Cheese
description: A LITTLE cheese biscuit from Brazil called pao de queijo is quietly building a big following in Manhattan. Baskets of the golden, puffy biscuits are showing up in trendy Latin restaurants, from Churrascaria Plataforma in midtown to Coffee Shop, the Brazilian cafe on Union Square. But the ones made at Good and Plenty, the catering and takeout shop at 410 West 43d Street, are particularly irresistible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRINNIN, JOHN MALCOLM
description: BRINNIN-John Malcolm. The members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters note with sorrow the death of their esteemed colleague whose passing will be mourned by the world of literature.

title: Scraping Away at the 'Black Legend' of a Spanish King
description: King Philip II not only lost the invincible Armada in 1588 while trying to invade England but also sunk in most history books, as the epitome of the cruelty and intolerance associated with imperial Spain.

title: PHARMACY SERVICE PROVIDER GETS $2 BILLION CONTRACT
description: The McKesson Corporation, the pharmaceuticals-distribution giant, has received a five-year, $2 billion supply-management contract from the American Stores Company's American Drug Stores unit. The contract, which takes effect on Aug. 1, will give McKesson revenue of more than $400 million a year from direct store deliveries. Under the deal, McKesson will also provide $1.5 billion of pharmaceuticals to American Drug Stores warehouses in La Habra, Calif., and Elk Grove, Ill. McKesson, of San Francisco, is a retail pharmacy service provider with annual revenue of $20.9 billion. American Stores, based in Salt Lake City, is one of the nation's largest grocery and drug chains.

title: A Race for the Soul of the Suburbs
description: For all the images of Dorothy's farm, the rail lines of Topeka or the aerospace plants of Wichita, the typical Republican voter of Kansas lives here in the traffic-jammed mallscape of suburban Johnson County.

title: Cohen Sees No Further Unknowns for Tomb
description: As the family of First Lieut. Michael J. Blassie prepared at last to bury him, 14 years after his remains were placed in the Tomb of the Unknowns, Defense Secretary William S. Cohen said today that it was unlikely the nation would ever again have to lay an unknown serviceman to rest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARKE, SYLVIA (NEE STEIN)
description: CLARKE-Sylvia (nee Stein). On June 29. Loving wife of the late Herbert M. (Nobby) Clarke. Beloved sister of Selma Cohen and her husband Eli. Devoted aunt of Theodora Raab, Dr. Alan D. Kramer, Joyce Fishman, Marc Rosenbaum & Peter Rosenbaum. Doting great aunt of Samantha & Sophie Rosenbaum. Caring step-mother of Ann Bedford. Cherished and irreplaceable friend of those whose lives luckily intersected with hers. As the founding editor-in-chief of the professional journal, ''Social Work in Health Care''; and as a top social work administrator, leader and teacher at Brooklyn Veterans Medical Center, Roosevelt Hospital and Mount Sinai Hospital, she was a mentor and role model to three generations of social workers and other health care professionals. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Three Leave One Big Bank For Another
description: In a high-stakes game of musical chairs, Credit Suisse First Boston has hired the leaders of Deutsche Bank's global high-technology banking business.

title: Accounts
description: Opryland Hospitality and Attractions Group, Nashville, a division of Gaylord Entertainment Co., to Buntin Group, Nashville, to handle its advertising and public relations for properties including the Opryland Hotel, which had been handled by Ericson Marketing Communications, Nashville. Billings were estimated at $2 million to $3 million.

title: Venus Williams Is a Snazzy Winner
description: Venus Williams, spared the vexing task of taking on her brash little sister in the Round of 16, made good on her previously ''broken promises'' to attempt some snazzy serve-and-volley maneuvers today during a 6-3, 6-1 dissection of 47th-ranked Virginia Ruano Pascual. The seventh-seeded Williams reached her first Wimbledon quarterfinal by unveiling a complex grass-court game, including 24 winners on 29 net approaches and the conversion of six of eight break chances from backcourt.

title: Fed Extends Alert on Bank Lending Standards
description: The Federal Reserve warned banks today to keep up their lending standards as the boom in the economy will not last forever.

title: Host Marriott Asia Move
description: The Host Marriott Corporation said today that it had formed a joint venture with Jones Lang Wootton to acquire four- and five-star hotels in Southeast Asia and the Pacific Rim. The Singapore-based venture will be managed by both. With the recent economic turmoil in Asia, Host Marriott said it saw an opportunity to acquire hotels at significant discounts. Host Marriott is based in Bethesda, Md. Jones Lang, based in London, is a large real estate advisory and asset management firm.

title: Fierce Fighting as Serbs Try to Push Rebels From Kosovo Town
description: Fighting between Serbian forces and separatist rebels in Kosovo Province was heavy today as senior Serbian officials vowed to drive the rebels from a town near the provincial capital and open roads obstructed by rebel barricades.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the poet and biographer John Malcolm Brinnin yesterday cited a survivor erroneously. No immediate family members survive. Mr. Brinnin's companion, Bill Read, died some 20 years ago; he had lived with Mr. Brinnin in Boston and Duxbury, Mass., not in Key West.

title: A Lot of All-Star Talk, But a Tarnished Start
description: There is no good time to have a bad outing. But in Rick Reed's case, this was a particularly bad time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, JULIUS
description: LEWIS-Julius, age 92. Died June 29, 1998. Dear and loving father of Abby Kosovsky & Carole Rifkind, grandfather of Jane Kosovsky, Robert Kosovsky, Barbara Rifkind and Nancy Rifkind, greatgrandfather of Hailey McInerney and Luke McInerney, and father-in-law of Richard Rifkind. Burial will take place at New Montefiore Cemetery in Farmingdale, New York on Wednesday, July 1st, at 1:30 P.M. Family and friends may call at the home of Abby Kosovsky on Wednesday and Thursday, from 7:00 to 9:00 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOLL, MARIE UNDERHILL
description: NOLL-Marie Underhill. President Hunter R. Rawlings III, members of the Board of Trustees, and staff of Cornell University mourn the passing of Marie Underhill Noll, Class of 1926. Mrs. Noll was a Presidential Counselor and with her late husband, A. Robert Noll, was recognized as a foremost Benefactor of Cornell. Mrs. Noll's many Cornell friends extend heartfelt condolences to her sister-in-law Claribel Underhill; her cousins, Virginia Miller and Howard Miller; her nephew and niece, George Underhill and Georgiana Underhill Gehret; and the rest of her family during this time of great sadness.

title: Shifting Demographics of H.I.V.
description: There is now little doubt that AIDS is becoming an epidemic of color, striking the African-American community to a disproportionate and devastating degree. Yet neither political leaders nor black institutions anticipated this demographic shift early enough to protect a vulnerable population that historically has been neglected in health care and prevention.

title: Ebbing Influence Hinders Taxi Fleets in Fight Over New Rules
description: As New York City Councilman Noach Dear geared up last fall to run for Congress, a group of taxi executives wrote a letter to its members urging them to contribute to ''our good friend,'' saying that without Mr. Dear's help, ''our taxi industry might not exist today as we know it.'' They gave generously.

title: Flag Amendment Returns Lost Power; Vandalism, Not Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Polish Jewish Cemetery
description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Traffic Violations On the Menu

title: Commissioner Election Set
description: Unless Bud Selig plans to produce a surprise candidate, the baseball owners will elect him commissioner at a meeting July 9 in Chicago. ''At the meeting,'' according to a notice sent to owners Monday, ''the clubs will be asked to conduct an election to fill the position of commissioner.'' The notice did not say who the candidate or candidates will be, but there is really only one, and he has been the acting commissioner for nearly six years.

title: Big Ratings for the Big City
description: The Yankees-Mets series last weekend produced strong ratings for the outlets that carried them.

title: A.C. NIELSEN BUYS BASES GROUP, A TEST-MARKETER
description: The A. C. Nielsen Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired the privately held Bases Group, a provider of simulated test-marketing services with annual revenues of $65 million. It will initially pay $65 million and may make further payments if certain financial targets are met. A. C. Nielsen, the Stamford, Conn., company that conducts the Nielsen TV ratings survey, had 1997 revenues of $1.39 billion. Its shares rose 18.75 cents yesterday, to $25.3125. Bases, of Covington, Ky., conducts test-marketing early in a product's development.

title: Microsoft's Windows 98 Sells Much Better Than Expected
description: Windows 98 went on sale last week with little fanfare and supported by a puny marketing budget compared with the spending for its relentlessly promoted predecessor, Windows 95. And Windows 98 also came to market under a legal cloud, as Exhibit A in the Justice Department's antitrust suit against the Microsoft Corporation.

title: The Overstretched Privilege
description: The White House bristles at comparisons between its tactics in the independent counsel investigation of Bill Clinton and President Nixon's Watergate strategy. Yet echoes of Nixon's effort to block access to his tapes were inevitable on Monday, as President Clinton's lawyers worked to block testimony by Bruce Lindsey, one of his closest aides. But there was a striking new element in these arguments before a Federal appeals court in Washington.

title: An Eagle Spurs Rohlf to a Four-Shot Victory in the Ike
description: In the middle of the fairway, with four holes to play, Greg Rohlf was told he was tied for the lead. So he decided it was time to take the lead all by himself. He proceeded to eagle the 528-yard sixth hole this afternoon at Wykagyl Country Club and catapult himself to the championship of the Ike, the stroke-play championship of the Metropolitan Golf Association.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Princeton Cancer Expert Is New Rockefeller U. President
description: Having quietly expanded its research operations and recruited a new crop of scientists since it was embroiled in a research fraud case seven years ago, Rockefeller University, the biomedical research institution in Manhattan, has selected a prominent cancer researcher as its next president, university officials said yesterday.

title: Rubin Hoping Thais Back Requirements Of the I.M.F.
description: As he continued to gather damage reports from the crisis-torn economies of Asia, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin expressed optimism today that the political leaders of Thailand would be able to marshal public support for the difficult work of reforming that economy.

title: President Sees Risks To Growth for China
description: President Clinton told American business leaders in Shanghai that corruption, environmental neglect, weak financial regulation and restrictive trade practices threaten China's growth and full entry into the global economic system.

title: One More Mission For Gung-Ho B-1 Bob
description: When Robert K. Dornan was a member of Congress, representing California's dependably Republican and conservative Orange County for the better part of two decades, he was not much given to Capitol Hill's special brand of civility, comity and convention. He was better known, instead, as the master of boastful bluster, the ad hominem assault and the blunt riposte.

title: Ralph S. Brown, 85, Professor And Expert on Copyright Law
description: Ralph S. Brown, a law professor at Yale Law School for more than four decades and an expert on unfair competition, copyright, government security and the rights of individuals, died on June 17. He was 85 and lived in Guilford, Conn.

title: At 67, Marlboro Mental Hospital Closes
description: Marlboro Psychiatric Hospital closed today for good, 67 years after it opened and after three years of blistering opposition from unions whose members lost good jobs, from the families of some patients who worried that their loved ones would be hurt and from homeowners who did not want mentally ill people as neighbors.

title: Getting Royal Opera House in Order
description: The Royal Opera House, dogged by accusations of elitism and financial mismanagement, came under renewed attack today when a Government-sponsored report said that its internal organization often ''resembles a World War I battlefield.''

title: Corporate Underwriting Soared in First Half of '98
description: Wall Street generated more money for corporate America in the first half of this year than any other six-month period in history, as historically low interest rates and a still buoyant stock market gave fresh momentum to the business of issuing stock and debt.

title: Restaurants Stake Out Your Pantry
description: CHEFS may want to get you into their restaurants, but now more than ever, they have their eye on your pantry shelf as well.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FLEMING COS., Oklahoma City, a food distributor, sold its supply center in El Paso to Furr's Supermarkets Inc., Albuquerque, N.M., for as much as $45 million as part of a lawsuit settlement.

title: Serving Bar Food With Attitude
description: THERE was a time when you could walk into just about any bar in the country and know what to expect: big food, things like burgers and fries, that went well with your beer. It is true that out in the real America you might find the odd regional treat -- in Buffalo, it could be spicy chicken wings with celery and blue cheese, or in St. Louis, toasted ravioli. But bar food definitely knew its place.

title: In Book Publishing, Some Editors Still Care
description: To the Editor:

title: New Metrocards Sold In Spite of Orders
description: Officially, the new unlimited-ride Metrocards do not go on sale until Saturday. But some merchants who will be official vendors of the new cards are ignoring orders not to sell them before the start of the program and are selling them to subway riders who fear that the new cards will be in short supply.

title: Peruvian Injustice
description: To the Editor:

title: The Thrill of the Grill Is in Charcoal, Not Gas
description: EVERY day, or so it seems, the mail carrier delivers another brochure touting a new gas mega-grill. These gleaming steel behemoths, which can cost more than $5,000, are nothing less than fantasy kitchens reconfigured for outdoor use. Each promises to provide ease, convenience and great grilled food at the flip of a switch.

title: They're Ready For Their Layups Now
description: In real life, Timothy B. Smith is a ''mystery shopper'' for Taco Bell, buying chicken incognito at the fast-food joints and reporting to headquarters whether it is cooked too little or served too cold.

title: Envisioning '60 Minutes' II
description: Only Don Hewitt knows for sure exactly how involved he will be in supervising the production of a second version of ''60 Minutes,'' the granddaddy of news-magazine programs.

title: It's a Picnic, From Soup to Nuts
description: MANY restaurants will pack meals to go, but a few -- usually those close to a park -- will pack picnics to go. What's the difference between a takeout meal and a picnic? It depends on where you buy your picnic, and how much you're willing to spend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, TESS
description: GOLDMAN-Tess. Age ninety. On June 30th, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Henry Goldman. Loving mother of Jim and Sue and mother-in-law of Pat and Seth. Cherished grandmother of Amy, Alicia, Elizabeth and Alex. Great grandmother of Zachary. You will be remembered by all for your spirit, your wit and your devotion to family.

title: Reed and Leiter, at Least, Get Good News
description: On a miserable afternoon for Mets pitchers, there were at least two bright spots: Rick Reed was selected to the National League team for next Tuesday's All-Star Game, and there were signs that Al Leiter might be sidelined a lot less than four weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLES, JULIA
description: PERLES-Julia. On July 1, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Howard. Devoted sister, loving aunt, great aunt & cherished friend. Graveside service Friday, 11 A.M., at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, IRVING
description: BAUM-Irving. Beloved husband of Lila for forty-eight years. Adored father, father-in-law, grandfather and friend. Services today at 12 Noon, at Kirschenbaum, 1700 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Liberty's Winning Streak Ends as Detroit's Rolls On

title: Artists See No Decency In Ruling On Grants
description: The United States Supreme Court decision upholding a decency test for Federal arts grants has been greeted by a wave of disappointment in the world of the arts. Performance artists directly affected by last week's ruling vigorously condemned it, while the response of playwrights and others ranged from the embattled to the calmly accepting. All who spoke on the issue expressed confusion about the vagueness of the court's language and the difficulty of determining just what decency is.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGRATH, EDWARD P.
description: McGRATH-Edward P., Reverend of Oakdale, Connecticut, died after an illness Monday, June 29, on the 29th anniversary of his ordination as a Roman Catholic priest. He was 62. Father McGrath was born on December 2, 1935 in Buffalo, New York, the son of the late James and Mary Agnes (Devitt) McGrath. He graduated from Saint Teresa Elementary School and in 1954 graduated from Bishop Timon High School in Buffalo. In June 1962, he received his Bachelor of Arts degree from Don Bosco College in Newton, New Jersey with a major in History and a minor in Philosophy. He taught at Mary Help of Christians School in Tampa, Florida from June 1962 to June 1963. He then taught at Saint Dominic Savio High School in East Boston, Massachusetts for the 1964-65 school year. He earned his Master of Theology at the Salesian Order's Seminary in Benedixtbuern, Germany. During that time, he spent summers working at the Catacombs in Italy. Father McGrath was ordained as a priest in the Salesian Order of Don Bosco on June 29, 1969 at his parents' home parish, the Church of the Immaculate Conception at Inaugh, County Clare, Ireland. Following his ordination, he taught at Salesian High School in New Rochelle, N.Y. Since 1970, he has served as Chaplain at Saint Thomas More School in Oakdale, Connecticut, where he taught Theology and Philosophy, as well as German and History. His students affectionately refferred to him as ''Padre'' or ''Pod''. He spent his summers as an Associate Pastor at Saint Patrick's Church in Cannonsburg, Pennsylvania; Queen of Heaven Church at Koppel, Pennsylvania; and Purification Church in Elwood City, Pennsylvania. Father McGrath is survived by his brothers and sisters John, James, Martin, Mary Agnes (Doyle), Ann (Haettich), Robert, and Teresa (Gilliland), and many nieces and nephews. He is also survived by many aunts and uncles in Ireland, as well as his second family, the faculty, students, & administration of Saint Thomas More School. A Rite of Christian Burial will be held Wednesday from 2-9 P.M. at Our Lady's Chapel at Saint Thomas More School in Oakdale, followed by a Mass of Christian Burial on Thursday at 11 A.M. Funeral Services will be held Friday, July 3, from 2-9 P.M., at the Reddington Funeral Home, 657 Abbott Road, Buffalo, New York, followed by a Mass of Christian Burial Saturday July 4 at 9 A.M. in Saint Teresa's Church, Seneca Falls, New York. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to the Father Edward McGrath Schoarship Fund, C/O Saint Thomas More School, 45 Cottage Road, Oakdale, CT. 06370.

title: NEWS WATCH; With a Ball-Point Scanner, Cupboards Need Never Be Bare
description: Yet another reason to stay indoors: Symbol Technologies has introduced the Infopen, a ball-point pen that is also a portable bar-code scanner. ''Whenever you notice that something is running short, you just scan the bar code of the product,'' said Michel Jacobeus, vice president for scanner marketing. ''Whether it be in the kitchen, in the bathroom, wherever -- you cannot drag a PC around with you.'' The user can upload the bar-code data through the included Infopen docking station into a PC and place an on-line order. The Infopen is $195.

Livoti was convicted in Federal court of violating the civil rights of a Bronx man who died in his custody, the Police Department announced last night that it had placed his former partner and another officer on modified duty as it investigates allegations that those officers had perjured themselves and colluded to cover up for Mr. Livoti.

title: Murders in New York Lowest Since 1966
description: Violent crime in New York City continued its six-year decline in the first half of 1998, according to police statistics made public yesterday, as the number of murders fell to the lowest level since 1966. Murders have dropped by 25 percent so far this year compared with the first six months of 1997, and police officials said that if the trend continued through December, New York would record its lowest number of homicides since 1963.

title: Critic's Notebook; I Think, Therefore I Am, but There's So Little Time
description: It may be true, as it is often said, that people don't read anymore. Certainly it is true that, outside of a few academic departments, very few of us are reading the classics of philosophy, for example, Immanuel Kant's ''Critique of Pure Reason'' or Rene Descartes's ''Discourse on Method'' or Jean-Paul Sartre's ''Being and Nothingness.'' Given that the edifices of thought built by the likes of Kant and Descartes are among the great achievements of the human mind, that is a shame.

title: QUALCOMM TO SPIN OFF SOME WIRELESS PHONE COMPANIES
description: Qualcomm Inc. said yesterday that it planned to spin off its investments in land-based wireless operating companies into a separate publicly traded company. Qualcomm, based in San Diego, makes digital wireless systems and Internet products. Stockholders will receive one share of the new company for each four Qualcomm shares. Qualcomm will receive a warrant to purchase up to 18 percent of the new company's shares over a 10-year period. The new company will own Qualcomm's interests in ventures in Mexico, Russia, Ukraine, Chile and Australia as well as Chase Telecommunications Inc. in the United States. Qualcomm will provide financing in the form of a $250 million secured line of credit and $10 million in cash.
