description: REAL SKY CD(Astronomical Society of the Pacific; $250 for each of Northern or Southern sky, $450 for both; Windows 3.1, 95 and NT, and Macintosh.)

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; After accounting for Boeing's accounting, the gloom lifts.
description: AS Boeing turned the corner?

title: IN SLAP AT STARR, A JUDGE DISMISSES HUBBELL TAX CASE
description: A Federal District Court judge here threw out the tax evasion case against Webster L. Hubbell today, ruling in a powerful critique of the independent counsel's tactics that Kenneth W. Starr had both exceeded his authority and reneged on a promise to grant him immunity.

title: RIS RESOURCES TO PAY $110 MILLION FOR WYOMING PLANT
description: The energy concern RIS Resources Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 50 percent of Western Gas Resources Inc.'s share of a gas-processing complex in Wyoming for $110 million. Western Gas, based in Denver, processes natural gas. It owns gas-gathering, processing and storage operations throughout the United States. RIS Resources is the United States arm of the RIS Resources International Corporation of Canada. The agreement includes gas plants and associated compression and gathering systems in the Greater Green River Basin of southwest Wyoming.

title: Two States Outline Sanctions on Swiss Banks in Holocaust Case
description: New York and California outlined sanctions yesterday against two Swiss banks, after negotiations collapsed over how much money the banks and Swiss Government will return to Holocaust survivors and heirs.

title: LIBRARY/ASTRONOMY SOFTWARE; With a Desktop Computer's Aid, Your Own Planetarium
description: REDSHIFT 3, VERSION 3.0(Piranha Interactive Publishing; $49.95; Windows 95 and 98, Macintosh will be available in July.)

title: Anchored by Church Teachings, Driven by Vatican Change
description: The television producer who sets out to profile as deeply admired a religious figure as Joseph Cardinal Bernardin risks losing the human being in an aura of reverence. So credit is due to Martin Doblmeier and Frank Frost for putting together a fond portrait that allows the man to emerge.

title: New Rebuke, With Force
description: Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, has taken a lot of grief lately from Democrats in Congress, President Clinton's lawyers and friends and some journalists.

title: Once Is Enough, Steinbrenner Says of a Home-and-Home Series With Mets
description: George Steinbrenner likes playing the Mets once a year, but the Yankees' principal owner indicated yesterday that he would fight a tentative plan in which the teams would play six games next year, three at Yankee Stadium and three at Shea.

title: 3 Police Warnings Fail to Muzzle a Beijing Critic
description: A former senior Chinese official who was jailed for opposing the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown has been warned a third time by the Chinese authorities to stop talking to foreign journalists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMENY, LEO
description: KAMENY-Leo. Beloved husband of Mildred. Loving father of Robert and David. Dear brother of Seymour and Pauline Weber. Cherished grandfather of Janice, Jennifer, Daniel, Joshua and Amanda. Service Friday, 2PM, at Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, N.J.

title: France Selects Buyer For State-Owned Insurer
description: The French Government said yesterday that it would sell its 87.1 percent stake in the insurer Groupe des Assurances Nationales to Groupama Assurances for 17.25 billion francs ($2.8 billion). The move will make Groupama the fourth-largest insurance company in France.

title: Intrigue and Defection: A Tale of 2 Co-ops
description: TWO days after the writer Joan Didion assumed the presidency of the board of her prestigious Upper East Side co-op, she was faced with the first crisis of her administration. The building's superintendent, Thomas D. Riordan, announced that he had been lured away by the Beresford, a larger and even more prestigious co-op on Central Park West, home of Richard C. Holbrooke, nominated as American representative to the United Nations, as well as Beverly Sills, Tony Randall and, soon, Jerry Seinfeld.

title: PULTE EXPANDS SOUTHEAST OPERATIONS BY BUYING DIVOSTA
description: The Pulte Corporation, the nation's biggest home builder, said yesterday that it had bought the closely held Florida builder DiVosta & Company, expanding operations in the Southeast. Pulte did not disclose the terms of the acquisition. But in a research report, the Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company home building analyst, Peter Dannenbaum, estimated the company paid about $150 million for DiVosta. DiVosta, based in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., built 850 homes and generated $134 million in revenue last year. Pulte, based in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., sold more than 15,000 homes in 1997, including about 3,000 in Florida.

title: Waiting for a Chance to Tumble
description: The American Dance Festival loves to take risks. That is why it keeps attracting dancers and audiences to its performances on the campus of Duke University here. On Tuesday night, it took a big risk by offering the premiere of ''Triptych Humpty-Dumpty,'' a three-act work choreographed by David Grenke, a member of the Paul Taylor Dance Company from 1989 to 1996 and one of this year's recipients of the festival's Doris Duke Awards for New Work. As performed by Mr. Grenke's Thingsezisee'm Dance/Theater at the Reynolds Industries Theater, the work was sometimes exasperating, often compelling and always peculiar.

title: Consumer Marketers Name New Agencies
description: Two consumer marketers have made changes on their accounts after reviews.

title: Trial Lawyer For Hikind Says Actions Were Legal
description: The lawyer for Dov Hikind, the Brooklyn Assemblyman who is on trial on charges of receiving illegal payoffs from a social services group, told jurors in his closing argument yesterday that prosecutors had concocted a false case by turning ''perfectly appropriate acts by an elected official'' into supposed criminal conduct.

title: Five Up, Five In: Mets' Rojas Continues to Struggle
description: Last Friday night, Mets Manager Bobby Valentine walked to the mound in the top of the seventh inning and summoned reliever Mel Rojas. The Mets were leading the Yankees, 4-3, but there were two runners on base, only one out and Paul O'Neill was at the plate. It was a tough assignment, and Rojas responded by allowing a three-run home run on his first pitch, putting the Yankees ahead for good and leaving Valentine to endure a weekend of questions about why he used the struggling Rojas in the first place.

title: Year 2000 Data Can Be Shared
description: The Government signaled yesterday that companies would be allowed to cooperate and share information about how to fix the year 2000 bugs in their computer systems without violating the nation's antitrust laws.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRISCH, MARGOT
description: KRISCH-Margot. Beloved wife of Alex Wendrow & the late Gerhard. Loving mother of Nancy & Barry Gordon. Adored grandmother of Rebecca and Jared. Service at Larchmont Temple, Larchmont, New York, Thursday 11:30AM. For information call Plaza Memorial Chapel, 1-800-227-3974.

title: Politics Laces Discussion at Gore's Forum on Social Security
description: The fourth question for Vice President Al Gore today at a town hall discussion here on Social Security came from Eve Goldberg, who turned 100 on April 18.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, OWEN BENJAMIN
description: HIRSCH-Owen Benjamin. A unique and special man who lived his life with a joie de vivre, accomplished international businessman, beloved by his daughter, Liz; his son, Robert; his grandson, Phillip; daughter-in-law, Karen; his companion, Uschi; his brothers, Alfred and Edgar, and family and friends. He will be missed. Services today, July 2, 11:30 AM, at The Riverside, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Footlights column yesterday about an impending cast change in the musical ''Cabaret'' misstated the given name of the actress now playing the role of Sally Bowles. She is Natasha Richardson, not Miranda.

title: A Warning From the Fed
description: Banks are lending out cash a bit too easily, with too little regard for the risks that will come if the economy stumbles into recession. So says the Federal Reserve in an unusual letter sent to all banks last week and released to the public this week.

title: In America; Saving the Cities
description: For many years the goal of people concerned about the nation's cities was, for the most part, simply to stop the hemorrhaging. Crime seemed out of control, longtime residents were fleeing, entire neighborhoods were collapsing into rubble and ash.

title: Economic Scene; Selling uranium plants to enrich the private sector?
description: THE Treasury's announcement on Monday that it would soon privatize the Government's half-century-old uranium enrichment plants made waves largely because of the proposed method of sale. While an initial public offering of shares in a Government-owned corporation is not unprecedented, it is certainly a novelty in keeping with the spirit of the high-flying stock market.

title: Iran's President Likes U.S. Tone but Says Actions Speak Louder
description: President Mohammad Khatami of Iran lauded the Clinton Administration today for softening its tone toward his country but added that a concrete change in American policy toward Iran was necessary.

title: Soccer and Savagery
description: David Beckham is in serious distress. His countrymen hate him. Worse still, his country's tabloids have begun to howl for his head in the frightening manner of the Fleet Street wolf pack.

title: Plugging In to the Internet: Many Paths, Many Speeds
description: THE first thing anyone who wants to connect to the Internet has to realize is that the Net is not a single entity -- it is a collection of networks joined by a set of standard ways to exchange data. The name Internet even implies that it links networks. This means that almost any system for carrying data -- wires, radio, fiber optics or even smoke signals -- can be hooked into the Internet if it can send that data in the format known as the Internet Protocol, or I.P.

title: LIBRARY/ASTRONOMY SOFTWARE; Putting the Stars Within Reach
description: IT is 3:24 A.M. in New York City on Saturday, Sept. 12, 1998. You are returning home after a long night of partying. Looking high in the east, you see a half-moon. You notice what appears to be a reddish star right next to the moon, near the imaginary line that divides the light and dark parts. Suddenly, the star disappears. Yet there are no clouds in the sky, and the moon remains crystal clear.

title: Turf; The Long Road Home to a Building Full of Memories
description: WHEN Laurie Miller said goodbye to the narrow house on Quincy Street, there was still a pull chain attached to the wooden toilet tank up near the ceiling. There was still a claw foot bathtub. The boiler didn't always work. It was home, though, and had been since she was 10 years old, when she often ran the five blocks to the previous owner's house with the mortgage payments, grabbing a hastily drawn receipt for the cash her mother had handed her.

description: The nation's largest Hispanic political organization, showing sharp preferences among possible Republican presidential contenders, made Gov. George W. Bush of Texas feel right at home today while treating Speaker Newt Gingrich as a guest more tolerated than welcomed.

description: The state yesterday announced an overhaul of the agency that oversees the safety and well-being of 49,000 children on welfare and 6,800 others in foster care.

They slept on dirt floors, cooked over campfires, raised chickens and goats and tended an organic garden. Their dream: to build a Utopian community.

title: The University Calls In Its Flock
description: Factories used to be the big employers in American cities, and their workers (and owners) lived right downtown. When manufacturing moved out of cities like Baltimore; Birmingham, Ala.; Provo, Utah; New Haven, and Philadelphia, a strange phenomenon emerged. Colleges and universities replaced steel plants and knitting mills as the largest employers; but the faculties and staffs -- even students -- often commuted from the suburbs.

title: Frank B. Rowlett, 90, Wizard In Making and Breaking Codes
description: Frank Byron Rowlett, one of the foursome who started the Signal Intelligence Service of the United States Army in 1930, died on Monday at the Wilson Health Care Center in Gaithersburg, Md. He was 90 and moved to the center last year from a retirement home in Sarasota, Fla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLEY, JONATHAN
description: KELLEY-Jonathan. Suddenly on June 30, 1998. Much loved riding instructor at Chelsea Piers Equestrian Center and past teacher at Clairmont Riding Academy. Beloved son of Eugene and Chetta Kelley. Loving brother of Seana Chase, Eugene Kelley, Jr., and Heather Carr. Cherished grandson of Madeline and the late Michael Solimando, and Martin and Helen Kelley. Dear uncle of Sophie, Rachel, Alexandra, Eugene, Justin and Michael. Visiting hours Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, July 7, in Milton, Mass.

title: Heads of Volvo and Volkswagen Hold Talks
description: Volvo A.B. of Sweden confirmed today that its chief executive had discussions last Friday with the chairman of Volkswagen A.G., Ferdinand Piech, as the stock prices of both companies jumped on speculation of a possible alliance or merger.

title: HBO Is Adding Six Lewis Bouts
description: Home Box Office announced in London yesterday its six-fight contract extension for Lennox Lewis, and it also made a $20 million-plus offer for Evander Holyfield to meet Lewis in a heavyweight title unification bout in December. But Jim Thomas, Holyfield's lawyer, said the offer was sleight of hand.

title: New Type of Laptop Bus Puts The 'Port' Back Into Portables
description: Laptops are made for portability, unlike desktop models, but they have their own problems, like smaller screens, smaller keyboards and less useful pointing devices. You can buy full-size peripherals for your desktop but as manufacturers downsize their portable computers, they often leave off ports. A port replicator is one solution, but they are not available for many machines.

description: KLEIN-Bernhard. On July 1, 1998, peacefully at home, in his 92nd year. Loving uncle, great uncle, and great-great uncle. Services are private.

description: SOLAR-POWERED fiber optics? Photovoltaic cell-laminated tensile hyperbolic paraboloids? Today's visionary gibberish is tomorrow's plain English. The nifty thing about emerging technologies is the way they sneak up on you, then transform your life overnight.

title: Mexico's Leader Demands Rebels Rejoin Talks
description: President Ernesto Zedillo, on a whirlwind tour through the troubled state of Chiapas, impatiently issued what sounded like a last call to the Zapatista rebels today to return to peace talks, which lapsed a year and a half ago.

title: It's a Video Game, It's TV, and You're the Star
description: ON television, a montage of hockey footage unfurls against the ESPN National Hockey Night musical theme, leading into Dan Patrick and Kenny Mayne making fun of themselves in one of those self-mocking Sports Center commercials. Then you see a screenful of ESPN graphics about the matchup, an exhibition game between the Detroit Red Wings and the Colorado Avalanche. title: A Lighted Aspirin Holder
description: ''Germans spend an average of $350 for medicine cabinets,'' said Howard Katz, director of design and manufacturing for Robern, makers of custom bathroom storage units. ''Americans spend $49.'' He explained, ''Europeans take cabinetry with them when they move, so they care more.''

title: CHOCK FULL O' NUTS IN DEAL FOR HOT-BEVERAGE BUSINESS
description: The Chock Full o' Nuts Corporation said yesterday that it planned to purchase the hot-beverage business of the closely held Park Foods for undisclosed terms to increase its coffee and tea sales. Chock Full o' Nuts, the coffee roaster and marketer, said the Chicago-based Park Foods unit had 1997 revenue of $70 million from the sale of coffee, cappuccino, cocoa and leaf tea. The New York-based Chock Full o' Nuts had 1997 revenue of $366.3 million. The acquisition is expected to add at least 15 percent to Chock Full o' Nuts unit sales. Shares of Chock Full o' Nuts were unchanged at $6.75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, LOUIS
description: HARRIS-Louis. Beloved husband of Thelma, loving father of Eric and Jesse (Candie), wonderful grandpa of Jason and Brian. Services Thursday, 10 A.M., Parkside Chapels, Queens Boulevard at 66th Avenue, Forest Hills.

title: Post-Yogurt Lives Of the Container
description: Eurotrash -- what could be hipper? In this case, it's a building product made from recycled German yogurt containers. Made in Germany, Polyal contains polystyrene and aluminum, no additives. In six whites and one black, all flecked with aluminum seals, Polyal is nontoxic and weatherproof, and it can be made into tabletops, bookshelves and more. From $7 to $24 a square foot at Decor Cable Innovations, (800) 444-6271.

title: Rangers Aim for Richter But Keep Options Open
description: The Rangers say they are still trying to sign Mike Richter, now that their veteran goalie has become an unrestricted free agent. But they are hedging their bets by also negotiating with Curtis Joseph, another veteran goalie, who is a free agent from the Edmonton Oilers.

title: Swiss Bank Selling Units To Italian Insurer
description: UBS A.G. said yesterday that it would sell its Banca della Svizzera Italiana unit and its Boss Lab S.A. information technology unit to the Italian insurer Assicurazioni Generali S.p.A. for 1.92 billion Swiss francs ($1.3 billion). UBS, the world's second-largest bank, was formed this week through the merger of Union Bank of Switzerland and the Swiss Bank Corporation. The merger was approved on the condition that both Banca della Svizzera Italiana and Boss Lab be sold.

description: Want to recall that fabulous Web page you found yesterday? You know, the one you forgot to list in a bookmark?

title: LIBERTY FINANCIAL TO BUY SAN FRANCISCO FUND MANAGER
description: The Liberty Financial Companies said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Progress Investment Management Company, a San Francisco fund manager that oversees about $2.5 billion in assets. Liberty declined to disclose the price it paid for Progress Investment. A ''significant portion'' of the total is pegged to the firm's performance over the next five years, said Porter Morgan, senior vice president at Liberty, which is mostly owned by the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company in Boston. Progress Investment, which matches minority women-owned firms and other ''emerging managers'' to institutional investors, has revenues of about $5 million, an industry analyst said. Shares of Liberty rose $1, to $35.50.

title: Bad Timing for Some Epic Projects; Asia's Financial Crisis Leaves New Airports Scrambling for Passengers
description: When President Jiang Zemin of China leaves here on Thursday after celebrating the first anniversary of Hong Kong's handover, he will be the first passenger to take off from the new $20 billion Hong Kong International Airport. Unfortunately for Hong Kong, there will be nowhere near as many people following him as originally planned.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RITTER, IRL
description: RITTER-Irl. In Orinda, California, on June 30, 1998, at age 81. Services were held in Los Angeles. Donations to Jewish Family Services of the East Bay, 2484 Shattuck Avenue, Suite 210, Berkeley, California 94704.

title: Martinez Gets The Key Hits To Lift Wells
description: The scoreboard message begged the fans to make some noise in the fifth inning last night at Yankee Stadium, but the electronic plea was unnecessary. The decibel level had started to increase when Tino Martinez sauntered to the plate with the bases loaded. Martinez had homered off Philadelphia's Matt Beech three innings earlier, so everyone affiliated with the Yankees was hoping he could go deep again.

title: Flaw in Word 98 Can Spread Your Personal Information
description: It's a paranoid computer user's worst nightmare: private information from your hard disk made accessible for the reading enjoyment of strangers. And it could happen if you use Microsoft Word 98 for Macintosh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVER, PAUL
description: SILVER-Paul. Of Boca Raton. Formerly of Rockville Centre, N.Y. Former President of Millicent Sportswear Corp. and Elyse Fashions. Beloved husband of Evelyn (nee Otner). Devoted father of Dr. Mark R. & Elyse R. Silver. Fatherin-law of Virginia. Grandfather of Jeffrey and Julie. Dear brother of Alvin. Brother-in-law of Audrey Milk and Rita and Dena Silver. Uncle and great-uncle. Services are today at Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel in Boca Raton.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER SLUMPS. Copper prices fell to a 10-year low after a big copper producer reached an accord with its unions, unsettling an already weak market. Copper for July delivery fell 1.35 cents, to 72 cents a pound.

title: Judge in New Jersey Says Dying Medical Examiner Can Testify on Videotape
description: In a decision that could broaden the use of technology in criminal trials, a judge ruled today that prosecutors can videotape the testimony of a dying medical examiner who may not survive to testify in seven murder cases, including four in which the defendants face the death penalty.

description: More than 18,000 people were evacuated in northeast Florida late today as wildfires whipped by high winds burned dozens of homes and businesses bringing a threat that had affected mostly rural areas to the midst of population centers.

description: A Federal appeals court has ruled that a New Jersey bank can sue the State of Florida over the state's unauthorized use of a college-savings program, saying that states can be sued for infringing the patent owned by an individual or a company.

title: Clinton Sends Dual Message To China in Interview on TV
description: President Clinton, in his last opportunity to address a mass audience in China, said Wednesday that he would continue to speak out on behalf of democracy and individual liberty, but that the United States did not seek to dictate the path of China's development.

description: On the last stop of his six-day, four-country sweep of Asia, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin made his most pointed comments about a country that he did not even visit, Japan.

title: Corrections

She was Monica Hill, an English teacher, not Dr. Gale E. Gibson, director of the freshman year program.

title: 30-Year Treasury Unchanged As Fed Holds Line on Rates
description: The price of the 30-year Treasury bond was unchanged yesterday, after, as expected, the Federal Reserve policy-making committee decided not to adjust interest rates.

title: On the Job With Putt-Putt, Freddi Fish and Pajama Sam
description: SHELLEY DAY'S friends tell her it is no surprise to them that she is running her own computer game company, Humongous Entertainment. As a child, she would save up her allowance to buy the latest board game and then lasso the neighborhood gang into the basement of her parents' home in Redding, Calif., to help her puzzle it out.

description: In another significant step in the peace effort in this British province, Protestant and Roman Catholic members of the Northern Ireland Assembly began today to discuss a new political structure for the province that is designed to give the Catholic minority more power.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS

title: U.S. INDUSTRIES TO TAKE ABOUT $180 MILLION OF CHARGES
description: U.S. Industries said yesterday that it would take about $180 million of charges against its third- and fourth-quarter earnings for reorganizing its businesses making tools, toys, plumbing and lighting fixtures. Problems in its Rexair vacuum-cleaner and Ertl toy units will cut earnings in the third quarter ending tomorrow to 30 cents to 35 cents a share, U.S. Industries said. Three analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation had predicted earnings of 51 cents. The company made its forecast after the close of trading. Its shares rose 87.5 cents, to 25.625. U.S. Industries also said it would make cuts in its Mexican toy-making business, move toy production to Asia to reduce costs and close some plants and reduce its corporate staff.

title: For the Minimalist at Nap Time
description: The daybed at left is like Mona Lisa's smile -- a curve that is intriguingly minimal. Designed by Christopher Deam, pictured here, it was produced by Unified Studios for Design and Architecture, a San Francisco consortium of small architecture and design firms dedicated to making and marketing works of art that double as furniture.

title: Metro Business; Ferry in Jersey City To Go to Foxwoods
description: The LeFrak Organization of Rego Park, Queens, and the Mashantucket Pequot Tribal Nation have agreed to offer a high-speed ferry from the Jersey City waterfront to a port near the tribe's Foxwoods Resort Casino in Connecticut, officials said yesterday.

description: A proposed pilot program intended to allow greater school choice has been scaled back in response to protests by legislators that the first proposal went beyond what they had intended in a 1996 law.

title: Political Memo; Big Victory for the Republican Right
description: As a battle for the soul of Southern Republicanism, the Alabama primary runoff that Gov. Fob James Jr. won so convincingly on Tuesday reinforced a number of truths about the party and the region. Religious conservatives still wield immense influence. Strong stands against taxes still sell. Race still matters. And even as Southerners take a leading role in national politics, they still deeply resent Federal intrusion.

title: Immune System Can Revive After AIDS, Studies Suggest
description: The body's immune system can recover to a large extent, even after it has been ravaged by severe AIDS, according to evidence reported here today by French scientists at the 12th World AIDS Conference.

title: South Korea's President to Free Even the Unrepentant Political Prisoners
description: With little fanfare, President Kim Dae Jung on Wednesday ordered the release of political prisoners, even if they do not renounce their ideological views.

title: Design Notebook; Return to Innovation In a House That Dares
description: WHATEVER happened to truly innovative houses? Houses so radical in concept, so bold in execution and at the same time so comfortable and appealing that they made people want to change the way they lived?

title: Labor's Abuse of the City
description: The construction workers who clashed with police and tied up midtown Manhattan for hours on Tuesday turned a lawful rally against the use of nonunion contractors into an illegal assault on civic life. No union, or its members, should be allowed to take the constitutional right to protest and turn it into a license to paralyze the city and rough up civilians and police officers.

title: Holiday on Saturday: The Fourth of July
description: NEW YORK

title: The Giant Insect Sofas Invade
description: It figures. Who but two engineers turned self-taught furniture designers could have made the biomorphic sofa at right. Roz Hayes and Dani Stoller, founders of Lush Life, a design-and-manufacturing firm in Los Angeles, engineered their sofa's firm curves using a 1960's technique: the polyurethane foam was girdled with rubber webbing, and the whole thing was wrapped with stretch wool.

title: Sun Microsystems Will Cut 200 Jobs
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. said today that it would cut about 200 jobs as part of its reorganization of business units.

title: Starr's Inquiry Degrades the Legal System
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, JULIUS
description: LEWIS-Julius. The Municipal Art Society of New York expresses our deepest sympathy to the family of Julius Lewis, father of our Trustee and dear friend, Carole Rifkind.

title: Caution Flags at the F.D.A.
description: The withdrawal of two prescription drugs from the market suggests that the Food and Drug Administration may be having some trouble balancing political demands to speed up the drug approval process while maintaining its tradition of rigorous safety review. President Clinton's nominee to head the Food and Drug Administration, Jane Ellen Henney, will face the tough job of improving the agency's efficiency while resisting pressures from Congress and the drug industry that can undermine the cause of public safety.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAY, ROBERT DEAN
description: JAY-Robert Dean. Of Lloyd Neck, Huntington, NY died at Huntington Hospital, June 30. He was born in Paris, France, the son of Nelson Dean Jay & Anne Augustine Jay. He attended Stowe School in England and was in the Class of '42 at Harvard, where he held the track record for the mile. He served in the U.S. Navy in the Mediterranean, & was in the international division of the Bankers Trust Company. He was on the boards of the Helen Keller National Center for Deaf-Blind Youths and Adults, the Helen Keller Industrial Home for the Blind, and the Heckscher Museum in Huntington. His family learned to share his love of the outdoors, for summers on Nantucket, skiing in New Hampshire, sailing and canoeing in Maine. He will be mourned by his wife of 49 years, the former Cynthia White, and by his six sons, two daughters & twenty grandchildren. Services will be held at 11:00 on Friday, July 3rd, at St. John's Church in Cold Spring Harbor, New York, where he was a former Vestryman. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Helen Keller Services for the Blind, 57 Willoughby Street, Brooklyn, New York 11201. For more information: A. L. Jacobsen Funeral Home.

title: Defying Urban Ennui, and Gravity
description: ''Villa Villa,'' a performance art show by an Argentine group called De la Guarda, is described by its creators as a celebration of life. Each night, at the Daryl Roth Theater, they aim to recreate the wild atmosphere of random unity that occurs at street festivals in South America.

title: China Still Trails Russia in What Matters Most
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M.'s June Sales Soared; Strikes to Hurt July's
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that June car and truck sales were the highest for any month in nine years but that July sales would plummet because of two strikes that have shut down most of the auto maker's North American assembly plants.

title: Sharpton Lawyer Says Brawley Case Is Test of Civil Rights
description: In his summation today in the Tawana Brawley defamation case, the lawyer for the Rev. Al Sharpton evoked the memory of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and described the trial here as a test of the rights of civil rights leaders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSTONE, ALEXANDER MILLER
description: JOHNSTONE-Alexander Miller. Died peacefully on 29 June 1998 in Monaco, age 88. Beloved husband of Margaret. Much loved father of Fiona and Patricia and grandson Tim.

title: A Whole Summer To Show the Colors
description: SEEING red, white and blue this weekend? Take off the color blinders for the rest of the summer. After the parades pass, refresh the table with garden settings: new green majolica plates, silk poppy napkin rings and bright orange and pink napkins. Or with new reproductions of American classics like a glass hobnail pitcher. They're perfectly patriotic.

title: Gymnastics, of Course, but With a Serious Dose of New Jazz
description: Pilobolus Dance Theater is up to its new tricks in ''The Hand That Mocked, the Heart That Fed,'' a quirky and uneven premiere choreographed to a score by the experimental jazz composer Maria Schneider. Both music and dance were commissioned by the American Dance Festival and the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in a joint venture, the Doris Duke Millenium Awards.

title: The $600 PC Is Here. Is Anybody for $500?
description: It was considered a breakthrough last year when new Windows-based personal computers were offered for less than $1,000. But now it looks as if the $500 barrier will be next to crack, at least if an Internet-based PC company called iDOT continues its current pace.

title: Yanks' Williams Is Back; For How Long Is the Issue
description: Bernie Williams shook more hands in the Yankees' clubhouse than grooms do at weddings as teammates welcomed him back from his rehabilitation assignment in Tampa, Fla., and congratulated him for being one of the five Yankees chosen for the American League All-Star team yesterday. But there are indications that those salutations could turn into goodbyes once the 1998 season ends.

title: Theodore Beaubrun, 79, Haitian Comic and Actor
description: Theodore Beaubrun, one of Haiti's leading comedians and actors, died on Tuesday at his home in a Port-au-Prince suburb. He was 79.

title: Easier Way to Copy LP's
description: To the Editor:

title: A Muckraking Program Draws 300 Million Daily
description: It is hardly surprising that President Clinton chose the wildly popular news magazine ''Focus'' as his final forum to address the Chinese people. Every evening at 7:38 more than 300 million people tune in to the 15-minute program whose hard-hitting investigations and interviews show just how far the Chinese media have come since the days when they provided little more than Communist Party dogma.

title: Usti nad Labem Journal; A Wall Not Yet Built Casts the Shadow of Racism
description: On the outskirts of this depressed industrial town, about 50 Gypsy families live in two dilapidated, graffiti-strewn apartment blocks along Maticni Street where voices are often loud and celebrations boisterous.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVACK, BARBARA
description: NOVACK - Barbara. Beloved mother of Joshua. Devoted daughter of Ronnie and Marshall Miller and the late Jane Firestein Miller. Loving sister of Harvey. Cherished fiancee of Bertrand Seidman. Services ''Boulevard Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, 1:30PM Friday. Interment Sunday 1:30PM Beth Shalom Cemetery, Pittsburgh, PA.

title: The Blossoming of Internet Chat
description: SINCE the first time someone went on line and thought to type in a question like ''What are you wearing?'' to an unseen stranger in cyberspace, computer chat has had a somewhat shady reputation.

title: Union Pickets Hospital To Protest Privatization
description: Before Bergen County leased the former Bergen Pines Hospital to private operators in March, union officials and patients' families warned that privatization would result in deteriorating service. Yesterday, a union representing 400 nurses and other staff members, which is now in contract negotiations, picketed the 1,180-bed hospital, insisting that the quality of service had declined.

title: Glitzy Pastime, Gambling, Entices Elderly
description: For Milford Hartz, the adrenaline started to flow about the time the deluxe motor-coach bus pulled into the parking lot in front of the Wal-Mart store here. It was 8:30 A.M. and the bus was soon loaded with more than 30 elderly people, most of whom had spent a lifetime of early morning hours toiling on the nearby farms and in factories.

title: A Novel Of Lust Becomes An Opera
description: It has become an American genre, albeit a minor one: opera as a storyteller's art, the news set to music or, as in the case of ''The Postman Always Rings Twice,'' by Stephen Paulus, familiar fiction given the added boost of song.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: CLARK USA TO BUY OIL REFINERY FROM BRITISH PETROLEUM
description: Clark USA Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the British Petroleum Company oil refinery in Lima, Ohio, for $215 million. Clark will pay $175 million for the refinery and another $40 million for its inventory and other working capital. Clark, based in St. Louis, owns three other refineries and 16 distribution terminals, as well as 700 gasoline and On the Go convenience stores in the Midwest. It is 68 percent-owned by the Blackstone Group and 31 percent-owned by the Occidental Petroleum Corporation. The company has annual revenue of about $4 billion. British Petroleum, based in London, had been planning to close the refinery and focus on its other Ohio refinery in Toledo, where it is spending $235 million to upgrade the plant.

title: Amid Boom, Workers Fret About Future
description: Dennis Scudera wears his $7,800 Rolex watch with his hard hat, which he wears while making $34.64 an hour running the 3-ton Caterpillar to scoop out a basement for a Planet Hollywood Hotel being built in midtown Manhattan.

title: Anthony Avena, 83, Is Dead; Shoeshiner and Queens Fixture
description: Anthony Avena, a shoeshiner of 75 years whose shop became a Queens institution and who successfully fought the city to save it, died on June 22. He was 83 and lived in Whitestone, Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALE, HENRIETTA (GOLDSTERN
description: DALE-Henrietta (Goldstern). Of North Bergen, New Jersey. On June 30. Beloved wife of the late Michael. Cherished aunt & cousin. Service today 1 P.M., at Beth El Cemetery, Washington Township, NJ. For information GuttermanMusicant. 1-800-522-0588.

title: Task Force on Murders To Continue Its Work
description: Patricia A. Hurt, the Essex County Prosecutor, announced yesterday that the task force she formed on March 31 to delve into the unsolved slayings of 14 black women, several believed to be prostitutes, would continue until at least the end of the year.

title: A Life's Discoveries In the Geometric
description: The best way to approach the new Tony Smith retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art is from the north. Then you can stop at the Doris C. Freedman Plaza at 60th Street and Fifth Avenue and check out ''Cigarette,'' one of his best big, all-black steel sculptures from the 1960's. It's a virtual primer on how Smith's works work, when they do.

title: With All of the Hoopla, U.S. Envoy's Star Rises
description: Apart from Bill Clinton, who has clearly been having a ball, possibly no one has taken greater satisfaction in the presidential visit to China than the United States Ambassador to Beijing, James R. Sasser.

title: Highlights of Report on Inquiry Into CNN Broadcast
description: Floyd Abrams, the laywer specializing in First Amendment cases, advised CNN to retract its broadcast of ''Valley of Death,'' after he had investigated the ''five pillars'' on which the June 7 television report and the subsequent Time Magazine article were based. The reports had asserted that in Operation Tailwind the United States military had dropped nerve gas on a Laotian village in 1970, while pursuing American defectors. However Mr. Abrams concluded that each of the report's pillars was flawed:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEDY, LILLIAN T.
description: KENNEDY-Lillian T. (nee Walsh). Devoted wife of James T. Loving mother of Karen, Lynn De Natale, Christine Pedone, James Jr. and Kevin. Fond grandmother of eight. Reposing: McLaughlin, Kramer & Magiel, 220 Glen Street, Glen Cove, Sunday, 3-5 and 7-9, Mass of the Resurrection, on Monday, St. Gertrude's R.C. Church, Bayville, 10AM. Interment, Locust Valley Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEBNER, ROBERT A.
description: STEBNER-Robert A., 59. Of Sea Girt, New Jersey, on July 2, 1998. Husband of Martha (McLaughlin), son of John and the late Mary (Anderson) Stebner, father of Matthew and Jane Anne Goodwin, brother of Mary Daniels, grandfather of Ryan and Margaret Goodwin. Mass 9:30AM St. Mark's Church, Sea Girt. Burial Holy Rood Cemetery, Old Westbury, Long Island, NY. Visiting Sunday 7-9PM and Monday 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM at O'Brien Funeral Home, Wall, NJ (732-449-6900). In lieu of flowers, contributions to either Friends of Special Children or St. Mark's Social Concerns Committee, Crescent Parkway, Sea Girt, NJ 08750 would be appreciated.

title: Saving Japan's Banking System
description: At long last, Japan has put together a credible bank rescue package that contemplates closing banks that are hopelessly insolvent while taking bad loans off the books of banks that can make it. If executed well, the plan should help pull Japan out of recession and ease Asia's economic crisis.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. A review of ''Talk to Me,'' a film opening today, appears on page 8.

title: About New York; Double Mocha With a Shot Of Watercolor
description: FRANCISCO RIVERA ROSA likes his coffee jet black and jet-fuel strong. He's particularly partial to a bitter blend that's thick as paste. ''No milk, no sugar,'' he insists. ''No anything.'' Except for the occasional splash of watercolor. Or acrylic. Or mud.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLACKWELL, JOSEPH B., JR
description: BLACKWELL-Joseph B., Jr. Happy 25th anniversary in Heaven. Rest in peace, dear father. The world is a better place for your having lived in it. Your loving children, grandchildren and great grandchildren.

title: American Food
description: What is American food? The question no longer has an easy answer. On the eve of the Fourth of July, here are 12 quintessentially American restaurants. Happy birthday. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Executive Changes
description: BERTELSMANN A.G., Gutersloh, Germany, named Peter Olson chairman and chief executive of Random House Inc., created by the merger of Bantam Doubleday Dell and Random House. Also, Erik Engstrom, president and chief executive of Bantam Doubleday Dell North America, was named president and chief operating officer of Random House Inc.

title: 'On Stage, and Off'
description: The 'On Stage, and Off' column will resume with the new theater season in the fall.

title: Revision Offered On Sex Bias Pact
description: Smith Barney Inc. and lawyers for women who sued the firm for sex discrimination proposed an amended settlement yesterday to the Federal judge who rejected their previous agreement.

title: Holiday Tomorrow: The Fourth of July
description: NEW YORK

title: Amish Are Facing Modern Vice in a Drug Case
description: At a glance, they looked little different from any other defendant indicted on illegal drug charges. Standing before Judge Jay C. Waldman at their arraignment in Federal District Court this morning, the two men with the same name looked anxious, frightened, perhaps even a little embarrassed.

title: Defeating Outdoor Pitfalls With an Afternoon Frolic
description: It is a risky proposition to present dance outdoors in an urban setting. The program must be strong enough to survive the depredations of jets, boomboxes, weather shifts and audience inattention. As a result, mere accessibility often overrules artistic taste and quality. That was not the case, however, with ''Dancing With Myself!,'' presented by the Bryant Park Restoration Corporation in a late-afternoon performance on Wednesday on the lawn of Bryant Park.

title: Ex-F.C.C. Chief Named to Board
description: Ascend Communications Inc., the No. 4 computer networking company, said today that it had named Reed E. Hundt, the former chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, to its board.

title: Columbia Crew Advances
description: It was January in July, weather-wise, at the Henley Royal Regatta yesterday, but most American rowing teams thrived nevertheless on the River Thames.

title: Citicorp Will Close 3 Credit-Card Offices
description: Citicorp is closing credit-card processing offices in Salt Lake City, Denver and Columbus, Ga., to cut costs and improve efficiency.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE FALLS. Coffee prices dropped on expectations that moderate weather in Brazil would improve the prospects for that country's crop. Coffee for September delivery fell 2.2 cents, to $1.0935 a pound.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GTECH HOLDINGS CORP., -- West Greenwich, R.I., the lottery operator, paid $:16.8 million ($27.8 million) for an 80 percent stake in Europrint Holdings Ltd., a British provider of games that media use for promotions.

title: School Rehires Teacher Fired Over Marriage
description: A Roman Catholic school in Cortlandt Manor, N.Y. agreed today to rehire a teacher who was dismissed from her job because she had married a divorced Episcopalian who had never had his previous marriage annulled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNOW, VERNON F.
description: SNOW-Vernon F. New York University notes with sadness the passing of Dr. Vernon F. Snow, educator, friend and benefactor of New York University. Through the John Ben Snow Memorial Trust, Dr. Snow assisted many artistic and educational endeavors. At NYU, he is remembered for his longtime support of the Root-Tilden-Snow Scholarship Fund at the School of Law and the John Ben Snow Scholarship Fund at the Stern School. We shall miss him greatly. L. Jay Oliva, President Laurence A. Tisch, Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: Irving Sloane, 73, Self-Taught Guitar Maker
description: Irving Sloane, a self-taught luthier whose how-to books on high-end guitar construction paved the way for the current proliferation of finely crafted hand-built guitars, died on June 21. He was 73.

title: Britain's G.E.C. Says Revamping Is Complete
description: The General Electric Company P.L.C., Britain's largest manufacturer, said yesterday that it had finished reorganizing its business and had an $8 billion war chest to make acquisitions.

title: Gart Offers $445.2 Million For 70% of Sports Authority
description: Intensifying the battle to consolidate the troubled sporting goods industry, the Gart Sports Company has offered $20 a share, or a total of $445.2 million, in cash for 70 percent of the Sports Authority Inc.

title: Sports of The Times; Star System Is Declining In the N.B.A.
description: THE New Jersey philanthropist who envisions the Nets becoming part of Newark's downtown revival apparently did his homework in basketball economics. Ray Chambers, who helped broker the deal that will very likely transfer the team to two real estate developers, called around the sport's power circles and raised the question that most owners haven't satisfactorily answered themselves.

title: The CNN-Time Retraction
description: The pre-launch publicity for a new Time-CNN collaboration called ''NewsStand'' made its first piece sound like the daring international scoop of every journalist's dreams. But yesterday, less than a month after CNN and Time jointly charged that America secretly used nerve gas on a mission designed to kill defectors during the Vietnam War, they took it back.

title: CNN Retracts Report That U.S. Used Nerve Gas
description: Cable News Network executives yesterday retracted the network's report that the United States military used lethal sarin nerve gas in a secret 1970 mission in Laos with the intention of killing American defectors.

title: Jobs Growth Eased In June, Data Show
description: Job growth slowed in June, as the unemployment rate edged up to 4.5 percent, the Government reported yesterday, in a sign that the hot economy was cooling somewhat.

title: Six Years in the Making, Songs Seek Perfection
description: Lucinda Williams carried her songs onstage at Tramps on Tuesday night in a black vinyl binder, each lyric sheet encased in clear plastic, protected from sweat and spilled beer. Every so often, she would glance toward a page, nailing down an old verse or a new one. Mostly, though, she dug those phrases from memory, and the book seemed more like the ark of a covenant Ms. Williams had made with herself and the audience that eagerly awaits her every word.

title: June Job Data Show Growth Eased a Little
description: The hot United States economy is showing signs of cooling, but by only a few degrees. In June, the Labor Department reported yesterday, unemployment edged up to 4.5 percent and job growth slowed.

title: FLORIDA FIRES SEND MANY MORE FLEEING
description: Parts of the northeast coast of Florida felt like a war zone today as wildfires consumed brush and buildings with no hindrance from nature and hundreds more residents of Volusia and Brevard Counties fled towns threatened by the flames.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Japan Announces a Plan To Tackle Bad Bank Loans

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMANN, LEONORE L.K.
description: HERMANN-Leonore L.K. On July 1, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Adolph I. Klein & Dr. Nathaniel R. Hermann. Loving mother of Kathryn Briger, Richard Klein and stepmother of Susan H. Ginsberg and Patricia Hermann. Adoring grandmother of Devon & Peter L. Briger Jr., Matthew H. Briger, Margaret & Brian Caylor, Cristopher S. Goodman and Nicholas T. Goodman. Dear sister of Harriet Friedman. Services and interment are private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the scholarship fund of the Art Student League of New York, 215 West 57 Street, New York, New York 10019.

title: Whitman And Mayor In Dispute Over Arena
description: A war of words has erupted between Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and Mayor Sharpe James of Newark over the Mayor's suggestion that race might be a factor in the decision on whether the New Jersey Devils hockey team would move to a new arena in Newark.

title: It's Not All Comets, Asteroids And Giant Mutant Lizards
description: Hollywood has never issued an official declaration. But the Fourth of July weekend is the peak of the silly season in movies. As fireworks detonate around the country, thousands of screens will light up with fantasies of the world (or part of the world) saved at the last minute from destruction by the savvy and courage of comic-book heroes going up against catastrophic forces.

title: Tripp Returns To Grand Jury For 7 Hours
description: Linda R. Tripp returned to the grand jury room here today and spent nearly seven hours behind closed doors, apparently explaining her motives for secretly recording 20 hours of phone conversations with Monica S. Lewinsky, the former White House intern who was once her friend.

title: Restore Hamilton To His Pedestal
description: If you join the crowd on the Mall this Fourth of July, you'll see majestic and luminous monuments to George Washington, Abraham Lincoln and Thomas Jefferson, and even a new memorial to Franklin Roosevelt. But something is missing. There is no Hamilton memorial. This omission is not only unjust, but peculiar. For Alexander Hamilton, as much as any other American, deserves credit for the United States' pre-eminent position among nations.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNYDER, BEATRICE
description: SNYDER-Beatrice. The Board and Staff of the YWCA/NYC extend their condolences to Beryl Snyder on the recent passing of her mother Beatrice Snyder. We offer our deepest sympathy to Beryl and her family. Sally T. Butler, President Vivian Manning Fox, Executive Director

title: Investment Firm Branches Out By Buying Cellular Company
description: The Centennial Cellular Corporation agreed today to be acquired by Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe for $43.50 a share, or about $1.5 billion in cash, in the investment company's first move into the phone business.

title: Down by 3 in 9th? No Worry, as Yanks Win in 11th
description: With a two-out, ninth-inning, game-tying home run swing last night, Tino Martinez turned what had been a dreadful evening for the Yankees into yet another chapter in their enchanted season.

title: Ceiling Fans, Courtly Men And a Whiff Of Old Cuba
description: The Buena Vista Social Club basked in the latest wave of Cubaphilia when it performed on Wednesday night. The concert was more than a musical occasion. Musicians from Cuba in their 70's, 80's and 90's, some emerging from retirement, were making their United States debuts at no less than Carnegie Hall.

title: Sports of The Times; Despite Nationalism, Stars Share a Deep-Rooted Camaraderie
description: ON television or in the grandstand, the World Cup appears stridently nationalistic. When the English chant during the Argentine national anthem and the Argentines whistle during ''God Save the Queen,'' it sounds like the guns of August of 1914 all over again.

title: On a Trip Back to Futurism, Women and Settings Merge
description: In the brief life span of the Italian Futurist movement, the short-lived Umberto Boccioni (1882-1916) was a blazing comet. With Filippo Tommaso Marinetti (1876-1944), the poet and critic who founded Futurism, Boccioni was a fiery theoretician of the movement, drafting two Futurist manifestoes in 1910 and 1912 that exalted the force and energy of contemporary life. They called for an art that glorified speed, violence and the machine age, one that above all reflected the dynamism of an engine-driven civilization.

title: Prosecutors Broaden Investigation Into Police Brutality
description: Federal prosecutors investigating whether a pattern of brutality or misconduct exists in the New York City Police Department are seeking access to a deposition in which a senior police official discussed his inability to have Officer Francis X. Livoti transferred in 1991 despite nine brutality complaints filed against him.

title: Antiques; Green Fees (So to Speak) For Golfers
description: In his 1968 book ''The Truth About Golf, and Other Lies'' (Doubleday), Buddy Hackett describes a round of golf with Jimmy Durante: ''Jimmy's first round was a total disaster. As he came to the 18th hole, his partner, who had long since lost count, estimated Jimmy's score was over 200. After holing out for 12, the Schnoz turned to his companion and asked, 'What should I give the caddie?' Without smiling, the friend answered, 'Your clubs!' ''

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Richard Prince

title: Treasury Prices Stage a Rally As the Dollar Gathers Strength
description: Treasury prices rallied in an abbreviated pre-holiday session yesterday, as the dollar gathered strength in currency trading and the Government's latest report on employment suggested the economy was slowing.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Death Metal With a Twist Of Cheer
description: The common style of singing in death-metal is an animal noise. It's not like Eartha Kitt's impish growl; it's an enraged gust scraped clean of any tonal quality, roughed up in the throat, leonine or dinosaurlike. As the singer intones over the caustic guitars and rhythmic detonations going on underneath, syllables become just about unintelligible, as if the words had been run through a chipper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, FRANCES C.
description: ISRAEL-Frances C. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its member, Frances C. Israel. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Martin I. Klein, President Shirley Steinhauser, Sisterhood President

title: Debuts in 'La Sylphide,' With Poses Rarely Seen
description: American Ballet Theater, which ends its engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House with ''Le Corsaire'' tomorrow night, saved some of its most interesting debuts for this final week.

title: Who Bears Harassment Burden?
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST BRANDS TO ACQUIRE 2 PRODUCT LINES FROM COLGATE
description: The First Brands Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Handi Wipes re-usable cleaning cloths and Wash'n Dri pre-moistened towelettes from the Colgate-Palmolive Company for an undisclosed price to expand its household products business. First Brands, which generated $1.12 billion in sales in the 1997 fiscal year through consumer products such as Jonny Cat cat-box litter and STP automotive products, said the two towel brands, each market leaders in their respective categories, had combined sales of $20 million in 1997. First Brands shares fell $4, to $21.9375, and Colgate's shares fell 37.5 cents, to $88.25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, HAROLD, M.D.
description: WEISS-Harold, M.D. Cherished husband of Lena. Devoted father of Diana Podolnick, Norman Weiss, and Arlene Lewis. Dear brother of Flora Goldberg. Much loved grandfather of Jeffrey, Robert, Rachel, Scott, Jessica, Ephram and Tara. Also survived by 5 great-grandchildren. Services today at 12 Noon at Garlick's Funeral Home, Coney Island Avenue near Avenue N, Brooklyn.

title: Another Milestone in Cart (Not That Martin Is Counting)
description: Though he dismissed its significance, Casey Martin reached another milestone with his golf cart today while shooting a 71 at the Canon Hartford Open.

title: Resilience and Spirituality in a Fellini Treasure
description: There is more grace and courage in the famous image of Giulietta Masina smiling through her tears in Federico Fellini's 1957 ''Nights of Cabiria,'' the restored treasure of the summer movie season, than there is in all the fire-breathing blockbusters Hollywood has to offer.

title: Two Men Are Arrested In East Village Murder
description: A 32-year-old man was shot dead outside an East Village nightclub just after midnight yesterday, and two men who were found a short time later hiding in a nearby Dumpster were arrested and charged with his murder, the police said.

title: U.S. Nuclear Hypocrisy
description: To the Editor:

title: World Bank, A Bit Nervous, Resumes Aid To Indonesia
description: The World Bank resumed aid to Indonesia today for the first time since President Suharto was forced from office. It approved a $1 billion loan and predicted that major industrial nations would soon announce another $6 billion in aid.

title: Internal Inquiry Clears C.I.A. of Political-Influence Charges
description: A yearlong internal Central Intelligence Agency investigation of unauthorized contacts between a Democratic Party leader eager to help a wealthy party donor and the C.I.A. has found that no laws were broken by officials at the spy agency, Government officials say.

title: African Opportunity
description: For the Western Governments that have watched with dismay for the last three decades as much of Africa suffered through chaos and bankruptcy, the news from Nigeria today is the most gratifying from that continent since the establishment of a multiracial Government in South Africa under Nelson Mandela.

title: The Flag and Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Sign Fraser, a Wing
description: While they continued negotiations for several high-profile free agents yesterday, the Rangers announced the signing of one who is lesser known. Agreeing to terms was Scott Fraser, a 26-year-old who calls himself ''an up and down right winger.''

title: Red Dogs Win Local Matchup
description: The New York CityHawks got a gift of a fumble late in the game, but they still lost, 39-32, to the New Jersey Red Dogs last night before an announced crowd of 9,692 at Continental Arena.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, SAMUEL
description: FELDMAN-Samuel. Extraordinary attorney at law. Beloved husband of Beatrice S. Feldman, devoted father of Alice and Jerold Gingold, and Nancy De Fren. Beloved by all who knew him. Services Friday, 12:30 at Schwartz Brothers Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd, 76th Rd, Forest Hills.

title: Japan Is Still Key To China's Growth
description: To the Editor:

title: BROWNING-FERRIS TO BUY BACK $750 MILLION IN STOCK
description: Browning-Ferris Industries said yesterday that it would buy back $750 million in stock, or about 21.4 million of its shares. The buyback represents about 12 percent of the company's 176.2 million shares outstanding. Browning-Ferris, a Houston-based waste and recycling services company, said it expected to complete the buyback by Sept. 30, 1999. Browning-Ferris finished buying back shares on June 30 under a $500 million repurchase program. Shares of Browning-Ferris closed at $35.25, down 62.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Dow Slips by 23.41 Points In 3d-Lightest Day of Year
description: Stocks fell yesterday on the third-lightest trading day of the year after Government reports on jobs and manufacturing suggested that profits could suffer from a slowing economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIMMEL, ALLAN LEE
description: KIMMEL-Allan Lee. Beloved husband of Margaret (Peggy). Loving father of Karl and Frederick. Dear brother of Sondra Jordan. Cherished grandfather of Christine, Nicole, Tiffany, Kathryn and Kyle. Educator and musician, passed away July 1, 1998.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Judith Rothschild

title: G.O.P. Delivers Unusual Praise On Clinton Trip
description: Even before President Clinton's return from China, many prominent Republicans concede that the trip has been a political success that could deprive their party of a potent election-year issue.

title: UBS Told to Tighten Risk Controls on Trading
description: UBS A.G., the world's second-biggest bank, was told yesterday by Swiss regulators to tighten its risk controls in the wake of the old Union Bank of Switzerland's loss of 625 million Swiss francs ($406 million) on derivatives last year. The loss was attributed to ''several deficiencies'' in controls and unnamed individuals' mistakes. About half were incurred in trading on Japanese convertible bonds.

title: CRESCENT TO PAY $548 MILLION FOR 4 OFFICE BUILDINGS
description: Crescent Real Estate Equities Inc., led by the billionaire investor Richard Rainwater, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy four office buildings for $548 million, extending its position as one of the largest United States office owners. The properties contain 3.16 million square feet and consist of the BP Plaza in suburban Houston, Woodfield Corporate Center in suburban Chicago, Two Town Center in Costa Mesa, Calif., and the 6701 Tower in West Los Angeles. Separately, Crescent sold $225 million of convertible preferred stock to the Prudential Insurance Company of America and the seller of three of the buildings. Crescent, based in Fort Worth, owns a concentration of properties around Houston, Dallas and other Southwestern cities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NADEL, HARRY
description: NADEL-Harry. A very special man, you will be missed by your family at Sholom & Zuckerbrot Realty. You touched our hearts. Our condolences to the Nadel family.

title: Lawyer in Brawley Trial Insists the Plaintiff Is Guilty
description: Steven A. Pagones, the plaintiff in the Tawana Brawley defamation case, is ''lucky he is not in jail'' for the rape and kidnapping of Ms. Brawley a decade ago, one of the defense lawyers said in his summation today.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Gooooaaaallll! Univision's Audience Takes Off
description: Henry Cisneros looks at the number of Hispanic television households tuned to Univision's World Cup broadcasts and is bowled over: 1.5 million for Germany-Mexico, 1.4 million for Belgium-Mexico, 1.3 million for South Korea-Mexico.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWRENCE, ADELE MARIE
description: LAWRENCE-Adele Marie (nee Cohen). Of Lincoln, MA. Formerly of Freeport, NY. On July 1 at age 78. She will be deeply missed by her devoted and loving husband Jack. Her memory will be cherished always by her children Jon Lawrence and Vicki Blier, their spouses Gerd and Malcolm, and her grandchildren Stefan, Marika, Sam and Zack. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Amyloid Research Center at Boston University Medical Center.

title: When High Jinks Outweigh Shakespeare's Words
description: It must be the fashion this year for theater productions to begin before the audiences arrive. Turn up half an hour early for ''Cabaret,'' for instance, and there are the decadent Kit Kat Girls, slithering and stretching onstage, establishing the Weimar atmosphere for the show to come. Arrive a little early for the International WOW Theater Company's production of ''Macbeth,'' and there are various cast members with swords, witch's brooms and other props, moving about and interacting in clearly choreographed ways. Periodically one of the jumpsuited actors identified in the program as the Machinists comes to the center and speaks into a walkie-talkie in a loud voice of intense fear. This is expert mood establishment.

title: British Prudential's Pension Sales at Issue
description: The Prudential Corporation, Britain's largest insurer, was sharply criticized yesterday by members of Parliament for misleading people when selling pensions in the 1980's. The Government has said British insurers persuaded tens of thousands of people to switch from company pensions to more costly and lower-paying personal plans and has ordered them to restore the losses.

title: Anti-Sweatshop Coalition Finds Itself at Odds on Garment Factory Code
description: Eight months past its self-imposed deadline to set up a code of conduct for apparel factories, a Presidential task force remains at stalemate over a number of pivotal issues, including the frequency with which those factories ought to be inspected and whether any of them ought to be in China.

title: Annan Says Nigeria Plans to Free A Candidate and Other Prisoners
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan of the United Nations said today that Nigeria's new military Government pledged to release all remaining political prisoners, among them Moshood K. O. Abiola, who was jailed after apparently winning the 1993 presidential election.

title: The Flag and Speech; What 'Desecrate' Means
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLES, JULIA
description: PERLES-Julia. Our partners, associates and staff express our deepest sorrow at the loss of our esteemed former Senior Partner, Counsel and Chair of our Matrimonial Department. Julia Perles was a remarkable individual and an outstanding leader of the Bar whose foresight, perseverance, and leadership in the field of Family Law shaped the law in many ways over several decades, most notably in securing passage of New York's Equitable Distribution Law. She was a trusted friend and colleague whose candor, determination and wisdom manifest her richest legacy to us. We will sorely miss her distinctive presence in our professional and personal lives. We express our deepest condolences to her beloved family. Phillips Nizer Benjamin Krim & Ballon LLP

title: Corrections
description: A listing of holiday closings yesterday for the New York metropolitan area misstated the Metro-North Railroad schedule for today and tomorrow. It is the regular Friday and Saturday schedule, not a holiday schedule. A complete corrected listing appears today on page B2.

title: Anti-Government Freemen Are Found Guilty of Fraud
description: A Federal jury convicted the leadership of the anti-government Freemen movement today on several charges, largely financial fraud, but was unable to reach verdicts on other counts including the conspiracy charge that is at the core of the case.

title: Who Bears Harassment Burden?
description: To the Editor:

title: Batboy Paid Price In Brawl
description: The two-inch fish hook cut across Joe Rocchio's forehead is six weeks old. The pink gash might fade, but a plastic surgeon told the batboy that it would not disappear. Guess what? Tino Martinez was not the only casualty in the infamous brawl between the Baltimore Orioles and the Yankees on May 19.

title: Failed Tests on Monkeys Frustrate Hopes for AIDS Vaccine
description: Hopes for a vaccine against AIDS were set back today at the 12th World AIDS Conference here when researchers reported that a vaccine made from a weakened simian virus and injected into monkeys had caused the disease it was designed to prevent.

title: Central Park To Get Taste Of Cafe Scene At 2 Kiosks
description: The ever-expanding coffee-and-pastry-shop universe reached Central Park this week with the construction of two lacy, cast-iron food kiosks under the trees inside the park's Columbus Circle entrance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOUGLAS, WILLIAM W.
description: DOUGLAS-William W., MD, FRS, Professor Emeritus of Pharmacology, Yale University. On July 2, 1998, peacefully at Hospice after a difficult illness. Beloved husband of Jeannine, father of Alan and Colin, father-in-law of Maria, and devoted grandfather of Tristan & Jeremy. An outstanding scientist and a great human being. Funeral private. Donations to Connecticut Hospice in Branford.

description: 'The Academy of the Sword'

title: Herbert Haufrecht, 88, Pianist, Composer, Folklorist and Editor
description: Herbert Haufrecht, a composer, pianist, folklorist and music editor, died on June 23 at the Albany Medical Center. He was 88 and lived in Shady, N.Y.

title: Hundley May Return Next Week
description: Todd Hundley thinks he has a chance to return to the Mets next Thursday for their first game after the All-Star Game break.

description: Laura Davies is much better at golf than she is at making predictions.

description: CANTOR-B. Gerald. My darling Bernie, Always Missed, Always Treasured, Always Loved. Iris

description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Art galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Summer hours vary for galleries and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.
