description: Hamilton, Madison, Franklin, Washington, Adams and Jefferson had these ideas.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNSTEIN, RICHARD H.
description: BERNSTEIN-Richard H. Today is your 53rd birthday. Life goes on and you are with me constantly. Love you, Mom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUCH, HELEN
description: STRAUCH-Helen (nee Abrams). On July 1, 1998 at age 101. Wife of the late Edward Strauch of Watertown, NY. Beloved mother of Arnold Strauch and Lois Rosenblatt. Cherished & adored grandmother & great grandmother. Graveside service on Friday, 10:30 A.M., at the Westchester Hills Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBENSTEIN, SYLVIA (NEE GERVIS
description: RUBENSTEIN-Sylvia (nee Gervis). On July 2, 1998. Wife of the late Philip of Philadelphia, PA. Formerly of New York. Mother of Lynne Kaiser and Bobbi (Kenny) Gray. Grandmother of William (Marcy) Kaiser, Lauren (Paul) Kaiser Albert, Paul (Kimberly) Kaiser, Garrett (Lisa) Gray, David Gray, Ronald Gray. Great-grandmother of Samuel Kaiser, Jessica Gray, Jason Gray, Elizabeth Kaiser, Abigail Kaiser, Matthew Kaiser. Relatives & friends are invited to crypt side services, Sunday, 2PM, the Mausoleum of Abraham & Sarah at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey. The family respectully requests contributions in her memory can be made to M.A.D.D. or the American Cancer Society or the American Heart Association. Platt Memorial Chapels, Inc., Cherry Hill, New Jersey.

title: New Hampshire Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Higher-Level Lapses Found in Ski Lift Crash
description: Failures by the Marine Corps and the Air Force to pass along crucial information cast ''substantial doubt'' on whether the pilot of a plane that struck a ski lift cable in the Italian Alps in February could be convicted in a court-martial, a hearing officer found in a report released today.

title: THOMAS & BETTS IN DEAL FOR TELECOMMUNICATIONS DEVICES
description: The Thomas & Betts Corporation said yesterday that it would buy the closely held Telecommunications Devices Inc. for about $74.4 million in stock. Thomas & Betts, one of the top three makers of electrical connectors and electronic components, will pay 1.5 million shares of its stock for Telecommunications Devices. Telecommunications Devices, which is based in Chicago, is the largest maker of battery packs for mobile equipment, excluding mobile-communications companies producing their own. It had revenue of $145 million in 1997 and employs about 850 people. The stock of Thomas & Betts, which is based in Memphis, rose 12.5 cents, to $49.625.

title: Nation-Building With Prints
description: Mexico's version of Social Realism dominates ''Mexican Prints From the Collection of Reba and Dave Williams'' at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, and that makes for dreary viewing.

title: Fiore Is Hired
description: Ted Fiore, a former coach at St. Peter's College of Jersey City, a Division I school, will be named head basketball coach at Division III Montclair State University at a news conference Monday, the school announced yesterday.

title: WORLD CUP '98: Strength in the Mouth of the Goal; The Assertive Schmeichel Gives Denmark an Advantage
description: As he stood in goal for Denmark's 4-1 dismantling of Nigeria, Peter Schmeichel grabbed his head with his hands and twisted it from side to side as if he were unscrewing a bottle cap. Then he repeatedly flexed his jaws, limbering the muscles of his mouth the way others stretch their hamstrings. He is considered the best goalkeeper in the world, and also the loudest.

title: Japan Is Still Key To China's Growth
description: To the Editor:

title: Stanton's Suspension Upheld
description: Gene Budig, the American League president, declined yesterday to reduce the five-game suspension he imposed on Yankees pitcher Mike Stanton for hitting the Orioles' Eric Davis with a pitch on June 16. Budig's decision irked Stanton and Manager Joe Torre.

title: In a Starry Ballroom, To the World's Beat
description: For the annual Midsummer Night Swing festival, which ingeniously presents world music in the context of an outdoor ballroom on the Lincoln Center Plaza each summer, Rebecca Weller, the founding producer, will fly halfway around the globe to hear bands recommended by her trusted network of connoisseurs. Once she finds the bands, however, she sometimes has to convince them that playing for dancers is worthwhile.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It is hard to understand how this is serving any useful purpose to God or to politics.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GROSSMANN, MALVINE
description: GROSSMANN-Malvine. Died July 3, 1996. Loved forever Ernest

title: A Guidebook Lists the Warning Signs of Sexual Abuse
description: The four youths in Brooklyn who the police say were raped and sodomized by relatives did not appear at a medical clinic with symptoms of venereal disease. Nor did the children, who were under the supervision of the city's child welfare agency, immediately tell their caseworker of their long ordeal.

title: A Mix of New and Old in the Berkshires
description: Performances by the Paul Taylor Dance Company and Donald Byrd/ The Group are the formal attractions this weekend at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass. But informal dance sprouts, it seems, in every lawn, hill and grove, ranging from spontaneous eruptions like solitary pirouette practice in a parking lot to free organized events like lectures, exhibitions, book signings, self-guided walking tours and even a hands-on interactive computer installation.

title: TV Weekend; The Nation's Essence in the Anecdotes
description: ''American Stories: The American Dream,'' from the Discovery Channel, is a discount version of ''People's Century,'' the 26-part world-history lesson that started on PBS in April and promises to carry on into the 20th century's twilight. Both productions offer resounding events as experienced by people who were caught up in them: history from below. But the Discovery Channel series, which arrives tomorrow, concentrates on the United States and does the job in a mere five hours.

title: Hop On, Hop Off: The Unlimited Metrocard Arrives
description: A new era for the New York City's mass transit riders begins at midnight tonight, when the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's unlimited-ride Metrocard passes go on sale, offering what transit officials hope will be a huge new incentive to use subways and buses.

title: 11 Firefighters Are Fined in Cafe Fracas
description: A month after accounts of a drunken brawl among firefighters at a midtown restaurant, Fire Commissioner Thomas Von Essen yesterday penalized 11 firemen with a loss of pay for their involvement, and closed an investigation into what he called ''a very sad day in the history of our department.''

title: State Department Seeks Extradition of Chesimard
description: The State Department has asked Cuba to extradite about 90 people to the United States, including Joanne D. Chesimard, a former member of a black militant group who was convicted of killing a New Jersey State Police trooper in 1973.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PREDMESKY, AKIBA, RABBI DR.
description: PREDMESKY-Akiba, Rabbi Dr. SAR Academy mourns the loss of the beloved husband of Byrdie, cherished father of Shulamit and Rabbi Joel Cohn, Principal of SAR. Shiva will be observed at 76-51 173rd Street, Flushing, New York, on Friday, Motzei Shabbat and Sunday until 9PM; it will continue at 137-79 70th Road, Kew Gardens all day Monday and Tuesday AM. May the entire family find sustenance in his memory and be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jack C. Bendheim, President

title: Residential Real Estate; Midtown Developer Mixes Work With Pleasure
description: Betting that renters will venture into a nontraditional residential area for large loft apartments, the owners of 545 West 34th Street are transforming the 88-year-old warehouse into a rental loft building in which tenants can both live and work.

title: Networks Consider Lockout Telecasts
description: CBS and Fox Sports have contacted National Basketball Association player agents about broadcasting exhibition games during the lockout, two agents confirmed yesterday.

title: The Punch Line Is No Joke For Comics Turned Pilots
description: In Masayuki Imai's play ''The Winds of God,'' two comedians in modern Tokyo recover memories they were unaware they had lost, and with them a chapter of history often avoided in Japan as simply too bitter to dwell on. Wiped out in a motorcycle accident on a Tokyo street, they find themselves reincarnated as airmen training to be kamikaze pilots in the final days of World War II. Other pilots in the squadron all treat them like old friends, and gradually the two realize that the men they now inhabit must have been former selves who died on suicide missions to destroy American ships.

title: Where History and Beaches Meet
description: Look at a map and you'll see the problem instantly: the pint-size right triangle of land called Delaware looks like a cartographic afterthought.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Not 'Raging Bull,' But It's a Start

title: G.M. Dealers See Dwindling Supply of Hot Models
description: Ask David White Jr., a Chevrolet dealer here, how long he can last during the current strikes against without running out of vehicles, and his initial response is full of confidence: two months, because he has about 220 new cars and trucks in stock and typically sells 110 a month.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Sunday about Linda Tripp's appearance before the grand jury investigating President Clinton's relationship with Monica Lewinsky referred to a report in the first issue of Brill's Content, the journalism magazine, that Ms. Tripp and a literary agent orchestrated the disclosure of the relationship with the help of a Newsweek correspondent, Michael Isikoff. According to the Content account, Ms. Tripp and the agent believed that Mr. Isikoff had suggested the kinds of tangible evidence he needed to publish an article.

title: Recent Appointee Quits Campaign Finance Panel
description: One of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's representatives on the Campaign Finance Board has resigned, less than 10 months after his appointment stirred criticism that the Mayor was trying to pack the board to avoid being penalized for fund-raising violations.

title: LAIDLAW STOCK DOWN 12% ON NEWS OF TAX RULING
description: The stock of Laidlaw Inc. fell more than 12 percent yesterday after the company said it had lost a United States tax ruling. A United States Tax Court judge ruled that the company, the largest provider of ambulance and school bus service in North America, owed taxes from 1986 to 1988 of about $49.6 million, plus interest of $91.4 million. The taxes are related to a Dutch subsidiary, which was used to finance United States operations. Laidlaw said it might also owe taxes from 1989 to 1994, bringing the total amount to about $500 million. The company has $200 million of available tax reserves. The company, based in Burlington, Ontario, had 1997 revenues of $3.03 billion. On the New York Stock Exchange, Laidlaw stock fell $1.5625, to $10.6875, below the previous one-year low of $11.125 set on June 24.

title: WEEKEND WARRIOR; Backhand Fantasy: Revenge of the Lawn
description: For me, the Fourth of July has always had a British spin. My most memorable Independence Days began by setting the alarm clock for an early breakfast of strawberries and cream and the gentlemen's finals at Wimbledon on the telly: Ashe and Connors, McEnroe and Borg, Becker and Edberg, Sampras and whoever.

title: Pressing On In a Quest For Wisdom
description: H. T. Chen has been moving steadily over the last two decades toward a form of dance that is seldom seen in the United States. Mr. Chen, who trained in Chinese and Western dance and theater in his native China and in Taiwan and the United States, has almost always seen heroes in the common man, first in narrative dances and later in his unusual, big, roiling dance-based spectacles. In ''Warriors of Light,'' performed by Chen and Dancers on Tuesday night at St. Mark's Church in the East Village, Mr. Chen moves closer to pure abstraction.

title: LEUCADIA TO SELL A 25% INTEREST IN ARGENTINE INSURER
description: The Leucadia National Corporation, an investment holding company, agreed yesterday to sell a 25 percent interest in the privately held Argentine insurance company Caja de Ahorro y Seguro S.A. for $140 million. Leucadia, which said in May that it might liquidate because it could not find any more businesses to buy at inexpensive prices, owns businesses as diverse as insurance companies and wineries. It said it expected to record a pretax gain of about $100 million on the Argentine sale. Leucadia, which is based in New York, said it was selling the stake in the Argentine insurer to a private Argentine company that is also an investor in Caja. Leucadia will still have a 5 percent stake in the company. Its stock rose $1.25 yesterday, to $34.25.

title: A Mets Switch in Time Scores 10 and Now 9
description: The experiment is only two days old. But so far, Mets Manager Bobby Valentine's juxtapositioning of John Olerud and Mike Piazza in the heart of his struggling lineup has provided some extremely promising results.

title: Talkeetna Journal; Crowds Wager With Death on the High One
description: The cemetery in this risk-lover's domain should be enough to keep most people from trying to stand atop the High One, or Denali, as Athabascan Indians call Mount McKinley. The climbers came from all over the world, drawn to the highest peak in North America, and they ended up with their names on granite here -- 118 dead over the last 65 years.

title: Midway in a Verdi Cycle, With a 25th Anniversary
description: Vincent La Selva, the artistic director of the New York Grand Opera, has been presenting staged operas in Central Park for 25 years. So Wednesday night's performance of Verdi's ''Luisa Miller,'' the first offering of this summer's anniversary season, was preceded by several tributes, speeches and a congratulatory letter from President Clinton, which was read to the Summerstage audience. ''Regretfully, the President is unable to be here tonight,'' a member of the company's board announced implausibly. But the enthusiasm was understandable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELDEN, RICHARD CLINTON
description: WELDEN-Richard Clinton. June 29, 1998. Husband of Mary Thenebe Welden. Father of Thorn, Wickford and Trafford. Brother of Robert E. Welden. He was a partner with the law firm Decker, Hubbard, Welden and Sweeney, NYC. Memorial service Tuesday, July 14, 1998, 11AM at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at 91 Street.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Why Shelves Empty Faster
description: The old question of why you often can't find what you want in a video store has taken on interesting ramifications because of new ways in which movie studios are doing business with video stores.

title: New Asteroid May Indicate Hidden Threat
description: Astronomers at the University of Hawaii have discovered an asteroid that they believe represents a hitherto undetected type, a type that could hit Earth without warning.

description: In Queens, Bald Is Beautiful

title: Home in Child Sex Abuse Case Was Deemed Safe by the City
description: Six months before the police arrested Daniel Robacker and Theresa Fremgen on charges of repeatedly raping their two daughters in a filthy Brooklyn apartment, child welfare officials approved the home as a safe place for the teen-age girls.

title: Henman vs. Sampras: Cause Meets Special Effect
description: The prayer rugs come with explicit instructions and have already been mass-produced. Pray for Henman, command the tacky paper mats, which helpfully provide a pair of racquets marking the spot for each knee of obedient kneelers.

title: Graf Will Play In New Jersey
description: Fourteen years ago, Steffi Graf played for the first time in New Jersey's warm-up for the United States Open. This year, at age 29 and returning from knee surgery that almost led her to quit the sport, she will be back in New Jersey.

description: Good Will Hunting

title: Great Brington Journal; At Diana's Shrine, All's Not Adoration
description: If there were any dissenters here who found it all a bit much -- the rush of cars on once-quiet country roads; the $15 commemorative pillboxes; the fresh expressions of grief that made it seem almost as if Diana, the Princess of Wales, died last week instead of last August -- they were mostly keeping quiet today.

title: Healthy Vegan Kids
description: To the Editor:

title: How a Home's Sale Led to Discovery of 2 Murders
description: For nearly 14 years, the bodies of two murder victims, a young man and a teen-age girl, were hidden in a crude and shallow grave beneath the crawl space of a tiny Cape Cod house near Atlantic City. The homicides might not have been discovered, the authorities said yesterday, but for the sale of the house and the new owner's plans to remodel it.

title: Stiff Rules Set Up to Review Racial Bias by Jurors
description: The Connecticut Supreme Court established new, rigorous guidelines today for how a trial court should investigate allegations of racial bias by jurors, after finding in a decision released today that a judge should have done more to look into such claims in a murder trial here in 1996.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

description: To the Editor:

title: Infant Girl Left in Car Dies of Heat Exposure
description: A 4-month-old girl died on Wednesday from heat exposure after her mother absent-mindedly left her in a parked car for three and a half hours, county prosecutors said. The prosecutors have charged the mother, Malke Pinter, 24, of Lakewood, with manslaughter and child endangerment in the death of her daughter, Donya Chaya Pinter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, RALPH SHARP
description: BROWN-Ralph Sharp. The Dean and Faculty of Yale Law School mark with sadness the passing, on Wednesday, June 17, 1998, of Ralph S. Brown, Simeon E. Baldwin Professor Emeritus of Law and Frank E. Taplin Professorial Lecturer in Law, longtime friend and beloved colleague. He will be warmly remembered for over four decades of devoted teaching and service at Yale Law School; and for his scholarly contributions to the law. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. A memorial service for Professor Brown will be held at the Yale University Press, 302 Temple Street, New Haven, CT., Sunday, September 27, 1998, at 5 P.M. Memorial contributions may be made to The Ralph S. Brown Fund for Student Needs at The Yale Law School Fund, PO Box 208341, New Haven, CT. 06520-8341. Anthony T. Kronman, Dean Yale Law School

title: Dial M for Mating Game: Betty and Veronica Seek a Guy Who's No Jughead
description: Betty and Veronica are the focal females of ''Talk to Me,'' but the action is far from the teen-age angst of Archie Comics.

title: Prayer in a Bronx School
description: The dismissal of Mildred Rosario for leading a sixth-grade public school class in prayer last month has brought a predictable flood of denunciations, and in an odd way performed a valuable service. Joining Mayor Rudolph Giuliani in defending Mrs. Rosario, a bilingual teacher in the Bronx, were such luminaries of the Christian right as Representative Tom DeLay, the Republican whip, and Gary Bauer of the Family Research Council, who said ''we need countless teachers like this.'' In fact, Mrs. Rosario's actions showed precisely why we need to keep the ban on prayer in schools.

title: The Witness Enhancement Program
description: As Linda Tripp emerged this week to testify before a grand jury, her lawyer let it be known that she had felt maligned by the press and that her testimony would vindicate her. That rehabilitation would also be in the best interests of Kenneth Starr, the independent prosecutor investigating President Clinton.

title: Notes Show Fed Is Still Worried About Inflation
description: Despite signs that the economy might be slowing, the Federal Reserve remained concerned at its May meeting about a potential outbreak of inflation. Two of the 12 members on the Fed's policy-making committee voted against the panel's decision then to hold interest rates steady.

title: Mayor Promotes Budget Director To Deputy Mayor for Operations
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday promoted his budget director, Joseph J. Lhota, to Deputy Mayor for Operations, the position that has traditionally been second in command at City Hall.

title: Back on the Offensive for City Charter Guru
description: EIGHT years ago, Frederick A. O. Schwarz Jr. took his celebrated family name and several shelves of civic accomplishments and quietly departed from New York City's public arena. He had just led the commission that rewrote the City Charter, and -- unlike his old boss, Mayor Edward I. Koch -- found it unnecessary to comment on how it was carried out or offer his momentary opinions on Mr. Koch's two successors.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ON THE STREET

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Charles Long

title: Senator Arrested After Altercation With Police
description: An altercation between a New York State Senator and a police officer last night ended with the Senator being sprayed with Chemical Mace and handcuffed after the police said she bit the officer in the hand.

title: Frisk Me Now Among Nine Set to Meet in the Suburban
description: New York racing will fire its customary Fourth of July flare tomorrow when Belmont Park runs the final race in its ''handicap triple,'' the $350,000 Suburban at a mile and one-quarter.

title: Novotna Ousts Hingis to Meet a Finalist Her Own Age
description: Jana Novotna sank to her knees on the cold grass and pumped her fist with vengeful ferocity. Only the 29-year-old woman who had just taught a lesson to the same teen-ager who robbed her of her chance to win Wimbledon last year would comprehend the emotion.

title: The Campaign Never Rests: On the Road in China, Clinton Was Right at Home
description: As President Clinton traveled through China, his permanent campaign rolled on.

title: Strong Challenge to Kohl Is Strained by Infighting
description: Gerhard Schroder, the Social Democratic challenger to Chancellor Helmut Kohl in Germany's national elections in September, has gone out of his way to polish his image as a leader who would be good for business.

title: That Pakistan Nuclear Expert May Be a Lowly Accountant
description: A self-proclaimed defector from Pakistan's nuclear weapons program is not a scientist at all, but a low-paid accountant for a company that makes bathroom tiles, a director of the company said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUTTLE, VIRGINIA L.
description: SUTTLE-Virginia L. Died on June 27, 1998 at her residence in New York City. She was a native of New Orleans, LA. She was a graduate of Sophie Newcomb College of Tulane University and received a Master's Degree from Louisiana State University in Baton Rouge. She served for many years as a trustee of St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital in NYC. Mrs. Suttle was preceded in death by her husband, Harold L. Suttle. She is survived by cousins: Martha Ann Cassel of Tyler, TX; Gretta Hogan and Gretta Robb of Wichita Falls, TX, and W. Connally Powell of Dallas, TX. Private services. If desired in lieu of flowers memorials designated for research purposes may be made to St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital, 1000 Tenth Ave., NY NY 10019.

title: Baseball Names Clemente's Widow a Captain
description: When Major League Baseball announced last year that it would retire No. 42 to honor Jackie Robinson, there was universal applause for a sport rarely credited with hitting the right note.

description: PITT-Harry W., 90 years, died on July 2, 1998. Beloved husband of Rhoda. Devoted father of Susan and Richard Weiss, and Sally and David Perlman. Loving grandfather of Peter, Lauren and Michael. Services private. For further information call Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 516-487-9600.

title: A Medley of Show Tunes Can't Kick the Clouds Away
description: Summer has a concert life of its own in New York City, and much of it takes place free of charge in the city's parks. Besides the concerts by the Metropolitan Opera and the New York Philharmonic, mini-festivals like the weekly concerts in Washington Square Park, and special series like the New York Grand Opera's seven-year traversal of the Verdi operas, there are several venerable summer series that connect the New York of the 1990's with concertgoers of times long past. The Naumburg Orchestral Concerts, which opened on Tuesday evening at the Naumburg Band Shell in Central Park, have been offering symphonic fare, often with young musicians as soloists, since 1905.

title: Julia Perles, Groundbreaker In Divorce Law, Is Dead at 84
description: Julia Perles, a longtime Manhattan lawyer who played an important part in bringing about a significant change in New York State's divorce legislation, died early Wednesday at Sarasota Memorial Hospital in Sarasota, Fla. She was 84 and had lived in Sarasota for about four years.

title: BEACON CAPITAL TO BUY 14 PROPERTIES IN DALLAS AREA
description: Beacon Capital Partners Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 14 properties in the Dallas area from Breunig Commercial Management Inc. of Dallas for $91.5 million. The properties comprise seven office properties and seven research and development holdings. The portfolio is 95 percent leased, and more than 50 percent of the leases will come up for renewal within three years, giving the company a chance to raise rents, it said. Beacon Capital is led by Alan M. Leventhal, who sold his Beacon Properties Corporation real estate investment trust to Equity Office Properties Trust late last year in a $4 billion deal. In January, Mr. Leventhal created Beacon Capital as a new REIT and completed a private placement in April.

title: Knicks Seek Upfront Payment For Tickets Despite a Lockout
description: Tom Malmud, a New York lawyer, said he was shocked when he received the renewal notice for his three Knicks season tickets. He was angry that, despite a lockout of the players by the club owners, threatening the start of the season, the Knicks have raised ticket prices for their 43 home games in Madison Square Garden and want full payment upfront.

title: U S Airways Turns to Airbus In Ordering Long-Haul Planes

She is survived by her husband, Dr. Stanley Gross, of Greenwich; her son, Dr. Charles Gross, of Canton, OH; and daughter, Dr. Charlotte Gross, of Raleigh, NC. Memorial services will be held Sunday, July 5, at 3 PM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mt. Vernon, NY. title: Michael Crawford Becomes The Phantom of Radio City

But in imbuing this hunk of seductive bombast with creepy-crawly melodrama, no one can touch Michael Crawford, who has performed it onstage more than 3,000 times.

title: Mr. Starr Should Not Tarry
description: Kenneth Starr has every right to appeal the dismissal this week of the tax evasion charges he brought against Webster Hubbell, the former Associate Attorney General. The decision by Federal District Judge James Robertson seems questionable in several respects. But Mr. Starr should heed the larger message of this and other adverse rulings of recent weeks. That message is that the investigations of President Clinton must soon be brought to a conclusion. Although we are sympathetic to Mr. Starr's complaint that the White House has tried to impede his investigation, the time has come to lay out his evidence and conclusions.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Collecting; How My E-Type Jag Spent Last Summer
description: SUPPOSE you fulfill your fantasy and actually buy a classic car, say a 1969 E-Type Jaguar roadster. What in the world would you do with it? What if you cast prudence and all reason aside, hint at adventure to a dear photographer friend and drive it cross-country -- some 10,000 miles in 39 days? Cover 21 states, 8 national parks and 4 big cities. And while you're at it, endure five breakdowns (the car's, not your own). After all, it is a 60's Jag, a finicky breed of cat that many Americans love to look at, whether it is tearing down the road or sitting on the shoulder waiting for a tow truck.

title: Counterculture Rocker Reclaims His Heritage
description: Northern California has a river delta, but it's nothing like the one depicted in the stage set John Fogerty used at Radio City Music Hall on Thursday night. As evocative of humidity as the Sacramento River delta near Mr. Fogerty's hometown, El Cerrito, replete with friendly-looking alligators, tin shacks and a devilish moon, the scene was also unabashedly fake. It served as a tacit acknowledgment that the mythic Southern narrative Mr. Fogerty has explored since the late 1960's, the riverboat dream of ''Proud Mary'' and the voodoo hallucination of ''Born on the Bayou,'' was a tall tale from beginning to end.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHALEN, JANE RADFORD (MRS. CLIFTON W.
description: PHALEN-Jane Radford (Mrs. Clifton W.). Beloved wife, mother, grandmother, great grandmother and friend to many. On July 2, 1998. Contributions in her memory may be made to Saint Mary's Episcopal Church, Shelter Island, New York 11964.

title: With All the Tools at Hand, Using Only What Is Needed
description: Five days before his 85th birthday, the blues pianist Pinetop Perkins appeared at Chicago Blues on Thursday night like a wily sage who knows how to make silence eloquent. Mr. Perkins, who was a mainstay of Muddy Waters's band, has the entire blues vocabulary in his fingers, from boogie and shuffle bass lines to florid barrelhouse trills and filigrees. He can splash chords around or riffle up and down the keyboard, but without good reason, he doesn't; he plays with a ruthless economy.

title: Pope's Guidance on Dissent Provokes New Debate in the U.S.
description: In issuing an apostolic letter this week deeming some of the most controversial issues within the Roman Catholic Church beyond debate -- including euthanasia, the ordination of women and sexual relations outside marriage -- Pope John Paul II ignited new debate among Roman Catholics in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CAPLAN, MARK J.
description: CAPLAN-Mark J. It is one year since you are gone. Hard to believe you are not with us today. We miss you & shall never forget you. Always in our hearts and minds. Mom, Dad and Ron

title: Producer of Retracted CNN Report Defends Story, but Critics Fault Her Style
description: Ever since she entered the television news business in the mid-1980's, April Oliver has impressed her colleagues as an extremely confident and dedicated journalist. She gathered and synthesized details quickly. Her brisk, articulate presentations inspired trust.

Avex, a supplier of engineering and electronics manufacturing services, is a unit of the closely held J. M. Huber Corporation of Edison, N.J.

description: So the Israeli Government announces plans to extend the authority of the Jerusalem municipality over the hills and towns, primarily to the west and southwest of the Israeli capital. It says this is to improve city planning and services. The U.S. denounces this as a provocation that could derail peace talks. The Palestinians howl in protest. The U.N. moves to censure Israel. But behind the scenes, everyone is still asking: What is this Israeli move really about? Annexation? Provocation? Better bus service?

description: At long last, Tom Jenkins has that winning feeling again.

The 65 yen (47 United States cents) price is the lowest ever for a McDonald's hamburger in Japan. Cheeseburgers, which usually cost 160 yen, will be sold for 80 yen.

title: Obstructing Local Welfare Reform
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani made the right moves when he required New York City welfare recipients to work for benefits and asked new applicants to exhaust the search for employment before asking for aid. But as he makes it tougher to obtain welfare, he needs to make sure that the city also has policies and programs that offer tools to move into the work force. Among the big inconsistencies are proposals to limit remedial work at the City University of New York, tighten admission standards and delay student workfare. All are at odds with the aim of preparing more people to be wage-earners.

description: With the Liberty, which is undefeated at home, playing host to the Washington Mystics, who have not won on the road, last night's outing looked to be an easy one for New York.

description: The extortionist wanted his demand taken seriously, but apparently did not want to hurt anyone.

title: Vision World to Be Sold
description: Vision Twenty-One Inc. has agreed to buy Vision World and its 38 retail optical stores in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area for about $18.3 million in cash. Vision Twenty-One, which provides administrative services for eye-care specialists and is based in Largo, said Thursday that the purchase of Vision World, with 1997 revenue of $25.8 million, would raise the company's annual revenue to about $245 million.

title: Whitman Confirms Plan On Talks With Yankees
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's office confirmed yesterday that the state's Commerce Commissioner had written a memorandum outlining a plan between the New York Yankees and state officials to explore the possibility of moving the baseball team to New Jersey.

title: Corrections

title: When Fashion Jumps Into Sports Arena
description: PARIS  Fashion and sport may just be a match made in heaven. Ticket scams and hooligans aside, 80,000 spectators and an estimated 1.7 billion television fans will watch the World Cup soccer championship on July 12 and the warm-up act will be Yves Saint Laurent's 300 models gliding through the Stade de France, a symbol of what Pierre Berge describes as "the mysterious wedding of beauty and sport."

title: Wet Winter, Then Drought Are Linked to Florida Fires

description: Wearing black ski masks, a phalanx of gun-toting Russian tax police swept into a dingy warehouse this week and confiscated thousands of shiny bottles of vodka complete with phony markings indicating that alcohol taxes had been paid.

title: The Rites of Independence Day
description: The Fourth of July seems almost to steal over a small town daydreaming the summer away. A young boy rides his bicycle in a serpentine pattern down the middle of a dusty street. Blue sky divides a broken pavement of clouds. The road out of town seems to stretch farther than usual before it fades out of sight between fields of corn or soybeans, alfalfa or cotton. Near a railroad siding, the silence of noon is broken by the sound of a mechanic's hammer ringing against steel in the darkness of a repair shop. An old horse sleeps in a small corral behind the drive-in. The mail fails to arrive. A firecracker goes off in the alley.

title: Brosius Hit In 9th Inning Lifts Yanks
description: Baltimore Manager Ray Miller said he would not hesitate to employ Armando Benitez in Yankee Stadium, in spite of the reliever's status as Public Enemy No. 1 there. But last night, Miller would not use Benitez in a situation tailored for him, and the Yankees took advantage.

title: Summer Rally?
description: On Wall Street, they call it the summer rally, even though no one has ever demonstrated that stocks rally in any consistent fashion in the summer months. There have long been periodic surges in June, July and August, but a look at performance in the last decade indicates that while the market rallies more often than not, summer is not always the time of year for bulls. David Barboza

description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said today that it had withdrawn from a joint bid for Rosneft, Russia's last state-owned oil company, because low oil prices would limit returns from the project it was expected to finance.

title: Rewards of a China Summit
description: President Clinton's visit to China, like most Presidential journeys abroad, was carefully choreographed to further the interests of host and guest. Both sides hoped to move relations past the lingering trauma of the Tiananmen Square massacre nine years ago, and largely succeeded. The trip also burnished the leadership credentials of President Jiang Zemin, let Mr. Clinton talk about human rights directly to the Chinese people and advanced the easing of tensions between Washington and Beijing. But the hardest issues between the two countries were not resolved, and there was a fair amount of show in place of substance.

title: The Cozy Way to Shop in Paris
description: PARIS  Shopping at La Belle Hortense bookshop and literary bar in the Marais is not unlike dropping in on someone's home for a drink. On a Friday night and in a shop the size of a Parisian living room (31 Rue Vieille du Temple), the owner Nathalie Chkroun is the perfect hostess, flitting between guests, greeting, gossiping and filling empty glasses.

title: Consulting Firm In Acquisition

title: Songs Made for You and Me
description: Billy Bragg doesn't want Woody Guthrie to be remembered as a humorless, two-dimensional agitprop songwriter. He wants to avoid that same fate himself; Mr. Bragg, too, writes songs with direct political messages as well as songs on more personal topics. After being invited by Guthrie's heirs to dig through an archive of 2,500 Guthrie lyrics whose melodies were never recorded, and to write new tunes for them, Mr. Bragg has become more of a Guthrie fan than ever. His new album, ''Mermaid Avenue'' (Elektra), is a collaboration with the country-rock band Wilco, which backs him up and plays its own Guthrie finds.

description: ''I just figured with all these firefighters around these fires couldn't get out of control. People don't realize how rural Florida really is. They think beach, palm trees and bikinis.''

title: Pollution Puts People in Peril On the Border With Mexico
description: Every day Ciudad Juarez, the Mexican city across the Rio Grande from El Paso, produces 75 million gallons of raw sewage, much of which flows through irrigation ditches into the river, the prime source of water for nearly every community in both Mexico and the United States between here and the Gulf of Mexico. Ciudad Juarez has no sewage treatment plant.

title: Ground Level
description: To the Editor: The price comparisons for train coach and sleeper service in the Practical Traveler are a bit scary -- but not when compared with airline first class or business class rates. As far as passenger comfort goes (unless the passenger is three feet tall and weighs less than 60 pounds), train travel of any type has it all over airline coach class. Sleeper accommodations are far superior to first or any other airline class.

title: Space Aged
description: John Glenn got elected to the Senate on the basis of his space flight. Now he has been chosen by NASA for the mission in October on the basis of his Senate seniority and retirement. He may not have said one word to President Clinton and Vice President Gore about another flight, but such details ignore the nuances of Washington life. Far more important is what we all saw Glenn accomplish for the White House during Senator Thompson's hearings on campaign finance. Remarkable performance!

title: Orvieto, Above and Below Ground

Renaissance palaces and medieval basilicas crowd to the rim of La Rupe, the 165-foot tufa massif on which the town perches. Although Orvieto is on the main road between Rome and Florence, the strong currents of history at the foot of the mesa have rarely reached the summit. Kings and overlords, popes and the Medici ruled Orvieto only fitfully, and left the town's self-reliant island mentality intact.

But in fact, it is a century-old mystery that Sandra Anagnostakis, a scientist at the Agricultural Experiment Station, is slowly unraveling in the laboratory and forests. title: Two Shows: Frescoes and Landscapes

One example is this pretty hamlet with a waterfront that, once a port of call for sidewheelers and cargo boats working the Hudson River, is now ye olde mini-mall, complete with storefront galleries exhibiting contemporary art. Gentrification's incongruities are mild when compared with those perpetrated by the founding Surrealists but they are nonetheless significant for showing how the philosophy of the irrational, once cause for outrage, has become a part of daily life.

title: PULSE; Sandal Chase

The wooden-heel sandal, a luxury take on the classic Dr. Scholl's, came out this season in black, gold, maroon and natural for $195 at Hermes boutiques. By now, they're virtually sold out. But hopeful shoppers still drop by the store at 57th Street (Fifth Avenue) to scoop up a returned pair or dial Hermes shops from California to Paris. Ellen Niven, Hermes's publicity director, suggests calling the Hermes help line, (800) 441-4488, to track down Quebrars ''in whatever corner of the world they're left,'' she said.

title: Going Up?
description: A THIN, blue-eyed girl of 13 with curly light brown hair in a school uniform, I drew curious looks as I spoke in Japanese with my host family on the fifth stage of Mount Fuji. I was the the only person around without hiking clothes. My older brother, Eric, was the rock climber in the family back home in Great Falls, Va., and had always made fun of my lack of athletic prowess. The quizzical glances of the Japanese probably mirrored my own thought: What was I doing trying to climb Fuji?

Our pets are no different, though minus a thumb, they are forced to test all possibilities directly: object to mouth.

title: New Dialing System For Italian Telephones
description: Revolutions come in all sizes. In Italy, June 19 marked a mini-revolution in the national telephone system. People calling from abroad must now dial the country code (39), then a 0 in front of the old city area code. Someone calling Venice from New York, for example, must dial 011-39-041 and then the local number. Even telephone calls made within a city must now be prefaced by that city's area code. A Roman calling another Rome number must dial 06 before the local number. The system has been introduced to allow for the addition of 140 million telephone numbers.

title: On the Wings Of Angels
description: EVERY year large groups of people come to the southern Italian hill town of Loreto on foot, though it is a long and wearing climb, even if you start only from the plain below. But, no doubt, it is a dramatic approach. Arriving more comfortably by car, you still have to maneuver the curving road that makes the same ascent in long loops of asphalt, as you see the town above you appear and disappear in the high, hazy distance: a ruddy agglomeration with a tower or two rising into the broad sky of the Marches -- the Adriatic region of Italy that extends from the Veneto southward to Apulia. This is a part of Italy that, even in our accelerated, knowledge-greedy age, is not well known; and for those travelers who love it, it remains a treasured private place, so rich in beauty and art that there is always something more to see, some hidden corner remaining to be explored.

Peggy Gallagher, whose collection of newborn and ''retired'' Beanies is valued at more than $300,000, agrees. ''The world has gone Beanie mad,'' she laments. The women may have a point. Now that the PVC-pellet-filled pets are selling on the secondary market for up to 1,000 times their original retail prices, there has been an unprecedented outbreak of noir-shaded Beanie crime -- counterfeiting, Internet fraud, fencing schemes, even violent robberies. Here's a look.

The film, about a mathematician who unlocks the secret of the stock market, is only one piece of an unlikely pi trend. ''The Joy of Pi,'' a book by David Blatner (Walker & Company, 1997) includes a history of attempts to calculate the infinite number (3.14159265 etc.), pi jokes and odd factoids. For instance, Mr. Spock of ''Star Trek'' once foiled an evil computer by ordering it to ''compute to the last digit the value of pi.''

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Downsized All the Way
description: Terms like ''layoff'' and ''downsizing'' have become so common they have lost their power to alarm. CLOSING: The Life and Death of an American Factory (Double Take/Norton, $27.50) restores their emotional impact. Bill Bamberger, a photographer, and Cathy N. Davidson, a professor of English at Duke University, chronicle the final months of the White Furniture Company in Mebane, N.C. A family-owned business, White was established in 1881, bought out in a hostile takeover by a manufacturing corporation in 1985, and shut down in 1993. With piercing, candid photographs, Bamberger documents the dismantling of the factory and its workers' livelihoods. The photographs capture the shock, uncertainty and despair of what Davidson calls the ''human spirit . . . downsized.'' While the images record the factory's death, they are also vibrant reminders of its life. Bamberger preserves the spirit of its employees and their pride in their craft. Davidson's eloquent text describes, in concise, vivid detail, the stories of five employees who ''represent a cross section of the American work force.'' In an unflinchingly fair analysis, she writes of their independence and fulfillment at White, but resists the temptation to idealize the factory and denounce the corporate players behind the buyout and the closing. Hard-edged and realistic, ''Closing'' offers no sugar-coated solutions. Instead, in using White's as a microcosm of what is wrong with the American economy, it issues a bold challenge to ''business as usual.'' Stephanie Sun

It's a shellac finish that's applied by rubbing the shellac onto the wood by hand. The technique is laborious and takes time and practice to master. Nevertheless it is an essential technique for anyone who wants to recreate the look of authentic period furniture.

title: When Children Are Soldiers
description: Last month guerrilla soldiers kidnapped 19 grade-school children from the northern Uganda city of Gulu to join the Lord's Resistance Army. Most have since escaped. But the army, which is waging a campaign against Uganda with the backing of Sudan, has already abducted more than 8,000 children to use as soldiers, most under 16. Children who have escaped say they were forced to torture and kill one another. Once psychologically broken, they are used as sex slaves for other soldiers or become vicious fighters themselves.

title: Word & Image; When Is Private Pain a Public Good?
description: In media law, it is often a case of give me liberty or give me space. Often, the freedom of the media turns out to rob some citizens of privacy, and the edification of a mass audience requires the mortification of some individuals. The instruments of intrusion grow more powerful in every decade, but the tension between liberty and privacy persists unchanged.

title: Crossing the Border to the Caramoor Festival
description: THE Caramoor Festival, just across the state border in Katonah, N.Y., has long been a favorite destination for Connecticut music lovers. ''Musical enrichment and enlightenment stem from our wish for a better world,'' said the Caramoor artistic director, Peter Oundjian. ''The spiritual nourishment of music is vital to our civilization. At Caramoor we celebrate human creativity and spontaneity at every performance.'' The ambiance -- beautiful gardens and the European elegance of the Spanish Courtyard and Venetian Theater -- doesn't hurt either.

title: Intern Invasions: Survivors' Tales
description: There's a good deal to be said for internships. Some say they give the intern a head start on a permanent job. Then again, some interns, working for meager or no wages, say they are a head start on slavery. Women complain that they clean the office fridge and answer the phones while their male counterparts receive genuine training. And some bosses, who paid their dues doing menial jobs when they were interns and still aren't afraid to get their hands dirty, wonder about a new generation that looks askance at putting fresh paper into a fax machine.

title: Dance Outdoors at Wave Hill

For the last eight summers, though, a series of outdoor dance programs have been designed to take advantage of that natural beauty. ''It's an in-town festival with out-of-town ambiance,'' Ann Carlson, the artist-in-residence, said. ''We will be creating evocative new experiences for the Wave Hill audience, showcasing exciting new works, and using newly commissioned scores.''

Using the toilet on the bus is difficult and can be dangerous or unsanitary. The ''rest'' stops between Minneapolis and Chicago were limited to five minutes. Requests to use the station rest room were refused because of the ''time limits of the schedule.''

title: Keepers of a Flame That Once Burned for Russia
description: IT is one of the most unforgettable sequences in film history: As the Czar's soldiers try to crush a sailors' rebellion in the seaport city of Odessa in prerevolutionary Russia, a young mother pushing a baby carriage tries to flee and is shot. As she collapses, she loses her grip on the carriage and it rolls down flights of stairs leading to the sea. Step by step, frame by terrifying frame, the camera follows the carriage as it picks up speed amid jackbooted soldiers, slain men and frantic women and children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLANCY, CLEO GARIS
description: CLANCY-Cleo Garis. Of Key Largo, FL, formerly of Short Hills and Spring Lake, New Jersey, on June 28, 1998. She was born in Newark, New Jersey, on June 30, 1905 the daughter of the late Lillian M. and Howard R. Garis who were authors of numerous children's books including early Tom Swift & Bobbsey Twins books. Howard Garis was also the creator of The Uncle Wiggly stories which he began shortly after the turn of the century & continued to write until his death in 1962. Mrs. Clancy was also preceded in death by her brother, Roger C. Garis. She & the late John J. Clancy were married in 1928. John Clancy practiced law in New Jersey for over fifty years until his death in 1979. He served as a Commissioner of The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and at the time of his death was Chairman of Carteret Savings. Mrs. Clancy was a graduate of St. Vincent's Academy and The Faucett School of Fine Arts, and was herself the author of several children's books. She is survived by her daughter and son-in-law, Carroll and Sheldon Brooks of Key Largo, Florida. Interment will be in Spring Lake, NJ. Or so ruled Justice Alice Schlesinger of State Supreme Court, who handed down a decision on June 26 in a bitter dispute after a dozen trees were felled in the park four years ago.

title: Lineage of a Legend: Two German Troupes Return to New York
description: WHEN John Cranko, the artistic director of the Wurttemberg State Theater Ballet, took his company to New York in 1969, he warned his dancers, ''Don't unpack your bags until after the first-night reviews.'' But the critics raved and the company returned to Germany triumphant. From then on it would be known as the Stuttgart Ballet, a named bestowed by the dance critic Clive Barnes, and today ballet companies everywhere aspire to its success.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAVES, MARILYN PRESTON
description: GRAVES-Marilyn Preston. Died on July 3, 1998 in Fairfield, CT after a long respiratory illness. Beloved daughter of the late Helen Mitchell Graves and the late Duncan Graves. A life-long New Yorker, Marilyn devoted 44 years of her life as a volunteer at The New York Hospital, and more than 20 years as a volunteer at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, first by helping patients in several clinics and then by dedicating her life to New York Hospital's Patients' Library, which was named for her late twin sister, Helen Mitchell Graves. She was honored for her outstanding volunteer accomplishments by New York City Mayors Lindsay and Beame, as well as, by the United Hospital Fund. She was an active volunteer for many years in the Junior League of New York and was a long-time member of the Colonial Dames in the State of New York and the Daughters of the Cincinnati. Her immediate survivors include her cousins, Augustus W. Kelley III and his children, Christina Gilmartin, Corrine Wagner and Marc W. Kelley, and by Reginald H. Fullerton, Jr., and Nan Fullerton Shupe. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, July 23, at 11 AM at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 661 Old Post Rd., Fairfield, CT. title: The War Between the States ... and Washington
description: Some people play favorites with the Bill of Rights. The favorite amendment of gangsters is the fifth (no self-incrimination), of liberals the first (free speech), of drug dealers the fourth (no unauthorized search), of gun fondlers the second (to bear arms). Now, many people have a new favorite, the long-neglected 10th (powers not specifically assigned to Washington are reserved to the states). As recently as 1985, when the Supreme Court reversed one of its rare decisions based on the amendment (Garcia canceling Usery), the 10th was being called a dead letter. Certainly few people tried to ''take the 10th'' the way gangsters and fellow travelers ''took the fifth.''

title: Style; Can't Commit
description: Let's say you buy a pair of shoes, wear them once and realize they're the wrong size. Now you're angry at yourself, that you got so seduced by that fetching little ruffle and the shape of the heel and so caught up in your fantasies of where you would wear them and of that guy you flirt with sometimes suddenly falling prostrate at your feet, that you failed to notice that they pinched your toes. And the worst of it is, you're out 400 bucks (you buy your shoes at Manolo Blahnik), which would have paid the phone bill. You get over it. The shoes sit in their box at the bottom of your closet, where you come upon them twice a year, until eventually you give them away to a friend. End of story. Or you spring for a cocktail dress because you've got a party looming on the horizon, and the first time you wear it, you catch sight of yourself in a mirror and think, Gee, that woman looks fat, and then you realize that that woman is you. Not good. You're angry with yourself, but, again, not for long. The dress hangs forlornly in the place where you store your clothes for the off-season, until two years later you consign it to a thrift shop and recoup a fourth of your original investment, which pays the phone bill.

description: On this Independence Day weekend, it is fitting and timely to ask: Who coined the name United States of America?

title: Wildfires Still Raging in Florida, Though Some Are Now Contained
description: For the last three weeks, George Colombis has left the Volusia County Correctional Facility to work 10-hour shifts around the perimeter of wildfires. Today, he and a crew of 20 other inmates raked and shoveled, turning the ground over in the back woods of an expensive housing complex here to make sure a forest that steamed like a boiling pot did not erupt in flames again.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on June 21 about a man who was killed after brandishing guns at police officers outside a station house misidentified the state for Shelby, where the incident occurred. It was North Carolina, not South Carolina.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPP, HILDE
description: RAPP-Hilde. On July 3, 1998. Beloved sister of Martha Stein. Loving aunt and dear friend. She will be profoundly missed. Service Sunday, 12:15PM, ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

title: A Tentative Farewell to the Bridgeport Barriers
description: BY the time the city decided in 1993 to put up 38 concrete street barriers to cut off easy in-and-out access by suburbanites from Interstate 95 to notorious drug dealing areas, Bridgeport had become a national symbol of urban violence and decay.

title: At Vanguard, It's Full Speed Ahead
description: To hear John J. Brennan tell it, there's really nothing much afoot at the Vanguard Group, the giant fund company he heads.

title: The Courts' Great Expediter; A Social Worker for Hire Solves Problems With Flair
description: Hillel Bodek hurtled through the interstices of 100 Centre Street, the voluminous State Supreme Court building in Manhattan where criminal cases are heard, muttering to himself his signature refrains, ''It is what it is'' and ''What can I tell you.'' Even at his fleet pace, he never gets far before someone flags him down.

title: Piazza Hurt in Mets' Latest Loss
description: One long swing of the bat overshadowed anything else that happened on the field during the Mets' 4-1 loss to the Atlanta Braves tonight.

title: The World: Historical Amnesia; Happy 4th of July, Canada!
description: IT'S been fairly well demonstrated that Americans aren't too swift when it comes to their own history -- as, for example, when surveys show that most students can't place the Civil War in the right century. Last week came striking new evidence that Canada has historical amnesia too.

title: Schools for Sale
description: As a former teacher in a Mississippi freedom school, where students were inspired to challenge and transform their segregated public schools, I find the claim of advocates that ''school choice is the civil rights struggle of this generation'' an arrogant trivialization of the struggle for racial justice of those years.

title: Making African Pop Safe for Western Ears
description: IT happens too often. An African rock band comes to New York and plays a brilliant set, turning listeners into dancers with complex, scintillating grooves that billow and tickle and drive. Afterward, full of anticipation, new fans track down the band's latest album, only to find that it doesn't sound anything like what the band played on stage.

title: At Lamb's Club, a Long-Running, Real-Life Drama
description: As many good dramas do, this tale blends love, loss and art, and involves a man and a woman. And, oh yes, one gloriously assembled pile of bricks.

title: Americans Advance To Finals of Five Events
description: The fireworks at the end of yesterday's fourth-round elimination heats at Henley-on-the-Thames had a rocket's red glare as American crews advanced to the finals in five events at the Henley Royal Regatta, with a semifinal still to come this morning in a sixth.

title: Putting Pain Aside, Italian Sailor Is to Go Solo
description: An accident at sea has placed a melancholy grip on Giovanni Soldini, the Italian solo sailor whose close friend and racing partner died three months ago. But anyone who knows Soldini, an otherwise spirited competitor, expects him to return with gusto to ocean racing today.

title: In Black, And No Place To Hide
description: IT was a female disaster of the first order, up there with meeting someone really cute and realizing you have lipstick on your front teeth. Invited to the Museum of Modern Art's ''Party in the Garden,'' one of the last blowouts on the spring black-tie calendar, I decided to try my gown on ahead of time to check the fit.

title: Vultures on the Roof, in the Trees, Around the Dog
description: Dan and Carol Ann O'Byrne sit in their breakfast nook each morning, look out at their horse paddock and the woods beyond and face mortality.

title: OUTDOORS; Climbing a Mountain Can Prove Family Fun
description: Parents feel a mixture of awe and pride watching their offspring progress from a crawl to a walk. It is one of those priceless charms of parenthood. Imagine then what I felt, tethered by a rope to my 10-year-old daughter, as I watched her meticulously advance up a near-vertical slab of granite several hundred feet above the ground. So it goes, rock climbing in New Hampshire, family style.

title: Starbucks Saved the City From a Lot of Bad Coffee
description: To the Editor:

title: Up the Creek Without a Plunger
description: WHEN the sewer backed up into my apartment, I was so deep in the labyrinth of the new computer that I might not have noticed the house on fire. I was trying to transfer the copy of a document from the hard drive to a disk. On my friendly old Mac, that was easy, fun, just drag and click. On this refrigerator of a Dell with Windows 95, it was impossible.

title: Bill to Aid Small Airlines in New York Divides Legislators
description: On the surface, the two problems seem about as related as toothaches and hangnails: the budget-busting cost of flying on business out of New York's upstate cities, and the nerve-jangling roar of jets using La Guardia and Kennedy Airports in Queens.

title: School Principals Still Seeking a Little Respect, and a Contract
description: For more than two years, members of the union representing New York City's principals and assistant principals have worked under an expired contract. But getting the attention of Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, let alone winning the sympathy of anyone outside the school system, has proven no easy task.

title: China and Taiwan Are Warming to Each Other
description: To the Editor:

title: PULSE; For a Snip And a Snack
description: ''One part salon, one part cafe, one part cocktail lounge.'' That's the official description of Tonic, a mixture of unisex hair salon and cafe, which opened six months ago at 107 Norfolk Street, between Delancey and Rivington Streets. It is the latest consumer space turned into a place to hang out, like gym restaurants and bookstore-coffee bars. John Sarefield, an owner of Tonic, explained the logic of making a salon the first and last destination of an evening. ''You go to a salon or a cafe to gossip,'' he said. ''You go to a salon to look good, then to a cafe to be seen.''

title: 4 Eagles May Finally Land
description: A battle royal of words and news releases over four bronze eagles that the city removed from Fort Greene Park 36 years ago because of concerns about vandalism appeared to end last week when the Brooklyn Borough President extended an olive branch to the city's Parks Commissioner.

title: A Soprano's Life Near the Top
description: SOME performing artists, though they earn the deep respect of colleagues and enjoy productive careers, never quite reach the top in terms of recognition, clout with managers and performance opportunities. Sometimes the reasons reflect well on an artist's integrity: a lack of flashiness; an unwillingness to compromise artistic standards; an attraction to more challenging repertory. The reason may simply be the presence of more marketable artists on the scene. In some cases, it's just bad luck.

title: June 28-July 4; Arson in Ulster
description: A rash of arson in Northern Ireland provided a reminder of the depth of divisions there despite a historic peace agreement signed in April. There were 10 arson attacks on Catholic churches followed by attacks on Protestant institutions in apparent reprisal.

title: European Beaches Get Yearly Report Card
description: The European Commission's annual beach report -- always a year behind -- has just been published, providing information about bathing conditions at European beaches in 1997. Beaches are organized in categories that reflect the levels of chemical and biological pollutants in the water: high quality, minimum quality or substandard quality. In some cases beaches remain unrated for lack of information.

title: June 28-July 4; No Longer Unknown
description: Fourteen years ago, President Ronald Reagan placed the remains of an unidentified American killed in Vietnam into the Tomb of the Unknowns at Arlington National Cemetery. But now, the Pentagon announced, new genetic tests have made his identity known.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: The Endeavor in Norwalk

title: Gorging On a Diet Of Deals
description: THEY are serial acquirers -- companies that play Pac-Man by gobbling up other companies, paying for the purchases with high-priced stock. It's a cycle that feeds voraciously on itself: The more a company acquires, the higher the stock price, fueling even more acquisitions.

title: Investors Bet on Revival for Troubled Newark
description: Real estate investors hungry for new and cheaper territory have begun placing bets on downtown Newark, buying up a dozen buildings over the last 18 months in an early sign that the fortunes of New Jersey's largest city may be reversing after decades of decline.

title: With Just a Bit of Gloating, New Jersey Raises Its Flag on Ellis Island
description: Like the men on the moon 30 years ago and Christopher Columbus before them, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey laid symbolic claim to a chunk of land yesterday by raising their state's flag on a piece of Ellis Island that can no longer be called a part of New York.

description: To the Editor:

description: GOLDSTEIN-Jacob (Jack). Son of the late Louis and Mary. Brother of the late Samuel and Meyer. Previously of Yonkers, New York. Died in Phoenix, AZ., on June 29, 1998. Buried in CA., July 2, 1998. Survived by wife Ada, sons Louis J. and Martin H., grandchildren, nieces and nephews.

title: Coach Isn't Problem
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Crime
description: A strange dawn bathes the bayou waters of New Iberia, La., in a blood red light, prefiguring the violent events of James Lee Burke's new Dave Robicheaux mystery, SUNSET LIMITED (Doubleday, $24.95). Viewing certain parish disruptions in this lurid light, the Cajun detective finds good cause to be spooked when a clumsy thief called Cool Breeze runs afoul of New Orleans mobsters, when two bully boys shoot a rapist and dump his body in the swamp, and when the snooty Terrebonne family opens its plantation home to a company of filmmakers.

title: SHOPPING WITH: Yeohlee; It's Not Necessary To Be Japanese At Yaohan Plaza
description: BADTZ MARU pops up everywhere at Yaohan Plaza, the riverfront Japanese mall in Edgewater, N.J. His pudgy cartoon features glower on miniaturized note pads and canvas backpacks, and he puffs himself up importantly on a child's lunch box, where he caught the eye of Yeohlee Teng, the Malaysian-born New York designer, who goes professionally by her first name only.

title: Foiling a Pessimist
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 2d Firefighter Dies, 1 Month After Brooklyn House Fire
description: Capt. Scott LaPiedra, the New York City firefighter who had been unconscious and struggling for his life for nearly a month after being engulfed in an inferno in a Brooklyn fire, died last night at Jacobi Medical Center in the Bronx.

title: Tammy Miles, Milton Brown
description: Tammy Melitta Miles, the daughter of Janet and George L. Miles Jr. of Pittsburgh, was married on Friday to Milton Brown, a son of Mildred and Terryl Brown of the Bronx. The Rev. J. Michael Sanders performed the ceremony at the Fountain Baptist Church in Summit, N.J.

title: Crusade Saves The House of Horace Greeley
description: HORACE GREELEY, one of the great figures of the 19th century and Chappaqua's favorite son, was a man of vision. But it is doubtful that his progressive views included foreseeing his beloved house here being chopped up into luxury rental apartments.

title: Ellen Passloff, Mark Thompson
description: Dr. Ellen Simone Passloff, the daughter of Marina Passloff and Dr. A. Stephen Passloff of New York, is to be married this evening to Dr. Mark Alan Thompson, a son of Laura and Paul Thompson of Minneapolis. Rabbi Ted Falcon is to officiate at the Woodmark Hotel in Kirkland, Wash.

title: The World: Searching for Tibet; The Shangri-La That Never Was
description: IN 1888 an American diplomat-turned-adventurer named William Woodville Rockhill set out to explore Tibet, a territory he described in his journal as ''a very imperfectly known portion of the Chinese Empire.'' It still is.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Tours by Trolley

title: In the Nation's Capital, a Contest Makes a Case for the Arts
description: THE tunnel that runs between the United States Capitol and the Cannon House Office Building is one of Washington's corridors of power. But by itself, it isn't much to look at.

title: Valet Parking Arrives At Newark Airport
description: Newark International Airport has 2,300 new parking spaces, including 800 with valet service.

title: INSIDE
description: Security Tightened in Ulster

title: Arizona Forest Plays Host to a Different Kind of Family Reunion
description: Down a dusty, rocky trail and through a knot of pine trees, past a naked guy chewing leaves, a fully clothed Christian choir and a retired Jewish pie thrower, is the meadow where the Rainbow Family is holding its 27th annual gathering to party and pray for peace.

title: Ideas & Trends: Defining Disability; AIDS Virus Case Opens Door for Infertile
description: A40-YEAR-OLD woman struggling to conceive a baby is told by her doctor that the quality of her eggs is poor and the lining of her uterus doesn't replenish itself well enough to sustain a pregnancy. Is she fairly average, or is she disabled?

title: Hem and Him
description: A yard wide and a few yards long, the sarong and its variants have served as everyday wear for men since the days of ancient Egypt. Wrapped and tied around the waist, it was the uniform of many Pacific islands, for women as well as men, until this century. Western men have achieved a similar effect with bath towels. Last weekend, at the Gay and Lesbian Pride March, the sarong appeared on a few experimenters in leisure wear, teamed with T-shirts, vests or a chiseled torso.

title: Sick Aloft
description: To the Editor: In reference to ''Airlines Fight Heart Attacks Aloft'' (June 7), I get called almost once in every flight to see patients with urgent problems. I am pleased to hear that some airlines are adding expensive equipment to fight heart attacks. How about placing in the ''first aid kits'' some working stethoscopes and sphygmomanometers and replacing used medications? It is frustrating to be called to attend to an emergency in a flight only to find inadequate equipment and supplies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOFFERMAN, FRIEDA
description: SOFFERMAN - Frieda. Loving wife of Milton (deceased), beloved mother of Lenore and David, and cherished grandmother of Joel, Jeffrey and Rhonda. Passed away on July 2, 1998.

title: Coloring the Shade With Unfamiliar Plants
description: MANY shade gardens demonstrate the popular misconception that if you don't have hostas or impatiens, you can't have color after trees leaf out. And yet, if you look closely when you walk through native woodlands, you are bound to see colorful splashes of flowers, foliage and berries scattered throughout the forest greenery from summer well into fall.

title: A Business of Chronicling Lives on Videos
description: RECOLLECTIONS, shoe boxes crammed with photographs, reels of home movies and corporate artifacts are all raw material to David Fiderer, president of Video Memoirs in Dobbs Ferry. He founded the company to produce biographies and memoirs for individuals and corporations on videotape and CD-ROM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHILD, MALCOLM
description: CHILD-Malcolm. Died in Miami, FL, on June 28, after a respiratory illness. Born in NYC on June 12, 1917, Mr. Child worked in radio broadcasting as an announcer, producer and interviewer for WBBC and WEVD and was a classical music announcer for WQXR. He wrote and produced records for children, including ''Herman Ermine in Rabbit Town,'' ''Kitchen Music,'' and ''Beethoven for Young People.'' He wrote five books on baseball: ''How to Play Big Leauge Baseball,'' ''Cathching,'' ''Hitting,'' ''Fielding'' and ''Pitching,'' and in the 1950's, established the American Baseball Academy which sponsored an after-school adtivities program for teens manned by volunteers from the NY Yankees. Mr. Child is survived by his son Josh of Dillon, CO, his daughter Lisa of Revere, MA, and six grandchildren.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Developers Are on the March to Rural Manorville
description: THIS rural corner of the Town of Brookhaven still seems far removed from the hectic pace of development that has enveloped most of western Long Island. Thick pine forests line winding country roads and tree nurseries flourish alongside fields of vegetable crops.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENNINGS, JOHN QUINCEY
description: JENNINGS-John Quincey. Passed away June 26, 1998 at age 92. He retired from Singer and lived most of his life in New York City. He moved to New Braunfels, TX to be closer to his family. The family suggest memorials be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: An 80-Foot Mural Becomes a Bridge to the Future
description: IT was an ordinary stretch of urban road, a nondescript railroad bridge leading to the main business district here.

title: Avoiding Some Bumps Along the Sector Road
description: SECTOR funds, which concentrate their holdings in particular industries, are notoriously volatile. Investing in one can result in a home run or a strikeout.

title: Q&A/Dr. Jeffrey A. Lederman; How to Travel and Maintain Good Health
description: GETTING sick is no fun at any time, but getting sick in a foreign country at best ruins an expected good time and at worst leads to serious problems. Whether the concern is diarrhea, mosquitoes or a chronic medical problem, travelers can take steps to reduce the chance that they will encounter major medical problems far from home.

title: Books of Knowledge
description: ROUTLEDGE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF PHILOSOPHY Edward Craig, general editor. 10 volumes. 8,680 pp. New York: Routledge. $2,495.

title: As Apple Pie as Tail Fins and Burning Rubber; Cadillac DeVille: Lost Generations
description: AFTER decades in which Cadillac represented the epitome of American luxury cars, it plans to sell its first truck this fall, a sport utility vehicle akin to the Chevrolet Tahoe and GMC Yukon. Cadillac dealers are overjoyed. At last they will have something for a hot part of the market.

title: Not Just for Gay Men
description: To the Editor:

title: Sarah Smith, David Yezzi
description: Sarah Harrison Smith and David Dalton Yezzi were married yesterday in Brooklin, Me., at the home of the bride's mother, Marlis de Greve Smith. The Rev. George C. McCormick, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Less Than Meets the Eye?
description: THE second quarter was pretty rocky for equity managers, but not for Investment Advisers Inc. of Minneapolis and two of its previously obscure and undistinguished mutual funds.

title: Aram Glorig, 92, Authority On the Ear and Its Disorders
description: Aram Glorig, a leading expert on the effects of noise in the workplace whose work helped untold numbers of people with deafness or hearing loss, died on June 22 at the South Coast Medical Center in San Clemente, Calif. He was 92 and lived in San Clemente.

title: Who Are We? A Book of Answers
description: THE latest edition of Westchester's Databook is full of useful information, including facts not only about the county's government, its labor force, its infrastructure and taxes but also about many little-known and sometimes colorful statistical details.

title: The Sheff Ruling, Two Years Later
description: TWO years ago, the state's Supreme Court ruled that the de facto racial segregation of Hartford's public schools was unconstitutional and ordered the governor and the legislature to find a remedy. Since then, says Wesley Horton, one of the lawyers for the plaintiffs in the desegregation case known as Sheff v. O'Neill, Hartford's schools have grown even more racially unbalanced.

title: June 28-July 4; The Verdict: Suicide
description: Slavko Dokmanovic, 48, was approaching the end of his case before the United Nations tribunal on war crimes in the Balkans. A former Mayor of Vukovar, Croatia, he was charged with helping Serb soldiers organize a 1991 massacre of more than 200 Croats. . His verdict was due on July 7. But Mr. Dokmanovic's body was found hanging from a door hinge in his cell early Monday morning. The case is now closed. MARLISE SIMONS

title: Say Hay
description: When the partner of the San Francisco writer Armistead Maupin first heard of Hay-on-Wye, he shouted, ''And hold the mayo!'' He was not to know that Arthur Miller had made the same joke years ago. Miller, when first invited to go there, quipped: ''Hay-on-Wye? Is that some kind of sandwich?''

title: Sports of The Times; Lone Fan in Provence Can't Help the Italians
description: DON'T twitch, my wife warned me. Was it that obvious? My legs were jerking under the table, but I thought I was controlling my arms and face.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMSON, SAMUEL
description: ABRAMSON-Samuel. Cherished and beloved husband of almost fifty years to Jeanne (nee Quint). Devoted and respected father of Radine and Bill Spier, Ellis and Helene Abramson. Adored grandfather of Rosalyn, David, Michael and Jason; step-grandfather to Jonathan Spier, Debby and Bruce Prince, Evan and Malka Spier; and G.G. Sam to Zev and Benjamin. Brother of Dr. David A. Abramson. A most honored brother-inlaw, uncle and great-uncle. Sam, a long-time educator in New York City, was a gentle soul whose compassion, humor & love of music he shared with all who knew him. He will be deeply missed.

title: Margaret Liu And Paul Tropp
description: Margaret Kotin Liu, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Liu of Fremont, Calif., was married on Thursday to Paul David Tropp, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton E. Tropp of Manhasset Hills, N.Y. Rabbi A. Allen Block officiated at Temple Emanuel in New Hyde Park, N.Y.
