description: Armageddon

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIEL, JOHN J., M.D.
description: PIEL-John J., M.D. Died on June 26th, peacefully at home in San Francisco, age 81. Born Woodmere, Long Island; son of the late William and Loretto Scott Piel; brother of William, Mary Peil Ward (the late), Rita Piel Brown, Gerard and David J.; husband of Carolyn Forman Piel, M.D., father of John J. Piel Jr., Mary Piel Hubbard, Elizabeth & William Scott Piel. Graduate of the College and Medical School of Stanford University, Captain U.S. Army Medical Corps. In practice of pediatrics 50 years in San Francisco; a founder of the American Adolescent Society and of the University High School (San Francisco); patron of San Francisco Symphony, Opera and Ballet and of Ashland Shakespeare Festival in Oregon. Memorial Service to be held on July 7, 5:00 P.M., St. Francis Yacht Club, San Francisco. In lieu of flowers, family requests gifts to John J. Piel, M.D. Scholarship Fund, Stanford University, Development Department, 301 Encina Hall, Stanford, CA. 94305.

title: Bolts From On High
description: Peak lightning season starts about now in Florida, which is also a peak lightning state. ''In Florida you're much, much more likely to be hit by lightning than win the lottery,'' says Kevin Yeaton, 43, head of the Florida chapter of a group with the self-explanatory name Lightning Strike and Electric Shock Survivors International. This is particularly so in the Tampa-St. Petersburg area, where Yeaton lives. In 1996, 105 Floridians and visitors were hit by lightning; 96 survived.

title: Surf and Turf in a Celebrity's New Outpost
description: B. SMITH'S is a picture-perfect East End restaurant: a strikingly beautiful place with outside waterfront dining. Additionally, there is the sparkle of a celebrity owner who just might attract other famous faces.

title: June 28-July 4; A Rebuke and Setback For Starr's Inquiry
description: In a decision that surprised even the defendants, a Federal judge decided that the Whitewater prosecutor, Kenneth W. Starr, went too far when he indicted Webster L. Hubbell, his wife and two tax advisers on tax evasion charges.

title: Looks Like a Fox, Costs Around $1,000
description: Anyori Hernandez, 22, was walking on Houston Street when a beautiful twosome turned his head. ''What kind of dogs are they?'' he asked, offering his palm to a wet nose. ''They look like foxes. Where would you purchase a dog like this?''

title: Toxic
description: Long before Secretary of the Interior Bruce Babbitt decided to pursue a career in government, he was a devoted student of the bedrock upon which all government is built. Not the laws or principles. The actual rock. Babbitt has always been drawn to rocks. In fact, years before he earned his geology degree at the University of Notre Dame and then went on to graduate studies in the newly emerging field of plate tectonics at the University of Newcastle in England, he was spending the better part of his childhood roaming the Grand Canyon hard by his family's ranch in northern Arizona, looking for fossils and dinosaur tracks, trying to trace in the canyon's walls the striations of time.

title: LONG, Strange Trip
description: Last summer, Bob DeBris, a photographer, loaded up his truck and drove from California to Roswell, N.M. His mission? To document a weeklong festival honoring the golden anniversary of the Roswell Incident, a famous alleged alien crash landing in July 1947. DeBris took his time getting there, pulling off the highway for any attraction that remotely said ''space,'' including the Space Age Lodge in Gila Bend, Ariz., and the burial place of Ham the astrochimp in Alamogordo, N.M. Along the way, he met U.F.O. researchers, people in alien garb (like the ''Yellow Foam Alien'' spotted at a Roswell bash, pictured right), bushy-haired surfers, cowgirls and more. Among the 35 photos from his trip -- now on display at the Roswell Museum and Art Center -- his favorite is ''of a girl who told me simply, 'If you don't believe, just pretend.''''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPECCHI, RENATO
description: CAPECCHI-Renato. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of our friend and colleague, Renato Capecchi. His Met career spanned forty-three years and encompassed a wide variety of roles. We will remember him especially for his many fine comic interpretations, but also for his personal charm and thorough professionalism. We offer our sincerest condolences to his family and friends. Joseph Volpe, General Manager James Levine, Artistic Director

title: Unlimited-Ride Metrocards Are Hot Tickets at Token Booths
description: The line at the Third Street entrance to the West Fourth Street subway station at 12:01 A.M. yesterday was not as long as it might have been if the Metropolitan Transportation Authority were selling, say, Spice Girls tickets. In fact, it consisted of exactly one person, Tony Triche.

title: Life as a Hooter Girl
description: FOR the price of a hamburger or a glass of beer, patrons can't touch, but they can look at, talk to or take pictures of any of the 25 waitresses at Hooters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALESKOVSKY, EMMA G. CLARK
description: ALESKOVSKY-Emma G. Clark. Age 84. Emma G. Clark Aleskovsky will be honored during a memorial service at Hickory Hill Community House on Hickory Hill La, Tappan, N.Y. at 2PM on July 12, 1998. She worked as a business teacher, reporter, community news editor and tailor. She was also an active member of the Democratic Party, and, late in life, acted as a senior citizen spokesperson. In New York, she worked under the name of Pat Clark for the experimental city newspaper, PM. She also worked in a variety of capacities for a local weekly, The Rockland Independent. She was the beloved wife of the late Nathan Aleskovsky, and is survived by her three children Annie Zeybekoglu of Boston, Ruth Aleskovsky-Haiblum of New York City and Paul Aleskovsky of Florida, and their spouses and four grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Tappan Public Library, Tappan, N.Y.

title: Sharon Gordon, Brian Ferber
description: Sharon Lisa Gordon, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Eric M. Gordon of West Bloomfield, Mich., is to be married this evening to Brian Adam Ferber, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan I. Ferber of East Brunswick, N.J. Rabbi Milton Arm is to perform the ceremony at Adat Shalom Synagogue in Farmington Hills, Mich.

description: With posters reading ''The Lands of the Orthodox Are for Its Real Owners'' and ''Stop the Liquidation of Our Church Property,'' about 200 Orthodox Christian Palestinians protested today at the Jaffa Gate to the Old City, thereby demonstrating yet another aspect of the ancient and complex struggle for the Holy City.

description: HOLDING their noses, two model-pretty teen-age girls in bikinis shot down the matching Shotgun Slides and into the air before crashing into the water. They bobbed up to the surface, and it didn't matter that they suddenly looked like half-drowned rats, with their long hair tangled over their faces. They shoved the matted tresses back, gasping -- and laughing wildly.

description: SCHREIBER-Jane. On June 30, of Kingwood, Texas; formerly of Jericho, N.Y. Mother of Paul and Debbie Schreiber, Peter and Jean Schreiber; Grandmother of Wendy, Susan and Steven Schreiber.

description: Lisa Loveys Lindstrom, a daughter of Lee D. Lindstrom of Morristown, N.J., and the late Lillian L. Lindstrom, was married yesterday to Christopher Raymond Conroy, a son of Katharine and John Conroy of New Rochelle, N.Y. The Rev. Kerry Stoltzfus, an uncle of the bride and a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony with Msgr. John J. Mescall at the Presbyterian Church in Morristown.

title: Far From Home
description: Based on the Lederer-Burdick novel about an idealistic diplomat trapped in a dangerous Asian political upheaval, THE UGLY AMERICAN (1963) offered a challenging central role for Marlon Brando (above right, with Aruthur Hill), who made the most of it with a superbly memborable protrayal. The gleaming, exotic tapestry is well thronged by a firm supporting cast, including Sandra Church, Eiji Okada, Pat Hingle and Mr. Hill. George H. Englund's direction keeps the plot simmering through to an uncompromising wrap-up. This is one of the better vehicles for a star whose performances now are few and far between - TUESDAY at 3 P.M. on Bravo.

title: Imperfect 10 by Hammond Spoils a Nearly Stellar Round
description: With two holes to go today in the third round of the Canon Greater Hartford Open, the veteran Donnie Hammond was leading and needed only two pars to post a course-record 61 and put him at 12 under par for the tournament.

title: A Mini-Philadelphia At Morris Arboretum
description: Train buffs and garden lovers may rub shoulders at the Morris Arboretum of the University of Pennsylvania this summer, where model trains travel through a miniature re-creation of historic Philadelphia -- all made with plant material. Large-gauge model trains traveling on tracks set throughout a scale model of the city will be on display through Oct. 4.

title: Laura Dziedzic, Christopher Cook
description: Laura Elizabeth Dziedzic and Christopher Donovan Cook, medical students at the University of Virginia in Charlottesville, are to be married this afternoon in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Dennis Keane, a Roman Catholic priest, is to officiate at the Princeton University Chapel, and the Rev. Peter Bowell, a Presbyterian minister, will take part in the ceremony.

title: Ms. Rimerman and Mr. Serota
description: Randi-Sue Rimerman, a trial lawyer for the Civil Division of the Justice Department in Washington, was married last evening to Howard Scott Serota, who teaches the fourth grade at the McLean School in Potomac, Md. Rabbi Martin Rozenberg officiated at the Crescent, a banquet hall in Bayville, N.Y.

title: Israelis Now, But Carrying On A Russian Flair For Fireworks
description: MAKING theater in Israel would seem a daunting task, what with a history more intense than any drama, a potpourri of cultures that have resisted melding and a life forever mired in crisis. Yet these are the very ingredients that Yevgeny Arye has conjured to propel his Gesher Theater to a predominant position in Israel in less than seven years, a troupe that has received raves both inside the country and beyond.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-6

title: Protests Over Closed Day-Care Site
description: THE closing of a day-care center here has prompted protests from loyal parents and supporters of the Beginnings Early Learning Center on Weaver Street, which closed on June 27 after the Mamaroneck Town Board decided not to renew the center's lease. The day-care center, which offered full-year child care for children 18 months and older from 7:30 A.M. to 6:30 P.M., had leased the town-owned space for seven years.

title: Swiped!
description: SWIPE, swipe, swipe again.

title: To the Joy of Shoppers, Green Markets Bloom
description: On a table in front of her refrigerated truck, Ethel Terry was setting out lettuce. First, the French variety, then red leaf, salad bowl and butter crunch. Next came thick bunches of radishes, fresh spinach, carrots, bok choy, rhubarb, collard greens and arugula. Then potatoes and 240 quarts of strawberries, picked fresh the night before at her family's 200-acre farm.

title: Quick Bite/Harding Township; Fresh Produce and Not-So-Humble Pies
description: The country life has suited the Wightman family just fine for 76 years. Both their home and their business are quite literally rooted in a 150-acre orchard in rural Harding Township, about five miles south of Morristown.

title: June 28-July 4; Republican Strategy Split
description: A parade of prominent Republicans, notably the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, have stepped up their criticism of homosexuality recently. These Republicans, apparently trying to energize the religiously conservative base of the party, have described homosexuality as a sin.

title: Exotic Accumulations in Miniature Spaces
description: THE 16th- and 17th-century Dutch were probably not the first Westerners to be more interested in this world than the next, but they pursued that interest with unusual energy, openness and intelligence.

title: In Trenton, a Budget and Several Changes for Drivers
description: In the last voting session before summer recess, state lawmakers took action Monday on 87 bills and resolutions, ranging from the adoption of a state budget to the designation of Grandparents Day.

title: Prime Site Rented
description: Kinko's, a store specializing in copying documents, will move into the long vacant Wallach's men store in White Plains, on the corner of Post Road and Mamaroneck Avenue, said Bill Christopher, a managing partner for Group 5 Limited, the building's owner.

title: Where Are the Editors?
description: To the Editor:

title: Emerging as a Leading Man of Supporting Actors
description: FOR the actor Will Patton, it's the end of the world. Again.

title: Clinton's Sojourn in China, Viewed From the Cookout
description: Sitting on a bench under a maple tree near Abraham Lincoln's old law office in this cornfield-hemmed Illinois capital, Janice Reese, who works on the cleaning staff at a hospital, confessed that she knew little about American diplomacy in China.

title: Sara Goldhaber, Jeremy Fiebert
description: Sara Naomi Kress Goldhaber, the daughter of Suzan Goldhaber and Dr. Alfred Goldhaber of Setauket, N.Y., is to be married this afternoon to Jeremy David Fiebert, the son of Jill and Larry Fiebert of Lansdale, Pa. Rabbi David Starr is to perform the ceremony at Young Israel of Brookline, in Brookline, Mass.

title: In America; Ending A Retail Drought
description: Big news: Last Tuesday a supermarket opened at the corner of Whalley Avenue and Orchard Street in New Haven.

title: Small Business Is Fueling Island's Growth
description: CHIEF executives of dozens of small companies around Long Island, citing the robust business climate, said they would increase their work forces by 5 percent and raise salaries by 6 percent during the next 12 months, according to a survey by KPMG Peat Marwick and Hofstra University.

title: Lives; Autoerotic
description: Let's sing a fond doo-wah for those bygone summers when cars were cars -- chromed, finned, whitewalled; with manual trannies, sofalike suspensions and iron-lunged, octane-hungry power plants that exhaled a deep, throaty rumble almost musical in its sweetness. ''Cherry'' was what we called it when the sound was especially ripe and mellow. If you were a teen-ager back then, in the 50's and 60's, a car was more than a ride. It was a passport to freedom (even if freedom meant nothing more than cruising back and forth on the same well-traveled stretch of blacktop), and it was the embodiment of sexual possibility.

title: As the Fed Points Out, History Doesn't Lie
description: Will today's easy-money atmosphere at American banks lead to hard times tomorrow?

title: Lure of Poughkeepsie: The Powerhouse Theater Productions
description: THE county is not a nurturing place for professional theater, that much is clear. ''So we're trying to get theatergoers to look north,'' said Beth Fargis-Lancaster, the executive producer of the Powerhouse Theater season here.

title: Lindsay Jewett, Daniel Sturman
description: Lindsay Spencer Jewett, a daughter of Jonathan Jewett of New York and the late Tucky Jewett, was married yesterday at her father's house in Lyme, Conn., to Daniel Franklin Sturman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Sturman of Pepper Pike, Ohio. Rabbi Steven J. Mason officiated, and Dana Colley, an Episcopal seminarian, took part in the ceremony.

title: New Transportation Chief Named
description: COUNTY EXECUTIVE Andrew J. Spano finally gave one County Legislator what he had been pushing for -- the appointment of a black person with the title of commissioner.

title: 'I'll Start With Six California Rolls . . .'
description: MAX DUNCAN hunched over a wood block covered with soy sauce and wasabi-stained rice at Tsunami restaurant on West Third Street. He slid the rice clumps -- all that remained of his 12 pieces of yellowtail tuna sushi -- onto the table and threw a napkin on top.

title: Buzzers and Bumpers
description: If winning -- or losing -- money at an old-fashioned slot machine isn't thrill enough, Resorts Casino Hotel in Atlantic City is now offering gamblers a new option: a machine that lets them play pinball while trying to hit the jackpot.

title: How the Sky Lights Up
description: It's a scene to delight the senses: the whir of a rocket catapulting through the night sky, a blinding white salute, an ear-splitting bang and finally a release of incandescent color that shoots through the heavens and then filters back to earth amid the faint aroma of sulfur. Since their creation by the Chinese some 2,000 years ago, fireworks have fascinated young and old alike, earning a place of honor at celebrations -- even births and deaths -- around the world.

title: Love Affair With the Often Difficult Daphne
description: COLLECTIONS of favorite plants can begin in all kinds of ways. Sometimes it starts with membership in a particular society specializing in one sort of plant. Or a friend or neighbor could stir enthusiasm for a specific plant group.

title: AIDS MEETING ENDS WITH LITTLE HOPE OF BREAKTHROUGH
description: The 12th World AIDS Conference ended here on Friday in a somber mood.

title: Schools for Sale
description: I am not convinced that school choice is all its proponents say it is (''Schools for Sale,'' by Michael Winerip, June 14). Yet, I would not be surprised if the small percentage of children in charter schools did get a better education than the majority of students in public schools. Take any school where there is political and administrative support, funds raised and earmarked specifically for the instruction of students, a decent physical plant, small class size, dedicated faculty and committed parents, and there are sure to be positive results.

title: Steering Clear Of Traffic Jams
description: TALK about traffic jams! This summer's hot spots on the national traffic-jam roster include a couple at least a year old. Several new repair projects are creating major delays, up to two hours. As resurfacing and widening of the middle-aged Interstate system continues, long-distance drivers who have been barreling along may find themselves trapped in a maze of overheating cars.

title: PULSE; On-Line Shop With Attitude
description: For those times when a style-minded young woman has nothing to wear and no time to trek to the stores, Laura Eisman created Girlshop, a new Web site with nine on-line ''boutiques'' (www.girlshop.com). Ms. Eisman offers only her favorites: Pixie Yates, Amy Chan Handbags, Selima Optique, Ellen for Le Corset Lingerie, Tony & Tina nail polish and other designers who appeal to ''stylish urban girls ages 18 to 35,'' she said. ''It's like making a trip to SoHo without leaving your office.''

title: A Return Visit for the Tall Ships
description: LONG ISLANDERS will be going down to the sea to see ships next weekend, when Glen Cove and Greenport will be co-hosts of Americas' Sail '98, a sailing competition for tall ships that left Savannah, Ga., on the Fourth of July.

title: The Nation; With Enemies Like That, They Don't Need Friends
description: LAST week, from faraway California, Monica Lewinsky watched her former best friend, Linda Tripp, take center stage in Washington as marquee witness for the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr.

title: Streets of Dreams; When You're Asleep, New York Becomes Another World
description: EVERY night, behind millions of closed eyelids, little New York movies flicker, as fleetingly as yesterday's fireworks: images of an Upper West Side apartment where one room opens into another, then another; of verdant midtown oases; of downtown lofts with streets running through them, of an A train that takes the dreamer far from Harlem.

title: Political Briefing; Signs of Discontent In the Aloha State
description: The Democratic Party has always carefully cultivated Hawaii's disparate racial and ethnic groups and, as a result, few states are more Democratic than the Aloha State. But that Democratic dominance faces a major test this year because the Hawaiian economy, unlike those of almost all other states, is in a deep, seven-year slump, its tourism sector hammered by Asia's financial crisis and unable to offset steady shrinkage in the agriculture and military sectors.

title: As Indexes Boom, Many Funds Fizzle
description: WITH the stock market hot as a firecracker, pushing the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index to record highs, why aren't mutual fund holders cheering? Because it is no fun to have few or no gains in one's fund holdings while the indexes race ever higher.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANNECK, JAY
description: VANNECK-Jay. The Friends of Bailey Arboretum mourns with great sadness the death of Jay Vanneck, President of Bailey Foundation. He was a generous and caring supporter of the Arboretum. Deepest sympathy is extended to his family. Board of Trustees, Bailey Arboretum

title: Yes, but What of the Touch of Spain?
description: WE approached Costa Brava, a new restaurant in Norwalk, with considerable anticipation. The name suggests the rugged Mediterranean coast northeast of Barcelona, the Catalan region which has its own distinctive version of Mediterranean cuisine (and a rarity in Connecticut).

title: A Wider Impact
description: To the Editor:

title: A Focus on Seafood in Larchmont
description: WE previously enjoyed the efforts of Brian MacMenamin, chef at Larchmont Avenue Oyster House here, when he was cooking up similarly ambitious dishes at Larchmont's now defunct Sea Grill. As is obvious from the name of his new restaurant, Mr. MacMenamin's focus on seafood continues, and the crowds waiting for tables could not be more pleased.

title: PULSE; The Message Is the Logo
description: Stylish urbanites are turning toward Mecca. Mecca, U.S.A., that is, a line of T-shirts, jeans and other sportswear that is winning over young logo lovers once faithful to Tommy Hilfiger and Polo.

title: An Auction to Make Merchant Ivory Proud
description: WHAT is a country-house auction without the house? The answer: A mirage of marketing. That is the case with the sale on Wednesday at Christie's in London dedicated to Wentworth Woodhouse in Yorkshire, the biggest house in Britain. Relying on reflected glory and occasional provenance by association, the auction house has spun a slender cache of books, art and furniture into a Merchant Ivory-like production.

title: John J. Ryan, 86, Investment Banker
description: John J. Ryan, a former investment banker and founder of John J. Ryan & Company, died on June 23 at River Extended Care Residence in Red Bank, N.J. A resident of Palm Beach, Fla., and Red Bank, he was 86.

title: Perspective; Team Profits and Labor Peace
description: The Florida Marlins lost more than $30 million last year. Right, and Dennis Rodman has no tattoos.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANDEL, MALCOLM STUART
description: KANDEL-Malcolm Stuart. July 2, 1998. Beloved husband of Adele. Adored father of Andrew & John. He will be remembered with love always. Memorial service Tues., July 7, 12:30PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in his memory to Memorial Sloan-Kettering or Calvary Hospital.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article last Sunday described a zoning dispute over 11 acres of pasture in the town of New Castle.

title: Bryan Drew
description: Drew helped establish Great Britain's Football Intelligence Unit, which investigates criminal behavior among soccer fans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDSON, SIDNEY W., JR.
description: DAVIDSON-Sidney W., Jr. Formerly of Lyme, CT and Bedford, on July 1, 1998. Survived by his wife of 54 years, Grace Moffat, his five children, Susan M., Mary B., Sidney W. III (Tres) Davidson, Anne D. Hardy (David) and Sarah D. O'Leary (Sean). He is also survived by a grandson and his four sisters and a brother. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made to Yale University Class of 1944 Fund, c/o Yale Alumni Office, New Haven, CT 06508-1890, or to Lawrenceville School, Class of 1939 Fund, c/o of Lawrenceville School, Lawrenceville, NJ 08648. Memorial service to be held at Saint Matthew's Church, Bedford, NY on Monday, July 13 at 3:00 PM.

title: Hernandez Gives Yankees 60th, by a Decision
description: On his first Fourth of July in the United States, a defector from Cuba found himself on a pitcher's mound, doing what he loves most, at a place called Yankee Stadium. To Orlando Hernandez, the coincidences were too many. Gracias a Dios, Hernandez said, after he allowed just six hits in eight innings and beat Baltimore, 4-3. Thanks to God.

title: Mr. Shawn's New Yorker
description: To the Editor:

title: OPINION; Freedom From High-Tech Slavery
description: ONCE upon a time, I couldn't imagine life on this planet without the myriad of connections at my fingertips. I'm the modern version of the six million-dollar woman, connected to the world with state-of-the-art gadgets: reachable by beeper, cell phone, fax or E-mail, 24 hours a day, seven days a week.

title: The New York Times Business Best Sellers
description: HARDCOVER

title: POP/JAZZ; Coming Home To a New Strain Of Southern Rock
description: ONE evening not long ago I was backstage at Wetlands, a rock club on the Lower West Side of Manhattan, talking with Mike Farris, the 27-year-old singer for Screamin' Cheetah Wheelies, a band from Tennessee. Standing nearby was Warren Haynes, the North Carolina-born guitarist for Gov't Mule and a former member of the Allman Brothers Band. Mr. Haynes was chatting with the Allmans' longtime road manager, Kirk West, who was up from Georgia for a couple of weeks and had decided to check out the Wheelies show. The vibe in that musty, beer-strewn dressing room felt as familiar as a family reunion, and I noticed that my own North Carolina drawl had sneaked right out of me without my having realized it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELDEN, RICHARD CLINTON
description: WELDEN-Richard Clinton. June 29, 1998. Husband of Mary Thenebe Welden. Father of Thorn, Wickford and Trafford. Brother of Robert E. Welden. He was a partner with the law firm Decker, Hubbard, Welden and Sweeney, NYC. Memorial service Tuesday, July 14, 1998, 11AM at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at 91 Street.

title: For Novotna, Wimbledon Tears of Joy at Last
description: Jana Novotna's painstaking quest to win a Wimbledon title had begun to take on legendary proportion, and today the Duchess of Kent helped to give it a fairy-tale ending.

title: Compassion, Responsibility And the Work of Welfare
description: The boxes are packed in William Waldman's ninth-floor office. The reins of the Department of Human Services are about to be handed over to his deputy, Michelle Guhl.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Ditmas Park, Brooklyn; A Suburban Enclave in an Urban Setting
description: A PROBLEM of definition arises with Ditmas Park, an area of Flatbush known for jumbo-sized, richly detailed, nearly century-old Colonial Revival houses and ever-increasing ethnic diversity.

title: Showing Managers The Door
description: BREAKING up is hard to do; knowing when to do it is even harder. Hiring a new managing agent -- a firm that handles the details of running a co-op, condominium or other multifamily building -- is similarly dicey; it is essential to gauge with some skill when the the old one must go.

title: Schools Chief Out
description: After months of haggling over a separation agreement, the Yonkers School District and its Superintendent for five years have parted ways. Reginald Marra left the school system last month with $300,000 in severance pay and a contract prohibiting him from disparaging the district. Meanwhile, Deputy Superintendent J. Russell Garris has been appointed to oversee the schools while a search for a permanent leader continues.

title: Schools for Sale
description: Contrary to what Michael Winerip wrote in your article, I do not disparage Jersey City's public schools. We have many fine public schools, with many fine teachers, and I have fought for equitable financing of our public-school system.

title: Look at the Camera, Smile . . . Got It! A Work of Art!
description: THE slightly off-center picture of Aunt Minnie at the beach, that out-of-focus shot of your dog you took when you were 7, the photo you accidentally snapped of your own foot: just about everyone has countless pictures like these tucked into albums, stuffed in drawers or hidden in old shoe boxes. Yet we don't often look at our snapshots, and when we do it's the personal content we focus on (''Whose baby was that?'' ''What was I thinking when I got that perm?'') not the look of the pictures themselves.

title: Gershwin, Restored and Admired Anew
description: PAYING homage to George Gershwin's genius could prove daunting in a year when musicians and musical organizations throughout the world are observing the centenary of his birth. Friends of the Arts takes up the challenge next weekend with its ''Gershwin Celebration,'' two days of music and talk exploring the many and complex facets of the composer's art.

title: Space Aged
description: The news that John Glenn is scheduled to go into space again took me back almost 56 years to the time we were both members of the first class in the Navy preflight school, in Iowa City. What I remember about him was his singing ability -- not as irrelevant as it may sound. The training included lots of hikes, and it speeded those trips along if we could sing. Glenn's repertory was enormous.

title: June 28-July 4; CNN and Time Apologize
description: In the latest in a string of embarrassments for journalism, Cable News Network and Time magazine apologized for falsely reporting last month that the American military had used lethal nerve gas in a secret 1970 mission in Laos meant to kill American defectors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAVITZ, JEFFREY L.
description: KRAVITZ-Jeffrey L. Devoted friend. Our family will forever be inspired by the way you lived your life. We will miss you, but never forget you. Your smile will always be in our hearts. Larry, Suzanne and Zachary Miller

title: Fame Goes to Her Head So Liberty Clips Access
description: It's enough to give a lady a headache -- and a lot of tourists heat exhaustion. Crowds wanting to climb to the crown of the Statue of Liberty have become so large in recent summers that the National Park Service has restricted access to the crown -- 22 stories up -- to passengers on the first ferries of the day from Battery Park in Manhattan and Liberty State Park in Jersey City.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/

title: THE NATION: A New Broom Needs a New Handle; Welfare as We Know It Goes Incognito
description: WITH a wave of a wand and a mayoral proclamation, New York City's welfare system is vanishing. Job centers are replacing welfare offices. Financial planners are replacing caseworkers. And the entire bureaucracy is morphing into the Family Independence Administration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIEGEL, IRVING
description: SPIEGEL-Irving, 82. On June 28. Dear devoted, beloved husband of Alyce (nee Camen). Beloved, caring father of Bruce and the late Barry Spiegel. Dear father-in-law of Barbara. Adored grandfather of Jared, Meredith and Mia.

title: REIT's Place Their New York Area Bets
description: AS real estate investment trusts flourished around the country in recent years the New York City area was a comparative exception. But activity by REIT's in the area, each with a distinctive investment strategy, has picked up sharply.

title: Birth Rate and Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: Korean Adoptees Eager to Visit Motherland
description: JASON NOONE is an American. He grew up in Nassau County the land of seashore and shopping malls. ''My fatherland is the U.S.,'' he said. But Mr. Noone was born in Korea. ''That's my motherland,'' he said. ''And a person shouldn't go through life without knowing his mother.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, EMMA MABEL
description: COHEN-Emma Mabel. Age 96. Died on July 2, 1998 in Media, Pennsylvania. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Joseph George Cohen, who was former Dean of Teacher Education, City Colleges of New York City. Cherished mother of Vera (Mrs. Joseph) Gottlieb of Charlottesville, VA, and Michael Cohen of Wynnewood, Pennsylvania. Loving grandmother of Jane Rogers, Robert Gottlieb, Adam Cohen, Jonathan Cohen & Alison Cohen. Devoted great grandmother of Megan Elsensohn, Jonathan Gottlieb and Alexander Gottlieb. She was a dedicated teacher of English, volunteer librarian and inspired gardener.

title: SPENDING IT; Medical Accounts: Mixed Reviews
description: WHEN medical savings accounts became available last year, Eric R. Bryen, Matthew C. Dailey and Julie A. Griswold all signed up, eager for the chance to save tax-free dollars for medical expenses.

title: Beach-Blanket Babel: Another Reason to Stay at the Pool
description: EVENTUALLY, somebody is going to figure out a way to implant advertising messages directly into the human cerebral cortex. Meanwhile, Patrick Dori has come one small step closer to a universe of ubiquitous advertising. He has invented a device to print ads directly onto a beach.

title: SOAPBOX; Joe D., the Babe and Pop
description: FOR 75 years, Yankee Stadium has been the site of great moments in the history of our national pastime. As special a moment as any occurred on July 5, 1930.

title: Word for Word/Internet Gags; The Information Age Is Here. Ah-Ha-Ha-Ha-Ha-Ha-Ha!
description: WHY'S everybody so down on the Internet? Sure, it's a refuge for conspiracy theorists, bigots and perverts, but look at the bright side: It also preoccupies jokesters and assorted knuckleheads with entirely too much time on their hands.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: CRUISES ON THE YANGTZE: Regal China Cruises is offering a 30 percent saving on all summer cruises on the Yangtze River. The discount is good for cruises that are booked by Aug. 1; travel must be completed by Aug. 31. With the discounts, fares start at $581 a person, double occupancy, for a five-night cruise. Three-day cruises are also available, and there are further discounts for children. All the itineraries take travelers to the site of the Three Gorges hydroelectric dam project. The three German-built ships accommodate from 258 to 270 passengers. Information: (800) 808-3388 or (212) 768-3388.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Free Choices

title: Winds Can't Move Pak Out of the Open Lead
description: Strong winds arrived at the United States Women's Open today, causing havoc throughout the leader board.

title: China and Taiwan Are Warming to Each Other
description: To the Editor:

title: Location, Location: How 'Side Man' Made All the Right Moves
description: THEATER often has less to do with passion, art or even accomplishment than it does with real estate commitments that, in turn, help to decide which plays and shows we see and which are allowed to drift into oblivion.

title: Brooklyn's Underused Waterfront
description: New Yorkers' understandable thirst for greenswards along the city's 578-mile waterfront has coaxed a series of administrations in City Hall and Albany to begin building the 65-acre Hudson River esplanade and to mull the open-space potential of the 173-acre Governors Island. Yet even as the city embarks on its most ambitious round of park development since Olmsted and Vaux built Central Park, a breathtaking opportunity on Brooklyn's East River waterfront has languished. More than 60 acres of piers, just south of the Brooklyn Bridge, could be transformed into a harborfront park whose vistas alone would make it a required destination for residents and visitors alike.

title: Saratoga Springs
description: To the Editor: I read with incredulity a letter from Maryann Dizozza (April 26), who complained that when she visited Saratoga Springs after seven years away, she found it changed for the worse. She complains about ''all the fast-food chains and coffee houses'' on Broadway and laments the loss of antique stores. In particular, she implies that the new Eddie Bauer store displaces an antique shop.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEWIS, RANDEE LYNN
description: LEWIS-Randee Lynn. 4/30/57-7/15/70 (Tammuc 11) In everlasting memory. Leonard, Robin, Sharyn Lewis Seena Elbaum, Max N. Hurwitz

title: Flaws or Value in Closed-End Funds?
description: WITH closed-end funds developing a reputation as a dysfunctional branch of the fund family tree, shareholder activists have grown restive. That's fine with some analysts, who feel that helps make many such funds look like bargains as of late.

title: As Apple Pie as Tail Fins and Burning Rubber; Corvette: Now That's American
description: NO modern car on the American road is more red-white-and-blue blooded than the Chevrolet Corvette.

title: No Crowd for One-Stop Shopping
description: WHEN mutual fund companies started pushing so-called life-style and life-cycle funds, they seemed like sure-fire hits: single funds that were meant to simplify the decision-making process for befuddled investors.

title: The World; Meet Kosovo, the World's Biggest Little Tinderbox
description: IN the heart of the Serbian province of Kosovo, not so far from Albania and pretty close to Macedonia, lies a hamlet called Kijevo. Like other settlements in the area, it was a place where men spent hours watching the traffic between Pristina and Pec while they sipped coffee from little cups and ate sausages and yellow peppers. Nearby, goats chewed the grass along the roadside.

title: The Real, Live Diva And the Pretenders
description: A DIVA is a goddess who transforms whatever she touches into beauty. From its Latin root to the noble tradition of grand opera, the classical designation demands regality, command and largess. Think Maria Callas (La Divina), Joan Sutherland (La Stupenda), Leontyne Price, who to many opera lovers represents the epitome of the beloved diva's contrariness: stateliness and distance divinely touched by warmth and incomparable sound.

title: Astros Have Made Moves to Improve, and Their Numbers Show It
description: The Houston Astros, the defending National League Central champions who have been in first place since May 2, reach the midseason interlude as perhaps the least heralded and most ignored of the six first-place teams.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Judgment Call; Sure Justices Legislate. They Have To.
description: ANY nominee who appears before the Senate Judiciary Committee these days can expect a lecture on the sins of ''legislating from the bench'' or ''making law instead of interpreting the law.'' Judges who believe otherwise ''should resign to run for public office -- at least then they would be accountable for their actions.'' So said Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the Utah Republican who heads the Judiciary Committee, a few weeks ago in a speech on the Senate floor.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE FIRE GOSPELS

title: Pizzas, Pastas and Salad Greenery In Brooklyn Heights
description: Brick oven pizzas with numerous fresh toppings, made-to-order pastas and salads are offered at a new Brooklyn Heights restaurant, Monty Q's, at 158 Montague Street (between Clinton and Henry Streets).

title: Approaching Midpoint, Yanks Keep Pace With History
description: The Yankees may be the most storied franchise in professional sports, with an extraordinary history of success. But the 1998 Yankees had the best record through 80 games posted by any Yankees team, with a 60-20 mark. That was two games better than the 1928 Yankees (58-22), three games better than the 1939 Yankees (57-23) and four better than the 1927 Yankees (56-24).

title: Yesterday's Bad Deal, Today's Big Break
description: Buck Williams is neither gloating nor asking for an apology from his peers. But three years after the former union president helped negotiate a deal with the owners -- a deal that was widely ridiculed by National Basketball Association players for being pro-management -- Williams, the 17-year veteran forward, has finally gained a measure of vindication.

title: Looking at the Lawn, and Below the Surface
description: SOMETHING awful is happening to the planet Earth. It has been invaded by the Earth-snatchers. It is being turned into a pod planet, one lawn at a time. Thirty-two million acres have been snatched thus far on the North American continent alone. More land is now occupied by lawns than is given over to the cultivation of wheat, corn or tobacco. It costs $750 million annually to seed this turf. Another $25 billion is invested each year in mowers, clippers, gardening gloves, hoses and other do-it-yourself tools.

title: Croatia Stuns Germany With the Aid Of a Red Card
description: Late in the first half, Croatia's players began making the sign of the cross, putting their hands together prayerfully and looking upward, as if they felt divine intervention would be necessary to defeat mighty Germany in their first trip to the World Cup.

title: A 60's Free Spirit Whose Main Subject Was Herself
description: HOW do you classify Yayoi Kusama? Art historians, critics and even other artists have found it difficult to categorize the work of the Japanese-born artist, whose career flourished in New York during the 1960's but whose art is not exactly Pop, or Minimalist, or psychedelic, or Abstract Expressionist. But from today's late-post-modern vantage point, Ms. Kusama's art shared affinities with or anticipated all of these tendencies and others, too. They include performance art, body art, ''feminist'' art and art forms full of role-playing or mass-media manipulation that anticipated those developed later by artists like Cindy Sherman, Yasumasa Morimura and Jeff Koons.

title: June 28-July 4; A Plummeting Black Birth Rate
description: For years, the high birth rate among unmarried black women was a hot button in the debate over the causes of poverty among African-Americans. Now it has plummeted to its lowest point in 40 years. The National Center for Health Statistics said there were 74.4 births per 1,000 unmarried black women in 1996, well below the peak of 90.7 per 1,000 reached in 1989. Demographers cited an increase in contraceptive use, sex education and efforts by some community groups to encourage abstention.

title: What's So Wrong With This Picture?

Her name was Christina Olson, and the painting she inspired, both well painted and poignant, announced the arrival of a major American artist. Either that or it's overrated schlock -- people tend to have very strong opinions either way. Thomas Hoving, former director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, has called Wyeth ''one of America's most distinguished painters, the great observer.'' To Hilton Kramer, the art critic, Wyeth's paintings ''have nothing to do with serious artistic expression.''

title: 'Soft Money' Is Bad Business

We let them know that the ''soft money'' system -- substantial, unregulated contributions to political parties -- is bankrupting our democracy. And we urged them to look beyond the short-term interests of their political parties or their Congressional leadership and do what's right for the country.

title: Shear, Deadhead and Let Bees Alone
description: Shear back by half spring-blooming, clump-forming plants like nepeta and dianthus species. As flowers fade, deadhead yarrow and butterfly weed to lateral buds for repeat flowering. Harvest herbs frequently and don't let basil go to seed. Stake dahlias, lilies, monkshood and hollyhocks. Feed containers every two weeks with dilute fish emulsion or seaweed fertilizer. If you haven't yet done so, mulch vegetable, annual and perennial beds.

title: The High School at the End of the Road
description: In august 1996, jerry mcginnes, a sulking, brooding 18-year-old, awaited sentencing in a Fort Collins, Colo., courtroom. His tattoos -- the sun and a cross on his forearms and unintelligible markings on his knuckles, a result of a drunken evening -- lent Jerry an air of defiance. The Juvenile Court magistrate, Joseph Coyte, asked if he had anything to say. Jerry, who had dropped out of school, had been on probation for stealing a car when he cut off his ankle monitor and fled for San Diego to live with his sister. There, he smoked marijuana and hung out until deciding he'd had enough of being on the run. He then turned himself in. The prosecutor asked that the judge send him to a youth prison. Jerry rose; his hands, manacled and shaking, clutched a penciled four-page letter he had written. He read it aloud.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Years With No Handles
description: The stories in STRIPPING AWAY THE SORROWS FROM THIS WORLD (Mercury House, paper, $14.95) grow out of the land Jesus Gardea writes about: the vast, unforgiving plains and broken-down settlements of the northern part of Mexico. ''Around here,'' a character in a story called ''No Loss'' is told while clearing a junk-filled lot for what turns out to be no reason, ''the years . . . have no handles to grab onto.'' Nor does much else. Translated into an appropriately raw English by Mark Schafer (who also made the selections for this volume), the stories are bleak and unforgiving. People and events are presented without context, explanation or much connection to anything else. And the narrative itself is reduced to short bursts of language: barely linked sentences carry meanings that seem to evaporate even as they are read. What lingers and eventually dominates is the raw power of nature. ''The emptiness is immense,'' observes a man walking to his death in ''Bridge of Shadows,'' adding that ''God must not pass through these parts.'' The hugeness of the landscape belittles human efforts to make any sort of impression. This is an inexorable place. (''The cold was the kind that unfurls. That gains ground inch by inch.'') But also one of great and insoluble mystery. (''The silence of the night contains so many closets.'') The book's use of nature as its protagonist recalls the harsh fiction of Juan Rulfo, but Gardea includes subtle ironies and grace notes that are all his own. James Polk

description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: How to Deal With Teething Time
description: TEETHING is a painful process all young animals must endure: the dislodgment of milk teeth as the adult set applies pressure to emerge. Human babies gum and grope for things munch on to soothe the pain. Pets are no different, though minus a thumb, they are forced to test all possibilities directly: object to mouth.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: Offbeat protagonists dominate a superior cluster of vintage movies on television this week: a television idol, a fading film star and a physician with a penchant for experimentation.

title: Designing the Clothes, Then a Store to Hold Them
description: They created the merchandise and now the store. Derek Price and Tess Roman, the couple behind the women's clothing label Price Roman, opened a boutique of their own design last month at 153 Wooster Street, near Houston Street, in SoHo.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Israeli Exchange Hopes Domestic Companies Keep One Foot at Home
description: DUAL citizenship is one advantage that Israel offers to keep immigrants coming. Now it is trying to use dual citizenship to keep stocks from leaving.

title: Susan Kramer, Christophe Guillemot
description: Susan Rochelle Kramer, a daughter of Esther and Stuart Kramer of Fair Lawn, N.J., was married last evening to Christophe Patrick Guillemot, a son of Marie-France and Pierre Guillemot of Chateau-Thierry, France. title: Sports of The Times; Yankees' Torre Takes Nothing for Granted
description: FOR the 61st time this season, the Yankees did yesterday what they have done with regularity since April: They won.

title: A 6-Hour Move, and Landing in Hong Kong Loses a Thrill
description: In less time than it takes to fly from London to New York, Hong Kong closed down its international airport today just after midnight and moved the contents 19 miles west to a new $20 billion airport in time for the first flight to land at 6:20 A.M.

title: Absent a Battle Cry, War for the House Is Fought at Home
description: After two Congressional elections that were seen as referendums on the direction of the nation, this year's battle for control of the House is being fought the old-fashioned way: candidate by candidate and district by district.

title: Tabloid Offers Reward And Gets Small Thanks
description: Trial watchers here are saying People of the State of California v. Mikail Markhasev may not have come to pass were it not for The National Enquirer.

title: Compressed Data; We'd Like to Announce: Oh, Nothing; Never Mind
description: The Software Publishers Association got a little ahead of itself last week in promoting its efforts to crack down on software piracy. On Monday, it sent out a two-page press release indicating that it had reached an out-of-court settlement for $150,000 with a New Jersey medical supply company. The release stated that the company, Edison-based International Technidyne Corporation, agreed that it had used unlicensed or pirated software from 23 of the association's companies.

title: Sampras Can Finally Crack a Smile
description: Pete Sampras is a historical, not hysterical, sort of guy. He reacted to his latest triumph on Wimbledon's Center Court, the garden spot that has now provided 5 of his 11 Grand Slam championships and left him one Slam title shy of equaling Roy Emerson's career record, with consummate restraint.

title: Essay; The Rest Is History
description: Letters, handwritten notes and the contemporaneous recollections of yesterday's insiders helped us understand ''the way it really was'' in America's past. But technology, fear of prosecution and the blindness of publishers threaten to deny tomorrow's historians access to this generation's primary sources.

title: Bruising Race Seen for State Senate
description: When John M. Gangemi Jr. undertook his first political campaign for State Senate two years ago, he was warmly embraced by Republican Party officials in Brooklyn and Staten Island. And in the two years since losing that race to a Democrat, he has been preparing to run again for the seat, hoping once more for widespread support from his fellow Republicans.

title: After a Year, No Letup in Asia's Economic Crisis
description: Few alarm bells rang here a year ago this weekend, when Thailand's currency melted down.

description: To the Editor:

description: ''The core of the team is the team.''

title: Northern Ireland Relatively Calm as Protestant Marchers Are Kept From Catholic Area
description: The British Government used hundreds of combat-ready army troops and Northern Ireland policemen today to prevent several thousand Protestants from marching, as Protestants have since 1807, through a small Roman Catholic enclave in this town.

title: Among the Ashes, Florida Victims Sift For the Bright Side
description: Ed Callahan, who served all over the world with the Army Special Forces and has the tattoos to prove it, stood in front of a pile of melted glass, scorched metal and blackened wood and talked tough about the wildfire that leaped out of the Florida palmettos and consumed his house.

title: Peru Reporters Say Officials Direct Harassment Effort
description: A leading reporter here, Angel Paez, is no stranger to trouble. He has received anonymous telephoned death threats for years. Marxist terrorists have tried to kill him two times. He has been accused at different points of being a Communist and a Central Intelligence Agency spy.

title: Trial to Begin In Big Lawsuit By Smokers In Florida
description: The resolve of cigarette makers to fight lawsuits following the collapse of last year's nationwide settlement plan faces its toughest test today with the start of a large class-action case brought on behalf of smokers in Florida.

The former frenzy has given way to the kind of skepticism that only five years of Internet-driven market chaos could have inspired.

title: A Nighttime Forest That's Full of Melody and Light
description: David Parsons had people dancing in the dark when his Parsons Dance Company performed on Thursday night as an attraction of the American Dance Festival. The well-chosen program at Page Auditorium on the campus of Duke University here often made a dark stage seem bright. By so doing it emphasized several important facets of Mr. Parsons's choreographic temperament, including his ability to entertain, his affinity with jazz and his love of unusual scenic effects.

title: Technology Finance Plan Is Scuttled By University
description: The California State University, the nation's largest college system, has scuttled a much-disputed plan to accept a $300 million investment from a group of high-technology companies to upgrade the university's networks and other technology infrastructure.

title: DVD Leads Race for TV Disks, but It Is Looking Over Its Shoulder
description: The companies backing DVD, the CD-size digital disk that contains a feature-length movie, are boasting a lot these days, telling anyone who will listen that their product is selling faster than either compact disk players or VCR's did at the corresponding points after they were introduced.

description: Nanci Donnellan is interested in jazz, opera and popular culture, but you would never know it from her radio persona: the self-described Fabulous Sports Babe, the only female host of a nationally syndicated sports talk show.

title: Compressed Data; A Line of Computers Without Windows
description: As a market test, Ralph Nader's Consumer Project on Technology recently tried to order a personal computer from a dozen companies without Microsoft's Windows as the operating system. No luck, reported David Chun, the Nader summer intern who made the calls to Dell Computer, Gateway, I.B.M. and others -- not even when he asked for a PC with no operating system at all.

description: Americans marched up to the podium to collect four of the Henley Royal Regatta's most prestigious trophies today, receiving the prizes from Prince Philip.

title: Monarch of Center Court
description: This has been a vintage year for fans who appreciate great, seasoned athletes performing brilliantly in the hallmark competition of their sport. First there was John Elway, the Denver Bronco quarterback, leading his team to a Super Bowl victory, the first of his distinguished career. Then Michael Jordan propelled the Chicago Bulls to another National Basketball Association championship. Yesterday, it was Pete Sampras's turn. He dispatched Goran Ivanisevic in a difficult five-set match to win his fifth Wimbledon title.

title: A Gentle Evening With a Sunny Haitian Big Band
description: The most genial music in the Caribbean may well be Haitian kon'pa, big-band dance music with an easygoing midtempo lilt and an endless supply of sunny riffs. The music has survived on Haiti since the swing era, even as kon'pa has turned into compas and been rearranged for guitar bands. On Friday night, the Midsummer Night Swing series at Lincoln Center presented Orchestre Septentrional, a 20-member big band from Cap-Haitien that marks its 50th anniversary on July 27. One of the group's original nine members, Ulrick Pierre Louis, leads the band, surrounded by younger musicians and swaying to the beat with his fellow saxophone players.

title: Mets Add Bad Luck To Their List of Woes
description: All the frustration of the first half of the season boiled down to one hotly contested play at home plate today for the Mets.

title: Sid Luckman, Star for the Bears, Dies at 81
description: Sid Luckman, the Columbia University star and quarterback of the great Chicago Bears teams of the 1940's who helped trigger a revolution in how the game of football was played, died yesterday at Aventura (Fla.) Hospital and Medical Center. Luckman, who lived in Aventura, was 81.

title: A SOUTHERN BUYER WILL ACQUIRE SAKS
description: Saks Fifth Avenue, one of the most venerable names in retail, said yesterday that it would be acquired for $2.1 billion by Proffitt's Inc., a Southern retailing company that is all but unknown to New York shoppers.

title: Privacy in the Digital Age
description: As more and more Americans communicate and do business electronically, the fear is spreading that information they transmit can be seized by hackers or criminals and used for illegal or unsavory purposes. Fortunately, the technology to thwart such invasions already exists. It is called encryption, or the encoding of digital information to secure its privacy. But the Federal Bureau of Investigation is trying hard to prevent the growing use of encryption, both in the United States and abroad, because of fears that the protective technology itself will get into the wrong hands. That shortsighted stand will undermine efforts to protect commercial transactions and may actually hamper law enforcement rather than help it.

title: Gentle Zephyr Forces Cone to Alter Strategy
description: David Cone played Yankee Stadium yesterday like a golfer might have. It was as if he lugged a few blades of grass to the top of the mound, flipped them upward, read the gusting air currents and adjusted his pitching to honor the whims of Mother Nature.

Miroslav Blazevic has a fondness for cigarettes, chocolates, watermelon and astrology. The fax came from his astrologer in Zagreb.

title: John Prescott, 63, Ex-Director Of New England Aquarium
description: John H. Prescott, a marine biologist who directed the New England Aquarium in Boston for 22 years and was among the first to describe how dolphins use sound waves to find food, died on Tuesday at his home in Weston, Mass. He was 63.

description: While traveling abroad in the late 19th century, Mark Twain once observed that German was a slippery language, ''elusive to the grasp'' and German literature was ''easy enough to read when you hold them before the looking glass or stand on your head.''

title: The Most Important Deal
description: In any Hall of Fame, some players are obvious candidates for induction as soon as they reach the age limit. Billy Eisenberg of Boca Raton, Fla., who recently had his 60th birthday, is in this category and is to be inducted into the Bridge Hall of Fame this month in Chicago. His credentials include five world championship titles in the Bermuda Bowl series and the title of Grand Master. He is a regular commentator for the World Bridge Federation in its championships and has coached many national teams from other parts of the world. In another field, he is a former world backgammon champion.

title: Abroad at Home; The Engine Of Law
description: One of the agreements reached on President Clinton's China visit was to move ahead quickly on what he and President Jiang Zemin called the rule of law initiative. It drew little attention, but it has the potential to be an engine of change in China.

title: 'Armageddon' Shows Strength at Box Office
description: Never mind what film critics tell you, or predictions that movie audiences are losing their appetites for vacuous, special-effects-laden thrill rides. ''Armageddon,'' the story of oil drillers who take time off to save Earth from a collision with an asteroid, is estimated to have brought in a solid $52.9 million at the box office since opening last Wednesday to some of the most savage reviews of the year.

title: A Nice Place to Visit; A Hotel! Bus Tours! Brooklyn Hits the Tourist Map

title: A Performing Arts Center Takes a Bow; In Newark, a Strong First Season Raises Hope

description: GRAVES-Marilyn Preston. Died on July 3, 1998 in Fairfield, CT after a long respiratory illness. Beloved daughter of the late Helen Mitchell Graves and the late Duncan Graves. A life-long New Yorker, Marilyn devoted 44 years of her life as a volunteer at The New York Hospital, and more than 20 years as a volunteer at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, first by helping patients in several clinics and then by dedicating her life to New York Hospital's Patients' Library, which was named for her late twin sister, Helen Mitchell Graves. She was honored for her outstanding volunteer accomplishments by New York City Mayors Lindsay and Beame, as well as, by the United Hospital Fund. She was an active volunteer for many years in the Junior League of New York and was a long-time member of the Colonial Dames in the State of New York and the Daughters of the Cincinnati. Her immediate survivors include her cousins, Augustus W. Kelley III and his children, Christina Gilmartin, Corrine Wagner and Marc W. Kelley, and by Reginald H. Fullerton, Jr., and Nan Fullerton Shupe. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, July 23, at 11 AM at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 661 Old Post Rd., Fairfield, CT. title: We Can't Save Everything

title: A Record $33 Million for a Monet
description: On July 28, 1954, an English collector wandered into a London art gallery and spent about $7,000 for a colorful Monet. The painting, ''Waterlily Pond and Path by the Water,'' was one of six the artist had made of his water garden in Giverny in 1900. Until it was offered for sale at Sotheby's here last week, it had been hanging in that same collector's house for the last 44 years. On Tuesday night, in a hushed salesroom, five telephone bidders battled for the painting; it ended up breaking previous records for the artist anywhere, selling for a staggering $33 million, more than three times its estimate.

title: Editorial Observer; The Latin Left Searches for a Practical Agenda

Today, the left knows it opposes what Latins call neoliberalismo, the region's singleminded pursuit of foreign investment and the accompanying austerity and inequality. But leftists have no clear idea what they are for.

title: Claims for Art Collection Pose a Challenge to Hungary
description: Martha Nierenberg was one of the lucky ones. When the Nazis invaded her native Hungary on March 19, 1944, ''the whole family went into hiding with a friend in Budapest,'' she recalled. ''By noon, they were looking for my father.'' Unlike others with Jewish backgrounds, she and most of her relatives soon escaped, including her father, Alfonz Weiss. The Weisses were so important economically -- employing 30,000 workers to make everything from airplanes and tanks to tin cans and needles -- that they bartered a 25-year lease on their factory for freedom. When they fled, they were escorted by police cars.

title: What Do Female Bugs Want? Surprise: It's Shape, Not Size
description: THE movie posters for ''Godzilla'' read: ''Size does matter.'' Hey, wipe the scales from your eyes, you overstuffed iguana! Size is not the point: points are the point. Titillators and claspers are the point. So are hooks, knobs and grooves, cerci, epiprocts and paraprocts. How about something that unfolds blade by blade, like a Swiss Army knife -- or the phallus of a male oriental cockroach? If big is the best you can do, darling 'Zilla, no wonder you've been a box office snore.

title: DAVEL TO GAIN MORE PAY PHONES WITH PEOPLES PURCHASE
description: Davel Communications Group agreed to buy the Peoples Telephone Company, based in Miami, for about $111 million in stock. Davel will also take on $100 million in debt. The acquisition will make Davel, based in Tampa, Fla., the nation's largest operator of pay phones, aside from the Baby Bell local companies and the GTE Corporation. Davel will pay 0.235 of a share for each Peoples share, valuing Peoples at about $5.86 a share. Peoples's shares rose 93.75 cents yesterday, to $4.0625, while Davel's tumbled $2.50 each, to $22.4375.

Safeguard, based in Wayne, Pa., is a computer-services and software company. Pac-West, based in Stockton, Calif., offers local phone service to customers in California. The investor group includes three private equity funds associated with Safeguard: TL Ventures, with $540 million under management; SCP Private Equity Partners, with $265 million under management, and Enertech Capital Partners, with $50 million under management. It also involves William Blair Capital Partners of Chicago; Bruce Westphal, chairman of Pac-West, and John La Rue, its founder and president.

title: Women's Music: Who Can Tell?
description: The right to compose music is one of the last that women have chosen to claim, which raises an interesting question. But that right is now being energetically upheld. A fair proportion, if nothing like 50 percent, of the most talented composers at work in the United States happen to be women: Joan Tower, Ellen Taaffe Zwilich, Barbara Kolb, Thea Musgrave, Shulamit Ran and Augusta Read Thomas are outstanding examples. Abroad, prominent composers include women like Betsy Jolas, Olga Neuwirth, Kaija Saariaho, Judith Weir and Sofiya Gubayidulina. The battle for recognition is over. The question now is, What is women's music or what might it be?

description: THE largest gathering of Apple Macintosh fans on the East Coast begins tomorrow in Manhattan, and they have several reasons to be optimistic after more than a year of darkness and turmoil. Led by co-founder Steven P. Jobs, Apple appears to have stabilized its management team, cut costs, made some money, halted a precipitous decline in market share, outlined (at last) a clear path for its Mac operating system, and streamlined and reinvigorated its product lineup.

title: Critic's Notebook: The Right to Perform, the Right to Compose; Loss of 'Peony' and Players
description: With much of Tibetan culture put at risk by actions of the Chinese Government, it may seem petty and impertinent to fret about the fate of Chinese opera; even more, about one particular corner of it. But Chinese opera, which has long been the central manifestation of the performing arts in China, deftly combining music, drama, poetry, dance, design and acrobatics, is waning. And Kunqu opera, the revered style that began in Kunshan, near Shanghai, in the 14th century and gave birth to so many later varieties, including the dominant Peking opera, appears to be dying. Really dying, not just wallowing in confusion, as so much of Western classical music is doing.

title: Army Says a Former General Committed Adultery and Lied
description: The Army's former deputy inspector general engaged in a pattern of ''inappropriate behavior'' or adulterous affairs with the wives of four officers under his command, according to a Pentagon report given today to members of Congress.

description: President Clinton has agreed to travel to Russia in early September to meet with President Boris N. Yeltsin, although the Russian legislature has not fulfilled a request to ratify an important arms control treaty, the White House announced.

description: Viagra, the Pfizer Inc. pill for correcting male impotence, smashed all records in its first three months, according to I.M.S. Health, an industry consultant, which released numbers yesterday.

title: Personal Health; Protecting Children From Bugs That Bite
description: WITH the summer season now in full swing in most parts of the country and youngsters spending more of their waking hours out of doors often skimpily attired, biting insects are finding easy targets for the blood they need to reproduce. And parents once again are challenged to find the best way to protect their children from annoying and possibly dangerous bites from such critters as gnats, mosquitoes, biting flies, chiggers and ticks.

Web sites and telephone lines have been updated daily to keep the citizenry informed. For more than a week, enthusiasts have trekked through the lobby of the Fuqua Conservatory, cameras in hand, in order to monitor and record the progress.

Superior Services, an acquisitive solid waste services company based in West Allis, Wis., had 1997 revenues of $177.8 million.

Meanwhile, the Boston Symphony Orchestra opened its own season on Friday evening and this afternoon, and beautiful weather for those concerts could lull a listener into thinking, for the moment, that Tanglewood was its old idyllic self.

title: African, With Ideas From Afar
description: For African pop musicians, using ideas from other places has never been a tough decision; creative assimilation is part of both the pop process and African tradition. The real questions are how to use borrowed materials, and how much. Africa Fete, the package tour that brings African musicians to American audiences, presented four distinct answers -- from Mali, Senegal, Somalia and Congo -- at Central Park Summerstage on Sunday afternoon.

title: Big Deficit for Japan In Last Fiscal Year
description: Japan's deficit in its general account budget for the year that ended on March 31 was the largest since 1981, as declines in sales and profits led to lower tax revenues, Government figures showed yesterday. The budget, which excludes social security and long-term construction projects, had a deficit of 1.56 trillion yen ($11.2 billion) last year, according to the preliminary Finance Ministry estimates. Tax collections were 2.229 trillion yen ($16 billion) less than had been anticipated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, SAMUEL
description: KAPLAN-Samuel. Age 86, formerly of Brownsville, died peacefully in Kendall, Florida on July 1, 1998. ''Sammy'', a member of the New York City ''schoolboy'' and amateur championship basketball teams of 1930-1934 known as the DUX, A.C. Played professionally between 1935-1946 in the American Basketball League for Kate Smith's ''Celtics''; the ''Jewels'', Kingston ''Colonials'' and Wilmington ''Bombers''. Upon his return from US Army service in WWII, he was overwhelmingly elected to the New York State Assembly for the 24th A.D. serving in 1947-1948. He became a residential housing developer in South Miami these past 30 years and hosted annual reunions of former New York City basketball players of the 30's at Kaplan's ''Kamelot'' in Kendall. He truly put the ''Basketball of Life in the Basket of Success.'' M.R.M.

title: Review/Fashion; Getting Personal in Paris With Romantic Visions
description: Designers working in Paris create such highly personal collections that it is somewhat surprising that they find an audience at all for their men's wear collections, which were shown here over the weekend. But they do, because within their peculiarities often lie the seeds of many fashion visions. It was impossible to ignore the free and gentle breeze wafting through Paris as designers led by Yohji Yamamoto and Rei Kawakubo crystallized the romantic theme shown earlier in Milan, Italy.

title: Traffic Accidents Kill 6 Over Holiday Weekend
description: Six people were killed in automobile accidents over the Fourth of July weekend in New Jersey, the authorities said yesterday.

title: For Many Driven Out by Florida Fires, Returning Is Relief
description: For an excruciating three days, an estimated 35,000 people waited in shelters and hotel rooms just outside Flagler County, as a result of a mandatory evacuation, while firefighters battled the worst wildfires in Florida's history. This morning, evacuees collected their photo albums, cats, dogs and other belongings and came home, most of them, to relief.

title: Review/Fashion; In Milan, Tom Ford Lightens Up the Gucci Man
description: The trendy designer, embodied by Tom Ford at Gucci, and the unapologetic industrialist, represented by Giorgio Armani, now define fashion in Milan, and it speaks well of the city that both can thrive in such a hothouse. description: Gun-control advocates who want the firearms industry to be held responsible for gun-related injuries or deaths are threatening a fragile agreement on broad legislation that would affect lawsuits against manufacturers.

description: Roy Rogers, a shoe factory worker's son from Cincinnati who rode a golden palomino and a harmonious voice to fame as Hollywood's most beloved and quintessential singing cowboy, died yesterday at his ranch in Apple Valley near Victorville, Calif. He was 86.

title: SWIFT ENERGY TO BUY OIL AND GAS PROPERTIES FROM SONAT

Swift, based in Houston, is an oil and gas company that focuses on natural gas on land in the United States. It had revenue of $15.8 million in the quarter ended March 31. Sonat, based in Birmingham, Ala., is a natural gas pipeline company that has diversified into oil and gas production. Sonat reported revenue of $1.1 billion for the quarter ended March 31.

description: ''People here perceive themselves on the defensive, defending their culture, their religion, their communities, against outside forces. They see these changes, such as homosexuality, and they rebel.''

title: The Illusion of Democracy in Nigeria
description: The high-level American delegation that landed in Nigeria yesterday is the latest in a stream of international visitors that has so far included British and Commonwealth officials and the United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan. All have carried essentially the same message -- that Gen. Abdulsalam Abubakar, Nigeria's new military ruler, should carry out a genuine transition to democracy.

title: Salomon Set To End Group On Arbitrage

title: PIERCE LEAHY BUYS FOUR RECORD-MANAGEMENT COMPANIES
description: The Pierce Leahy Corporation said yesterday that it had bought four records-management concerns for $57 million in cash. The largest, Houston-based Kestrel Data Management and Storage, accounts for more than 90 percent of the total purchase price. Pierce Leahy, based in King of Prussia, Pa., is the largest records-management company in North America as measured by cubic feet of storage. The other companies that it purchased were Data Protection Services Inc. of Birmingham, Ala.; Bender Records Management of Reno, and Keystone Records Storage of Harrisburg, Pa.

title: Reshaping the Teachers' Unions
description: Public education is under heavier attack today than at almost any time in its history. Fearful of the voucher movements and increasingly bad press, the two largest teachers' unions -- the American Federation of Teachers and the National Education Association -- are seeking to merge, thereby increasing their powers to fight back. The merger efforts were dealt a setback Sunday, when delegates to the N.E.A. convention voted overwhelmingly against merging with the teachers' federation. The merger, which may yet be approved in some revised form, has been cast mainly in political terms. But if the unions are to raise themselves in public esteem, they need to lead the reform effort, not just follow it.

title: Health Watch; Kids and Smoking
description: Every day as many as 3,000 youngsters begin smoking, with the average teen smoker picking up the habit at age 14.

title: A Cowboy's Trail
description: There is, in America, no more pliable figure than the cowboy. He is whatever we want him to be whenever we need to imagine him. He rides in from somewhere else, driving cattle, chasing badmen, fleeing the past or simply mulling over the landscape as it looks from the back of a horse. He is as artificial as the worst of movies can make him, and he is more authentic than even the truest of stories that are told about him. How richly we have elaborated the myth of cowboys -- surrendering the reality nearly completely in the process -- can be demonstrated by a simple thought-experiment. Try to imagine a western that could star both John Wayne and Roy Rogers, who died yesterday at 86. It can't be done.

description: DAVIDSON-Robert T.H., Esq. Formerly of Brooklyn, New York, Santa Fe, NM and Bellport, Long Island, died July 5, 1998 at his home in Killingworth, CT after a long respiratory illness. Graduate of Yale, Class of 45 W and of Yale Law School. Past President of The Brooklyn Hospital and the Rembrandt Club of Brooklyn. Member of The Century Association of New York. Amateur magician and goldsmith. He is survived by his wife of 42 years, Patricia Foote and their daughter, Carol Foote Davidson of London, England. He is also survived by his four sisters. His brother, Sidney W. Davidson, Jr. died four days earlier. There will be a memorial service later in the summer. Friends and colleagues will be notified. Donations in his memory may be made to The Cerimon Fund (for charity), C/O Mrs. Leslie A. Floyd, Vice President, U.S. Trust Company of CT., 225 High Ridge Road, Stamford, CT. 06905.

title: In the Bronx and Beyond, Summer Camp Calls
description: If 11-year-old Joey Antonio had his way, he would spend the next six weeks of his summer at home in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx watching television, preferably ''Fresh Prince of Bel Air.'' But his mother had a different plan.
