title: Unions and Local Groups Join To Form a New Political Party
description: A coalition of labor unions and community groups announced yesterday that it was forming a new political party that it hoped would prod Democratic candidates to pay more attention to the organizations' needs.

title: CLINTON TO PUNISH INSURERS WHO DENY HEALTH COVERAGE
description: President Clinton will punish health insurance companies that deny coverage to sick people, in violation of a 1996 law, by excluding them from the lucrative insurance market for Federal employees, Administration officials said today.

title: World News Briefs; 5 Indonesians Are Killed By Police Fire at Protest
description: Five people died in a hospital on Monday night after security forces fired on a crowd demonstrating for independence in the remote Indonesian province of Irian Jaya, legal aid sources there said today.

title: News You Can Use
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TRINET CORPORATE REALTY TRUST INC., San Francisco, a real estate investment trust, bought a Dallas-area office building from Koll Real Estate Group for $45.7 million.

title: ZAPATA STOCK DOUBLES AFTER COMPANY SPLITS
description: The Zapata Corporation is splitting into two entities: Zapata, which includes the company's marine protein and food packaging business, and the ZAP Corporation, consisting of its Internet operations. Wall Street welcomed the deal. Shares of Zapata, which is based in Houston, more than doubled, soaring $11.625 each, to $21.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. As part of its plan to focus on Internet business, ZAP will offer links to electronic-commerce businesses. ZAP formally announced it would acquire 21 Internet sites and electronic commerce businesses that would be integrated into ZAP.com, the new company's Web site. Zapata also said it would buy back, over time, up to five million shares, or 21.5 percent, of its stock.

title: No End to Suffering
description: The news flashes carry eerie echoes of the old days. Two girls are repeatedly raped by parents in a Brooklyn home deemed safe by the city. An emaciated toddler hidden in a dark, airless room nearly starves on a urine-stained mattress because his caseworker fails to visit his foster home in Staten Island.

title: Italians Recover 3 Paintings Stolen in a Brazen Robbery
description: Bursting into apartments in Turin and Rome in pre-dawn raids, the Italian police today recovered two Van Goghs and a Cezanne stolen from the National Gallery of Modern Art. The raids ended a seven-week search for the paintings, among Italy's most valuable post-Impressionist works.

title: Foreign Affairs; Mideast Future Shock
description: The big talk in Israel last week was that three young Israeli software designers, and their venture capitalist backer, just sold their two-year-old company -- Mirabilis -- to America Online for $287 million. Mirabilis is an Internet communications tool that allows users to talk and exchange computer files while on line. Israel is now second only to the U.S. in the number of computer-related start-up companies spawned in the 1990's.

title: Russia Should Put Its People First
description: Last year Yegor Gaidar, the architect of Russia's early economic reforms, predicted that by the end of 1998 Russia would be where Poland was at the beginning of 1992 -- that is, well on its way to a market economy.

title: Teachers Urge a Renewed Effort on Merger
description: A day after rejecting a merger with the American Federation of Teachers, delegates at the National Education Association convention gave their leaders a green light to negotiate a revised merger agreement more to the delegates' liking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, WILLIAM F.
description: MAYER-William F. On July 5, 1998. Of Rye, New York. Beloved husband of Susan S. Devoted father of Paul and Robert. Loving brother of Elsie Lewis and Irma Rathe. Dear grandfather of Daniel, Gregory & Anna. A religious service will be held Tuesday, July 7, 10 AM at the Community Synagogue of Rye, 200 Forest Avenue, Rye, New York. Interment Cedar Park Cemetery, Westwood, N.J.

title: In Closing, Maddox Tells Jury Brawley Suit Is a 'Lynching'
description: In his summation today, Alton H. Maddox Jr. told jurors that the Tawana Brawley defamation suit was an effort at ''three judicial lynchings'' of the Brawley advisers, ''financed by rich fat cats in New York City.''

description: SCHUCK-George, Jr. The Officers, Staff and Members of Local Union #

title: 'Peony' Ticket Holders Have Three Options
description: Ticket holders for ''The Peony Pavilion,'' which has been canceled at Lincoln Center Festival '98, have options, the festival has announced. The face value of a ticket may be applied toward the cost of a ticket to another festival performance, the ticket may be donated to the festival as a charitable donation or a refund may be obtained by mail or at the box office.

title: Clinton Agrees to Meet Yeltsin In Russia in Early September
description: President Clinton has agreed to travel to Russia in early September to meet with President Boris N. Yeltsin, although the Russian legislature has not fulfilled a request to ratify an important arms control treaty signed with the United States, the White House announced today.

title: FAIRCHILD PLANS TO SPIN OFF UNIT THAT MAKES FASTENERS
description: The Fairchild Corporation, a maker of aerospace and semiconductor products, said yesterday that it would make its fastener business a separate company, dropping an earlier plan to spin off its technology unit and other interests. The unit, which will be known as Fairchild Fasteners when it becomes a separate company, is the No. 1 maker of heavy-duty screws and latches for the aerospace industry. It had sales of $269 million in its 1997 fiscal year and also makes fasteners for the automotive and electronics markets. Fairchild, based in Chantilly, Va., also said it wanted to sell its Turkish can maker and its real estate holdings on Long Island and to find a merger partner or ''strategic ally'' for the Fairchild Technologies unit. Fairchild's shares rose $1.1875 each, to $21.4375.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Tuesday about the signing of a contract in Beijing for Air China to buy Boeing jets misidentified an American shown shaking hands with the president of Air China. He was Raymond W. Bracy, president of Boeing China, not Commerce Secretary William M. Daley.

title: Workers at Rally Should Fear for Jobs
description: To the Editor:

description: GOLDEN-Fred. Died July 3, 1998. The Board of Directors of the Carcinoid Cancer Foundation, Inc. records with deep sorrow the unexpected passing of our dear friend and fellow Board member, Fred Golden. We extend our deepest condolences to his loving wife, Hope, and family. His sage counsel and ''joie de vivre'' made him a rare person who will always be missed and never forgotten. David H. Polinger, President Richard R. P. Warner, M.D. Medical Director Monica Warner, Director, Development and Research

title: Worries Over Japan and U.S. Send Treasury Prices Higher
description: Concerns about Japan and signs of a slowdown in the United States sent Treasury prices higher yesterday.

title: Bail Is $150,000 for Man Accused of Firing Shots
description: The man accused of firing five bullets into a house in Linden where a paroled rapist was living was ordered held in $150,000 bail by a Superior Court judge who also ordered the suspect to avoid contact with the parolee.

title: L-3 COMMUNICATIONS HOLDINGS TO BUY SPD TECHNOLOGIES
description: The military contractor L-3 Communications Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the privately held SPD Technologies Inc. for $230 million. SPD Technologies, based in Philadelphia and Anaheim, Calif., provides electronics and electrical power products to the Navy and other customers. It had revenue of $170 million in 1997. L-3 Communications, based in New York, is a supplier of secure communications systems. The company, which is 50.1 percent owned by Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. and 34 percent owned by the Lockheed Martin Corporation, reported revenue of $186.6 million in the quarter ended March 31. Its shares rose $2.375 each, to $36.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Black Pioneer Answers the Call; Detroit Entrepreneur Sees 'Sleeper' Market in Namibia
description: This windswept capital in the Namibian desert is not the kind of arena where Michael Jackson normally plays. And 500 buttoned-down executives and finance ministers talking tariffs are not his usual audience. But the singer came in May, striding up a conference room aisle in full fedora, lipstick and Sgt. Pepper jacket, with a pushy entourage trailing along, to give a quick speech deploring ''the plight of the children of the universe.''

title: Jury Gets Case in Second Trial Under the Death Penalty Law
description: With an impassioned closing statement, the lawyer trying to save Dalkeith McIntosh from a death sentence urged jurors to put themselves in his place as they considered his guilt or innocence in the face of first-degree murder charges.

title: Doctor Tells of Issuing Steroids to East Germans
description: A former East German sports doctor admitted today in a Berlin court that he handed out anabolic steroids for use by young female swimmers. It was the first formal confession of such practices by an official of the Communist state that once churned out gold-medal winning athletes with bizarre consistency.

title: Burnett and MacManus Continue Talks
description: The Leo Burnett Company in Chicago and MacManus Group in New York said yesterday that they were continuing discussions on possibly broadening a media alliance.

title: Palm Founders to Form New Company
description: The two founders of Palm Computing, an innovative Silicon Valley company that helped pioneer the market for hand-held pen-based computers, have left the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, JEFFREY ALAN
description: GOLDSTEIN-Jeffrey Alan. Died at the age of 20 on July 5, 1998 after a tragic accident. Cherished son of Sharon and Stephen Cutler and Jane and Steven Goldstein. Dear brother of Eric, Evan and Nicole. Grandson of Ann and Percy Goldstein. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. For day and time of service call 516-295-3100.

title: Gay Rights Movement Meets Big Resistance in S. Carolina
description: It was not by accident that the first shot of the Civil War was fired in this tradition-bound state, where few things are viewed so seriously as an assault on the inherited culture. It is a place where lawmakers still scoff at suggestions that the Confederate battle flag be removed from the Capitol dome and where only a Federal court order enabled women to enroll at the Citadel.

title: Another Damaging Damages Bill
description: The Senate leadership and the White House are rushing to win approval of a new, slimmer product liability bill that omits some offensive provisions from prior versions, but still retains their main defect. Like its flawed predecessors, the new proposal would cut back on the rights of consumers and weaken the ability of juries in civil suits to punish the makers and sellers of unsafe products.

title: Fallon Names Office President
description: Fallon McElligott said yesterday that it had named Alison Burns to head its New York office as president. Bill Westbrook, president of the agency's flagship Minneapolis office, had been handling those duties on an interim basis. Ms. Burns, 35, had been president and chief executive of KTNY, the New York arm of a London-based executive search firm, Kendall Tarrent P.L.C. Before that, she worked for agencies like Bartle Bogle Hegarty and Young & Rubicam Advertising and for marketers like Pepsico Worldwide.

title: Williams Reinjures Knee In Minor League Tuneup
description: Bernie Williams, the Yankees' center fielder, reinjured his right knee last night while making his first rehabilitation appearance in a Class A game in Clearwater, Fla., and will be out of action another week, or possibly longer, according to General Manager Brian Cashman.

title: Essay; It's July, the Greenest Month in Hospitals. No Need to Panic
description: THIS is New Year's week at your local hospital, where July 1 marks a beginning just as fraught with symbolism and expectation as Jan. 1 is elsewhere. Medical schools end in June and hospital training programs start in July; last week everyone in them lurched a step forward.

title: Disputed Hourly Pay Rule at Heart of G.M. Strike
description: Until the strike began a month ago, Steven M. White's work day at a General Motors parts factory here followed a familiar routine. Arriving at 6:30 every morning, he stood at an assembly line welding steel rails in semidarkness, wearing heavy protective clothing in a factory with no air-conditioning and temperatures exceeding 100 degrees on summer days.

title: If These Stones Could Talk . . . A Polynesian Mystery Tale; Easter Island Giving Up Its Secrets, But Only Grudgingly
description: ON the sacred slopes of Rano Raraku, a Polynesian Mount Olympus, the impassive faces on huge statues carved out of soft volcanic stone look across fields tinted dusty pink by the ripening tall grass and far out to the blue waters of the Pacific Ocean. The vista encompasses the entire world that could have been known to the creators of the enigmatic statues, the most distinctive expressions of an ancient society coping with life in isolation on the most remote inhabited island on Earth.

title: Corrections
description: Excerpts on Saturday from President Clinton's news conference in Hong Kong, transcribed by The Associated Press, rendered a phrase incorrectly in referring to United States policy toward Taiwan. It is ''the three noes policy,'' not the ''three note policy.'' (''Three noes'' refers to a State Department statement last fall that Washington did not support Taiwan independence, did not favor ''two Chinas'' or ''one China, one Taiwan'' and did not back Taiwan membership in international organizations made up of sovereign countries.)

title: CNN Employees Pointedly Ask How Managers Escaped Purge
description: Hundreds of angry Cable News Network staff members in the network's Atlanta headquarters and more calling in from CNN's bureaus around the world took part in two meetings at which some demanded to know why the network's top managers stayed on the job after last week's apology and repudiation of its report that the American military had used nerve gas on a 1970 mission in Laos.

title: First Genocide Trial of a Bosnian Serb Opens in The Hague
description: The United Nations tribunal dealing with war crimes in the former Yugoslavia today opened the trial of a Bosnian Serb charged with the crime of genocide, the first time an international trial for genocide has taken place in Europe.

title: Dairy Management Changes Agencies
description: Dairy Management Inc., which conducts advertising and promotional programs for the American Dairy Association and the National Dairy Council, said yesterday that it would move media planning and buying duties for cheese and milk campaigns to Bozell Worldwide and TN Media in New York, units of True North Communications, from the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago, effective on Oct. 5. Billings were estimated at $50 million.

title: King Jury Adjourns After a Full Day
description: The jury in Don King's Federal wire-fraud trial adjourned yesterday after its first full day of deliberations over whether the promoter and his company defrauded a Lloyd's of London insurance syndicate out of $350,000 by submitting a fake contract for a canceled 1991 Julio Cesar Chavez bout.

title: France Hoping for Title At End of the Rainbow
description: France is the home team in this World Cup, and yet much of that team is rarely at home. Like French wines and designs, French soccer players are a popular export.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RETREATS. After three days of gains, crude oil prices fell on growing skepticism about production cuts planned by OPEC nations and other oil exporters. August crude oil fell 58 cents, to $13.92 a barrel.

title: Look What's Happened to Those Bananas
description: ''Yes! We Have No Bananas,'' Frank Silver and Irving Cohn's 1923 novelty sensation, is a nugget of transcendent pop nonsense that borrows its melody from an 1860's song called ''The Vacant Chair,'' which in turn was adapted from another 1860's song, ''When I Saw Sweet Nellie Home.'' The very same tune later influenced Cole Porter's ''Old Fashioned Garden.''

title: VERISIGN BUYS SECURE IT, RIVAL IN INTERNET SERVICES
description: Verisign Inc., an Internet security company, said yesterday that it had acquired the closely held Secure It Inc. for about $69.1 million of stock. Verisign, based in Mountain View, Calif., issued 1.67 million shares to buy Secure It, a 20-month-old company based in Norcross, Ga., that provides Internet security consulting, testing and educational services to clients.

title: Those Who Can't Teach
description: This spring, Massachusetts administered its first statewide test for candidates hoping to teach in the public schools. The recent announcement of the results has provoked astonishment and outrage. Almost 60 percent of the candidates failed. Thirty percent failed a basic test in reading and writing, and the failure rate on subject-matter tests varied from 63 percent in mathematics to 18 percent in physical education.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEURTLEY, JASNA PERVAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURTLETAUB, BEATRICE
description: TURTLETAUB-Beatrice, wife of Alan Turtletaub, Chairman and Founder of The Money Store. Mrs. Turtletaub, the daughter of the late Morris and Nellie Feldman and her brother Bernard, founded Feldman's Department store in Lakewood, Toms River and Long Branch. Mrs. Turtletaub, born in Bordentown, married Alan in 1942. They resided in Short Hills and had seasonal residences in West End, NJ and Palm Beach, FL. Mrs. Turtletaub was very active in Jewish and community organizations among which is the Sisterhood of Temple B'nai Abraham, Daughters of Israel, Deborah Hospital, Auxillary of St. Barnabas Medical Center. Mrs. Turtletaub was very active in Meals On Wheels, B'nai B'rith, the N.J. Council of Jewish Women, Friends of the Millburn Library. She received the gold pin as a lifetime member of Hadassah, United Jewish Appeal Lion of Judah Award and past recipient of humanitarian awards from the Kidney Fund of New Jersey and Bezalel Hebrew School. Mrs. Turtletaub, besides her husband, Alan, is survived by her son Marc, CEO of The Money Store and nephews Mark Feibush and Jed Feibush and her grandson Alex Emil. In lieu of flowers donations in her memory may be made to The National Hadassah Foundation, New York, New York. Funeral services conducted from Temple B'nai Abraham, 300 East Northfield Road, Livingston, NJ 07039 on Tuesday, July 7, 1998 at 11:00 am. Entombment B'nai Abraham Memorial Park, Union, NJ. For information, The Menorah Chapels, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, NJ.

title: Union Pacific Fights Tougher Regulation
description: The Union Pacific Railroad, seeking to fend off demands for tougher Federal regulation, said today that congestion was easing, capacity expanding and competition with rival carriers intensifying.

title: 92 Holes Later, Pak Wins Second Major
description: It finally ended on the 20th playoff hole. It was the longest United States Women's Open ever, and one of the most dramatic, a compelling championship duel between two 20-year-olds seeking their place in their sport's history. And while Se Ri Pak's victory firmly established her as a new force in women's golf, the performance of Jenny Chuasiriporn, who nearly became the second amateur to win the Women's Open, was extraordinary in its own right.

title: After Legal Odyssey, Man Faces 2d Trial in Officer's Death
description: Many of his alibi witnesses are dead, crucial evidence has been lost and the police officers who arrested him have long since retired. But after a 22-year legal odyssey that has taken him from courtroom to prison to freedom and back again, Vincent James Landano is to go on trial again today for a murder he has consistently maintained he never committed.

title: Missing Woman, 82, and Tenant Are Sought
description: The police are searching for an 82-year-old woman who was last seen Sunday morning wearing her nightgown in her Upper East Side building, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Wider Strike in Puerto Rico
description: As many as 500,000 workers from 50 unions are expected to walk off their jobs on Tuesday in a show of support for striking Puerto Rico Telephone Company workers who are protesting plans to privatize the company.

title: Chess; Faster and More Accurate, Polgar Outplays Karpov
description: In an action match (30 minutes each for all moves) in Budapest, the top woman in chess, Judit Polgar, defeated the International Chess Federation's world champion, Anatoly Karpov, by 5 to 3. In the eight-game series, held June 9 to 12, the 21-year-old Polgar used the hot pace of her moves to confuse the slower, 47-year-old Karpov.

description: A day after a Protestant Orange Order parade was blocked from marching through a Catholic neighborhood, the British Parades Commission reversed two earlier decisions today and gave permission for another Protestant march to parade past a Catholic area.

title: Forsaking the Rat Race To Lend a Helping Hand

Tonight brings a sequel, an earnestly intentioned, earnestly delivered documentary that is heavy-handed enough to send viewers rushing to the shopping mall to waste some money.

title: Metro Business; Niagara Mohawk Is Sued

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROOSEVELT, W. EMLEN
description: ROOSEVELT-W. Emlen. Born New York City, August 29, 1917July 4, 1998. Eldest son of John Kean Roosevelt and Elise Annette Weinacht. Widower of Arlene King Roosevelt (12/75). Survived by his daughters Lucy M. Sewall/Rubinow of Brookline, Ma., the Reverend Nancy A. Roosevelt of Rochester, NY. Granddaughters: Jennifer R. Taylor of San Francisco, Constance M. Taylor of San Francisco, Margaret Sewall/Boogaard of Somerville, Ma. Sisters: Mrs James Armentrout, Jr of Ambler, Pa. Elizabeth E. Roosevelt of Oyster Bay, NY. Brothers Alfred James Roosevelt, Marfa, Texas, Peter Kean Roosevelt, Englewood, Colorado. W. Emlen Roosevelt was a close relative of Theodore Roosevelt. His grandfather and Theodore were first cousins. He attended Phillips Academy, Andover, Ma (1931-1935). Sailing was a family hobby and Emlen had a passion for it. At the age of 12, he was probably the second youngest ever to compete in the Bermuda races and when attending Princeton University he rowed on the crew. Princeton University (1935-1938) leaving in the middle of his Junior Year despite the fact that he held second honors as a student. Two reasons for leaving, he wanted to learn banking and he wanted to go to work. He was an Economics Major. His banking career began as a messenger boy at the Central Hanover Bank & Trust Company in New York. In June 1940 he was offered and accepted a partnership in his Uncle's investment banking firm (Roosevelt & Son). After his World War II duties were concluded he returned home a Major with the Bronze Star and a Meritorious Service Citation. He worked in the credit department of the Chemical Bank & Trust Company for two years and then left to join Dick & MerleSmith, an investment partnership that had been part of the old Roosevelt & Son prior to 1933. During this period he became a Director of the National State Bank of Elizabeth, of which his cousin John Kean was president. When John died in October of 1949, his associates offered Emlen the job. He became President of the National State Bank on January 1, 1950 and served in that capacity until 1984 and subsequently Chairman of the Board. He was named to the Regional Advisors Committee of the Comptroller of the Currency (1965-1968). He was also Chairman of the Alexian Brothers Hospital in Elizabeth, NJ (1973) being the first layman to be appointed to their Board of Trustees. He is a retired Director of the E'town Gas Company (subsidiary of NUI), Elizabethtown Water Company, Hackensack Water Company, now United Water Resources and Realty Transfer. He is also a retired Director and Trustee of Diocesan Investment Trust of the Diocese of New Jersey in Trenton. His Club memberships include: Sewanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, Oyster Bay, NY, Union Club, New York City, Manasquan River Golf Club, Manasquan, NJ. Baltusrol Golf Club, Springfield, NJ and the Down Town Association in New York City. His hobbies include Fishing, Photography, Birding and Sailing. In Lieu of Flowers Donations can be made to the following institutions of Charity of your choice: Princeton University, PO Box 46, Princeton, NJ 08544-0046, Trustees of Phillips Academy, 180 Main St, Andover, Ma 01810-4161, Youngs Memorial Cemetery Corporation, Box 720, Oyster Bay, New York 11771-0720. A Memorial Service will be held Wednesday July 15, 1998 at 11:00 AM in St John's on the Mountain Episcopal Church, Mount Harmony Road, Bernardsville. Interment Private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROD, JAMES P.
description: ROD-James P. The Board of Directors of Riverkeeper notes with great sorrow the death of Jim, age 53, our Vice President, on July 4 in New York City from cancer. A native of Ames, Iowa, he studied wildlife biology at Iowa State University and received a B.S. degree in journalism from Iona College. He was an educator and advocate who led a life in the exaltation and a defense of nature. In 1973, he became the Assistant to the President of the National Audubon Society, and in 1982 he assumed the post of manager and warden of Constitution Marsh Sanctuary in Garrison, N.Y., where, until a month ago, he established and ran an educational program for 5000 visitors a year. His favorite question repeated by every school child in the area was, ''Where do fish come from?'' His answer, ''Cattails,'' which provided a vivid lesson on habitat and the food web. Greatly respected, Jim received Audubon's Golden Egret Award last year. Our hearts go out to his wife, Dee, his mother and his brothers, Doug and Bill. There will be a service at 10:30AM, Thursday, July 9, at the Clinton Funeral Home in Cold Spring, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to National Audubon's Jim Rod Memorial Fund to establish an endowment dedicated to the support of activities at the marsh which he loved and for which he did so much. Contributions should be sent care of, Constitution Marsh Sanctuary, RFD #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASCOLO, ALFRED E.
description: MASCOLO-Alfred E. Emeritus Dean of Instructional Services and Professor of Business at Kingsborough Community College, The City University of New York. The adminstration, faculty, staff and students of Kingsborough Community College mourn the passing of a most valued colleague and friend on Sunday, July 5. Dean Mascolo joined Kingsborough on October 15, 1971, directing admissions, registration, and the computer center until his retirement in 1987. He was affiliated with a number of professional societies, including the Catholic Teachers Association, American Association of Collegiate Registrars and Officers of Admissions, and Schoolmen's Post 543, American Legion. Before coming to Kingsborough, Mr. Mascolo spent five years at Borough of Manhattan Community College, holding the posts of Dean of Institutional Services, Dean of Administration and Professor of Business Administration. His career in education began at New York City Community College, where he served as Associate Dean of Administration from 1950-1966. Mr. Mascolo was educated at New York University, where he earned a Bachelor of Science in 1961 and a Master of Arts in 1966. His dedication and professionalism were an inspiration to many members of the Kingsborough community. His warmth, his positive outlook, and his honesty will be greatly missed. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his family.

description: The Schering-Plough Corporation in Madison, N.J., said yesterday that it had signed Joan Lunden, a former host of ABC-TV's ''Good Morning America,'' as a spokeswoman for its Claritin prescription allergy remedy. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Home Run Fever
description: Baseball aficionados are savoring this summer's three-man assault on one of the game's most celebrated milestones, the single-season home run record. At midpoint of the season, Mark McGwire of the St. Louis Cardinals, Sammy Sosa of the Chicago Cubs and Ken Griffey Jr. of the Seattle Mariners are hitting long balls at a pace that, if sustained through September, would vault them past Roger Maris's mark of 61, set in 1961. McGwire, the leader, has already hit 37.

title: RUSSIANS SAY LOAN BY I.M.F. MAY FALL SHORT OF THE NEED
description: The International Monetary Fund and the Yeltsin Government are negotiating an aid package that may produce less money than foreign investors say is needed to help ease Russia's financial crisis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINTRAUB, MORRIS (A.K.A. MURRAY TRAUB)
description: WEINTRAUB-Morris (a.k.a. Murray Traub). Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Morris Weintraub, beloved father of our devoted member Susan Traub. Sincere condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVIN, MELVIN R.
description: LEVIN-Melvin R. 9 years, always remembered. Wife, Son, Daughter, Granddaughters, Grandsons, Great-Grandson Mel and Sister

title: Sometimes, Foster Care Is the Easy Way Out
description: Sometimes you see only what you want to see. That's the case with two very different recent cases of child abuse in New York City.

title: Test Kitchen; Where There's a Pit, There's a Way
description: AMONG kitchen gadgets, the cherry pitter has one of the narrowest roles. It does not slice cherries or remove their stems. It only pits them. And even if you're an ambitious cook, you use it maybe once a year. But a fresh cherry pie is almost impossible to make without one. So, cherry pitters hang in stores all year, and then sell like crazy during June and July, the cherry season.

title: 5 Indicted in Sex Abuse of 3 Children in Brooklyn
description: In a case that has raised questions about the city's monitoring of abused and neglected children, prosecutors in Brooklyn handed down a multiple-count indictment yesterday charging five adults with a variety of sex offenses involving three minors.

title: By the Book; Vegetable Dishes With Science
description: RECIPES for fennel, orange and walnut salad appear in many cookbooks. But few of these recipes instruct you to rub the onions with salt, which softens them and draws out any bitter juices, or to toss the fennel with lemon juice, salt and pepper as soon as it is sliced. The one in James Peterson's latest book, ''Vegetables'' (William Morrow, $40), does. And this is exactly what makes his book such a treasure, and so refreshingly different from the masses of vegetable cookbooks on bookstore shelves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CINDER, GAIL ELLEN
description: CINDER-Gail Ellen. Died peacefully on July 6, 1998. Beloved daughter of the late Helen Cinder, and the late Jules Cinder, devoted niece of Florence Aibel, Sol Shanus and the late Gilbert Shanus, cherished cousin of Sarene Shanus, Corey Shanus, Robin Shanus, & Susan Shanus Liucci. Graveside services at 2 P.M. Wednesday, July 8, Mount Lebanon Cemetery.

title: Fund-Raiser Is Indicted In Tax Case
description: A California Democratic fund-raiser who has already been charged with disguising illegal campaign contributions to President Clinton's re-election campaign was indicted today on Federal tax charges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, FRANK, MD.
description: GREENBERG-Frank, MD. Passed away on Friday, July 3, 1998 in Washington, DC at age 49 from complications due to AIDS. Dr Greenberg was a tireless advocate for people with genetic disorders and AIDS. He is survived by his partner, Linwood Vincent of Washington, DC; his mother, Frances Greenberg of Cupertino, CA; and his sister, Susan Englander, brother-in-law, Jeff Englander and nephews Jacob and Ben of San Jose, Ca. The family requests that memorial donations be made to charities supporting people with AIDS or genetic disorders. Memorial services will be held in Washington, DC and Houston, Tx. For information contact the Oak Hill Funeral Home, San Jose, Ca, 408-297-2447.

title: At Trial in Bomb Plot, Officer Recounts Raid
description: Testifying yesterday in the trial of two men accused of plotting to bomb a subway station last year, a police officer who took part in the violent predawn raid that led to their arrests said he fired at the two defendants after one of them tried to take his gun and the other lunged toward a bag he believed contained a bomb.

title: Alcoa's Profits Exceed Estimates
description: The Aluminum Company of America, the world's largest aluminum producer, reported today that it had a greater-than-expected gain of 6.3 percent in its second-quarter profit as increased shipments offset lower aluminum prices.

title: Wine Talk; The Important First Sip: Not to Be Taken Lightly
description: DO you remember the wine that first won you over? The bottle that first made you say, ''I don't know anything about wine but this is good stuff.''

title: Court Bars Damages In Touch-Football Injury
description: A man who sued Middletown Township because he tore cartilage in his knee while playing touch football in a municipal parking lot with potholes is not entitled to damages, the state's Supreme Court ruled yesterday.

title: Stari Tng Journal; Below It All in Kosovo, A War's Glittering Prize
description: The metal cage tumbled to the guts of the Stari Tng mine, with its glittering veins of lead, zinc, cadmium, gold and silver, its stagnant pools of water and muck, its steamy blasts, its miles of dank, gloomy tunnels and its vast stretches of Stygian darkness.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Chancellor Media Is Buying Lin TV for $902.7 Million

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENRIETTE, MARCUS
description: HENRIETTE-Marcus. The Department of Medicine of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine notes with deep regret the passing of our Emeritus Associate Professor, who was a long-time expert & highly respected chest physician. Milford Fulop, M.D. James Scheuer, M.D. M. Henry Williams, M.D.

title: Owen McGivern, 87, Dies; Judge Led Appellate Court
description: Owen McGivern, the son of an iceman who with the backing of Tammany Hall, Manhattan's powerful Democratic organization, rose through the ranks to become presiding justice of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, died on Monday at New York University Medical Center. He was 87.

title: A Pack Rat's Art Treasures; For Morgan Library, Pierre Matisse's Archives Are a Bonanza
description: During his 60 years as a dealer, Pierre Matisse exhibited some of the greatest artists of this century in his gallery in the Fuller Building at 41 East 57th Street, including modern masters like Miro, Balthus, Chagall, Dubuffet, Tanguy, Mondrian, Giacometti, de Chirico and his own father, Henri Matisse.

title: Left Bank to Right Wing, a Nation Cheers
description: A strange thing has happened on the way to the World Cup final: this fractious country, never in agreement about anything, eternally divided, deeply skeptical, has united around a soccer team that is now lauded by workers, politicians and even intellectuals.

title: A Hamilton Monument? Not on the Merits
description: To the Editor:

title: Roughnecks Of Distinction; Oilfield Workers Acquire Status in Labor Shortage
description: For Daniel Shumate, a 32-year-old parolee, it's another chance to get his life on track. For Melissa Bolton, 23 and also a parolee, it's an opportunity to show that a woman can handle heavy work in the oilfields. For Ruben Garza, 20, it's a way to break out of toiling at minimum wage. And for Ben Hilgreth, 21, a college student, it's a way to build up a stake that he can use to invest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, LILLIAN J.
description: FISHER-Lillian J. The William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Insititue and Society note with profound sorrow the sudden passing of an esteemed graduate and member. Dr. Fisher's vibrant career was exemplified by her openness to new ideas and by her bold and pioneering spirit. One of the first psychologists to work at the North Side Center in Harlem, she also traveled to India on a Fulbright, to Great Britain for a series of interviews with R.D. Laing, and always pursued her fervent interest in the arts. Our heartfelt sympathies to her beloved sons, her dear family members, friends and colleagues. Marylou Lionells, Ph.D., Dir. White Insititute Robert Watson, Ph.D., President White Society

title: VERIO BUYS TABNET, WEB SITE CREATOR, FOR $45.5 MILLION
description: Verio Inc., an Internet service provider, acquired Tabnet, which helps in setting up World Wide Web sites, for $45.5 million in cash. Verio said it would also pay as much as $43.2 million if Tabnet meets certain levels of revenue and cash-flow growth, through December. Verio, based in Englewood, Colo., has bought more than 30 smaller Internet service providers since 1996. With Tabnet, it gets a large collection of registered Internet, or ''domain,'' names as well as Tabnet's advertising agreements with top Internet sites. Verio, which went public in May at $23 a share, holds more than 55,000 domain names. Its shares rose 12.5 cents, to $27.25.

title: Arafat Likely to Declare Statehood in '99
description: With every day that passes without movement toward an Israeli-Palestinian settlement, the probability grows that in 10 months' time, probably on May 4, Yasir Arafat will declare a Palestinian state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, CURTIS
description: BERGER-Curtis. Age 72. Died July 6, 1998 of cancer. Beloved husband of Vivian. Devoted father of Ellen Lewis and John, Cathy and Wendy Berger, and loving grandfather of eleven. Caring brother of Gloria Drehmel, Glenna Cook, and Philip Berger. Graduate of the University of Rochester and Yale Law School. Lawrence A. Wien Professor of Real Estate Law at Columbia University, where he taught since 1962. Among numerous professional activities, past president of the Association of American Law Schools and The Bridge. Author of many publications, including casebooks on property, real estate law, and partnership taxation. Also an avid birdwatcher. Services Thursday, 11:15 AM at the Riverside, 76th and Amsterdam Avenue. There will be no calling hours. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Bridge, 248 West 108 Street, New York, NY 10025.

title: Dancers Leap Past Death To Reclaim Life's Rhythm
description: Celestin Minani was only 17 when he joined the National Ballet of Rwanda. His father and sisters danced with the troupe, he said, and his brothers were drummers, ''so I was pushed in that direction.''

title: The Battle Over Hog Factories
description: Hogs used to be a staple of the small-farm economy. But as American agriculture has grown more specialized, they have begun to be raised in concentrated numbers in confinement systems. These operations contain between 2,000 and 100,000 sows, which eat, excrete and reproduce in metal barns with concrete floors. The waste is stored in lagoons and eventually sprayed on fields.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday describing the election outlook in Germany reversed the numbers for eligible voters in western and eastern Germany and omitted the date of the figures. In 1994, there were 46.2 million voters in the west and 14.2 million in the east.

title: Yankees' Williams and Nelson Reinjured
description: The All-Star break is supposed to be for rest and relaxation, but for the Yankees this year, it's all about reinjury and rehabilitation. The outfielder Bernie Williams and the reliever Jeff Nelson, both of whom already are on the disabled list, suffered injuries Monday that will keep them sidelined longer than expected.

title: Guilty Plea in Death of Newborn at Prom
description: Rather than risk a murder conviction and life in prison, the New Jersey teen-ager accused of killing her newborn son at her senior prom 13 months ago has decided to plead guilty to a lesser charge, a person familiar with the case said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REIZMAN, ELFRIEDE
description: REIZMAN-Elfriede. Beloved wife of the late Marcel. Devoted mother of Victor Reizman, Loretta Lalin, Vivian Atlas & Peter Reizman. Cherished aunt, loving grandmother of eleven & great grandmother of six. Services are at The New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York, Thursday, 1 PM.

title: Vanbiesbrouck's Signing Frees Up Others
description: John Vanbiesbrouck signed with the Philadelphia Flyers yesterday, leaving Mike Richter and Curtis Joseph as the only prominent goalies on the free-agent market and strengthening the position of the Rangers in talks with Richter.

title: GENE LOGIC TO PAY $38 MILLION IN STOCK FOR ONCORMED
description: Gene Logic Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Oncormed Inc., a genetic research company, for as much as $38.2 million in stock. Gene Logic will swap 0.48 share for each Oncormed share, though the value will not exceed $3.79 a share. Shares of Gene Logic fell 25 cents, to $7.9375. Shares of Oncormed were unchanged at $3.3125. Oncormed's stock has fallen 42 percent in the last year. The company has been shedding some of its genetic testing programs to focus on the study of how people's genes determine how they may react to medicine.

title: Meet the Quarrymen, Minus the Famous Alumni
description: Every career has to start somewhere, and John Lennon's started when he was playing skiffle music with the Quarrymen in the late 1950's. A rock footnote came to life when the Quarrymen performed on Monday night at the Bottom Line.

title: An Awkward Ally
description: With the abrupt death yesterday of Nigeria's most prominent civilian politician, Moshood K. O. Abiola, Nigeria has suddenly lost in the space of only one month the two leaders whose rivalry has locked this country in a costly four-year stalemate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRIMAVERA, ANNE M. (NEE FREVOLA)
description: PRIMAVERA-Anne M. (nee Frevola). July 5, 1998. Beloved wife of the late George J., M.D. Loving mother of Dr. John A. and Carol Burcham. Dear grandmother of Lt. jg John Peter & Danielle Buser. Devoted sister of Elena J. Frevola. Visiting Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9PM, McLaughlin & Sons, Third Ave. at 97 Street, Bklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 11 AM, Our Lady of Angels Church. In lieu of flowers, donations to Victory Memorial Hospital Fund appreciated.

title: Possible Mistrial Looms in King Case
description: The trial of Don King and his company on wire fraud charges veered toward a possible mistrial yesterday when the jury forewoman said she was convinced that a verdict was impossible because of the intransigence of one juror.

title: Evolutionary Biology Begins Tackling Public Doubts
description: As a major scientific field, evolutionary biology is in an extraordinary position: its basic tenets, surveys show, are rejected as false by one of every two Americans.

title: For Weiss, an Ovation to Remember
description: Perhaps no player will hold the memory of the All-Star Game dearer than Walt Weiss, the National League's starting shortstop, who received the longest ovation from the predominantly Colorado Rockies' crowd last night during the player introductions at Coors Field and went on to get two hits, drive in a run and score a run in a losing effort.

title: Hold Teachers to Higher Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: Sanwa Bank Liquidating U.S. Securities Unit
description: Sanwa Bank Ltd. of Japan said yesterday that it would liquidate its United States securities unit, the Sanwa Securities (USA) Company, in a move to concentrate on more profitable operations. The unit will give up its status as a primary dealer for United States Treasury securities and exit the business of United States Government securities, the company said.

title: California's Budget Struggle Is Bitter Despite Big Surplus
description: Gov. Pete Wilson began his tenure here seven summers ago with the largest budget gap that any state ever faced, a $14.3 billion shortfall that forced him and the Legislature to raise $7 billion in new taxes and slash spending by the same amount. The budget was finally passed 17 days after the July 1 deadline, and the next year, the wrangling was even worse, with a record 63-day standoff over how to spread the pain.

title: Company Led by Top Admiral Buys Michigan Vaccine Lab
description: The State of Michigan yesterday approved the sale of the nation's only licensed manufacturer of anthrax and rabies vaccine to a company led by Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., a former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the United States Ambassador to Britain until last year.

title: CHESAPEAKE ENERGY CONSIDERS POSSIBLE SALE OR MERGER
description: The Chesapeake Energy Corporation said yesterday that it was exploring business alternatives, including a possible sale or merger of the company. Chesapeake, an oil and gas company, said the review was based on a desire to raise its stock price. Shares of Chesapeake slipped 31.25 cents, to $3.50, giving the company a market capitalization of almost $368 million. Chesapeake expects to report a second-quarter loss of up to $250 million, which it attributes to lower oil and gas prices and acquisitions completed in the second quarter. Chesapeake, based in Oklahoma City, had 1997 revenues of $280.3 million.

title: Career of a CNN Star Hangs in the Balance Over a Repudiated Report
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Journal; Milli Vanilli News
description: If you're a star, you can get away with -- well, if not murder, then at least with accusing other people falsely of murder.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''In the past, the choices have been so painful that they led to paralysis. It takes two or three months to decide whether you're going to take guide dogs away from blind people. But there isn't any road map for what they're dealing with now.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Sam Shepard, Beyond the Writing and Acting
description: As a strong, silent type on the movie screen and, more important, the author of plays that are loud eruptions of anguished language, Sam Shepard has long been an odd, contradictory presence on the American cultural scene. He's well-known but unknown, handsome and seductive but willfully remote. He's almost too easily the archetype of the authentic American, at home in the wide open spaces but not really at home anywhere.

title: Nissan Diesel Said to Be In Engine-Supply Talks
description: The Nissan Diesel Motor Company, Japan's fourth-largest truck maker, may supply diesel engines to Daimler-Benz A.G. of Germany, according to an anonymously sourced Japanese newspaper report yesterday. Nissan Diesel shares jumped 27 percent, to 372 yen ($2.68), after the newspaper Nihon Keizai Shimbun said the truck maker might supply ''several tens of thousands'' a year of its newly developed, fuel-efficient diesel engines to Daimler, starting next year.

title: Florida's Flat Land and Shrubs a Haven for Fires
description: Tools for fighting wildfires these days include airplanes to dump chemicals and water, satellites to locate hot-spots and laptop computers to keep track of blazes, trucks and people. But the firefighters' basic technique has been the same for decades: trying to throw a defensive perimeter around each fire, and praying for rain.

title: Palestinians' U.N. Role Widened; A U.S. 'No' Vote Is Overwhelmed
description: The General Assembly voted overwhelmingly today to give the Palestinians a larger role in the United Nations and a voice in many of its peripheral activities.

title: PROFIT RECOVERY IN CASH AND STOCK DEAL FOR LODER, DREW
description: Profit Recovery Group International said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the privately held Loder, Drew & Associates for $70 million in cash plus 803,535 restricted shares. At current prices, the stock consideration would be worth about $24.8 million. Profit Recovery also agreed to pay Loder, Drew up to an additional $70 million based on financial performance. Loder, Drew, based in San Juan Capistrano, Calif., provides accounts payable and other recovery audit services to manufacturing, financial and other nonretail companies. Profit Recovery, based in Atlanta, provides accounts payable and recovery audit services in retail, government and health care sectors. Shares of Profit Recovery rose $4.3125, to $32.625.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, SANFORD H. (SANDE)
description: EISENBERG-Sanford H. (Sande). On July 6, 1998 at age 80 at home in Chevy Chase, MD. Cherished husband of Patricia. Beloved father of Nancy & Jean. Grandfather of Brittany and Courtney. Dear brother of Everett Eisenberg and Sydelle Diner. He is mourned by family, patients, friends, colleagues and staff who were privileged to be a part of the life of this extraordinarily caring man. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be made to HealthCare Chaplaincy, Eisenberg Fund for Bioethics, 307 E. 60 St., NY, NY 10022.

title: Court Orders Secret Service To Testify in Lewinsky Case
description: Dealing a sharp setback to the Clinton Administration, a Federal appeals court today ordered Secret Service officials to testify before a grand jury about what they knew of any relationship between President Clinton and Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: GEMSTAR INTERNATIONAL SHARES RISE ON UNSOLICITED BID
description: The shares of Gemstar International Group Ltd. rose yesterday after United Video Satellite Group Inc. made an unsolicited $2.8 billion cash bid late on Monday. Gemstar's shares rose $1.125 each, to $43.625, in Nasdaq trading after touching a 52-week high $46.25 early in the day. For the year ended March 31, Gemstar had revenue of $126.6 million. United Video, which is controlled by two affiliates of Tele-Communications Inc., the No. 2 cable television company, is offering $45 each for Gemstar's 62 million shares outstanding, as it seeks to expand its television listings business. Gemstar said in a statement that it was evaluating the offer, though Gemstar has had previous discussions with United Video that have failed because of several concerns.

title: Mr. Starr's Coercion
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Wild West? Nyet, St. Petersburg
description: If you believe the portrait of St. Petersburg presented by Aleksei Balabanov's terrifically stylish gangster film ''Brother,'' the former Leningrad has become a lawless, shoot-'em-up frontier town in the post-Soviet era. While the city's rootless youths clutch voraciously at the cheesiest elements of Western pop culture, warring outlaw factions have turned the city into an Eastern European version of 1930's Chicago.

title: Repairs Start After Vandalism In Historic Black Cemetery
description: Nearly a year after vandals destroyed a historic black graveyard on Staten Island, church members began work yesterday on restoring 26 marble and granite stones that were toppled like dominoes and smashed to pieces.

title: Sports Concerns Wary on Profits
description: Venator Group Inc. and Sports Authority Inc. said yesterday that their second-quarter earnings would be less than expected, causing their shares to fall and threatening the merger of the two biggest United States sellers of athletic shoes.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Guide column of the Connecticut section on Sunday about an exhibition by Yale graduates at the Yale Art Gallery misstated the date of a talk and screening by the filmmaker and writer Michael Rush. They are at 4 P.M. this Sunday; they were not last Sunday.

title: Mr. Starr's Coercion
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Backs Ouster Of a Judge Assailed For Lenient Rulings
description: Lorin Duckman, the New York City judge who became a favorite target of politicians' complaints about a fuzzy-minded, too-lenient judiciary, lost his final bid to retain his job today when the state's highest court ruled that a state commission was right to remove him from the bench because he abused prosecutors and showed a bias for criminal defendants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARBE, ERNEST H.
description: GARBE-Ernest H. On June 28, 1998, peacefully at home in the house of his birth in his beloved Brooklyn. He was devoted to his family, his church and his country. A W.W. II veteran, he served as a non-commissioned officer, 389th Port Battalion, U.S. Army, European Theater. A graduate of Columbia College, in New York City, and a true believer in the fraternal, moral and patriotic principles of his beloved Phi Kappa Psi Fraternity, he lived and served by the principles he learned so well. Service Wednesday at 10 A.M., Church of the Virgin Mary, 216 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Food Stuff
description: A Tell-All Volume About Smoothies and Juices

title: Editors' Note
description: An obituary on March 18 about Anne Sayre, an author, described a book she wrote in 1975 about the role of Rosalind Franklin, a British biologist, in the discovery of the structure of DNA 45 years ago. The article recounted an incident in 1952 in which Maurice Wilkins, a colleague of Dr. Franklin's, showed other scientists in the field an X-ray photograph she had taken.

title: About New York; Justice Takes Its Sweet Time In Son's Death
description: REYNOLD JORDAN waited three years to see his son Trevor's killer convicted. During that vigil, he and his family were frustrated by the knowledge that although two of them had seen Patrick Stephens kill 19-year-old Trevor outside their Brooklyn home, the gunman was living in the relative refuge of Florida.

title: A youth-influenced anti-smoking effort doesn't mince words.
description: THE next phase of an ambitious anti-smoking campaign, created for and in part by teen-agers, is as audacious as any tobacco company advertisement featuring anthropomorphic animals, fit and healthy athletes or models who flash sparkling white teeth.

title: Sports of The Times; 'I've Got To Drive The Guys In'
description: UNTIL a month ago, Juan Gonzalez had never heard of Hack Wilson nor of Wilson's major league record of 190 runs batted in. But for the Texas Rangers' slugger, it's now a magic name, a magic number and a magic mission.

title: In Interior Design, a Clash of Rivals; Owner of Uptown Center Wants Promotional Street Signs
description: Just before an annual design and furnishings trade show in Manhattan last fall, a block of East 58th Street sprouted a new, chintz-draped street sign proclaiming it ''Designers Way,'' and East 59th Street was transformed into ''Decorators Way.''

title: How the U.N. Voted
description: Following is the roll-call vote today by which the General Assembly adopted a resolution giving the Palestin-ians a larger role in the United Nations:

title: Metro Business; Payroll Tax Refunds Begin in Jersey City
description: After a two-year legal battle in which the Jersey City business community eventually triumphed over its Republican Mayor, the city has begun refunding $2.8 million in municipal payroll taxes it collected in 1996.

title: Jenny Craig Names Finalists in Review
description: Jenny Craig Inc. in La Jolla, Calif., which operates weight-loss programs, has further narrowed a review for the creative and media parts of its domestic account, with billings estimated at $40 million.

title: Campbell Driving Favorite in Pace
description: Sealed N Delivered, last year's top 2-year-old pacing colt, will be teamed again with driver John Campbell as the 2-1 favorite for Saturday night's $1 million Meadowlands Pace in East Rutherford, N.J. A field of 10 3-year-old pacers was entered yesterday for the race, with Sealed N Delivered drawing post position No. 8.

title: London and Frankfurt Stock Exchanges Form Alliance
description: In the clearest sign yet that national boundaries are disappearing within European financial markets, the stock exchanges of London and Frankfurt announced a broad alliance today aimed at creating a pan-European trading system.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Some Clouds Dim a Star of On-Line Trading
description: Datek Online, one of the nation's fastest-growing on-line brokerage firms, has postponed an initial public offering of stock because of widening investigations into its trading practices, according to bankers who were briefed on the deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THURSH, JUNE R.
description: THURSH-June R. On July 4, 1998 after a lengthy illness. Beloved wife of the late Joseph J. Thursh. Devoted sister of Lillian, Irvin and Priscilla. Loving mother of Joan. Grandmother of Louis and Jody. Aunt of Sue & Bob, Joel and Lisa, Stacy, Bobby and Bonnie. Loyal friend and inspiring teacher and mentor to many. A pioneering advertising woman, recipient of the prestigious Ad Woman of the Year Award and numerous other professional awards and honors, she was Advertising Director of J.C. Penney in New York City and Lits in Philadelphia. Services are on Thursday, July 9 at 11 A.M., Montefiore Cemetery, Church Road, Fox Chase, PA.

title: Paris Aghast at Mere Hint of U.S. Stake in the Tower
description: Sell the Eiffel Tower to the Americans? Mayor Jean Tiberi of Paris was as outraged at the idea today as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York City might be at a suggestion that the Brooklyn Bridge was for sale.

title: The Chef
description: THERE is nothing more satisfying than a warm stew or ragout. Although they are among my favorite dishes, they are difficult to serve at a serious restaurant. The very qualities that make them so pleasing -- a comforting formlessness and simplicity -- also make them less than elegant on the plate. And on a nice evening out, elegant is what many people want.

title: Court Allows Increase In La Guardia Flights
description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that the United States Department of Transportation could allow more flights into and out of La Guardia Airport, rejecting a suit by the city charging that the additional flights would substantially increase noise and automobile traffic in Queens.

title: REPUBLIC ENGINEERED IN TALKS WITH BLACKSTONE AFFILIATE
description: Republic Engineered Steels Inc., a steel-bar producer, said yesterday that it was in talks to be acquired by an affiliate of the Blackstone Group. Negotiations with Blackstone, an investment firm, started after Republic Engineered announced last month that it expected a takeover bid from an unnamed suitor. Republic Engineered, based in Massillon, Ohio, with sales of $753.5 million last year, has 10 plants in six states. Blackstone's holdings include real estate, hotels and a nickel producer. Shares of Republic rose 37.5 cents, to $5. It disclosed the Blackstone talks after the close of trading in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLEW, MARION ELIZABETH (NEE HUGHES)
description: GLEW-Marion Elizabeth (nee Hughes). On July 3, 1998. Survived by two daughters, Leslie and Jane Glew. Memorial service St. James Episcopal Church, Monkton, MD today at 11 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMINSKY, MOLLIE
description: KAMINSKY-Mollie. Beloved wife of Herman Kaminsky. Loving mother to Helen Hitz and Sylvia Levy; grandmother to Louise Rubenfeld and Andrew Oelbaum; great-grandmother to Michael, Ashley, and Matthew Oelbaum and Josh and Julia Rubenfeld. Died on July 4, 1998. Services by Riverside Memorial Chapel were held on July 6, 1998 at Beth David Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUPFERSTEIN, HARRY (HERSHEL)
description: KUPFERSTEIN-Harry (Hershel) July 4, 1998. Born in Warsaw, Poland in 1916. From age 12 embarked on a long, rich career in printing, began as an apprentice printer for the ''Folks Tseitung'' of Warsaw followed by being a typesetter for ''Dos Vort'' in post WWII Paris, then for the Jewish Daily Forward in New York City. He became the owner and operator of Knight Printing Corporation from 1958-1982, Founding Board Member of Camp ''Hemshekh'', and more recently was the Editor of ''Unzer Tsait'', the journal of the Jewish Labor Bund. He also did biweekly political commentary on radio WEVD (until his last breath). He dedicated his life to socialist ideals and Yiddishkeit. Devoted husband to his beloved Feigele for 59 years, a loving and generous father and grandfather. He was one-of-a-kind.

title: Tarnished Goddess, Alloy of Iron and Pain

description: Germany's jobless rate fell to 11 percent in June, its lowest rate in 19 months and the sixth consecutive month of decline.

description: Without a job as recently as 1995, Claudio Taffarel was fully employed tonight, and when he had finished his long evening's work in the Brazilian goal, his gift for getting in the way of penalty kicks had made him a soccer hero at home again.

title: Case of Accused General Leads Army to Alter Retirement Process
description: The Army said today that it had revised its procedures for allowing generals to retire, a result of a controversy over the deputy Army inspector general who was allowed to retire quietly in February even though he was under investigation for sexual misconduct.

description: If only for a moment today, the tumult of Maryland state politics this year was calmed.

description: The Chancellor Media Corporation, the second-largest radio company in the nation, announced today that it would enter the television industry with the acquisition of the Lin Television Corporation for about $902.7 million in stock.

title: CHS ELECTRONICS AND METRO IN $320 MILLION DEAL
description: CHS Electronics Inc. plans to buy four European personal computer subsidiaries of Metro A.G. of Germany for about $320 million. CHS, a computer-products distributor based in Miami, said the purchase price consisted of $295 million in cash and $25 million in stock. It will also assume an undisclosed amount of debt. CHS Electronics said the units that it was acquiring had combined 1997 sales of $2.3 billion. CHS Electronics also disclosed that it had purchased most of the shares of Metrologie International of France, a European distributor of hardware and software, on June 30. CHS Electronics had 1997 sales of $4.76 billion. Metro, which is based in Cologne, Germany, has annual sales of about $60 billion.

title: Sluggers Have Their Night as the A.L. Bats Prevail
description: In an All-Star Game that matched the offensive nature of the season and fit the park that was host to it, the American and National leagues produced the highest-scoring All-Star Game in history tonight.

title: Slide in Oil and Internet Shares Helps Stall Summer Rally
description: A summer rally stalled yesterday as concerns about stock valuations caused investors to sell shares that had strong gains in recent weeks.

title: 2 States Agree to Preserve Farmland Along Border
description: In what officials called the first joint effort by New York and New Jersey to preserve farmland, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman yesterday turned over a check to help buy the development rights to a 205-acre horse farm that straddles the states' border.

title: $25 and Under; Tibetan Dishes That Speak of Tranquillity
description: AS I was waiting for friends on the airy deck behind Lhasa one recent evening, sitting near the small garden of white rocks that conveys a sense of Tibetan serenity, I thought I spied them coming in. I began to wave, but it turned out to be Lhasa's owner, Neeru Kapoor, who rushed over to see what I wanted.

title: Third of Births Aren't Registered, Unicef Says
description: Perhaps one-third of all babies do not have their births registered, leaving them in an official limbo that can mean missed educational opportunities and health care, Unicef says in a new report.

title: L.I. Restaurant Owners Win Smoking Ban Delay
description: Restaurant owners in Suffolk County have won a temporary restraining order against the county's new ban on smoking, one of the toughest in the country.

title: Temptation; For Licorice Lovers, a Sublime Confection
description: LET me say this straight out: I love licorice and always have. On Halloween, I was the kid avidly collecting the black jelly beans as fast as my friends could discard them.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the new transit passes that offer unlimited rides for a fixed price in New York City misstated the number of trips it would take to make a pass worthwhile. It is an average of one round trip a day, not one trip a day.

title: Needed: Techies Who Know Shakespeare
description: High-technology companies are so desperate for programmers, according to recent reports, that they are luring students out of the classroom with well-paying jobs. It's the schools' fault, say people in the industry and some computer-science professors. Students aren't being taught the skills they need and therefore don't see the point of getting a degree.

title: SYSTEM SOFTWARE PLANS TO TAKE A $120 MILLION CHARGE
description: System Software Associates Inc., a pioneer in software that connects all of a company's operations, said yesterday that it expected to lose money and take a $120 million charge in its third quarter and cut about 300 jobs, or 12 percent of its staff, in an effort to become profitable. The Chicago-based company will discontinue some software programs, reduce its office space by 25 percent and recognize certain warranty commitments. System Software sells software to help companies control manufacturing, inventory, customer and financial information. Shares of System Software rose 50 cents, to $7.375.

title: Summing Up, Plaintiff's Lawyer Calls Brawley Advisers Evil
description: In the final argument before the jurors consider the Tawana Brawley defamation case, the lawyer for the plaintiff called Ms. Brawley's three advisers evil men and self-promoters who destroyed the lives of others for their own advancement.

title: Benefits of School-Business Alliances
description: Employers, whose low opinion of American public education has generated much alarm in recent years, have come under growing pressure to get involved with their local high schools by offering things like materials and tutorials about the world of work.

To her husband, Samuel; her children, Dr. Robert Marion, Professor of Pediatrics at Einstein and a member of the Class of '79, and Dr. Lester Marion; and her entire family, we extend sincere condolences. title: Bay Networks Acquisition
description: Bay Networks Inc. has acquired a small German networking company called Netserve. Terms were not disclosed. The deal is an attempt by Bay to capitalize on the AT&T agreement to acquire Tele-Communications Inc. Using TCI's cable television network, AT&T hopes to deliver local telephone service and high-speed access to the internet. Netserve makes technology that allows cable systems to carry telephone calls. By acquiring Netserve, Bay is trying to sell more equipment to AT&T.

title: M.V.P. Stays in the Alomar Family
description: For the first time, two brothers have not only earned the most valuable player trophy in the All-Star Game, but they have done it in consecutive years.

title: Business Travel; The American Society of Travel Agents is giving airline passengers a new avenue for complaints.
description: PASSENGERS with a gripe about airlines have a new way to complain, courtesy of the American Society of Travel Agents, which has issued an Air Traveler's Bill of Rights and is inviting feedback on flights at a new Web site.

title: Indonesia Slips Into a Recession
description: Indonesia's economy has slid into a recession -- its first in more than 30 years -- as the rupiah's collapse and record interest rates have choked off business, the Government reported yesterday. The gross domestic product at the world's fourth-most-populous country shrank 16.5 percent in the second quarter from the corresponding period in 1997, after falling 6.2 percent in the first quarter. And Indonesia's statistics bureau said it was likely that G.D.P. would fall by 13.06 percent this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDER, MILTON J. (MIKE)
description: LINDER-Milton J. (Mike). Passed away on July 6, 1998. He was a resident of Boca West Country Club for several years. He is survived by his children, Steven and Kathy, Craig and Susan, Robert, Tracy and Jonathan; his grandchildren Adam, Wyatt, Sierra, Kyle; and his sister Muriel White and brother Samuel; and by his very close and dear friends Marc and Susie Kaye. He was born in New York, 1919 & graduated NYU. He volunteeered for the Army Air Corps where he entered as a Private and finished as a First Lieutenant and was awarded medals of bravery. He will be interred in the family estate at Mount Ararat, Long Island, N.Y. He will be missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, ROY
description: ROGERS-Roy. The Board of Trustees of Our Lady of Mercy Healthcare System, and Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center, and the children served by the Roy Rogers & Dale Evans Children's Center mourn the death of America's ''King of the Cowboys'' Roy Rogers, beloved husband of Dale Evans. We extend our deepest sympathy to Dale, their children and grandchildren. Indeed, he will be remembered, not only for his motion pictures, television shows, rodeo shows and stage performances, but also for his acts of kindness and dedication to children and family values. He was committed to many charitable causes, and lent his name and support to the Roy Rogers & Dale Evans Children's Center of Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center in the Bronx. We are grateful to Roy Rogers & Dale Evans for their generous support of our treasured youngsters and for giving children everywhere role models they could believe in. This great American icon will be greatly missed, but will live on through the hearts and minds of people of all ages around the world. Edwin S. Mruk, Chairman Our Lady of Mercy Healthcare System Gary S. Horan, FACHE President and CEO Our Lady of Mercy Healthcare System

title: Snooping on Fish Causes Cry of Foul
description: A VIDEO camera that reveals the secrets below the surface of lakes in far more detail than other electronic fish finders has renewed an intense debate about the use of technology in the pursuit of game fish.

title: No Monkey Business In Browser for Kids
description: THERE was a time when the phrase ''kid friendly'' actually referred to something that was fun for kids instead of good for them. In my own childhood, for instance, I once created what I considered a kid-friendly ant farm by sprinkling several teaspoons of sugar onto the front steps.

title: FRESENIUS TO SELL UNITS AND TAKE $100 MILLION WRITE-OFF
description: Fresenius Medical Care A.G., the world's biggest provider of dialysis services, said it would sell its United States diagnostics and home care businesses for $100 million. The diagnostics unit has been sold to Navix Radiology Systems in Coconut Grove, Fla., and Fresenius hopes to sell the home care unit in the third quarter. Fresenius Medical, majority owned by Fresenius A.G. of Germany, said the sale would lead to a second-quarter after-tax write-off of $100 million because it valued the units at $200 million on its books. The units were acquired under a 1996 deal that created Fresenius Medical Care from the dialysis businesses of W. R. Grace & Company and Fresenius USA Inc.

title: Europeans Act To Clear Way For Air Pacts, Conditionally
description: More than two years after American Airlines and British Airways P.L.C. announced an alliance that would dominate air traffic across the Atlantic, European regulators proposed preliminary conditions yesterday that appeared to clear the the way for its approval.

title: KRANZCO TO BUY SHOPPING CENTERS IN MIDWEST AND SOUTH
description: Kranzco Realty Trust said yesterday that it had agreed to buy nine community shopping centers in the Midwest and the South for a combined $85 million in cash and assumed debt. The real estate investment trust, which had 1997 revenue of $60.3 million, said it expected the purchase to increase its annual revenues by 15 percent. Kranzco, which is based in Conshohocken, Pa., owns and operates 59 shopping centers in 16 states. Last year it invested about $125 million in acquisitions, new development and expansion -- the largest investment since the company's initial public offering in 1992.

title: Tillman Durdin, 91, Reporter In China During World War II
description: Tillman Durdin, a longtime foreign correspondent for The New York Times who was one of the first to write about the Japanese atrocities in China that became known as the Rape of Nanking, died on Tuesday at the Green Hospital in San Diego. He was 91 and lived in San Diego.

title: Annals of The New Yorker
description: After six years that seemed like 60 when measured in hoopla, the Tina Brown era is over at The New Yorker. In an announcement that followed weeks of media chattering about the magazine's financial losses and recent murmurings about the editor's personal angst, Ms. Brown told her staff yesterday morning that she was moving to a new ''media venture'' launched by Miramax films. Like many of the events during her term as editor, this news sent tremors through the hushed, off-white corridors of the magazine and reverberated throughout the journalism and literary worlds.

We extend our sympathies to his wife Jean and his entire family. Dr. Jane Altes, President, Empire State College, SUNY. Dr. Marie Wittek, Dean, The Harry Van Arsdale Jr. School of Labor Studies.

title: Site-Seeing: Medical Information; Sorting Health Facts From Fiction on Line
description: SUPPOSE you just found out that you have diabetes or high blood pressure, or someone in the family has asthma or cancer, and you need to learn about it. Search engines provide thousands of hits for a word like asthma with no evaluation of the information. Where can you turn?

title: Accounts
description: * 3D Systems, Valencia, Calif., to Howard, Merrell & Partners, Raleigh, N.C., to handle advertising for the maker of rapid product development systems, which had been handled on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $3 million.

title: Essex Lawmakers to Call For Stadium in Newark
description: A group of Essex County lawmakers announced yesterday that they would introduce a resolution in the Senate calling on the State Sports and Exposition Authority to build a new arena for the New Jersey Nets and Devils in downtown Newark.

title: THE GOLF REPORT; Lyme Disease's Tick Adds Hazard to Rough
description: If you play golf, you're at risk for getting Lyme disease. In fact, the worse you play, the greater your chances. Deer ticks, prime agents in the spread of Lyme and other tick-borne diseases, lurk in the damp, tall grass of the rough and leafy underbrush of the surrounding woods.

title: The Secret Service and the Law
description: In a firm, correct decision, a Federal appeals court in Washington has rejected the Clinton Administration's creative concoction of a new ''protective function privilege'' to prevent Secret Service officials from testifying before a grand jury in the Monica Lewinsky case. The Administration is pondering whether to pursue an appeal. The nation and the Presidency would be better served if the White House took its unanimous legal defeat by a three-judge panel as a message to switch from the obstructionist mode that has needlessly prolonged Kenneth Starr's inquiry.

title: Japanese Premier Promises Tax Cut for Long Term, Too
description: Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto today promised long-term tax cuts beginning next year, but he gave no details about how much the move might fatten pocketbooks or lift the sagging Japanese economy.

title: Nigeria Edges Toward Anarchy
description: The only way Gen. Abdulsalam Abubakar can bring Nigeria back from the brink of political chaos is to act immediately on his promise yesterday to restore democracy. With unrest and rioting erupting, Africa's most populous nation cannot wait for General Abubakar to weigh his options. Nigeria urgently needs a civilian transition government and a date for free elections.

title: THE FINE PRINT: Helping a Home-State Company; Lott Tries to Avert Amendments to Bill; Then He Adds One
description: As the final push for a bill that would set a nationwide product liability standard began this week, Senator Trent Lott, the Republican majority leader, urged his colleagues not to burden the measure with amendments. But today a hand-written amendment sponsored by Mr. Lott suddenly appeared in the bill, an amendment that would significantly benefit a major company in Mississippi, his home state.

title: Citing Study, Mayor Says Workfare Doesn't Hurt Students
description: Brandishing a new study by the City Comptroller's office, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that despite fears to the contrary, his workfare policy requiring welfare recipients to work for their benefits is good for students at City University of New York who are receiving public assistance.

title: Mexico Cuts '98 Budget Outlays to Match Drop in Oil Income
description: Mexico said today that it would slice an additional $730 million from federal spending in 1998, taking bitter fiscal medicine for the third time this year in an effort to maintain stability despite dropping oil prices.

title: FESTIVAL REVIEW/Music; A Program Weds 2 Who Led the Philharmonic
description: Deprived of its centerpiece, the musical arm of Lincoln Center Festival '98 must find another. I doubt it will be the New York Philharmonic. Tuesday's Bernstein-Mahler concert was to have been corollary to the opening of ''The Peony Pavilion,'' the 16th-century opera that Chinese officials have declined to send abroad. Leonard Bernstein remembered was always a subtheme of this year's festival; but judging from this makeshift evening, it will serve as poor substitute for a main event.

It can be steamed up on the Aga or zapped in the microwave oven, then served in a room newly commodious with a kitchen sofa, pillows, even an armchair.

title: Fast Track to Programs With I.B.M. Keyboards

title: Not to Debunk the Berlin Airlift, but Have You Heard This?
description: Half a century after the Berlin airlift, heroic images endure: courageous West Berliners under Soviet siege, saved from starvation by valiant American and British pilots flying food and fuel to the beleaguered cold-war outpost.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PICARD, PHILIP G.

ST Microelectronics' current systems-on-a-chip technology will also be made available to I.B.M. The companies will have access to each other's research and will cross-license each other on patent restrictions.
