title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAHNIGEN, DENNIS W., M.D.
description: JAHNIGEN-Dennis W., M.D. The Board, staff and members of the American Geriatrics Society (AGS) note with great sadness the passing of our colleague, friend, and Immediate Past President, Dr. Dennis W. Jahnigen. A warm, compassionate and talented physician, Dr. Jahnigen was deeply commited to geriatrics practice, research and education. The Goodstein Professor of Geriatric Medicine and Director of the Center on Aging at the University of Colorado Health Sciences Center, he was long recognized as an extraordinary teacher, with a number of awards from students and faculty. He is the author, co-author or editor of 68 books, book chapters and articles on a wide variety of geriatrics topics. Under his leadership, the AGS developed numerous national programs to enhance geriatrics education and attract trainees to the field. The AGS recently named him winner of the 1998 Milo D. Leavitt Award, which is given annually to an eminent individual with a distinguished, nationally recognized career in geriatrics eduation. Dr. Jahnigen's clinical skills and heartfelt concern for older adults continue to flourish in the many students who have benefited from his teaching and mentorship. His personal warmth, wise counsel and national leadership will be sorely missed by his students and colleagues, as well as his patients and their families. The AGS extends its deepest sympathy to his family.

title: MOBILEMEDIA TO SELL 163 PAGING TOWERS FOR $170 MILLION
description: The Mobilemedia Corporation of Ridgefield Park, N.J., the fourth-largest United States paging company, agreed to sell 163 paging towers to the closely held Pinnacle Towers Inc. for $170 million in cash. Mobilemedia, which filed for bankruptcy last year, will continue to operate transmitters on the towers and will lease space from Pinnacle for $10.7 million a year for 15 years. The towers, on 140 sites around the nation, give Pinnacle valuable real estate as prices to lease space on wireless phone and paging towers have soared with a rush of new competitors. Mobilemedia, in turn, gets cash to expedite its struggle to emerge from bankruptcy. Mobilemedia, with 3.3 million pagers in service, leases space on more than 4,000 other towers nationwide.

title: FORTRESS GROUP IN $333 MILLION DEAL FOR 12 BUILDINGS
description: Fortress Investment Group L.L.C., made up of UBS Securities Inc.'s former real estate group, bought 12 buildings yesterday for $333 million from the Union Bank of Switzerland. The purchase is the first by the New York-based firm since it raised $410 million this month for a fund to invest in real estate in North America, Europe and Asia. The properties contain about 2.73 million square feet and are leased mostly to the United States Government, Fortress said. The purchase may be the first of many from the Union Bank of Switzerland. In May, Wesley Edens, now Fortress chief executive, and a 30-person group left UBS to start Fortress. The defection came after UBS Securities' parent company, Union Bank of Switzerland, agreed to a $33 billion merger with the Swiss Bank Corporation.

In heaven they sing. The only person who does not is the Devil, and Hildegard's decision to make his a spoken role (or, as she seems to have wanted it, a shouted role) is fruitful if also problematic.

description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Art galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Summer hours vary for galleries and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Mets Open 2d Half Handing One Away
description: The day began with bad enough news, with the Mets learning that their closer, John Franco, had been suspended for three games because of his angry outburst at the umpires at the end of last Sunday's disputed extra-inning loss to the Atlanta Braves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FROMM, ALFRED
description: FROMM-Alfred. The American Friends of The Hebrew University of Jerusalem mourn with sorrow the passing of Alfred Fromm, a noted philanthropist and generous supporter of The Hebrew University since 1977. He and his wife, Hanna, sponsored numerous student scholarships and founded the Fromm Institute for Lifelong Learning at The Hebrew University based on the program at the University of San Francisco. We extend our deepest condolences to his entire family. The American Friends of The Hebrew University Keith L. Sachs, President Fred S. Lafer, Chairman of the Board Adam B. Kahan Executive Vice President

title: Smoke Detectors Gone, Four Die in a Fire
description: A man, his daughter and two 3-year-old girls were killed yesterday morning in a fire in their home, from which smoke detectors had been removed in anticipation of an interior paint job, fire officials said.

title: Construction Union Puts Off Lawsuit
description: The federation representing the city's unionized construction workers put off plans yesterday to file a lawsuit seeking to force the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to cancel a $33 million building contract with a nonunion company.

title: Recanting a Sex Abuse Charge; Family Needs to Heal, but Which Statement Is the Lie?
description: At her father's sentencing last year, Stacey Hoehmann was a figure of tortured outrage, providing her own pronouncement of doom for what she said was his sexual abuse of her as a teen-ager.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATKIN, DR. MAURICE B.
description: ATKIN-Dr. Maurice B. Died on Monday, July 6. Beloved husband of Diana, loving father of Peter and Michael. He will always be in our hearts.

title: Monmouth Bid For Skip Away
description: Monmouth Park is expected to raise both the purse and the distance of the Iselin Handicap, perhaps as soon as today, to induce Sonny Hine to run his champion Skip Away in the Aug. 30 race at the Jersey Shore track.

description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Big Board brokers win more in arbitration than they lose.
description: THE New York Stock Exchange may be the market of choice for investors who want the best execution of their securities trades.

title: City Students Test Lower In Reading
description: The percentage of students in New York City who passed an annual statewide reading test dipped this year, prompting officials of the City Board of Education to complain yesterday about the difficulty of this year's exam.

title: George Lloyd, 85, British Symphonic Composer
description: George Lloyd, a British symphonist and opera composer who rejected the major stylistic currents of the 20th century in favor of the language, coloration and sheer lushness of late Romanticism, died on July 3 at University College Hospital in London. He was 85.

title: WELLPOINT HEALTH TO PAY $500 MILLION FOR CERULEAN
description: Wellpoint Health Networks Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the Cerulean Companies, Georgia's largest health insurer, for about $500 million in stock and cash. Cerulean, which is converting from a nonprofit private organization to a for-profit company, is the parent of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Georgia and has about 1.7 million members. Wellpoint, one of the largest managed-health-care companies in California, is buying the Atlanta-based Cerulean to expand outside its core market in California. Shares of Wellpoint, which is based in Woodland Hills, Calif., rose $1.4375, to $71.0625, on the New York Stock Exchange. Wellpoint also said that it was increasing its share buyback program to as many as 8 million shares from 1 million shares.

title: SPARE TIMES: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: THE BABY BUST: A special report.; Population Implosion Worries a Graying Europe
description: Mia Hulton is a true woman of the late 20th century. Soft-spoken, well-educated and thoughtful, she sings Renaissance music in a choral group, lives quietly with the man she loves and works like a demon seven days a week.

title: CRESCENT AND RECKSON IN JOINT VENTURE FOR TOWER
description: The Crescent Real Estate Equities Company, led by the billionaire investor Richard Rainwater, and the Reckson Associates Realty Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Tower Realty Trust for $24 a share in cash, or $445 million. Tower shareholders also have the option of receiving 0.4615 Reckson share and 0.3523 Crescent share. Crescent and Reckson will also assume about $289 million of debt. The sale ends the short-lived public life of Tower, which had its initial public offering at $26 a share in October. Tower fell 56.25 cents yesterday, to $23.125. Crescent, one of the largest office property owners, and Reckson, the biggest landlord on Long Island, are buying Tower through Metropolitan Partners, a newly formed joint venture in New York.

title: Cipollini Has One Goal: Just Look at His Bicycle
description: Mario Cipollini, the biggest hot dog outside the dreams of Oscar Mayer, has come to Ireland for the start of the Tour de France with a bicycle as green as a shamrock.

title: New Crop of Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Decrease in Exports Slows Growth in France
description: French economic growth slowed in the first quarter as recession in Japan and some other Asian economies cut exports, the national statistics office said yesterday. France, the world's fourth-biggest economy, expanded six-tenths of a percent from the fourth quarter, the slowest pace for a year and down from a gain of eight-tenths of a percent in the fourth quarter.

title: Bullets Designed to Maim
description: The New York Police Department's decision to switch from conventional full-metal-jacketed bullets to more lethal hollow-point bullets is regrettable. The hollow-point bullets, which expand when they enter flesh, are banned as inhumane in warfare by the Geneva Conventions because they cause great damage to internal organs. Unless the Police Department can show that conventional bullets are inadequate to protect public safety, there is no reason to switch to a type of ammunition that can result in more severe injuries for suspects, bystanders and police officers.

title: A Taste of Rich Man's Time (on a Bun, With Mayo)
description: The thing of it is not so much that thanks to my neighbor, Howard Tedoff, we ended up flying to Bar Harbor, Me., just to eat some lobster rolls on a recent Saturday, but that we got to experience rich man's time.

title: Curbing Soft Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZGERALD, MARILYN E.
description: FITZGERALD-Marilyn E. July 8, 1998, of Rye, NY. Wife of Walter P. Mother of Tracey Sullivan of Rye, N.Y., Joan Clarke of Larchmont, NY, and Pamela Fitzgerald of Harrison, NY. Daughter of Elizabeth D'Arco of Greenwich, CT. Sister of Joan McCabe of Potomac, Maryland. Survived by 4 grandchildren. The family will receive friends on Friday 2-4 & 7-9P.M. at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd, Rye NY. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 10 A.M. at the Church of the Resurrection, Rye, N.Y. Interment Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye, New York.

title: Japanese Banks Cutting Back on U.S. Presence
description: Overcome by bad loans in their home country, Japanese banks and other financial institutions are in a broad retreat from the United States market, closing offices and cutting back on their lending to American companies.

title: Tobacco Companies Seek New Accord With States
description: Negotiators for tobacco producers and state attorneys general have held secret talks in recent weeks in an effort to devise a new tobacco settlement proposal, state officials and lawyers say.

title: Sports of The Times; When Hundley Comes Marchin' Home Again
description: ON the first night of the second season, the Mets looked awful. Little League base-running blunders, shoddy defense and shaky relief pitching -- less a surprise than a signature of this team -- were all part of a 9-8 extra-inning loss to the Montreal Expos. This is not what Manager Bobby Valentine had in mind for the beginning of a run for a playoff berth.

title: Again, Russia Delays a Sale Of Oil Giant
description: Russia's faltering economy and plunging world oil prices prompted the Government of President Boris N. Yeltsin today to postpone the sale of its state oil company.

title: A Family Confronts Its Demons
description: Something ugly has been going on in the King family's apartment, and now that Nessa is dead, at age 14, the truth may come out. In ''You Shouldn't Have Told,'' the family's story and Anne L. Thompson-Scretching's intelligent, observant play about sexual abuse, no one is completely innocent.

title: At the Movies; Tracking 'Armageddon'
description: The most jittery place in town this week is at the Walt Disney Company, whose most expensive film ever, ''Armageddon,'' opened to a disappointing box office and faces an uncertain future.

title: On Stage and Off
description: The ''On Stage and Off'' column will resume with the new theater season in the fall.

title: 'Unknown,' Redefined
description: To the Editor:

title: Will Asia Turn Against the West?
description: The fire raging in East Asia today jeopardizes one of the central achievements of postwar American foreign policy -- the stabilization and growth of East Asia. Even more dangerously, if it continues to fester, this crisis could undermine support for an open global economy and economic and political liberalization across the world.

title: Constantly Stepping Out Of Those 2 Straight Lines
description: There's a picture-book prettiness to the terribly sweet film version of Ludwig Bemelmans's ''Madeline'' stories, so that the Paris and the schoolgirls and the matching hats of the author's delightful drawings really do spring to life. But ''terribly'' is the key word in that sentence, since the film's preciousness often threatens to eclipse its ingenuity. With a cast of 12 pert little girls who seemingly have been encouraged to lisp, and with a primness that outlasts the film's ingenuity, this ''Madeline'' is best watched by viewers who approach the material in a state of pre-adoration. Anyone else will begin to wish that a 13th, hell-raising little iconoclast had been thrown into the mix.

title: Antiques; Collectors Go Hunting For Tapas
description: Before there was cloth, there was tapa, or bark cloth, a primitive kind of paperlike fabric made by tribes in South America, Africa, Asia and Polynesia. Now, centuries later, collectors are drawn to these graphically patterned pieces and are buying them as works of art.

title: ON THE TRAIL WITH: Bill Bryson; A Little Uphill, Downhill and Out of Shape
description: A book about hiking the Appalachian Trail? Spare me.

title: 10,001 Nights of Greco, Mr. Lounge
description: Manhattan and Atlantic City are only about a hundred miles apart, but in terms of pop music cultures they might as well be different planets. In certain downtown Manhattan clubs, lounge music (everything from Dean Martin to Henry Mancini) is self-consciously embraced by young audiences as a campy retro-hip genre, while in Atlantic City it remains a stalwart pop tradition.

title: Traditional Materials In Modern Incarnations
description: Ever since Modernism divorced art from craft around the end of the 19th century, craft has been having an identity crisis. How could craft define itself as separate from yet equal to modern art? Its traditionalism made it an unlikely source of innovation or revolution, and its focus on materials and techniques limited its ability to develop meanings and metaphors. Meanwhile, the Industrial Revolution was making handwork obsolete.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINAPPLE, EVELYN
description: WEINAPPLE-Evelyn (nee Karpin). Loving wife of the late Henry; Beloved mother of Martin and Sharon, Stanley & Gertrude, and the late Donald. Dear Sister of Celia, Phyllis and the late Amy and Pearl. Devoted Grandmother of Richard, Sharon, Robert, Alan, Gabriella, David and Daniela. Great Grandmother of Emilia, David, Daniel & Donald. Graveside services will be today 2PM at Pinelawn Memorial Park, Farmingdale, N.Y. Donations in her loving memory to Anchor House, P.O. Box 2357, Trenton, New Jersey 08607.

title: 'Humble County'
description: D'Amelio Terras Gallery

title: Spanish-speaking consumers are the object of a growing number of marketers' desires.
description: ILINGUAL education may be under attack in the public schools, but American businesses do speak Spanish.

title: G.E. Posts 13% Rise in 2d-Quarter Profits
description: The General Electric Company said today that its second-quarter profit rose 13 percent, driven by record sales at the maker of everything from light bulbs to loans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSCHILD, DR. JACOB
description: ROTHSCHILD-Dr. Jacob, at 76. On July 9th. He was a true gentleman and scholar. Born in Zurich, he established a life as a student, scholar and mohel in Zurich, psychologist in NY and most recently as a scholar and student in Israel. He led a blessed life. He is survived by his wife Eileen (TuretskyMetchik); eight brothers and a sister; five children: Mitchel and Dr. Rachel Yehuda Rothschild; Dr. Jan Rothschild & Andrew Wiener; Vivian and Jordan Lurie; Shu-Shu and Moshe Har Shemesh; and Diane Rothschild; and nineteen grandchildren. Funeral at Schwartz Bros. Chapels, on Friday 9 A.M. Shiva at his residence.

title: Bernstein Revisited: A Master Of It All
description: Whenever Leonard Bernstein had to list his profession on some official form, like his income tax returns, he did not write composer, conductor, pianist or any other limiting term. He called himself a musician. He liked the word's embracing quality and venerable history. In earlier eras, all professional musicians were composers as well as performers, not to mention teachers, proselytizers, organizers and whatever else it took to keep the tradition going.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARX, THELMA
description: MARX-Thelma. On July 8, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Harry M., devoted mother of Jerry and Stanley; loving mother-in-law of Leslie and Judy; dearest grandmother of Amanda, Ariel, Harrison, Samantha and Gabrielle. Devoted sister of Edna Feinstein and Walter Kaplan. Services Friday, July 10, 1998 at 11:30 am ''Boulevard Riverside'', 312 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn. Contributions may be sent to the Chemo Therapy Foundation, 183 Madison Avenue, NY NY 10016

title: Doctors to Buy a Stake and Run 2 Chicago Hospitals
description: In a novel effort to take control of their patients' care, a group of physicians said yesterday that they had reached agreement to salvage an eminent teaching and research hospital on Chicago's South Side that had been especially rocked by the turmoil in the nation's health care.

title: Hasidic Village Loses Again in Schools Ruling
description: The village of Kiryas Joel lost yet another decision yesterday when a state appellate court ruled unanimously that the third and latest effort by the Governor and the State Legislature to create a public school district solely for Hasidic children violated the Constitution's establishment-of-religion clause.

title: Tourism Account Goes to Saatchi
description: The New Zealand Tourism Board in Wellington said yesterday that it had named the Saatchi & Saatchi unit of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. to handle its worldwide account, which had been handled by various local agencies. Billings were estimated at $40 million a year for a two-year contract.

title: TV Weekend; A Doomed Quest for Home and Heroism
description: Mira Nair, the director from India, seems a bold choice to make a disease-of-the-week television film. With ''My Own Country,'' on Showtime's Sunday night schedule, she puts her own imaginative and exotic stamp on the lumpen form, conjuring moments that satisfy the eye and the heart. Ultimately, though, that form's limitations defeat Ms. Nair (whose movies include ''Mississippi Masala'' and ''Salaam Bombay!'') and her familiar cast.

title: Cambodia's Stunted Election Campaign
description: It is not particularly surprising that as the July 26 election day approaches in Cambodia, the campaign is dominated by the dictator, Hun Sen. His party runs the local and national election commissions. His image and propaganda monopolize the media except for a five-minute daily ad permitted each opposition group. His supporters menace opposition activists, especially in the countryside, and are suspected of political killings. Yet the outside world is pretending that an acceptably fair election can be held in this climate of intimidation.

title: Prices Higher On Treasuries In a Light Day
description: Treasury prices made modest gains yesterday, bolstered by a strong dollar. But trading was light, with many investors waiting for new economic data before making any significant committments.

title: Ogilvy and Singleton In Australia Venture
description: Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York, part of WPP Group P.L.C., and Singleton Group Ltd. in Sydney, Australia, have agreed to merge their advertising operations in Australia and New Zealand. Though financial terms were not disclosed, Singleton will own two-thirds of the merged operation -- which would be one of the four largest in the market -- and Ogilvy the remainder.

title: Take Away the 'Acting' Label: Selig Is Baseball's Commissioner
description: On Bud Selig's 2,130th day as acting commissioner, Major League Baseball club owners looked at him and liked what they saw. So today they elected him quickly and unanimously as the sport's ninth commissioner.

title: FIRST SOURCE BANCORP AGREES TO ACQUIRE PULSE BANCORP
description: First Source Bancorp Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Pulse Bancorp Inc., a New Jersey holding company, for about $100 million in stock. First Source, formerly known as First Savings Bank of New Jersey, is based in Perth Amboy, N.J. Under the agreement, First Source will acquire Pulse, based in South River, N.J., for 10 million shares. For each Pulse share, Pulse shareholders will receive $32 in First Source shares, or 3.2 First Source shares if First Source's share price exceeds $10. The ratio would be adjusted if First Source's shares fall below $8.50 or rise above $11.50 a share. Shares of First Source closed at $9.50, down 37.5 cents, and Pulse's were at $29.625, up $1.125.

title: Some Human Risk Is Seen From Drugs in Food Animals
description: Humans can contract antibiotic-resistant infections from food animals, a National Academy of Science panel said today, but the risk to public health from eating meat or poultry or being in contact with the live animals or meat products has not been determined.

title: In a Fractured Family, a Girl Tries to Make Things All Better
description: Maybe on a rainy day after school or late at night on the Family Channel there is a slot on television for ''Home Before Dark.'' But no compelling reason exists for running out to see this listless, tiresome movie in a theater.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEHR, ROBERT O., DR
description: FEHR-Robert O., Dr. The Directors of the Heineman Foundation for Charitable, Educational and Scientific Purposes Inc. note with profound sadness the passing of Dr. Robert Fehr, a longtime member of the Board. Bob's wide range of knowledge and his dedication to the purposes of the Foundation were instrumental in guiding the Board over many years. Above all, Bob was a much loved and devoted friend, whose presence will be irreplaceable.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CIRCLE INTERNATIONAL GROUP, -- San Francisco, an import and export company, agreed to acquire Alrod International Inc., an international freight forwarder, through an exchange of common stock.

description: June Kelly Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEW, ELIZABETH V.
description: NEW-Elizabeth V. Born 1917-died on July 8th, 1998 of cancer at the Jacob Perlow Hospice in New York City. Dear wife of the late William Kohman, loving mother of Peter Kohman & friend to many. Graduate of Wheaton College and Columbia University. Betty was a child psychologist, a caring counselor and psychometrician with extensive experience at New York Hospital/Cornell Medical Center, The Chapin School and private practice. At her request there will be no funeral. Contributions in her name may be made to Wheaton College, Norton, MA.

title: Name That Address
description: The ''21'' Club, at 21 West 52d Street in Manhattan, made it fashionable for restaurants to incorporate street addresses in their names. Nowadays, ''21'' is simply one of many restaurants for which location is also a name. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Evidence Emerges on Inquiry Involving Archer Daniels
description: After more than three years of being shrouded in secrecy, evidence from the Government's investigation of a huge price-fixing conspiracy involving the Archer Daniels Midland Company is emerging as the first criminal case stemming from the inquiry heads to trial.

title: FESTIVAL REVIEW/Opera; Romance Colored by Danger and Ecstasy
description: The composer Paula M. Kimper and the librettist Wende Persons, whose three-act chamber opera ''Patience and Sarah'' received its world premiere on Wednesday night as part of Lincoln Center Festival '98, believe that the opera is the first to portray an openly romantic relationship between two self-affirming women.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUCKMAN, SID
description: LUCKMAN-Sid. The Columbia University Department of Athletics mourns the passing of Sid Luckman, one of its most illustrious athletic alumni, who distinguished himself on the playing fields of both Columbia and the NFL as one of the first great, modern quarterbacks. We extend our sincere condolences to his family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, JESSICA JENNIFER
description: COHEN-Jessica Jennifer, 25, a journalist, died on June 29th, 1998, in Tempe, AZ. of a brain tumor. She was born in Santa Fe, New Mexico, to J. Susan Cedar and Eugene D. Cohen. She was engaged to Claude Mottier, and is also survived by her stepfather, Gary Lowenthal, and siblings, Jessica Anne Lowenthal, Adam Cohen, and Martin Lowenthal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONNELLY, JOHN A.
description: DONNELLY-John A. Died on July 7th, 1998, at age 78 at home in Vero Beach, Florida. Due to complications from Cancer. Born in Brooklyn, NY, May 29, 1920. Was a WWII Veteran and had a long and celebrated career as a Television Producer in Advertising. Survived by his loving wife of 48 years, Joan T. Donnelly and his children Jack Donnelly of Pound Ridge, NY, Brian Donnelly of Overland Park, Kansas, Maryann Kreischer of East Meadow, NY. Donations in his memory should be sent to: Hospice of The Treasure Coast, POB 1748, Fort Pierce, FL 34954. Funeral services were held on July 9th, 1998 at Holy Cross RC, Vero Beach, FL.

title: Misha Dichter and Caramoor Celebrate 25 Years of Fresh Discoveries
description: Anniversaries are a peculiar commodity in the classical music world. Concert programmers and record company executives believe -- and the anecdotal evidence suggests they may be right -- that when composers reach even-numbered anniversaries, listeners become eager to hear their music again, even if they've been hearing it all along. Institutions and performers use their own benchmarks as a reason to party, and that being the case, an anniversary of some sort can almost always be found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUS, MADELAINE
description: STRAUS-Madelaine. On July 9, 1998. Beloved sister of Eleanor Muenz. Loving aunt to Larry and Janet and great-aunt to Jonathan and Daniel. Services private.

description: Concerns on Global Court

title: Teen-Agers Get Terms in Prison In Baby's Death
description: Denouncing Amy S. Grossberg for egocentric indifference to the life of her newborn son, a Delaware judge sentenced her today to 30 months in prison for contributing to the baby's death in November 1996. Minutes later, the judge, Henry duPont Ridgely, issued a gentler scolding to Ms. Grossberg's co-defendant and former high school sweetheart, Brian C. Peterson, and gave him a two-year sentence.

title: Coppola Awarded $80 Million For Unmade Pinocchio Movie
description: A jury here ordered the Warner Brothers movie studio today to pay the director Francis Ford Coppola and a partner $60 million in punitive damages for blocking their efforts to make a movie based on the story of Pinocchio.

title: Funeral for Firefighter Who Battled Burns for Month
description: This was a tough one for the New York City Fire Department, maybe tougher than some of the others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INWOOD, EVELYN GLASSER
description: INWOOD-Evelyn Glasser, 79 years old. Died July 8, 1998. One of a kind, intense, stormy, devoted, generous mother of David M.D., Richard M.D., & Alan J.D., motherin-law of Linda, Sandra, and Linda. Grandmother to Shoshanah, Benjamin, Jonathan, Davora, Sara, Jacob & Gabriel and beloved friend of Elaine Henderson & wife of the late Louis M.D. Services, Parkside Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, at 11:30 A.M., on Friday, July 10.

title: U.S. Specifies Terms for War Crimes Court
description: The United States set out new conditions today for taking part in an international criminal court, calling for sharp limits on its scope and authority.

title: Watching Paris Change at St.-Lazare
description: Art exhibitions that resemble art history seminars often do so at their peril. Full of wordy text panels, such shows can swamp the viewer with extraneous information or make interesting points that one would rather encounter in book form, sitting down.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Review Panel to Control Camden's Finances
description: The State Local Finance Board voted on Wednesday to create a seven-member review panel with the power to control the city of Camden's troubled finances.

title: June Retail Sales Are Clouded By Hints of Hesitant Shoppers
description: American retailers reported June sales yesterday, and the results were reliably perplexing. Following two months of stellar sales for the entire industry, companies were all over the map in June, demonstrating that when shoppers tighten their purse strings even slightly, retail wheat and chaff quickly become separated.

title: Brazil's Coach Never So Sure Of Winning As He Is Now
description: Never has he been more confident of victory, Mario Zagallo, the much-criticized Brazil coach, said today as Sunday's World Cup final against France approached. And never has he been more nervous. The dependability of Ronaldo's scoring and Taffarel's goalkeeping have not been enough to calm him, he said. So he has resorted to tranquilizers.

title: King Acquitted in Second Trial on Fraud Charges
description: A Federal jury acquitted Don King of nine counts of wire fraud yesterday, the second time he was tried on charges of attempting to defraud a Lloyd's of London insurance syndicate out of $350,000 following cancellation of a boxing match involving Julio Cesar Chavez.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, LISSI
description: KRAMER-Lissi. Left us on July 8, 1998. She was the devoted wife of the late Henry H., and the loving mother of Fred and Madeline Kramer, Ernest and Susan Kramer, Anne and Paul Strauss. She adored her grandchildren, Valerie, Andrea, Martin, Diana, Lisa, David, Tracy and Richard, and their spouses, and her great grandchildren, Aaron, Seth, Allyson, Matthew, Andrew, Natalie, Lily and Stephen. They will always remember their ''Omi'' with great affection. Lissi was a valiant woman who cherished her family and was faithful to her many friends. She was an inspiration to us all and her memory will live from generation to generation.

title: Suspects in a Disappearance Have Been Running for Years
description: Over the last two years, Sante and Kenneth Kimes, a mother-and-son team with long criminal records, have traveled across the United States and beyond, always remaining a step ahead of criminal investigators seeking to question them about theft, arson and murder.

title: Favorite Trick Will Sit Out Travers Stakes
description: The 3-year-old stars of the class of '98 may be plotting their summertime reunion at Saratoga in the Travers Stakes on Aug. 29, but Favorite Trick, last year's juvenile champion and Horse of the Year, will not be joining them.

title: SPECIAL METALS AGREES TO ACQUIRE ALLOYS UNIT FROM INCO
description: The Special Metals Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Inco Ltd.'s Inco Alloys International unit for $408 million in cash. Inco Ltd., based in Toronto, is one of the world's largest producers of nickel. Its Inco Alloys International unit had revenue of $668 million in 1997. Special Metals, based in New Hartford, N.Y., makes superalloy products used mainly in jet engine parts. Special Metals also said that it had arranged to sell $125 million of convertible preferred stock to the Titanium Metals Corporation and form a strategic alliance to develop new uses for titanium and nickel alloys.

title: Ex-Sunbeam Chief Backs Record And Demands His Severance Pay
description: Albert J. Dunlap, dismissed last month as chairman of the Sunbeam Corporation after six months of losses, called his ouster unfair today and said he was certain he would have turned the company around in 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAHERTY, CLARENCE J.
description: FAHERTY-Clarence J. Of New Rochelle, New York, on Thursday, July 9, 1998. Beloved husband of Inge E. (nee Fleischman). Father of Roger, Peter, Dennis. Dear grandfather of fifteen, great grandfather of six. Father of the late David who died in 1965 and his first wife Helen Zabrisky who passed away in 1979. Funeral from the Meehan Funeral Home, 555 Warren Ave., Spring Lake Heights, New Jersey on Saturday, July 11, 1998. Mass of Christian Burial 9AM St. Catharine's RC Church, Spring Lake, N.J., 9 A.M. Interment St. Theresa Cemetery in Summit, N.J. Visitation Friday evening 7-9 PM only. The family of C.J. Faherty mourns the passing of their hero.

title: Senators Back Sale of Wheat To Pakistanis
description: Bowing to pressure from farmers, the Senate today unanimously agreed to exempt food exports from sanctions that the United States imposed on India and Pakistan after the two countries conducted nuclear tests in May.

title: Residential Real Estate; Super-Luxury Condo Market Broadens
description: One of Manhattan's major rental developers is entering the super-luxury condominium arena. The Related Companies, which has 10 rental apartment buildings in existence or under construction in Manhattan, is planning three condo projects that over the next two and a half years will produce a total of up to 348 apartments expected to be priced from $500,000 to $5 million each.

title: Dow Jones Profit Rises Before Charges
description: Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that its second-quarter operating profit rose 11 percent, before charges and losses at its former Telerate unit, while earnings from print publishing fell because of revenue shortfalls stemming from the Asia crisis and higher newsprint costs.

title: Hadera Journal; Jewish Family Heirloom: 15 Square Miles of Death
description: Last year, at the age of 62, Zypora Frank learned a terrible truth: her family had owned part of the land on which the Auschwitz death camp stood, and where most of her mother's family perished. In fact, she held the deed to that land.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a picture caption was omitted on Wednesday with an Arts Abroad article about an exhibition of works by the Mexican artists Frida Kahlo and her husband, Diego Rivera, at the Musee Maillol in Paris. title: National League; 1999 SCHEDULE
description: Baseball owners voted yesterday to approve the 1999 schedule conceptually but not the details of it, Paul Beeston, the chief operating officer of Major League Baseball, said. The owners still want to do some tweaking, Beeston said after the meeting in Chicago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAZ, MARGARET (PEGGY) ANN (NELIGAN
description: DIAZ-Margaret (Peggy) Ann (Neligan). Of Matinecock, N.Y., and Palm Desert, CA., on July 8, 1998. Wife of John. Mother of Drew, Patrick and Kathryn. Grandmother (Nini) of Patrick, Sarah, Julia, John and Clare. We will all miss your generosity and love, curiosity and intellect, spunk and wit, courage, character and integrity. Your beautiful self will live on within us and future generations. Service will be private, but the family will receive friends at home in Matinecock on Friday, July 10 from 58PM. In lieu of flowers, donations or tributes to the charity of your choice would be appreciated. ''The weight of this sad time we must obey.'' -Shakespeare, King Lear

title: Rangers Sign MacLean, A Devil for 14 Seasons
description: The Rangers, still negotiating with Mike Richter to fill their goaltending position, plugged another significant gap in their lineup yesterday when they signed right wing John MacLean, who played for the Devils for 14 seasons.

title: 2d Crown Hts. Sentence
description: A man convicted of inciting the crowd before the killing of a Hasidic scholar in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, in 1991 was sentenced yesterday to 21 years in prison, a term even longer than that dealt to the person who committed the stabbing.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER SLUMPS. Copper prices touched an 11-year low on growing expectations that demand from Asia will slow. September copper fell 0.40 cent, to 71.80 cents a pound, the lowest since June 1987.

title: Valentine Says Hundley Should Be in Peak Form
description: Todd Hundley is finally scheduled to make his major league outfield debut tomorrow night. When he does, it will be the first time he has appeared in a game for the Mets since last September.

title: Morton Plans Cutbacks
description: Morton International Inc. said today that it would close three operations and eliminate 120 jobs, as the company, a producer of specialty chemicals and salt, moves to cut costs in its chemicals business. Morton is closing an administrative and sales office in Danvers, Mass.; a plant in Garlasco, Italy, and a sales office and laboratory in Coventry, England. The company plans to sell the three operations.

title: Prime Minister Accused of Favoring Lobbyists : Blair Beset in Scandal Over Money for Access
description: LONDON  Of all the forces that swept Tony Blair's Labour Party into government last year, few were as powerful as the string of bribery scandals involving Conservative politicians that allowed Mr. Blair to campaign against "Tory sleaze."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALERNO, ISMAELE ''SAL''
description: SALERNO-Ismaele ''Sal''. July 9 of Bayside, Queens, N.Y. Husband of the late Maria Luigia. Devoted father of Anthony Salerno of Newburgh, NY and Elizabeth Cardile of Sag Harbor, N.Y. Father in-law of Carmelo. Devoted grandfather of Lynn Cardile Caniglia, Serafina Autumn Salerno, Emma Mary Salerno & Grant Joseph Salerno. Reposing at the Lloyd Funeral Home, 39th Avenue at 215th Street, Bayside, on Saturday and Sunday 2-5 & 7-9 PM. Mass Sacred Heart Church, Bayside, Monday, at 9:45 A.M. Interment in Saint Raymond's Cemetery, Bronx, N.Y.

title: Wayne Calloway Dies at 62; Was Chief at Pepsico 10 Years
description: Wayne Calloway, the former chairman and chief executive of Pepsico who combined a quiet, introspective leadership style with an intensely competitive business strategy, died on Wednesday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 62 and had been battling prostate cancer since 1992.

title: New Touches (Like Rage) for Stuttgart's 'Onegin'
description: Lincoln Center Festival '98 has brought the Stuttgart Ballet back to New York City with the tried and true. After John Cranko's ''Romeo and Juliet,'' his ''Onegin,'' the company's signature piece, introduced new dancers in familiar roles at the New York State Theater on Wednesday night.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Strong Retail Sales Push Shares of Retailers Higher

title: Quit Whining and They Will Come
description: Could George Steinbrenner's storied ambivalence about keeping the New York Yankees in the Bronx after 2002 really be melting? His team's winning streak this season and Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer's prediction that fan attendance could break the three million barrier moved Mr. Steinbrenner to a tantalizing comment. ''Do the three million, and then we'll talk about the Bronx after the season,'' he said. ''That isn't getting me where I want to be, but maybe it would be worth talking about.'' This attitudinal shift, if genuine, is a welcome development.

title: Hospital Has New Plan To Correct Deficiencies
description: Shaken by a highly critical state report on the way St. John's Episcopal Hospital cares for its patients, the newly appointed head of the hospital gave the state a detailed plan yesterday to correct a long list of deficiencies.

title: LUCENT SAYS IT WILL BUY DUTCH COMPANY'S ETHERNET UNIT
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. will acquire the Lannet Ethernet unit of Madge Networks N.V., a Dutch networking products company, for $117 million. Lannet, based in Tel Aviv, supplies switching systems for local area networks. It has 500 employees. Costs associated with writing off research and development acquired in the transaction will lower earnings by an unspecified amount for the quarter ending Sept. 30. The acquisition will enable Lucent to take advantage of growth in data networking related to the Internet and to gain customers and sales channels in Europe. Lucent, based in Murray Hill, N.J., makes telecommunications systems and software, and business telephone systems. Its shares slipped 56.25 cents, to $86.625.

title: Nigeria Holds Its Breath Waiting to Hear How a Prisoner Died
description: Stores were shuttered today, isolated fires burned and streets were unusually empty as Nigeria anxiously awaited a verdict on the sudden death of its main opposition leader, Moshood K. O. Abiola, and a timetable for the promised birth of a democratic system.

title: Murder Suspect Tries to Commit Suicide
description: A man charged with murdering two pizza deliverymen last year tried to commit suicide yesterday, only hours before he was expected to plead guilty to avoid the death penalty in the so-called thrill killing.

title: Pentagon to Weigh Competitor in Missile Plan
description: The Defense Department said today that it would consider finding a competitor to the Lockheed Martin Corporation as the prime contractor on the Army's trouble-plagued $15 billion antimissile system, a project that had been seen as the forerunner of a much larger program to shield the entire nation from missile attack.

Novacare also provides employee services. The company, which is based in King of Prussia, Pa., said it was the second-largest provider of outpatient rehabilitation services in the United States. Shares of Novacare rose $1.375 yesterday, to $12.625, giving the company a market capitalization of $780 million.

Peter Bart, the editor of Daily Variety, called magazine articles ''the source du jour for movies.''

description: Republican strategists conceded today that their party was vulnerable on managed-care legislation and needed to pass a credible bill before the November elections or risk political punishment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROD, JAMES P.
description: ROD-James P. The directors and staff of the Hudson River Foundation and the Hudson River Improvement Fund note with deepest sorrow the death of Jim Rod, manager of the Constitution Marsh Sanctuary. We celebrate Jim for his love of, and attention to, the natural world and his particular fervent commitment to understanding and protecting the Hudson River. We extend our sympathy to his family as we share with the entire Hudson River environmental community a feeling of immeasurable loss.

description: WHILE the art community may look upon ''The Art of the Motorcycle'' at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum as 114 pieces of 19th- and 20th-century kinetic sculpture from around the world, the hordes of motorcyclists who will see the show this summer are likely to view it as a long-overdue celebration of the sport, the machines and the pioneers they love.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROTMAN, MARTIN
description: BROTMAN-Martin. Artist and lifelong student of the Civil War, died July 6, 1998 at age 70. Survived by wife Gloria, daughter Zoe Denahy and son-in-law William, son Ivan and daugher-in-law Leslie, grandsons Jackson, Beauchamp, his father Jack and stepson Farrel Bove and wife Pam. He had a long career as a commercial artist & art director and was a watercolorist and member of the Brooklyn Watercolor Society and the New York Civil War Roundtable.

title: Legendary Artist Fit for the 90's
description: The Japanese-born Yayoi Kusama, 69, is a legend in postwar art, and an elusive one. A show at the Museum of Modern Art concentrates on her most innovative decade, 1958-1968. It includes the small gouaches and watercolors of biomorphic forms, like ''Seeds'' (left), that are, as a group, her most persuasive works.

title: A Fear of Violence Hovers Over Ulster's Parade Standoff
description: David Trimble, the new First Minister of Northern Ireland and head of the Protestant Ulster Unionist Party, said today that this British province ''faces a quite awesome prospect'' if a compromise is not reached soon over the Government's decision to ban a Protestant parade through a Roman Catholic community in Portadown, west of here.

title: New Yorker Staff Takes Deep Breath
description: Wearing a black T-shirt to a meeting that was anything but casual, S. I. Newhouse Jr. told uneasy staff members of The New Yorker yesterday that the departure of his star editor, Tina Brown, would not create precipitous changes at the magazine his family owns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, SIMEON, MD
description: SIEGEL-Simeon, MD, 86. Retired physician of New Milford, N.J., died on July 4 at Bergen Regional Medical Center after a long illness. He maintained a general family practice in Dumont, NJ for over 35 years. He was a member of the medical staff of Englewood Hospital & Bergen Pines County Hospital. At Bergen Pines, he served as Chief Physician of Alcoholism and Drug Rehabilitation Services from 1972 until his retirement in 1984. In addition, he served as a school physician for the Dumont Public Schools and as a staff physician for the former New York Central Railroad. Dr. Siegel was a veteran of World War II. He served for five years as a Captain in the United States Army in the European Theater of Operations. He is survived by his wife, Fanny, three children, Jessica, Norman and Steven & one grandson, Theodore. He is also survived by his brother Professor Paul Siegel of New York. His family invites friends, colleagues and former patients to remember him at a memorial service at his home, 2 Lynwood Avenue at the corner of New Bridge Road, in New Milford, NJ. The service will be held Saturday, July 25 from 2-5PM. Telephone 201-836-7453. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Bergen Regional Medical Center.

description: An organizer of an unsuccessful ballot initiative against affirmative action in Houston last year has accused the city's former mayor and his former employer, the brokerage firm Paine Webber, of trying to pressure him to curtail his political activities.

title: Ritual Angst Of a Girl, 17, In New Jersey
description: Lank-haired and sullen, and with a horsy face that can suddenly bloom into an expression of secret, dreamy-eyed rapture, Anna Stockard (Liza Weil), the central character of Susan Skoog's high school drama ''Whatever,'' is a slightly older, more unsettled, downscale version of Claire Danes's character in the television series ''My So-Called Life.'' Portrayed with a remarkable fluidity and naturalness by Ms. Weil, this mildly rebellious 17-year-old senior in a New Jersey high school is at a perilous crossroads.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELDEN, RICHARD C.
description: WELDEN-Richard C. Died on June 29, 1998. Husband of Mary T. Welden. Father of Thorn, Wickford and Trafford. Brother of Robert E. Welden. Born May 6, 1924 in Hartford, CT. Graduate of Loomis, 1942, Yale University, 1948 and Harvard Law School, 1951. U.S. Army veteran of World War II serving in India and China. Partner with law firm of Decker, Hubbard, Welden and Sweeney, NYC. A gentle man, he was an avid bird watcher & nature lover. Modest and loyal, he was always ready to assist friends and family. He loved hiking, tennis, Central Park and the beauty of the English language. Always on the go, full of energy and determination, he was a man of great integrity. He was always cheerful. We will miss him greatly. Memorial service on Tuesday, July 14, 1998, 11 A.M. at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Ave. at 91 Street. Donations in his memory may be made to the National Audubon Society or the Central Park Conservancy.

title: An Innovator Battling Demons of Society and Her Mind
description: The Japanese-born Yayoi Kusama, 69, is a legend in postwar art, and an elusive one. Her innovative work had high visibility in the 1960's, when she was living in New York and traveling frequently to Europe. After her return to Japan in the 70's, she faded from the international stage. Only in the 90's has she come back into view, and her art has never made more sense than it does now.

title: Return to Profitability Bolsters Club Med Stock
description: The shares of Club Mediterranee S.A. jumped yesterday after the company, Europe's largest package-tour operator, returned to profit after two consecutive annual losses. Shares jumped 27 francs, to 567, after the company said late Wednesday that it had a profit of 132 million francs ($22 million) in the first half, which ended April 30, from a loss of 413 million francs a year earlier. Under Philippe Bourguignon, the former head of Euro Disney S.A., who took over from Club Med founders in February 1997, the company began a three-year plan to cut costs and reorganize its resorts.

title: The History Behind Trent Lott
description: Senator Trent Lott's recent condemnation of homosexuality and a variety of anti-gay initiatives in Southern communities point up an important trend in American politics, and a threatening one for advocates of inclusive democracy. Curiously, this more restrictive attitude toward social freedom is linked to a newly expansive exercise of religious freedom. Starting about 20 years ago, evangelical Christians began shedding their traditional aversion to political activism. In the South especially, they have flooded into the electoral process, settling mainly in the Republican Party. In doing it, they have charged and changed American politics as has no other force since the civil rights revolution. They have transformed the Republicans, bringing to the party a potent bloc vote, boundless energy and an unwillingness to compromise on certain domestic social issues.

Brakes screech, drivers veer and vehicles go bang while Mr. Gibson endures this nightmare until Danny Glover manages to hoist him off the pavement at high speed. After this, the two stars crash straight through an office building in their runaway car. Pardon me for having groaned in anticipation of what, in the full perspective-warping heat of the summer movie season, turns out to be one of the nicer blow-'em-ups around.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAVES, MARILYN
description: GRAVES-Marilyn. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend Marilyn Graves. A woman of great spirit and dedication, Ms. Graves was a volunteer at The New York Hospital for 44 years & also served as Treasurer of the Auxiliary of The Society of the New York Hospital for many years. In recognition of her outstanding commitment, she was the first person nominated by the hospital to receive the United Hospital Fund's Auxiliarian of the Year Award. She was much loved and will be greatly missed. Our sincere sympathies are extended to her family and friends. David B. Skinner, M.D. Vice Chairman and CEO, New York Presbyterian Hospital.

title: Far-Fetched Shakespeare, With an Air of Reason
description: Now, about that bear. As Shakespearean cameos go, his is one of the silliest. He lumbers onstage in the middle of ''The Winter's Tale'' to startle poor old Antigonus, a brief encounter that not only enables a switch of scene from staid Sicilia to exotic Bohemia, but also makes possible one of the most diabolically unambiguous stage directions of all time: ''Exit, pursued by a bear.''

title: DELUXE ENDS AGREEMENT TO SELL TWO OF ITS BUSINESSES
description: The Deluxe Corporation, the nation's largest check printer, said yesterday that it had ended its agreement to sell its Paperdirect Inc. and Social Expressions specialty paper and greeting cards businesses to a private investor, because some conditions were not met. Deluxe agreed in April to sell the units for an undisclosed price so that it could focus on check printing and electronic-payment services. Paperdirect and Social Expressions had sales of $231 million last year, about 12 percent of the company's $1.92 billion in revenue. Deluxe, based in St. Paul, said it would work to market and sell the units. Deluxe's stock fell $1.125 a share, to $36.8125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBOIS, JOAN FITZGERALD
description: DUBOIS-Joan FitzGerald, 50. Prominent Los Angeles philanthropic executive, died May 20 while on vacation in Canada. A graduate of St. Joseph's College for Women, Brooklyn, and the New York University School of Law, Mrs. DuBois had a distinguished career. Over the past 14 years she became recognized as one of the leading philanthropic executives in the country. Until December, 1996, she was program vice president at the W.M. Keck Foundation, one of the nation's largest foundations. Since then she consulted with major institutions on their philanthropic strategy. Mrs. DuBois was responsible for the Keck Foundation's grant programs in medical research, law and its special Southern California Program. Her collaboration with Howard B. Keck, the Foundation's chairman during her tenure, resulted in the Foundation becoming a recognized national leader in philanthropy, benefiting medical research and legal education. During that time the medical research program focused on significant grants to major institutions with an emphasis on innovative research design in the fields of molecular biology and neuroscience. The Foundation's program in law produced a substantial body of work on legal ethics education during this period, and its Southern California program sought principally to benefit children in its grantmaking to education, the arts and health care. Earlier in her career, she was an attorney and planner for the Children's Defense Fund in New York and Cambridge, Mass. She was one of the original members of The Defense Fund and worked closely with the Hon. Justine Wise Polier and Marion Wright Edelman, the founders. Her work with the District of Columbia Committee of the House of Representatives resulted in the writing and passage of the first mandatory child abuse and neglect reporting law in the United States. That statute served as the model for the National Child Abuse and Neglect Reporting Law which set up the National Center on Child Abuse within the DHEW. Active in community affairs, Mrs. DuBois was a sustaining member of the Junior League of Los Angeles and a member of The Blue Ribbon, a support group for the Music Center of Los Angeles County. She is survived by her husband, Peter, of Los Angeles, her parents, Benjamin and Agnes FitzGerald of Mendham, N.J., a sister, Eileen Sudler, also of Mendham, and 10 nieces and nephews.

title: Going Everywhere, at Home Nowhere but Within Himself
description: In 1940, Gordon Parks, the son of a dirt farmer in Fort Scott, Kan., who made his living playing piano in a brothel, washing dishes in a restaurant and waiting on tables on a transcontinental train, found himself broke in Minnesota. So he did what any poor black man trying to support his wife and kids would do: He went to an exclusive clothing store in St. Paul and told the owner that he would like to take fashion photographs. Amazingly, the store gave him a chance. He borrowed lights and a camera, muddled through a roll of double exposures and got one good picture, the shot that started his illustrious and improbable career in photography.

Mr. Rasamny was born in Lebanon, July 20, 1915 and had lived at 1067 Fifth Avenue, NY. With his four brothers he founded Rasamny Brothers, Inc., distributors of goods to Lebanon, Liberia and the United States. He was a former Director of the UBAF Arab American Bank, former Director and past executive Vice President of the US-Arab Chamber of Commerce, and was a honorary life member of the American University of Beirut. He was decorated by the Republic of Lebanon with Le Chevalier de L'Ordre Nationale du Cedar and by the Republic of Liberia with the Commander of the Star of Africa. He also served on the American Task Force for Lebanon along with Senator George Mitchell and then Chief-of-Staff John Sununu. He was also a member of a special delegation to the Gulf States. He was predeceased by his wife, Attia Ibrahim Rasamny and a son, Jerrir. He is survived by four children Leila R. Gorra of NYC, Robert Rasamny of Chappaqua, NY, Richard K. Rasamny of Redding, CT., and Linda R. Kansao of Redding, Connecticut, three brothers in Lebanon, thirteen grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. Calling hours are Saturday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M., at Hull Funeral Home, Danbury, CT. Burial services from Hull Funeral Home to Umpawaug Cemetery, Redding, Conn., at 1 P.M., on Sunday. description: A circuit judge in Butts County, Ga., today denied a request that he overturn the 16-year-old murder convictions of Wayne B. Williams, the Atlanta man sentenced to life in prison in 1982 in the murders of two adults and blamed but never indicted in the series of child killings here in the early 1980's.

title: Push by Secessionist Forces Adds to Economic Pressures : Reforms Unleash Habibie Foes
description: JAKARTA  Emboldened by promises of political reform in Indonesia, groups demanding independence are intensifying their activities in East Timor, Irian Jaya and other remote parts of the country, creating new challenges for the government of President B.J. Habibie as it battles to prevent economic collapse.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROUSSIN, ARTHUR RICHARD
description: ROUSSIN-Arthur Richard. March 12, 1926-July 11, 1993. ''If you press me to say why I loved him, I can say no more than it was because he was he and I was I.'' Montaigne I miss you so much. Stuppy

title: Foreign Affairs; Over and Over Again
description: If someone were to make a movie about the Mideast peace process, there could be only one appropriate title: ''Groundhog Day'' -- where the same day, the same discussions, just get repeated over and over. But even Groundhog Day eventually came to an end. And so will the peace process version. It closes May 4, 1999 -- the day the Oslo agreement runs out.

title: Official at S.E.C. Is Joining Law Firm
description: Colleen P. Mahoney, acting general counsel at the Securities and Exchange Commission and a former deputy enforcement director, disclosed this week that upon leaving the commission, she would become a partner in securities and litigation matters at the New York law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom.

title: A Big Welcome Mat in the Outfield
description: At a little past 7 tonight, Todd Hundley will jog to the outfield grass of Shea Stadium, where he will play somewhere other than behind home plate for the first time in his major league career.

title: Relatives of Immigrants Testify at Hearing
description: It was around 11 A.M. today when 21-year-old Cheng Xing Da finally felt a little less lonely in an unfamiliar land.

title: SAP, Software Maker, Says Profit Pace Slows
description: SAP A.G., the world's leading maker of business-management software, disclosed figures yesterday that indicated that rising labor costs and weaker Asian currencies had crimped profit growth in the second quarter of the year. Profit growth slowed to 26 percent from 71 percent in the first quarter. Second-quarter pretax profit of 504 million marks ($276 million) was calculated from figures supplied by the company for the first half of the year. SAP did not directly report net income.

title: Police Arrest 9 in a London Bombing Plot, Saying Explosives Were Just About to Go Off
description: In a coordinated sweep, the police in Ireland and England arrested nine people today and said they had foiled a plot to bomb central London with only moments to spare.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: SOFTBANK OF JAPAN IN $400 MILLION ON-LINE DEAL
description: The Softbank Corporation, Japan's largest software distributor and an investor in on line companies, agreed to pay $400 million for 27.2 percent of E*Trade Group Inc., the biggest Internet-based brokerage firm. Softbank paid $25.56 a share for 15.6 million new shares of E*Trade. E*Trade last traded at $24.50, down $1.0625, before trading in the stock was halted. E*Trade is the latest addition to Softbank's collection of Internet companies. The Tokyo-based company increased its stake in Yahoo Inc., the most-visited Internet directory, to 31 percent earlier this week. It also owns 35 percent of Geo Cities, a World Wide Web-based community, and 71 percent of Ziff-Davis Inc., a media company specializing in computers and software.

title: Much More Than A Game
description: Hundreds of millions of people throughout the world will be watching when France and Brazil meet in Paris in the World Cup final tomorrow.

title: A Diocese Settles a Case Of Sex Abuse
description: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Dallas agreed today to pay $23.4 million to eight former altar boys and the family of a ninth who say they were sexually victimized by a priest in the 1980's and early 1990's.

title: About New York; Danger Signs, But No Sense Of Urgency
description: IN the corner of Alice Herb's living room is a game her grandchildren play whenever they visit her in Greenwich Village. It's called ''Snafu -- the Maze Game That Runs You Ragged.'' ''Push the buttons,'' the instructions read. ''Spin the dials.'' If she had to spin her wheels, Grandma could probably win with ease; she has had practice in another labyrinth.

title: TEAMSTERS TOLD THAT PROMISED JOBS ARE HALTED
description: United Parcel Service of America Inc., the world's largest package delivery company, has told the teamsters' union that it will not create 2,000 full-time jobs as promised last year in a settlement that ended a national strike. The Atlanta-based company declared the job-creation pledge ''null and void,'' citing an escape clause requiring U.P.S. to create the jobs only if the number of package deliveries returns to pre-strike levels. U.P.S. said shipments were still down. The move, which was reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal, threatens to reopen a dispute between the two sides that escalated into a two-week strike last summer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAZER, WILLIAM
description: MAZER-William. The Brandeis University community mourns the death of a cherished and longstanding friend. A gentle and generous man, he provided wisdom and support as a member of our Board of Trustees for over four decades. In appreciation of Mr. Mazer's leadership, at Brandeis and in the community at large, the university awarded him the Distinguished Service to Higher Education Award in 1975, an honorary doctorate in 1977, and the Jacob A. Goldfarb Medal in 1982. Together with his late wife Helen, Mr. Mazer supported faculty research, undergraduate research and many other areas of Brandeis activity. The William and Helen Mazer Residence Hall stands as a testament to their devotion to the ideals of education. We extend our deepest sympathies to his children, Linda Berkowitz and her husband Leonard, Frank Mazer and his wife Angela, and Robert Mazer and his wife Magda; to his seven grandchildren, including three Brandeis alumni-Steven Bercu '85, Alan Berkowitz, M.M.H.S. '93, and David Berkowitz '91; and to his entire family. Jehuda Reinharz, President Barton J. Winokur, Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: Wasted Waterfront
description: To the Editor:

title: A Settlement on Implants
description: The tentative $3.2 billion settlement agreement between Dow Corning Corporation and lawyers for thousands of women who claim they have been made ill by silicone breast implants seems a prudent financial move for both sides. A settlement would allow the company to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy and plaintiffs would get compensated for suffering and for the costs of getting the implants surgically removed. A legal settlement does not resolve scientific questions about the safety of the implants. But those questions could not have been fully answered in a court of law, even if the cases had gone to trial.

title: P.K. Bloch, 79, Whose Company Developed Uses for Ultrasound
description: Peter K. Bloch, a founder and former president of Branson Instruments, a company that developed ultrasound fetal monitoring and a number of other medical and commercial uses for ultrasound, died on Tuesday in New London, N.H. He was 79 and lived in New London.

title: Teammates at the Meet, Strangers at Practice
description: The three girls are fast, confident, fiercely competitive and accomplished enough to have won a total of six national high school sprint titles. They live on the same block, were friends for years, played on the same community softball team and this past season led the powerful Montclair High School track squad to state and East Coast records in the Penn Relays.

title: Bridge; Should You Bid 1 No-Trump With 5 in a Major? Depends
description: Should an opening bid of one no-trump conceal a five-card major suit? There are four schools of thought about this. Some do it routinely, and may have responding methods that allow the five-card suit to be shown. Some, like the late great Edgar Kaplan, never do it at all. Some do it when the hand has scattered honors and seems best suited to no-trump. And some conceal hearts but not spades.

title: Secret of the Eternally Young Sleuths
description: After nearly 70 years, Nancy Drew is still going out with Ned Nickerson and Joe Hardy is still dating his friend Chet's sister, Iola. There are certain things about the Nancy Drew and Hardy Boys series that just never change. Yet these wildly popular teen-age detective novels -- since they began in 1927, about 200 million volumes have been sold -- are nonetheless seen to reflect historical changes.

title: Police Officer and a Friend Are Found Shot to Death
description: A decorated veteran of the Jersey City Police Department and a friend were found shot to death in the officer's apartment Thursday, and a prime suspect, the officer's former roommate, apparently killed himself in rural Pennsylvania, officials said.

title: Irabu Grins: Starter's Role Is Rightly His
description: Hideki Irabu, showered and dressed, waited for his teammates at the clubhouse door after the Yankees beat Tampa Bay, 8-4, tonight. When Joe Girardi, his catcher, walked into view, Irabu wore the broad grin of a man redeemed.

title: Gill Says He Wants To Stay With Nets
description: The lockout of the N.B.A. players by the league's owners is not bothering Kendall Gill of the Nets. But talk that he could be dealt before the players are back on the court does bother him.

title: Guard Given 4 Years In Immigrant Beating
description: The last defendant in the 1995 beating of illegal immigrants at the Union County Jail was sentenced yesterday to four years in prison.

title: Protecting New York's Children
description: Two years after the creation of New York City's Administration for Children's Services under the leadership of Nicholas Scoppetta, child protection programs have improved but serious deficiencies persist. The brutal sexual abuse of three children in Brooklyn and the near-starvation of a 2-year-old boy in a Staten Island foster home show recent reforms have not been swift or comprehensive enough to protect these children who were under the city's watch.

title: Japan's Political System Freezes Out Reformers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSHOWITZ, LOUIS
description: GERSHOWITZ - Louis. Beloved husband of 50 years of Charlotte. Loving father of Howard Gershowitz and Barbara Wachs. Cherished father-in-law of Pamela Gershowitz and Alan Wachs. Adored grandfather of Scott and Jennifer Wachs, and Danielle Gershowitz. Dear brother of Dorrie Gershowitz and Mildred Greene. Services Sunday, 12 noon, at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Monday with an article about campaigns for the House of Representatives misidentified the Congressional seat held by Representative Vic Fazio. It is California's Third District, which covers the Sacramento Valley, not the 31st District.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNOTT, LOIS A.
description: KNOTT-Lois A. In Westport, CT. On July 8th, 1998. Wife of the late John S. Knott, Sr. Mother of John S. Knott, Jr. and Sara A. Knott. Formerly of New York City, New Canaan, CT., and Rumson, N.J. Services Tuesday, July 14, 10AM in Christ & Holy Trinity Episcopal Church, Westport. Interment in Fairview Cemetery, Red Bank, NJ. Memorial contributions may be made to the John S. Knott Memorial Fund, C/O Yale Development Office In Memoriam Program, PO Box 1890, New Haven, CT. 06508-1890.

title: Agreement Ends 40-Day Philadelphia Strike, Restoring Transit Service
description: A 40-day strike that shut down the network of buses, trolleys and subways serving 435,000 passengers a day here ended today when the Transport Workers Union and the regional transit authority announced that they had reached a tentative agreement on a new contract.

title: Acquisition Gives Roche Big Jump in Revenue
description: Roche Holding A.G.'s implied second-quarter sales rose 37.9 percent, as revenue at the company, the world's sixth-biggest drug maker, was lifted by its takeover of Corange Ltd. and the introduction of new drugs. Second-quarter sales rose to 6.69 billion Swiss francs ($4.33 billion) from 4.85 billion francs a year earlier. Quarterly revenue, not disclosed by Roche, was calculated by comparing announced results for the first half and first quarter.

title: Tuition at Rutgers To Increase 7 Percent
description: Rutgers University announced yesterday that it would raise tuition by 7 percent for its 48,000 graduate and undergraduate students this fall.

title: A Fluke Score Dooms CityHawks
description: A fluke score helped the Portland Forest Dragons defeat the CityHawks, 56-51, last night before 4,817 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Pilot and Navigator in Ski Lift Accident Face Involuntary Manslaughter Charges
description: A senior Marine Corps general yesterday ordered a court martial on the most serious possible charges for the pilot and the navigator of an electronic warfare jet that hit a ski lift cable in Italy in February, killing 20 people.

title: In Questions, Brawley Jury Shows an Eye For Details
description: The jurors in the Tawana Brawley defamation case deliberated for a second full day without reaching a verdict, but sent signals today that they were working hard to find answers to the 11-year-old questions posed by the case.

title: Hurtling and Skimming In a Celebration of Jazz
description: Billy Siegenfeld is an Al Pacino look-alike with a rough purr of a singing voice. He and his collaborator, Jeannie Hill, move with a speed and expansiveness that suggest that their feet disdain mere human dance steps. But with one exception, the program of five pieces that Mr. Siegenfeld, Ms. Hill and their Jump Rhythm Jazz Project presented on Tuesday night at Kaye Playhouse was a disappointment.

title: For a Champion of Nigerian Unity, a Stoning by Its Foes
description: In a somber room, where straight-backed women mourned, a former Nigerian Vice President spoke today of his country's fragility and its need to give all citizens, irrespective of ethnic background, a sense of belonging.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-5

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK STRENGTHENS. The mark gained as Russia, with which Germany has close business ties, seemed near an accord with the International Monetary Fund. The dollar fell to 1.8180 marks, from 1.8288 marks on Thursday.

title: A TV Blackout For a Weaker Team
description: USA Basketball will not permit networks to televise the world championships in Athens next month, citing concern over what a weakened team would mean to its marketing efforts, said Craig Miller, a spokesman for USA Basketball.

title: SUNBEAM GRANTED MORE TIME ON LOANS BY LENDERS
description: The Sunbeam Corporation, Delray Beach, Fla., the money-losing appliance maker that dismissed its chairman last month, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with its lenders that averts a default on $1.7 billion in loans until at least the end of the year. Sunbeam, the largest United States maker of small appliances, said Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company, the First Union Corporation and the BankAmerica Corporation had agreed to waive loan covenants that would have caused a default. Sunbeam has $1.4 billion in debt and about $300 million available under a credit agreement.

title: SCOTTS AGREES TO PURCHASE OF RHONE-POULENC UNIT
description: The Scotts Company, a maker of lawn and garden products, agreed yesterday to buy Rhone-Poulenc S.A.'s lawn and garden unit and the Netherlands-based ASEF for a combined purchase price of about $220 million, completing an acquisition program it began last year. Scotts, the maker of Miracle-Gro and Hyponex garden products, said it would use debt to buy the businesses. The purchase of Rhone-Poulenc Jardin, Europe's largest garden-care company, and privately held ASEF will immediately help earnings, Scotts said. The move gives Scotts, which makes most of its sales in the United States, a larger foothold in Europe.

title: Ulster Parade Talks Planned
description: Protestant and Roman Catholic officials agreed today to begin negotiations on Saturday to end the rising Protestant violence over a disputed Protestant parade through a Catholic neighborhood west of here.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a young woman who recanted trial testimony that her father had sexually abused her misstated the given name of the judge in the case. He is Victor J. Alfieri, not Vincent.

title: With Better Arms, Kosovo Separatists Turn Tide in War
description: Ethnic Albanian rebels have acquired arsenals of anti-tank and antiaircraft weapons that are shifting the balance of power in the war in Kosovo Province.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the Pakistani Foreign Secretary's criticism of India misspelled his surname. He is Shamshad Ahmad, not Ahmed.

title: Boardman Distracted but Determined
description: This whole year has been a roller-coaster ride, physically and mentally, for Chris Boardman, and now, as his biggest moment in the bicycle-racing season arrives, he is heading down, down, down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMILER, RUTH
description: SMILER-Ruth, on July 9th, 1998. Loving wife of Albert, mother of Dennis and Eric, mother-in-law of Barbara & Florence, grandmother of Scott, Todd, Brooke, Jason and Darren. Your memory will live in our hearts forever, for you were truly unique. Burial took place on Friday, July 10th, at Gutterman's in Woodbury.

title: Think Tank; When Life Is a Day at the Beach
description: His full-color business card shows him on the white sands of Lanakai Beach in Oahu, wearing white shorts and matching knit shirt, his shadow knifing out into the blue-green waters.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''She decided to write a life and did it by living it -- and she more or less lived it to the hilt.''

title: 3 Teen-Agers Accused Of Thefts on Subway
description: Three teen-agers were arrested yesterday afternoon after they robbed a carload of subway commuters at gunpoint on the East Side of Manhattan, the police said.

title: William Mazer, 92, a Leader In Charity and a Paper Company
description: William Mazer, who made his fortune in the paper industry and shared it with charities at home and in Israel, died on Tuesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 92 and lived on the Upper East Side.

title: Gallic Smiles Have Erased Gallic Gloom, for Now
description: Until just recently, the French motto seemed to be, ''I could have been a contender.''

title: Political Briefing; Maryland Governor Gets Lesson in Unity
description: When Louis L. Goldstein, Maryland's longtime State Comptroller, died last week, leaving one of the state's most politically powerful posts open, Gov. Parris N. Glendening, a Democrat involved in a tough re-election fight, thought he saw an opportunity to give his campaign a boost. He talked former Representative Michael D. Barnes, his campaign chairman, into jumping into the contest to succeed Mr. Goldstein.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNKLAU, DOROTHY RISS
description: BERNKLAU-Dorothy Riss, 1991. Remembered fondly. Her children David and Renee, and four-yearold granddaughter Danielle.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Business Digest on July 1 referring to an article about Pepsico's new diet cola with an artificial sweetener known as Ace-K referred incorrectly to a statistic about the market. The $55 billion figure represented the size of the carbonated soft drink market in the United States -- not the amount that the sweetener is expected to add.

title: Man in L.I. Beating Case May Act as Own Lawyer
description: A white man accused in the near-fatal beating of a black man outside a Westhampton Beach nightclub can represent himself in his retrial, a judge ruled yesterday.

title: At the Mercy of Lust, Yet in Total Control
description: It's a mistake to underestimate Janet Jackson. True, she's not the strongest singer around, or the most original songwriter; she works slowly, with four-year gaps between albums and tours, and keeps quiet between projects. Yet long after the other masters of the 1980's pop spectacle have withdrawn -- Madonna to motherhood, Michael Jackson to fatherhood -- Ms. Jackson has not just persevered but thrived.

title: The House and the I.M.F.
description: Playing politics with the International Monetary Fund may seem good sport to House Republicans, but their games now imperil international financial stability and the future growth of the American economy. When the House returns to work next week, it must approve America's long-delayed $18 billion contribution to the I.M.F.
