title: Daddy Dearest: Do You Really Matter?; Everyone Agrees You Do, but So Far No One Has Established Why
description: It seems self-evident to just about anyone who has ever had a father that a caring, involved dad is good for a child.

title: At Play in the Microtones of the Blues
description: Andy Bey isn't your typically ingratiating jazz singer-pianist; in performance, his extraordinary talent can seem protected in a glass museum case, resting on a pillow. And his sense of pacing asks that you travel at least halfway toward him.

title: Hyundai Offers Early Retirement
description: The Hyundai Motor Company, South Korea's biggest auto manufacturer, said today that it would begin a fourth early retirement program on Monday as part of its push to cut its original 45,000-strong work force by 20 percent.

title: Boeing Raises Base Prices of Commercial Jets
description: Seeking to improve its long-term financial performance, the Boeing Company said yesterday that it had increased the base prices of its multimillion-dollar passenger jets by 5 percent, the first such increase since 1975.

title: Under Political Pressure, Silver Weighs Allowing Vote on Parole Bill
description: Sheldon Silver, the Assembly Speaker, is considering bringing it back into session this summer to vote on the Governor's proposal to toughen parole rules for violent felons, aides and allies say, now that he has come to fear that the Assembly's failure to approve it earlier this year may hurt the Democrats at the polls.

description: Optimism on Earnings Bolsters Stock Market

description: ROLLINS-Jack Leon. July 5, 1998 at his home in Sun City, AZ. Retired textile executive with Cohen Hall Marx in N.Y., Chairman of the Board, Associated Textiles of Canada, Montreal, and Chairman of the Board, United Merchants and Manufacturers, U.K., Ltd. He was the devoted husband of the late Dorothy Langdon & loving father of Nancy Ginsberg & Janet Berry. He leaves three grandsons and six great grandchildren. Memorial gifts may be made to Sun Health Foundation, Sun City, Arizona, University of Missouri-Columbia ''Rollins Scholarship'' or National Federation for the Blind.

title: Political Briefing; Illinois Democrats Spur Their Candidate
description: Some leading Democrats in Illinois are worried that Representative Glenn Poshard's campaign for governor is flagging, and they have begun urging him to pick up the pace and sharpen his attack.

title: Journal; Tina and Disney Elope
description: A few weeks ago I went with the last surviving habitue of the Algonquin Round Table, the artist Al Hirschfeld, to his old stomping ground in search of the past. The Algonquin Hotel has just been lovingly refurbished, but the past wasn't there. ''They make no attempt to recreate the table exactly,'' said Mr. Hirschfeld, 95, who pointed out the spot in the room where he used to dine with Dorothy Parker, Charles MacArthur and Robert Benchley. Not that the unsentimental Mr. Hirschfeld minded. ''The round table was square anyway,'' he said.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNAUGH, GEORGE LOUIS
description: LYNAUGH-George Louis, 58. Died July 9 at his home in Milan, N.Y., after a long and courageous battle with lung cancer. George was executive vice president of McCann Erickson, culminating a lifelong career in advertising. After retirement he was owner and operator of the Hyde Park Antique Center, his labor of love. He is survived by his mother Nancy, brothers Leonard & Louis, sister Eileen Durst and six dear nephews. He will be sorely missed by his many friends and beloved animals. In lieu of flowers donations made to cancer research or an animal care organization would please him. For information Dapson-Chestney Funeral Home, Rhinebeck, New York 914-876-6000.

title: Love's Arrows
description: Cupid and Diana

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUCHAZIK, TED
description: KUCHAZIK-Ted. 82. Of Grove St, Jersey City, of Okinawa and Rutherford, NJ. Loving husband of Toshiko, father of Ignace, and uncle of Rudy. Beloved brother of Frances, Steve, Rudy, John, Leon and Archie. Donations to City Meals on Wheels or Hale House. ''Ponder this as you pass by-as you are now, so once was I. As I am now soon you will be. Prepare for death and follow me.''

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; From Economist to Playwright
description: One look at his desk and you know John Tepper Marlin, New York City's chief economist, is a busy man. But Mr. Marlin, 56, is not only in the midst of city budget preparations these days. He's also pondering the finishing touches on his first full-length drama.

title: Furious Fabricators of a Faust for the Digital Age
description: LA FURA DELS BAUS is as unusual a name in Catalan as it is in English: the Ferret from the Baus. But there was method to the fantasy of the five young street performers who chose the name of their new experimental theater company in Barcelona in 1979. The ferret, which can be trained but not tamed, appealed to their anarchic instincts, while the Baus is the name of a dark ravine near their hometown of Moya, 30 miles north of Barcelona, where the five would hang out before they moved here in their late teens. So it sort of made sense.

title: The Green Between
description: I HAVE always been a little in awe of the approach to the Field Museum in Chicago. Heading south on Lake Shore Drive, which unwinds between the park-lined shores of Lake Michigan and the towering edge of the city, the motorist is lured straight on toward the broad steps and classical columns of the Beaux-Arts museum. At the last moment, the busy road is forced to bend to this monumental temple of knowledge, and until recently, the solution was symmetry. The southbound lanes passed to the west, and the northbound to the east, cutting a close arc past the area's other two lakefront museums, the John G. Shedd Aquarium and the Max Adler Planetarium and Astronomy Museum.

title: Rethinking a Landmark in Marrakesh
description: La Maison Arabe in Marrakesh, a near-legendary restaurant that closed a decade ago, was reborn this year. But this time it's a hotel. A charming and beautifully decorated collection of 11 rooms meanders through the two buildings that housed the restaurant on a side street in the Medina (old city).

title: Nicole Toran and Tony Stovall
description: Nicole Elise Toran, the daughter of Dr. Marjorie Toran and Anthony Toran of Brookville, N.Y., is to be married there this evening to Tony Andre Stovall, a son of Barbara and John Stovall Jr. of Detroit. The Rev. Alan B. Ramirez is to perform the ceremony at the Brookville Reformed Church.

title: Home Buyers Find More Brokers
description: PHILIP YOUNG of Norwalk was ready to buy a home. His lease was ending on a rental unit in Fairfield, he knew what he wanted in a new condo, and he didn't have much time to make his decision.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMYTHE, CLEMENTINE (NEE SCOTT
description: SMYTHE-Clementine (nee Scott). Of Englewood, NJ, passed away away on June 27, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Robert J. (1973), devoted mother of the late Gloria Patricia Smythe (1994). Predeceased by a sister, Juliet Verrill, and a brother, Ed Scotti. Dear aunt of Robert L. Davidson, Beryl Tittle, Muriel Clawson, and Donald Smythe. Funeral is private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUSH, JOHN ''JACK.''
description: BUSH-John ''Jack.'' Of Cotuit, MA. Husband of Virginia. Father of Paula Fagerholm, Patricia Scadding, Peter, Timothy and Richard Bush. Brother of Dr. Richard Bush. Grandfather of seven. A memorial service will be held in St. Peter's Episcopal Church, Osterville, MA, on Wednesday, July 15, at 10:30 AM. Donations to American Cancer Society, 1115 West Chestnut St., Suite 301, Brockton, MA 02401.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on April 13 about a Jewish celebration in the West Bank city of Hebron referred incompletely to the people at the gathering. Along with settlers from the West Bank, they included Jews from Israel proper. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Flatiron? It's Behind the Sign
description: Max Sabrin used to be able to see the Flatiron Building from the 11th-floor window of his office at 928 Broadway, near 22d Street, where he works as a job recruiter. Now he looks out onto the back of a sign. ''One day, I have panoramic views,'' he said. ''The next day, I'm staring at a big black wall.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOMBAY, ARNOLD
description: BOMBAY-Arnold. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Arnold Bombay, associated with The Times from 1976.

title: Three Centuries Of the Dust Jacket
description: 1672, London: The printer Erasmus Weeble's dogsbody disfigures the tooled leather cover of the Duke of Thumbsdown's ''Dissertation Upon the Comickal Physiognomy of the Swine, Dedicated to Lady Plinth on Her Recovering From the Dropsy'' with kipper juice from his breakfast. Weeble hastily binds the volume in the lad's burlap sandwich wrapping and delivers it to the Duke, who has him promptly clapped in irons for insulting a nobleman.

title: Shanaz Nagji and John Diefendorf
description: WHILE she is petite, Shanaz Nagji is rarely timid, especially on the subway. One morning, two and a half years ago, while she was boarding the No. 9 train at West 116th Street, she firmly pushed a total stranger, John Diefendorf 3d, over to the side so she could have a spot by the door.

title: London
description: Dark, serious London opens up like a relieved flower in the summertime. The spectacular blooms and new broods of ducklings in the parks; the residents in short sleeves and flowing dresses; the young office workers enjoying after-work pints on the sidewalk at pubs -- all conspire to lift the mood.

title: 'Someone Else's House'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Business of Child Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Cyberpalooza
description: Meet Lara Croft, pinup gal for the digital age. Rising from humble beginnings as a computer-generated figure in Tomb Raider, an action-adventure mystery game, she is now poised to become the most prominent Western example of a phenomenon already familiar in Japan: a ''virtual idol,'' the cybercreation as celebrity. ''Lara's Book,'' by Douglas Coupland, arrives in stores this weekend, celebrating the ''life'' and times of a British aristocrat with a wild streak, a woman who combines the dash of a James Bond with the oversupplied physique of a Bond babe. Rizzoli is publishing a book next year, Tomb Raider 3 is set for a November release and a big-budget feature film is in the works for late 1999.

title: Pitfalls In Luxury Decontrol
description: UNDER a law passed in 1993 and amended last year, rent-stabilized tenants who pay $2,000 or more a month for their apartments and whose annual household incomes were more than $175,000 in each of the two preceding years are not entitled to the protection of rent stabilization.

title: Sara Osborne And John Quale

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSCHENBAUM, LEAH
description: KIRSCHENBAUM-Leah. Beloved wife of the late New York State Supreme Court Justice Irving Kirschenbaum, passed away on Friday, July 10, in Maine. Mrs. Kirschenbaum was 82, and lived in Harrison, NY. She grew up in Brooklyn, NY. During early married life she was active in the B'nai B'rith and Hadassah. In later years she and her husband were active in a wide range of Jewish charities, and served as founding memebers of the Harrison Jewish Community Center. She is survived by her loving children: Jerome and Lois of Little Deer Isle, ME; Stephen and Barbro of Mt. Kisco, NY, and Santa Fe, NM; Bruce and Judy of Reston, VA; and Rose-Eve Lewis of Carmel Valley, CA. Mrs. Kirschenbaum is also survived by nine grandchildren: Joshua, Leif, Robert, Kerstin, Boaz, Ari, Genevieve, Jamie and Anne-Marie. She is also survived by her brother, Irving Warmstein. Services will be held at 10 AM, on Sunday, July 12, at the Harrison Jewish Community Center. Contributions in lieu flowers may be made to the Elie Wiesel Foundation for Humanity, 1117 Avenue of the Americas, 36th flr, NYC 10036.

title: Schools For Sale
description: As an educator who has devoted her life to public education, I would like to congratulate Michael Winerip for sharing a few of the sobering realities of school choice, although he left out one sad reality (''Schools for Sale,'' June 14). This year we re-enrolled eight children at my school whose parents had opted for charter schools early on but ended up (for a variety of reasons) back where they started. Since no provision exists for returning the per-pupil allotment of funds to the public sector when a child returns to public school, we end up in a lose-lose situation.

title: A Cuban Exile Details the 'Horrendous Matter' of a Bombing Campaign

It was something shocking and inexplicable in a police state notorious for its tight security, and from one end of the island to the other, people speculated about who might be responsible.

When she reached for her leather cigarette case, however, the bartender told her she would have to step outside. Although a canister of matches was still on the counter, smoking was no longer allowed.

This means that the notable and multifarious permanent collection can be savored by late-summer visitors, and it also means more special exhibitions. These might often relate to the season without having an expressly summer theme. For example, one of the spate of current shows takes place in the shade, on deep olive walls and with spotlights trained on the paintings, which helps to bring out their fine details.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRONAN, LEO J.
description: CRONAN-Leo J. Age 91. Husband of the late Loretta (Kelly) Cronan, died in Warrenton, VA, on July 5. Born in Beverly, MA son of the late Daniel and Elizabeth (Gibney) Cronin, he was a graduate of Beverly High School and attended Pinkerton Academy and was a graduate of Notre Dame University in the Class of 1934. Mr. Cronan served as a Lt. Commander in the US Navy during WW II and was a teacher and coach for the Brook School of North Andover, MA, and the Weston High School of Weston, MA. Survivors are one daughter, Marcia Cronan and her daughter Elizabeth Thomas, both of Marshall, VA, and several nieces and nephews. He was also the father of the late Christopher Cronan and brother of the late Daniel Cronin. The funeral will be at the Campbell Funeral Home, 525 Cabot St., Beverly, MA, on Wednesday, at 8:15 AM, followed by a Funeral Mass at St. Margaret's Church, Beverly Farms, MA, at 9 AM. Visiting hours are Tuesday from 4 to 8 PM. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Notre Dame Club of Boston Scholarship Fund, PO Box 887, Boston, MA 02103.

These aspects of Chicago's cultural environment are un deniable, but the city has such a superabundance of building styles that even architects and architectural fashions that are not identified with the Midwest flourished there. In fact, anyone who wants to sample fully the architectural banquet that is Chicago should consider touring the Prairie Avenue Historic District, the city's first Gold Coast.

She has a question. She has just spoken at a Planned Parenthood meeting in Albany and is now focusing on her next campaign appearance, a speech to the Nassau County Democratic Committee at Hofstra University on Long Island. ''What do I say?'' she asks an aide back at campaign headquarters, then lets out a sharp burst of awkward laughter.

title: Some Black Humor From the Grim Reaper
description: It was not until someone giggled as they left a wake at the Buen Pastor Funeral Home that the owners noticed the Grim Reaper was literally hovering above their door. The man with the scythe appeared last month on a billboard advertising Combat roach traps on the roof of the funeral home, at Second Avenue and East Second Street. The ad, which asks ''Got Death?'' spoofs the ''Got Milk?'' ads, but its juxtaposition with the business below has received mixed reviews from mourners visiting Buen Pastor, Adelia Crespo, a secretary at the funeral home, said. ''Some people see it and they laugh,'' she said. ''But others don't. They take these occasions very seriously.'' JESSE McKINLEY

title: The World: Bolivia Falls Short; When Even an Economic Miracle Isn't Enough

Such books brim with hope for the future, and they are beginning to appear even in this backwater capital high in the Andes. But here, they still have to share shelf space with a rather depressing best-seller that carries a very different message.

The price is $45 million but will raised to $55 million if New Jersey approves off-track and telephone betting, said Christopher C. Castens, corporate secretary for International Thoroughbred Breeders, the current owners. The sale is anticipated to close in September.

title: Nudes Across America

The goal: to coax ordinary folks into posing nude in public places in all 50 states. (Pictured right: 1,200 nudes, shot last August during a Phish concert in Maine.) The statement? Liberation! The show opens at the I-20 Gallery in Manhattan in September. Here's a look.

Each would have long since agreed on how to divvy up the intellectual terrain. Science would continue its inevitable march toward a grand explanation of how the material world works, leaving to religion the endless arguments over why the universe came to be and how people ought to behave in it.

The company's name, said Maureen Foley, one-half of Hazelwood Films, comes from a line of Yeats's poem ''The Song of Wandering Aengus'': ''I went into the hazel wood because a fire was in my head.''

title: Running of the Bull, American Style (i.e., Tame)
description: Pumped up by the sort of foolishness that flourishes at bachelor parties as nowhere else, Jim Hamill and several buddies interrupted their weekend-long debauchery in Las Vegas to drive about an hour northeast to a dusty ranch here for what they expected to be the wildest, craziest adventure imaginable.

description: ALL STREET securities analysts occasionally deliver bad news on a stock. But it's unusual when they unequivocally call their past advice to buy it a blunder.

description: A new gay bar opened last week on Amsterdam Avenue and West 109th Street, after months of charges and countercharges in the neighborhood alleging racism on one side and homophobia on the other.

title: Parental Control And Teen-Age Drivers
description: The article on limiting teen-agers' driving [''Limits Sought on Teen-Age Driving,'' June 21] failed to discuss an important aspect of restriction -- parental control.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRACY, WILLIAM
description: TRACY-William. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of William Tracy, associated with The Times from 1923, until retiring in 1965.

title: Hundley Brings Bat Back, and Maybe Stability
description: Todd Hundley was greeted with much fanfare and a standing ovation upon his return to Shea Stadium last night, a sign of how much the team and its fans need the latest indispensable ingredient in the Mets' effort to get to the post-season for the first time in a decade.

description: President Clinton said the Government would no longer do business with any health insurance company that flouts a 1996 law intended to guarantee access to coverage for people who change or lose their jobs.

description: A large majority of United Nations members, concerned about the lack of progress toward peace between Israel and the Palestinians, voted with a group of Arab and developing countries to expand the Palestinians' rights in the General Assembly.

title: Windows on The Canals
description: IN many cities the hotels with the best locations and views command the highest prices. But in Amsterdam a web of canals threads through the central city, insuring that even those without deluxe accommodation budgets can ensconce themselves in rooms with glorious waterfront views.

title: What's Behind the Forecast? Pure Poetry
description: WHEN people tune in Ira Joe Fisher on CBS ''News 2'' in the evening, he tells them to expect rain or shine. Away from the studio, however, the weather definitely goes backstage. Poetry is Mr. Fisher's passion.

title: THE JOY OF VEGETABLES
description: Hoping to jazz up vegetables' boring image, the Vegetarian Society, a British group, recently released ''Hot Dinner,'' an erotic public-service cinema ad bursting with rapid-fire shots of sizzling chilies and oozing peaches. ''We tried to avoid the real cliches like cucumbers and eggplants,'' says Chris Dessent, the organization's head of public affairs. Likewise, cauliflower must wait. ''Just couldn't make cauliflower sexy,'' he says. ''We succeeded with a pea, though. We shot a male hand gently tickling one.'' The British Board of Film Classification got a bit ''steamed'' about it all, and declared that the 40-second ad should not be viewed by anyone under 15. ''People must be scared of the power of fruit and veg!'' says Dessent.

title: Peter Pan He's Not
description: SHORTLY before 2 P.M. on Wednesday, Steve Cornish will put on a foam rubber costume and a red, white and green cape to transform himself into Biscotti Boy. Then, in the atrium of Harrah's casino, he will attach himself to a wire that will hoist him 20 feet into the air and then dunk him twice into an 800-gallon cup-shaped tank of industrial-grade instant cappuccino.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DURDIN, F. TILLMAN
description: DURDIN-F. Tillman. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of F. Tillman Durdin, associated with The Times from 1937, until retiring in 1974.

description: JOHN STANISLAUS JOYCE

title: Can I Have That In a Plain Brown Wrapper, Please?
description: In his Endpaper ''Can I Have That in a Plain Brown Wrapper, Please?'' (June 7), Jeffrey Goldberg criticizes Smart Money for profiling an Asian fund manager who bemoans the ''disastrous effect'' that the Tiananmen Square riots had on the Hong Kong market. ''In reality,'' Goldberg rejoins, ''Tiananmen Square had a disastrous effect on the people who died there.'' Goldberg goes on to cite this as an example of the ''pinched worldview'' of the personal-finance magazines and why readers should avoid them.

title: Amrita Deol, Scott Schroeder
description: Amrita Deol, a daughter of Dr. Jasbir Singh Deol of Easton, Pa., and the late Dr. Ripu Nalwa Deol, was married in New York yesterday to Scott William Schroeder, the son of Patricia Schroeder, the former Colorado Congresswoman, and James W. Schroeder of Alexandria, Va. The Rev. James R. Covington, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Manhattan Penthouse.

title: Taking Remedial Class Is Like a Second Start
description: When Adam Padron was 16, high school bored him. ''I wasn't paying attention,'' he said this week. ''I lost interest.'' And so he dropped out of Bloomfield High School his freshman year. But, he said, ''I always wanted to go to college.''

title: Trying Men's Souls
description: Members of a historical association in New Rochelle hope to erect a monument on the National Mall in Washington in memory of the Revolutionary War hero Thomas Paine.

title: Reading For the Beach Bag
description: A LIVELY piece of fiction peeking out over the top of a straw bag is the quintessential accessory for a day the beach. Two novels, examining New York City from the perspective of an immigrant family and an E.M.S. medic working in Hell's Kitchen, offer summer reading pleasure.

title: Feiner in a Quandary Over Elderly Tax Relief
description: FOR his entire political career, first as a County Legislator and now as Supervisor of Greenburgh, Paul J. Feiner has sought to portray himself as the friend of the little guy against big government and an advocate for the elderly. To his dismay, he now finds himself supporting a decision to deny some older residents a property tax break.

title: With Hundley Cleaning Up, So Do the Mets
description: There was a roar from the crowd at Shea Stadium last night when Todd Hundley's name was announced in the lineup. When he emerged from the dugout to play catch, a second cheer was accompanied by a big smile from Hundley and a tip of his cap.

title: Southern Comfort
description: ROXANNA SLADE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANT, RICHARD H.
description: GRANT-Richard H. On July 7, 1998, of Forest Hills, NY. Father of Sarah and Henry and the late Elizabeth. Grandfather of Isaiah, Ethan and Rowan Corcoran. Kindly address sentiments or make donations to St. Luke's Church, 85 Greenway South, Forest Hills, NY 11375.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday in the special Mutual Funds Report, part 2 of this section, listing the best-performing diversified stock funds for the five years ended June 30, misstated the return of the United Income fund, class A, and ranked it incorrectly. (The five-year return was also misstated in the quarterly mutual fund tables.)

title: Little Suffolk Airports Seeking New Niches
description: A DRIVE into Francis S. Gabreski Airport in Westhampton, with its worn World War II-era barracks and wide runway, is like a trip back in time.

title: Turning to Berries for Summer Desserts of Puddings and Tarts
description: CHILLED English summer pudding, a ruby red dome filled with berries, is one of my favorite desserts. It could not be easier to make. Raspberries, red currants and blueberries are stewed in their own juices with a little sugar and put in a pudding bowl lined with day-old bread (in England black currants are normally used, but blueberries make a fine substitute). The bowl is covered with weights and refrigerated overnight so the bread soaks up the juice of the berries. The next day, the pudding is turned out onto a platter, surrounded by fresh berries and served with whipped cream or creme fraiche. It tastes as wonderful as it looks (people who have never had this before rarely guess that it is made with bread and not some fancy spongecake).

description: TAXING

description: To the Editor:

description: TUESDAY

title: Hillary Lyden And Jay Murphy
description: Hillary Jean Lyden, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John K. Lyden of Armonk, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jay Robert Murphy, a son of Elizabeth Davis Murphy of Deerfield, N.H., and Robert J. Murphy of North Conway, N.H. Msgr. Charles M. Kavanagh performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Fatima Church in Wilmington, Vt.

title: July 5-11; The Masters Regained
description: The thieves who stole two Van Goghs and a Cezanne from a Rome museum in May were real pros, one investigator said, ''but they didn't know too much about art.'' In their grand plans to sell them for millions, they forgot that no one would touch such famous paintings.

title: At Caramoor, Festival Of International Music
description: IT is another all-star week at the International Music Festival at Caramoor in Katonah, starting today at 4:30 P.M. as Misha Dichter celebrates his 25th summer at the festival. Nor will the pianist be alone in the Venetian Theater; he will be joined for the Schumann Quintet by four of his equally renowned colleagues -- the violinists Robert McDuffie and Nicholas Mann, the violist Lawrence Dutton and the cellist Carter Brey -- then partnered by his wife, the pianist Cipa Dichter, in Saint-Saens' ''Carnival of the Animals'' with zoological narrations by Blythe Danner.

title: Beauty In a Bucket
description: In packaging for fashion products, froufrou is out and nail polish in a paint can is in. So are other industrial-looking items that seem more suited to Home Depot than Henri Bendel. But it's Bendel's that later this month will offer Hardware, a line of nail polish whose 22 shades, at $15 each, come in miniature stainless steel paint cans with a built-in brush. The store, at Fifth Avenue and 56th Street, also has Tomgirl's Beauty Parlor Night Kit, a paint pail stocked with products for facials and pedicures ''for a six-girl slumber party'' ($35).

title: Yonkers Industrial Park
description: A potential buyer for a 21-acre Yonkers industrial park now owned by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey will most likely continue the leases of Kawasaki Rail Car with its 450 jobs and the leases of several companies with about 125 jobs, said Edward A. Sheeran, executive director of the city's Industrial Development Agency.

title: In SoHo, as Galleries Depart, Temples of Beauty Are the Show
description: A PALE woman in black stands on the corner of Mercer and Prince Streets, twirling like a weather vane. ''Lip liner?'' she mutters, stepping forward, then abruptly swings around 90 degrees. ''Or polish?'' A young visitor from Denmark, she's in hot pursuit of beauty, but she's not sure where to start.

title: Indonesian Leader Makes Important Gain in Party Election
description: Indonesia's new President, B. J. Habibie, consolidated his hold over the country's politics today when one of his close advisers won a hotly contested vote to lead the country's dominant political party.

title: Commercial Property/Bruce Ratner; Meeting the Demand for Stores Outside Manhattan
description: BRUCE RATNER made a big splash when he moved the 7.2-million-pound Empire Theater 170 feet on 42d Street to serve as an anchor for the entertainment and retail complex he is now building.

title: Classical Brief

title: Civil War Regiment Receives Capital Tribute
description: AS a young civil-rights worker in Mississippi during the 1960's, Frank Smith Jr. developed an interest in the little-known story of the black soldiers who fought for the Union during the Civil War. As a City Councilman in recent years in Washington's Shaw neighborhood -- named after Robert Gould Shaw, the white commander of a black Civil War regiment, portrayed in the 1989 movie ''Glory'' -- Mr. Smith has pushed to bring that slice of history to broader public attention.

title: 5-Day Wait to Buy Guns May Become Election Issue
description: The law requiring a five-day waiting period to buy a handgun is scheduled to expire in November, and gun-control advocates are girding for a bruising late-summer fight with the National Rifle Association and its supporters in Congress over whether to extend it.

title: Dredging Up A Revived Waterway
description: The muck-ridden Gowanus Canal, which dates to the 19th century and runs through Cobble Hill, Park Slope and Carroll Gardens, has been so smelly that for decades it's been compared to the River Styx, the mythological river of the dead. Many people who live nearby have all but given up hope of seeing something done about the odor. But now the city is set to take a step toward addressing the problem.

title: If They Don't Win, It's a Shame
description: New Jersey's six minor-league baseball clubs are approaching the halfway point in the season, the first for four of them. Five years ago, the state had no minor-league baseball, and some have doubted whether it can support so many teams. So far, fan support ranges from enthusiastic to tepid.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BACHENHEIM, MARCELLA
description: BACHENHEIM-Marcella on July 11, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Morton, devoted mother of Michael, loving mother-in-law of Carole, cherished grandmother of Jennifer and Meredith. Private services were held July 12, Mt. Neboh Cemetery, Cypress Hills, NY.

title: Think Orange
description: Orange, a color long associated with the lowly and the offbeat -- prison jumpsuits, Hare Krishna robes and Halloween decor -- is unexpectedly dappling the collections of top fashion designers. This spring, Alexander McQueen for Givenchy presented pumpkin-colored cowgirl skirts with leather fringe for $1,520 (Madison and 75th Street). Prada has sandals with tangerine heels from $150 to $190 (Madison and 70th Street). And for fall, Sinatra's favorite shade is showing up at Issey Miyake (a flame-colored quilted jacket for $1,815 and matching skirt for $915, at Madison Avenue and 77th Street), and Jil Sander (a carrot-hued wool felt jacket for $1,355, at Bergdorf Goodman), and in the orange chiffon robes of Chanel's 1999 cruise collection.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINDELL, HARRIETT
description: MINDELL-Harriett, age ninety, of Clifton, N.J., on July 9, 1998. Survived by her son Marvin and her daughters Patricia Pancer and June Gelbart. Also survived by her eight grandchildren, nine greatgrandchildren and her brother Robert Covell. Services are at 12 Noon, on Monday at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel 150 Rt 4 East, Paramus, NJ 201-843-9090

Recent complaints from a store owner, who felt her business was being impeded by the stand, might have gotten it to move, but in the process it became even more of an icon for the town, replete with tradition, a symbol of Yankee ingenuity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUZMAN, ALBERTO LUIS

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC; For an Early Post-Modernist, A Day of Overdue Vindication

Compositional techniques involving Serialism, extreme dissonance and mathematically derived ''spots on the page'' had become so entrenched that it seemed there was no turning back. But a backlash did come, and by 1983 the vogue for big tonal pieces had become so pervasive that the New York Philharmonic was able to present a series of concerts of music by John Harbison, David Del Tredici, Bernard Rands, John Adams and others under the provocative title ''A New Romanticism?''

These were new productions, mainly premieres but also revivals of works so rarely seen that they took on the aura of a premiere. A prime example was Hurok's historic presentation of a full-length ''Sleeping Beauty'' when the Sadler's Wells Ballet made its New York debut in 1949.

Today, it is Gantry Plaza State Park, and its inhabitants are more likely to be anglers, fashion photographers and local families.

Abiola, there lurks a simmering anger against the United States, which was so conspicuously present at the moment of Mr. Abiola's demise on Tuesday, but generally absent as Nigeria had slipped into the abyss.

Sometimes we realize that the revision was beneficial after all in comparison with the original, in, say, Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly,'' which presents Pinkerton as such an obvious and irredeemable cad that Butterfly could only have been a fool to trust him for a minute.

Back in the 60's, my dad manufactured a cologne whose theme conflated surfing with ersatz Hawaiiana. Bottled in a cork, with a compass rose on the label, Hawaiian Surf was cologne for ''individualists'' looking to crack the fusty Old Spice mold. title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Eight Sides to Everything
description: No one's imagination survives entirely free after he has seen the glowing Castel del Monte in Apulia, in southeastern Italy -- a stupendous octagon with an octagonal tower at each of its eight corners. It is not the shape that is singular; many octagonal buildings date from late Roman times, and the interior of Charlemagne's chapel at Aachen is octagonal. But Castel del Monte is an intricate elaboration of eight-sided shapes multiplied in astonishing precision. It was built in the 13th century by Frederick II (1194-1250), the last Hohenstaufen Holy Roman Emperor and the most learned ruler of his time, who contributed to the design of many of the buildings he left behind. This one has long aroused speculation among historians, architects and archeologists. In CASTEL DEL MONTE: Geometric Marvel of the Middle Ages (Prestel/te Neues, $65), Heinz Gotze, a German archeologist, art historian and book publisher, summarizes the scholarship and uses his deep knowledge of history, architecture and mathematics, along with scores of mesmerizing pictures and diagrams, to advance his own persuasive theory. This is not casual reading -- that it could be clearly translated is impressive -- but close attention is richly rewarded, and anyone with a little geometry will be enchanted. Gotze demonstrates that the building draws on Gothic, Norman, Greek and Byzantine ideas, as one might expect, but also on the most powerful thinking about design and mathematics in the Islamic world. The ground plan, seen clearly in aerial shots of the citadel, perfectly illustrates all possible forms of an eight-sided polygon: four symmetrical axes, simple octagon, eight-pointed star formed by two intersecting squares and the pointed star polygon, universally known as the Islamic eight-pointed star. Castel del Monte is, as a computer simulation proves, a fractal whose iterations are immediately apparent -- one of the most beautiful structures ever to rise from the human mind, and the mind, recognizing it, is naturally captivated. D. J. R. Bruckner

title: Science Fiction
description: There is no finer writer of science fiction today than Kim Stanley Robinson, and he is at the top of his form in ANTARCTICA (Bantam, $24.95). The genesis of this novel was unusual. While researching his Mars trilogy, which concluded in 1996 with the masterly ''Blue Mars,'' he learned that scientists who study Mars often spend time in Antarctica because it is the part of Earth most like Mars. Within two weeks of completing his Mars trilogy, Robinson was off to Antarctica, courtesy of the National Science Foundation, which sponsors a program that sends artists and writers to the southernmost continent. The result is an exhilarating addition to a body of work distinguished by two elements all too rare in modern science fiction: a sense of character and a sense of place. Robinson brings the two together by writing about people who are in love with where they are. Appropriately enough, the book begins, ''First you fall in love with Antarctica, and then it breaks your heart.''

title: SPENDTHRIFTS

Among the past year's outlays: House Speaker Newt Gingrich spent $510.85 on ''Cokes for meeting services'' in a three-month period; Representative Linda Smith spent $1,496.01 on cell-phone calls over 90 days; Representative Harold E. Ford Jr. spent $66.49 to wash his district car, and Representative Saxby Chambliss ordered two jumbo U.S. flags, $440.02 each, for a car dealership and a trucking company back home. title: Next Stop . . . the Loop
description: The billboard high above East 86th Street near Third Avenue could make pedestrians look up and scratch their heads at the same time. There's something odd about the subway car that Beth Israel and St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospitals used to give a distinct New York flavor to this ad celebrating their partnership. The ad, which has been up for a month, was produced by an advertising agency whose staff looked through hundreds of stock photographs to find a representative example of a New York subway train. But Joseph P. Brennan, a rail buff who is a computer specialist at Columbia University, took a closer look after people began asking where that subway car was really from. His verdict: ''That's definitely not New York. It looks like the Chicago el.'' Sure enough, he found a Web site (http://members.aol.com/chictafan/p3200.jpg) where you can see a twin of this car. The billboard was scheduled to be up for six months, but now that word of Mr. Brennan's discovery is out, the ad will be replaced in a couple of weeks. ''It's a chance for us to include our new partnership with Long Island College Hospital,'' said Kathleen McGovern, vice president for public affairs and marketing at Beth Israel and St. Luke's Roosevelt. And the subway car pictured, she said, will be changed to one that is ''clearly a New York City train.'' MICHAEL MOLYNEUX

title: The Little Cars That Could

Arriving in Italy at 9 P.M., not noon, my husband, James, and I hurried to the car-rental desk, jumped into the offered Fiat and immediately headed out. Our expensive week's rental of an Umbrian cottage, several hours north, was already one-seventh over.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, ARTHUR
description: ROSENBERG-Arthur. Born on February 6th, 1915 in Brooklyn, New York. Died on July 8th, 1998. Predeceased by his beloved wife of 58 years, Helen M. Rosenberg. Adoring father of Susan Rose and Leslie Nagy. Devoted grandfather of Julie Weiner, Carrie Pillar, Alissa and Pamela Nagy, whom he referred to as ''his girls''. Father-inlaw to Allan Ghitterman & Colonel William Nagy, USAR Ret. Arthur attended Cornell University and started an insurance underwriting corporatiion in New York City, Kaye Agency, Inc. After nearly 60 years in the insurance industry, Arthur retired, and in 1996 moved to Santa Barbara, CA. Prior to moving to Santa Barbara, Arthur had lived in New York City and Pound Ridge, NY, where he and Helen were long time members of Rockrimmon Country Club. Arthur died peacefully at home, as he wished, surrounded by his family. Services will be held in California. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to your favorite charity.

title: SEE DIANAVILLE!
description: * This month Charles, Earl Spencer, officially opened Althorp, his 550-acre estate, to a rush of tourists who have 60 days to see the estate's new museum devoted to Diana, Princess of Wales. * Disgruntled locals call it ''Dianaville.'' * On view in the museum: an exhibit called ''Spencer Women,'' devoted to Diana's ancestors; Diana dresses, and, in the Tribute Room, the ''original text'' of the Earl's funeral oration. * When rain threatened a benefit concert at Althorp last month, David (''Baywatch'') Hasselhoff publicly prayed to Diana to stop it. The rain stopped. * Spencer has described the lake around Diana's island gravesite as ''a buffer against . . . the insane and ghoulish.'' * The media deference of last summer is officially over. The Guardian newspaper recently opined that the real lesson of her life was: ''Don't get in the car'' if the driver is drunk.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 28 about the estate-planning benefits of the Roth I.R.A. referred incompletely to a rule on mandatory withdrawals of money in traditional individual retirement accounts after the account holder's death. Assuming that the holder's spouse has died first, the required withdrawal depends depends on the chosen distribution method: under the ''recalculation'' method, all money must be withdrawn by Dec. 31 of the year after the holder's death. But under the ''term certain'' method, beneficiaries are usually entitled to withdraw the money over a longer period.

title: PULSE; Elbows And Eggs
description: Sample sales are associated more with cat fights over cashmere than anything as sweet as pancakes and syrup. But Rebecca Taylor, a New York designer, is civilizing the ritual by organizing a July 18 brunch/sample sale at the Astor Restaurant and Lounge (316 Bowery, at Bleecker Street; (212) 253-8644). ''No one has any time in New York, so we thought it'd be great to combine shopping and eating,'' said Beth Hutchens, Ms. Taylor's business partner. Since a sample sale scrum can ruin the heartiest appetite, the deals and meals will be done on separate floors: eggs are upstairs, and down in the lounge are summery designs by Ms. Taylor and Susanna Monaco, beaded leather handbags from Go Fish, and Indian accessories and furnishings from Ohm. Prices: $20 to $100 (with some rare Indian tapestries at $800). For those who don't want to binge after they splurge, there's also a bar. ''You can go have a drink,'' Ms. Hutchens said, ''to calm down.'' CHRISTINE MUHLKE

title: So Much of Bach, to How Much Avail?
description: PERHAPS especially for an Englishman like Christopher Herrick, who is to play the Bach organ works at Alice Tully Hall in the Lincoln Center Festival over the next two weeks, the Bach Problem resembles the Shakespeare Problem: we have all the great works and can easily learn about their background, but we know little about the extraordinary person who produced them. In each case, slender documentation leaves us to guess almost everything about the creator of works so gripping that we each construct a special understanding of him, how he came to do what he did, what he meant by it. Mystery of person and remoteness of culture add to the power of ideas that we cannot get out of our heads.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; They Failed Their Finals
description: With DEFIANCE (Dutton, $23.95), Carole Maso, a professor of English at Brown University whose five previous books have involved large literary ambitions and small presses, makes a stab at luring a more mainstream audience. And ''stab'' is putting it mildly. The novel is the prison journal of Bernadette O'Brien, a Harvard physics professor who has sexually toyed with, then murdered, two male students. Bernadette has her reasons, and that, too, is putting it mildly. Chief among them are a grubby upbringing in Fall River, Mass., with parents who more or less prostitute themselves, and the victimization -- first by a pedophile priest, then by the Vietnam War -- of a beloved brother. Then there's the bad hair, the hobbled gait, the prodigious intelligence that make her a pariah until she sets her mind on a make-over and revenge. At first,''Defiance'' sounds like Fay Weldon without the jokes, but Bernadette is a fine monster in the prison-doll tradition, dishing out delightful contempt for the vicious society she believes she mimics, even the young men she so clinically seduces. She is, above all, a scientist, and in feverish, incantatory prose she sifts the shards of her past, trying to grasp the precise mechanics of class and sex that sealed her fate -- ''the click of the box,'' as she puts it. So relentless is her honesty that this hard-boiled book turns unexpectedly tender as Bernadette drops her monster mask -- her defiance -- to show the human face beneath. Patrick Farrell

title: Keeping a Hand in Centuries-Old Russian Art
description: SINCE 1962, the Rev. John Walsted has been dipping his sable brush in a mixture of pigment, water, alcohol and egg yolk to create icons on wood panels. He's a retired Episcopal rector and a keeper of the flame. Father Walsted paints in the iconographic style of Nizhny Novgorod, Russia, during the 14th to 16th century. With his palette of egg tempera, and gold leaf, he meticulously approximates the traditional method. One such painting, ''Our Lady of Kazan,'' is shown here. On Friday, 23 of his icons, along with four Italian Renaissance paintings from the Samuel H. Kress Foundation, are to go on display at the Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences.

title: Mugging the Environment
description: Since sweeping into Washington in 1995, the Contract-With-America Republicans have tried every legislative trick in the book to undermine the nation's environmental laws. Heroic efforts by moderate House Republicans and timely Presidential vetoes have held them off. But the G.O.P. contractors are a patient bunch, and after lying around in the weeds for a while, they have now loaded up two big appropriation bills with nearly 20 anti-environmental riders. None of these riders challenge any basic law, but collectively they threaten the nation's struggle to clean its air and water, restore important fisheries and protect its public lands. The moderates must try to sanitize these bills. If that fails, Mr. Clinton should veto them if they reach his desk in anything like their present form.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARTY, CHARLES F.
description: McCARTY-Charles F. A retired Army Colonel, died early Sunday morning, June 7th, 1998 (after a long illness). Colonel McCarty was born in Brooklyn, New York, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles F. McCarty. He graduated from Xavier High School in New York City and from the United States Military Academy, West Point, New York, in the Class of 1946. In his early years he was an instructor at the Infantry School, where he also became a paratrooper. He graduated from the Command and General Staff School at Ft. Leavenworth, Kansas, the Armed Forces Staff College at Norfolk, Virginia and the Air War College at Montgomery, Alabama and received a Master's Degree from George Washington University. He served his country proudly and with valor during the Korean and Vietnam Wars earning the Silver Star, Bronze Star and the Purple Heart. Other decorations include two Legion of Merits. After a distinguished military career, he founded McCarty and Associates, a direct marketing and advertising company, using his expertise in writing developed over the years on the Army General Staff. He and his wife, Jessie, moved to the Indian River Colony Club in Melbourne, Florida in 1992. Survivors include his wife, Jessie; daughters, Helen Eubank of Santa Fe, New Mexico, Elizabeth Gheesling of Alexandria, Virginia and son Charles F. McCarty III, of San Diego, California; three grandsons and a sister, Helena Miller of Scarsdale, New York. He will be remembered as a beloved husband & father & a true gentleman of great compassion and Irish wit. The family of Colonel McCarty would welcome any friends of the Colonel, or friends of his family to attend the Memorial Service at The United States Military Academy, West Point, New York on July 17th, 1998 at 1:00 P.M.

Ms. Weibusch and the 23 other cancer patients and care givers crammed last week into rooms and hallways of the Bethany Memorial Reformed Church on First Avenue and East 67th Street are caught in an increasingly bitter battle involving religion and real estate. title: A Burst of Rock, Bright as the Rising Sun

Terri MacMillan, a music manager, watches with a banana grin, convinced that she has found a future superstar. She can picture him headlining arenas to mobs of guys playing air guitar and teen-aged girls screaming his name. She is literally jumping up and down in rapture. Only we are not in New York, Seattle or Omaha. We are in Tokyo. And Ms. MacMillan is the only other American in the club.

title: Civilizing the Prairie
description: ON trips abroad I have always been a tireless house-and-garden visitor. A few years ago, I realized how little I knew of the glories surrounding my own hometown, Chicago, and set out to rectify my ignorance. I took a series of day trips and explored four handsome estates whose gardens are open to the public, all within an easy drive of downtown. Since then I have visited and revisited these sites, always finding a peaceful respite from the city. They are Cantigny, about three-quarters of an hour from Chicago in Wheaton, Ill., with an antiques-furnished mansion and gardens filled with magnolias and roses; Fernwood, an hour and a half from the Loop in southwestern Michigan, surrounded by formal gardens and a prairie strewn with wildflowers; Montefiori, in Lemont, Ill., 40 minutes southwest of downtown, reminiscent of a Tuscan estate; and finally, Cuneo, in Vernon Hills, Ill., less than an hour north of the city, where formal gardens blend with a mansion containing a remarkable collection of European antiques.

title: Vuitton as a Guide

Now for the highflying nomad, Louis Vuitton introduces City Guides, a seven-volume paperback set for travelers who want to know, say, which Paris bistro the Jean-Paul Gaultier staff prefers. (Le Square Trousseau.) Featuring 30 European destinations, the City Guides eschew star ratings, including only hotels that can be categorized as ''luxurious,'' ''trendy'' or ''charming.'' They excel on restaurants, cafe bars and shopping, shopping, shopping. Where to get Iranian caviar in Prague? (Flambee.) Haute hippie-wear in London? (The Cross.) Available at Saks, Bloomingdales, Macy's and Louis Vuitton (49 East 57th Street), the guides come in a plain cardboard box ($50), or a leather case ($125). But don't throw out the Michelin. The guides are featherweight on culture, with three times as much on Prada as the Prado. ELENA KORNBLUTH

title: Prof. Curtis Berger, 72, Expert On Real Estate Law at Columbia
description: Curtis Jay Berger, who trained generations of aspiring lawyers in the fine points of real estate and property law, died on Monday at his home on the West Side of Manhattan. He was 72.

title: OPINION; Recapturing the Island of My Youth
description: I grew up on Long Island's beaches, in its waters, wandering its salt marshes. As a young man I spent two years on Reynolds Channel, on the western end of the South Shore, restoring an old boat. I often slept onboard because I was too tired to drive home after 12 hours of sanding.

title: Bad Bargain in Afghanistan
description: Women are essentially under house arrest in Afghanistan. The Taliban, a fundamentalist Islamic group that runs most of the country, has issued edict after edict keeping women and girls from studying, working, receiving medical care and even leaving their homes. International organizations and private relief groups want to help women, but to get permission they need to compromise with the Taliban. The question of how far to go has no good answer, but an agreement the United Nations signed recently is a terrible mistake.

title: Media Talk; Inspirational Author Founds Her Own Press
description: Seeking more creative and financial control over her work, Betty J. Eadie, a best-selling inspirational writer, has formed her own press, Onjinjinkta Publishing.

title: Paul L. Klein, 69, a Developer Of Pay-Per-View TV Channels
description: Paul L. Klein, an executive who helped pioneer new forms of pay television, died on July 4 at the Plaza Fifty Suite Hotel in Manhattan, where he was staying with his wife. He was 69 and lived in Catskill, N.Y.

title: One Man's Battle With the Managed-Care Monster
description: As a doctor who ran afoul of managed care, I find it fascinating to hear the explanations of health maintenance and other managed-care organizations for the low opinion the public has of them. For example, the California Association of Health Plans, my state's trade group for H.M.O.'s, blamed ''a couple of stories being repeated over and over'' for their bad image.

title: Clyde Ryals, Expert on Carlyle, Is Dead at 69
description: Clyde de Loache Ryals, a Duke University English professor and an authority on British Victorian literature, died on Friday at his home in Durham, N.C. He was 69.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, ROSE
description: LEVINE-Rose. Age 89, of Brooklyn, NY, died on July 11, 1998. Beloved widow of Max. Sister of Herbert. Aunt of four nieces and nephews, great-aunt of six greatnieces and nephews, and greatgreat-aunt of seven great-great nephews, all of whom loved her and will miss her.

description: GRAF-Frank A. Age 82, of East Hampton, on July 10, 1998. Dear brother of Margaret Graf Backen, and Theresa A. Donations to East End Hospice, PO Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978 would be appreciated.

The artist, who is displaying wall photographs and monoprints, is Yves Chaudouet, as reflected in the subheading, not Chandouet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPPAPORT, LESTER D.
description: RAPPAPORT-Lester D. Died on July 11, 1998. Beloved husband of 52 years of Ileen. Loving father of Jane Diamond, Andrew Rappaport and Jill Rosell. Cherished father-in-law of Andrew Diamond, Debora Rappaport and Kurt Rosell. Devoted grandfather of seven grandchildren. He was the owner and president of Tower Security Services and Telephonic Enterprises. He served in the U.S. Army during World War II from 1941 to 1945 and for 10 years was a loyal volunteer of the Scarsdale Fire Department. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, July 14, 1998, at 10 AM at Riverside Chapel in Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Belgian Wins in Dublin
description: The leading players were the same, but this time Erik Zabel did not swerve and have to be penalized and Tom Steels did not throw his water bottle at Frederic Moncassin and have to be ejected although, once again, Moncassin did do his best to win, to no avail.

title: Political Briefing; Black Voters Exiting This Campaign Bus
description: From the start, this year's Senate race in Missouri had the look of a close contest, with Democrats figuring they might just capture the seat and nibble away a bit at the Republican hold on Capitol Hill. The Republican incumbent, Christopher S. Bond, a moderate who has struggled in more than one election, seemed to Democratic campaign strategists to be hardly any stronger in 1998 than he was in 1992 when he squeaked through to a second term with just 52 percent of the vote.

title: In This Corner of the E.R., Brutal Night Claims Nelson
description: If a boxing card can be measured by the number of participants who landed in the hospital, then the show at the Alamodome on Saturday night was brutal. And perhaps no one felt the sting worse than Azumah Nelson, the three-time world champion who may have fought the last fight of an illustrious career.

title: Applied Materials Offers Warning on Profit
description: Applied Materials Inc., the world's largest maker of semiconductor-manufacturing equipment, said late Friday that its fiscal third-quarter results would fall below analyst forecasts, hurt by delayed orders and cutbacks in capital spending by chip makers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUSTANOWITZ, GLADYS (NEE FRANKEL)
description: KUSTANOWITZ - Gladys (nee Frankel). Of Clifton. Beloved wife of the late Jacob. Devoted mother of Al and Shulamith. Loving grandmother of Esther, Jack and Simmy. Services at the Louis Suburban Chapels, Fair Lawn, NJ, on Monday at 10 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOO, TEH, CHANG
description: KOO-Teh-Chang. Age 82. Died on July 9 in Kissimmee, FL. He was the eldest son of Dr. V.K. Wellington Koo. As a Lieutenant Colonel in the Chinese Air Force, he served with the Flying Tigers under General Chennault. He founded Dirksen, Inc., an international trading company in Taiwan. He is survived by his loving wife of 30 years, Joanna; three sons, David, Norman and Jimmy; three daughters, Kathy, Linda and Irene; six grandchildren; and his sister, Patricia Koo Tsien. Funeral service will be held in Orlando, FL, July 18.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZGERALD, THE REVEREND PETER A., C.M.
description: FITZGERALD-The Reverend Peter A., C.M., 78, of the Vincentian Community at Niagara University, on July 10, 1998. Survived by his brothers Arthur and Matthew Fitzgerald, and his two sisters Jane Kelly and Eileen Ireland. Brother of the late Joseph Fitzgerald. Family will receive friends at Vincentian Residence, St. John's University, Utopia and Grand Central Parkways, Jamaica, on Monday from 7 to 9 PM, and Tuesday, 9 to 10:15 AM. Mass will be celebrated at the Vincentian Residence Tuesday, 10:30 AM. Interment St. Joseph's Seminary, Princeton, NJ. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to Our Lady of Lebanon Church, Niagara Falls, NY.

title: Partner in Whitewater Seeks to Postpone Embezzlement Trial
description: The lawyer for Susan H. McDougal has asked a California state court judge to postpone her embezzlement trial, which was scheduled to begin on Monday, after he received 1,500 pages of new evidence from prosecutors.

title: Political Notebook; Candidate Is Suing to Change Rules for Ballot Position
description: Just as top billing carries a certain cachet in movies, it holds significance in politics, contends G. Oliver Koppell, the former New York Attorney General who is seeking the Democratic nomination for his old job.

description: In the recent talks aimed at reaching a new tobacco settlement, the best clues as to strategy were probably found in the five state attorneys general with whom the tobacco industry chose to negotiate.

title: Burying Dreams: Abiola's Death Stalls Movement
description: As the Nigerian opposition leader, Moshood K. O. Abiola, was laid to rest, the frenzy of the moment conveyed all that was being buried with him. Feverish men shoveled red earth onto the corpse and African chants and Muslim prayers mingled with the wailing of the women in the heaving crowd.

description: ''We are morally bankrupt in a situation that will bring us to hell.''

title: When Airborne Angels Saved Berlin
description: It was the West's earliest victory in the cold war and an exhilarating hour in the long face-off between Communism and democracy. ''The Berlin Airlift'' takes us back 50 years to when a defeated and divided Germany was the main arena of confrontation between the Soviet Union and the Western allies. It may be only a historical footnote now, but as tonight's spirited documentary confirms, the West's stand with the people of Berlin against a Soviet takeover still brightens the memories of those who delivered the goods.

title: Tina Brown Edits Her Career to Match the Zeitgeist
description: Of all the documents that passed over Tina Brown's desk in June, two received particular attention. One was the proposed five-year contract that would insure she remained The New Yorker's editor through mid-2003. The other was Brill's Content, the ballyhooed new magazine about the press.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLECHER, ANNE
description: BLECHER-Anne. Devoted wife of the late Sam. Loving mother of Joseph and Harvey. Her memory and sacrifice for her family will always be cherished. Services were held at Plaza Memorial Chapel.

description: The cars started arriving on East 111th Street before 8 A.M. yesterday. Most were late-model vehicles. Some had license plates from as far away as Florida. Each glided into a parking space like a horse into a barn, instinctively and without question.

title: Dead Diver From North Puts Seoul on Alert
description: South Korean military commanders put troops on the country's eastern coast on alert today and declared a curfew in the area after finding the body of a diver who they said was a North Korean commando.

description: Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto resigned this afternoon after voters gave Japan's governing party a brutal drubbing in parliamentary elections on Sunday.

description: HAUSMAN-Jack. Age 96. On July 10, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Ethel Hausman. Father of Richard and Michael and the late Peter Hausman. Grandfather of eight and great-grandfather of nine. Brother of Leo and the late Samuel Hausman and the late Anne Herrmann. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Sunday, 5-8 PM, with service Monday, 9:45 AM. Memorial service at a later date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, LI or United Cerebral Palsy of NYC, 105 Madison Ave., NY NY 10016.

Yseult Lendvai's Tatiana, Tamas Detrich's Onegin and Vladimir Malakhov's Lensky delivered the definitive performance that the ballet had lacked until then during the German company's season in Lincoln Center Festival '98.

description: The number of pedestrians and bicyclists killed by drivers in New York City declined sharply in the first five months of this year, putting the city on a pace to reach a record low, preliminary police records show.

description: Miramax Films has named Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG in New York to handle its New York advertising account, which includes print media buying with billings estimated at $25 million as well as various creative assignments. title: Oscar Anibal Ayala, 71, an Economist
description: Oscar Anibal Ayala, an economist who helped start the Inter-American Development Bank in 1959, died on June 22 at Georgetown University Medical Center in Washington. Mr. Ayala, who was born in Paraguay and lived in Alexandria, Va., for more than 40 years, was 71.

title: Chicago and Pacific Markets Are Said to Be in Merger Talks
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange and the Pacific Exchange are discussing a merger that could strengthen their position in the rapidly consolidating world of financial markets, people close to the exchanges said.

title: Violence Spreads in Zulu Area as New Party Gathers Force
description: Political violence has broken out once more in the troubled KwaZulu/Natal Province. Only this time it is not the traditional players going at one another. A new battle seems to be emerging between South Africa's newest political party, headed in this area by a local strongman, and President Nelson Mandela's party, the African National Congress.

title: A Little Controversy in Mets' Outfield Is Good for the Team
description: Never before has a routine fly ball to left field at Shea Stadium been greeted with such enthusiasm and such anxiety. But this was Todd Hundley backtracking on Vladimir Guerrero's climbing shot into the wind yesterday, and he is not an ordinary outfielder nor an ordinary Met. Right now, Hundley is Mr. Met, a sort of savior slogging around in left.

title: FESTIVAL REVIEW/Dance; 'Romeo and Juliet' With Simplicity and Little Touches of Humanity
description: John Cranko and Kenneth MacMillan seem to have a corner on the ''Romeo and Juliet'' market, at least so far as dance in New York is concerned. The Cranko production, presented by the Stuttgart Ballet at the New York State Theater on Saturday afternoon and evening, is less theatrical than the MacMillan staging, created three years later, in 1965. Cranko's characters also tend to be more recognizably human and less prone to larger-than-life bursts of passion and pyrotechnical display.

title: Compressed Data; The Mac Is Out; The Mac Is Back
description: Just as Steven P. Jobs was taking the stage in New York to flaunt Apple Computer's financial upturn and sing the praises of the company's new consumer strategy, Wells Fargo Bank was busy informing its on-line banking customers that it would no longer support the Macintosh version of Quicken, the leading financial software program from Intuit Inc.

description: Shortly after former Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona died in late May, Mayor Skip Rimsza of Phoenix suggested that a wonderful way to honor the man many called Mr. Arizona was to change the name of Phoenix's Sky Harbor International Airport to Barry Goldwater International Airport.

title: It's All False, Exiles Say
description: The Cuban-American National Foundation today denied a report in The New York Times that the group's late founder, Jorge Mas Canosa, and other leaders financed the activities of Luis Posada Carriles, who said he carried out a bombing campaign against Cuba last year.

title: Weaseling a Mole Into the White House
description: LUCKY BASTARD

title: Revisions; Offbeat Arts That Touch Modern Emotional Chords
description: Some of the best work billed as theater right now can't be fitted into just one form or genre, let alone style. History is too complicated, and our imaginations are too restless. But what people like to call a post-modernist esthetic, with its love of pastiche -- a clever assemblage of previous styles and a juxtaposition of genres and allusions, all signaling their capacity for playful irony at every moment -- really isn't enough. This kind of irony has become as safe, as cliched for us as melodrama was for an earlier age. It draws energy from parodying earlier forms, yet rarely generates any passion or daring of its own.

title: Robert S. Burger, 84, Teacher of Concise Writing
description: Robert S. Burger, a former journalist and professor who later spent more than three decades teaching business executives how to write, died on July 5 at Chester County Hospital in West Chester, Pa. He was 84 and lived in West Chester.

title: Patents; A proxy parent, in image and voice, stands ready to turn itself on in response to a baby's demands.
description: IT'S summer, and the living is supposed to be easy. For new parents, Donald Spector's recently awarded patent could ease the wails of a crying baby.

description: Two years after the Bay of Pigs invasion ended in ignominious failure on the beaches of Cuba, two young Cuban exiles stood next to each other in the spring sun at Fort Benning, Ga., training for the next march on Havana.

description: In many ways, Donald and Mildred Othmer were like any other faculty couple. He was a professor of chemical engineering at Polytechnic University in Brooklyn, a workaholic with scores of patents and a sideline in consulting. She was a former teacher and a buyer for her mother's dress stores who volunteered at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden and Planned Parenthood. They had no children, unless you count the students he invited home to dinner.

title: The City Life; Sidewalk Rhetoric
description: Somewhere in the west 30's, in Manhattan's sequin and applique district, a taxi idles, trapped in a box canyon of double-parked trucks. There is not much to see from the taxi's windows except an inaudible conversation taking place between two men standing on the curb. The tall man is making a point. The short man is taking it. The tall man's point is so forceful that it bends him forward at the waist. The short man bends backward to avoid being toppled by gusts of the tall man's rhetoric. A forefinger prods the air and then the short man's breastbone. Being prodded, however, causes the short man to stand up straight, causing the tall man to stand up, too. The taxi moves on.

title: A Glorious First for France
description: In Brazil, where soccer is almost a religion, and where the nation's identity is bound tightly to the fortunes of its national team, there will be weeks of mourning and months of bitter recrimination. In France -- well, the French will be toasting their heroes for days to come, and might actually begin to work up some lasting Gallic passion for a sport that has always competed for public affection with the Tour de France and even rugby.

title: Compressed Data; Chat Software Company Joins America Online
description: Decisions of the digital age: What do you do when your small technology start-up is bought by America Online for $287 million? The founders of Mirabilis, based in Tel Aviv, know. They flew the entire staff to New York for a weekend-long celebration.

title: Gemstar Move Against United Video's Bid
description: The Gemstar International Group Ltd. announced a shareholder rights program yesterday aimed at making a $2.8 billion hostile takeover bid by the United Video Satellite Group more difficult to complete. The company also announced that it was enhancing its new business relationship with the Microsoft Corporation.

title: San Antonio Journal; Novelist's Purple Palette Is Not to Everyone's Taste
description: Sandra Cisneros, the poet and novelist whose work explores the relationship between home and identity, did not want her own long-yearned-for house to be bland or timid or understated. The old coat of beige paint it had would not do. Ms. Cisneros found what she was looking for in Sherwin-Williams Corsican purple. Overnight, her bungalow became the Purple House.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMALLWOOD, STEPHEN JONES
description: SMALLWOOD-Stephen Jones. Passed away July 9, 1998. A memorial service will be held August 1 at Hendricks Chapel on the campus of Syracuse University. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Syracuse University through: The Smallwood Family Endowment Fund, c/o Syracuse University, Office of Donor Relations, 820 Comstock Ave., Syracuse, NY 13244-5040.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDWARDS, ALICE HOWLAND
description: EDWARDS-Alice Howland. Age 84 on July 8, 1998. Singer of opera & art song & vocal coach. Beloved wife of the late Sidney Edwards, cellist. Loving mother of Kate and Harriet Edwards. Grandmother of Victoria Kirk. Devoted sister of Harriet Flynn and Thielo Howland. Interment private. Memorial service at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84 Street, Sunday, August 23, 2 PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Melvin D. Yahr Parkinsons Research Fund, 5 East 98 Street, New York, New York 10029.

title: Russian Folk Flavor and Sardonic Humor Cavort Beneath Trinity's Vaulting
description: Trinity Church, at Wall Street and Broadway, offers free lunchtime concerts by superb young soloists and ensembles all through the season, but last year the church staked its claim in the world of summer festivals by offering a thematically coherent series. With a grant described in its program book as ''an anonymous donation to the glory of God and in honor of Johannes Brahms,'' it commemorated the centenary of Brahms's death with an overview of his chamber, orchestral and choral works, ''Brahms on Broadway.''

title: The Neighborhood Business; Geocities' Cyberworld is Vibrant, but Can It Make Money?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REA, EMELINE ELLIDA
description: REA-Emeline Ellida. At home in Garden City, NY, on July 10. She was 87. Her father, Edgar Mora Davison, was a banker and was involved in the financing of The New York Times in the early part of the century. Her mother, Emeline Virginia Middleton, was a direct descendent of Arthur Middleton, a signer of the Declaration of Independence. Mrs. Rea was a graduate of the Brearly School and Bryn Mawr College. She was the devoted wife of the late John Morse Rea. She was active in church and community affairs for many years, and helped found the Garden City Public Library. She was the mother of three sons: Mora Davison Rea of Oakdale, NY, the late John Paul Rea, and Edward Middleton Rea of Arlington, VA. She is also survived by seven grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Service on July 18, 3:30 PM, Cathedral of the Incarnation, Garden City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Cathedral, 50 Cathedral Ave., Garden City, NY 11530, or Friends of the Garden City Public Library, 60 7th St., Garden City, NY 11530.

title: Media Talk; Journalists Defending The 'How' in Their Work
description: Who? What? When? Where? Why? These are the questions journalists are trained to ask. But the question that continues to haunt journalists who are hauled into court is ''How?'' How did the journalist get the information? How did he or she approach sources? What did the journalist say to the subjects of the story?

To Mr. Chernow, author of ''The House of Morgan,'' which won a National Book Award in 1990, Rockefeller was a ''ghostly'' figure. ''He seemed impenetrable,'' Mr. Chernow said last week. ''Secretiveness was at his very essence. He spent his life trying to evade the notice of the press and politicians and others.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSCHILD, DR. JACOB

His dedication to his patients and generous sharing of knowledge with fellow clinicians were highly valued and will be missed. We extend very sincere condolences to his family. Administration, Board of Directors, Staff Advanced Center for Psychotherapy

He will be mourned and missed by us all, his sister Jean Rogers and family, his brother Gordon Popper, Dr. Jacqueline Maier-Leifer and her children who were like his own, Mark, Nicole, Daniella, Lori and David, Walter and Susan Maier and family, Joseph P. title: Hillary Clinton Inaugurates Preservation Campaign
description: The heroic bronze figures on the Francis Scott Key Monument are corroded, and an oar that was once in the statue's supple-looking stone waters is long gone. But standing in front of this beleaguered 1911 monument to the national anthem in a quiet, green square this afternoon, Hillary Rodham Clinton spoke of renewal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVICK, IRVING
description: NOVICK-Irving. On July 11, 1998 in The Bronx. Age 95. He was one of the organizers in the 1920 of the Committee for Aid to Foreign Born Workers, now known as the American Commitee for Aid to the Foreign Born, Founder of the Immigrants Technical Aid Bureau which he headed for 50 years. Mr. Novick was born in Poland and came to the U.S. in 1921, where he quickly became active in left wing politics. He gained admission to the U.S. for thousands of immigrants who had fled oppression in totalitarian regimes in Germany, Eastern Europe and Latin America. He also helped many others with unpopular ideas to resist deportation from this country. His wife of 60 years, Ruth Rosenblatt, died in 1994. He is survived by two sons, Robert and Sheldon, his brother Avram, four grandchildren and two great grandchildren. A graveside service will be held at the Cedar Park Cemetery, Westwood N.J. at 1PM, today.

title: PARKER HANNIFIN AGREES TO BUY VERIFLO IN CASH DEAL
description: The Parker Hannifin Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire B.A.G. Acquisition Ltd. and its Veriflo Corporation unit for an undisclosed amount of cash. Parker Hannifin said Veriflo, of Richmond, Calif., makes high-purity regulators and valves for precision gas delivery and sampling applications in the medical, analytical, petrochemical and semiconductor industries. Veriflo, which had 1997 revenues of $65.4 million, has manufacturing plants in Richmond and in Carson City, Nev., and sales offices in Brussels, Glasgow, Shanghai and Singapore. Parker Hannifin, based in Cleveland, produces motion and control components for industrial and aerospace markets.

title: QUALCOMM GETS $650 MILLION SUPPLY CONTRACT IN MEXICO
description: Qualcomm Inc. received a three-year contract yesterday to supply Pegaso PCS, a joint venture in Mexico, with $650 million of infrastructure equipment and deployment services. The equipment will be used to build a mobile personal communications services and wireless services network in Mexico. Qualcomm will plan, build and start the network. Pegaso PCS is a unit of Pegaso Telecomunicaciones S.A. de C.V. Pegaso Telecomunicaciones was formed by a group including Qualcomm and Grupo Pegaso. Qualcomm, based in San Diego, makes digital wireless communications systems and products. Its shares fell 56.25 cents yesterday, to $55.9375.

title: A Singing Voice on the Sexual Fringe
description: Grumblings go on about how we are living through a drought of great singers. Recordings from two or three generations back are forever being cited as evidence, though we ought to wonder whether their simple existence does not half-prove the case. In no other time have the great dead among performers lived on to challenge the living, providing competition that is unfair in two ways. The old singers are taken to set the standard and do not allow the art of singing to change. Also, what may have been their very finest performances, captured on record, become the measure for what happens on any particular night at the Met.

Newell, based in Freeport, Ill., is a consumer products company with interests in hardware, home furnishings, office products and housewares. It had sales of $3.23 billion in 1997.

The decision could enable Samsung Motors Inc. of South Korea to turn itself into a major force in the world's fifth-largest car industry by buying Kia. The Government could have excluded Samsung by restricting the auction to larger companies.
