title: Chess; Computers as 'Partners': Do They Level the Play?
description: An unusual type of partner chess was organized by Garry Kasparov in Leon, Spain, in June. A human, Kasparov, teamed up with a computer against another human, the Bulgarian grandmaster Veselin Topalov, along with another computer, for what Kasparov termed a match of ''Advanced Chess.''

title: Injunction Denied in Cantor Fitzgerald Suit
description: A Delaware judge acknowledged in a decision released Sunday that Cantor Fitzgerald L.P. is likely to prevail in at least part of a legal battle over use of bond-trading technology. But he nevertheless denied the company's request for an injunction to stop the introduction of Market Power, an interactive electronic trading system that is scheduled to start on July 31.

title: The Face-Off at G.M.
description: It began 39 days ago as a simple strike at a single General Motors factory over how modern-day workers should build fenders and hoods. But like two neighborhood toughs daring each other with escalating taunts, G.M. and the United Automobile Workers union have fallen into a dispute so big, complicated and destructive that a solution now seems more elusive than ever.

title: Birkdale's Blustery Welcome Serves as an Early Warning
description: The wind was howling at Royal Birkdale Golf Club today, with players wearing ski caps and layered clothing to try to stay warm during practice rounds.

title: Calm Ulster Marches After Violent Week
description: Tens of thousands of Protestants paraded peacefully in Northern Ireland. The marches followed a week of Protestant upheaval over the issue of patriotic marches in Roman Catholic neighborhoods and the death of three young Catholic brothers in an arson attack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LALONDE, GERALD V.
description: LALONDE-Gerald V. Suddenly on Saturday, July 11, 1998 at home in London, Ontario at the age of 79. Beloved husband of Lorraine Lalonde (nee Beaugrand-Champagne), dear father of Carole and her husband Robert Beauregard of Bronxville, NY. Please call Madill Funeral Home, 519-264-1100 for donation information.

title: Senate Halts Property Bill Backed by G.O.P.
description: Blocking a conservative drive to make it easier for developers to challenge zoning and environmental laws in Federal courts, the Senate today effectively killed a property rights bill supported by Republican leaders.

title: Nasdaq Sets a Record on Gains From Technology Issues
description: A brighter earnings outlook for several leading technology companies propelled the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index to its fourth consecutive new high yesterday.

title: When Psychiatrists Try to Play Judge

title: Whittier Journal; Tether to Anchorage Tugs at a Town's Isolationism
description: On rare days when the clouds lift, it is still hard to see why anyone would want to live in this toenail of a port at the foot of a glacier on Prince William Sound. It rains more than 15 feet a year -- and snows another 10 -- and the town has the sort of why-bother feel that is common to places where snow will soon cover whatever rusted appliance has been left to the elements.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODS, FRANCIS

description: When Birch Evans Bayh Jr., the notable Democratic United States Senator of the 1960's and 70's, first learned that his son wanted to run for public office, the elder Bayh was wary.

description: David Remnick, a Pulitzer Prize-winning author who has spent the last six years writing for The New Yorker on topics from Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn to Mike Tyson, was named the fifth editor of the magazine in its 73-year history yesterday.

title: Essay; Wondering How the World Will End? Some Mordant Thoughts from Physics
description: IN contrast with the malevolent scientists of horror movies, most physicists are well-adjusted, friendly, attractive people whose conspicuous brain power is generally mixed with the milk of human kindness.

description: Assemblyman Is Acquitted

title: As Silent Killer Returns, Doctors Rethink Tactics To Lower Blood Pressure
description: BACK in 1972, when the National High Blood Pressure Education Program was established, its public health message was simple and compelling: Treating high blood pressure would save lives. It was right. The program has been credited with substantially lowering death rates from stroke and coronary heart disease.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Legal-Fee Firecracker in the Cendant Case
description: Since 1995, Federal securities laws have been clear about who should be in charge of a securities class-action case: the plaintiffs with the biggest financial stake.

title: Soccer: Too Few Commercials for Americans?
description: To the Editor:

title: Motorola to Buy Software Maker
description: The Motorola Corporation said today that it would acquire a software company that has developed technology to link wireless devices like cellular phones with a wide range of information appliances, including personal computers.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: The Skyline as Headline
description: Recently a friend who had been spending many extra hours at work told me that he hadn't heard about Frank Sinatra's death until the next night, when he saw that the Empire State Building was lighted up in blue and asked someone why. Those 1,336 blue lights became, for him, a sort of news report.

title: By Design; Hats On!
description: A swimsuit and sun block are essential on the beach, and so is a hat with a protective brim.

title: World Cup Snapshots: 32 Teams, 32 Stories
description: As if on cue, a soaking rain gave way to breezy sunshine today as the victorious French soccer team paraded down the Champs-Elysees in an open-air bus, carrying the World Cup championship trophy and the well wishes of an entire nation.

title: Selig's Biggest Task: End Owners' Sniping
description: Two days before he was officially elected commissioner, Bud Selig was already putting his job in jeopardy. He was on the field before the All-Star Game talking to people -- reporters, perhaps some players, maybe even an umpire or two.

title: Relief Is Felt in Tokyo That the Message Has Finally Gotten Across
description: While investors are worrying that the Prime Minister's resignation today has left a political vacuum that may lead to economic paralysis, voters are sighing in relief that their political message may have finally gotten through to the top.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROBBINS, LESTER
description: ROBBINS-Lester. Your family and close friends are thinking of you, remembering your warmth, strength, wit and your deep and abiding interest in and love for each of us. We miss you. Sheila

description: MILLS-John Porter. Died at home in NY on July 10, 1998 at age 94. Survived by his daughter, Nancy Gilbert, brother Robert, grandchildren Roger, Elizabeth and Scott, and great-grandson Nicholas. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Church of St Paul and St Andrew, West End Avenue at 86 Street, NY 10024 where a memorial service will be held Tuesday, July 14 at 6:30PM.

title: The Rebirth Of a Writer Murdered In Poland
description: In the sort of twist he might have found paradoxically engaging, fate has finally turned kind to Bruno Schulz decades after a Gestapo officer shot and killed him in 1942 as he crossed a street in Drogobych, the provincial Polish hometown he hated but could never leave.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MUFSON, MARVIN R.
description: MUFSON-Marvin R. We greatly miss your warmth, wisdom and humor and think of you every day with love forever. Laura, Bennett, Dan, Steve, Agnes

title: Canadian Agency Opens Chicago Site
description: The Vickers & Benson Companies Ltd. in Toronto, one of Canada's oldest agencies, is expanding its operations to the United States by opening an office in Chicago.

title: Jury Acquits Assemblyman Hikind of Corruption Charges
description: Dov Hikind, a Democratic Assemblyman from Brooklyn who is known for his maverick politics and outspoken manner, was acquitted yesterday of charges that he took tens of thousands of dollars in illegal payoffs from officials of a social services group.

title: CHESAPEAKE EXPLORING OPTIONS FOR 2 BUSINESSES
description: The Chesapeake Corporation said yesterday that it might sell its profitable timberlands and building-products units to focus on its tissue and packaging products. The company said it had hired Goldman, Sachs & Company to advise it on the units, the Chesapeake Forest Products Company and the Chesapeake Building Products Company. A decision is expected in this quarter. The businesses, which represented about $40 million in revenue last year, or less than 1 percent of Chesapeake's total 1997 sales of $1.02 billion, could sell for as much as $250 million, said Anna Torma, an analyst with Toronto Dominion Securities Inc. Shares of Chesapeake, which is based in Richmond, fell 50 cents yesterday, to $40.0625.

title: Woman Reports Rape On Estate of Singer
description: The authorities are investigating a report by a 19-year-old woman that she was raped over the weekend during a party on the grounds of the Mendham estate of the singer Whitney Houston.

title: Russia and Lenders Seal Accord On $17 Billion in New Support
description: The Russian Government and international lenders concluded an agreement today aimed at easing Russia's financial crisis and restoring confidence in its economy.

title: A Louder Voice for Poetry; From Self-Publication in the 50's to Contests Today
description: America is a nation of poets; New York is a city of poets. But it often seems that only poets themselves are aware of the fact. Audiences for their work are small, financial rewards meager, opportunities to appear in prominent public forums few.

title: Crash Knocks Boardman, Tour's Leader, From Race
description: What started as a festival day in the Tour de France to celebrate a hero of the past, Sean Kelly, ended in disaster today for a hero of the present, Chris Boardman, the man in the leader's yellow jersey.

title: Intel Says 3 PC Manufacturers Were Not Denied Chip Data
description: In its first formal response to an antitrust suit brought by the Federal Trade Commission, the Intel Corporation insisted it was within its legal rights when it withheld some technology and sought to retrieve other technology from three computer companies with whom it was engaged in litigation.

title: Canadian Ruling Unmasks a Company's Internet Critics
description: In a ruling that may impose new limits on some on-line discussions, a Canadian court has unmasked several pseudonymous critics that attacked an Ontario-based recycling company on an Internet message board.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article about Tina Brown's departure as editor of The New Yorker to start a company affiliated with Miramax, the film studio, misstated the title of Ronald A. Galotti, who will be Ms. Brown's partner in the new venture. He is currently publisher of Vogue, not its editor. Anna Wintour is the editor in chief of Vogue.

title: Welcome to the Dream Academy: Prodigies Rub Elbows, Massage Egos
description: Despite age restrictions on the women's tour and the need for a power game on the men's tour, tennis prodigies continue to spring up like mushrooms, many of them traveling to the United States with eager parents who still believe that the sport can deliver their children to the pot of gold at the end of a global rainbow.

title: Faulty Rigging Blamed in Death of Window Washer
description: A Bronx man preparing to wash windows at Lincoln Center yesterday morning became entangled in improperly rigged scaffolding and was dragged down six stories to his death, authorities said.

title: Lawyers Defend Suspects in Disappearance
description: Nine days after Irene Silverman mysteriously vanished, the lawyers for the mother and son under investigation in the case went to the socialite's lavish East Side mansion yesterday and accused the police of concealing evidence that might clear the suspects of any suspicion in her disappearance.

title: The Murky Life of an International Gun Dealer
description: An athletic-looking Dane, with blond hair, blue eyes and an arrest warrant for armed robbery, hires a British arms dealer with a Walter Mitty complex. In Latvia, they buy a Russian cargo plane and have it flown to Bulgaria where it is loaded with 77 cases of weapons, including 300 assault rifles, ammunition, pistols, hand grenades and rocket launchers.

title: Op-Art; Mr. Giuliani's Wild Ride
description: Jeff MacGregor is a writer in Manhattan. Owen Phillips is an illustration editor at The New Yorker.

title: Appeal Set in Ruling on Secret Service Testimony
description: The Clinton Administration has decided to appeal a decision last week ordering Secret Service agents to testify before a Federal grand jury in the Lewinsky matter, a senior Administration official said today.

title: Metro Business; Ex-Olympia & York Buildings for Sale
description: Metropolis Realty Trust Inc. said yesterday that it was exploring the sale of the two New York office buildings that it acquired as part of the bankruptcy of Olympia & York Developments Ltd.

title: Long Wait For Life To Return To Normal
description: Their life together has never been normal, Steven and Niki Pagones were saying today, just hours after the verdict had come in. Their wedding, their first child, the birth of identical twin girls -- not a blessed event has gone by untainted by a thought or mention of the Tawana Brawley affair.

title: Sharpton's Past Returns to Haunt Him
description: The defamation finding against the Rev. Al Sharpton in the Tawana Brawley case yesterday struck at the heart of what is surely the longest-lasting of the many campaigns that Mr. Sharpton has waged in New York over the last 10 years: The campaign to establish himself as a mainstream political force.

title: Another Draft Pick Agrees to Contract
description: The Jets added one more draft pick to the fold yesterday, giving them a total of 9 among their league-high 12 choices. But even if the Jets are unable to sign any of those remaining, there will be no impact on the start of training camp next Wednesday.

title: Personal Health; Sunscreens May Not Block Worst Skin Cancer
description: JUST when dermatologists and cancer specialists had Americans convinced that sunscreens could protect them from skin cancer and wrinkles, a scientist at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York concluded after a review of available research that sunscreens might not prevent melanoma, the deadliest form of skin cancer, at least not the way products were formulated and used in the 1980's. This news is particularly significant given the rising rates of melanoma.

title: Rowland Opens Re-election Effort With a Pledge to Cities
description: Formally starting a re-election campaign that has been under way for a year, Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut declared today that his top priority in a second term would be helping to rebuild the decaying cores of the state's largest cities.

description: Chrysler Profits Double, Topping Analysts' Forecast

description: Toy Biz Inc. won approval today from a Federal judge for its plan to reorganize Marvel Entertainment Group Inc., clearing the way for the world's largest publisher of comic books to emerge from bankruptcy protection as early as August.

title: Foreign Affairs; Desperado Democracies
description: Three weeks ago I visited Tirana, Albania, and on my way out of the airport to board my plane, I was stopped by an Albanian customs ''official.'' She looked me up and down and asked: ''How much money are you carrying?'' There was a certain Jesse James tone in her voice. I told her I had $3,500. ''$3,500,'' she repeated, her eyes lighting up. ''He has $3,500,'' she said to her fellow customs agent. ''Where are you from?'' he asked, apparently trying to determine if I was a diplomat and therefore immune from this bureaucratic stickup. ''I'm from The New York Times,'' I answered. ''Let him go,'' the man said, apparently concluding it wouldn't be good publicity to separate me from my money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORRAO, MARTHA E.
description: CORRAO-Martha E. 76. Of Marlboro on July 11, 1998. Loving wife of Eugene. Dear mother of Kathryn Thomas and her husband, Robert Thomas. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELDEN, RICHARD C.
description: WELDEN-Richard C. Died on June 29, 1998. Husband of Mary T. Welden. Father of Thorn, Wickford and Trafford. Brother of Robert E. Welden. Born May 6, 1924 in Hartford, CT. Graduate of Loomis, 1942, Yale University, 1948 and Harvard Law School, 1951. U.S. Army veteran of World War II serving in India and China. Partner with law firm of Decker, Hubbard, Welden and Sweeney, NYC. A gentle man, he was an avid bird watcher & nature lover. Modest and loyal, he was always ready to assist friends and family. He loved hiking, tennis, Central Park and the beauty of the English language. Always on the go, full of energy and determination, he was a man of great integrity. He was always cheerful. We will miss him greatly. Memorial service on Tuesday, July 14, 1998, 11 A.M. at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Ave. at 91 Street. Donations in his memory may be made to the National Audubon Society or the Central Park Conservancy.

title: Critic's Notebook; A Japanese TV Show That Pairs Beauty and Pain
description: Japanese television is known around the world for its outrageous, sadistic antics. There are game shows in which men compete to see who can keep from going to the bathroom the longest and in which women play games of Ping-Pong and the loser must strip. Now, thanks to the hit weekend television comedy show ''Super Jockey,'' one more popular culture apparition can be added to the list. And it comes not from a desire to see beautiful, scantily clad women or to see men in pain, but to see beautiful, scantily clad women in pain.

title: Plaintive Songs of Love and Exile
description: If Rumsey Playfield in Central Park wasn't filled to capacity for Sunday's ''Vive le World'' concert, part of the Summer Stage series, it must have been because France was busy beating Brazil in the World Cup. The concert, the first of a three-stop American tour, presented three acts with current residence in France and roots in North Africa; there was a wide representation of French speakers onstage and in the audience.

title: U.N. Agrees to Help Albanian Government Disarm Civilians
description: At the request of the Albanian Government, the United Nations has agreed for the first time to help disarm a civilian population that has amassed hundreds of thousands of weapons and a vast supply of ammunition, a senior official said today.

title: White House Hopes Japan Can Restore Confidence
description: The White House today urged Japan's next Government to move quickly to ''restore confidence in Japan's financial system,'' even while Administration officials said they feared that political paralysis in Tokyo greatly complicated efforts to ignite a recovery in Asia and ease pressure on other countries, including Russia.

title: On heels of soccer's World Cup and baseball's All-Star Game, a big pitch begins for the N.F.L.
description: THE annual advertising offensive to stimulate interest in National Football League games will begin almost two months earlier than usual and involve almost four times as many promotional commercials as before.

description: KOO-Teh-Chang. Age 82. Died on July 9 in Kissimmee, FL. He was the eldest son of Dr. V.K. Wellington Koo. description: BASEBALL

title: A Clangor Of Pianos And Bells Under The Stars
description: The second Summergarden program at the back of the Museum of Modern Art, on Friday, worked a lot better than the first. Whatever misgivings one might have about hearing music over a public address system, at least the amplification was working consistently. More important, most of the music was good to hear in an outdoor space at night.

title: Thousands of Protestants March Peacefully in Ulster
description: Tens of thousands of Orange Order Protestants walked peacefully today in several hundred parades throughout Northern Ireland, after a week of Protestant violence over the issue of patriotic marches in Roman Catholic neighborhoods and the death of three young Catholic brothers in an arson attack.

title: A Long Night For Salsa And Its Stars
description: By midnight on Saturday, the sold-out house at Madison Square Garden was flattened. The audience, there for a concert put on by the radio station La Mega and featuring some of salsa and merengue's biggest stars, suffered through four hours of continuous ear-wrecking musical volume, repetitive nationalistic flag waving and advertising on the part of the radio station. It all reduced the place to a stupor. Enter Los Hermanos Rosario, a Dominican dance machine, and the place exploded yet again, with the audience up on its feet, dancing to the tractor-engine power of the music.

title: Tenneco Said To Halt Talks On ITT Unit
description: Tenneco Inc., a leading maker of car mufflers and shock absorbers, has halted talks to buy the European brakes division of ITT Industries Inc., a person close to the company said late yesterday.

description: A city teacher who was dismissed a month ago for asking her sixth graders if they wanted to accept Jesus Christ as their Saviour will receive two weeks' back pay, Board of Education officials said yesterday.

title: For F.D.R., 'Fatigue' Was Lethal
description: THOUGH wholly without glamour, hypertension has played a noteworthy role in the course of human events, rarely more than in the case of President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

title: PHYMATRIX HIRES SALOMON TO WEIGH OFFERS
description: The Phymatrix Corporation said yesterday that it had hired Salomon Smith Barney, the investment banking unit of the Travelers Group, to evaluate offers it has received as it considers a merger or a sale of all or part of the company. Phymatrix, a company in West Palm Beach, Fla., that runs and manages physician networks and medical properties, had $346.6 million in sales in its latest fiscal year. It said it was considering a merger, spinoffs, asset sales, a management buyback and other options. The company's share price has fallen from a 52-week high of $17 on Oct. 30 to $7.75 yesterday. At the current price, Phymatrix has a market capitalization of $258 million.

title: Inquiry on Campaign Finance Is Running Dry, Officials Say
description: Twenty-one months after accusations of illegal fund-raising arose from President Clinton's re-election campaign, law-enforcement officials concede they have no big cases to show for their effort and express doubts that they will obtain evidence to warrant prosecution of senior White House or Democratic Party officials.

title: Treasury Prices Fall on Hints Of Japan and Russia Recovery
description: Treasury securities suffered their worst one-day losses in more than a month yesterday on suggestions that Japan and Russia would overcome their economic crises, which diminished the allure of United States bonds as a safe-haven investment.

description: PETERSON-Lou. Thanks for years of friendship. R.I.P. Jules

The foundation said there was ''no truth to any of the allegations made in the story.''

description: A Brooklyn man robbed a nun at a Queens church yesterday morning, making off with more than $2,000 before being chased down by police officers, the authorities said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about an American group's proposed acquisition of a stake in Credit Foncier de France, which has an interest in the company that operates the Eiffel Tower, misidentified an American investor. It is the Bass Group, an investment group led by Robert M. Bass -- not the Bass brothers -- that is joining the GMAC Commercial Mortgage Corporation in buying the stake.

title: Setback for Sharpton
description: The defamation finding against the Rev. Al Sharpton in the Tawana Brawley case struck at the campaign he has waged to establish himself as a force in mainstream politics.

title: Abortion Bill Won't Encourage Teen-Agers to Reach Out to Parents
description: To the Editor:

title: Lobbyist Is Indicted Over Campaign Donations
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted a Thai businesswoman who worked as a Washington lobbyist on charges that she and her family funneled hundreds of thousands of dollars in foreign money to the Democratic Party to gain access for her clients to President Clinton and members of the Administration.

title: What's at Stake as Prada Toys With Gucci
description: When Patrizio Bertelli, the chairman of Prada, made his purchase early last month of 5.5 percent of Gucci stock, he met with Domenico De Sole, the chief executive of Gucci, to tell him so.

title: Corrections
description: Two sports picture captions on Sunday with an article about Todd Hundley's return to the Mets referred incorrectly to his surgery in some editions. It was on his elbow, not his knee.

title: Northern Ireland's War Over Peace
description: We live, my three young children, my wife and I, in a quiet housing estate in the county of Wicklow, the garden of Ireland. It is neither here nor there, in this part of Ireland, that my wife is Protestant and I am Catholic. Indeed, such a thing means almost nothing in these present times.

title: For Los Angeles Homeless, a New Set of Hassle-Free Wheels
description: For the homeless on the streets of Skid Row here, just a couple of blocks from the glass towers of downtown, a shopping cart is much more than a basket on squeaky wheels. It is also a rolling closet, a hope chest and an office, and sometimes a ticket to jail since the carts are typically the property of grocery stores and other businesses.

title: Exploding Elevators
description: Q. Why is grain dust in elevators explosive?

title: U.N. Chief Denies He's Seeking to Mediate the Chiapas Conflict
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan denied today that the United Nations was looking to mediate the conflict in Chiapas, even though he expressed concern over the fragile state of peace in Mexico's southernmost state.

title: Penguin Keeper's Eden No Tuxedo Junction
description: IF you're looking for someone who knows penguins, you could do worse than have a chat with Celia Ackerman, a zoo keeper at the Central Park Zoo. She knows the names of the 38 birds in the penguin building and can tell you where their immigrant ancestors came from. (They were collected, as eggs in the Antarctic, by the people at Sea World, and shipped, after hatching, to New York.)

description: STEUER-Sally Jane. On July 12, 1998, after a long illness. Daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. William Jacobson. title: Family Discount at Public Pools Turns Into Gay Rights Debate
description: What Mark R. Melanson loves about living in the suburbs with his gay partner, he says, is that they have a lot in common with everybody else in their suburban neighborhood, including the elderly woman who lives next door and the nuclear family down the street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, MARVIN
description: GORDON-Marvin. Of Lake Success. Beloved husband of Thelma, devoted father of Carol Wulfson and Nina Schwartz. Cherished grandfather of Michelle, Harris, Lauren and Russell. title: Little Talk of Compromise as N.A.A.C.P. Speakers Defend Affirmative Action
description: The nation's oldest civil rights organization stood firmly behind affirmative action today, publicly scorning compromise on the issue and attacking its critics, including the Supreme Court.

title: AVECOR CARDIOVASCULAR TO BE PURCHASED IN STOCK DEAL
description: Medtronic Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Avecor Cardiovascular Inc. for about $91 million in stock. Avecor shareholders would receive $11.125 in Medtronic stock for each share held. Avecor's shares closed at $10.0625 yesterday, up 18.75 cents. The company, based in Brooklyn Park, Minn., makes disposable medical devices for heart and lung bypass surgery and long-term respiratory support. It had sales of $46.9 million in 1997. Medtronic, of nearby Minneapolis, makes implantable medical devices and had sales of $2.6 billion in the year ended April 30.

title: THE LEARNING COMPANY SELLS A CANADIAN BUSINESS
description: The Learning Company, the large educational software maker, said yesterday that its Canadian unit had sold its Canadian income tax software business to a unit of Wolters Kluwer N.V., the Dutch publisher, for $45 million in cash. The Learning Company unit, Softkey Software Products Inc., sold the tax-preparation business to CCH Canadian Ltd. The Learning Company, based in Cambridge, Mass., said it wanted to focus on instructional and entertainment titles. Proceeds from the sale will help pay for recent acquisitions.

title: U.S. Shouldn't Pay for Asia Bailout; Immature 'Tigers'
description: To the Editor:

title: Arrests in Separate Cases Of Child Abuse and Death
description: Three adults were under arrest and others were being questioned last night in the deaths of two children and the severe abuse of another in separate incidents in the Bronx and Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Hopes Soar and Necks Crane as Falcons Thrive in City
description: FROM the canyons of Wall Street to the city's great bridges, from the steeple of Riverside Church to one of the city's most prestigious medical complexes, peregrine falcons, once near extinction, are nesting, breeding and, most assuredly, endearing themselves to Gotham residents.

title: Japan's Voter Revolt
description: Japanese governments do not normally resign after election losses for Parliament's less important upper house. But so emphatic was the defeat voters inflicted on the ruling Liberal Democratic Party on Sunday that Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto decided to quit. The L.D.P. had expected to take about 60 of the 126 seats being contested. It won only 44.

title: People
description: * Murray Dudgeon was named to the new position of executive vice president and worldwide media operations director at McCann-Erickson Worldwide, New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos. For the last year he was managing director of Classic FM, a radio station in London owned by GWR Group; before that he worked in other posts for McCann-Erickson.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Hashimoto is one of the best that the L.D.P. can produce. Unless someone terribly fresh and surprising comes along, it's hard to see how the next Prime Minister can handle the issues head on and fast.''

title: Corrections
description: A pop music review yesterday about Lisa Germano's performance at the Knitting Factory last Wednesday misidentified the album, to be released this month, on which she sings ''No Colors Here.'' It is ''Slide,'' not ''Shine.''

title: NEW YORK ACCOUNTING FIRM BOUGHT BY AMERICAN EXPRESS
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that it had bought the accounting firm Goldstein Golub Kessler & Company. Terms were not disclosed. Goldstein Golub has more than 400 employees serving 1,500 commercial clients and 3,500 individuals. The firm, based in New York, will be folded into the American Express Tax and Business Services unit, the nation's 10th-largest accounting company, according to Bowman's Accounting Report. Goldstein Golub's chairman, Gerald L. Golub -- who is not related to the American Express chairman, Harvey Golub -- will become chairman of the unit.

title: For Mild Hypertension, Healthier Life and Diet May Be Good Medicine
description: FOR people with high blood pressure who hate to take pills, recent studies have offered good news: changes in daily routine can lower blood pressure enough to let some people with mild hypertension postpone the need for medicine or avoid it altogether.

title: John Michael O'Mara, 84, N.Y.U. Administrator
description: John Michael O'Mara, a retired vice president of New York University who had an earlier career as a rackets investigator, died on June 19 at Hackensack University Medical Center in New Jersey. A former resident of Leonia, N.J., he was 84 and more recently lived in Norwood, N.J.

title: Clinton Seeks Power to Lift India-Pakistan Sanctions
description: The Clinton Administration asked Congress today for more flexibility in its dealings with India and Pakistan, saying that current sanctions against the two countries for their nuclear weapons programs are too rigid and limit Washington's ability to halt a South Asian nuclear arms race.

title: Anemic Offense Stops Yanks Short of a New Mark
description: Paul O'Neill leaned forward dejectedly on a chair in front of his locker tonight, elbows on knees, his voice barely a whisper as he discussed the Indians' 4-1 defeat of the Yankees, which ended the team's 10-game winning streak.

description: The United Healthcare Corporation said today that Federal antitrust enforcers are seeking information about the company's proposed $6.23 billion acquisition of Humana Inc., a deal that would create one of the largest United States managed health care companies.

description: The National Basketball Association has sued its players union, contending that the league should not have to pay players during the lockout and that it should not have to go to arbitration over the issue.

title: The Case For Duckman As a Scapegoat
description: IT is safe to say that Lorin Duckman, formerly Judge Lorin Duckman, is one of the more reviled public figures in New York City. The attacks against him have been so harsh, you would almost think that Mr. Duckman alone stood between New York and Periclean bliss.

title: As Rangers Talk to Joseph, Richter Remains Hopeful
description: While the Rangers remained close to an agreement with the free-agent goaltender Curtis Joseph yesterday, Mike Richter and his agent expressed hope that a deal to keep Richter in New York could still be worked out.

title: At Macworld Show, Apple Turns Out New Products and Plenty of Promises
description: THE relatively sparse crowds and smaller exhibit booths at last week's Macworld trade show in New York were tangible evidence of the decline of Apple Computer in recent years. Visitors to the show typically found that promises almost outnumbered actual products. But while dazzling new products were scarce at Macworld, no doubt many people were just as happy to take home some optimism about the future of Macintosh.

title: Corrections

title: Science Watch; Science by Nature's Design
description: NATURAL experiments are those in which nature designs the test of some hypothesis and the only effort required of the scientist is to figure out what experiment is being conducted in nature's laboratory.

title: Harare Journal; Mugabe Attacks, and Gay Zimbabweans Fight Back
description: Nearly three years ago, in a dispute over a small stand at an obscure book fair, President Robert Mugabe suddenly lashed out against gay men and lesbians, making remarks that echoed around the world. He said they were ''worse than pigs and dogs'' and had no civil rights in Zimbabwe.

A memorial service will be held at 2 PM, July 26th, at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Oceanside Public Library.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER RALLIES. Copper rose 2.8 percent, helped by lower output in China and hope that a leadership change in Japan would hasten an economic revival there. September contracts rose 2 cents, to 74.30 cents a pound.

title: At Ease Amid Pandemonium
description: Billy Childish, the reigning world champion of garage rock, has worked on the docks and been on the dole; he loves the writing of Knut Hamson but has trouble keeping all the names straight in Russian novels. A self-made intellectual of a particularly English stripe, Mr. Childish has sworn loyalty to populist art at its rawest. He publishes rants and elaborate jokes disguised as poetry and exhibits paintings that would not feel out of place in the Museum of American Folk Art.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNEBORN, HENRY, III, PHD.
description: SONNEBORN-Henry, III, PhD. description: A parolee who was convicted of murder in the 1995 slaying of a reclusive Upper East Side woman was sentenced yesterday to 25 years in prison.

description: Four more illegal Chinese immigrants who landed on a New Jersey beach on May 30 posted bond yesterday, only to be immediately rearrested by Federal authorities as witnesses in a continuing investigation into smuggling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDRING, HELEN
description: GOLDRING-Helen. We are very saddened to learn of the passing of Helen Goldring, the beloved mother of our esteemed Professor Roberta Goldring Coles and the wonderful spouse of our late Professor William Goldring, both in the Department of Medicine at NYU School of Medicine. Helen Goldring was an alumna of the NYU School of Law (1928). She was a unique woman who combined professionalism with the leadership of a very special family. Helen was the pillar of strength who guided and supported the outstanding careers of the late William, who was a highly regarded leading clinical investigator in hypertension and renal disease, and Roberta, who is an acclaimed, productive and respected clinician, investigator and teacher in pulmonary physiology, pathophysiology, and disease. Helen was the special role model who pursued excellence and made the name Goldring synonymous with excellence. She was the very proud and supportive spouse, mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. She was the finest of the fine. We owe her a great deal for providing us with unique members of our alumni and faculty. She was the spouse of William; mother of Roberta and the late Nancy; mother-in-law of the late Dr. Robert Coles of our faculty and an alumnus of our School of Medicine (1945); grandmother of Deputy Mayor Anthony, John, an accomplished movie director, and sister, Dr. Nancy Coles Goldstein of our faculty, special alumnae (1985) and member of our Board of Governors; and great-grandmother of eight wonderful great-grandchildren. We express our deep sympathy to the entire family. Saul J. Farber, M.D., M.A.C.P. The Frederick H. King Professor & Chairman, Department of Medicine

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK RISES FURTHER. The mark strengthened to its highest level since late June on news that the I.M.F. would increase aid to Russia, Germany's main trading partner. The dollar fell to 1.8017 marks in New York from 1.8180.

title: Ousted Condo Owners Get Chance to Recoup Money
description: Ten months after city officials declared a Queens condominium tower structurally unsound and evacuated more than a third of its residents, lawyers for the apartment owners announced a deal yesterday in which the owners will be able to sell their apartments and recoup at least 80 percent of their investment.

title: Italian Media Tycoon Convicted Again on Corruption Charges
description: Silvio Berlusconi, the flamboyant media tycoon and former Prime Minister, was convicted by a Milan jury today of making illegal political donations and was given a sentence of two years and four months, as well as a $5.6 million fine.

title: Don't Call It Journalism
description: For some time now, especially as media giants devour other media giants, synergy has taken on the elusive shimmer of a corporate grail. The idea has always been that various divisions of Viacom or AT&T/TCI or News Corporation would work together to promote one another's ''product.'' An article from the magazine wing creates the book for the publishing arm, which then segues into the movie that launches the toy soldiers that -- sold altogether by one big mother company -- make a ton of money for the happy stockholders.

title: 3 Held After Cocaine Is Found in Guava
description: Three Queens men have been arrested in connection with the discovery of 714 pounds of cocaine that arrived at Port Newark wrapped in layers of frozen guava pulp, the United States Customs Service announced yesterday.

title: MCI Reported To Be Near Full Internet Sale
description: The MCI Communications Corporation is close to an agreement to sell its entire Internet business to Cable and Wireless P.L.C. for $1.5 billion to $2 billion in cash, executives close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: UNITED AUTO EXPANDING INTO CALIFORNIA MARKET
description: United Auto Group Inc. said yesterday that it had bought two San Diego franchises and had agreements to buy two more as it expands into California. United Auto, a retail chain based in New York, completed the purchase of Kearny Mesa Toyota and Lexus Kearny Mesa for undisclosed terms. Its agreements to buy Kearny Mesa Dodge and Mazda Kearny Mesa are still subject to manufacturer approval. The four franchises have estimated 1998 revenue of $160 million. The acquisitions represent a westward expansion for United Auto, which has 98 franchises nationwide, mostly on the East Coast. The company, which had 1997 revenues of $2 billion, is the country's second-largest publicly traded auto retailer, behind Republic Industries.

title: A Conversation: With Dr. Leon Lederman; Science Is Serious Business to the 'Mel Brooks of Physics'
description: THE small loquacious man lighting into a slice of rhubarb pie at a South Loop restaurant on a recent Chicago evening is Dr. Leon M. Lederman, 76, City College class of 1943, director emeritus of the Fermilab National Accelerator Laboratory, the author of ''The God Particle,'' (Houghton Mifflin, 1993) and the winner of the 1988 Nobel Prize in Physics.

title: Justice Delayed and Derailed
description: Attorney General Janet Reno is going to report to the Senate Judiciary Committee today, but nothing she says is likely to change one big fact or clear up one lasting mystery. The fact is that even with the Independent Counsel Act, if an Attorney General is determined to protect a sitting President from investigation there is little that Congress or Federal law enforcement agencies can do. The mystery is why any Attorney General would want his or her chief legacy to be the preservation of a cover-up.

title: A Three-Alarm Pursuit of an Old Flame
description: Sometimes Western civilization declines in deliriously funny style. Why bother to list the myriad offenses given by ''There's Something About Mary,'' the proudly obnoxious new film by Peter and Bobby Farrelly, when it's easier -- definitely much too easy -- to enjoy them? In the raunchy wake of ''Dumb and Dumber'' and ''Kingpin,'' the Farrelly brothers have made a romantic comedy that's a hoot in every sense, worth a smidgen of disapproval and a whole lot of helpless laughter. But the Farrellys are as gleeful as they are crude, and they certainly aren't witless. The film works ridiculously well because it never stoops to being mean-spirited or (despite all appearances) authentically inane.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day yesterday about the Intel Corporation's response to an antitrust lawsuit by the Federal Trade Commission misstated the company's position. As the article noted, Intel contends that it was within its rights; it does not deny having withheld technology from three computer companies.

title: Focus in Squeegee Shooting Is Request to Fellow Officer
description: Investigators are exploring the possibility that a New York City police officer charged with trying to kill a squeegee man in the Bronx last month may have asked another officer to cover up for him in the minutes after the shooting.

title: First Boston Hires More Than 100 From Deutsche Bank
description: Credit Suisse First Boston completed one of the biggest talent raids in Wall Street history yesterday, luring more than 100 technology bankers and analysts from Deutsche Bank A.G.

title: The Boathouse: In Harmony With the Park
description: AS the sun is setting, the final notes of music slide off the dock, skip across the water and disappear into the trees. A swan glides into view, tracing a graceful path through the last of the light. Birds swoop and call; a gondola appears on the horizon.

title: Bucking Trend, Debt in Albany Keeps Growing
description: There is an audacity to the way New York State borrows money that can make even critics sound almost admiring.

title: Hikind Decides to Skip Race for Congress
description: A day after he was acquitted of charges that he accepted illegal payoffs, Assemblyman Dov Hikind said he would not run for the Congressional seat being vacated by Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn.

title: A Friendly Merger of Generations
description: Walking back from a water cooler near the third tee at the Wykagyl Country Club today, Nancy Lopez handed Se Ri Pak a cup of water. ''Here, let me buy you a drink,'' Lopez said with a big smile. Smiling back, Pak took the cup and thanked her playing partner.

title: Close Call on Campaign Finance
description: A bare majority of the House tonight narrowly fended off another effort to amend a bipartisan campaign finance bill, keeping the measure intact through another night of debate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JARWOOD, ARTHUR
description: JARWOOD-Arthur. Arthur Jarwood, June 26, 1998. My beloved husband, my dearest friend. There was never a love like yours. The cherished memories you've given me. The scent of you. The sight of you. The sound of you. The joy of you. You'll always be with me, so goodnight sweet prince. You'll forever abide in the heart of the one who adored you. Ashley.

description: ''Look at what has become of this country. We are one of the world's biggest producers of oil, and we have no fuel. We have more power stations than we need, and no electricity. Madness.''

title: GMAC-RFC Picks Campbell Mithun
description: GMAC-RFC in Bloomington, Minn., the investment arm of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, which issues car loans and leases, said yesterday that it had named Campbell Mithun Esty in Minneapolis to handle its marketing account, which had been handled in-house. Billings were estimated at $8 million to $10 million. Campbell Mithun, which is majority-owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies, was awarded the assignment after a four-month review that had been narrowed to that agency and one other finalist, Clarion Marketing and Communications Group in Greenwich, Conn., part of MacManus Group.

title: The Players' Favorite Is Westwood
description: Asked to pick a favorite for this year's British Open, many players have named Lee Westwood, who has won three times in his last four starts on the European Tour.

title: Metro Business; HMV to Enter Harlem
description: HMV Worldwide plans to open Harlem's first music superstore next year, on West 125th Street next to the Apollo Theater.

title: Paul Chow, 69; Helped Save Immigration Site
description: Paul Q. Chow, who helped lead the effort to preserve and restore the Angel Island Immigration Station as the Ellis Island of the West Coast, died on June 30 at his home in San Francisco. He was 69.

title: Police Accord Would Drop '48-Hour Rule'
description: The union that represents police sergeants in New York City reached a tentative agreement with the Giuliani administration yesterday on a contract that eliminates the right of police officers to wait two full business days before having to answer questions from the Police Department about possible misconduct.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DETWILER, VALERIE (NEE BYRNE)
description: DETWILER-Valerie (nee Byrne), a state of Arizona Community Health Nurse, former resident of Long Beach, Long Island and nineteen year resident of Tucson, died Wednesday, July 1, 1998 at Tucson Medical Hospice Center. She was sixty years old. She was born on December 24, 1937 in the Bronx, NY to Eugene & Therese Byrne. She attended St. Nicholas of Tolentine High School and in 1963 received her nursing degree from St. John's Nursing School. She joined the Army in 1966 as a Second Lieutenant and subsequently rose to the rank of First Lieutenant. She served in Southeast Asia acting as a surgical nurse for severe casualties of the Vietnam War. In 1968, she married Chief W.O. Jack Sheridan Detwiler. They resided in Long Beach for ten years. She was a member of St. Ignatius R.C. Church and cared for the elderly in Long Beach and participated in other local community organizations. In 1979, she moved to Tucson with her family where she was a parishioner at Our Mother of Sorrows R.C. Church. She continued to care for the elderly and to volunteer at several local organizations including the Girl Scouts of America. In addition to her husband Jack, she is survived by their children Victoria and Andrew of Tucson and Mark of Hawaii; five stepsons: Jack of Minneapolis, Minnesota, Don of Oceanside, Long Island, Robert of Tucson, Michael & Daryl of Tulsa, Oklahoma; their three grandchildren: Victoria, Andrew and Brooke; eleven step grandchildren; one step great grandchild; and her brother, E. Michael Byrne of Bronxville, NY. Her parents Eugene and Therese preceded her in death in 1968 and 1990, and her sister, Denise M. Hanrahan, in 1989. First Lieutenant M. Valerie Detwiler will be laid to rest July 16th at 1:00 P.M., at Arlington National Cemetery with full military honors. Donations in the name of Valerie Detwiler may be made to the Tucson Medical Center Hospice, 5301 East Grant Street, Tucson, Arizona 85712 or National Kidney Cancer Association, 1234 Sheridan Avenue, Suite 203, Evanston, IL. 60202.

title: Pettitte And Yanks Maintain Their Edge
description: Like superpowers in the baseball world, the Yankees and the Cleveland Indians are wary of each other, their resources and abilities comparable, their recent history tense. Before the Yankees even earn a chance to win the World Series and establish themselves as one of the greatest teams of the 20th century, they could very well face Cleveland in the playoffs.

title: With Pillow Talk, Boyz II Men Hold Their Pajama Party
description: Fans waited an entire hour for the pajamas during the Boyz II Men's performance at Radio City Music Hall on Monday night. The anticipated costumes weren't really pajamas anyway, just loose white loungewear in diaphanous silk. And almost immediately, the four Boyz pulled them off to reveal black tank tops and pre-ripped jeans, in keeping with their tentative new image as hip-hop-loving roughnecks. It was as if they'd forgotten that the pajamas are what it's all about.

title: Students at Aviation High Tend to 747's
description: Oscar Mendez would sit on his porch and admire the small cropdusters. They flew low to the ground fumigating the rice fields near his home in the Dominican Republic.

title: Southern Bombing Fugitive Is Seen in North Carolina
description: After five and a half months in hiding, the man wanted in the bombing of an Alabama abortion clinic emerged from the woods of western North Carolina last week, took a large amount of food and a pickup truck from a residence, and then abandoned the truck and vanished once more, the Federal authorities said today.

description: New York City's sex shops and their customers have lost yet another round in their court fight to block tough zoning laws intended to restrict the adult-entertainment industry, and their legal remedies have essentially been reduced to one: an appeal to the United States Supreme Court.

description: ALMOST a decade after Alaska lost its nonstop passenger service to Japan, Northwest Airlines is currently making weekly nonstop flights between Anchorage and Tokyo.

description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation downgraded the credit rating of Pakistan yesterday to CCC from B-, which is the lowest assessment of any country rated by S.& P.

description: IN another ambitious effort to improve its competitive position on Madison Avenue, the Leo Burnett Company said yesterday that it would join rival agencies in the rapidly growing field of business-to-business technology marketing by acquiring TFA Communications L.L.C., a leading shop in that realm.

title: DelValle And Jones Differ Often
description: The way Roy Jones Jr. remembered it yesterday, he was the older guy who took the young Lou DelValle under his wing. He made him a sparring partner, he gave him a job, he hung out with him. But DelValle, who faces Jones Saturday night at the Theater at Madison Square Garden in a bout to unify the light-heavyweight title, has become ''a traitor,'' according to Jones.

title: Hauling Rates For Garbage Rising Again, Shops Report
description: Two years after city officials cracked down on abuses in the garbage hauling industry, small-business owners said yesterday that the price of private collection is starting to rise again, while haulers warned that a few large companies are dominating the market.

description: KIRSCHENBAUM-Leah. We profoundly regret the passing of Leah Kirschenbaum, our devoted friend. Together with her beloved husband, Judge Irving Kirschenbaum, she enriched the lives of all who knew her. We shall miss her greatly. Elie Wiesel, President Marion Wiesel, V.P. Arnold Thaler, V.P. The Elie Wiesel Foundation For Humanity 450 Lexington Ave, NY NY 10017

description: The General Motors Corporation announced today that its profits plunged 81 percent in the second quarter, mainly because of strikes here. The auto maker also filed a lawsuit demanding that the United Automobile Workers union allow immediate arbitration of the dispute.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESS, STEPHEN R.
description: HESS-Stephen R. The Board of Directors and members of the Quaker Ridge Golf Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Stephen R. Hess, whose many years of friendship and devotion to the Club will always be remembered. We extend our deepest sympathy to the family. Richard M. Feldman, President Edward J. Landau, Secretary

title: Police Hope Clues in Car Lead to Missing Woman
description: Still no closer to finding Irene Silverman, the wealthy widow who vanished under suspicious circumstances 10 days ago, city detectives yesterday focused on clues that might place her in the car of the two suspects in her disappearance, examining minute samples of hair and saliva recovered from the back seat to determine whether they match hers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERRILL, VERNON L.
description: MERRILL-Vernon L. Of Locust Valley, NY, beloved wife of Robert G. Merrill, died on July 13th after a long battle with breast cancer. She was 72. Mrs. Merrill is survived by six children: Lynn Gray of Locust Valley; Gail Merrill of New Canaan, CT.; Edmund Merrill and Douglas Merrill, both of Denver, CO.; Signa Herman of St. Louis, MO.; and Nina Ogan of Denver. She is survived by 8 grandchildren, a stepgrandchild, her sister, Signa L. Mills and her brother, Edmund C. Lynch, Jr. Mrs. Merrill was the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edmund C. Lynch. Mr. Lynch was a founder of Merrill Lynch & Co. Mrs. Merrill was an accomplished athlete; she excelled in tennis and croquet. Active in many educational endeavors, she served on the boards of trustees of several schools and colleges. In addition, she was active in the North Country Garden Club and was the current president of the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Associates. The burial is private. A memorial service will be held at 11:00 A.M., on Saturday, July 18th at St. Paul the Apostle Church, Cedar Swamp Road in Brookville, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, P.O. Box 100, Cold Spring Harbor, New York 11724, would be appreciated.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Refurbished Behemoth Is Filling Up in Chelsea
description: In January, when Taconic Investment Partners took control of 111 Eighth Avenue, the mammoth former Port Authority building between 15th and 16th Streets had nearly 500,000 square feet of vacant space. No more.

title: Corporations Still Give, but Also Get
description: While corporations continue to lend major support to colleges and universities, their giving is rarely so purely philanthropic as in the past, the leading organization of education fund-raisers was told at its annual meeting over the weekend.

title: Deregulation Fosters Turmoil in Power Market
description: As Paul McCoy watched a monitor displaying wholesale electricity prices, he could not believe his eyes. Hour after hour, Mr. McCoy, a senior vice president at the Commonwealth Edison Company, the utility that serves Chicago, saw prices surging to levels never seen before, peaking at about 100 times normal.

title: Phnom Penh Journal; When He Writes a Song, Cambodia Better Listen
description: Pity the pagoda boy, barefoot and hungry, living on handouts from the monks. But now the pagoda boy is grown up and important and he sits in a big chair.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONALD, ROBERT W.
description: McDONALD-Robert W. Age 48, of Evanston, IL. On July 11th, 1998. He is survived by his loving wife Donna, their daughter Maura and his brother John. He was a kind and gentle man who cared greatly for his family. A Mass will be held to celebrate his life on July 18, 1998, 10 A.M., at Saint Athanasius Church, 1615 Lincoln St., Evanston IL. Contributions in his memory may be made to Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center Foundation, 1124 Columbia St., LY120, Seattle WA. 98104. He will be deeply missed by family and friends.

title: Citing Low Chip Prices, Intel Earns Less Than Forecast
description: The Intel Corporation reported a 29 percent drop in second-quarter earnings today, a greater-than-expected decline that the leading maker of computer chips attributed to weakened prices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUSMAN, JACK
description: HAUSMAN-Jack. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York note with sadness the death of a legendary figure, Jack Hausman. Throughout his distinguished life, he was deeply committed to helping the less fortunate in our society. Along with his brothers, he was among the founding fathers of our organization who built for the future while honoring the past. Though the community is diminished by this loss, we derive strength from the memory of his dedication and vitality. We extend our condolences to his sons, Richard and Michael; his brother, Leo; his grandchildren and great-grandchildren; and all the members of the family. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: Limping Strawberry Becoming A Concern

Strawberry was in the lineup tonight, after meeting with Manager Joe Torre about three and a half hours before the game to discuss his knee, but Torre has watched Strawberry's gait evolve from a slight to a heavy limp.

title: Critic's Notebook; With Barbecue, New York Is Mostly Just Whistling Dixie
description: WHAT do Kansas City, Mo.; Chicago, and Oakland, Calif., have that New York does not? Great barbecue, for one. When it comes to real barbecue -- meat cooked ever so slowly over a low wood fire until it is imbued with the tantalizing aroma of smoke -- these cities thoroughly outdo New York.

description: For more than 25 years, computer scientists have been working to develop a technology known as distributed computing that would put the processing power of a supercomputer in the hands of average users.

description: NAGLER-Robert. Beloved husband and father. You are always in our thoughts. Ellen, Hilary and Adam

description: HAYES-Julian L. On July 12, 1998, in Louisville, KY. In his 83rd year, beloved husband of 58 years of Nanette Hayes, father of Lea Fischbach, Susan MacDonald, Nanette Adkins, six grandchildren, two great-granddaughters. Formerly Director Public Relations of the Anaconda Company, Council of the Americas. Memorial service will be held July 25th in Louisville and in NYC at a later date.

title: North Korea Said to Block Inspection of Nuclear Sites
description: North Korea is refusing to allow international inspectors full access to its nuclear sites, raising concern that it will be impossible to determine if North Korea has hidden away enough plutonium to build nuclear weapons, Congressional investigators said in a new report.

title: Heralding a New Era, Babbitt Chips Away at Harmful River Dams
description: Standing amid one of the most elaborately engineered hydraulic systems in the world, Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt took a sledge hammer to a dam in California's Central Valley today, heralding the start of what he said would be an era when many of the nation's 75,000 dams would be judged by whether they did more harm than good.

description: THE Mets, through no fault of their own, are giving a whole new meaning to the term ''sandwich generation.''

title: A Shivering Hoch Joins British Open
description: Scott Hoch stood by the 18th green today at the Royal Birkdale Golf Club with his hands in his pockets trying to stay warm. He looked as if he had just stepped out of a refrigerator.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUBER, FRIEDA B.
description: LAUBER-Frieda B., 89. Beloved wife of late Hugo Lauber, died Tuesday in Norwalk, CT. Born in Germany, NYC resident since 1936. Survived by two daughters, Kate Dickstein, Westport, CT and Irene Tomlinson, Pleasanton, CA, sister Kate May, two sons-in-law Howard Dickstein and Chris Tomlinson, five grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Graveside Service Thursday, 11:00 A.M. Beth El Cemetery, Washington Township, New Jersey.

title: In a Group Home, at 70 Still the Star
description: The important news for those who saw ''Best Boy,'' the fine documentary that won an Academy Award in 1979, is that Philly is alive and kicking, or dancing when occasion invites. Philip Wohl, known to everybody in his family and in his Queens neighborhood as Philly, was 50 years old when his cousin Ira Wohl first decided to tell his story; now, at 70, he is the endearing hero of a sweet sequel, ''Best Man.''

description: The Brooklyn day care driver who found one of his young passengers dead in the back seat of his van on Monday was charged yesterday in connection with the preschooler's death.

description: For the first time in its 27-year history, ''Masterpiece Theater'' will present American literary masterpieces, starting next year, executives of the Public Broadcasting Service announced today.

description: Although it stands to reason that the most ambitious projects will also be the most difficult, the Lincoln Center Festival could hardly have imagined the misfortunes that were to befall its two musical marathons this year. The sad fate of the Chinese opera ''The Peony Pavilion,'' a recent victim of bureaucratic wrangling in Shanghai, is by now familiar.

title: HARD TIME: A special report.; Profits at a Juvenile Prison Come With a Chilling Cost
description: Here in the middle of the impoverished Mississippi Delta is a juvenile prison so rife with brutality, cronyism and neglect that many legal experts say it is the worst in the nation.

title: Dow Surges 1.6% to Join Other Stock Gauges at Record Levels
description: The stock market rallied sharply yesterday as several companies reported good or better-than-expected earnings for the second quarter, easing concerns about the drag from Asia's economic turmoil.

title: More Queries In Accounting Drub Cendant
description: The bad news got worse yesterday for investors in the Cendant Corporation, the marketing and franchising company whose accounting problems have devastated its stock price over the last three months.

title: Pomp and Soccer, and Some Politics, at a Bastille Day Party
description: Basking in the reflected glory of France's World Cup soccer championship, President Jacques Chirac appealed to his compatriots today, Bastille Day, not to lose the upbeat victory spirit.

title: Losing Our Souls, Bit by Bit
description: The cold war may be ancient history, but the Code War is only now beginning to heat up.

title: Bobwhites in the Bronx
description: By the year 2000, man and nature permitting, flora and fauna that have not been seen in these parts for years will be thriving in New York City's parks -- screech owls and luna moths in Manhattan, bobwhite quail in the Bronx, water shrews in Queens, butterfly weed in Brooklyn, tree frogs in Staten Island. These species are part of Parks Commissioner Henry Stern's experiment to enhance the biodiversity and the educational value of the urban landscape. Whether it works or not, his plan is powerful evidence of how far New York City's parks have come. Not so long ago the parks were dumping grounds for abandoned cars. Today they are healthy enough to allow their supervisors to think more ambitiously.

title: Court Agreement Revises Requirements on Schools
description: Under a court settlement announced yesterday, waivers granted by the state's Department of Education exempting hundreds of school districts from special-education requirements are no longer in effect. At the same time, officials said that sweeping revisions relaxing the requirements mean that many of those same districts no longer need the waivers.

title: First Union Reports $249 Million Profit
description: The First Union Corporation said today that its second-quarter operating earnings had risen by 23 percent, with income from fees largely responsible.

title: Consumer Prices Barely Rose Last Month
description: Consumer prices rose less than expected in June and retail sales for the month added to a strong gain in May, the Government said today in reports that suggested the economy was still expanding without causing higher inflation.

title: 4 Drug Makers Move to Settle In Pricing Suit
description: In one of the country's most bitter scuffles over fair trade, four pharmaceutical companies have tentatively agreed to pay $345 million to settle a class-action price-fixing lawsuit brought by 40,000 retail pharmacies, according to lawyers involved in the case.

title: Rangers, in About-Face, Sign Richter for 4 Years
description: In a sudden turn of events last night, Mike Richter, the unrestricted free-agent goaltender, went from odd man out of the Rangers' net to the team's goalie for the next four seasons.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: About New York; Hard Times for Art in Realm of the Coin
description: MARTIN RUSSELL took over a tiny Times Square movie house last year, spending 18 months and $100,000 to convert it into a performance space for poets, actors and musicians. Since he didn't learn carpentry or painting when he studied at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art, he improvised his way through fixing up raw space with sweat equity.

title: Even Though Brunei Has a Few Embarrassments Amid the Asian Crisis : The Sultan's Birthday Party Will Go On
description: BANDAR SERI BEGAWAN, Brunei  Workers in bright orange uniforms scrubbed the streets and sidewalks of this oil-rich town Tuesday, the eve of lavish birthday celebrations for one of the world's richest men.

title: Herb Lessons on a Platter in Vietnam
description: A RECENT trip to Vietnam taught me a great lesson in how to use herbs -- and lots of them. It was a lesson that was, quite literally, handed to me on a platter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENG, DR. LAWRENCE
description: ENG-Dr. Lawrence died on July 11, 1998. Survived by his wife Mei Ling. We will all miss him. Viewing to be held at the Chinese Cheung Sang, 22 Mulberry Street, Chinatown on Friday, July 17, 3PM-8PM. Funeral service Saturday, 10 AM.

title: THE CHEF
description: WHEN I was the chef at Greens, the vegetarian restaurant in San Francisco, we were affiliated with Green Gulch Farm, which was just across the Golden Gate Bridge, in Marin County. I lived at the farm and worked closely with the head gardener, and together we found and grew unusual seeds. As a result, we were able to serve all kinds of exotic vegetables at the restaurant. Although today it's expected that a restaurant of any stature will be working with farmers or even have its own farm, in 1979 this was not the case.

title: Times Web Site Ends Fee for Foreign Users
description: Seeking to expand the popularity of its World Wide Web site outside the United States, The New York Times said yesterday that it had eliminated the fee for access from overseas.

title: CAREMATRIX IN $100 MILLION DEAL FOR SENIORCARE GROUP
description: The Carematrix Corporation, a provider of housing services for the elderly with 1997 sales of $73 million, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Seniorcare Group Ltd. for $100 million in cash. Carematrix, based in Needham, Mass., will also assume $50 million of debt. The acquisition of Seniorcare, owned by the Robert Kaplan family, will add 10 operations with a capacity for 2,100 residents to Carematrix's existing 4,500 units in operation or development in the New York region. Five Seniorcare centers are open on Long Island and one in New Jersey. A seventh will open this month and three are in development. Carematrix currently has 3,600 units in 31 centers nationwide.

title: A Shrinking Europe Is Good for the Rest of Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Unpublished Poems by a Young, Overheated Borges
description: The essays, short stories and poetry of Jorge Luis Borges are an elaborate maze of paradoxes and clues as intriguing as they are ambiguous. If his literature defies easy understanding, so too does his life. He lived as a hermit, toyed with his interviewers and refused to embrace any literary or political doctrine for any sustained period.

title: Twain Rolls On To New Heights; Film Rides a Wave of Interest in the Author
description: Here now in the high noon of fence-whitewashing season, when sivilized people like Becky Thatcher and Aunt Polly might seek refuge in the shade of a porch, comes the latest Imax adventure. It's a colorful, noisy, globe-trotting three-dimensional celebration of -- Mark Twain?

title: More English Instruction Sought for Bilingual Pupils
description: With new graduation standards requiring all high school students to pass a rigorous English examination, state education officials are now proposing longer, more intensive English classes for students with limited English skills.

description: Emboldened by a recent court victory, the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, has issued subpoenas for the testimony of a dozen Secret Service agents for evidence of President Clinton's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky, Administration officials and lawyers involved in the inquiry said today.

description: Earnings Decreased 29% At Intel in Second Quarter

title: Metro Business; New Jersey Sees Fall In Its Jobless Rate
description: Even as unemployment rose nationally in June, New Jersey's jobless rate fell to the lowest point in eight years, 4.8 percent, the State Labor Department said yesterday.

title: Who Will Lead Japan? Kingmakers Will Decide
description: As Japan chooses a new Prime Minister, the procedure somewhat resembles a traditional village market in which hawkers bargain over their wares, in this case their favorite candidates to run the world's second largest economy.

title: The Miracle of Rye; In Germany, and among some here, rye bread is a spiritual thing.
description: IN Germany, I sometimes think, they don't care which side their bread is buttered on, or whether it's buttered at all, as long as it's made from rye.

title: Corrections

It was 1992, not 1993.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, WILLIAM P.
description: WHITE-William P. On July 11, 1998. Loving brother of Ellen White; devoted uncle of Eileen White; dear friend of Lois Dodd and Eli King. Mr. White was a Professor of Art at Jersey City State College. Funeral private. Memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: ALCOA TO CUT $1.1 BILLION BY END OF 2000 WITHOUT LAYOFFS
description: The Aluminum Company of America plans to slash $1.1 billion in costs by the end of 2000, as it tries to increase profit and eliminate overlapping expenses after it buys Alumax Inc. The Pittsburgh-based Alcoa will cut costs by $800 million at its existing businesses and by $300 million at Alumax, which Alcoa agreed to acquire in March for $3.8 billion. Alcoa does not plan any layoffs, according to its chief financial officer, Richard Kelson. The bulk of the savings will come from trimming duplicate overhead at the two companies' primary, or unfinished, aluminum operations. Shares of Alcoa rose $3.25, to $68.625, and Alumax rose $2, to $47.25.

title: BLACK & DECKER IS IN $194 MILLION DEAL WITH BUCHER
description: The Black & Decker Corporation has agreed to sell its glass container making and inspection business for $194 million to Bucher Holdings A.G. of Switzerland. After costs and taxes, the company expects to net $150 million from the sale, which is expected to close in the early fall. Black & Decker, based in Towson, Md., makes tools and small appliances. It had revenue of $1 billion in the quarter ended March 29. Its stock rose $1.3125 a share yesterday, to $65.1875. Bucher, based in Niederweningen, Switzerland, has interests in agribusiness, mechanical engineering and machinery manufacturing. It had 1997 revenue of 1.22 billion Swiss francs ($800 million).

Intrawest bought the 2,400-acre site from Sime Darby of Malaysia. The property is on the Gulf of Mexico midway between Pensacola and Panama City in the Florida panhandle. The acquisition by Intrawest, based in Vancouver, British Columbia, is aimed at smoothing variations in its quarterly earnings. The company generates most of its revenue at winter-sports sites.

It had $49.2 million in sales in 1997. National Vision, based in Lawrenceville, Ga., sells eye-care products. It had sales of $186.4 million in 1997. title: A Will to Suffer Draws Runners to the Desert
description: Lisa R. Smith leads what she calls a ''very ordinary life.'' Here is a glimpse: in the past four months, she ran 150 miles across the Sahara Desert in temperatures of up to 130 degrees, was stung by a scorpion along the way, but kept going and staggered across the finish line with a fever of 103. She slogged 400 miles through the Montana wilderness on a weeklong ''adventure race'' that included white-water kayaking, snowshoeing on glaciers and riding 100 miles on a mountain bike. And she raced 50 miles along the spine of Long Island in 6 hours 43 minutes in a super-marathon, where she won and set a course record.

title: Inside Jefferson's Other House
description: People assume that Monticello was Thomas Jefferson's dream house, but he longed to be at Poplar Forest, near Lynchburg, Va., a quirky octagonal private retreat. ''When finished, it will be the best dwelling house in the state, except for Monticello, perhaps preferable to that, as more proportioned to the faculties of a private citizen,'' Jefferson wrote in 1812. He worked on the interiors until his death in 1826. Exterior restoration has just been completed. Next month, work will begin on the interiors. Visitors may watch, but while the outside is a gem, so far the interior is only bricks waiting for their closeup. Poplar Forest is open Wednesday through Sunday, April through November. Admission is $6 for adults. Information: (804) 525-1806.
