description: An article on Tuesday about the Polish writer Bruno Schulz, whose ''Street of Crocodiles'' will be presented as part of the Lincoln Center Festival '98 in an adaptation by the British company Theatre de Complicite, reversed the publication order of his two books of reminiscences. ''The Street of Crocodiles,'' initially titled ''Cinnamon Shops,'' appeared first, in Poland in 1934. ''The Sanatorium Under the Sign of the Hourglass'' was published in 1937.

title: Home on the Wild West Side: Call It TunJav
description: MEAT trucks growl, shifting their gears as they lumber down the avenues around the Lincoln Tunnel. Empty taxis dash across West 36th Street in a race to the corner Gaseteria. Carriage horses plod home for the night.

title: Judge Asks G.M. and Union to Set Arbitration Date
description: A Federal judge asked General Motors and the United Automobile Workers today to schedule a date for the arbitration of strikes at two auto parts factories here as top negotiators from the auto maker and union talked face to face for the first time in three days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSHEI, BERNARD F., JR.
description: OSHEI-Bernard F., Jr. Air Force veteran, died July 1, 1998. Beloved brother of Robert, Sr., beloved uncle of Mary Elizabeth, William, James, John and Robert, Jr. Stepbrother of Julia. Memorial service to be held at the Community Center, 208 W. 13 St., Sat., July 18, 8PM.

title: New Proposal on Encryption Is Effort to Satisfy Government
description: Yet another encryption-export proposal has landed on the Government's table, this one led by Cisco Systems and including other industry heavyweights like Microsoft, Netscape, Intel and Sun Microsystems.

title: A Double-Edged Scalpel
description: To the Editor:

title: Administration Asks Rehnquist to Bar Secret Service Testimony
description: The Clinton Administration tonight asked Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist to intervene in its battle to keep the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, from forcing Secret Service agents to testify before the grand jury investigating the relationship between President Clinton and a former White House intern, Monica S. Lewinsky, Administration officials said.

title: How Millionaires Get That Way
description: The millionaires next door? To me, Donald and Mildred Othmer the ''unassuming'' Brooklyn couple who recently left a staggering $800 million estate to charity -- were the millionaires in the basement.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREENBERG, SOL
description: GREENBERG-Sol, 10/6/21-7/16/92. ''All I hear now is silence'' Joy

title: Two Picks Are Left After Fullback Signs
description: The Jets, who open camp next Wednesday, were down to two unsigned draft picks after yesterday's agreement with Dustin Johnson, a fullback from Brigham Young who was their sixth-round choice.

title: Festival Review/Theater; Dilemma: Perform or Die
description: The show must go on, even in a death camp. Adam Stein, formerly a Berlin circus star, is ordered to perform for the concentration camp commandant. Told to play a clown, he plays a clown. Ordered to impersonate a dog, he does that, too.

title: The Finance Fracas; Mr. Fossella Goes Astray
description: Representative Vito Fossella of Staten Island got elected to Congress last year with the help of nearly $1 million in ''soft money'' from the Republican National Committee. Soft money flows through a loophole in campaign finance laws that lets political parties collect unregulated contributions from special interests. The grateful Mr. Fossella is now eagerly assisting the Republican House leadership in its effort to scuttle any serious campaign finance reform. The parties want to continue raking in money from tobacco, casinos and other industries in need of political favors, and recycling the money into issue ads for their candidates this fall. But principled Republicans have united with Democrats to press for a fair vote on a campaign finance reform bill now pending before the House.

title: 'Ordinary Girl,' Until She Enters the Water
description: ''NOBODY recognizes me with my clothes on'' is a statement few people get to make with plausibility and a straight face.

title: Arts Abroad; A South African Festival Makes Fusion Its Focus
description: Africa's premier arts festival, 24 years old this year, is having a little trouble defining itself.

title: In Lasting Debate Over City Budget, Monetary and Political Capital Are Discussed Again
description: Laying the groundwork for a lawsuit against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the City Council heard testimony yesterday from budget experts who said the city had far more money than the Mayor anticipated in his budget plan.

title: Congressional Roundup; Census Money Held Up In Battle Over Methods
description: The House Appropriations Committee today approved only half the money the Census Bureau needs to prepare for the 2000 census, withholding the rest until Congress and the White House agreed on how best to count the nation's population.

title: Why Can't Science and Religion Just Get Along?
description: To the Editor:

title: Here's the Pitch: Yanks Have Best Starters
description: On the nights he doesn't pitch, Orlando Hernandez sits outside one end of the Yankees' dugout, his cap pulled low, his eyes watching everything carefully, like a sheep dog monitoring the flock. David Cone often stands in a corner of the dugout, overseeing the mound, particularly when Hernandez pitches. David Wells retreats to the clubhouse to watch Andy Pettitte, the other left-handed starter, on a big-screen television.

title: Essay; Hell Freezes Over
description: Attorney General Janet Reno told the Senate Judiciary Committee's Arlen Specter yesterday she was prepared to take -- and in reality evade -- his questions about Chinese penetration of the White House ''until hell freezes over.''

title: For Journalists, Navel-Gazing Is a Healthy Habit; Computers Can Do It
description: To the Editor:

title: Congress Is the Real Villain on Campaign Finance; On Sex, Out of Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Congress Is the Real Villain on Campaign Finance; End the Circus Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Value of U.S. Mergers Tops $1 Trillion
description: Domestic merger and acquisition volume topped $1 trillion for the year yesterday, shattering last year's record and moving quickly toward the $2 trillion projected for 1998, according to the Securities Data Company, which tracks merger activity.

title: People
description: * Daniel Morel was named to the new position of chief executive for the marketing services network of Euro RSCG Worldwide, New York, part of Havas Advertising. He had been senior vice president and worldwide director at Blau Marketing Technologies, Wilton, Conn., part of Snyder Communications.

title: Corrections
description: A book review of Charles Mc Carry's novel ''Lucky Bastard'' on Monday misstated the year of the Hungarian uprising against Soviet domination. It was 1956, not 1955.

title: POINTCAST WITHDRAWS PLAN FOR PUBLIC STOCK OFFERING
description: Pointcast, the leading purveyor of ''push'' technology, which delivers World Wide Web information to consumers rather than forcing them to forage through the Web to find it, said yesterday that it had withdrawn its planned initial public stock offering to pursue a possible sale of the company or another venture. Pointcast offers users free software that downloads news and advertising from the Internet and displays it on their computers. David W. Dorman, the chief executive, said Pointcast had developed new software that combines news, electronic mail and shopping opportunities and is of interest to companies racing to become the portal -- or front door -- for Internet users. He declined to say which companies the concern was negotiating with.

title: Battle Lines on Patients' Rights
description: Congress is under heavy pressure to pass legislation governing the operation of health maintenance organizations. Doctors have been telling patients they are being restricted in giving care. Patients believe that insurance bureaucrats are making medical decisions once reserved for physicians. That is why Republicans and Democrats in the Senate are vying to pass a patients' rights bill before everyone becomes totally absorbed in the midterm elections. The competing versions share some common ground, but the Republican plan has a flawed design. It tries to placate consumer unhappiness while causing as little inconvenience as possible for the insurance companies.

title: It's Time to Shrink The Big Software Box
description: AMERICANS are used to big boxes packed with cereal or cookies, but mostly with air. But it's a surprise to see the same packaging strategy from the computer industry, which constantly boasts of miracles of compression -- of laptops seven-tenths of an inch thin, multiple megabytes squeezed onto tiny disks and digital assistants the size of a Saltine.

title: Congress Is the Real Villain on Campaign Finance; Money Better Spent
description: To the Editor:

title: Congress Is the Real Villain on Campaign Finance; Tripp's Co-Conspirator
description: To the Editor:

title: Dubuque Journal; Hear Ye! 'Come Back to Your Future.'
description: From the porch views of the Victorian-era houses high on the limestone bluffs above the Mississippi River, it looked like a sad parade on the streets of Dubuque in the 80's, an exodus of downhearted Iowans fleeing the farm-crisis economy.

title: Apple Earnings Again Exceed Expectations
description: Confounding the skeptics yet again, a resurgent Apple Computer Inc. exceeded earnings estimates made by Wall Street analysts for the third consecutive quarter today. Apple said it had sold a record number of its G3 Macintosh computers and that profit margins improved in the quarter.

title: Spartan Chic From Europe to SoHo
description: Portico Home is adapting European Minimalism to American tastes. ''We wanted to offer a look with a midcentury modern feeling that's sleeker and cleaner than you might find at a Crate and Barrel,'' said Christiane Lemieux, Portico's creative director. The company's Richelieu chaise, below ($2,020), went on sale this month; more pieces are due next month. Portico has borrowed ideas from hip outlets like Wallpaper magazine and the Mercer Hotel. The Christophe chair ($2,300) and foot bench, right ($1,250), owe a debt to Christian Liaigre. But Ms. Lemieux said, ''We've done our own reinterpretations.'' Portico Home is at 72 Spring Street.

title: Invitation Brings Bouton To Tears
description: When Jim Bouton received a call today from someone claiming to be with the Yankees, he was sure it was a friend playing a joke. ''O.K., who is this?'' he said.

title: Once Held in Servitude, 13 Mexicans Go Home
description: As some of them raised the two-fingered sign that to them means ''Hello, I'm O.K.,'' and as others simply looked dazed and uncertain, 13 deaf Mexican men and women, along with four babies born to them while they were in the United States, returned to Mexico today for the first time since they were discovered living in virtual slavery a year ago.

title: U.S. to Investigate Electricity Price Run-Up
description: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, the agency that oversees the utility industry, said yesterday that it would investigate the huge run-up in the price for electricity on the wholesale market in which some Midwest utilities had to buy large amounts of power to get through a heat wave and disruptions caused by storms.

title: Festival Review; Honoring Bernstein And His American Roots
description: The heart of the New York Philharmonic's concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday evening were the words of Jeremiah, set to music by Leonard Bernstein, but the program itself also evoked another prophet, Ezekiel, and his vision of a wheel within a wheel. The concert was the second of two in which the Philharmonic remembers Bernstein by revisiting works of his own as well as works by composers with whom he was closely associated. But it is also part of a broader Bernstein celebration that includes the Hamburg Ballet's ''Bernstein Dances'' (the last performance is on Saturday), concerts of chamber rarities (on Monday) and works by Bernstein with literary connections (next Thursday). All this, in turn, is part of Lincoln Center Festival '98.

title: Japan Brokerage Firms Have Sluggish Quarter
description: Earnings at two of Japan's Big Three securities firms -- Nomura Securities and Daiwa Securities declined for the first quarter of the current fiscal year. The third, Nikko Securities, reported a loss. A sluggish stock market and partial liberalization of commission fees hurt the brokerage firms' results.

title: Union and Owners Discuss Plan For an International Expansion
description: The 2000 Olympics and a World Cup type of baseball tournament were among the topics discussed yesterday at an unusual meeting between union officials and owners. No decisions were made, but the meeting was significant because it was the formal beginning of a joint effort to expand baseball internationally.

title: Morgan, Anderson To Split Itself in Two
description: Morgan, Anderson & Company in New York, which specializes in marketing communications consulting and agency searches for advertisers, said yesterday that after 13 years in business, it would now be restructured as two independent companies, each to be led by a principal of Morgan, Anderson.

title: In America; A Long-Running Betrayal
description: A teen-ager, concocting a lie and hoping to make it convincing, smears feces on herself, scrawls racial slurs on her body and crawls half-naked into a filthy garbage bag. She does this outdoors in the cold of November. Her story is that a gang of white men abducted and raped her.

title: Train New Teachers, Don't Import Them
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P., IN SWITCH, BACKS MORE FUNDS TO SHORE UP I.M.F.
description: House Republicans took the first step today toward approving all of the added money requested for the International Monetary Fund, out of concern that the economic crises overseas might spread to the United States.

title: Panel Says U.S. Faces Risk Of a Surprise Missile Attack
description: Rogue nations could develop and deploy ballistic missiles for an attack against the United States with ''little or no warning,'' an independent commission announced today.

title: Editorial Observer; Russia Finds No Peace in Burying Its Last Czar
description: The Romanovs are making a comeback of sorts in Russia these days. For a small fee, visitors to Red Square can have their picture taken with a lookalike of Nicholas II. Across town, a gigantic statue of Peter the Great towers over the Moscow River. It seems an odd monument for the city Peter abandoned in favor of a new northern capital on the Baltic.

title: World Bank Suspends 3 Employees for Suspected Kickbacks
description: The World Bank, which lends billions of dollars a year for development projects in poor countries, is investigating possible kickbacks and other wrongdoing by at least three bank employees, bank officials said tonight.

title: Guides to Unfamiliar Rivers
description: FLYWATER INTERACTIVE

title: INSIDE
description: Panel Sees Missile Threats Multiply

title: It's an Easel, It's a Lectern (It Hides Books)
description: Highbrow collectors once hung art from bookcases suspended jauntily with big thick ribbons and wire. That inspired the Manhattan architect Robert Kahn to make a bookshelf easel. ''I like to do modern versions of older ideas,'' Mr. Kahn said. He designed a stand for frames or large books that can be clamped to bookshelves from one-quarter inch to one and a half inches thick. Made of hand-cut aluminum with a suedelike finish that doesn't show fingerprints, the easel costs around $675 through Mr. Kahn, (212) 473-0098, or at Shi, 233 Elizabeth Street, (212) 334-4330.

title: Ex-Officer Is Accused Of Robbing Drug Suspect
description: A former Newark police officer was charged by Federal agents yesterday with stealing $600 from a suspected drug dealer in January, and officials said up to seven other officers may have been involved in similar shakedowns.

title: The Slip and Slide Of Summer Floors
description: BLISS is having a summer rug that is impervious to wet feet, pets and sand. Want a washable, wipable, virtually indestructible rug? Here are six to choose from -- each without loops, pile or fuzz.

title: PLUS: TENNIS -- A.&P. classic; Kournikova to Skip Tournament
description: Citing the same thumb injury that forced her out of a tournament in England last month, Anna Kournikova withdrew last night from today's scheduled match with Jana Novotna at the A.&P. Tennis Classic in Mahwah, N.J.

title: High-Powered Charlotte Defeats Liberty Again
description: The Liberty played much better basketball tonight than in some of its recent losses. Sophia Witherspoon scored 17 points and Kym Hampton pulled down 12 rebounds, but for the slumping Liberty, better was not enough. The Charlotte Sting, playing without three of its key players, was still able to capitalize when it counted and won, 72-65, to extend its lead in the Eastern Conference of the Women's National Basketball Association to four and a half games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALMER, MARGE
description: PALMER-Marge. The Temple Israel of Long Beach Family marks with profound sorrow the passing of Marge Palmer, past president of Sisterhood and beloved friend. Our heartfelt sympathies to her husband, children, brother, and entire family. Mark I. Samuels, Bruce Sklover, Co-Presidents Marcia Kaskel, Sisterhood President Jacob Chiger, Rabbi

title: OLSTEN TO BUY BACK 4 MILLION SHARES AND CUT DIVIDEND
description: The Olsten Corporation, the largest provider of home health-care services in North America, said that it would buy back as many as 4 million, or about 5 percent, of its common shares outstanding and that it planned to cut its quarterly dividend payment by 43 percent. Olsten, in Melville, N.Y., is reorganizing its home-health business and has forecast a second-quarter loss. On Tuesday it agreed to buy the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation's home-health operations in Florida for $34 million. The company also provides staffing for industries other than health care. Its shares gained 43.75 cents, to $9.9375.

title: Banderas Quits Ataturk Film After Protests
description: Debate over the political legacy of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, the founder of modern Turkey, has upset plans for a film about him that was to have starred Antonio Banderas.

title: Congress Is the Real Villain on Campaign Finance; Give Starr a Break
description: To the Editor:

title: Pounding From Braves Puts Mets in Their Place: Buried
description: After winning a surprising 88 games last year, the Mets came into this season believing they could finally challenge the Atlanta Braves in the National League East. On May 31, fresh off their biggest trade in more than a decade and after winning their ninth straight game, the Mets -- bolstered by the addition of Mike Piazza -- trailed the Braves by just five games.

title: Price-Fixing Trial Begins For 3 Ex-Archer Officials
description: In opening arguments in one of the largest price-fixing trials ever, a Federal prosecutor said today that former senior executives with the Archer Daniels Midland Company ''were caught red-handed'' on secret recordings conspiring with competitors to set the market prices for a popular feed additive.

title: A Uganda Tribe Fights Genital Cutting
description: For the Sabiny people of eastern Uganda, 1998 is a circumcision year -- as are all even years -- when girls as well as boys would normally be expected to endure a painful rite of passage to young adulthood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIR, HENRY J.
description: LEIR-Henry J. Beloved husband of the late Erna D. Leir, died on July 15, 1998 at the grand age of 98. Henry J. Leir founded businesses in many countries. He began in his homeland in Germany at a very young age. He took refuge in Luxembourg in 1932, and has been a generous contributor to the commerce and charities of that country ever since. He foresaw the coming war and came to the US in 1938 and created businesses here which became international in scope. He generously shared his financial success and acumen with business associates, his family and friends, and with a long list of charitable organizations. He is survived by his devoted sister, Hedy Wegier. Services to be held on Friday, 10:00AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Metro Business; Washington Partner For a New York Firm
description: The New York law firm Shereff, Friedman, Hoffman & Goodman announced yesterday that it would merge with a Washington firm, Swidler & Berlin.

title: Ford's Operating Profit Up 6.7%, Beating Expectations
description: The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that its operating profit rose 6.7 percent in the second quarter, easily surpassing Wall Street estimates despite a decline in worldwide car and truck sales.

title: Congressional Roundup; House Dares Clinton on Abortion Bill
description: Daring President Clinton to cast an election-year veto on a sensitive issue, the House of Representatives voted today to make it a Federal crime for an adult to take a minor to another state for an abortion to avoid a parental-consent law in the girl's home state.

title: Congress Is the Real Villain on Campaign Finance; Money as Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Videoconferencing's Killer App May Be Sex
description: VIDEOPHONES add a new dimension of anxiety to the familiar problem of the phone ringing while you are in the bathtub. It turns out, however, that thousands of people actually look forward to video calls while they, and their callers, are undressed.

title: To Richter, Right Place To Be Is With Rangers
description: After all of the posturing and hard-line negotiating tactics, it took a face-to-face meeting between Mike Richter and Neil Smith on Monday for both to realize that New York was where Richter belonged.

title: Jump-Start From Windows 98 For the Universal Serial Bus
description: The Universal Serial Bus has finally pulled into the station, pushed along by the release of Windows 98.

title: Winds at British Open Heighten the Challenge
description: As a five-time British Open champion, Tom Watson knows a thing or two about the world's oldest major. So when asked to name the three most important ingredients for a British Open champion, Watson did not hesitate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSCHILD, BESSIE N.
description: ROTHSCHILD-Bessie N. 100 years old. Died July 14 at her home. Devoted mother of Barbara and Richard. Beloved grandmother of Jim and Jan Fogel; Lynn, Gail, Emily, Kate and Richard Rothschild. She is also survived by eight great-grandchildren. She founded in the 1940s, and was the first director of, the Council of Jewish Women's Ship-a-Box Program for children in Europe separated from their families and which continues as the Yad B'ad program for children in Israel. She was a member of the Clara de Hirsch Residence and, when it merged with the 92nd Street Y in 1962 was from then on a member of the Y Board. Funeral private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the 92nd Street Y or to the Yad B'ad program, NCJW, 53 W. 23rd St, NY, NY 10010.

title: Richard McDonald, 89, Fast-Food Revolutionary
description: Richard McDonald, who with his brother Maurice revolutionized the way that billions of people around the world eat in fast-food restaurants, died on Tuesday at a nursing home in Manchester, N.H. He was 89 and lived in nearby Bedford, N.H.

title: At Sloan-Kettering, an Unexpected Emergency
description: Patients arriving for cancer treatments at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center had to park several blocks away because they could not get around traffic barricades. Researchers and hospital administrators endured suffocating heat so that bedridden patients could have air-conditioning. Doctors' appointments were canceled, as were surgical procedures. Medical records were inaccessible.

title: Competing, Perfectly in Sync, Across Gender Gap
description: It was one of the memorable moments of television comedy: Martin Short on ''Saturday Night Live'' as a synchronized swimmer, an uncoordinated man with a silly fixed grin trying to crash a women's sport.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, KITTY
description: MILLER-Kitty. On July 14, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Murray. Loving mother of Paul and Jay. Adoring grandmother, greatgrandmother and aunt. Services are on Thursday, at 12:15 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Why Can't Science and Religion Just Get Along?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Double-Edged Scalpel
description: To the Editor:

title: Cold War Over, Air Force Must Compete for Space
description: As it scrambles to find new or expanded places to train fighter and bomber pilots, the Air Force is running into intensifying opposition from ranchers, environmentalists, sportsmen and American Indians who believe that the roar of low-flying jets is disrupting some of the nation's last refuges of peace and quiet.

title: Search for Widow Moves To the Area's 3 Airports
description: Law enforcement officials scoured the three New York metropolitan airports and parts of northern New Jersey yesterday in their search for Irene Silverman, the 82-year-old widow who vanished 11 days ago, but Police Commissioner Howard Safir said investigators had found no hints of her whereabouts.

title: Rape Cases Shake Up The Army In Canada
description: When Judith M. Taylor of Toronto marched into a recruiting station last month to enlist in the Canadian Army, she simply ignored a flurry of recent news reports that women in the army had been sexually harassed and even raped by fellow soldiers.

title: Sorenstam Aims to Push Pak Off Spotlight
description: Coming into the JAL Big Apple Classic, which begins here on Thursday, Annika Sorenstam has found out what a difference two weeks can make on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour.

title: For Journalists, Navel-Gazing Is a Healthy Habit
description: To the Editor:

title: Free to Grow Bluebells in England
description: LEAVING behind their confines for a temporary stay in the open air, seven prisoners from Her Majesty's Prison Leyhill in the Cotswolds won their second gold medal last week at the Hampton Court Palace Flower Show, the Royal Horticultural Society's summer extravaganza. Their show garden, ''Take a Walk on the Wild Side,'' included a woodland garden of wildflowers and grasses under linden and beech trees, with a stream flowing under a stone bridge.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about theories on the end of the universe misstated the name of the institute in Princeton, N.J., with which Dr. Frank Wilczek, a physicist, is affiliated. It is the Institute for Advanced Study, not the Institute of Advanced Studies.

title: Drop the '48-Hour Rule'
description: The perception that police officers are above the law erodes confidence in the entire criminal justice system. The Giuliani administration and the police sergeants' union took an important step toward repairing public confidence when they agreed in principle to discard a rule allowing New York City officers involved in shootings to wait two days before answering investigators' questions. The rank and file in the sergeants' union have yet to vote on giving up the so-called ''48-hour rule.'' But the time has long passed for all the police unions to surrender this special and unreasonable right.

title: Water Main Rupture Floods Streets and Disrupts Hospitals
description: A loose cap blew off a water main on Manhattan's Upper East Side yesterday, opening up a gaping sinkhole, sending water surging through the streets, shutting the nearby Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive for several hours and disrupting operations at some of the city's most prestigious hospitals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAZZEO, JOSEPH A.
description: MAZZEO-Joseph A. July 6, 1998. Beloved husband of Lucy (Welch). Also survived by his sisters, Mary Rinaldi, Mae Scolaro and Lauretta Korothy, and uncle of many nieces and nephews. Avalon Foundation Professor Emeritus in the Humanities of the Department of English & Comparative Literature at Columbia University. A Memorial service to be held at Westend Collegiate Church, 368 West End Avenue, New York City, Friday, July 17th, at 11 AM.

title: Subway Station to Be Renovated, Keeping Pace With Times Square
description: The Times Square subway station -- a bewildering snarl of grime-encrusted tunnels that is the neglected basement of what has become the city's most animated neighborhood -- is finally about to receive the renovation that has been promised for decades.

title: Time Warner Profits Surge; Stock Closes at 52-Week High
description: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that second-quarter net earnings more than tripled on the improved strength of its cable television operations, magazine advertising and Warner Brothers studios.

title: Compaq Reports Loss Following Acquisition
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation reported a second-quarter loss of $3.63 billion yesterday, resulting largely from its acquisition of the Digital Equipment Corporation. But Compaq eked out a tiny operating profit that beat analysts' expectations of a break-even quarter.

title: New and Future Missile Threats
description: Since the end of the cold war, Americans have not had to worry much about a missile attack on the United States. This week a bipartisan commission concluded that North Korea, Iran and Iraq could obtain long-range missiles significantly sooner, and with far less warning, than current intelligence analyses project. The commission's view deserves serious consideration. But it should not set off a scramble to mount a new, nationwide missile defense system, as many Republicans now advocate.

title: Congress Is the Real Villain on Campaign Finance; New Praetorian Guard
description: To the Editor:

title: Profit Up 35% at American Airlines' Parent
description: The AMR Corporation said today that its second-quarter profit rose 35 percent because of more passengers and lower fuel prices for its American Airlines unit, the second-biggest carrier in the United States.

title: Hincapie Can't Trade Red, White, Blue for Yellow
description: A few Americans' hearts were broken today on the D1 two-lane road at a spot marked by a green banner just outside the village of Plumelec in western France.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEIGEN, MAE
description: ZEIGEN-Mae. Beloved wife of the late Reuben. Adored mother of Mort and Irma Zeigen, and Evelyn and Marvin Kucker. Devoted grandmother of Debra Liebo, Susan Peyser, Gary Marshall, Peggy Thompson and Robert Zeigen. Also survived by eight great grandchildren. Services today at 10 A.M., at ''Parkside Memorial Chapels'', 2576 Flatbush Avenue, corner Avenue V, Brooklyn.

title: It's Official: '60 Minutes' Gets Double
description: CBS made it official today: ''60 Minutes,'' the oldest and most successful news program in the history of television, will expand to a second edition early next year.

title: Anticancer Agent Appears To Add to Radiation's Effect
description: Tests of a promising anticancer agent known as angiostatin have shown that it enhances the effects of radiation in treating human tumors grafted into mice.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LOBENFELD, RUTH
description: LOBENFELD-Ruth. It's 12 years, Babe. You're still the one and only. Love, Your Honey

title: Teaching The Computer To Do the Wave
description: Toshiba is developing a motion processor that can import three-dimensional images into a computer in real time, at a rate of 30 to 50 frames per second. The company says the product, which will be available in two years, will enable computers to respond to hand movements and could ultimately be used for gesture-based commands for people who have trouble using keyboards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESS, STEPHEN R.
description: HESS-Stephen R. Suddenly on July 14th, 1998 in Lenox, MA. Lifetime resident of New York City. Loving son of the late Leonard and Ruth Hess. Devoted brother of Katherine A. Hess. Special friend of Diane Dickinson. Beloved friend of so many others. Friends may call Thursday evening July 16th from 7-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St with service Friday, 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Stephen Hess Pediatric Social Enhancement Fund, c/o Lenox Hill Hospital, 100 East 77th St., NY NY 10021.

title: Galarraga Puts On Show of Power
description: Chipper Jones was leading off first base when Andres Galarraga connected with a Bill Pulsipher fastball yesterday in the fourth inning. The ball was clearly a home run as soon as he hit it, and to be professional, Jones did not watch the flight of the ball. He simply tucked his head down and trotted around the bases.

title: Jersey City Library to Get Private Management
description: In a move unprecedented in the region, the trustees of the Jersey City Public Library voted Tuesday night to turn over management of the library, the state's second largest, to a private operator.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLADSTONE, BERNARD
description: GLADSTONE - Bernard. Your love, values, humor and spirit are with us always. Services on July 17 at 1:30 at the Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel at 152 2nd Avenue.

title: Orange Protesters Evicted From Encampment
description: The police and British troops evicted unionist protesters and confiscated weaponry today from the hillside next to the Drumcree Protestant church that has been the flash point for the violence across Northern Ireland in the last two weeks.

title: Senate Votes to Lift Most Remaining India-Pakistan Penalties
description: The Senate unanimously agreed today to give President Clinton authority to temporarily waive most remaining economic sanctions on India and Pakistan.

title: Festival Review/Dance; War's Sorrow And the Joy Of Freedom
description: The Hamburg Ballet from Germany, which made its Manhattan debut on Tuesday night with a crop of striking young dancers as part of Lincoln Center Festival '98, is essentially a creative outlet for its American director, John Neumeier.

title: The More Trophies, The Less the Glory
description: AS the final match of the 16th World Cup was being played out in France on Sunday, a full third of the planet's population tuned in to witness the host nation's surprising capture of the most coveted trophy in the world: a thick, drippy, solid-18-karat-gold abstraction of two Atlaslike athletes shrugging the globe.

title: For Journalists, Navel-Gazing Is a Healthy Habit; Edges Are Blurred

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OFFENHARTZ, HARRY DONALD
description: OFFENHARTZ - Harry Donald. President of the New Heritage Music Foundation, died on July 13, 1998 from complications of congestive heart failure. He was 93 and lived in Manhattan. Called the ''last New Dealer'' by the NY Daily News, he was a Project Administrator for the WPA during the Roosevelt administration and later worked for Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, creating low cost housing in rural areas. He served in the Navy during World War I (lying about his age), and joined the Army in 1943 for World War II (this time lying about his age in the other direction). On May 18, 1935 he married Eilen Marie O'Donnell, their 62 year marriage ending when she died in a fire in their apartment in December, 1996. In 1995 he founded the New Heritage Music Foundation, which has been commissioning a series of new orchestral pieces to honor his heroes from the New Deal, as well as John F. Kennedy and Thomas Jefferson. The concert series will premiere on September 11 in Charlottesville, Virginia & continue at major locations across the country. A lifelong liberal Democrat, a founder and national Chair of the New Democratic Coalition, a supporter of women's rights, and a card carrying member of the ACLU, he was a Democratic Party activist and fundraiser. Harry is survived by his three sons: Peter of Wellesley, MA; Colin of Chappaqua, NY and Douglas of Walnut Creek, CA; his sisters; Billie Raphael of Sunrise, FL., & Yetta Horowitz of Brooklyn, by five grandchildren and one great grandson. Memorial contributions may be made to the Northern Westchester Shelter, PO Box 203, Pleasantville, NY 10570 or to My Sister's Place, 2 Lyon Place, Suite 300, White Plains, NY 10601. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: The Encore as a Second Chance

In his other choices -- Szymanowski's ''Metopes'' and Bartok's Bagatelles Opus 6 -- he perhaps was honoring his mixed Polish-Hungarian background, but if so, he sounded much more Hungarian than Polish. Or perhaps the problem with Szymanow ski's images from ''The Odyssey'' was simply one of scale. Mr. Anderszewski's sound is big, though at the same time tightly executed. In a large hall he could make that bigness work in Szymanowski's behalf, but here, for all the care and color of his playing, the music's rhetoric seemed empty. description: The two top executives at J&A Securities have relinquished control of the brokerage firm -- one of China's largest -- and are being questioned by central Government authorities over their personal financial dealings, company officials and securities regulators said yesterday. Zhang Guoqing, the brokerage's chairman, and Yang Jun, the president, have handed management control of the firm over to two senior-level managers. News that the company's two top officials had been detained has riveted China's stock markets for the last two days.

title: Investigators Say They May Never Find the Cause Of T.W.A. Blast
description: Two years after the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, the National Transportation Safety Board is moving toward finishing its investigation without knowing the source of the spark that touched off the explosion that destroyed the Boeing 747.

title: Tranquillity Inside an Eruption of Color
description: AS plots go, it is pure Barbara Cartland. Friends arrange a blind date between a model (J. Crew, Victoria's Secret) and a telegenic swain (''The Today Show''). The expected chemistry fizzles. The intended part amicably, only to give romance another chance a few days later. Today, a year after their disastrous first date, there is a pear-shaped diamond the size of a small almond on Annette Roque's left hand, compliments of Matt Lauer.

title: Observer; This Side of Outrage
description: Mr. Wisdom answers his mail:

title: For Imperial-Size Splashes
description: Spaced between solid tiles, pictorial tile murals catch the eye. From Rosan Imports of Chatham, N.J., comes a tile made to look like an ancient mosaic. Natural-color stones come pieced together with limestone to make Vegetable Basket, an 18-by-24-inch backsplash, for $832. To order, (973) 701-7350.

title: A Sea and Sun Vacation For Your Trusty Laptop
description: Q. I'm taking my laptop computer to the beach for a month. Do I need to worry about damage from the salt air?

description: HUGHES-Nelida. Widow of John A. Hughes. Died June 22, 1998 in Buenos Aires, Argentina. Memorial Mass will be celebrated Sat, July 18, 1998, 5:30PM at Saint Elizabeth Seaton Chapel, Saint Vincent's Hospital, W. 12th St, NYC

title: Metro Matters; Can You Judge A Sex Shop By Its Videos?
description: THERE'S a big question about female wrestling movies.

title: Council Panel Backs Letting Theaters Sell Air Rights
description: Amid fractious negotiations with the theater industry, property owners and residents of the Clinton neighborhood, a City Council committee yesterday scaled back, but then approved, a plan to allow the sale of air rights from theaters in the area around Times Square.

title: Congressional Roundup; Higher Surplus Estimate Stirs G.O.P. Tax Cutters
description: The Congressional Budget Office today more than doubled its estimate of the Federal budget surplus over the next decade, emboldening Republicans who want to use some of the money for tax cuts despite President Clinton's insistence that it all be set aside until Social Security's financial problems are solved.

title: Charter Panel's Mayoral Misery Tour; Giuliani Tactic Draws Eccentricity and Anger in 5 Boroughs
description: One speaker demanded that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani be impeached immediately. Others delivered heartfelt pleas for justice on behalf of persecuted artists, parents caught in custody battles, and their own peculiar travails. And there was the man who, for no apparent reason, shared a long-ago letter from Mother Teresa that thanked him for his devotion to the poor.

title: 3 Supervisors on Suspension After Leak at Sewage Plant
description: Three supervisors at a sewage treatment plant in Yonkers run by Westchester County remained suspended without pay today after 122 million gallons of waste water that had not been disinfected were released into the Hudson River on Sunday and Monday, Andrew J. Spano, the County Executive, said today. The workers will remain suspended awaiting the outcome of an investigation into why they did not alert senior officials or use backup procedures to treat the water.

title: Congress Is the Real Villain on Campaign Finance; Political Witch Hunt
description: To the Editor:

title: Down These Midstreets Traffic Must Flow
description: In Times Square, it's like V-J Day all over again every Wednesday, matinee day, at noon, when more than 7,000 pedestrians throng the theater district. Streets are hopping at night, too, especially in front of the Virgin Mega Store (Broadway and 45th Street). The Times Square Business Improvement District commissioned a survey of foot traffic. ''We were stunned by the sheer number of folks walking around,'' said Gretchen Dykstra, president of the organization. And when the Conde Nast and Reuters buildings open, as many as 16,000 working people will be added.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, AUDREY R.
description: BERMAN-Audrey R., 69. Of Allentown, PA., died Tuesday, July 14, in her home. She was the wife of Bernard Berman. They celebrated their 48th wedding anniversary last March. Born in Hazleton, PA she was the daughter of the late Harry and Helen (Biederman) Roman. She received her Bachelor of Arts from Cornell University, Ithaca, NY in 1950. She was a life member of the Arts College Advisory Board and a past member of the Arts College Administrative Board both of Cornell University. She was a member of Congregation Keneseth Israel 2227 Chew St. Allentown, PA., and a life member of its Sisterhood. She was a life member of Hadassah. She was a founding member of Society of the Arts of the Allentown Art Museum and received its volunteer of the year award in 1965. She was an active member of the Allentown Art Museum. She was the founder and administrative manager of Cooking In Florence, Florence, Italy. She attained the level of Dame d' Escoffier from the Escoffier French food and wine society. Surviving besides her husband are two daughters: Ann Berman wife of Sam Spektor of Cambridge, MA and Eileen wife of Roberto Fischmann of Allentown, PA and 3 granddaughters. Services 11:00 AM today in the synagogue. There are no calling hours. Interment Keneseth Israel Cemetery Allentown, PA. In lieu of flowers contributions to: Allentown Art Museum 5th &Court Sts. P.O. Box 388, Allentown, PA 18105 or The John & Dorothy Morgan Cancer Center, Lehigh Valley Hospital, P.O. Box 689 Allentown, PA 18105-1556. Info: J.S. Burkholder Funeral Home, Inc. Allentown, PA.

title: Videophones Evolve, Slowly
description: THE 1996 comedy ''Mother'' may be one of the only films to have a running joke about videophones. In the movie, a 30-something sports agent played by Rob Morrow tries to foster family unity by handing out the gadgets to his closest relatives. His brother, played by Albert Brooks, refuses even to unpack his, but the title character, played by Debbie Reynolds, gamely does her best. But despite all the instructions from her son and all the contortions she goes through, she can manage to send only a fuzzy picture of her neck or headless torso. ''I told him I like this,'' the mother confesses, ''but it's driving me crazy.''

title: Kremlin Asks Legislators to Adopt Economic Package
description: With billions in Western loans at stake, the Russian Government urged the lower house of Parliament today to pass a package of tax, budget and economic measures, the strings lenders have attached to any additional money.

description: Cable and Wireless P.L.C. of Britain said yesterday, as expected, that it had agreed to acquire the MCI Communications Corporation's Internet business for $1.75 billion.

title: Survey Finds TV Is Major Casualty of Net Surfing
description: MOST of us know that Internet use is up. But what is down?

description: KASSMAN-Milton. On July 15, 1998 at age seventy-three. Beloved wife of Natalie. Loving children Lisa, Fredric, and Ian. Cherished grandchildren Rafael, Maya, and Talia. Services will be held at 1PM today at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

description: YOUNG-William. Of Duxbury, MA. July 14, William C. 86. Beloved husband of Margaret E. (Klotz) of for 58 years. Father of Peter M. of Birmingham, AL, Margaret C. Robb of Summit, NJ, W. Mason of Manomet & John Sacret of Santa Monica, CA. He leaves 9 grandchildren, 2 brothers and 3 sisters. Services will be held Saturday, 11 AM, at St. John the Evangelist Episcopal Church in Duxbury. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Manomet Center for Conservation Sciences, P.O. Box 1770, Manomet, MA. 02345, or to the charity of your choice.

title: Prosecutor Drops Charges In Case of Infant's Death
description: A young Brooklyn mother arrested in May on charges of inadvertently starving to death her baby, whom she was breast-feeding, will not be prosecuted after all, the Brooklyn District Attorney, Charles J. Hynes, said yesterday.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: HIGHER MARK. The mark rose after lawmakers in Russia, which relies heavily on German trade and investment, approved some parts of a plan to qualify for international aid. In New York the dollar fell to 1.7937 marks from 1.8043.

title: Rome Journal; Religion's in Vogue, and the Vatican Is Scandalized
description: All fashion feeds on the new and the shocking -- and Italian fashion even more than most. But in a world inured to political scandal, nudity, profanity, sexual flamboyance and celebrities' eternal falls from grace, there are very few taboos left to break.

title: Police Talk to Coach of Festina in Drug Case
description: The management of the Festina bicycle racing team, under increasing pressure in a doping controversy in the Tour de France, announced today that the head of the team was being questioned by the French police.

title: Accounts
description: * Ateeco Inc., Shenandoah, Pa., to Avrett, Free & Ginsberg, New York, to handle advertising for Mrs. T's Pierogies, which had been handled by Greene & Co., Bethlehem, Pa. Billings were estimated at $3 million to $5 million.

title: Waiting on the Weather
description: Insufferable heat has stalled over the South and Southwest, taking out most of the Texas cotton crop and killing 16 people in Dallas alone, 20 more in Louisiana. Oklahoma and Georgia have declared agricultural disasters, and crops are faring little better in South Carolina. The torrid heat, which began late last month -- literally burning its way across central and northern Florida -- has now worked into New Mexico and Arizona. The high and low temperature forecast in Phoenix for the next five days looks like a lopsided N.B.A. score: 115-88.

title: On My Mind; The War Against Bibi
description: On May 31, 1996, Benjamin Netanyahu was elected Prime Minister of Israel, the first to be chosen by direct vote. On that same day most of the world's governments began a political war to destroy him.

title: Denied Discount for Pool, Gay Pair to Press Fight
description: The gay couple who spurred a controversy by asking for the family discount at town-owned pools said they would continue to lobby for a change in the policy, despite the Town Council's decision Tuesday night to turn them down for the second time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSHOWITZ, LOUIS
description: GERSHOWITZ-Louis. It is with profound sorrow that the Officers, Board of Trustees and members of The City Club of New York record the passing of our esteemed member. Our deepest condolences to his wife Charlotte and the family.

title: Sports of the Times; More, More Galleries Follow Pak
description: DURING the hazy, humid morning, the legions following Se Ri Pak up and down and across Wykagyl Country Club's hills had increased from about 200 on the first tee to maybe 500, and now, as golf's latest wonder woman strode up the ninth fairway, an Asian man pointed to another 500 spectators framing the green.

title: In Connecticut, Where Caravaggio First Landed
description: Modern and contemporary art are on view in several Connecticut museums, with a particularly ambitious and up-to-the-minute survey in Ridgefield, though the most glamorous show is devoted to an Old Master, Caravaggio, in Hartford.

title: Inside Art; Settlement Paid In Paintings
description: When a $5 million pledge to the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago from its chairman went unpaid, the institution took action.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHUSID, YETTA
description: CHUSID-Yetta. On July 14, 1998 of Hallandale, FL. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Devoted mother of Helene and Howard Regen, Susan, Dr. Arnold and Ricky. Loving mother-in-law of Hilde & Ronnie. Adored Nana to Stephen, Michael, Cindy, Rebecca, Jesse, Melissa, Megan and Jonah. Cherished great grandmother (G.G.) to Heather Paige, Ross, Samantha, and Zachary. Graveside services Friday, 11:30 AM, New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYERS, SELMA
description: BOYERS-Selma. On July 16, 1998. Beloved mother of Barbara Moore and Robert (Peggy) Boyers. Devoted grandmother of Jane and Susanna Moore and Lowell, Zachary and Gabriel Boyers and great grandmother of Cecila and Ivan Boyers. Dear brother of Arthur and sister-in-law of Irene Busell.

title: Chip Equipment Maker Cutting 711 Jobs
description: Silicon Valley Group Inc., a semiconductor equipment maker, said today that it would dismiss 711 employees, or 21 percent of its work force, in the face of a protracted slump in the market for microprocessors.

title: The Postal Service builds a marketing campaign on bicycle racing and the Tour de France.
description: THE United States Postal Service is one of the most recognizable national symbols, so if it were to lend its name to a single team sport, that sport would naturally be -- cycling?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENSTEIN, ANN
description: EISENSTEIN-Ann. On July 16, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Herman. Loving mother of Rita and Les, and mother-in-law of Bonnie. Cherished grandmother to David and Michael. Services on Friday, at 1 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Recordings Played in Trial Of 3 Ex-Archer Officials
description: A Japanese agricultural executive identified two former senior officers of the Archer Daniels Midland Company as having met with him in a price-fixing conspiracy, on a day when secret Government recordings of pricing discussions were played in public for the first time.

title: Double Click Starts A Local Ad Service
description: Double Click Inc. in New York, an Internet advertising network, is introducing a service to deliver local and regional ads to audiences of 70 Web sites. The service, Double Click Local, will combine the geographical capabilities of the company's ad delivery system, known as Dynamic Advertising Reporting and Targeting, and the network's 10 interest groups to enable advertisers to reach computer users on such sites as Alta Vista, Automobile magazine, the Food Network, Travelocity and U. S. News & World Report.

title: Spanish Plant for DuPont
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the largest chemical company in the United States, said today that it planned to invest more than $110 million in a new plant in Asturias, Spain, to meet growing demand for Corian, a stain-resistant material used for kitchen counters and other applications. DuPont, based in Wilmington, Del., said the investment was part of a $185 million global plan for Corian. The company had $45.1 billion in sales in 1997.

title: Harvard Man Whose Field Is Ruled by Fists
description: THE way you spot the HBO boxing executive Lou DiBella at a boxing event is by his beaming face, which, as Lou DiBella is 6 feet 3, shines as a beacon above the crowd. There is also the single gold earring in the shape of a boxing glove. You don't see many Harvard Law graduates who sport glove earrings or who can relate, as does the sweet-tempered Mr. DiBella, to a fellow who speaks movingly of his fighting cocks (the light-heavyweight champion Roy Jones Jr., fighting tomorrow at Madison Square Garden on HBO).

title: What? A Sign of the 'Z'? The Cunning Fox Is Back
description: ''The Mask of Zorro'' extends a tempting invitation: travel back to the days when swashbuckling was serious business, when boyish adventure films still had their innocence, when the bravado of thrilling stunt work was all a movie needed in the way of special effects. With a wealth of charismatic Zorros (two), a smashing heroine and a dauntless love of adventure, this is hot-weather escapism so earnestly retrograde that it seems new.

title: New York Times Posts 11.7% Decline in Net
description: The New York Times Company reported an 11.7 percent decline in net income yesterday for the second quarter but said that earnings before special items and a one-time charge rose 16.8 percent.

title: Not Just for Tourists: Exotica in New Jersey
description: For Manhattanites, and particularly those with underdeveloped driving skills, an art excursion to New Jersey is a breeze. Many of the state's museums and galleries are a quick trip by train or bus from Manhattan. And most of them hop with activity through the summer.

title: New York City's Bond Rating Is Raised by Wall St. Agency
description: A major credit-rating agency raised New York City's bond rating yesterday, and leaders of the City Council said it was the strongest sign yet that the budget they adopted last month was fiscally prudent.

title: SBC and Ameritech, Awaiting a Merger, Beat Earnings Estimates
description: SBC Communications Inc. and the Ameritech Corporation, which plan to merge, reported earnings yesterday that were slightly better than expected.

title: Judges Turn Down Justice Dept. In Bid to Block Agents' Testimony
description: Acting with unusual speed, nine judges on the Federal appeals court here today unanimously rejected a last-minute effort by the Clinton Administration to block the testimony of Secret Service officials, including the head of President Clinton's protective detail, in the Lewinsky investigation.

title: Stealing Love and Loyalty, Among Some Other Things
description: The first thing the handsome stranger steals in the Russian film ''The Thief'' is the devotion of Katya (Yekaterina Rednikova), a dewily beautiful young mother. The year is 1952. Katya and her 6-year-old son, Sanya (Misha Philipchuk) are traveling by train when they meet a flirtatious army officer named Tolyan (Vladimir Mashkov), who turns out to be a dangerous fraud. Except for the charm, nothing about Tolyan is what it seems.

title: Genetic Map of Syphilis Is Decoded; Hope for Vaccine Is Raised
description: The master plan of the deadly and elusive syphilis microbe has been deciphered by a team of genetic code-breakers, raising hopes that for the first time a vaccine can be devised against it.

title: F.B.I. Seeks Access to Mobile Phone Locations
description: Director Louis J. Freeh of the F.B.I. has asked members of a Senate committee to change the Justice Department appropriations bill to require telephone companies to provide police agencies with the precise location of cellular phone users, in some cases without a court order.

title: F.C.C. May Act to Aid Home Internet Access
description: Moving to accelerate the delivery of high-speed Internet access to American consumers, the staff of the Federal Communications Commission is close to recommending that the big local telephone companies be allowed to build data systems without having to resell their use to competitors, officials said yesterday.

title: It's Family That Matters, No Matter What Family
description: At a time when nontraditional casting no longer seems so rare, or even so nontraditional, leave it to a little-known group called the National Asian-American Theater Company to find a way to make it novel again. The troupe has taken ''Falsettoland,'' William Finn's lyrical paean to Jewish angst, with its aggressively Jewish New York sensibility and multiple references to gefilte fish, and recast it with Asian-American actors.

title: SPARE TIMES: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Coke's Earnings Down; Pepsi Reports Early With a Gain
description: The Coca-Cola Company reported a decline in earnings for the second quarter yesterday, and, in a burst of corporate competitiveness, Pepsico said its earnings rose.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We view this very much as a last chance for Russia. The country is running out of time.''

title: Settlement Allows Trash Companies to Merge After Divesting
description: Two trash disposal companies whose planned merger would have left them in control of 70 percent of New York City's waste transfer stations will instead start shedding some of their local operations, officials said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a British report on the safety of silicone breast implants referred incorrectly to Dr. Robert Garry of Tulane University. He has given a deposition in support of plaintiffs in a class-action suit involving the implants, and has appeared at a news conference arranged on behalf of lawyers representing women who are suing implant makers. But he has not testified frequently on behalf of plaintiffs in implant trials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYNES, MARLENE G.
description: HYNES-Marlene G. Wife of Patrick Hynes. On July 16, 1998 in Lancaster, PA. Funeral July 18th, 11AM at Saint Joseph's Church, Lancaster, PA. Memorial services Saturday, July 25th 11AM, Saint Paul the Apostle Church, Columbus Ave and 60 St, NYC. Contributions may be made to Cancer Care, 1180 Avenue of the America, NY, NY 10036, Attn A. Levine.

title: German Insurer Sells Unit to French Company
description: AMB Aachener und Munchener Beteiligungs A.G., Germany's third-largest insurer, said yesterday that it would sell its Dutch unit, Rodutch Holdings B.V., to Assurances Generales de France for 1.35 billion marks ($754 million). AMB will make a profit of about 800 million marks from the sale.

title: Spotting Drunk Drivers
description: How does a police officer tell when a driver is drunk? Officers must have probable cause to pull someone over, and before they invest the time needed to bring a driver to a breath-testing machine, they must have a good reason to believe the driver will test positive. So the National Highway Traffic Safety Admnistration published a booklet -- complete with a laminated card suitable for the officer's shirt pocket -- giving the following clues to when a driver's blood alcohol level is likely to exceed 0.08 percent, the legal limit in many states.

title: Hammel Isn't Main Attraction, but She Steals Show
description: After a convivial practice round on Tuesday, Nancy Lopez conceded that she had won a few dollars from Se Ri Pak in an informal ''closest-to-the-hole'' competition.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Art galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Summer hours vary for galleries and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Familiar Landscapes, Architecture and Miro on Long Island
description: Appropriately for the season, tranquillity prevails at the art museums of Long Island. From the Nassau County Museum of Art, the Heckscher Museum of Art and the Museums at Stony Brook along the North Shore to the Parrish Art Museum, Guild Hall and Pollock-Krasner House in the Hamptons, the offerings are interesting, sometimes delightful and, on the whole, comfortably familiar. There's little to disturb anyone's summertime bliss.

title: TV Weekend; Her Identity Vanishes With a Sense of Deja Vu
description: Angela Bennett, a young, beautiful and reclusive (''I keep to myself'') freelance programmer, gets a weird E-mail message about something called Copper Canyon. She shrugs it off and goes for her daily run, but when she stops at an A.T.M., the screen tells her that her account is closed. A carful of F.B.I. agents promptly arrest her, believing that she is a criminal named Elizabeth Marx.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENCH, SYLVIA F.
description: LENCH-Sylvia F. Passed away July 14, 1998. Born in New York on June 20, 1917. Survived by husband, Benjamin of Rancho Palos Verdes, CA. Daughters Barbara (Jaime) Merino of Mill Valley, CA. and Lisa Lench of Los Angeles, CA. grandchildren Susan & David, brother Herbert Friedman of New York & sister Tebbeth Schechter of Mission Viejo, Calif. Funeral services will be Friday, July 17, 1998, 1:00 PM at the Green Hills Chapel with interment to follow at Green Hills Memorial Park, Rancho Palos Verdes, CA. In lieu of flowers the family request donations to the American Cancer Society, 5731 Slauson Ave #

title: Morse Code Sinks Without an SOS
description: PARIS  As the inventor Samuel Morse might have said:

title: Laments of a Refugee On a Vigil Against Evil
description: One of the great, overlooked records of 1998 is ''Pretaluz'' (''Black Light'') by Waldemar Bastos, an Angolan refugee living in Lisbon. This weekend New York audiences will be lucky enough to hear his debut appearances here.

title: Enslaved Deaf Mexicans Tell of Life in City Shadows
description: The first time he was handed a backpack full of pencils and ordered to sell them for $1 each in the subways of New York, Jesus Barraza understood he had been lied to.

title: Delta Reports 20% Profit Gain, But Investors Are Still Unhappy
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. today posted a 20 percent gain in earnings for the latest quarter, exceeding analysts' expectations, benefiting from low fuel prices and strong passenger bookings. Even so, its stock price fell 1.2 percent because investors were disappointed that the results were not even better.

title: Disturbing The Peace To Keep It
description: THERE was a stir last week when the Police Department said that its officers would soon load their 9-millimeter Glocks with new ammunition, replacing full-metal-jacket bullets with hollow-point bullets.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about American sanctions against nine Russian enterprises included an outdated description of one company, Glavkosmos. It is private and acts as a broker of space and missile technology; it is no longer a Government space agency.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; With stock prices at record levels, not all share buybacks are good news for shareholders.
description: FOR years, share buybacks have been an investor's best friend. Even though buying back stock may not be the most inspired use of a company's cash, it has typically sent stock prices higher.

title: Hundley Move Catches Up With the Mets
description: Any realists affiliated with the Mets figured this was coming. They crossed their fingers, their legs and their toes each time a fly ball was hit to Todd Hundley, but it was inevitable that, sooner or later, the catcher hiding in the outfield would hurt the Mets with his defense. It happened sooner. It happened last night. Three excruciating times.

title: A Volkswagen With Class; German Car Maker Is Going Upscale
description: It isn't enough to buy Rolls-Royce Motor Cars and Lamborghini, the Italian sports car manufacturer. Ferdinand Piech, the chairman of Volkswagen A.G., also wants to build a monument to the company he rescued from decline.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: House Approves a Measure For Coverage of Birth Control
description: Despite the opposition of Republican leaders, the House tonight approved a measure requiring Federal health plans to cover prescription contraceptives like birth-control pills for Federal employees.

title: Charter Revision Panel Narrows Its Focus
description: A commission considering changes to the City Charter voted last night to focus on only three questions: whether to change the city's campaign financing laws, whether to eliminate partisan elections and whether to make membership on the City Council a full-time job.

title: Hyundai Dismisses 5.8% of Work Force
description: The Hyundai Motor Company of South Korea sent notices yesterday to 2,678 employees in the country's first large-scale layoff, the auto maker said. The employees, who will stop working on July 31, represent 5.8 percent of the work force at Hyundai, the nation's leading auto maker, a company spokesman said. The layoff, which is expected to spread to other local companies, follows a two-day strike this week by its workers.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 9.

title: Choreographing a Garden, From Telephones to Trees
description: Some choreographers who present outdoor events in the annual Dances for Wave Hill series treat the place like a wilderness. But on Wednesday evening Ann Carlson reminded people that this garden and art center in the Riverdale section of the Bronx is a cultivated space supervised by busy workers.

title: China Urged to Free 5 Political Activists
description: A human rights group based in Hong Kong said today that 100 Chinese dissidents had called on Chinese leaders to free five activists who were detained after trying to register an opposition political party.

title: Antiques; Presents For Children, Good and Bad
description: Long before there was a Disney, there were Staffordshire productions. Ceramics factories in Staffordshire, England, began producing china just for children about 1790. The ones showing idyllic scenes of perfect children at play -- riding, fishing, rolling hoops or skipping rope -- were probably directed toward adoring parents, but most of the production was directed toward the children themselves.

title: In Title Quest, Montgomerie Falters on 73
description: Still in quest of his first major championship, Colin Montgomerie opened with a disappointing three-over-par 73 in the British Open, immediately hurting his chances. Montgomerie was two under par through six holes, but then he faded, shooting a four-over 40 on the back nine.

title: U.S. Data Code Is Unscrambled In 56 Hours
description: In a 1990's variant of a John Henry-style competition between man and machine, researchers using a homemade supercomputer have cracked the Government's standard data-scrambling code in record time -- and have done it by outcalculating a team that had harnessed thousands of computers, including some of the world's most powerful.

title: Cuban Exile Group's Leaders Plan a Lawsuit Against The Times
description: Leaders of a Miami-based Cuban exile group announced today that they intended to file a lawsuit against The New York Times, saying the newspaper published ''outrageous and malicious'' allegations linking the group's founder to a bombing campaign in Cuba last year aimed at toppling Fidel Castro.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Lockheed Calls Off Merger With Northrop Grumman

title: Helendale Journal; A True Believer in a Beguiling and Teasing Art Form
description: In her world and time, Dixie Evans was a star.

title: Visiting Caravaggio and Tarzan
description: Summer, as always, offers a mix of shows in the region around New York City, which for someone with a car, a map, an appreciation for bad roadside food and an esthetic purview big enough to encompass Caravaggio and Johnny Weissmuller is a fair alternative to the beach. In New Jersey, for instance, the Newark Museum has a collection of souvenir masks from Zaire, posters of Weissmuller's Tarzan movies and a foot-long model helicopter covered with bright Zulu beadwork (it's based on the surveillance helicopters of the apartheid era), part of an exhibition of odds and ends from the tourist trade.

title: Opium Surge Threatens U.N. Aid to Afghans, Official Warns
description: An anti-narcotics program begun in Afghanistan late last year is in danger of being dismantled, a top United Nations official said, citing reports that opium poppy production may be increasing in areas under the control of the Islamic Taliban movement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENT, ERNEST E.
description: KENT-Ernest E., M.D. Died peacefully July 12th at home in NYC. Remembered with love by his nieces and nephews, friends and colleagues at Bellevue and NYU Medical Centers. Memorial on Tuesday, July 21, 4:30PM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St. In lieu of flowers contributions to PWA Health Group, 150 West 26 St, NYC 10001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLAIMITZ, MIRIAM (NEE GROSS
description: KLAIMITZ-Miriam (nee Gross). Beloved wife of Jakob. Respected and loved mother of Heidi and Leni and her husband Mitchell Berg. Caring and loving grandmother to Alexander and Madeline. Sweet peace has come to her after so many brave battles. We shall always miss this remarkable person - her intelligence, humor, style and good nature.

title: Woods Shows He's on Top Of His Game
description: Earlier this month, Tiger Woods borrowed a putter from his close friend, Mark O'Meara. Woods still hasn't returned it. And after today's performance by Woods, O'Meara may never get his putter back.

title: Family Praise To Thousands After Vain Bid To Save a Life
description: When Melissa Moy first asked people to help her leukemic younger sister, Cindy, in January, she knew that the odds were not good. Cindy, Melissa told people, had only a few months to live if she could not find an appropriate bone marrow donor. And historically, Melissa realized, an Asian-American's chance of finding a match was slim, because of a longstanding Asian belief that donating any part of one's body made one's soul incomplete.

title: C.I.A. Says It Used Nicaraguan Rebels Accused of Drug Tie
description: The Central Intelligence Agency continued to work with about two dozen Nicaraguan rebels and their supporters during the 1980's despite allegations that they were trafficking in drugs, according to a classified study by the C.I.A.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-9

title: Novartis Says Sales Rose 2.3% in 2d Quarter
description: Novartis A.G., the world's largest health care company, said yesterday that its second-quarter sales rose 2.3 percent and it predicted a ''marked increase'' in full-year net income as cost-saving measures take effect. Sales at the company, maker of Ciba Vision contact lenses and the organ-transplant drug Sandimmun, rose to 8.58 billion Swiss francs ($5.72 billion) from 8.39 billion a year earlier, amid sluggish United States drug sales. Quarterly revenue was at the lower end of analysts' estimates.

title: Contemporary Works Intended to Provoke
description: Whatever else may be said about it, no one can complain that the short list of artists eligible for the second Hugo Boss Prize is not, er, multicultural. The six finalists represent a wide geographical spread, from China and Korea to South Africa to the United States, and a respectable ethnic mix.

title: Shell and Mobil Quit Peru Gas Project
description: Royal Dutch/Shell and the Mobil Corporation have abandoned plans to spend $3 billion on a Peruvian natural gas project after the Government balked at their demand for a distribution monopoly and the right to set prices.

title: RESCUING RUSSIA: A special report.; The Bailout of the Kremlin: How U.S. Pressed the I.M.F.
description: Seven weeks ago the chief of the International Monetary Fund, Michel Camdessus, assured the world's financial markets that there was no reason to panic about Russia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACKSOUD, ALFRED C.
description: MACKSOUD-Alfred C., 79. Of Cambridge, N.Y. Died Tuesday July 7, 1998 at his residence in the company of his friends. He was the widower of Annette Connery Macksoud. Born March 21, 1919 in Hackensack, N.J., he was the son of Cheble and Leonie (nee Lallemand) Macksoud. He was a 1937 graduate of Ridgewood High School, N.J. During World War II he was a pilot in the U.S. Army Air Force serving some of his time in Europe. He was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross, the Air Medal and 11 Oak Leaf Clusters. Mr. Macksoud attended Columbia University, where he received a Bachelor of Architect degree in 1953. Upon graduation, he worked for Moon, Iwatsu and Macksoud. He retired from the American Electric Power in Englewood, N.J. and subsequently, moved to the Cambridge area with Annette in 1970. He is survived by his stepson Richard J. Brandes of Newport Beach, Ca., two sisters Adrienne Cameron of Madison, Wi. and Claire Assatly of N.J., five grandchildren and friend Gloria Dawley of Cambridge. Memorial service is 10AM Saturday, July 18, at St. James Episcopal Church in Arlington, Vt. with 11AM interment at Woodlands Cemetery, Cambridge. After services luncheon will be at 12 noon at the Springwater Inn, Saratoga Springs. Mr. Macksoud requested memorial donations be made to either the Hubbard Hall Projects, 25 East Main Street, Cambridge, N.Y. 12816 or Youth for Christ, P.O. Box 338, Cambridge, New York. For further information contact Ackley & Ross Funeral Home, Cambridge.

title: Nasdaq Tops 2,000 as Dow and S.& P. Gauges Also Hit Highs
description: The Nasdaq composite index topped 2,000 yesterday, powered by the high-technology stocks that dominate the index and investors' preference for big, well-known companies at a time when the market outlook is uncertain.

title: Three Minutes to Show You Can Rhyme With Gusto
description: Pop culture pundits have proclaimed the existence of Woodstock Nation and hip-hop nation, so why not Slam Nation?

title: PRIMESOURCE AGREES TO ACQUIRE UNIT OF BELL INDUSTRIES
description: The Primesource Corporation has agreed to acquire Bell Industries Inc.'s Graphics Imaging Group. Bell Industries said yesterday that the sale would allow it to pay closer attention to its core electronics distribution business. Proceeds from the sale will be used to reduce debt and for other purposes. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. The unit, which distributes graphics and electronic imaging supplies in the upper Midwest, Southwest and West, reported sales of $156 million in 1997. Bell Industries, based in Los Angeles, distributes products for the electronics and computer markets and for other industrial markets. Primesource, in Pennsauken, N.J., distributes graphic arts and products.

title: Pledge to Sell Weak Units Pushes Siemens Up 17.5%
description: Shares of Siemens A.G., Germany's largest electronics and engineering company, surged 17.5 percent today after the company said it would step up plans to rid itself of weaker-performing units.

title: Back Injury to Keep Nelson Off Mound
description: As the Yankees evaluate the impact of Jeff Nelson's back injury, they really don't worry about whether he will be ready next week or next month. They think about October.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVER, BERTHA
description: SILVER-Bertha. Tifereth IsraelTown and Village Synagogue mourns the loss of its beloved member of long standing and extends heartfelt condolences to her entire family. Rabbi Laurence A. Sebert Carol Green, President

title: It's Good Will, So Who's Counting?
description: Who cares if the first three Goodwill Games lost $109 million? Not Ted Turner. A few days before the fourth edition -- starting in New York tomorrow with the opening ceremony at Battery Park -- Turner abruptly dashed across his 29th-floor office in Time Warner's Manhattan headquarters to fiddle with his deskside computer.

title: Cipollini Avoids Crash and Cruises on Flat Stage
description: There was another crash near the finish of the Tour de France's daily stage today, but this time Mario Cipollini, Il Magnifico, was not in the middle of the sprawled bodies and bicycles as he has been twice this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFF, MANNIE
description: SCHIFF-Mannie. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Mannie Schiff beloved brother and uncle of our devoted members Helen and Michael Rubin. Sincere condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Microsoft Logs Gain of 28% In Earnings
description: The company, which is the leading maker of personal computer software, reported its financial results after the markets' close. In Nasdaq trading, Microsoft shares closed at $117.375, unchanged. In after-hours trading, shares fell to $116.875.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSNIAK, ABRAHAM O., MD.
description: POSNIAK-Abraham O., MD. Of Bal Harbour, FL. and Manhattan. Departed from this life the 14th of July, 1998. He leaves his wife Hanna and their children, Robert and Erica, and three grandchildren. Service Sunday the 19th of July at 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Thalidomide Approved to Treat Leprosy, With Other Uses Seen
description: Thalidomide, the sedative that produced thousands of babies with flipperlike limbs and other gross deformities, was approved today for use in the United States for the first time, nearly four decades after it was stripped from pharmacy shelves around the world.

title: License Renewals Replace Life Jobs For Schoolteachers
description: The New York State Board of Regents voted today to end lifetime licensing for teachers, but, bowing to pressure from the teachers' union, it passed the barest of standards for renewing those licenses. Teachers will have only to take continuing education classes, with grading standards not yet determined.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, THOMAS P.
description: NELSON-Thomas P. Of Secaucus, formerly of Upper Montclair and Glen Ridge on July 15, 1998. Reposing Friday at Shook's Cedar Grove Funeral Home, (973) 239-1489. Mr Nelson was the publisher and owner of 1840's Corporation in Secaucus.

title: Citing Insurance Costs, Group Urges Agencies to Buy More Houses in Flood Plains
description: Tens of thousands of homes across the nation have been flooded again and again while their owners repeatedly collected Federal flood insurance payments, often in amounts exceeding the total value of the houses, an environmental group said today.

title: CAPITAL ONE PLANS PURCHASE OF AUTO FINANCING COMPANY
