description: The Capital One Financial Corporation, the ninth-largest credit card issuer, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the privately held Summit Acceptance Corporation, a Dallas-based auto finance company specializing in loans to consumers with troubled credit histories, for about $55 million in stock. The acquisition will give Capital One about $260 million in serviced loans. Capital One, which is based in Falls Church, Va., said the purchase will probably have no effect on its earnings per share in 1998, but predicted it will add to them in 1999. Its shares fell $2.4375 each, to $124.6875.

title: Liz Claiborne in Japan
description: The Jusco Company of Japan and Liz Claiborne Inc. have agreed to set up a joint venture company in Japan. Beginning next year, the joint venture will open stores in shopping centers developed by Jusco and sell Liz Claiborne women's apparel and accessories, the companies said today. Jusco will have an 81 percent stake in the joint venture and Liz Claiborne a 19 percent stake.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS FALLS 4.4 PERCENT. Prices dropped on an industry report showing an unexpectedly sharp increase in stored supplies for the week ended July 10. August contracts fell 9.9 cents, to $2.13 for 1,000 B.T.U.'s.

title: Given a Shot at Lefties, Cone Trips Up
description: The Yankees could average about two victories a week the rest of the season and still make the playoffs. Now the guiding force behind most of Manager Joe Torre's decisions will be what's best for the Yankees in October.

title: 'On Stage and Off'
description: The 'On Stage and Off' column will resume with the new theater season in the fall.

title: Evidence Hints At Higher Risk Of Big Quakes
description: Geologists have found evidence that the land on which Los Angeles rests was rocked by severe earthquakes at least twice in the last 15,000 years, suggesting that the present risk for the city may be substantially greater than was believed.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: HERE AND THERE
description: Speaking Spanish or Russian, Hebrew or Hindi, a tide of newcomers have redefined the immigrant experience. No longer is the old country forsaken; instead, these immigrants shuttle between homeland and new land. A three-part series by Celia W. Dugger and Deborah Sontag.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENE, DR. RICHARD B.
description: LEVENE-Dr. Richard B. Passed away on July 13, 1998. Family is receiving on Sunday, July 19 from 1-5PM at home of his beloved mother, Bernice Levene, 15 Ingleside Lane, White Plains, NY.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Mahbub ul Haq, 64, Analyst And Critic of Global Poverty
description: Mahbub ul Haq, a former Finance Minister of Pakistan and an early proponent of economic liberalization who in later years argued that poor countries failed to prosper because they neglected the basic development of their people, died yesterday in New York. He was 64.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALDI, VIRGIL B.
description: BALDI-Virgil B. Of Greenwich, Conn. on June 15. Survived by his wife, Janet and four children; Malaga, Rebeca, Marta, Mark and four granddaughters. In lieu of flowers donations should be sent to the First Church of Round Hill Outreach Program, 464 Round Hill Road, Greenwich, Conn. 06830.

title: Residential Real Estate; In TriBeCa, a Condo Building on a Parking Lot Site
description: With many of the remaining old warehouses in TriBeCa being swallowed up by conversions to expensive lofts, plans are moving ahead for one of the first newly constructed condominium buildings in the area in a decade.

title: Scottish Punk Nihilists Offer Feedback on Tradition, Too
description: The Jesus and Mary Chain, the Scottish rock band that headlined Irving Plaza on Wednesday night, started out in the mid-1980's as a one-trick band, burying sulky rock songs in feedback and distortion. By the mid-1990's, it had changed to a different tactic, stripping away the guitar noise to prove that the songs could stand on their own. And by now, through sheer recalcitrance, the Jesus and Mary Chain is starting to sound like a band of die-hard rock classicists, dedicated to the verities of three chords, an implacable beat, a drone and an attitude. Two songs, ''Moe Tucker'' and ''Stardust Remedy,'' cited the Velvet Underground, the revered fountainhead for punk primitivism.

title: Mysteries Behind Story's Publication
description: Robert Olson, the general counsel at Chiquita Brands International, suspected someone was tampering with his voice mail on May 1 when he checked for messages and kept getting busy signals. The system operator quickly discovered an intrusion from outside the building, but it was too late.

title: Fourth Straight Loss by Liberty Proves None Too Tidy
description: The Liberty tried to snap a three-game losing streak the hard way tonight.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; Torments of a Math Whiz
description: Darren Aronofsky's ''Pi'' was the fever dream at the Sundance film festival this year, a hauntingly bizarre black-and-white fantasia made with daring ingenuity, especially in light of its $60,000 budget.

title: Coach and Ex-Officer Sentenced in Sex Cases
description: A former Union City police officer and a girl's soccer coach from Medford were sentenced yesterday in separate cases in which they were convicted of sexually assaulting youths who were in their care.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Great Expectations

title: Clinton and G.O.P. Press Rival Plans on Health Care
description: President Clinton traveled to Capitol Hill today to champion patients' rights, declaring to a crowd of doctors and Democratic colleagues that the right to sue should be a cornerstone of managed care legislation.

title: FIRST COMMONWEALTH TO ACQUIRE SOUTHWEST NATIONAL
description: The First Commonwealth Financial Corporation agreed yesterday to buy a competing Pennsylvania bank, the Southwest National Corporation, for about $270 million in stock. First Commonwealth, based in Indiana, Pa., will exchange 2.9 shares of its common stock for each share of Southwest National, valuing the offer at $88.63 a share based on Wednesday's closing price for First Commonwealth. Shares of Southwest National, which is based in Greensburg, Pa., surged $19.25 yesterday, or 35 percent, to $74.25, in Nasdaq trading. First Commonwealth fell $2.9375 a share, to $27.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. The acquisition will give First Commonwealth new assets of about $847 million and 16 branches in western Pennsylvania.

title: Coach of Cycling Team Suspended Over Drug Questions
description: The international governing body of bicycle racing today suspended the coach of the top-ranked Festina team, who had taken into police custody in connection with a drug scandal that threatens to overwhelm the Tour de France.

title: New Shares to Finance Purchase of MCI Unit
description: Cable and Wireless P.L.C., the No. 2 British phone company, will sell new shares to raise $:887 million ($1.5 billion) after expenses to pay for most of its acquisition of the MCI Communications Corporation's Internet business. The purchase, for $1.75 billion in cash, was cleared on Wednesday after the United States Justice Department approved Worldcom Inc.'s $49 billion acquisition of MCI. Cable and Wireless will sell 112 million shares at 800 pence, representing 5 percent of its total shares.

title: The Other Love Story of the Trojan War
description: Easily the most intriguing film in a mostly mediocre collection of gay-oriented shorts collected under the title ''Boys in Love 2,'' which opens today at Cinema Village, is Barry Purves's ''Achilles.'' The 11-minute animated film reimagines the history of the Trojan War as revolving around the star-crossed love of Achilles and his younger soldier and lover Patroclus. Although the movie, narrated by Derek Jacobi, is too abbreviated and jumpy to carry much dramatic weight, the film's puppet soldiers, who do battle and make love, are elegant imitations of classical sculpture brought to life.

title: Los Angeles to Reduce Dust From Dry Lake
description: Striking a compromise after decades of bitter conflict, representatives of Los Angeles and the Owens Valley agreed on Wednesday to a plan for reducing severe air pollution 225 miles north of here on the dry bed of Owens Lake, which Los Angeles drained in the 1920's to build its modern metropolis.

title: Too Late for Brawley to Testify, Judge Says
description: For more than a decade, Tawana Brawley's advisers refused to let her testify about her allegations that she was raped by a gang of white men -- both to the grand jury originally investigating the case and in the defamation lawsuit against the advisers that followed.

title: Houston Administrator To Lead Yonkers Schools
description: Andre J. Hornsby, a public school administrator in Houston, has been named superintendent of schools in New York's fourth-largest city as it begins the second phase of a Federally mandated $1.1 billion desegregation program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUSMAN, JACK
description: HAUSMAN-Jack. Dearly loved and sorely missed. Joyce Newman-Eichenberg The Goodman Memorial Fdn.

title: Reports of Embezzling at World Bank Jeopardize U.S. Financing
description: A key member of Congress said today that financing for some of the World Bank's poverty-fighting efforts had been put in jeopardy by reports that bank employees were suspected of embezzlement and of accepting kickbacks.

title: Volvo's Profit Rose 48% in 2d Quarter
description: Volvo A.B., Europe's seventh-largest car maker, said yesterday that its second-quarter profit rose a greater-than-expected 48 percent, as sales in the United States and Europe rose and the company registered one-time gains from the sale of an investment. Volvo, based in Sweden, said its profit rose to 2.894 billion kronor ($362 million), from 1.961 billion a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, PHILIP CRAWFORD
description: MITCHELL-Philip Crawford. Died suddenly July 16, 1998 in his home town of Bronxille, N.Y. A veteran of WW II, Mr. Mitchell flew a P47 Fighter Plane in the European Theater. Among his many decorations were the Distinguished Flying Cross, the Air Medal and the Purple Heart. In May 1998, he received a Medal of Honor from the Federation of French War Veterans for his WWII service. Prior his retirement, Mr. Mitchell served as the Chief Executive Officer of James E. Mitchell & Son, a familyowned construction management firm established in New York City in 1888. One of his many projects included the complete restoration of Saint Patrick's Cathedral, for which he was later appointed ''Keeper of the Fabric''. He was honored by Long Island College Hospital as ''Man of the Year'' for a decade of service as Construction Manager during the Hospital's major expansion program. Mr. Mitchell was President of the Saint Andrew's Golf Club in Hastings-onHudson, N.Y. from 1970 to 1982, and a Deacon of the Reformed Church in Bronxville, N.Y. At the time of his death, he was the Project Director for Church Restoration and Chairman of the Building and Grounds Committee. He is survived by his wife Jane Kerr Mitchell of Bronxville, his daughter Nan Mitchell Harman of Palos Verdes, CA., sons Peter Mitchell of Locust Valley, N.Y., Steven Mitchell of Palos Verdes, CA., grandchildren Hayden and Spencer Harman, both of New York City, Christopher Mitchell, a student at the University of VT. and Meghan Mitchell, a student at Middlebury College, a brother James S. Mitchell of Bronxville, 4 nephews and two nieces. Services will be held at the Reformed Church, Pondfield Road & Midland Avenue, Bronxville, N.Y. Saturday, July 18th, 3PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Reformed Church or Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: LOSS IN YUGOSLAVIA DEALINGS DEPRESSES SHARES OF ICN
description: The shares of ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc. fell 13 percent yesterday after the company, a United States drug maker, said it would take a charge of $172 million for the money owed to it by Yugoslavia, resulting in a second-quarter loss. ICN, based in Costa Mesa, Calif., generates almost one-third of its revenue in Yugoslavia. It said Yugoslavia defaulted on $39 million of its $176 million debt and warned that it would be unable to meet all credit terms. ICN shares fell $5, to $33.625. Under its chief executive, Milan Panic, an American United States citizen who served as prime minister of Yugoslavia during its transition from Communist rule, ICN has moved into Eastern Europe's pharmaceutical markets.

title: Gillette Says Earnings Rose 11% in 2d Quarter
description: The Gillette Company said yesterday that earnings rose 11 percent in the second quarter as higher profits from its Braun appliances and Duracell batteries offset lower-than-expected sales of Sensor razors.

title: A Place in the History of Women
description: Rachel Waite honored her foremothers today, during the 150th anniversary of the first American women's rights convention, by doubling the prices at her curbside lemonade stand.

title: The Great Outdoors
description: The decision to dine outdoors is often tricky, particularly in New York, where considerations like passers-by, noise and light are as important as the air-conditioning question. If outdoor dining seems enticing, here are 12 possibilities. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: In the Hudson Valley, A Feast With a Price
description: People venturing into the Hudson Valley in pursuit of interesting art have their work cut out for them. The summer shows are diverse, substantial and spread out, forming a feast that requires no small amount of mobility but is generally worth the effort.

title: Unisys Reports Big Rise in Net Income
description: The Unisys Corporation said today that net income more than doubled in the second quarter, aided by cost cuts and strong sales by its information-services business.

title: From Agassi and Courier, Big Opening Salutes for the Davis Cup Quarterfinal
description: Time was when it took a bit of arm-twisting to persuade Andre Agassi and Jim Courier to shoehorn patriotism, in the form of Davis Cup duty, into their itineraries. Not anymore.

title: GEMSTAR REJECTS UNITED VIDEO TAKEOVER OFFER
description: Gemstar International Group Ltd. yesterday rejected a $45-a-share cash takeover bid by United Video Satellite Group Ltd., characterizing it as inadequate. United Video, a company based in Tulsa, Okla., that is controlled by Tele-Communications Inc., provides program guides and other services to media companies. It disclosed the $2.8 billion offer to buy Gemstar, which is based in Pasadena, Calif., on July 6. United Video recently agreed to acquire TV Guide magazine for $2 billion. Separately, the General Electric Company's NBC network unit and Gemstar agreed to develop interactive program guide services. Under the agreement, NBC will acquire a 5 percent stake in TDN, a joint venture of Gemstar and Thomson Consumer Electronics Inc., based in Circleville, Ohio.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Bohemia Is Not For Everyone

title: Diner's Journal
description: The elderly couple at the table behind ours are not pleased. They look glumly down at the new menu at Le Regence. They do not want Kumamoto oysters on a bed of pickled Japanese cucumber with soy sauce, balsamic vinegar and shiso oil. The very idea of veal cheek and tongue terrine wrapped in a chicken-foie gras mousseline appalls them. Nor are they intrigued by a salad of warm smoked black cod, potatoes and arugula. They call the maitre d'hotel over.

title: Gallipoli Journal; Inferno of 1915: Can the Dead Hear Talk of Peace?
description: Here at the place where half a million men fell during one of the fiercest battles of World War I, the Turkish Government is planning to open a ''peace park'' dedicated to the memory of the dead and the ideal of reconciliation.

title: FESTIVAL REVIEW/Dance; A Reductive Revue of Leonard Bernstein's Life
description: Can one imagine Leonard Bernstein as a corn-fed innocent arriving wide-eyed in the big city? I don't think so. But that image is the springboard for John Neumeier's ''Bernstein Dances,'' the tedious but not entirely hopeless dance treatment of Bernstein's life and art that the Hamburg Ballet presented on Wednesday night.

title: Child Welfare Supervisor Is Held in Endangerment
description: A supervisor for the New York City Administration for Children's Services was arrested Wednesday night on charges that he looked up a 9-year-old girl's skirt while lying beneath a table in the children's books section of a Barnes & Noble store, officials said.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; Taking the License, Then the Car
description: PERSON convicted more than once of driving under the influence of alcohol usually faces the suspension or revocation of his or her driver's license. But many people who lose permission to drive still get behind the wheel, so a growing number of states have taken a more forceful response: instead of telling the driver to hang up the keys, they take away the car.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESS, STEPHEN R.
description: HESS-Stephen R. Suddenly on July 14th, 1998 in Lenox, MA. Lifetime resident of New York City. Loving son of the late Leonard and Ruth Hess. Devoted brother of Katherine A. Hess. Special friend of Diane Dickinson. Beloved friend of so many others. Friends may call Thursday evening July 16th from 7-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St with service Friday, 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Stephen Hess Pediatric Social Enhancement Fund, c/o Lenox Hill Hospital, 100 East 77th St., NY NY 10021.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Cowboys Start Fresh In New Town
description: This is what happens to the Dallas Cowboys when their play on the field is finally as bad their behavior off it. They get a new sheriff. They get plopped down in a new frontier for training camp.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSCHILD, BESSIE N.
description: ROTHSCHILD-Bessie N. 100 years old. Died July 14 at her home. Funeral was private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the 92nd Street Y or to the Yad B'ad program, NCJW, 53 West 23rd Street, New York, NY 10010.

title: Medicare Contractor Admits Longtime Pattern of Fraud
description: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Illinois pleaded guilty today to defrauding Medicare and agreed to pay $144 million in civil and criminal penalties.

title: A Revolution Made Of Gritty Intimacy
description: Nearly 20 years ago, a catchy hit song called ''Video Killed the Radio Star'' by a group called the Buggles eerily presaged the rise of MTV and the revolution in pop-music marketing that the promotional video clip was just beginning to incite. Today, when the mindless star-studded ''event movie'' has risen to become the economic cornerstone of the film industry, the time is more than ripe for an upstart video artist to concoct a similar fantasy that might be dubbed, ''Video Killed the Movie Star.''

title: Home Video; The Luxury Of Stopping
description: A Ross McElwee documentary is just about perfect for video. Since he usually chronicles his own life in films like ''Sherman's March'' (1986) and ''Time Indefinite'' (1993), the dramas couldn't be more intimate. Given Mr. McElwee's eye for odd happenings and juxtapositions, the scenarios are also provocative enough to make one want to pause and ruminate. ''It pleases me that on video people have the luxury of stopping,'' he said.

title: Corrections
description: The table of bank account rates in Business Day yesterday misstated the figure for a six-month certificate of deposit from Citibank. It is 4.55 percent, not 5.55 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, MILTON H.
description: STERN-Milton H. Died July 10 at home in Florida at the age of 92. Beloved husband for 69 years of the late Hannah; adored father of Carole Selig and Robert Stern; loving grandfather of Gregory, Scott, Lydia, Claudia and the late Erica Ann. For over six decades, Milton was a celebrated home furnishings fabric designer and executive of Titus Blatter and Milton H. Stern Associates, Inc. He was extremely respected and beloved by all who knew him. He will be buried side by side with Hannah, as they had always been until her death. Graveside services Sunday July 19 11AM at Westhampton Cemetery, Westhampton Beach, New York.

title: GOLF: ROUNDUP
description: DEPOSIT GUARANTY CLASSIC

title: Treasuries Slide Despite Signals Of Diminished Inflation Pressure
description: Treasury securities fell yesterday despite Government reports pointing toward lower economic growth and diminished inflationary pressure.

title: Adventures of a River Pilot: Tall Tales on a Tall Screen
description: As an experienced Mississippi riverboat pilot, Mark Twain surely knew shallows when he saw them. So he'd probably steer well clear of the thin murky brew sloshing around under the title ''Mark Twain's America in 3-D,'' the latest Imax attraction.

title: NBC and USA Networks Said to Halt Talks
description: Executives at NBC and USA Networks Inc. held exploratory talks earlier this month about a possible merger, but the talks fell through, several executives close to the companies said yesterday.

title: P.& G. Seeking Greater Diversity
description: The Procter & Gamble Company is broadening the depiction of families seen in some commercials to include nontraditional elements like adopted children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ACOSTA, MADELEINE (NEE BARKATZ
description: ACOSTA-Madeleine (nee Barkatz). 63 years old. Died July 15. Survived by mother Alice Schweitzer and brother David. Class of 1973 Harvard University. Memorial service will be held July 19 at SGI, 7 East 15 Street at 5PM.

title: Murder Suspect Returns To Jail After Suicide Try
description: Thomas J. Koskovich, the Franklin Township man who tried to commit suicide hours before he was expected to plead guilty to the murders of two pizza deliverymen, was released from Newton Memorial Hospital yesterday, county prosecutors said. He was transferred to the Walter Keogh-Dwyer Correctional Facility here and placed under suicide watch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUMBEIN, AARON D.
description: KRUMBEIN-Aaron D. The First Chairman of the Association of Orthodox Jewish Scientists (AOJS) Board of Governors, passed away in Shaare Zedek Hospital in Jerusalem, Israel on July 10, 1998. He was a graduate student in physics at New York University and a former Nahal Soreg Nuclear Research Center physicist. Born on April 6, 1921, Aaron was a valuable member of every community in which he resided over his 77 year lifespan.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Some Evidence of Forgery, But No Sign of Missing Widow
description: Police officers searching for an Upper East Side widow who vanished 12 days ago said yesterday that they had found evidence of a forgery operation, but no sign of the woman, after a tip led them to the New Jersey Meadowlands.

title: Serb Forces Are Said to Abduct and Kill Civilians in Kosovo
description: Serbian forces have been turning increasingly to the abduction and execution of small groups of civilians in their fight against ethnic Albanian separatists in Kosovo, according to human rights officials and witnesses.

title: Family Fare; American Hero, Onstage and Off
description: More schoolchildren have heard of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X than of the actor and singer Paul Robeson. Still, Robeson's life did not lack for courage or vision, and his devotion to civil rights was as passionate as that of many better-known black Americans.

title: Court Rejects Convictions Of 2 Drug Suspects
description: Police officers who conduct searches or make arrests based on information provided by informers must have evidence in addition to the tips to take action, the State Supreme Court ruled yesterday. In separate decisions, the court dismissed guilty verdicts against two men whose drug convictions were based largely on evidence from informers.

title: China Attacks 'Hidden' Crime: Smuggling
description: After years of tolerating a steady growth of lawlessness at their borders, China's leaders today announced a war on smuggling.

title: QUAKER TO SELL ITS ARDMORE FARMS UNIT TO COUNTRY PURE
description: The Quaker Oats Company agreed yesterday to sell its Ardmore Farms juice unit to Country Pure Foods Inc. for an undisclosed price as Quaker, the maker of Cap'n Crunch cereal and Gatorade drinks, focuses on its largest, most profitable brands. Ardmore Farms, with annual sales of about $40 million, supplies frozen juice and frozen-juice drinks to restaurants, cafeterias and other food-service businesses. Country Pure, a closely held company based in Akron, Ohio, makes supermarket-brand and other private-label juices.

title: Accounts
description: * CDW Computer Centers Inc., Vernon Hills, Ill., to Donino, White & Partners, Atlanta, as the first agency to handle its brand advertising account. Though billings have not been determined, overall marketing spending through 1999 was estimated at $85 million.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: STRONGER YEN. Japan's currency rose on reports that Seiroku Kajiyama, a former Cabinet secretary who favors economic stimulants, would seek the prime minister's job. In New York the dollar fell to 139.94 yen from 140.50.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LANDSTAR SYSTEM INC., Jacksonville, Fla., a transportation company, said it would sell its Landstar Poole Inc. trucking unit to the privately held Schneider National Inc., for about $41 million in cash.

title: British Telecom Pushes For U.S. Partnership
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C., Britain's largest telecommunications company, said yesterday that it was still considering ''every opportunity'' for an alliance with a United States phone company and declined to comment on a report that it had narrowed its choice to four potential partners. A report in The Financial Times said the company's list was thought to consist of Bell Atlantic, AT&T, Qwest Communications and Sprint.

title: A River Ran Through Their Dreams
description: FORTUNE IS A RIVER

title: 2 Westchester Beaches Reopen After Spill
description: Two Westchester County beaches on the Hudson River were reopened yesterday after county health officials detected no elevated levels of bacteria from a spill at a county-run sewage treatment plant in Yonkers.

title: Panel's Ruling on Request for Stay
description: Following is the ruling today by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit on the Justice Department's request to stay its decision requiring grand jury testimony by Secret Service agents from President Clinton's detail:

title: Metro Business; New Lease Signed By Goldman, Sachs
description: In a deal reflecting the resurgence of real estate in the Wall Street area, Goldman, Sachs & Company, the global investment bank, signed a 15-year lease yesterday to occupy more than 650,000 square feet at 180 Maiden Lane.

title: Salinas Brothers Tied to More Crimes; Few Mexicans Surprised
description: Downtown peddlers may not sell nearly as many of the caricature masks of the former President, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, as they used to. But nearly four years after he left office, he -- and members of his family -- remain very much connected in the minds of many Mexicans with corruption and abuse of power.

title: Yeltsin, in Reversal, Will Attend Rite for Czar and Family
description: It is difficult to upstage the burial of the final Czar, emperor and autocrat of all the Russias, the man whose remains were hidden for nearly eight decades by the Communists who killed him and seized his empire. But President Boris N. Yeltsin managed to do just that today.

title: Theater Complex Planned for Brooklyn
description: In a sign that developers are increasingly forced to scout out unlikely locales for new projects, a Manhattan company said yesterday that it would build a huge entertainment complex along the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn that would include the city's largest multiplex movie theater.

title: Agent Testifies On Content Of Pipe Bomb
description: A powerful pipe bomb that prosecutors say two men planned to explode in the New York City subway was covered with large construction nails that would have increased its potential to kill and mutilate people, a bomb expert testified yesterday at the men's trial.

title: Pleasures in the Heartland
description: Once this was the edge of American civilization, a portal to the unknown. The Santa Fe, Oregon and California Trails all started in Independence and Westport, two small frontier towns long since melded into greater Kansas City, and in the 1840's brave souls gathered there each spring for the arduous journey by Conestoga wagon to the golden West.

title: Chiquita Still Under Cloud After Newspaper's Retreat
description: Overlooked in the furor that followed when The Cincinnati Enquirer last month renounced a stinging series accusing Chiquita Brands International Inc. of wrongdoing were the extraordinary allegations at the heart of the series -- the questionable business practices of a major corporation with broad influence in the United States and across Latin America.

title: INSIDE
description: C.I.A. Worked With Rebels

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVER, WALTER
description: SILVER-Walter. Of Greenwich Village and Fire Island. Died July 14. Photographer and teacher. In fond memory from his friends Sheila Schwartz, Joan Diamond, Anita and Bernard Friedman.

title: Glimpses of the Gay Life: A Hollywood Perspective
description: Images and opinions abound in ''The Silver Screen: Color Me Lavender,'' but genuine insight and reportorial curiosity are in short supply in this film about Hollywood's treatment of homosexuality during its golden age, from the 1930's to the 60's.

title: Cummins Says Its Profit Was Flat for Quarter
description: The Cummins Engine Company, the world's largest producer of high-power diesel engines, said today that its second-quarter earnings were unchanged as interest costs from an acquisition offset an increase in sales.

title: A Cellar Full of Pickles and Soup Made With Blood: One Version of Earthiness
description: When Lena Olin, looking stunningly slim and sensual as Jadzia Pzoniak, a Polish-American cleaning woman, tells her lover Roman (Rade Serbedzija) that her body has been so ravaged by having children her husband doesn't look at her anymore, you wonder what body she could possibly be talking about. The discrepancy between what comes out of her mouth and what is visible on the screen isn't the worst problem with Theresa Connelly's muddled film ''Polish Wedding,'' but it is glaring enough to make you question everything else about this aggressively sentimental, nearly laugh-free comedy.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Rand to Assess How Federal Safety Board Runs Crash Inquiries
description: The National Transportation Safety Board has asked a research organization to analyze its operations and determine whether it maintains the proper relationship with airlines, plane manufacturers, the Federal Aviation Administration and other parties in its investigations of crashes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIR, HENRY J.
description: LEIR-Henry J. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns the loss of a most cherished friend of three decades. While small in physical stature, he was a giant of philanthropy and humanitarianism. Henry Leir was a visionary whose keen global insight into all spheres of life was truly remarkable. Wishing to help turn young boys from limited backgrounds into young men with limitless futures, Mr. Leir, a Chai Founder of Boys Town, established a major scholarship endowment at the school to provide scholarship assistance to disadvantaged Israeli youth. A man with a nobility of soul and generosity of spirit, Henry Leir will be remembered around the world through his legacy of doing so much to improve the quality of life for so many. His multitude of good deeds wil endure as an everlasting blessing and tribute. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his sister, Hedy Wegier, family and friends. Josh S. Weston, Chairman. Michael J. Scharf, President Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Rabbi Ronald L. Gray, Exec V.P.

title: U.S. Drug Chief Sees How Dutch Manage Liberal Drug Program
description: The Netherlands had its jaw tightly set today for the arrival of Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, the outspoken commander of the American war on drugs. Several days ago the general prepared for his visit by dealing a few public punches against the Dutch and their tolerance for narcotics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'DAIR, WILLIAM J.
description: O'DAIR-William J. Died after a long illness, on July 5th, age 68. Survived by his wife Margot M. O'Dair, and his daughters Barbara and Anne. He attended St. John's University and Columbia Law School. In 1976 Bill left a partnership at Carter, Ledyard and Milburn to become the Chief Legal Officer of several NYSE-listed companys, including Global Marine, Inc., and Challenger Electrical. More recently he did pro bono work on behalf of abused children.

title: Detectives' Union Agrees to Drop Disputed Rule
description: Following in the footsteps of the police sergeants' union, the union that represents police detectives in New York City reached a tentative agreement yesterday with the Giuliani administration on a contract that eliminates the so-called 48-hour rule for interrogating detectives accused of misconduct.

title: In Inquiry, County Detectives Will Help Run a Police Dept.
description: The Bergen County Prosecutor's office has started an investigation of several police officers in this small, working-class town and, as the inquiry proceeded today, it took steps to help run the Police Department.

title: A Movie Deal? Not So Fast
description: It's easy! Start a magazine with an eye toward Hollywood and then sell the articles to producers who will turn them into movies, money and fame. At least that's the image some might have gotten last week when Tina Brown announced she was quitting as editor of The New Yorker to start a magazine with Miramax Films that would funnel the articles to the studio.

title: Chana Timoner, 46, Rabbi and Chaplain, Dies
description: Chana Timoner, a onetime housewife with such a passionate devotion to tradition and social justice that she became first a rabbi and then the first Jewish woman to serve as a full-time Army chaplain, died on Monday at her home in New Haven. She was 46 and had received a medical discharge earlier this year after developing the Epstein-Barr virus.

title: Success Without The Fame
description: Since the early 1980's, American track and field has showcased such female stars as Florence Griffith Joyner, Jackie Joyner-Kersee, Mary Slaney, Gail Devers, Joan Benoit Samuelson and now Marion Jones. All this time, Regina Jacobs has been there, quietly winning titles and breaking records.

title: Metro Business; Chocolate Maker Bought
description: Barry Callebaut S.A., the world's largest maker of industrial chocolate, said yesterday that it had acquired the Van Leer Chocolate Corporation, a chocolate and cocoa products maker based in Jersey City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERRILL, VERNON L.
description: MERRILL-Vernon L. Of Locust Valley, NY, beloved wife of Robert G. Merrill, died on July 13th after a long battle with breast cancer. She was 72. Mrs. Merrill is survived by six children: Lynn Gray of Locust Valley; Gail Merrill of New Canaan, CT.; Edmund Merrill and Douglas Merrill, both of Denver, CO.; Signa Herman of St. Louis, MO.; and Nina Ogan of Denver. She is survived by 8 grandchildren, a stepgrandchild, her sister, Signa L. Mills and her brother, Edmund C. Lynch, Jr. Mrs. Merrill was the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edmund C. Lynch. Mr. Lynch was a founder of Merrill Lynch & Co. Mrs. Merrill was an accomplished athlete; she excelled in tennis and croquet. Active in many educational endeavors, she served on the boards of trustees of several schools and colleges. In addition, she was active in the North Country Garden Club and was the current president of the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Associates. The burial is private. A memorial service will be held at 11:00 A.M., on Saturday, July 18th at St. Paul the Apostle Church, Cedar Swamp Road in Brookville, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Associates, P.O. Box 100, Cold Spring Harbor, New York 11724, would be appreciated.

title: Robert G. Davis, 90, Author, Professor and Literary Critic
description: Robert Gorham Davis, a prolific literary critic and a professor emeritus of English at Columbia University, died yesterday at the Vernon Hall Nursing Home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 90 and lived in Cambridge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWSKY, ROSE
description: LOWSKY-Rose. On July 15, 1998. Loving mother of Howard Lowsky and Barbara Baum. Mother-in-law of Lois Lowsky and Al Baum. Loved by her grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Donations to your favorite charity.

title: LOCKHEED CANCELS NORTHROP MERGER, CITING U.S. STAND
description: Signaling the end of major mergers in the nation's military industry, the Lockheed Martin Corporation abandoned its planned $8.3 billion acquisition of the Northrop Grumman Corporation yesterday, a deal the Government opposed on antitrust grounds.

title: McCallister Link With Pogachefsky
description: After working together for the last seven years, three public relations agencies in Los Angeles -- Rachel McCallister & Associates, its Killer App Communications unit and the Pogachefsky Company -- are formally teaming up as mPRm, a public relations and marketing agency specializing in entertainment and new media clients.

title: Addled Sailors in Sea of Love
description: Everybody into the pool!

title: The Spotlight Brings Smiles For Novotna
description: Jana Novotna, still getting used to the expectations that come with being Wimbledon champion, seemed as stunned as the sellout crowd at the A.&P. Tennis Classic tonight when she failed to hold serve and squandered an opportunity to put away her match against Mariaan de Swardt.

title: Political Memo; Schumer Looks to Gun Control Fight for a Lift
description: ''It is painful for all of us to refight a battle once won,'' Sarah Brady, the gun-control advocate, said earlier this week in announcing legislation that would extend a law named after her husband, James, that expires this fall.

title: 20 in Precinct Accused of Sex With Prostitutes
description: Nineteen police officers and one sergeant working in the Midtown South Precinct face disciplinary action after being accused of having sex with prostitutes while on the job, Police Commissioner Howard Safir said last night. In addition, the top two commanders and another high ranking officer in the precinct are being transferred to other jobs because of what Mr. Safir called a ''breakdown of supervision.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LOBENFELD, RUTH
description: LOBENFELD-Ruth. It's 12 years, Babe. You're still the one and only. Love, Your Honey

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  VISCUSI, MILDRED
description: VISCUSI-Mildred. Fifth Anniversary, 7/16/29-7/17/93. Our thoughts and prayers are always with you. With much love. Fred, Laurie, Stephen and Casey

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: ENRON BUYS CONTROLLING INTEREST IN BRAZILIAN UTILITY
description: The Enron Corporation agreed yesterday to pay $1.27 billion for a controlling stake in one of Brazil's fastest-growing electricity distributors as part of the company's aggressive expansion into Latin America. Enron, based in Houston and one of the world's largest electricity and natural gas companies, will acquire a 47 percent stake in Elektro Eletricidade e Servicos S.A., which serves 1.5 million clients in the state of Sao Paulo.

title: New Standards May Worsen New York Teacher Shortage
description: Both City University and school officials in New York City said yesterday that the state's new standards for teacher colleges could worsen the teacher shortage in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWEN, EILEEN H. (NEE HALPIN).
description: LOWEN-Eileen H. (nee Halpin). Of Rockville Centre, N.Y. on July 17, 1998. Beloved wife of Theodore W. Devoted mother of Theodore W., III and Michael H. Loving grandmother of Katherine W. Dear sister of Mrs. Clare H. Bresnahan. Friends may call 2-4 and 79PM at Macken Mortuary, Inc., 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, Sunday only. Funeral Mass Saint Agnes Cathedral, 11AM Monday. Interment V.A. National Cemetery, Calverton, New York.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Turkish Government's plans to open a ''peace park'' at the site of the Gallipoli campaign in World War I misstated the former position of Bill Hayden, an Australian who spoke of the bond that has grown among onetime adversaries at Gallipoli. He is a former Governor General, not a former Prime Minister.

title: Some Mighty Dangerous Company Is Lying 3 Shots Back
description: While Brian Watts, an Oklahoman on the Japanese tour, will start the third round Saturday with the British Open lead, an impressive group of players lurk just a few strokes back.

title: Peace Prevails in Northern Ireland
description: When a television interviewer asked Chrissie Quinn yesterday if she thought the firebombing that killed three of her sons last weekend in Northern Ireland would change anything there, her answer was no. Her pessimism is understandable but unwarranted. The death of her sons, for which seven Protestants have so far been arrested, may help transform Northern Ireland, and for the better. The reason is not just the horror of the murders, but also that the peace process is working, giving the region and its leaders an alternative to violence.

title: Brothel Was Open Secret Around West 39th Street
description: On the gritty block of West 39th Street near the garment district and the ethnic food shops of Ninth Avenue, the police sex scandal rocking the Giuliani administration came as little surprise.

title: As Cambodia Nears Election, Leader Has Most of the Cards
description: Five miles down the newly graded Hun Sen Road, past Hun Sen Bridge and just beyond Hun Sen School, Cambodia's leader, Hun Sen, sat barefoot on the ground, smiling and chain smoking, as villagers gathered to thank him for the new Hun Sen irrigation canal.

title: Songs That Evoke Both Age and Eternal Youth
description: A transformation enveloped the crowd leaving Jimmy Page and Robert Plant's show at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night. As fans filed out, they let forth waves of booming cheers as spooky as the imaginary sounds made by mutating monsters or supermen. The tenebrous fury of Led Zeppelin, which Mr. Page and Mr. Plant have been reanimating since 1995, awakened some dormant urge within these people. The duo's weird magic still works.

title: Top Team Expelled By Tour de France Over Drug Charges
description: The Tour de France, bicycle racing's most prestigious and richest race, expelled all nine members of Festina, the world's top team, late today after its coach admitted to supplying illegal performance-enhancing drugs to his riders.

title: Journal; Stars and Stripes for Polo
description: A shopper at a Ralph Lauren Polo outlet store should only get a bargain as good as Ralph Lauren got in Washington this week.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FARBER, ROBERT D
description: FARBER-Robert D. July 18, 1948December 23, 1995. Not a day goes by that you're not part of. We celebrate your birthday even as we continue to long for you. I love you. Lindy and all of your family

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: HERE AND THERE
description: Speaking Spanish or Russian, Hebrew or Hindi, a tide of newcomers have re defined the immigrant experience. No longer is the old country forsaken; instead, these immigrants shuttle between homeland and new land. A three-part series by Celia W. Dugger and

title: For Seven Shining Innings, It's a Taste of '95 for Nomo
description: Eighty days and 13 starts. That is how long it had been since Hideo Nomo's last victory on April 28. Six times he had taken the mound for the Mets. And each time, he had nothing to show for it. Nothing except mounting frustration.

title: The Police and the Prostitutes
description: Whenever the New York City Police Department arrests a crooked officer, it trumpets the case as proof that the department can police itself. But this week's prostitution scandal involving about 20 officers at Manhattan's Midtown South precinct undermines that comfortable assumption. The officers are accused of cavorting with prostitutes while on duty, giving at least the impression that the police were trading sex for immunity from arrest. That officers in one of the city's more visible precincts could get away with this behavior for so long -- some officers were involved with prostitutes for as long as 15 years -- is hardly evidence of speedy and thorough self-investigation.

title: Northrop Limps As Lockheed Walks Away
description: Same news, same deal, different market reaction.

title: FESTIVAL REVIEW/Theater; A Haunting Vision Untainted by Order or Logic
description: Nothing, but nothing, stays the same, not even for an instant, in the richly disordered world of ''The Street of Crocodiles.'' This astounding production from the Theatre de Complicite, the touring English troupe responsible for the recent first-rate revival of Ionesco's ''Chairs'' on Broadway, creates a vision of provincial life in Poland in the early part of the century as a restless ocean of unending flux. Shadow and substance bleed and intermingle, and even the most fixed-seeming forms refuse to hold onto their shapes.

title: Slow Justice for Holocaust Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Joseph A. Mazzeo, 75, Scholar Of Renaissance, Biology and TV
description: Joseph Anthony Mazzeo, a Renaissance scholar at Columbia University whose interests ranged from Egyptian hieroglyphics to biology to television, died on July 6 in Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 75 and lived in Manhattan.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Those who committed this crime are as guilty as are those who approved of it for decades. We are all guilty. It is impossible to lie to ourselves by justifying senseless cruelty on political grounds. The shooting of the Romanov family is a result of an uncompromising split in Russian society into 'us' and 'them.' The results of this split can be seen even now.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RULNICK, HYMAN
description: RULNICK-Hyman. July 18, 1993. Five years in the peace of Paradise. Love you and miss you deeply. Your dear daughter Joyce

title: Religion Journal; Young Catholics Found to Be Paring Back Beliefs
description: If organized religion in America has entered a period of ''permanent transition,'' to borrow a phrase used by the church historian Bill Leonard, then sociologists have much to study (in an ongoing way) in the ebb and flow of patterns of popular belief.

title: G.M. and Union Agree to Start Arbitration on Wednesday
description: General Motors and the United Automobile Workers union said today that they would begin meeting with an arbitrator on Wednesday to resolve the legality of the union's crippling strikes here against the company, as bargaining between the two sides remained deadlocked.

title: Science on Trial, Confusion in Court
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Post Modest Gains In Advance to New Records

title: Republicans Introduce 2 Bills in Fight Against Homosexuality
description: Continuing their assault on homosexuality, House Republicans are considering a proposal to deny Federal housing money to cities that require organizations doing business with them to provide health-care benefits for the unmarried domestic partners of the organization's employees.

title: Reward in Swastika Case Fails to Bring Arrest
description: The offer of a $10,000 reward has so far failed to produce an arrest in the carving of a giant swastika into a cornfield near Princeton, officials said yesterday.

title: Broadcast.com Soars in an Opening-Day Frenzy
description: Shares of Broadcast.com, a small three-year-old company that streams live news, radio, music and other programs over the Internet, more than tripled in value yesterday in frenzied trading -- the best opening-day gain of any company in Wall Street history.

title: Young, Restless and Homeless on the Piers; Greenwich Village Reaches Out to Youths With Plan for Shelter and Services
description: It was about 9 on a recent Wednesday night, and the crowds had already started gathering around the West Village piers. More than three dozen young men lingered at the waterfront just off the West Side Highway, talking and smoking cigarettes and marijuana. Dozens more milled in front of a pornographic video store across the highway at Christopher Street.

title: 3 Market Barometers Climb Into Record Territory Again
description: Major stock market measures again reached records yesterday, but on modest gains. The Nasdaq composite index rose to its eighth consecutive high, propelled by earnings from Microsoft and Sun Microsystems.

title: Passenger Service Workers Unionize at United Airlines
description: In the biggest unionization victory in the private sector in two decades, about 19,000 reservations takers, gate agents and ticket sellers at United Airlines will become members of the International Association of Machinists, Federal officials announced yesterday.

title: With Love And Roses, Sisters All
description: A woman in the audience gave Natalie Merchant a dozen pink roses while she sang ''Life Is Sweet'' at the Jones Beach Amphitheater on Thursday. Ms. Merchant exulted, ''Beautiful flowers!,'' then tore them apart to sprinkle rose petals on the crowd. For the Lilith Fair, playing its second day at Jones Beach, it was the perfect gesture: feminine, communal and gently showy.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on the Media Business page on Wednesday about The Los Angeles Times's plans for a national edition misstated the size of the newspaper's Washington edition. It consists of two 12-page sections, not a single one.

title: Herbert J. Sweet, 79, Top Enlisted Marine
description: Sgt. Maj. Herbert J. Sweet, who served as the top enlisted marine during the corps' heaviest fighting in Vietnam, died on June 18 at his home in Alexandria, Va. He was 79.

title: Blue Jays Take Advantage Of Yanks' Depleted Bullpen
description: The first thread is hanging from the natty 1998 Yankees, and unless fixed in the season's final months and weeks, it could unravel this team in the post-season. The Yankees' middle relief is becoming a problem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROETZINGER, JON M.
description: GROETZINGER-Jon M. On July 16, 1998. A White Plains resident since 1950. Was President of the White Plains Regional Chamber of Commerce and Westchester Aquarium & Pet Supply Company. Voted 1972 White Plains Retailer of the Year, Paul Harris Fellow of Rotary International, and the 1st Annual Golden Apple Leadership Recipient. Also served as CoChairman of the White Plains Bicentennial Committee in 1976. He leaves his wife of 51 years, Elinor Lee, his only child, Jon Groetzinger, Jr. and daughter-inlaw Carol O'Connor of Cleveland, Ohio and three grandchildren Jack, Kate and Laura. Funeral service Sunday 10AM at Temple Emanu-El of Westchester. For information, call 914-949-0566.

title: Wishy-Washy Sanctions
description: To the Editor:

title: Breakaway Gamble Fails to Pay Off; Cipollini Wins Again
description: Three riders took the gamble in a breakaway today, at one point leading the rest of the 181-man field by 6 minutes 30 seconds: Max Sciandri, a dual-nationality Italian-Briton who rides for La Francaise des Jeux; Cedric Vasseur, a Frenchman with GAN, and Jose Rodriguez, a Spaniard with Kelme. They rode in single file, working together by taking turns at the front as the two others rode in the slipstream during the 127-mile sixth stage of the three-week Tour de France race.

title: Money Released for Vetoed Items
description: The White House said today that it would release $197 million in Federal money for myriad projects and programs, and that it would not try to overturn New York State's system of hospital taxes that help to finance health care for the poor.

title: At a Hearing, Nuclear Regulators Are Criticized on 2 Fronts
description: In a rare show of agreement, officials of the nuclear power industry and one longtime critic of the industry spent four hours today telling the Nuclear Regulatory Commission that some of its rules contributed little or nothing to safety.

title: Tributes Mark 2d Anniversary of T.W.A. 800 Crash
description: Casting roses into the sea, relatives and friends of the victims of the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 gathered on Long Island today in observance of the second anniversary of the disaster whose cause still remains a mystery.

title: About New York; From Haiti, With Style And Ambition
description: RONALD DELICE was already at work in a SoHo clothing store when his brother, Rony, walked through the door, stylish and late. The two smiled, giving each other the kind of once-over that was as professional as it was brotherly. ''You look very nice today,'' Rony cooed. ''Always.''

title: Four Players Sign Contracts
description: The Devils yesterday signed their fourth-round draft pick, Pierre Dagenais, to a multiyear contract. The 20-year-old, 6-foot-4-inch, 200-pound Dagenais, a forward, led his junior team in scoring last season with 66 goals and 67 assists.

title: Ex-Premier Of France To Be Tried In Blood Case
description: Former Prime Minister Laurent Fabius, now Speaker of the French Parliament, was ordered today to stand trial with two other former ministers on charges of manslaughter in the deaths of hundreds of patients who received transfusions in 1985 from Government blood stocks contaminated with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.

title: Trade Deficit Sets a Record As Exports Sag
description: The nation's trade deficit shot up again in May to a record, the Commerce Department reported today, providing compelling evidence that the economy stalled in the spring.

title: At Camps, Young U.S. Sikhs Cling to Heritage
description: For 70 years, daughters of the wealthy and well connected spent their summers here riding horses and playing tennis at an exclusive hilltop spread called Camp Robin Hood.

title: Peronists Wrangle Over 3d Term for Argentine President
description: The Peronist party split into two angry camps today during a convention intended to ease the way for President Carlos Saul Menem to seek a third term next year, a step that is barred under the Constitution.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about Gov. Evan Bayh of Indiana and his candidacy for the Senate misidentified Mr. Bayh's maternal grandfather. He was Delbert Hern, not Matthew E. Welsh, a former Indiana Governor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORBIN, CARL E.
description: CORBIN-Carl E. Died in New York City July 17, 1998 of Multiple Myeloma. He was 61. Beloved husband of 33 years of Carolin Wildes Corbin. Loving son of Isabel Corbin & the late James Corbin of Webster, MA. Devoted brother-in-law of Clyde Wildes and Danny Walters of San Francisco, CA. Funeral Mass will be held 11AM Tuesday at St. Joseph Church, Witcomb Street, Webster, MA. Visitation will be held from 9:30-10:30 A.M., on Tuesday at the J. Robert Miller Funeral Home, 366 School Street, Webster, MA. Interment will be in Evergreen Cemetery, Kennebunk, Maine. Memorials may be made to Glida's Club, 195 West Houston Street, NY, NY 10014. For information, call Bibber Memorial Chapel, Kennebunk, ME 207-985-2752.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARRINELLO, ANTHONY, M.D.
description: PARRINELLO - Anthony, M.D. The members of the Board of Trustees of Catholic Medical Center of Brooklyn and Queens mourn the passing of Dr. Anthony Parrinello, retired chairman of the department of occupational medicine and president and chief executive officer of Kennedy Medical Offices. We offer our heartfelt prayers and our deepest sympathy to the Parrinello family on their great loss. Most Rev. Joseph M. Sullivan Episcopal Vicar for Health and Human Services Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REZNIKOFF, ABRAHAM
description: REZNIKOFF-Abraham. On July 16, 1998. Age 88. Beloved husband of the late Libby. Loving father of Nathan, Rosalie and Ira. Loving father-in-law of Suzi, Carol and Paul. Grandpa Abe to Marc, Jodi, Jason, Lisa, Sara, Gabe, Tasha, Micah, Alex and Diana. Proud great-grandfather of Jamen and Rebecca. Cherished brother of Sam and Sally. Companion of Ann Goldstein. title: Foreign Affairs; The Mouse That Roars: A Global Tale
description: So I was talking on the phone to my mother out in Minnesota the other day, and she sounded upset. What's wrong, mom? I asked. ''Well,'' she said, ''I've been playing bridge on the Internet with three Frenchmen and they keep speaking French to each other and I can't understand them.'' When I chuckled at the thought of my card-shark mom playing bridge with three Frenchmen on the net, she took a little umbrage. ''Don't laugh,'' she said. ''I was playing bridge with someone in Siberia the other day.''

title: READ-RITE SAYS IT WILL SHUT OPERATIONS IN MALAYSIA
description: Citing oversupply in the market for disk-drive recording heads, the Read-Rite Corporation will lay off 4,000 employees in Malaysia and move its manufacturing operations there to existing plants in Thailand and the Philippines. The company, based in Milpitas, Calif., said it was consolidating the operations because of severe oversupply, pricing pressures and a move toward fewer recording heads per disk drive. All three factors have reduced demand for its products. The cuts will leave it with 18,000 employees. Read-Rite retains operations in Japan and Singapore.

title: Celebrating Seneca Falls
description: On July 19, 1848, a convention gathered in the small town of Seneca Falls, N.Y., to declare women's rights. A ''Declaration of Sentiments'' was read aloud by Elizabeth Cady Stanton, one of the convention's organizers, and amended after some discussion. The next day Stanton again read the Declaration aloud to the audience of women and men who would sign it, including Lucretia Mott, Mary Ann M'Clintock and Frederick Douglass.

Loving mother of Ryan, Matthew, Micaela, Carey, Colin and Timothy; grandmother of Charles, Lucy, Elizabeth, Kevin, Logan, & Jack; sister of Barbara. The O'Connells began summering in Easthampton in 1954 and became year-round residents in 1984. A former reporter and writer for Life Magazine, Time Inc., Pat O'Connell became a real estate broker when she moved to Easthampton. The family will receive visitors on Sunday, July 19th from 3 P.M. to 5 P.M. at The Williams Funeral Home, Newtown Lane, Easthampton. A Mass of Resurrection will be held at Most Holy Trinity Church at 9:30AM, Monday, July 20 followed by burial at The Most Holy Trinity Cemetery.

title: Safe Democratic Seat Is Looking Less So
description: After the 1990 census gave North Carolina a 12th Congressional district, the state legislature, responding to pressure to give blacks a greater say in electoral politics, drew up a new, majority-black district. Created by laboriously stringing together a number of far-flung urban centers stretching from Charlotte to Greensboro, it looked more like a meandering river than a political subdivision. But it was what its makers had wanted it to be: a 55 percent black district, in a state just over 20 percent black. And because it was so heavily black, it also turned out to be overwhelmingly Democratic: about 75 percent, in a state that was only about 55 percent Democratic over all.

Physicians and clergy members kept the boundaries drawn tight about their spheres, neither group trespassing into the domain of the other.

title: Bail Is Denied to 2 Suspects In Disappearance of a Widow

Lawyers for the pair, Sante Kimes, 64, and her son, Kenneth, 23, said they would appeal the ruling in the State Supreme Court's Appellate Division early next week.

title: EDISON INTERNATIONAL SETS $500 MILLION STOCK BUYBACK
description: The electric company Edison International said yesterday that it would buy back as much as $500 million of its stock. The repurchases, which will take place over an unspecified time, represent about 4.7 percent of Edison International's outstanding stock. Edison International has about 362.2 million shares outstanding. The shares were unchanged yesterday at $29.125 on the New York Stock Exchange. Edison International, based in Rosemead, Calif., is the holding company for Southern California Edison, Edison Mission Energy and other units. The company has repurchased 95 million shares, for $2.23 billion, since it began buying back its stock in 1995.

Johns Manville, based in Denver, had 1997 sales of $1.65 billion. Its stock rose 43.75 cents today, to $17.8125.

title: German Trade Surplus Surges to $8.2 Billion
description: Germany's merchandise trade surplus widened in May to a record 14.6 billion marks, or $8.2 billion, in a sign that exports to Europe are more than offsetting the slowdown from Asia. The surplus grew from 11.4 billion marks, or $6.4 billion, in April.

title: LAST CZAR BURIED: TALE OF 2 RUSSIAS
description: The Russians buried Czar Nicholas II today in true imperial fashion, beneath a ceiling of cherubim peeking from clouds, in a cathedral of mountainous oak and linden carvings sheathed in gold, among the white marble tombs of the czars who bestrode his empire for three centuries.

title: For Mandela's 80th, Parties and Talk of a Wedding
description: If you were a man who had grown up in a tiny village in rural South Africa, spent 27 years in jail for your political beliefs and succeeded in changing the course of history, what would you ask for on your 80th birthday? A bride?

title: Octav Botnar, 84, an Importer Named in British Tax Scandal
description: Octav Botnar, one of the first businessmen to import Japanese cars to Britain and whose last years were clouded by a huge tax scandal, died on July 11 at his home in Villars, Switzerland. He was 84.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON CUTTING JOBS FROM DIAGNOSTIC UNIT
description: Johnson & Johnson said yesterday that it would eliminate 400 jobs to cut costs in its Ortho-Clinical Diagnostics unit, which makes tests to screen for high cholesterol, H.I.V. infections and other medical conditions. Johnson & Johnson, maker of Band-Aids and the painkiller Tylenol, said it would offer incentives to employees with at least 12 years of service, or about half of the unit's 2,400 workers, to leave voluntarily. Johnson & Johnson, the world's fifth-largest drug maker, is relying more on its pharmaceutical business for profit growth as medical device sales drop, analysts say. Insurers and governments are paying less for medical tests. In response, Johnson & Johnson, which is based in New Brunswick, N.J., said it would cut more jobs and dismiss more employees if necessary.

title: Police Used Brothel So Often, Madam Got Worried

title: Henry J. Leir, 98, Key Figure in Metals Trading and Philanthropy
description: Henry J. Leir, who built a leading commodities trading firm and became a dedicated philanthropist after selling his company in 1968, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 98 and had gone to his New York office every day until Tuesday, said Steven Rosenthal, who had worked for Mr. Leir the last 14 years.

title: 3 Lawmakers Propose Gas Tax Plan Alternative
description: Three Republican lawmakers proposed an alternative yesterday to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's plan to increase the state gasoline tax to pay for transportation projects. The alternative plan would maintain the current gasoline tax rate and even reduce the general sales tax slightly.

title: DONALDSON, LUFKIN FUND TO PAY $23 A SHARE FOR DECRANE
description: DLJ Merchant Banking Partners II said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire DeCrane Aircraft Holdings Inc., a maker of avionics components, for $23 a share, a total of $172.5 million. The buyer is a $3 billion fund that makes equity-related investments. Its parent is Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., the New York financial services company. DeCrane, based in El Segundo, Calif., makes products for the commercial aircraft market. Its first-quarter sales were $29.1 million. DeCrane soared $5.0625, or 29 percent, to $22.6875.

title: DOCUMENTUM SAYS IT ACQUIRED RELEVANCE TECHNOLOGIES
description: Documentum Inc. said yesterday that it had bought Relevance Technologies Inc. for $36.5 million in cash and stock to expand its line of information management products. Documentum, based in Pleasanton, Calif., makes document-management software. It said it had paid $3.65 million in cash and stock for the San Francisco-based Relevance. The purchase price also includes a $1.5 million investment Documentum made a few months ago. Documentum develops software that lets companies sort and store computer-based information in manageable and understandable forms. Relevance developed a system that analyzes documents based on both content and meaning.

title: FENWAY BUYING 71% OF SIMMONS FOR $500 MILLION
description: Fenway Partners said yesterday that it would buy the Simmons Company, the maker of Beautyrest mattresses, for $500 million from the Bahrain-based Investcorp. The Atlanta-based Simmons has about 2,500 employees. Its sales were $550 million last year. Fenway, a private investment firm in New York, will own about 71 percent of Simmons. Managers and employees of Simmons and Investcorp will own the rest. Fenway's equity investment will total about $110 million, and the other investors will provide $45 million. The balance will consist of debt securities. Investcorp bought 72.4 percent of Simmons in 1996 from Merrill Lynch Capital Partners. A group of 40 Simmons managers bought 12.5 percent and employees owned the rest.

title: REGIONS FINANCIAL BUYING BULLSBORO FOR $35.6 MILLION
description: The Regions Financial Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Bullsboro Bancshares for $35.6 million in stock, expanding its businesses in Georgia. Regions, based in Birmingham, Ala., said it would exchange 3.65 shares of common stock for each share of Bullsboro common stock. Bullsboro Bancshares is the parent company of the Bank of Newnan, which has assets of $108 million and offices in Newnan and Sharpsburg, Ga. Regions is a bank holding company operating in six Southeastern states. Bullsboro's shares rose $3 each, to $68, while Regions rose 6.25 cents, to $42.0625.

title: James Flora, 84, Author and Album Cover Illustrator, Dies
description: James Flora, a magazine art director and children's book author and illustrator who in the early 1940's became one of the first artists to design and illustrate record album covers, helping to transform the way records were marketed, died on July 9 at his home in Rowayton, Conn. He was 84.

title: Broadway Musicians Ratify 5-Year Contract
description: Musicians who play in Broadway shows have overwhelmingly ratified a five-year contract with the League of American Theaters and Producers.

title: Iraqi President, Altering Tone, Predicts Slow End to Sanctions
description: In the first public hint that Iraq's hopes for an early end to sanctions have been set back by discoveries of nerve gas in Iraqi warheads, President Saddam Hussein said in a speech today that the embargo was instead more likely to crumble over time.

title: White House Memos to President Reveal Strategy to Shift Purview Over Satellite Sales
description: Soon after Secretary of State Warren Christopher decided in 1995 against relaxing sharp controls on the shipment of American satellites to China, President Clinton's deputy national security adviser began campaigning from the White House to reverse the decision, according to White House documents released today.

title: Sergeant in Lodi Arrested On Misconduct Charges
description: A day after the Bergen County Prosecutor disclosed that several police officers in Lodi were under criminal investigation, a 37-year-old sergeant in the department was arrested yesterday on two charges of official misconduct, officials said.

title: Favorite Trick Returning to Action
description: Favorite Trick, the 1997 juvenile champion and Horse of the Year, gets back into action tomorrow when he races six rivals in the $100,000 Long Branch Stakes at Monmouth Park. It will be his first competition since he finished eighth in the Kentucky Derby two and a half months ago.

title: Maverick Swiss Investor Buys Stake in HSBC
description: Martin Ebner, a maverick Swiss investor who has aggressively pushed Switzerland's biggest banks to increase shareholder value, has bought a stake in HSBC Holdings, Britain's largest banking company.

title: The Ups and Downs of a Return Visit
description: WHEN we heard that Spazzi, in Fairfield, had a new owner and new chef, we decided the time was right for a return visit. It was eight years since the restaurant had opened and changes seemed likely. The decor is much the same but one difference was evident the moment we entered: Instead of an uptight, indifferent staff -- which we remembered all too well -- current staff members were solicitous and extremely upbeat.

title: Many Tickets Are Left
description: More than half of the 500,000 tickets remain for the 15 sports in the Goodwill Games. Goodwill officials say they have sold more than 200,000 tickets and point out that last-minute tickets are almost always available for nonmainstream sports in the Olympics.

title: Editor's Note
description: An article last Sunday examined the phenomenon of career ''obituaries'' written about journalists implicated in fabrications or other occupational sins. It found that many such journalists survive the disgrace and some thrive in the business. As an example, it included Michael G. Gartner, who resigned as president of NBC News five years ago after his division rigged a truck to explode on a broadcast about safety. He now edits a small Iowa newspaper and won a Pulitzer Prize last year.

description: The 24 acres of land are not quite where the deer and the antelope play, but the Federation of Black Cowboys has been hoping for two years to hang its spurs there.

title: Style; The Bell Curve
description: Now that bell-bottoms are back on the runways and students who haunt flea markets and thrift shops are buying the bell-bottom jeans their parents discarded 10 years ago, the U.S. Navy has decreed that its everyday flared-leg dungarees will be discontinued, replaced by straight-legged pants. Described as ''traditional but unpopular'' in a recent news article announcing the decision, bell-bottoms have been the sailor's trademark for centuries and the American Navy's standard-issue trouser for some 60 years. Appearances aside, their great virtue was of a practical nature: back in the days when the crew of a ship scrubbed its decks in bare feet, bell-bottoms were easy to roll up above the ankle. Admiral Jay Johnson, Chief of Naval Operations, reportedly approved the change in response to widespread complaints from sailors who, according to the same article, felt that the old style ''smacked of an era gone by.''

title: Thousands May Have Cheered Then, but Now?
description: ONE of the better ways to understand your chosen field is through the eyes and ears of those outside it. ''As Thousands Cheer,'' the musical by Moss Hart and Irving Berlin that just closed after a successful resuscitation by the Drama Dept., had something to tell us about the early-music movement. The audience I shared it with not long ago helped explain why the operatic voice is such a hard sell to so many smart young listeners.

In a scene worthy of the old television show ''Queen for a Day,'' which crowned a hard-luck nobody and showered her with prizes, Mr. Zabor was whisked out of his grungy Brooklyn apartment and swept off to the glittering Washington award ceremonies by his publisher, which six months before had refused to pay his bus fare to a reading in Boston.

title: A Grand Garden Re-emerges, Dedicated to Its Original Laborers
description: A few years ago, the gardens surrounding the former estate of the financier Hamilton Q. Twombly, now on Fairleigh Dickinson University's Florham-Madison campus, were overgrown. It was difficult to see any remnant of the gardens that once drew admirers from around the globe -- such as the Emperor Meiji of Japan, who, in 1904, sent his gardener to the estate to learn the proper care of chrysanthemums. Then local residents decided to form Friends of Florham, a group of 25 led by Emma Joy Dana, dedicated to the restoration of the estate. The group's most recent accomplishment was the renovation and dedication of the Italian gardens this spring. Richard C. Simon, a novice historian and a member of Friends of Florham, and Mrs. Dana talked about the project. The garden and the 100-room Georgian revival mansion are opene for tours by appointment (973) 443-8921.

title: Children's Books; At Sea With the A B C's
description: I thought scratch art was done by preschoolers, not grown-ups. I can picture the kindergarten room still: little bodies hunched over paper, applying layer upon layer of crayon, eyes ever on the prize -- until that moment when, with great fierceness, the children would eclipse it all with a final coat of blackest Crayola. Only then would they be allowed to take the edge of a paper clip or the tip of a ballpoint or the tine of a plastic fork and start scratching. From the seas of ebony would soon arise crooked rainbows, variegated gardens, cheery houses with smoke curling from magical chimneys.

title: Backtalk; Protecting Swordfish and Fishers

The Give Swordfish a Break campaign, organized by the Natural Resources Defense Council and Sea Web, a project of the Pew charitable trusts, aims to force United States regulators and fishermen to take aggressive action to rebuild depleted swordfish stocks.

title: Does Amazon = 2 Barnes & Nobles?

Company A has never shown a profit and is expected to report on Wednesday even bigger losses than had been forecast, while Company B is enjoying a strong quarter and figures to be solidly profitable for the third consecutive year.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Alex Katz's Flat Farm
description: To Alex Katz, the world is flat. At least that is how he has depicted it in his paintings since the late 1950's, when he first caught the attention of the art world. Katz stood out from the crowd by doing figural works with a twist: he painted recognizable subjects, but dramatically emphasized the flatness of the canvas with bold blocks of color and hard-edged contours. Certain elements of the large paintings -- the slightly irregular, squared-off faces of his portraits and the signature black swoop of hair on his wife, Ada -- have marked his works for 40 years, and are on display in the 213 illustrations contained in ALEX KATZ: A Retrospective (Abrams, $65), by Irving Sandler. Sandler, who teaches art history at the State University of New York, Purchase, knows Katz personally and has written about him before; this familiarity gives the book a justifiably assured tone. He classifies Katz as a ''modern dandy'' -- one who has coolly chronicled the changing style of his affluent circle at cocktail parties and summer homes, but in pared-down compositions that celebrate surface in a sophisticated way. ''Indeed, his work is distinguished by the grace with which he bridges representation and artifice,'' Sandler writes. Only his last chapter, detailing the fall and rise of realist painting and Katz's relation to it, might be considered a bit abstruse. As Katz's painting continues to evolve, most recently into the realm of landscape, this book helps us see the big picture. Ted Loos

title: Beach Patrols Confront a Declining Number of Lifeguards
description: Low pay, a declining number of applicants and a dispute over professional affiliations threaten to make this summer anything but a day at the beach for lifeguards at New Jersey's beaches, lakes and pools.

title: Keeping the Boom From Busting
description: Only a few years ago, Japan was regarded as America's most dangerous economic rival. But during the third week of June, as Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin pondered the question of how to coax that country back in from the ledge, no one was yelling for Japan to jump. The debate was about whether we could help the sagging Japanese economy by intervening to support the yen, or by stepping back as it continued to slide.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; No Home Should Be Without It
description: Written over the past four decades, the 19 stories in Kit Reed's WEIRD WOMEN, WIRED WOMEN (Wesleyan University/University Press of New England, cloth, $40; paper, $16.95) explore the changing circumstances of women's lives. Beauty pageants, hi-tech motherhood, fat farms, game shows -- nothing involved in shaping women's expectations is immune from her satiric scrutiny. Consumer products often provide flash points for fallacies in her characters' thinking. A mail-order device in ''The New You'' glamorizes Martha as promised, but the old, dumpy Martha accidentally survives to wander the house, sneaking food, sleeping in closets, ultimately stealing not only the old husband but an improved version as well. In ''Cynosure,'' Norma immobilizes her cat, dog and 10-year-old daughter with a vacuum-like appliance, the better to keep her house clean. Most of these stories shine with the incisive edginess of brilliant cartoons, though ''The Mothers of Shark Island'' and a few others are so dampened by bitterness that they fail to ignite. The best take the form of darkly comic rants by women who have too zealously pursued what they thought was happiness. While Reed calls these stories ''speculative fiction,'' they are less fantastic than visionary, uncovering humor and horror where others have seen only clothes, make-up and recipes snipped from the newspaper. Enid Shomer
