title: HAPPY FEET
description: *''Self Portraits by Heterosexual Men,'' part of a new exhibit at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, is a bit different: it consists of 100 photographs of men's feet taken at the moment of sexual climax. * Why? The artist, Gabe Martinez, sees it as a nonpornographic way to comment on the ''worship'' heterosexual men receive in mainstream society. * To that end, the images are presented as tiny ambrotypes that resemble religious mementos. * The methodology was like a fertility clinic's. The men got visual aids and privacy -- they then photographed their feet using a camera with a long cable release. * Average session time: 20 minutes. * Five volunteers performed while standing; one wore black toenail polish; two forgot to trip the shutter and had to try again. *''It was difficult,'' says Michael O'Reilly, a filmmaker, ''to accomplish the task and trigger the camera at the same time.''

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Daewoo Leganza and Nubira; Daewoo Who? Some Low-Key Answers

title: THROW IT BACK
description: Some Presidents are ridiculed by impressionists, some by satirical writers. Bill Clinton is getting it from a guy who makes artificial fish bait. ''Bill's Lizard,'' a new bass lure that ''pulls to the left'' and offers ''attractive flip-flop action,'' was created by Larry Hacker, an Arkansas advertising man who hopes to market his gimmick to anti-Clinton fishermen everywhere. (Hacker is certainly no fan: a longtime designer of political paraphernalia, he offers ''liberal discounts for conservative Republicans.) The lures are affordable ($3.98 for six), and they allegedly catch fish, though that's not really the point. Shaped like a lizard, they come with a slimy texture in colors like Yellerbelly inside a package that features a Clinton caricature and a flirty fish. Hacker says his lures have not generated a response from Clinton, in part because ''we haven't sent any to him. He may not think it's so funny. We do, though.''

title: The Beastie Boys: Keen-Eared Survivors
description: THERE is a term in hip-hop, flavor. It is a good thing. Rappers want to have flavor: panache, style, something extra that enables them to stand out from the pack. In their 17 years together, however, the Beastie Boys have developed something much better than flavor: taste. This is not a hip-hop term. It is the key to survival in the mercurial world of pop. Musicians like David Bowie, Peter Gabriel and David Byrne have good taste; as most of their colleagues have fossilized, it has enabled them to remain relevant, even after their hit-making days ended.

Southwick, a Mississippi state appellate judge with a curious passion for hypothetical history, will release an uncommon political poll that ranks the major also-rans of American Presidential lore -- 41 in all, from Charles Pinckney to Ross Perot. Southwick, author of the recently published ''Presidential Also-Rans and Running Mates, 1788 Through 1996,'' modeled his work on the famous Schlesinger poll of Presidential performance, asking 46 historians to rate probable outcomes on a scale ranging from ''likely failure'' to ''superior.'' Here's a look.

title: The Mosquito's Killjoy
description: A flea collar for people! That bright idea led Frank Scarangella to invent the Bugchaser bracelet, which is guaranteed -- well, almost -- to keep mosquitoes at bay without having to spritz on the DEET, the chemical repellent. ''It has a sweetish kind of smell,'' Mr. Scarangella said of the bright yellow plastic band, whose active ingredients are d-Limonene (an extract of lime peels) and two pheremones. Although some wearers say the scent is as repugnant to humans as to bugs, once a bracelet is snapped on, it repels insects for about 60 hours. ''It works because it disguises the CO2 that comes out of your body -- 75 percent of the mosquitoes find you because they smell the CO2 ,'' said Mr. Scarangella, who is president of Island Marketing in New Hyde Park, N.Y.

title: At Least 600 Drown In Papua New Guinea
description: A 23-foot-high wave crashed into the northern coast of Papua New Guinea, washing away villages built on beaches, killing nearly 600, most of them old people and schoolchildren, and leaving hundreds of others missing, disaster officials said.

He was 70.

description: That was an era when struggles against giants like General Motors or United States Steel produced innovative benefits, like employer-financed pensions and cost of living adjustments, which were later granted to millions of other workers.

description: They arrived early, as older people tend to do, about 3,000 of them, carrying signs, wearing paper hats with slogans, waving tiny American flags and chanting, ''Open your heart, open the door, let the seniors have the floor.''

title: A Biodiversity Study Singles Out the Pinweed
description: THE fate of the slender pinweed may not seem important to the average person, but to a naturalist interested in biodiversity, it -- and every single species -- is an important component of a whole picture. The slender pinweed, for example, is a six-inch-high plant, which was found at Cranberry Lake Preserve in North White Plains during a biodiversity study, and it is noteworthy because, in the county, it exists only at the preserve. It was discovered in a recent biodiversity survey, a process that will be taking place more frequently on land owned and operated by the Parks Department.

title: Graf Shakes Off Her Frustration and the Week of Confusion
description: After a week in which her scheduled opponents have been dropping and ducking, it was not surprising that Steffi Graf played her first set today as though she did not even know her semifinal opponent in the A.&P. Tennis Classic.

description: Invariably inaccessible and often all but invisible, Roy Jones Jr. returned to public life, at least briefly, at the Theater in Madison Square Garden last night.

description: IF you want to make an Indian flustered, tell him you loved the 'Kama Sutra,' '' said Richard Crasta. ''He will promptly tell you that it is only a small part of the culture, that Indians are not erotic people.''

title: The Second Time Around, Late in Life
description: BACK at the alter at age 70 and up? Well yes. A growing number of America's increasingly older citizens are indeed remarrying and shattering stereotypes about aging in the process, says Dr. Gerard Kerins, director of the geriatric assessment program in Norwich of the University of Connecticut Health Center. With people 85 and older comprising the most rapidly growing segment of the population, perhaps it's not surprising.

title: A Candidate Who Believes In the Good of Government
description: Rush Holt easily gets through a short interview without actually invoking the name of Bobby or Gene, but his emphasis on 1960's values of the Democratic Party -- his focus on trust and the beneficence of a well-managed government -- certainly carry a strong whiff of the old Kennedy and McCarthy romance. And that is entirely intended.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC; A Pianist Explores Her Gifts for Words and Music
description: EZRA POUND composed music, Arnold Schoenberg painted self-portraits, and Elizabeth Bishop sketched landscapes. Anthony Burgess wrote not only poems but also musical works. Diaries continue to pour out of Ned Rorem, and Alfred Brendel has recently published very good verse. A polymath's talents overflow into a variety of genres and forms, usually to greater and lesser degrees of success and acclaim.

title: Times Sq. Cleanup Missed Underbelly; City's Busiest Subway Station Is Crumbling After Years of Neglect
description: There are still a few midnight cowboys out there who savor memories of squalor gathered on the streets of the old Times Square, before it was pasteurized. But it seems safe to say that a few steps below, no one will look back as fondly on the Times Square subway station once it, too, is transformed a few years from now.

title: Correction

description: Amy Grossberg got a prison sentence of two and a half years and Brian Peterson got two years in the death of their newborn. Were the verdicts fair?

title: Rambles Along a Remote Shore
description: CROSSING Vancouver Island on the Pacific Rim Highway that traverses it, you see an opening up, a broadening of the horizon, about halfway across as the Mackenzie Mountains come into view and signs of civilization dwindle to nothing. The patchwork shades of green covering the slopes, as you come closer, turn out to be immense reforestation projects in various stages of growth. Logging is an important part of the history of this island, as it is of all of British Columbia, and some of these giant forests of ancient cedar, Douglas fir and Sitka spruce were cut in the late 19th century. Other sections along the highway were logged as recently as the early 1990's. The new trees, and those from the 40's and 50's that are now imposing evergreens, are posted with neat company signs giving the reforestation dates. The waves of green stretch on endlessly, monotone within their individual sections, broken occasionally by a section of clear-cutting littered with ghostly silver spurs, stumps and low bushy growth.

title: The New Immigrant Tide: A Shuttle Between Worlds
description: Fernando Mateo has been shuttling between New York City and Santo Domingo since he was in utero. His pint-sized immigrant mother, belly swelling, flew back to her homeland so Mr. Mateo, now 40, could be born a Dominican. After that, his childhood was split between here and there, between a cramped Lower East Side apartment and a pink house beneath a mahogany tree in the Dominican capital.

title: Corrections
description: A review of the play ''Side Man'' on July 5 misspelled the names of two cast members. They are Kevin Geer, not Greer, and Angelica Torn, not Anjelica. In addition, the review misstated the original name of the building on West 43d Street now occupied by the Kit Kat Klub and the musical ''Cabaret.'' title: Death Penalty Weighed
description: The office of District Attorney Jeanine Pirro has filed a 22-count indictment -- with two of those charges carrying a possible death penalty -- against Anthony Ambrosovitch, 65, a former police officer. The charges were filed in connection with the June 11 killing in Tarrytown of Mr. Ambrosovitch's wife, Gloria, and a daughter, Melinda Podesta. Each victim was shot once in the head, officials said.

Because he often took years to finish one of his iconic black-and-white paintings, and because he lived the last 35 years of his life tucked away here, less has been seen of Stout's quiet, austere work than should have been.

title: Traditional Italian Dishes in White Plains
description: ITALIAN cuisine, so long beloved by Americans and so seemingly predictable, has recently and rapidly given way to regional influences that make veal parmigiana almost an anachronism when we find it on a menu. Even the best traditional Italian restaurants serving the cuisine of the south with its defining tomato now accommodate diners' taste for dishes from other areas of Italy. Gtallies', however, has resisted the trend, offering a circa 1960 menu listing the old favorites, a few reminding us why they became old favorites in the first place.

description: With an eye to the November elections, to the 2000 Presidential campaign and perhaps to his own legacy, President Clinton has embarked on an aggressive drive to repair divisions between the liberal and moderate wings of the Democratic Party.

title: Ice Cream At the Churn
description: Marie Dell, holding a cone of coffee gelato as if it were the latest fashion accessory, glanced at the line waiting to order: a young mother with a bright red bob explaining what gelato is to her young daughters, and a handful of model-handsome men exchanging bites between cigarette puffs. ''It looks like the kind of crowd you'd see at an art opening,'' Ms. Dell said. But the throng on the sidewalk was not spilling out of a gallery; it was milling around NoLIta's most popular hole in the wall: the small window cut out of Ciao Bella, a factory at 262 Mott Street, which has been shipping malted-milk-ball ice cream, strawberry-rhubarb sorbet and 82 other exotic flavors to the Rainbow Room, the Lobster Club, Nobu and top restaurants around the country since 1991. ''The neighborhood has sprung up around the factory,'' said F. W. Pierce, an owner. Three years ago, when the sleepy neighborhood began to boom with sidewalk traffic, he blasted an opening through which he could sell directly to passers-by. Though Ciao Bella has since opened two retail stores in New York, the crowds still seem to prefer the factory. ''You really get the feeling it's being made specially for you somewhere in there beyond the window,'' Ms. Dell said, being careful not to drip. KIMBERLY STEVENS

title: Florida Tourism Goes On Despite Blanket of Smoke
description: Visitors to the Sunshine State this summer are being greeted by a new slogan: ''Florida in Flames.'' Since Memorial Day, thousands of wildfires have burned about a half million acres of mostly forest land and threatened some communities. But even with intermittent road closures and evacuations of residents, and cancellation of Fourth of July events in some areas, it's been business as usual at most attractions, parks and beaches, state tourism officials said -- even under a blanket of smoke.

title: An Althorp Pilgrim's Progress
description: WHAT a week to be in London. For sports fans, there was World Cup fever and Wimbledon; for rock fans, the Prince's Trust Concert. For the fashion pack (and me) it was the high season of sales -- 40 percent off at Harvey Nichols! And a chance to be among the first to make the pilgrimage to Althorp, the 8,500-acre ancestral home and final resting place of Diana, Princess of Wales.

title: Prostitution Still Thrives in the Shadows
description: The undoing of a now-infamous brothel at 335 West 39th Street was its own popularity, law enforcement officials said yesterday, noting that it had been so busy and brazen that it had prompted many anonymous complaints.

description: FOR Kennedy assassination buffs, it was the ultimate collectible. Sure, it had been played and replayed on television, but the actual raw footage of the motorcycles swinging into view and the limousines speeding by -- and, of course, the split second that fueled endless conspiracy theories -- was available only on bootleg copies.

title: Florida Fights New Skirmish In Its Battle With Medflies
description: For the second summer in a row, Florida is battling the devastatingly destructive Mediterranean fruit fly, a costly and frustrating struggle to keep the ruinous medfly from gaining a permanent foothold in the United States.

title: Courier and Martin Send U.S. to Semifinals
description: After 3 hours 30 minutes of combat, the United States decisively eliminated visiting Belgium, 3-0, this overheated afternoon in the Davis Cup quarterfinals. A last-minute doubles pairing of Jim Courier and Todd Martin, along with a fifth-set fadeout by Belgium's 11th-hour pairing of Johan Van Herck and 17-year-old Xavier Malisse, proved the turnkey.

description: Weeks

title: Visiting Iran
description: To the Editor: Two weeks after returning home from Iran I read the report ''U.S. Tour Companies Venture to Iran'' by Betsy Wade (June 14). My tour of three weeks covered 3,000 miles, almost entirely by bus.

title: Lives; The Secret Sharer
description: We were going to the country. We hardly ever went places, let alone the country, just the two of us, my mother and I. This was a very special outing, a visit, I was told by my nurse, who didn't know much more than that. A visit to someone who had asked to meet me, that was all. And the someone lived in a place with a pretty name: Larchmont.

title: A Very Bad and Good Afternoon
description: OF course the Mayor's mandate for civility is doomed. And it's not because our leader is so patently uncivil himself. It's because New York City doesn't need public behavior laws. The city imposes its own standards. Regard this cycle, from betrayal to redemption, played out on a recent afternoon in less than an hour in lower Manhattan.

title: Ideas & Trends: Patients' Rights; Getting Litigious With H.M.O.'s
description: DEMOCRATS hope to win back the House come November in part by backing a ''patient bill of rights,'' whose purpose is to compel managed health-care plans to take good -- rather than merely cheap -- care of their members. Last week, buckling under to election-year pressure, Republicans signed on grudgingly, issuing less sweeping proposals. The two parties, though, remain far apart on one important provision.

title: Topless Club's Good-Neighbor Policy
description: HAVE you ever been to a club like ours before?'' Jon Vargo asked. He noticed that I seemed torn between the ball game on the big-screen TV over the bar and the woman dancing on the stage, topless.

title: BOOKEND; He Heard America Singing
description: As a boy in Brooklyn in the 1920's, Alfred Kazin devoured novels, poetry, travelers' accounts and, most of all, books about American history, which he would later call ''the automatic part of all my reading.'' The present, Kazin remembered in ''A Walker in the City,'' was mean, but ''the past, the past was great: anything American, old, glazed, touched with dusk at the end of the 19th century, still smoldering with the fires lit by the Industrial Revolution, immediately set my mind dancing.'' Inside his school's assembly hall, a photographic portrait of Theodore Roosevelt stared down at him (''There was America, I thought, the real America''); outside an old police station on East New York Avenue, Kazin would daydream of the 1880's, certain that Roosevelt himself, back then the Police Commissioner, would momentarily come bounding down the steps. Years later, his literary ambitions aflame, Kazin stood on the corner of Fulton and Cranberry Streets, in front of the place where Walt Whitman himself had printed ''Leaves of Grass,'' ''thinking that I had at last opened the great trunk of forgotten time in New York in which I, too, I thought, would someday find the source of my unrest.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPSLEY, CLAUD A.

title: Correction

title: Saris American Style
description: There's a potent Indian masala on the streets this summer -- and it has nothing to do with food carts. New Yorkers can't seem to get enough of the spicy colors of India. Apron dresses, billowy skirts and pocket squares, all made of diaphanous silk and cotton sari fabrics, are selling out of stores from Madison Avenue to Alphabet City. At Katinka, 303 East Ninth Street, the apron dress (above) is the summer's hot specialty. Made of hand-woven cotton speckled with gold dots, the dress, $50 to $75, comes in a riot of Bombay colors and one size (suited to the long and lean). ''Fashion editors are buying them and keeping it a secret,'' said Jane Williams, an owner of Katinka. She noted that customers wear the saris dressy or cut down the flash with casual accessories. The apron dress can be worn with a tank top and sneakers; and one of Katinka's dirndl skirts, $80 to $120, can go with a short cropped T-shirt. Other sari wear to style up or down includes Tracy Feith's slip dresses (right) from his Raj collection, $130 to $350; hand-printed silk dresses at Linda Dresner, 484 Park Avenue (58th Street), and skirts, pants and camisoles at Anthropologie, 375 West Broadway (Broome Street).

title: Uniforms in the Closet
description: 'Don't ask, don't tell'' should be replaced with a phrase for a new century: ''Doesn't matter.''

title: Career Paths That No Guidance Counselor Suggested
description: BASEBALL gloves. Clean windows. Altar rails. Wool sweaters.

title: Have Kevlar, Will Travel: Turning a Stage Into a Rink
description: THE technology for creating large ice surfaces has been improving rapidly in recent years. It will take Don Yontz, an ice engineer, and his crew about 24 hours to create an ice surface for Next Ice Age's performances on the Reynolds Industries Theater's 60-by-48-foot stage. After setting up side and front boards and putting down a plastic vapor barrier on top of the stage floor to form the shallow ''tank,'' they lay down the ice mat, which consists of small pipes that carry a refrigerant and are covered by a sheet of Kevlar, the material used to make bulletproof vests.

title: Paying Tribute To Maine's No. 1 Summer Family
description: FROM the front window of a converted Methodist church here, Penobscot Bay glimmered pale blue in the hazy June afternoon. A huge roller was smoothing the street's new asphalt, and down the block a landscaper's backhoes tied up traffic. Inside, the church's old amber windowpanes lighted the stairwells like a golden sunrise. Workers hung paintings in its newly finished galleries. It felt as if the staff was rushing to finish a big summer house for the family's arrival; in fact, that is what was happening.

title: Appearances; Naked City
description: It occurred to me, while watching my husband watch underdressed nymphettes stroll by our table on Columbus Avenue, that the story of fashion in the 20th century has been one of attrition. It began with corsets and skirts down to the ankles; it is ending in slit skirts and see-through sweater sets. It's as if the clothing industry no longer believes in its primary reason for being, to cover the body. The beauty industry, in contrast, has gathered strength and confidence with each inch of newly bared skin. Once, its mission was to provide a little powder for the nose. Now it offers firming creams, makeup, glitter and crayons for improving and adorning the body electric.

title: 'Babylon 5' Enters Its Final Stages
description: The future is not utopian, if the science fiction series ''Babylon 5'' is any indication. By the mid-23d century, the people of Earth have been in at least two interstellar wars and encountered several other species, from the large-haired dandies called the Centauri and their former slaves, the reptilian Narn, to the enigmatic Vorlons, shrouded in elaborate ''encounter suits,'' and the technologically advanced Minbari.

title: Marblehead
description: To the Editor: The map with ''In a Storm, Not Just Any Port'' has a grievous omission. It shows the environs of Salem, with places like the Salem Witch Museum and Witch House, but not the Peabody Essex Museum. It's the morning of D-Day, June 6, 1944, just off Omaha Beach. Laden with rifles and unwieldy packs, some of the men pray, others are sick into their helmets. A few are visibly shaking. So far, this is pretty much the kind of re-enactment of the historic World War II landing that you would expect from a big Hollywood movie: a top star surrounded by lesser-known supporting players, with sumptuous visuals and state-of-the-art sound -- sentimental, safe.

The heavy box contains a nest of inexpensive jewelry that I have bought over the years, mostly in developing countries. Buried within the tangle is a complex webbing of silvery chains attached to rings -- a sort of hand armor that Indian brides wear at their weddings; though pretty, the piece is as restrictive as a set of brass knuckles. Equally immobilizing is the Afghan bracelet like a cast stretching half the length of my forearm, and the weighty necklace from Baluchistan that compels one to walk slowly to avoid the painful effects of its forceful bouncing.

title: A Visionary Looks at the Universe, and Paints
description: THE power of William Blake's poetry lies in the plainness that proves he was simply reporting on imaginative experiences as real to him as a sunflower. With their Blakean titles, the three series of six paintings each that make up Gregory Amenoff's exhibition ''The Sky Below'' at Rutgers University's branch here make similar appeal to visionary experience. But Mr. Amenoff's canny, careful way with paint reveals it to be an experience sought, perhaps overtaken, but not ineluctably suffered -- not the source, but the aim of his art.

title: Memphis Without Blue Suede Shoes
description: THINGS can go wrong when you travel. But I hate when things go wrong for me.

title: July 12-18; Secret Service Agents Testify in Clinton Inquiry
description: After months of legal wrangling, the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, finally won the opportunity to begin interrogating Secret Service agents about what they saw of President Clinton and Monica S. Lewinsky. The Administration lost its last-ditch effort to block the questioning when Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist turned down a request to postpone the testimony until the Supreme Court considered the matter when it returns next fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, EVELYN
description: SOLOMON-Evelyn. Beloved wife of Bernard. Devoted mother of Leslie, his wife, and four children. We miss her terribly and hope she is with her deceased parents, Dr. E. Wainess and wife Ethel.

title: State Wants Commuters Off Liberty Park Ferries
description: Mike Evelyn had loosened his tie and was dozing aboard the little yellow water taxi after a long day trading bonds in lower Manhattan as he commuted back across the Hudson River to Liberty State Park, and a 50-minute drive home. ''If you live in New Jersey, the ferry's great,'' said Mr. Evelyn, 38, of Far Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRISS, ALVIN
description: CHRISS-Alvin. At age 68. A unique man of great knowledge, wisdom and vision. He lived each day to the fullest with great plans for the future. His incredible wit is legendary to all who ever were in his presence. His wife of 48 years, Rachelle, his children, Lisa, Alan, Joel, Daniel, Jodi and Stephen, his grandchildren Leslie, David and Drew, have a lifetime of memories and a future inspired by his extraordinary character. He will be missed forever and loved for always. Donations to Jacob Perlow Hospice, NYC, in memory of Alvin Chriss.

title: Water's Fine, For Us And for Jellyfish
description: The good news is that the Natural Resource Defense Council's annual beach survey, which was released last week, confirms that the water quality off the New Jersey coast is continuing to improve and that the ocean the clearest it has been in years.

title: Mates for Fresh Corn: From Polenta and Peppers to Tomatoes
description: THE corn season has started. Though fresh corn on the cob shipped from the South has been improving steadily over the years, in midsummer there is nothing quite like the local crop.

title: A Warm and Fuzzy Precinct House
description: Many of New York's older police station houses seem modeled on medieval castles, with turrets, towers and thick masonry walls that convey the message, ''Keep out.'' But in Washington Heights, where relations between the police and residents have been strained and more over the years, a new station for the 33d Precinct is designed to make the public feel welcome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEUBSDORF, BERTHA BOSCHWITZ
description: LEUBSDORF-Bertha Boschwitz. Died at the age of 90 on July 17, 1998. Dear wife of the late Karl Leubsdorf, caring mother of Carl and John Leubsdorf, proud and loving grandmother. Trained as a mathematician at a time when few women entered that field, with degrees from Hunter College and Columbia University, she devoted herself for many years to volunteer service for those in need. She was President of the Hunter Scholarship and Welfare Fund, Board member of the Hunter College Foundation, receiving an honorary degree from Hunter. She was also Secretary and Trustee of the Hospital for Joint Diseases, and President of that hospital's Women's Auxiliary. She loved all the arts, and was glad to have endowed the Karl and Bertha Leubsdorf Gallery at Hunter. Her family and friends will remember her as witty, capable, cultured, active, generous, devoted, and a good friend. Funeral service 11:30 AM, Monday, July 20, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Hunter Scholarship and Welfare Fund, 695 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10021-5085.

title: Liberties; Hillary's House of Mirth
description: On her tour of American landmarks last week, Hillary Rodham Clinton visited Edith Wharton's chateau, known as the Mount, in the Berkshires.

title: Mariah Ford, Courtney Brown
description: Mariah Hope Ford, a daughter of Mary Hope Lewis and Frank R. Ford 3d, both of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Courtney Ware Pierce Brown, a son of Betty Brown, also of Greenwich, and Stewart P. Brown of New York.

description: To the Editor: About the article ''When Flying Isn't an Option'' (Practical Traveler, June 14): All that transferring on buses isn't an option either. I am referring to all those over-75'ers who are not able to handle the connections and layovers, although I realize sometimes they just cannot be avoided.

We will always remember him for his keen interest in promoting closer United States-Chilean relations. Our heartfelt condolences to his family. John N. Myers, President

title: Don't Blink, Next Sprinting Star Is Within View
description: Marion Jones calls it simply ''the Day,'' and she has imagined its every moment and every nuance. She created it as a sculpture of the imagination on which she has labored -- lovingly, perhaps a bit obsessively -- until she now firmly believes it will all emerge, given time.

title: William Bertsche, Translator Of Documents, Is Dead at 79
description: William I. Bertsche, who had such a rapid-fire way with recondite words that he spent his life rattling off more than a dozen languages into English, died on July 11 at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. A resident of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., he was 79 and had been one of the nation's leading document translators for more than half a century.

title: C.D.C. Issues Warning  On Virus in Taiwan
description: A widespread viral illness on Taiwan that can be fatal to infants and young children poses some risk to international travelers, according to the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The virus causes a hand, foot and mouth disease that is identified by sores in the mouth and rashes on the palm of the hand and soles of the feet. Meningitis, encephalitis or a poliolike paralysis may follow. Sixty children under 3 years of age on Taiwan had died by July 7. The risk of death to visitors was described as ''very small''; the death rate in the age group in Taiwan was 1 in 10,000.

title: John Birknes, Emily Rheinfrank
description: Emily Lyman Rheinfrank, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lamson Rheinfrank Jr. of Kansas City, Mo., was married yesterday to John Kurt Birknes, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Birknes Jr. of South Dartmouth, Mass. The Rev. Peter T. Elvin performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Thompson Memorial Chapel at Williams College in Williamstown, Mass. The couple are Williams graduates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMAHON, ELIZABETH (BETTY
description: McMAHON-Elizabeth (Betty). Of New Canaan, CT. Devoted wife of Edward. Beloved mother to five stepchildren. Also survived by nine grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations to Bennett Cancer Center, Shelburne Rd., Stamford, CT. For info. call F. Hoyt Funeral Home, 199 Main St., New Canaan.

title: Prints, French Artists and Women
description: THE first half of this century was the golden age of American realist prints, but a full picture of the graphic art of the era has not been presented in a long time.

title: Putting a New Face on Justice
description: PICTURE a courthouse rotunda: sanctuary of law, cynosure of the community. Now pull it out of the building and set it in front, as an entrance. Taper it, tilt its central axis 3 1/2 degrees and top it with four square fins. Clad it in a sleek white sheath.

title: July 12-18; No Relief From Heat Wave
description: A heat wave across the South and West has resulted in the deaths of more than 50 people in Texas, Louisiana and Oklahoma, most of them elderly. Dallas has had nearly two weeks of 100-degree heat, with predictions of more of the same into this week. The heat and drought have caused an estimated $1.5 billion in damage to the state's cattle herds and crops, a figure approaching the $1.9 billion in losses resulting from a drought in the region just two years ago.

title: In Ulster, Still Horror, Still Hope
description: The premise of Northern Ireland's halting passage to a more secure future is that political solutions offer a way forward for tribal societies in continual combat. But at each point that assumption is being starkly challenged.

description: Elizabeth Dorothy Ward and Manuel Cuprill Jr. were married on Friday by the Rev. Eugene Callender, a Presbyterian minister, in a nondenominational ceremony at the Manhattan Penthouse.

title: How About Us? Middle Class Asks the Police
description: There was the house party in Rosedale, Queens, that began at 10 P.M. but lasted until 3:30 A.M., when the police were finally able to disperse the 700 guests and silence the refrigerator-size stereo speakers. And there was the bloody fistfight over a fender bender that snarled traffic on Richmond Avenue on Staten Island for 20 minutes until officers arrived.

description: A KILLING FROST

title: Anger Is Shaking a Dead Nigerian's Town to Its Foundations
description: Beneath the chaos of Nigeria lie the African anchors of custom and tribal tradition. But the shattering of a taboo here in the hometown of the late opposition leader, Moshood K. O. Abiola, has suggested that even these bulwarks are vulnerable to the country's angry mood.

title: Crime
description: Ever the master of form and sorcerer of style, Reginald Hill takes his Dalziel and Pascoe procedural series to highest ground with ON BEULAH HEIGHT (Delacorte, $22.95). Part murder mystery, part meditation on the love and loss of children, the disturbing narrative keeps us baffled on the one count while touching deep, distressing feelings on the other.

title: OPINION; A Spider, a Cricket and the Sea
description: WHEN my father reminisces about World War II, he always mentions the spider-vs.-cricket fights when he was stationed in the South Pacific. Placed inside a mesh cage, the two critters were pitted against each other while the men bet on their favorite.

title: Lloyd Webber Still Has Trouble Whistling Dixie
description: FOR some while now, Andrew Lloyd Webber has been planning what he calls a ''continuation'' of ''The Phantom of the Opera.'' But isn't that what his new musical, ''Whistle Down the Wind'' at the Aldwych Theater, could be said to be?

title: July 12-18; Lockheed Calls Off Merger
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation, the nation's largest military contractor, and the Northrop Grumman Corporation called off their proposed $8.3 billion merger, ending a wave of consolidations that has reshaped the defense industry since the early 1990's.

title: Tours and Museum  Focus on Aborigines
description: Travelers interested in Australia's aboriginal heritage can view traditional dances at the new National Aboriginal Cultural Center, scheduled to open in early August in the Darling Harbor section of Sydney. The center houses the most extensive collection of artifacts of the country's 200 aboriginal tribes, including some of the earliest rock art dating back at least 50,000 years. Other relics include masks, boomerangs, dancing sticks, fishing spears and colorfully painted didgeridoos, flute-like instruments made of eucalyptus wood. Artists and craftsmen from various tribal nations work at the center, open 9:30 A.M. to 8 P.M. daily. Dance performances take place at 11 A.M. and 1, 4 and 6 P.M. Admission, which includes performances, is $18.

title: Snake: It's What's For Dinner
description: Congratulations to Mark Brest van Kempen for his prolonged ''survival days'' (Sunday: ''Snake: It's What's for Dinner,'' June 28). My mother, an anthropologist, imposed on our family a weekly survival day. This usually fell on Mondays, and we had to forage for foods that grew naturally in the area surrounding our home.

title: Show Made of Driftwood and Rusty Metal
description: A SCULPTOR who is a university professor in Pusan, Korea, Kim Kwang Woo is on a sabbatical in the United States -- or he was until a countryman, also a sculptor, told him it was unthinkable for him to visit this country without exhibiting his work.

description: There was no way that Teresa Weatherspoon was going to let the Liberty lose this afternoon.

title: Special-Effects Specialist
description: Even among film buffs who know that C.G.I. stands for ''computer generated imagery,'' Kenneth Perlin is no household name, even though his work is what makes some part of ''Armageddon'' or ''Small Soldiers'' or the next special-effects extravaganza possible. Mr. Perlin won a 1997 Academy Award for technical achievement for his work in computer graphics and heads New York University's Center for Advanced Technology, which develops computer approaches that might be useful for industry.

description: CHARLES VAN NOSTRAND keeps on counting. It's not really his job, but then Mr. Van Nostrand is the president of Samuel French Inc., the publishing and licensing organization for ''La Cage Aux Folles,'' a very hot musical.

title: The Bane Of Every Vacation: Souvenirs
description: EVEN the happiest summer trip has a dark cloud of anxiety hanging over it. What to get for Aunt Ethel, who looked after the cats? What about the cats themselves? We MUST take something back for mother. And dare we forget the lawn person, the chiropractor, and all the people we love to hate at the office?

title: Cleaning Tips To Help the Sound
description: Long Island Sound could be healthier if people would think about what goes down their sinks. (''A Healthier Sound, Issue for Both Shores,'' June 28.) You can clean your sink, walls, floors and bath using one cup of water and one cup of white vinegar with two tablespoons of Murphy's soap in a spray bottle. Baking soda will clean pots and pans and your stove. I urge everyone to try these easy methods as most commercial cleaners are very bad for the environment.

title: Two Mediums Make Like One
description: ONLY a few years ago, John Lithgow was appalled at the notion of appearing in a television series. A character actor with a respectable theater and film career, Mr. Lithgow viewed the prospect of appearing on television with a disdain largely typical among his acting friends. It was a medium that most serious actors -- and writers and directors -- left, not entered; a refuge for, let's face it, actors and filmmakers whose careers had hit a brick wall.

description: IN visits to Suffolk County to promote his plan for the $7.3 billion partial state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company, Gov. George E. Pataki never missed a chance to extol one key benefit.

description: State Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Democrat from Greenburgh, has initiated a statewide investigation through the Commission on Quality of Care for the Mentally Disabled on how 26 developmentally disabled adults ended up in homeless shelters in Westchester this spring. The independent, federally financed agency will investigate not only why the situation in Westchester occurred and but also whether it exists in other areas of the state.

title: Murdoch
description: Some sons bond with their fathers through baseball, some through fishing. But for Lachlan Murdoch and his father, Rupert, there has only ever been the Business. As a child in London, Lachlan remembers his mother waking him for predawn breakfasts before his father jetted off. As a schoolboy in Manhattan, he recalls nights up late, listening to his father at the dinner table hashing out strategies with famous guests.

title: Finding the Edge Where Sport Ends And Dance Begins
description: A dozen skaters wearing simple black practice clothes are gliding with precision and concentration up and down a suburban Maryland ice rink. For a while they move in groups of four. Then their leader, a boyish, mild-mannered but intensely focused young man, demonstrates an intricate sequence including several shifts of balance and an elegant spiral. The skaters soon follow suit, performing the moves one by one under his watchful eye.

title: Powerboats, Picket Lines: Strikers Are Getting By
description: THE auto workers who have been walking picket lines outside two General Motors parts factories here for the last six weeks receive just $150 a week in strike benefits from their union, a paltry sum that conjures up images of workers living on bologna sandwiches and worrying that their houses and cars might soon be repossessed.

title: The Nation; Tales From the Front Line of Sexual Harassment
description: SEXUAL harassment laws have always been notoriously confusing, so there was much cheering when the Supreme Court clarified things by issuing new harassment guidelines last month.

description: Al Leiter took the mound at Shea Stadium yesterday afternoon for the first time since he partially tore a tendon in his left knee against the Yankees on June 26.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; A Family Grows With Each Summer
description: Barbara and Lloyd Horst's children do not live at home anymore, but it is obvious that the couple's cluttered living room remains a den for children.

title: Overheard Between Floors
description: What is it about an elevator? Everyone knows that it's impossible not to overhear or be overheard in what is really just a walk-in closet with wanderlust. But on any given workday you might hear all or part of some extraordinary conversations on the office elevator: bizarre tales, stunning revelations, head-scratching non sequiturs. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Dutch Say A Sex Ring Used Infants On Internet
description: In a case that investigators called nauseating, the Dutch police say they have discovered a ring of traders in child pornography whose images of abuse of even babies and infants were peddled via the Internet and other media to clients in Europe, Russia and the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHARF, WILLIAM A.
description: SCHARF-William A. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of William A. Scharf, associated with The Times from 1948, until retiring in 1976.

title: CD Player as Time Machine: Voices Echo Across Decades
description: ALL through the 1970's and until the LP era wound to a calculated close in the mid-80's, voice aficionados reveled in a deluge of reissues. On series like Columbia Odyssey, RCA Victrola and, especially, EMI References and HMV Treasury, the voices of esteemed but long-dead singers were revived, and new listeners were exposed to the glories of Galli-Curci and Rethberg, Gigli and Thill, Battistini and Schorr. But the digital era changed all that, as the major labels lost interest in such esoteric fare. Small labels with limited resources picked up some of the slack, but their efforts, though worthy, hardly compared with what had gone before.

description: A national identity is forged from many things, not the least of which is food. Would France still be France without steak au poivre? Would Chinese civilization have endured without Peking duck? A culture, after all, is only as strong as the language, religion, folk traditions and foods that bind it.

description: Auntie Mame, one of the top fillies in the country last year but a disappointment this year, came racing back to star status yesterday when she outran Tresoriere in a tense homestretch duel to win the 55th running of the New York Handicap by a length at Belmont Park.

description: BASEBALL

title: How Does Her Garden Grow? Don't Ask
description: I HAVE always heard that zucchini is the easiest vegetable to grow, that come August all zucchini farmers, amateurs included, are so overrun by it they're ready to swear off ratatouille for life. My only zucchini experience, five years ago, was different. I planted my crop, went on to other things, and one midsummer night dreamed that there was a giant zucchini lying in my garden. Freud might make more of this, but my dream was quite literal. There was a zucchini lying in my garden.

title: Fast Forward; Control Freaks
description: A little window into bill gates's soul opened the day the Microsoft antitrust negotiations broke down for good. The light came from a plaintive comment by an anonymous Microsoft executive, who was trying to explain why it would just be so unfair if the Government were to let computer makers substitute their own start-up screens for the Windows ''desktop'' -- especially screens that gave users an alternative way to run their software.

title: A 50-Year Trek Through the Territory of the Mind
description: ''HE just thought it was awful, nowheresville,'' William S. Burroughs said of Edmonton, the boyhood home of his great friend and collaborator Brion Gysin. Indeed, when a 16-year-old Gysin boarded a cattle car and headed east, he left behind this land of his ''exile'' and never looked back.

title: Time to Tone Down Rhetoric on Lilco
description: Re: the continuing debate over Lilco, Shoreham and the LIPA deal -- it's O.K. to argue that crimes were committed, but to do so without any specifies while tossing around generalities like ''massive crimes'' doesn't help.

title: Threatened Species, Threatened Livelihood
description: A SOLITARY predator, the regal swordfish once ruled the Atlantic, its broad bill a weapon so lethal that larger specimens -- they can exceed 1,000 pounds -- have been known to slash a hull in half. The species held its own against harpooners and rod-and-reel fishermen. But more than 30 years after the introduction of a new and more efficient method of catching these majestic and tasty creatures, the hunter has become so heavily hunted that Bill Akin, a Montauk fisherman, says it's a race to see ''who can catch the last fish first.''

title: Party Is Torn On Race Issue In Connecticut
description: Connecticut Democrats chose United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly as their candidate for governor today at a convention where her nomination was overshadowed by the awkward question of whether the party should include an African-American on its slate of seven statewide candidates.

description: Madeline

title: When Blues Guitar Is the Bond
description: Sure, the East Village film maker Mark Trottenberg had heard of the guitarist Bobby Radcliff. Over the years, he had seen him perform at places like Fat Tuesday's, and he even had all of his albums. So when he saw Mr. Radcliff's flier advertising guitar lessons, he wondered: Did he have the courage to ask him to be his teacher?

description: THE day after Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto resigned, adding politics to the list of Japan's financial and economic woes, one of the country's leading financial newspapers topped its front page with this headline: ''The Time Has Come to Buy Japan!''

title: Where the Wine Gets the Top Billing
description: A RESTAURANT in the wine country of the North Fork that calls itself Coeur des Vignes (heart of the vineyards) is making a statement: It is serious about wine. A glance at its listings confirms this. There are about 70 selections and they are not the usual cast of characters. Best of all, about a third of them cost $20 or less, a pricing policy any restaurant could follow but few do, especially on the East End where wine prices are routinely inflated. But wine, like everything else at Coeur des Vignes, is a hit-and-miss affair.

Thomas Leonard is to perform the ceremony at Mother Cabrini Chapel in New York.

title: Curious Comfort In the Traditional Art Of Quilting
description: QUILTS being created by artists these days have sometimes stolen the limelight, but the old-fashioned quilts that were their harbingers still have their followers.

description: Line up the usual suspects, toss them into the air and see where they land. Texas? Anaheim? Cleveland? San Francisco?

description: IT'S blimp season in New York. One by one, the giant lolling billboards of corporate America are floating slowly north in their annual migration to the city, home to more potential eyes to the skies than perhaps anywhere else in America.

title: Preserves
description: Advancing the theory that no anniversary goes unmarked, we have been notified that 1998 is the 140th anniversary of the invention of the Mason jar. This is no small thing to the Federation of Historic Bottle Collectors, which has organized an exhibition of 169 rare fruit jars - many of them Mason jars and many made in South Jersey - at the Museum of American Glass at Wheaton Village in Millville. For the first 60 years of production the glass jars with screw threads on the neck were embossed with ''Mason's Patent Nov. 30th 1858.'' Three in the show were actually manufactured that year. (The oldest, non-Mason, jars in the show are from 1835.) There are variations in color - opaque black, apricot and cobalt blue are among the hues - and size, including a single-oyster-size jar made in Phildalphia in 1876.

title: A Spoof Keeps Pace With Broadway's Excesses and Egos
description: GERARD ALESSANDRINI sat quietly in his seat at the Minskoff Theater, ruminating on the strange spectacle before him. ''Into the fire!'' sang a swarm of English aristocrats, prancing madly around the stage in ''The Scarlet Pimpernel.'' Mr. Alessandrini studied the scene with the focused air of a junkman scrutinizing the wreck of a 1959 Plymouth and wondering what it might be worth if broken down for parts.

Inside the two-bedroom bungalow, her husband lay bleeding from a self-inflicted knife wound.

title: Law School for Janet Reno
description: By studying the transcript of last week's Senate Judiciary Committee hearing, it is possible to reconstruct one of the more remarkable internal documents of the Clinton Administration. That is the tightly reasoned, 27-page legal memorandum in which Louis Freeh, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, told Attorney General Janet Reno that she was failing in her duty to appoint an independent counsel to investigate President Clinton's fund-raising.

title: Bilingual Education
description: A Yonkers school trustee failed in an attempt to preserve bilingual education for prekindergarten students when the matter came to a vote by the Board of Education Wednesday. His resolution countering a plan by other school board members to eliminate the classes was defeated. The proposal to stop offering bilingual education in prekindergarten was then passed.

title: When Artistry Plays Second Fiddle to Hype
description: THANKS to a body that does not age and a snarl that is ageless, Mick Jagger has managed to enter his 50's without seeming a parody of his Rolling Stones persona. But the bad girl of the violin, now 37, may not be so lucky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSNIAK, ABRAHAM O.
description: POSNIAK-Abraham O., MD. Of Bal Harbour, FL. and Manhattan. Departed from this life the 14th of July, 1998. He leaves his wife Hanna and their children, Robert and Erica, and three grandchildren. Service Sunday the 19th of July at 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: When It Comes to Softball Age (Almost) Doesn't Matter
description: JACK and Mary Siff were out at the ball diamond the other evening, watching their son Sandy's game. Sandy has been playing since he was 8 years old. But this has been a rough season for his team, and the two parents were the only spectators.

title: INVESTING WITH: Pedro Marcal And Eswar Menon; Nicholas-Applegate Emerging Countries Fund
description: FOR Pedro Marcal and Eswar Menon, both aggressive chess players, an exit from Asia was a bit like the unexpected moves that had clinched many a match. But here the stakes were much higher than in a Sunday afternoon face-off at the chessboard. The two men, co-managers of the Nicholas-Applegate Emerging Countries fund, knew that a wrong decision would hit shareholders hard.

description: AS if you didn't have enough to worry about, public television will now remind you that, geologically speaking, the earth is hazardous to your health, and there's not much you can do about it.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: James Collard; The Corner Of Straight And Gay
description: JAMES COLLARD had declined an invitation to a Bastille Day blowout for the designer Michael Kors. His idea of a night well spent was a quiet dinner someplace small and chic -- Restaurant Boughalem on Bedford Street fitted the bill. Afterward, he wanted cocktails someplace civilized. He pictured a bar that was not too crowded, not too empty, not too gay, not too straight.

description: SUMMER SISTERS By Judy Blume. Delacorte, $21.95.

description: New Yorkers tend to be proud of their neighborhoods. Who wouldn't tell strangers, perhaps with a certain self-satisfaction, that they reside in graceful Gramercy, trendy TriBeCa or the fabulous Flatiron? But people whose district has no appellation must borrow from their neighbors or make up a name.

title: The World: Achtung! English Spoken Here.; In Europe, Steps Toward a Common Language
description: UNCERTAIN whose side financial history was on, Britain declined earlier this year to abandon its venerable currency, the pound sterling, for the euro, the new currency of the European Union. But while the pound and its keepers at the Bank of England are not represented at the shiny new European Central Bank in Frankfurt, in the heart of Deutsche mark territory, Britain is a presence nonetheless. When the new bank's board holds its regular meetings, the language its 11 members use is English.

title: Sports and the Arts at Gay Games in Amsterdam
description: Amsterdam, one of Europe's gay capitals, is anticipating an influx of more than 200,000 people for the fifth Gay Games -- the first to be held outside North America. From Aug. 1 to 8, 15,000 participants from 64 countries will compete in 29 sports events and take part in 14 artist's workshops.

title: Robo-Shots
description: For several years, Graham Hawkes, an engineer based in Point Richmond, Calif., has been trying to interest investors in his Deep Flight submersible, a one-person submarine that in theory would allow plucky explorers to scoot down to the deepest parts of the ocean. The prototype is ready but . . . the R&D money just isn't rolling in. ''I still need about $7 million,'' Hawkes says.

His 100th year should work out somewhat better, even if the birthday is posthumous.

title: An Annual Appraisal of the Urge to Innovate
description: THIS year's edition of the New Jersey Arts Annual at the Montclair Art Museum doesn't just stand (or hang) there decorously. Some of the work is sharp and direct, while other pieces challenge through subtlety and indirection. Although the work mostly stays within traditional, recognizable genres and media, the 47 artists share an urge to innovate.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 5 about the Italian hill town of Loreto referred incorrectly to its geography and to that of the surrounding Marches region. Loreto is in central Italy, not southern. In addition, the boundaries for The Marches are Emilia-Romagna to the north and Abruzzi to the south, not Veneto and Apulia.

description: The revitalization of Fifth Avenue in Park Slope continues, albeit in fits and starts. Though many storefronts remain boarded up, an astonishing number of new businesses have opened recently.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNELL, PATRICIA S.
description: O'CONNELL-Patricia S. Died suddenly Thursday evening, July 16th, 1998 at her home on Cove Hollow Road in Easthampton, New York. Beloved wife of John J. O'Connell, a former Vice President for industrial relations at Bethlehem Steel. Loving mother of Ryan, Matthew, Micaela, Carey, Colin and Timothy; grandmother of Charles, Lucy, Elizabeth, Kevin, Logan, & Jack; sister of Barbara. The O'Connells began summering in Easthampton in 1954 and became year-round residents in 1984. A former reporter and writer for Life Magazine, Time Inc., Pat O'Connell became a real estate broker when she moved to Easthampton. The family will receive visitors on Sunday, July 19th from 3 P.M. to 5 P.M. at The Williams Funeral Home, Newtown Lane, Easthampton. A Mass of Resurrection will be held at Most Holy Trinity Church at 9:30AM, Monday, July 20 followed by burial at The Most Holy Trinity Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOROCK, NATHAN
description: BOROCK-Nathan. Former Assistant U.S. Attorney of Eastern District. Cherished and beloved husband of 57 years to Sylvia (nee Goldberg). Died at home on July 17, 1998. title: Bassist-Photographer's Jazz
description: MILT HINTON not only played alongside some of the century's jazz greats, he photographed them as well. His photographic career began in the 1930's when a friend gave him a camera. And six decades later, this celebrated bass player has taken more than 60,000 images depicting musicians on the road, in the recording studio, at parties and at home. Fifty of his photographs will be shown at the 92d Street Y in a retrospective that begins on Tuesday.

title: Still Waiting
description: 'I've never felt like anybody wanted me dead before,'' says Kendall Morrison, a 35-year-old New Yorker with AIDS. But an unnamed Michigan investor who purchased Morrison's life-insurance policies in 1993 surely did. Earlier this year, the investor threatened to sue the broker who sold him the policies for fraud and breach of contract. He was upset that, five years later, Morrison was still alive.

title: Books and Authors With Roots on the Island; Advice on Caring For Seriously Ill
description: BY the time Philip Bashe started to write, with Rodger McFarlane, ''The Complete Bedside Companion: No-Nonsense Advice on Caring for the Seriously Ill'' (Simon & Schuster), he had already been co-author of three books on medical issues. But the 44-year-old Mr. Bashe, who grew up in Jericho, began his writing career in a very different field: rock music. His first books were ''Rolling Stone Rock Almanac'' and ''Heavy Metal Thunder.''

title: At $117, Dell's Price Does Not Compute
description: It's Dell-lightful, it's Dell-lectable, it's Dell-lovely.

title: Alvin Chriss, 68, Who Created A Way to Pay Track Athletes
description: Alvin Chriss, a New York lawyer and sports administrator who created the system that allowed track and field athletes around the world to be paid, died on Friday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 68 years old.

title: Speculating on Science, Hitler and the Bomb
description: WHY did Werner Heisenberg, the German who formulated the uncertainty principle, pay a visit to Niels Bohr, the Dane who made key discoveries in quantum theory, in the occupied Copenhagen of 1941? A layman might think this the sort of topic that history-of-science students come up with when their search for a doctoral thesis is getting desperate. Yet the meeting of the two Nobel Prize-winning physicists could help explain why you and I are not now living in a world controlled by Son of Hitler and his cybernetic Gestapo. It certainly supplies Michael Frayn with the material for one of the boldest, meatiest plays the Royal National Theater has staged this decade: ''Copenhagen.''

title: Woman Is Thrown to Her Death From Roof of Housing Project
description: A young woman, gagged with duct tape, was thrown to her death from the roof of a 21-story housing project in the Bronx yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: When the Secret Service Talks
description: On Friday, Secret Service officers were summoned before a grand jury investigating the President they protect. They appeared after Chief Justice William Rehnquist refused to extend a court order blocking their testimony, ending a tug of war between the Justice Department and Kenneth Starr, the independent counsel. Here, some experts discuss the implications.

title: Britons Govern Their Own Retirements
description: Shelagh Wellbelove, a retired secretary from just outside London, lives on about $1,000 a month. That is enough, she said, to take vacations, pay for a car and generally live comfortably, especially since she paid off her mortgage. And it seems perfectly fair to her that most of the money comes from her own savings and investment, with Britain's version of Social Security kicking in less than half.

title: Uniforms in the Closet
description: Anyone who has ever been in the service knows there is one person in the military you can discriminate against: a coward. In a two-year hitch in the Army I never saw any cowards, and I certainly saw none in your article. The soldiers and sailors in your story wear the same uniform, take the same risks and salute the same flag we all do. What they deserve is our respect.

title: At Funeral Home Billboard, Death Takes a Holiday
description: It has been said that in every parting there is an image of death. In this case, the parting was the image of death itself. For several weeks, a billboard for Combat roach traps, featuring the Grim Reaper under the slogan ''Got death?'' hung on the side of the Buen Pastor Funeral Home, at Second Avenue and Second Street. The ad's proximity to the funeral parlor flummoxed mourners and pedestrians. But the specter of death passed on recently, replaced by an American Red Cross ad. Ismael Miranda opened the show with an exhibition of pure Puerto Rican salsa; he grew up on the Lower East Side of Manhattan and now lives in Puerto Rico. La India, also of Puerto Rican extraction, also of Manhattan but several generations younger, put on a pure show of synthetic music, borrowing from American pop and gospel styles, all integrated into the improvisational framework of salsa. In her hands, the form seemed endlessly expandable, built to reflect what it means to grow up within the torrent of cultures that make up New York.

In four of these cases there was some publicity about the judges' conduct before the commission investigated. However, none of the publicity -- except in the case of Judge Duckman -- could be called notorious.
