description: Stung by his Parliament's rejection of tax-and-spending reforms widely seen as the only way out of Russia's fiscal tailspin, President Boris N. Yeltsin did this weekend what he had long threatened: He decreed reforms on his own.

title: Cultural Modernity and Its Gifts of Grace and Struggle
description: ''This is a precious piece of Chinese culture,'' proclaimed the Shanghai Cultural Minister, Ma Bomin , of the opera ''The Peony Pavilion,'' before preventing it from traveling to the Lincoln Center Festival. She accused the production of distorting the 500-year-old work by displaying a skewed vision of China and grafting on to it ''pornographic'' elements. The implication? That it was sullied by an American perspective.

title: Mayor Plans Changes in Welfare System
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani plans to propose significant changes to New York City's welfare system in a speech today, an aide said last night. The Mayor's schedule for today did not disclose the topic but called the speech a ''major policy address''. The speech is scheduled for noon in the executive dining room of a bank in midtown Manhattan.

title: Giuliani Tells Sex-Based Shops That the End Is Drawing Near
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that sex shops and strip clubs violating the city's tough new zoning law could be shut down beginning tomorrow, and he warned businesses that last-minute changes -- like dressing dancers in T-shirts or bikinis -- might not help them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEO, JOSEPH U.
description: SEO-Joseph U. Of Rumson, NJ. Formerly of New York and Japan. On July 18, 1998. Husband of Betty (nee Haines) Seo. Father of Joseph Seo, Karen Seo and Janice Seo. Grandfather of Alexis Seo. Arrangements private. The family requests that memorial donations be made to The American Cancer Society, NJ Division, Inc., Monmouth Unit, 1540 Rt. 138, Suite 303, Wall, NJ 07719.

title: Teachers Pursuing Quality Control
description: John Cole, president of the Texas Federation of Teachers, objects to what he says has been the most widely used test to become a public school teacher: the thermometer test. ''If you register above 97 degrees, you pass,'' he lamented.

title: Can a Judge Abuse A Fake Lawyer?
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Ulysses' at Top As Panel Picks 100 Best Novels
description: ''Ulysses,'' that sprawling, difficult, but uniquely original masterpiece by James Joyce, has been voted the finest English-language novel published this century by a jury of scholars and writers.

title: Saturn Workers Vote to Authorize Strike
description: Workers at the General Motors Corporation's Saturn factory, which was once a model of cooperation between labor and management, voted overwhelmingly today to authorize their leaders to call a strike to protest G.M.'s moves this spring to buy more auto parts from outside suppliers.

title: I.M.F. Austerity May Deepen Crises; Global Slowdown
description: To the Editor:

title: A Victory In Mahwah Is a Boost For Graf
description: The situation was hardly unfamiliar to Steffi Graf, standing before an adoring crowd at center court with an oversized champion's trophy in her hands. But the first question asked while she stood there seemed to catch her off guard. It seemed simple enough, ''Is Graf back?''

title: Like Father, Like Son, In Judgment of U.A.W.
description: Few cities are as lastingly seared by a single event as Flint has been by the sit-down strikes in early 1937, a violent showdown between the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers that led to the union's first contract to represent the workers of a major auto maker.

title: Favorite Trick Rediscovers Winning
description: Favorite Trick, the 1997 juvenile champion and Horse of the Year, won the Long Branch Stakes by a head at Monmouth Park yesterday in his first appearance since he finished eighth in the Kentucky Derby two and a half months ago.

title: Familiar Faces Fall Just Behind
description: A handful of golfers left today's British Open dealing with deep disappointment.

title: In a Playoff, O'Meara Finds Another Blossom
description: Moments after Mark O'Meara captured a thrilling and memorable British Open today, his wife, Alicia, was asked why her husband is having his best year at age 41.

title: Political Briefing; Race Matters, a Lot, For Florida Democrats
description: Florida Democrats are moving to end the raw racial rift that threatens to cripple their party in this fall's elections and leave it weaker than at any point in more than a century. But is the move too little, too late?

title: Debate Grows Over the Role An Operating System Plays
description: Ask 10 computer scientists to state which features define an operating system, and you will probably get 10 different answers. Ask what those features will be four years from now, and the responses will range from some vague variation on the status quo to visions of vast, potent networks that empower individual computers with a sort of communal energy.

title: Family Life With a Vengeance
description: The facts are incomplete. The allegations have not yet been sifted nor indictments handed down. Still unknown is the fate of Irene Silverman, the wealthy widow who disappeared in early July from her East 65th Street town house. But already the story has shifted from the potentially tragic mystery of Mrs. Silverman's whereabouts to the strange lives of the only pair of suspects in this case -- Sante Kimes, 63, and her 23-year-old son, Kenneth, who were arrested in Manhattan on another matter the same day Mrs. Silverman vanished.

title: Holyfield Scoffs at Facing Jones
description: The heavyweight champion Evander Holyfield said today that he had no interest in fighting Roy Jones Jr., the newly crowned World Boxing Association light-heavyweight titlist, who has been hinting that he can be a distinguished heavyweight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYONS, JOHN THOMAS
description: LYONS-John Thomas. On July 16, 1998, of complications from Wegner's Granuloumatosa. Husband of Barbara Ann Dooley. Father of John (Sean) Lyons and father-inlaw of Mary O'Callahan, wife of Sean, and grandfather of Clodagh Lyons, granddaughter, all of Dublin, Ireland. And father of Bridgett and Brendan Lyons, Atlanta, GA. Son of Helene Lyons, East Hampton, NY, and brother of William Lyons, New York City, NY, and Mary Ellen McGuire, East Hampton, NY. On Thursday, July 23, from 6 to 9 PM, the family will receive friends at Green Funeral Home, 721 Elden St, Herndon, VA. A Mass of the Resurrection will be offered at 11 AM, Friday, July 24, at St. Thomas a'Becket Catholic Church, 1421 Wiehle Ave, Reston, VA. Interment private. Memorials may be made to the National Air and Space Museum, Attn: Joe Suarez, MRC 310, Suite 3731, Washington, DC 20560.

title: I.M.F. Austerity May Deepen Crises; An Incentive to Shop
description: To the Editor;

title: Robber Is Fatally Shot By Victim in Chinatown
description: What began as an attempted robbery in the elevator of a Chinatown apartment building early yesterday morning turned into a fatal scuffle, in which the would-be victim grabbed his assailant's gun and shot him once in the chest, killing him instantly, according to the police.

title: Tucuman Journal; An Out-of-Step Kind of Place Stands by Its Man
description: Antonio Domingo Bussi, the barrel-chested, cigar-chomping Governor here in this tiny northwestern province, has been getting a lot of bad press lately.

title: Nuclear Security for Sale
description: An ingenious arrangement that has encouraged Russia to convert its stockpiles of bomb grade uranium into much less dangerous civilian reactor fuel and earn precious cash in the process could soon be undone. The Clinton Administration, in a move that could easily disable the arrangement, is planning to sell off the United States Enrichment Corporation, the Government-owned company in charge of buying the Russian uranium.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENJAMIN, RANDI (HENSEL
description: BENJAMIN-Randi (Hensel). Colorado Springs, formerly Woodmere, NY. On July 19, after a ten year battle with cancer. Daughter of the late Norma and Zachary. Sister of the late Judy-Lynn. Survived by husband Robert, brother Leonard, sister-in-law Debrah and nieces Alyssa and Lori.

title: Media Talk; Networks Find Old News Can Become New Hits
description: Old news is apparently good news.

title: 24 Need Shots After Petting Rabid Raccoon
description: Two dozen people, including 14 children, have begun a monthlong series of rabies shots after petting and passing around a baby raccoon that a police sergeant and his wife had found and cared for in Woodstock, N.Y., but that was later found to be infected.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PEERCE, STUART B.
description: PEERCE-Stuart B. Three years today our hearts are still sad. We miss you. Rest in peace. Love, Lois, Margie, Mark, Steve, Wendy, Carol, Pamela, Ben and Sarah

title: Puerto Rico Stuns U.S. With 19-Point Comeback
description: Already wearing their road uniforms, the United States basketball players felt even less at home yesterday with many of the 8,617 fans at Madison Square Garden waving Puerto Rican flags and filling the arena with pro-Puerto Rican chants. After losing their opening game in the Goodwill Games, they felt even worse.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- Madison Ave. Is a Hall of Mirrors; Advertising About Advertising Makes Comeback in the 90's
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUTLER, BERNICE (NEE HEALY
description: BUTLER-Bernice (nee Healy). Died on July 18, 1998. Beloved wife of the late John A. Butler. Survived by brother Harold J. Healy and sister-in-law Judith S. Healy. A native New Yorker and longtime resident of Fort Lee, NJ, and Washington Heights, NY. In her lifetime she held executive positions with the law firm of Donovan, Leisure, Newton & Lombard and the Mennan Oil Co. Mass of the Resurrection at 12 noon on Tuesday, July 21, at the Chapel of Our Lady Queen of Peace of Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Interment to follow. For further information contact Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, Madison Ave at 81st St.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 22 about Paul Kellogg and his first two seasons as general and artistic director of the New York City Opera referred incorrectly to his relationship with the Glimmerglass Opera in Cooperstown, N.Y. Mr. Kellogg, who remains artistic director of Glimmerglass, was not its founder. It was founded by eight trustees in 1975. Mr. Kellogg became its first general manager in 1978 and later general and artistic director. Esther Nelson is now general director.

title: Starr Demands White House Log Of Visits by Lawyers for Clinton
description: The Whitewater independent counsel has subpoenaed records of White House visits made by President Clinton's private lawyers, David E. Kendall and Robert S. Bennett.

title: Older, Wiser Moceanu Finds the Right Balance
description: At 10, Dominique Moceanu was the youngest gymnast ever to make the United States junior national team. At 13, she was the youngest to win the United States senior championship. And at 14, when she was part of the United States gold-medal team in the Atlanta Olympics, she became the youngest athlete ever on a Wheaties box.

title: The Flaw in Student-Centered Learning
description: In a surprise vote last week, the New York State Board of Regents declined to lock in the education establishment's monopoly on teacher training. Rather than requiring all future teachers to get an education degree before stepping inside a classroom, the Regents left open the possibility that well-educated, qualified teachers could bypass the ordeal of education school and still be certified.

title: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:
description: Amerus Capital II, Des Moines, $750 million of adjustable conversion-rate equity security units, each consisting of purchase contract and a quarterly income preferred security. Goldman, Sachs & Co.

title: I.M.F. Austerity May Deepen Crises; Accountability Counts
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Representatives Schedule Meeting With Stern
description: For the first time since the National Basketball Association instituted its lockout at the end of last month, representatives of the players association will meet with Commissioner David Stern on Tuesday.

title: Man Faces Charge of Abusing Mother and Keeping Her in Filth
description: A Newark man charged in New York with assaulting his 76-year-old mother with a stun gun is expected to be extradited to New Jersey today and charged with neglecting her and a brother in their fetid and vermin-infested apartment.

title: Zanardi Overcomes a Lot To Win His 4th Straight
description: Alex Zanardi overcame an engine failure, a rare driving mistake that caused him to spin and several very close calls in a most improbable and dramatic victory today in the Molson Indy.

title: Florida Gives Teen-Age Smokers a Day in Court
description: Once a month for a couple of hours, Judge Steven G. Shutter of Broward County clears his courtroom of lawyers and defendants to make room for restless teen-agers and their inconvenienced parents for what is known as Teen Smoking Court.

title: New Threats Reported as Rapes in Indonesia Are Investigated
description: Editorial DeskHuman rights workers who are investigating scores of organized gang rapes during three days of rioting here in May say they and the victims have been receiving threats from unidentified men.

title: Usual Suspects Unzip Political Satire
description: For political satirists, 1998 is turning out to be a very good year. Washington hasn't produced such an irresistible array of lampoonable personages since Gary Hart posed with Donna Rice next to a boat called ''Monkey Business.''

title: Mets Take Phillies' Gift And Hand It Right Back
description: The Mets held Family Day before their game with Philadelphia yesterday when the children of players and executives took turns hitting plastic balls and running around the bases. The real family day came later, though, when the game was on the line and when Al Leiter watched Mark Leiter pitch and Hal McRae watched Brian McRae bat.

title: Political Briefing; Drawing a Battle Line At a Rally for Unity
description: In 20 years on Capitol Hill, Representative Doug Bereuter of Nebraska has built a reputation as a solid Republican moderate, seldom given to partisan, in-your-face confrontation. The Republicanism practiced in his First Congressional District, centered on Lincoln, the capital, tends to be considerably less conservative and strident than the brand practiced in Nebraska's two other districts, where the Christian right increasingly holds sway.

title: SPX Planning $2 Billion Deal for General Signal
description: The SPX Corporation is expected to announce today that it is acquiring the General Signal Corporation, a diversified manufacturer, for about $2 billion in stock and cash, according to people close to the deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAI, PING Y.
description: TAI-Ping Y. Age 85. On July 19, 1998. Beloved wife of the late J. T. Tai. Loving mother of Yuan S. Tai and the late Nora Chin. Adored grandmother of Peter Chin and Deborah Lor and great-grandmother of Martin, Anthony, John and Adam. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, with service Saturday, July 25, 11:30 AM. Entombment to follow at Ferncliff Mausoleum.

title: A Man Who Saw Around the Corner
description: TITAN

title: In India, an Arranged Marriage of 2 Worlds
description: Vinit Sethi, a New Yorker born and bred, was wired from days of celebration when he mounted a small white horse to ride toward his bride. Dressed up like a Rajput prince, he nervously adjusted his golden turban and the strands of plump emeralds that hung around his neck.

title: Thomas Mendenhall, 88, Rowing Author and Smith President
description: Thomas Corwin Mendenhall, the sport of rowing's foremost American historian and a former president of Smith College, died on Saturday at Windemere, a long-term care facility on Martha's Vineyard, where he and his wife lived. He was 88.

title: From Hips to Heels, Johnson Regaining His Form
description: To hear his coach talk, Michael Johnson's hips have been out of alignment, much like the front end of a car. That, in turn, has left his wheels wobbling, from his tight hamstrings to his strained Achilles' tendon. But after a frustrating early season, Johnson said he is ready to road-test his form at 400 meters, where he is accustomed to reaching the finish line greeted by a checkered flag.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALABAN, SIGMUND
description: BALABAN - Sigmund. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Devoted father of Aileen Silver, Mark and Barry Balaban. Cherished grandfather of Alanna and Beth Silver, Scott and Brian Balaban. Loving brother of Frieda Ashare and Reuben Balaban. He was the founder of Sigmund Balaban and Co., CPA's, a retired army captain during World War II and an avid outdoorsman. He will be deeply missed by all those who knew and loved him. Services Monday, 1 PM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIMMEIR, PAUL
description: RIMMEIR-Paul, 73. A resident of Miami and Philadelphia passed away Friday, July 17, 1998, in Philadelphia. He had been a resident of Miami for over 50 years. Paul will be sadly missed by Janice, his beloved wife of 33 years, his son Spencer, grandchildren Stephanie and Jacob, and his many devoted friends all over the country who will cherish his memory. Paul was a fun-loving, outgoing, active entrepreneur who enchanted everyone who came in contact with him. A member of the Friar's Club in New York City for many years, he befriended numerous show business personalities who will remember him for his good humor and generosity. Chapel Service 1:00 PM, Wednesday with entombment to follow at Lakeside Memorial Park. A memorial service will be held in Philadelphia at a later date. For information, Eternal Light Funeral Chapel 305-948-9900

title: Reuters Undecided On Stock Buyback
description: Reuters Group P.L.C., the world's largest financial-information distributor, has made ''no formal decision'' about whether it will go ahead with a plan to buy back up to $:200 million ($329 million) of its shares this year, a spokesman said yesterday. A report in the newspaper Sunday Business said the company had decided to put the buyback plan on hold as it awaited the result of a United States criminal inquiry into whether it stole proprietary information from Bloomberg News, one of its rivals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, PHILIP
description: GORDON-Philip. Of Lincolndale, N.Y. and Lake Worth, Florida on July 19, peacefully at home. 96 years old, a man of strength and determination with a clever wit will be remembered with love and respect. Beloved and devoted husband of the late Diana. Deeply loved by his children Natalie Berke, Martin Gordon, Aaron Gordon and Marsha Dick and their spouses Leslie Gordon and Joey Dick. His grandchildren, great grandchildren, nieces & nephews. Graveside services will be held at the Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla today at 2 P.M. Shiva will be observed at the home of his daughter, Marsha Dick.

title: Chess; Kasparov Can't Snap Back After Two Early Losses
description: Garry Kasparov's immunity from defeat was nowhere to be seen in the Siemens-Nixdorf Tournament of Giants in Frankfurt, Germany, June 17 to 21. The strongest player in the world received two shots in Rounds 1 and 2 and failed to recover from them. That left it open for Viswanathan Anand to capture first place and for Vladimir Kramnik to capture second. These were the ones who defeated Kasparov.

title: Another Silent Night For Mets' Meek Bats
description: He came in billed as the savior of a franchise that was very much in need of a marquee player. Instead, Mike Piazza has become the symbol of the Mets' mounting frustrations.

title: A Mexican Town That Transcends All Borders
description: In the dark before dawn, when the priest bumped his pickup truck through town to wake everyone up, Monica Cruz groaned and put her pillow over her head. In New York City, as the assistant manager of a store in SoHo, she enjoys daylong access to cappuccino. Here in her dusty little hometown, there is not a cup of coffee to be had.

title: Coast Guard Suspends Search for Powerboat
description: The Coast Guard suspended an overnight search for two men on a powerboat yesterday morning, 13 hours after a distress call in which a man told the authorities that the craft could stay afloat for only one more hour.

title: School Manual Intended To Combat Drug Abuse
description: State officials yesterday released a 273-page manual of guidelines intended to help school districts guard against drug abuse by students within legal limits.

title: Cruise Ship Catches Fire; 60 People Are Hurt
description: A cruise ship with more than 3,400 people on board caught fire shortly after leaving the port of Miami this afternoon, generating huge clouds of dark smoke before United States Coast Guard vessels came to the rescue and doused the flames.

title: Hold H.M.O.'s Liable for Bad Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Personal Health; After 100,000 Miles, Even Soles on Feet Wear Out
description: THERE seems to be a week for just about every health problem that afflicts a significant number of Americans. But where is the week for those ''poor, poor feet'' celebrated in song a generation ago in ''The Pajama Game''? Our feet take a beating, bearing our full weight for a lifetime of walking and running, often in shoes that squeeze, rub or deform them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIDA, SABINA W.
description: LIDA-Sabina W. Beloved mother, devoted friend, supportive colleague, social worker, generous donor to charities and liberal causes, Holocaust survivor. Died peacefully in her sleep on Saturday, July 18, 1998. She will be missed by her son David, daughter-in-law Judy, and numerous friends and relatives.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ARGAND, GREGORY PAUL
description: ARGAND-Gregory Paul. Beloved son 12/05/50-07/21/83. ''A song unheard in hearts that weep.''

title: More Bus Riders Mean More Bumps and Falls
description: The transit system's growing pains are not just a metaphor, according to figures released yesterday by New York City Transit. While more people are riding the city's buses, more people are also falling down bus stairs, tripping in aisles and knocking into each other when the increasingly jammed buses stop short.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ROZ
description: COHEN-Roz. Roz was a very special person and friend. We Will miss you dearly. The Mathias and Chesslers

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUH, FRED
description: KRUH-Fred. On July 14, 1998. Devoted father of Roberta Goldman, Lawrence Kruh & Helene Byron. Cherished grandfather and greatgrandfather. Beloved brother of Irving. Services were held at Riverside Cemetery, Lodi, N.J.

title: O'Meara Put Varied Skills on Display
description: With a dramatic victory Sunday in the British Open, his second major championship of the year, Mark O'Meara guaranteed himself the kind of year most golfers only dream about.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEEHAN, HELEN VERONICA
description: MEEHAN-Helen Veronica. Age 88. On July 20th, 1998. Beloved mother of Dr. Edward F. Meehan. Mother-in-law of Dr. Nurper Gokhan and grandmother of Delfin Gokhan Meehan. Reposing Redden Funeral Home, 325 W. 14 St, NYC Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 10 A.M., Our Lady of Guadalupe Church, 229 W. 14 Street, NYC.

title: A Queen Retires the Way She Ruled: With Class
description: Her grandmother named her after Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, because she wanted her to grow up to be ''the first lady of something.'' Jackie Joyner-Kersee fulfilled her grandmother's dream. She retires this week at 36 as the greatest female athlete of her generation, the first lady of track and field.

title: A 72-Year-Old Young Turk in Japan's Premier Race
description: Courting world opinion is not something most Japanese politicians are good at or consider important to their success, but Seiroku Kajiyama, one of three candidates to become the next Prime Minister, took a stab at it today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVOW, SAMUEL
description: LEVOW-Samuel. Tifereth IsraelTown and Village Synagogue mourns the loss of its beloved member of long standing and extends heartfelt condolences to his entire family. Rabbi Laurence A. Sebert Carol Green, President

title: Old Fears Battle New Optimism in East Timor
description: There is an unsettling mix of terror and hope in this threadbare capital of the disputed territory of East Timor, where a solution to two decades of separatist warfare and military brutality suddenly seems possible.

title: New Leader Of W.H.O. Gets Big Grant To Hire Experts
description: To mark a long-awaited change in leadership at the World Health Organization on Tuesday, the Rockefeller Foundation will provide a $2.5 million fund to the new director general, Gro Harlem Brundtland of Norway, to aid her in recruiting top-level experts during the next two years.

title: Financial Post to Become Part of a New Canadian Daily
description: After stirring up the Canadian newspaper market with his plans for a new national daily, Conrad M. Black, the owner of newspapers from Vancouver to Jerusalem, shook things up even more today with the announcement that he was buying The Financial Post and would use the Toronto-based paper as the financial section of his new project.

title: Inquiry and Pleas for Calm After Westchester Police Shooting
description: Even as more details emerged on the fatal shooting of a black man early Sunday by three police officers, Westchester County District Attorney Jeanine Pirro and community leaders called for calm today after protests here on Sunday night. And they asked that people withhold judgment while the shooting was being investigated.

title: Cricket Invaders Turn an Auction Into 'Madness'
description: The Giuliani administration has seen many protests, but perhaps never one so large in number but so small in girth.

title: Arts in America; A Good Place to Shoot Movies? Why, That's Baltimore
description: Novelists often explore what they know best, and the same sometimes applies to filmmakers. At least it does for Barry Levinson, who has made his hometown, Baltimore, a star in many of his feature films.

title: Cosmetic Breast Enlargements Are Making a Comeback
description: BOARDING a flight from LaGuardia to Minneapolis last Thursday, passengers could not help but notice Ana Voog. Strikingly attractive, with huge brown eyes, flawless skin and cropped platinum hair, Ms. Voog, who is 5 feet 2 inches tall and weighs 90 pounds, also has remarkably large breasts for such a petite woman. Her clingy white pullover bore a startling inscription: ''YES, THEY'RE FAKE.''

title: A Plan for Nigerian Democracy
description: By setting elections in Nigeria for early next year and promising a civilian government by the end of May, Gen. Abdulsalam Abubakar yesterday pointed his country toward democracy. Unhappily, he did not remove himself or his fellow generals from power immediately, leaving open the possibility that the military will once again betray Nigeria with false promises of reform.

title: Prudential Complex Sale
description: Avalon Bay Communities Inc. said today that it had bought the apartment property portion of Boston's Prudential Center from the Prudential Insurance Company of America for $130 million. Prudential Center, which is in Boston's Back Bay section, has been a fixture of the city's skyline for 30 years. Avalon Bay bought the center's three 27-story apartment towers, which contain 781 units. Last month, Boston Properties Inc. bought the commercial property portion of the complex for more than $500 million.

title: Ballet Theater Elects 2 to Lead Board
description: Hamilton E. James has been elected chairman of the board of American Ballet Theater. Anne M. Tatlock has been elected the board's president. The two positions had been held by Peter T. Joseph, who died last month.

title: Around the Mars Pathfinder in 83 Days
description: On July 4, 1997, NASA landed its Pathfinder spacecraft on Mars, and for the next three months Earthlings were fascinated by the wanderings of the robotic rover Sojourner. Now NASA has released a photomosaic showing Sojourner's path.

title: Rose's Pro Debut Is Set for Thursday
description: As expected, Justin Rose of England turned professional yesterday, a day after tying for fourth place at the British Open, the highest finish in the event by an amateur since 1953.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TARTARO, ANGELO JOSEPH
description: TARTARO-Angelo Joseph, 58. Of North Hills, CA., passed away on July 16, 1998. Angelo is survived by his loving wife Vivian, Devoted daughter Vanessa & son Angelo. Angelo was a retired New York City police captain. He was former NY State Commissioner as well as past President of Footprinters Lodge #

title: LEVEL 3 TO SELL NETWORK SPACE TO NEXTEL AND MCCAW
description: Level 3 Communications Inc. agreed yesterday to sell capacity on its nationwide fiber optic network to Nextel Communications Inc. and other affiliates of the entrepreneur Craig McCaw for $700 million. Level 3, which plans to have its network operating by 2001 to compete with systems being built by Qwest Communications International Inc. and others, also declared a 2-for-1 split of its shares. The investment will help Level 3 pay for the $2.2 billion, 15,000-mile network. The shares of Level 3, which is based in Omaha, rose $5, to $76.75.

title: Rarity Caps a Callas Series
description: There has always been a reliable market for Maria Callas recordings. EMI Classics (formerly Angel Records), the company with which she was most closely associated, has done well with its extensive Callas discography.

title: Last Days of XXX? Memories and Gloom in Times Sq.
description: The voluptuous woman in the spiked heels flashed her neon charms from the sign above grimy Eighth Avenue, just as she has every day and night for years, to advertise the Playpen sex club. But not even her perpetually saucy smile quite managed to dispel the sense of doom down below at sidewalk level, where extinction threatens the X-rated video stores, ''hug-and-squeeze rooms'' and topless bars around Times Square.

title: High Technology Is First Mate In the Race for America's Cup
description: AKLAXON sounds and the sleek hull of the racing yacht begins knifing through cool, calm waters at increasing speed. The bow heaves as it pushes through the flat water, raising a wave as it moves faster and sending ripples fanning from the waterline.

title: Singapore's Exports Had 6.1% Gain in June
description: Exports of goods made in Singapore posted a gain of 6.1 percent in June, reversing two months of decline, helped by higher electronics exports to the United States and Europe. Still, the Government warned that the better-than-expected numbers might not signal an economic turnaround.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAI, PING Y.
description: TAI-Ping Y. Age 85. On July 19, 1998. Beloved wife of the late J.T. Tai. Loving mother of Yuan S. Tai and the late Nora Chin. Adored grandmother of Peter Chin and Deborah Lor & great-grandmother of Martin, Anthony, John and Adam. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, with service Saturday, July 25, 11:30 A.M. Entombment to follow at Ferncliff Mausoleum.

title: In a Reversal, China Will Allow A Resumption of Amway Sales
description: China has backtracked from a blanket ban it imposed on direct selling to consumers just three months ago, allowing the Amway Corporation to resume operations there.

title: Officials Suspect Some Are Wrongly Accused in Sex Scandal
description: Some of the 20 Manhattan police officers facing disciplinary action and possible criminal charges for suspected involvement in a prostitution sex scandal may have been wrongly accused, law enforcement investigators said yesterday, adding that other officers from the Midtown South precinct could be implicated in their places.

title: Speaker Yields On Albany Bill Limiting Parole
description: Responding to harsh election-year attacks on Assembly Democrats, Speaker Sheldon Silver announced today that he would bring the Assembly back for a special session next week to pass Gov. George E. Pataki's proposal to limit parole for violent felons.

title: Public Lives; 'Titanic,' 'Titanic' Everywhere
description: Guess which film was scheduled when EILEEN IVERS, a New York violinist, settled in for a flight to London. Here is a clue: She was on her way to a recording session for a compact disk called ''Back to Titanic'' with the London Symphony led by JAMES HORNER, who won an Academy Award for the score for the film ''Titanic.''

title: Times Square Station Is No Gift to Riders
description: To the Editor:

title: After Tragedy, an Ecstatic Aria; Barcelona's Opera Is Rising, Without Crossed Swords
description: It was neither the oldest nor the most beautiful building in Barcelona, but when fire destroyed the Gran Teatre del Liceu on Jan. 31, 1994, its loss was mourned here like a death in the family. For close to 150 years, the legendary opera house had been at the heart of Barcelona's social life. And on its stage, generations of Catalan singers had launched their careers, not least Victoria de los Angeles, Montserrat Caballe and Jose Carreras.

title: FPA Medical Files for Protection Under Bankruptcy Laws
description: FPA Medical Management, a troubled company that bought the businesses of thousands of doctors, filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy laws Sunday, eliminating the value of stock it had used in paying physicians. FPA was the most disastrous case of a big health care company that grew so fast it lost track of costs and could not pay doctors for their work.

title: Heat Wave in Texas Brings 15th Straight Day Over 100degrees
description: Horacio Hernandez took a brief break from pouring and troweling highway concrete while the temperature rose to 101 here this afternoon, pulled away his tinted safety goggles and tried to wipe them off with a T-shirt that was already soaked.

title: Review/Fashion; In Paris Couture, the Spectacle's the Thing

The poor, overtrained beast with a model on its back didn't bring to mind fairy tales; it recalled instead Bianca Jagger barebacking it through Studio 54, a defining moment of tortured excess. And everyone knows how Studio 54 got its comeuppance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, AARON
description: LEVY-Aaron, 87. Passed away at his home in North Miami, FL., after a brief illness. Beloved husband of the late Lillian. Loving father of Esther (Michael) Blynn and Steven (Schelly) Levy. Beloved grandfather of Jeremy, Elisa and Sharon Blynn. Dear brother of Simcha (Fredzia), Joseph and Jacob. Dear brother-in-law of Theda Mann and her family. Aaron Levy was a renowned attorney, a legal and Jewish scholar. He was the Director of Corporate Regulation of the S.E.C. from where he retired into private practice with The International Law firm of Leboeuf, Lamb, Leiby and McCrae. He moved to Florida in 1995 to reside with his daughter and son-in-law when he finally retired from law. During his career he argued before the U.S. Supreme Court on the Bankruptcy Act and the Public Utility Holding Company Act. Services will be Wednesday at 2 P.M. at Adas Israel Congregation in Washington, D.C. Shiva will be observed in Florida at the Blynn residence and in Washington, D.C. at the residence of Steven Levy. For information Levitt Weinstein Memorial Chapel 305-932-2700. Memorial contributions may be made to The American Heart Assoc, University of Chicago Law School, The Yale University School of Law or City College of N.Y.

title: Giants and Top Pick Nearing Agreement
description: The Giants expect to sign their first-round draft pick, U.C.L.A. safety Shaun Williams, in time for Williams to participate in the team's first training camp workout Saturday. The Giants are still negotiating with their other top draft picks, wide receivers Joe Jurevicius and Brian Alford, but neither was expected to be a training camp holdout.

title: FAIRCHILD SEMICONDUCTOR TO DISMISS 200 WORKERS
description: The Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation, whose chips are the building blocks for electrical components in everything from toasters to cars, said yesterday that it planned to dismiss about 200 workers because of the worldwide slowdown in the electronics industry. The closely held Fairchild, which was spun off last year from the National Semiconductor Corporation, said it planned to trim payroll costs by 10 percent. The company, based in South Portland, Me., employs about 7,000 workers worldwide, and the 200 being dismissed are in the United States. The company also plans to reduce the payroll through attrition and cutbacks in contracted services.

title: Ending Welfare
description: Speaking in the executive dining room of a local bank yesterday, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani announced his goal for New York City's poor. ''We're going to end welfare by the end of the century completely,'' he promised. The old system would be replaced by a ''universal work requirement'' for anyone hoping to receive financial help from the city. Like his crime and civility campaigns, turning welfare recipients into independent citizens sounds like an aim worthy of the Mayor's energies and ambitions. One question is whether the Giuliani administration is increasingly shifting people from welfare to work or shoving them into other kinds of dependencies. Another is whether citizens will be able to get the information that will enable them to separate accomplishments from hype.

title: HORSE RACING: It's a Long, Uphill Ride To Racing's Big Leagues; But St. Julien, a Black Jockey, Is on His Way
description: Not too long ago, Marlon St. Julien was another clean-pants rider in the rundown jock rooms of Louisiana's Evangeline and Delta Downs, an afterthought on a second-rate circuit waiting for a break. He was young, inexperienced and black.

title: After Losing a Marathon, The Yankees Gain a Split
description: The Yankees re-entered an orbit not of their liking last night when they lost for the fourth time in five games, something unheard of since the first five games of their otherwise spectacular season.

title: Man Accused of Abusing Relatives Ordered Held
description: A man accused of abusing his elderly mother and his mentally disabled brother in their squalid apartment in Newark was arraigned in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday on a weapons possession charge and ordered held in New York for 30 days while an investigation continues.

title: Science Watch
description: What Bugs an Insect?

title: Frank X. Altimari, 69, Judge Who Affirmed Ban on Begging
description: Frank Xavier Altimari, a senior Federal appeals judge who wrote the ruling that affirmed the ban on begging in city subways and transit terminals, died on Sunday at his home in Old Westbury, N.Y. He was 69.

title: Hearts Laid Bare in Old-Fashioned Love Songs
description: Voices were strong and hearts were wounded when the Royal Soul Explosion appeared here tonight at the Westbury Music Fair. The all-star soul revue was a respectful showcase for seven singers -- Jerry Butler, Gene Chandler, Chuck Jackson, Ben E. King, Lloyd Price, Percy Sledge and Irma Thomas -- who made hits in the 1950's, 60's and 70's. With the Uptown Horns band led by G. E. Smith on guitar and Peter Wolf as a dancing M.C., the revue set out to be something more than a typical oldies show.

title: Hold H.M.O.'s Liable for Bad Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Changes
description: NEC ELECTRONICS INC., Santa Clara, Calif., an electronics maker and affiliate of the NEC Corp., named Hirokazu Hashimoto president and chief executive.

title: SYQUEST HIRES CIBC OPPENHEIMER TO EXPLORE OPTIONS
description: Syquest Technology Inc., one of the largest makers of removable computer storage disks, said yesterday that it had hired the investment-banking firm CIBC Oppenheimer to help it explore acquisitions and financing. Syquest, whose shares have plunged to little more than $1, from $18.50 in January 1995, has been hurt by slowing sales and weakening demand for personal computers. A rival, the Iomega Corporation, cut prices as much as 26 percent last month on its newest Jaz disk drives. CIBC Oppenheimer will assist Syquest, which is based in Fremont, Calif., with its ''ongoing review of strategic and financial alternatives.'' Syquest shares were unchanged at $1.40625, giving the company a current market capitalization of $134 million.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICHEK, BESSIE D.
description: REICHEK-Bessie D. Died on July 20th, 1998 at age 89. Beloved wife of Max Reichek. Beloved mother of Ruth Baron and Nathaniel Reichek. Loving grandmother to Jennifer and Matthew Reichek and Rafe Baron. Devoted sister to Solomon, Joseph and Wolf Citron who predeceased her. Beloved mother-in-law of Robert Baron and Lesly Reichek and grandmother-in-law of Minnie Reichek. Teacher to generations of New York's children. She never met a child she could not teach and love. Funeral service at Bet Am Sholom Synagogue, White Plains, N.Y.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CORN RETREATS. National Weather Service forecasts for an end to searing Midwest heat pushed down corn 2.5 percent, erasing most of the previous session's gains. The December contract fell 6 cents, to $2.3625 a bushel.

title: With Cuban Rhythms, Swinging and Dancing
description: Azucar Negra, from Cuba, included one song in both of its sets at Midsummer Night Swing on Saturday night: ''Almas Disfrazadas'' (''Souls in Disguise''). It's an exuberant tune that like many compositions in the modern Cuban style called songo goes through multiple transformations: from lilting pop to a jazzy interlude to a sequence of driving dance vamps. Its lyrics, meanwhile, promote safe sex without mincing words: ''If you fall into the temptation of this carnal desire/ Never forget to use your condom.'' Without interrupting the party, it aims its message directly to the dance floors where liaisons begin; the song is endorsed by Cuba's Ministry of Public Health.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROLFE, MITZI
description: ROLFE-Mitzi. Of Key Biscayne, Florida, passed away July 19, 1998. Beloved wife of Arthur, cherished mother of Richard, Rose, and sonin-law Kevin, sister of Helen and her late sister Harriet. We will miss her deeply.

title: Cohen Hopes for Standard Adultery Policy Soon
description: Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen said today that he hoped to create a standard, less onerous approach to prosecuting adultery in the military, even though a draft proposal for him to do so has met some resistance within the services.

title: CANADIAN MERGER TO FORM FILM AND TELEVISION COMPANY
description: In a combination of two Toronto companies, the Alliance Communications Corporation plans to acquire Atlantis Communications Inc. to form Alliance Atlantis Communications Inc., a film and television company. Alliance said yesterday that it would offer Atlantis shareholders a half share for each share held, giving the acquisition a value of about $109 million. The combined entity, which will have the core businesses of television programming, motion pictures production and cable-television systems, is expected to have revenue of about $504 million for the year ending next March 31.

title: In Israel's Bitter Culture War, Civility Is a Casualty
description: Receiving a lifetime-achievement award at the Jerusalem Film Festival this spring, the Israeli filmmaker Assi Dayan congratulated organizers for putting on so fine a festival ''in this damned city.'' Then, turning to Mayor Ehud Olmert, he loosed another curse: Please tell your friend, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, ''that he should go to hell.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERRY, GRACE L.
description: BERRY-Grace L. Suddenly on July 18, 1998. Graduate of the College of Mt. St. Vincent. Retired Administrative Assistant at Lehman College. Devoted volunteer and Eucharistic Minister at St. Patricks Home, Kingsbridge Heights Rehab Center, and the Methodist Church Home. Beloved wife of the late Thomas F. Dear sister of Agnes Large, Mae Robbin, Gwynne O'Donnell, Everitas Houghton, and the late Arthur Large. Also survived by many nieces & nephews. Family will receive friends Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232nd St., Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at Visitation Church, Wednesday, 10 A.M. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: PENNCORP TO GET $75 MILLION FROM RISK CAPITAL GROUP
description: Penncorp Financial Group Inc., an insurance holding company based in New York, said yesterday that it would receive as much as $75 million in new capital from a group of investors including the reinsurance company Risk Capital Holdings Inc. Penncorp also said two insurance units it was trying to sell might bring in less than the $450 million originally expected. Penncorp shares rose $1.50, to $13.50. But the shares fell 38 percent last week and are down 53 percent from their high on April 23. Risk Capital, a reinsurance company in Greenwich, Conn., and Securitas L.L.C., an investment firm backed by the Swiss Reinsurance Company and Credit Suisse Group, led the investors that agreed to buy newly issued shares of Penncorp.

title: Group Proposes Voluntary Guidelines for Internet Privacy
description: In a continuing effort to head off new laws governing how companies can collect and use personal information gathered on the Internet about consumers, an industry coalition today proposed a voluntary enforcement program to certify World Wide Web sites that comply with privacy guidelines.

title: Hold H.M.O.'s Liable for Bad Care
description: To the Editor

title: Suggestion for the Next 3 Days: Hide in a Cool, Dry Place
description: After skirting the Northeast for most of the summer, some of the fiery heat that has seared crops and led to deaths and destruction in the Southwest and Florida touched down in the metropolitan region yesterday, and meteorologists said the irritating and oppressive conditions are expected to settle in for at least the next three days.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SELZER, SIDNEY SHELDON
description: SELZER-Sidney Sheldon. Special husband, father, grandfather and now great grandfather. Today and everyday remembered with love.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHMANN, EBBA (NEE EBBA DUFFY)
description: LEHMANN-Ebba (nee Ebba Duffy), 73, of Massapequa, Long Island, New York, July 18, 1998. Wife of William H., mother of William R., & Gregory, & sister of Barbara.

title: Mayor Wants To Abolish Use Of Methadone
description: As Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani outlined plans to dramatically expand his workfare program to include drug addicts, he veered unexpectedly from his prepared speech yesterday and announced his desire to abolish all methadone treatment programs for heroin addicts in New York City.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BURRIDGE GROUP L.L.C., a unit of Affiliated Managers Group Inc., acquired Sound Capital Partners L.L.C., a Seattle-based money management firm that oversees about $200 million of assets for institutional clients, for an undisclosed amount.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIR, HENRY J.
description: LEIR-Henry J. The officers, board & staff of the American Technion Society express profound regret at the loss of Henry Leir of New York City, a philanthropist and major benefactor of many Jewish causes. As a supporter of the American Technion Society, he demonstrated great vision and commitment to the Technion and to Israel. His support will help ensure the university's continued excellence and vital contributions to Israel and the world. American Society for TechnionIsrael Institute of Technology Irving A. Shepard, President Ben Z. Sosewitz, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Exec. VP Cindy Sipkin, NY Metropolitan Region Chair Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Prof. Zehev Tadmor, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVOW, SAMUEL L.
description: LEVOW-Samuel L. On July 19, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Isabel Rockmore Levow. Devoted father of Melissa, Wendy and Beth. Father-in-law of David and Alan. Loving brother of Evelyn Mendelsohn. Dedicated grandfather of Davina, Jessica and Adam. Dear brother-in-law and uncle. Services Tuesday, 12 Noon, at the Gramercy Chapel, 152 2nd Ave, near East 10th St, Manhattan. Donations may be made to Parkinson's Unity Walk, 30 W. 90 St, Suite 8C, New York, NY 10024.

title: Hold H.M.O.'s Liable for Bad Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sunday Styles this week about recent books and movies that portray a growing antipathy between the sexes misidentified the publisher of ''How to Make Your Man Behave in 21 Days or Less, Using the Secrets of Professional Dog Trainers,'' by Karen Salmansohn. It is the Workman Publishing Company, not St. Martin's Press.

title: A Drug Maker Reports Profit Gain of 46%
description: The Warner-Lambert Company reported a 46 percent gain in second-quarter earnings yesterday, helped by strong sales of prescription drugs including Lipitor, a cholesterol-lowering medicine introduced last year.

title: National Health Scare
description: Four years ago the Clinton Administration tried to federalize one-seventh of the American economy by creating a government health care system that would have limited our choice in doctors, cost millions of jobs and created new bureaucracies and tax increases. The American people and Congress soundly rejected the plan.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a spate of killings in Fulton County, New York, misstated the number of counties in the state. It is 62. (The figure of 58 in the article is the number of counties covered by the County Risk Profile, which state agencies use to compare social conditions in the state.)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the literary critic and author Robert Gorham Davis on Friday misstated the name of an award he won for short story writing. It was the O. Henry Award, not O'Henry.

title: Metro Business; 5 Indicted in Land Scheme
description: Five real estate appraisers were indicted yesterday on charges that they inflated the values of dilapidated properties in a land-flip scheme in New Jersey, the United States Attorney's office said.

title: INVESTORS FINANCIAL AND BANKBOSTON IN $50 MILLION DEAL
description: The Investors Financial Services Corporation said yesterday that it would buy the BankBoston Corporation's domestic institutional custody unit for as much as $50 million, increasing the administrative business it does for such clients as endowments and trusts. Investors Financial will pay $44 million at closing plus as much as $6 million a year later, depending on how many clients stay on after the sale. The transaction will raise Investors Financial's total assets processed for clients to $234 billion. Investors Financial shares rose $3.25, to $60.50. BankBoston shares fell $1, to $55.3125.

title: By Design; For Makeup as Light as a Breeze
description: When the weather is hot and steamy, makeup can add weight and warmth. So, summer is the time to switch to sheer makeup, which is feather-light and results in a natural, unmade-up look that suits the season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, WAYNE DOXSEE
description: MOORE-Wayne Doxsee. Of Islip, NY, July 19, 1998 at the age of 80. Beloved husband of Margaretha ''Peggy'' Moore. Cherished father of Kathleen Doxsee Moore Gamboa and Kevin Doxsee Moore. Father-in-law of Melanie Moore and Joe John Gamboa. Devoted grandfather of Caroline Doxsee Moore & Charles Doxsee Moore. Step grandfather of Michael Alleva & Kimberly Aleva. Fond cousin of Mary Moore Remington, Margaret Moore Fisher & Marjorie Moore Dunton. Loving nephew of Mrs. Joseph A. Moore. Mr. Moore was a graduate of St. Lawrence University & a member of Sigma Alpha Epsilon fraternity. He served 4 years in the Army Air Force during WWII with the 500th Bomber Group. President & Chairman of the Board of Cornwall and Stevens Co., Inc. and the principal shareholder of Lloyds, New York. Mr. Moore recently retired after commuting from Islip to NYC for over fifty years. Visiting hours Wednesday, July 22, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at the Overton Funeral Home, 172 Main Street, Islip, NY. Funeral services Thursday, 10:30 AM, with interment to follow at Oakwood Cemetery, Bay Shore, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the American Heart Association or the Presbyterian Church of Islip.

title: Late Push Propels U.S. Past China
description: This time, there was no second-half collapse.

title: Widowed Homeowner Foils Trump in Atlantic City
description: It was a case that pitted a widowed homeowner and the owners of two small businesses in Atlantic City against the state and Donald J. Trump, one of the brashest personalities in the casino business. And today, the little guys won.

title: Cruelty of Giant Wave: 'Most of the Children Are Dead'
description: Relief workers continued counting the dead in Papua New Guinea yesterday, as fears rose that the giant wave that obliterated several fishing villages on Friday swept away far more children than adults.

title: Pepsico to Pay $3.3 Billion For Tropicana
description: Just when you thought the breakfast table had been left unspattered by the cola wars, Pepsico announced yesterday that it was buying the Tropicana juice business from the Seagram Company.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Big-Ship Economy
description: There was a funny political cartoon recently, spoofing the fact that nothing President Clinton does seems to affect his poll ratings -- as long as the stock market keeps rising. The cartoon showed a newscaster announcing that a severed head had been found in Mr. Clinton's sleeping quarters in the White House, but with the Dow having reached a new record high the U.S. public was indifferent.

title: Vague Charges Accuse Korean Official of Letting Economy Fall : From Finance Ministry to Cell No.3
description: EUWANG, South Korea  Suffering from high blood pressure and losing sight in one eye, Kang Kyong Shik has no desire to read the fine print of newspaper articles about South Korea's financial crisis.

title: Sotheby's, Expanding, Plans a Showplace
description: An ambitious plan to expand Sotheby's headquarters on York Avenue and 72d Street into a department store for art with a sleek glass and granite facade and a sculpture garden on its roof has reached a critical stage in the city's approval process.

title: Loss in Data Services Keeps GTE Profits Flat
description: The GTE Corporation said today that its earnings were flat in the second quarter, with strong revenue growth offset by wider losses in its new data operations.

title: I.B.M. Earnings Up a Bit, Despite Hardware Woes
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that its earnings edged up four-tenths of a percent in the second quarter as sharp declines in hardware sales were offset by gains from the company's computer services and software divisions.

title: Peeks at the Complexities of a Very Private Genius
description: STEPHEN SONDHEIM

title: The Quantitative Leap; Investing by the Numbers Doesn't Offer a Great Edge
description: Put some of the world's smartest math scholars together with the fastest computers. Give them a wealth of historical data and a few billion dollars. Do they have a chance of predicting swings in the stock market?

title: After '97 Deal, New Showdown Over the Budget
description: Just a year after President Clinton and the Republican leadership succeeded in reaching a bipartisan balanced budget agreement, the two sides are again headed toward a showdown over taxes and spending.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Suntrust Banks Is Buying Crestar in $9.5 Billion Deal

title: Dr. David Nichols, 72, Specialist In Pelvic Reconstruction Surgery
description: Dr. David H. Nichols, a surgeon whose research on pelvic reconstruction and incontinence focused attention on the long-neglected medical needs of women in their 60's, 70's and 80's, died on Wednesday in his office at Brown University. He was 72 and lived in Providence, R.I.

title: Norsk Hydro Profit Falls 36% in Quarter
description: Norsk Hydro A.S.A.'s second-quarter operating profit fell 36 percent, which was less than expected, as higher earnings from aluminum production helped cushion some of the blow from lower oil and fertilizer prices. The company, Europe's largest fertilizer maker and Norway's second-biggest oil company, said its profit excluding one-time gains fell to 954 million kroner ($127 million), from 1.496 billion a year earlier. Second-quarter sales fell to 24.932 billion kroner from 25.042 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGELMAN, ETHEL
description: ENGELMAN-Ethel. On July 20, 1998. Wife of Isidore (Pete) Engelman and the late Julian Shapiro. Mother of Carolyn Stoller, Meryl Shapiro & the late Bruce Shapiro. Grandmother to Chad (Rie) Stoller and Cindi (Sean) O'Neill. Great grandmother to Kelly Julia. Sister of Judith Lewis. Services private. The family will receive at the home of Carolyn Stoller.

title: Debate on Rights and H.M.O.'s Engenders Unlikeliest of Alliances
description: The struggle over patients' rights legislation has scrambled old alliances and created some extraordinary new ones. It is throwing together doctors, trial lawyers and consumers, and pitting them against insurers and managed care companies, who in many cases are fighting each other over how much regulation they can take.

title: BankBoston in Brazil
description: The BankBoston Corporation plans to open 19 additional branches in Brazil by the end of the year, bringing its total network to 64, the bank's president and chief operating officer said today. At an event in New York sponsored by the Brazilian American Chamber of Commerce, the executive, Henrique de Campos Meirelles, said BankBoston wants to derive 25 to 30 percent of its operating income from its expanding Latin American operations by the year 2001, from its current 19 percent.

title: FAMOUS TO A FEW: Musicians in New York -- Musical Weather Vane With a Global Spin; A Producer, Performer and Agitator of Pop
description: Making art isn't always a solitary activity. There is a type of intensely social artist who rubs against as much of the world as possible to help turn the wheels of his own creativity, the artist for whom the other side, the newest level in esthetic thinking or a degree of change in direction is just a handshake and an animated conversation away. The writers Andre Breton and Susan Sontag, the musicians Quincy Jones and Gil Evans, these were and are spongelike presences whose enthusiasms made them hubs, rather than moving parts, of culture.

title: Power Move: Greene Surges to Victory in 100
description: A year ago, Maurice Greene was a promising but unfulfilled sprinter, one who changed coaches in hopes of changing his luck on the track. By the end of last summer, he had become world champion at 100 meters. And with tonight's victory in 9.96 seconds at the Goodwill Games, Greene again demonstrated that his reliability now matches his speed.

title: For Election Year, House Approves Arts Financing
description: In a sharp election-year conversion, the House today overwhelmingly approved money for the National Endowment for the Arts, long the scourge of conservatives and a prime target of Republican leaders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRAZER, MARGARET HURT
description: FRAZER-Margaret Hurt. Died on July 18, 1998 after a long illness, age nienty-three, in Palm Beach, Florida. Beloved wife of the late Persifor Frazer III. title: Weaving Bits of History, Schoenberg to Spirituals
description: The pianist Marilyn Nonken's concert on Monday night at the Flea, on White Street in TriBeCa, included both the earliest work she plays (Schoenberg's Three Pieces, Op. 11 of 1909) and the slowest (Alvin Lucier's Music for Piano With Pure-Wave Slow-Sweep Oscillators). What she prefers is new and fast, and she does it well. She has agility, stamina and thoughtfulness. She also has loyalty, as she showed in playing again the composition by Jason Eckhardt, ''Echoes' White Veil,'' which she performed at Merkin Concert Hall earlier this year.

title: A Rare Politician With Passion Appeals to Japanese Youth
description: Making trouble has not been the best way to become the Prime Minister of Japan, a role traditionally conferred on the member of the governing party who has caused the least offense over time.

title: More Secret Service Officers Testify as Starr Narrows the Focus of Inquiry
description: Prosecutors summoned several uniformed Secret Service officers before the grand jury here today as the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, tried to piece together what they knew about Monica S. Lewinsky's visits to the White House last December before her relationship with President Clinton was revealed.

title: Lesbian in Uphill Race for Congress
description: Although she has never run for office before, Margarethe Cammermeyer would seem to have a resume tailor-made for politics: she is a mother of four, a nurse with a doctoral degree, a retired Army colonel and a Vietnam War veteran who won the Bronze Star.

title: Chinese Gymnast Paralyzed
description: A Chinese gymnast was paralyzed last night after fracturing a bone in her neck during warm-ups for the women's vault at the Goodwill Games.

title: Europe's Drug Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: N.Y.U. Sues Web Site Operator, Saying Photos Are Not From Dormitory
description: Contending that its name had been tarnished by falsehoods on the Internet, New York University has filed a lawsuit against the operators of a sexually explicit Web site that claims to offer a secret camera to spy on women students at the university who ''romp for your enjoyment in their own dorm room.''

title: A Spiritual Trek By Yak Caravan
description: At several points in ''The Saltmen of Tibet,'' Ulrike Koch's profoundly absorbing study of a small band of nomads trekking across the Tibetan high country with a caravan of 160 yaks, the camera draws back to observe from afar an annual pilgrimage that has been taking place for 2,000 years. The spectacle of the distant caravan almost imperceptibly inching its way across an arid, seemingly endless steppe rimmed with snow-capped mountains is such a primal image of human perseverance that it has the power to sweep away for a moment more sophisticated reflections on civilization and its discontents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZTOL, PAULYNE (SUNNY)
description: SCHWARTZTOL - PAULYNE (Sunny). In Miami, Florida, at age 86, following a brief illness. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin; dear mother of the late Karel. Survived by devoted son, Robert (Holly); sister, Minnie; grandchildren, Steven Ainbinder, Jill, Larry & Andrew. Sunny was a vibrant woman who lived life to the fullest. Services were held.

title: SEMPRA ENERGY PAYS $48 MILLION IN CASH FOR CNG ENERGY
description: Sempra Energy said yesterday that it had purchased CNG Energy Services, a unit of the Consolidated Natural Gas Company, for $48 million in cash to expand into Eastern United States natural gas sales. Sempra Energy was formed last month when the Enova Corporation, a San Diego electric and natural gas utility, bought the Los Angeles-based Pacific Enterprises, the largest natural gas utility in the United States, for $4.5 billion. Sempra will get CNG Energy's contracts to sell natural gas to utilities and industrial customers and rights to use natural gas storage and pipelines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERSON, ALBERT
description: MERSON-Albert. Age 82, of Aventura, FL and Fort Lee, NJ, on July 20, 1998. Survived by his children Andrew and Catherine Merson, and his grandchildren Steven and Loren Merson. Contributions may be made to National Parkinsons Association, NY, NY. Services are 12 Noon, today, at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Route 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

title: Champagne as the French Know It
description: VEUVE CLICQUOT is the kind of Champagne you can take to any party and know that your host will instantly recognize and appreciate it. This is because everyone brings it.

title: Johnson & Johnson to Buy Medical Device Maker
description: Johnson & Johnson, the big diversified health care manufacturer, agreed yesterday to buy DePuy Inc., a successful maker of orthopedic devices, for $3.5 billion in cash. After the purchase, Johnson & Johnson would be one of the largest makers of artificial joints and other devices that replace or strengthen body parts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODSKY, WILLIAM
description: BRODSKY-William. Of Sunrise, FL., on July 20, 1998. Beloved husband of Florence. Devoted father of Stephen (Grace) and Edward (Carol). Beloved grandfather of Marc, Lisa, Jennifer, and Eric. Dear brother of Harry. Services Thursday, July 23, at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, N.Y., 1:30PM.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the proposed acquisition of the Crestar Financial Corporation by Suntrust Banks Inc. referred incorrectly to Suntrust's previous large deal. In 1986, the company acquired the Third National Corporation of Nashville, not the First Tennessee National Corporation.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption last Wednesday about the funeral of three Roman Catholic boys killed in a firebombing in Northern Ireland referred incorrectly to John Dillon, a pallbearer. He lived with the boys' mother, Chrissie Quinn, for five years and helped rear the children, but he was not the biological father of any of them, according to family members.

title: Scaffold Collapses, Paralyzing Times Square
description: A temporary elevator tower at a problem-plagued construction site in midtown Manhattan collapsed yesterday morning, raining tons of steel on streets below, killing an 85-year-old woman and creating a day of chaos as officials ordered the evacuation of nearby buildings and closed much of Times Square to traffic and pedestrians.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KOLBERG, BEATRICE S.
description: KOLBERG-Beatrice S. Happy Birthday, Aunt Beatrice. Lovingly remembered and cherished always.

title: Hewlett-Packard Says Profit Will Fall Short
description: The Hewlett- Packard Company warned today that its third-quarter profit would not meet analysts' expectations because the company was struggling with slowing sales, mostly in Asia.

title: Third-Quarter Results Slide 2% at Disney
description: The Walt Disney Company's fiscal third-quarter profit fell 2 percent as weak films, soft video sales and reduced demand for consumer products in Asia held back growth.

title: Mobs Reported to Loot Plantations : Loss of Jobs Pushes Indonesia Into Upheaval
description: CIPURINGIN, Indonesia  What can you do if you lose your job? Millions of Indonesians have.

title: Celebrating a Ruling, AIDS Group Rallies on City Hall Steps
description: Waving mocking placards of a smiling Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani stamped ''AIDS criminal'' in blood red, about 45 people from a housing advocacy group rallied yesterday for improved services for people with AIDS on the steps of City Hall, New York's most famous soapbox.

title: Marketing Clout: The Fans Flock To See McGwire
description: In St. Louis, Cardinals fans are snapping up blocks of tickets for mid- and late September, preparing for the moment they believe Mark McGwire will clout his 62d home run. And, hoping to touch what the Bunyanesque slugger has bashed, fans are clamoring for faraway seats in the outer reaches of left field.

title: Chase and Citicorp Lead Strong Earnings at Banks
description: Chase Manhattan and Citicorp, the nation's biggest banks, reported surprisingly high second-quarter earnings yesterday on gains in investment banking and currency trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACKS, SAMUEL D.
description: SACKS-Samuel D. Devoted husband of the late Lillian. Beloved father of Ellen Chodorow and Rachel Tippit. Proud grandfather of Devin and Brett Chodorow, Leland & Zachary Tippit. Cherished father-in-law of Ingram Chodorow and Bill Tippit. Services Thursday, 11 A.M., Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, New York. For further information call 718-853-4000.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TREIMAN, OSCAR BARD

title: LUCENT TECHNOLOGIES AND SBC SIGN $2.4 BILLION CONTRACT
description: Lucent Technologies received a five-year contract worth up to $2.4 billion to provide switching telecommunications equipment to SBC Communications Inc. and its telephone subsidiaries. Lucent also received two contracts from the Saudi Telecommunications Company worth a combined $810 million. Under a $699 million contract, announced on Monday, Lucent will expand Saudi Arabia's G.S.M. mobile phone network, and under a $111 million arrangement modernize Saudi Telecommunications' telephone switch systems, which cover more than 900,000 telephone lines. Lucent, based in Murray Hill, N.J., builds communications networks.

title: Bills Curbing Minors' Web Access Pass Senate
description: The Senate today approved two proposals for controlling children's access to pornography on the Internet, endorsing without debate one measure that would make it illegal for commercial Web sites to distribute adult material to minors and another that would require software filters on computers in libraries and schools that receive Federal Internet subsidies.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Still Life With Shell Beans
description: SOME artists, like Monet and Toulouse-Lautrec, were passionate about food and liked to cook. Matisse, however, was no foodie, so the connection between him and the food of the Cote d'Azur in ''Matisse: A Way of Life in the South of France,'' by Gilles Plazy, Jean-Bernard Naudin and Coco Jobard (Rizzoli, $40), is merely a device for a lavish book.

title: EDISON IN $300 MILLION DEAL FOR WESTEC SECURITY UNITS
description: Edison International, California's third-largest electric utility, agreed yesterday to buy two units of Westec Security Group Inc. for $300 million in a bid to expand the company's presence in the home-security business. Edison, which had $9.24 billion in revenue last year, will buy Westec Residential Security Inc. and Valley Burglar and Fire Alarm Company through its Edison Select subsidiary. While terms were not disclosed by Edison, Westec's parent, the Secom Company of Japan, said the purchase price would be about $300 million. Westec, based in Newport Beach, Calif., has more than $72 million in annual revenues from its home-security business.

title: Pentagon Report Dismisses Nerve Gas Charge
description: With veterans of a once-secret mission by his side, Defense Secretary William S. Cohen issued a detailed Pentagon report today dismissing the accusation in a media report that United States forces involved in a 1970 operation in the Vietnam War used nerve gas to kill American defectors.

description: Forecasts of slowing growth in corporate earnings later in the year and cautionary words about inflation from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, sent stocks tumbling yesterday.

title: It's Official: U.S. to Consider Dutch Trial in Lockerbie Case
description: The Clinton Administration said today that the United States and Britain would seriously consider the creation of a special court in the Netherlands to try two Libyans suspected of planting a bomb aboard a jumbo jet that exploded over Lockerbie, Scotland, a decade ago.

title: When Bernstein Saw the Future
description: It's difficult to understand the controversy that surrounded Leonard Bernstein's Norton Lectures at Harvard University in 1973 unless you were around at the time. Not literally in attendance, because the telegenic Bernstein made sure that his six talks were videotaped and broadcast. They were elaborate events, run through with musical examples ranging from simple points Bernstein made at the piano to entire compositions performed under his direction by the Boston Symphony Orchestra.

title: Executive Changes
description: LEVI STRAUSS & CO., San Francisco, named William Chiasson chief financial officer, effective next month, succeeding George James, who retired on June 30. Mr. Chiasson is senior vice president-finance and information systems of Kraft Foods Inc., a unit of Philip Morris Cos.

title: Jett, Ex-Kidder Trader, Must Repay Millions
description: An administrative law judge has ordered Joseph Jett, the former star bond trader at Kidder, Peabody & Company who was accused of manufacturing huge phantom trading profits, to repay $8.2 million that he received in bonuses. The judge also fined Mr. Jett $200,000, and barred him from the securities business.

title: All Nippon May Cut Affiliates' Costs
description: The All Nippon Airways Company, Japan's second-largest airline, may combine the accounting, personnel and management operations in its hotel division and later undertake similar administrative consolidations in other affiliated businesses, Mitsuo Ota, a senior managing director of All Nippon, said. The change would cut costs as the carrier faces intensifying competition within the airline industry.

title: U.N. Aide Quits Iraq Relief Post
description: Denis J. Halliday, an Irish expert in development who was given the job of injecting momentum into a faltering relief program in Iraq, has decided to leave the post after less than a year, United Nations officials said today.

title: Cone Delivers In Short Order
description: On the night after, David Cone restored some semblance of sanity to Yankee Stadium. The Yankees and the Detroit Tigers did not play 26 innings, or even 17. They did not take 5 hours 50 minutes to play the game the Yankees won, 5-1.

title: Volatile Chemicals Suspected in '96 Plane Fire
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said today that it suspected the cause of an in-flight fire on a Federal Express DC-10 in September 1996 was improperly shipped hazardous material, volatile chemicals in a piece of biomedical equipment. But today's final report on the incident stopped short of identifying those chemicals as the definitive cause of the fire.

description: Sizzling on the Internet: Barbecued Hog and More

title: Why Roast In the Heat? Just Poach, Add Sauce, Chill Out
description: LIKE many cooks, I often shy away from cooking meat on a hot summer's night -- unless someone else volunteers to fire up the grill, of course. But roasts and other large cuts of meat do not have to be forsaken completely this time of year: simply poach them ahead of time and serve them cool, with a flavorful sauce on top. With a salad on the side, you've got an easy supper that cuts down on heat in the kitchen and gives the cook a well-deserved break.

title: Bear Stearns Reports Rise in 4th Quarter
description: The Bear Stearns Companies said yesterday that earnings for its fiscal fourth quarter rose nearly 47 percent, led by investment banking and commissions.

title: $45 Million for School That Fosters World Peace
description: A $45 million gift to an international school that promotes world peace and understanding was announced yesterday by the money manager Shelby M. C. Davis and his wife, Gale.

title: Via Flushing to Dumplings, Eels and Old Shanghai
description: I WOULDN'T call myself desperate to find good Chinese restaurants: I'm just extremely eager. So when I received an effusive letter from a reader about Shanghai Tang, a new restaurant in Flushing, Queens, I was on my way.

description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that inflation remains more of a risk than recession, despite the sharp slowdown in economic growth caused in recent months by Asia's financial crisis.

description: ''Several stories worth of this torn tracking just started to separate from the structure, and the construction workers began herding people out of the way. It was like Godzilla coming. Everyone was scattering and I ran for my life.''

title: Starts on New Homes Grew 5.6% in June
description: Builders started work on more new homes in June than in the previous month as they sought to keep pace with record sales.

description: WHILE you browse the menu at Destinee, on East 61st Street, your napkin is lifted and handed to you and a small white plate is set down on your place setting. If you are lucky, it will hold a precisely cut cylinder of smoked salmon, filled with fresh shredded crab and dabbed with caviar, a glistening stain of pesto oil spooned around it.

title: Reed Keeps the Pirates Off the Plate
description: Rick Reed provided one of his amazingly precise pitching performances last night. So precise that the only unanswered question was why Mets Manager Bobby Valentine did not leave him in to pitch the ninth inning and possibly record a shutout. So precise that Reed's greatest concern after the 4-0 victory over Pittsburgh was how quickly he could pack for the departure to Milwaukee.

title: RAYTHEON TO BUY ALLIED SIGNAL'S COMMUNICATIONS UNIT
description: The Raytheon Company, a military giant, agreed yesterday to acquire Allied Signal Inc.'s Communications Systems business. The Allied Signal Communications Systems business, based in Towson, Md., develops secure communications technology systems for combat identification, military radar and civilian air traffic management. Its 1998 revenue is estimated at $122 million. Raytheon, based in Lexington, Mass., said it had also agreed to sell its commercial aviation training business to GE Capital. Raytheon Systems Ltd. Flight Training, based at London's Gatwick Airport, provides commercial aircraft pilot training services and leases flight simulator time. Raytheon's class A shares fell $1.50 each, to $57.25.

title: Standard Chartered May Buy Asian Stakes
description: Standard Chartered Bank P.L.C., Britain's eighth-largest bank, said yesterday that it had been approached about buying stakes in several Asian banks and that it was considering making a purchase. The London-based bank, which earns about 60 percent of its money in Asia, has not held talks with these banks' shareholders and is waiting for ''the right opportunity,'' said Eva Law, a Standard Chartered spokeswoman in Hong Kong.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAESZLER, DONALD
description: BAESZLER-Donald. Passed away July 18, 1998. Formerly of Beverly Hills CA., and Staten Island, NY. He was a retired 27 year veteran homicide detective of the New York City Police Department. He was a recipient of the medal of valor from the police department. He is survived by a son Donald, of Finland, a daughter Lynn of Sarasota, FL, 4 grandchildren, a sister, Mrs. Doris Anglin and a nephew Jack Anglin, both of Staten Island, and dear friends Mr. and Mrs. Robert Tanenbaum and family of Beverly Hills, California. A funeral service will be held on Wednesday at the Good Shepherd Church, Beverly Hills, California.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBLATT, LILLIAN L.
