title: Golota Wins Decision Over Sanders in Slugfest
description: In a heavyweight fight right out of the old Movietone newsreels, Andrew Golota and Corey Sanders tonight took the 3,679 fans at Trump's Taj Mahal back to an era when two big lugs stood toe to toe and slugged each other from the opening bell. In the end, both fighters were standing and Golota (31-3) walked away with a 10-round unanimous decision over the less-experienced Sanders (16-6).

title: Minor Leaguer Signs Contract
description: The Rangers yesterday signed the free agent Chris Winnes, a 31-year-old right wing who had 17 goals and 23 assists in 64 games last season for the Rangers' American Hockey League affiliate in Hartford.

title: Profit Down For Texas Instruments
description: Texas Instruments Inc., the leading maker of semiconductors for mobile phones, reported a greater-than-expected decline in second-quarter profit yesterday, attributing it to weak prices for memory chips.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR FALLS 5.4 PERCENT. Sugar tumbled on speculation that a planned increase in import taxes by Russia would curtail demand from the leading importer of sugar. October contracts fell 0.49 cent, to 8.51 cents a pound.

Beloved husband of the late Belle, father and friend to son Leonard, loving grandfather of Holly and Kevin, devoted brother of Frieda Eckstein, Lillian Ziesel, and the late Erna Hochman, Otto, Emil and Jules Rothman. Robert was a mechanical engineer. Funeral service Wednesday, July 22 at Schoem's Menorah Chapel, West 150 Route 4, Paramus, N.J. at 10 A.M.

A Memorial Service will be held later in the summer in Claryville, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Frost Valley YMCA, 298 Claremont Avenue, Montclair, NJ 07042.

description: The Senate Finance Committee voted today to give President Clinton enhanced authority to negotiate international trade agreements, setting up an unusual political confrontation with the White House.

description: Oil revenue of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has fallen by a third this year because of the severe decline in prices, industry trade data show.

Beloved wife of the late Louis Hirsch; loving mother of Mary-Ann Hobel and her husband Philip; devoted grandmother of Joseph Hobel and his wife Marjorie Cohen, Michael Hobel and his wife Michal and Sara Hobel & her husband Andrew Gordon; cherished great-grandmother of Madeleine and Cleo Gordon, Adam, Ethan, Samuel and Zachary Hobel. We all love you. Rest in peace. Service on Thursday, July 23rd, 9:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: City Hall Memo; 11 Steps That Help to Insure One's Point of View Is Heard
description: A few weeks ago, a group of Hasidic rabbis issued a press release announcing plans to ''invoke a biblical curse on any city official'' who dared to support a bill that benefited gay and lesbian couples in New York City. The time: noon. The place: where else but on the steps of City Hall?

title: Nova of Canada to Purchase Huntsman Styrene Business
description: The Nova Corporation of Canada will acquire the bulk of the styrene operations of the Huntsman Corporation for $860 million (United States) in cash and preferred stock, the companies announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIVLEHAN, DENIS
description: KIVLEHAN-Denis, 66. Of Orangeburg, died on July 19, 1998 at his home. Mr. Kivlehan was born on July 4th, 1932 in Tubbercurry, County Sligo, Ireland, to Thomas and Bridget Kivlehan. He was married to Brigid (Della) Oates. A resident of Orangeburg since 1962, he formerly lived in the Bronx. Mr. Kivlehan formerly worked as a national school teacher in Ireland from 1954 to 1962; he was a loan department clerk for Morgan Guarantee Trust Company in New York from 1962 to 1987 and worked as a paper assembler for the New York Times in Edison, NJ, from 1987 to 1997. He was a parishioner of St. Catharine's R.C. Church in Blauvelt. Survived by his wife Brigid (Della), daughters Maureen Labarbera of Waldorf, MD., and Patricia Dougherty of Glenside, PA., and his son Thomas of Hellertown, PA.; sisters Theresa Davey of Blauvelt and Margaret Kelly of the Bronx; a brother Martin of Blauvelt, and three grandchildren. Wake today, 2-4, 7-9PM, Moritz Funeral Home, Tappan, NY. Mass of Christian Burial, Thursday 10AM, St. Catherine's R.C. Church, Blauvelt. Burial follows in St. Anthony's Cemetery, Nanuet. Memorial donations may be made to the United Hospice of Rockland, New York.

title: The New Immigrant Experience
description: New York City is the capital of the new global economy and also America's traditional port of immigration. Put these together and you get, as Deborah Sontag and Celia Dugger have vividly reported in The Times this week, a new phenomenon of people living in two homelands, old and new, virtually at once. Previous immigrants remembered and even revisited their homelands. But this is the first immigrant generation that can connect back home instantaneously by cell phone, videophone and the Internet. Cheap airfares and relaxed rules on dual citizenship also help many people maintain lifelong relationships with their ancestral lands.

title: Court Upholds Limits On Signs at Sex Shops
description: The State Supreme Court yesterday affirmed an Appellate Division ruling that a state law regulating signs posted outside sex shops does not violate free speech rights.

title: LERNOUT & HAUSPIE IS IN $71 MILLION DEAL FOR GLOBALINK
description: Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products N.V. has agreed to buy Globalink Inc. for about $71.1 million in stock. Lernout said late on Monday that it would pay $5.60 a share for all of Globalink's 12.7 million shares outstanding. Globalink, based in Fairfax, Va., provides language translation software. The company had 1997 revenues of $14.7 million. Lernout & Hauspie, based in Belgium and Burlington, Mass., develops speech-recognition equipment. The company had 1997 revenues of $99.4 million. Shares of Globalink rose 18.75 cents, to $4.8125.

title: S.E.C. Settlement In Insider Case
description: Joseph Penna, an associate of a former AT&T labor relations executive, Charles Brumfield, settled Securities and Exchange Commissions allegations today that he earned $36,671 in illegal profits on call option contracts bought with inside information about a planned acquisition by the AT&T Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   RAFSKY, ROBERT ALAN
description: RAFSKY-Robert Alan. July 22, 1945-February 21, 1993 With pain so deep we do not cry For we refuse to say goodbye We call your name and hope you'll say, ''Hi! How are you, how's your day?'' Your voice still echoes in our souls And will forever as time unfolds

title: So Much for Elections
description: Anyone wondering why New York City is cursed with an abysmally weak Congressional delegation could find the answer this week in Queens. Representative Thomas Manton, the longtime incumbent from the Seventh District, announced in the dark of night that he would not be running for re-election. Before most of the active Democrats in the district had even heard the news, Mr. Manton had engineered the installation of a hand-picked successor in a method that appears to guarantee a virtually uncontested election this fall.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about voluntary guidelines on Internet privacy proposed by an industry coalition misidentified the author of a bill intended to protect the privacy of children on line. He is Senator Richard H. Bryan, a Nevada Democrat, not Representative Ed Bryant, a Tennessee Republican.

title: Tests at Construction Site Fail to Explain Illnesses
description: Tests on soil, air and water samples taken at an Edison construction site have failed to offer an explanation for the dizziness, nausea and yellowing tongues reported by workers since March, the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration said yesterday.

title: FESTIVAL REVIEW/Music; What Bernstein Wasn't Ready to Have Heard
description: No doubt many composers have all sorts of pieces written for all sorts of occasions buried away in file drawers and closets, works not quite ready for the public. Leonard Bernstein produced a fair share of such pieces, and though he made no attempt to display them during his lifetime, he would probably have been delighted that Michael Barrett, a pianist, conductor and music adviser to the Bernstein estate, did so for him.

title: New Pro, Rose, 17, Has Talent and Maturity
description: The men are still being separated from the boys in golf, but not always in the traditional order. Though Mark O'Meara won his second major of the year at age 41 when he captured the British Open today, change still appears to be in the wind in this game where experience and maturity have long had the edge on youthful insouciance and exuberance.

title: Philip Morris Posts 8.9% Rise in Earnings
description: The Philip Morris Companies, the world's largest cigarette maker, reported an 8.9 percent gain in second-quarter operating earnings yesterday on increased sales of its Marlboro brand overseas, which helped offset the effects of a decline in smoking in the United States. The diversified food company, which also makes products such as Kraft cheeses and Miller beer, said earnings before one-time charges rose to $2 billion, or 82 cents a diluted share, from $1.84 billion, or 75 cents, a year earlier. That matched the average forecast of analysts polled by the First Call Corporation, which tracks earnings estimates.

title: The Zen Of Building A Plane Yourself
description: Building a homemade airplane in 30 days sounds like a sufficiently antic project to make for an engaging three hours of television. But ''Plane Crazy'' also involves being in the company of Robert X. Cringely for most of the time, which can be wearing.

title: Suspects in Bomb Plot Had 'Warped' Politics, Prosecutor Says
description: A Federal prosecutor urged a jury yesterday to convict two Palestinian immigrants of plotting to explode a powerful pipe bomb in the New York City subway in a scheme that he said had been motivated by a ''warped view of Palestinian nationalism.''

A memorial service will be held at All Saints Church, 230 East 60 Street, Monday, July 27 at 6:30PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Glaucoma Foundation, 33 Maiden Lane, New York, New York 10038.

description: The Kmart Corporation is joining the ranks of retailers promoting their private-label jeans lines with a national television campaign for its Route 66 brand. The commercials are unusual for Kmart in their hip, contemporary attitude meant to reach younger consumers.

description: Bob McAllister, who talked his way into a television career without moving his lips, became the host of an acclaimed children's show, then made magic his metier, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 63 and best known for his decade as the ebullient, Buster Brown-coiffed host of ''Wonderama.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARKE, JOHN HENRIK
description: CLARKE-John Henrik. The Hunter College community notes with sadness the passing of John Henrik Clarke, a distinguished, selftaught and outspoken scholar. Founder and former Chairman of the Hunter College Black and Puerto Rican Studies Department, prolific author and editor, Mr. Clarke revolutionized the field of African studies with his brilliant and iconoclastic writings. Hunter has been privileged to benefit from his wise teaching and ardent advocacy of incorporating African history and culture into the context of world history. We extend our condolences to his family.

title: CONAGRA BUYS SEVERAL MARGARINE BRANDS FROM NABISCO
description: Conagra Inc. said yesterday that it had bought several margarine brands, including Fleischmann's, Parkay and Blue Bonnet, from the Nabisco Holdings Corporation for undisclosed terms, giving Conagra the second-largest United States margarine business. Conagra, the No. 2 United States food company, is also buying the Touch of Butter, Chiffon and Move Over Butter spreads and Egg Beaters egg substitutes. The products had sales of $480 million last year. Nabisco said it sold the margarine business as part of its efforts to focus only on snack foods like Ritz crackers and Oreo cookies. title: UNITED COMPANIES LOOKS FOR STRATEGIC PARTNER
description: The United Companies Financial Corporation, a home mortgage lender, said yesterday that it was looking for a ''potential strategic partnership,'' which could include selling the company, to help increase earnings as competition rises. The company, based in Baton Rouge, La., also warned that second-quarter earnings were likely to miss analysts' forecasts as borrowers paid off loans faster than expected. It now expects to report next week that net income for the quarter fell about 50 percent, to between 10 and 15 cents a diluted share. Analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation expected 29 cents a share. The stock of United Companies rose $1.375, to $15.8125, giving the company a market capitalization of $455.44 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHELFELDER, PHYLLIS DEVENEAU
description: MICHELFELDER-Phyllis Deveneau. Of Gulfstream, FL, was born in Chicago, Illinois, on December 30, 1921 and died on July 18, 1998, at Boynton Beach, FL., following complications from surgery. She was predeceased by her husband, William F. Michelfelder, author & freelance writer. Mrs. Michelfelder, a graduate of the University of New Hampshire, had a Master of Science degree in Counseling Psychology from Nova University, and was a Licensed Mental Health Counselor and Certified Addictions Professional. Before moving to Palm Beach County with her husband in 1971, Mrs. Michelfelder was on the staff of New Jersey College for Women (now Douglass College of Rutgers University). Her career included development/fundraising administrator at Columbia University in New York City, and several women's colleges. She also served as the Associate Director of the Independent Colleges Funds of America and was a member of the professional fundraising firm of Tamblyn and Brown in New York City. In 1974, she and Dr. Susan B. Anthony cofounded Wayside House, Inc. in Delray Beach, a multi-faceted center for the treatment of drug and alcohol abuse, and family and children's counselling. Mrs. Michelfelder started as a volunteer at Wayside House and was President of the Board of Directors until December 15, 1977, when she assumed the position of Executive Director, which she held consecutively thereafter until her retirement on April 1, 1998. In 1994 she received the Pioneer Award for life-long commitment and outstanding contributions in her field from the Comprehensive Alcoholism Rehabilitation Program (CARP). Her many awards also include: Professional of the Year from the Florida Alcohol and Drug Abuse Association; Nurses Annual Award; United Way/Red Ribbon Award, and the Susan B. Anthony Award as ''Outstanding Palm Beach County Feminist'' by South Palm Beach County's Chapter of NOW. Mrs. Michelfelder is survived by her brother, Nelson E. Deveneau and his family; her sister, Marion D. Stevens, and her family; and many friends. A memorial service will be held at 11:30 a.m. on Saturday, July 25, 1998, at Church of the Palms, Delray Beach, Florida, with a reception immediately following at the Wayside House. Interment will be private and at a later date. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Wayside House, Inc., or to the Church of the Palms Scholarship Fund, both of Delray Beach, Florida.

title: FRESH DEL MONTE IS IN $145 MILLION DEAL WITH IAT GROUP
description: Fresh Del Monte Produce Inc. agreed to acquire the operating subsidiaries of the privately held fresh fruit producer IAT Group Inc. for $25 million in cash and $120 million in stock. Fresh Del Monte will also assume $130 million in debt. The deal creates a combined entity with estimated 1997 sales of $1.5 billion and 16,000 employees in 20 countries. Fresh Del Monte, based in Coral Gables, Fla., has annual sales of $1.2 billion. IAT, with sales of $250 million, is a grower and exporter of fresh fruits and operations in Chile, Uruguay, California and the Netherlands. The company is owned by the Abu-Ghazaleh family, which also owns 63 percent of Fresh Del Monte Produce.

title: Brooklyn Judge Imposes A Death Sentence
description: A Brooklyn judge formally imposed a death sentence yesterday that a jury mandated last month for Darrel K. Harris, the former correction officer who was convicted of killing three people in a robbery in a social club. Mr. Harris is the first person sentenced to death under New York State's three-year-old capital punishment law.

title: 2 Securities Firms Will Pay Orange County $117 Million
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company and Nomura Securities International agreed today to pay a total of $117.5 million to Orange County, Calif., the latest in a flurry of settlements related to the largest municipal bankruptcy in the nation's history.

title: This House Is Not a Home: It's a Paul Smith Store
description: Local schoolchildren already have wind of the free gum-ball machine in the Children's Room (which also has an igloo-shaped changing area by the English designer Tom Dixon). Older shoppers wandering into Westbourne House, Paul Smith's new flagship store at 122 Kensington Park Road in London, get to see what happens when someone makes a new store out of an old house. With a discreet signature over the door and a traditional facade, Westbourne House looks much like every other Victorian town house in Notting Hill, a posh neighborhood of rock stars and bankers. But inside, six rooms function as boutiques selling Paul Smith men's, women's and children's wear, accessories, and a jumble of antique clothing, furniture books and curiosities. ''It's like Mr. Bean meets Savile Row,'' Mr. Smith said. ''My whole way of working is very tongue in cheek and often self-mocking.''

title: Alan B. Shepard Jr. Is Dead at 74; First American to Travel in Space
description: Alan B. Shepard Jr., the first American to fly in space, lifting national spirits at a decisive moment of cold war anxiety, and later one of only 12 astronauts to walk on the Moon, died late Tuesday night at a hospital in Monterey, Calif. He was 74 and lived in Houston and Pebble Beach, Calif.

title: Justice and Pan Am Flight 103
description: It has been nearly 10 years since terrorists bombed Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, killing 270 people. Early on, American investigators concluded that two Libyan intelligence agents had planted the bomb. But despite the pressure of international economic sanctions, Libya has refused to turn over the suspects to either Britain or the United States, preventing the case from coming to trial.

title: LUSCAR COAL BIDS FOR MANALTA COAL, A CANADIAN RIVAL
description: Luscar Coal Income Fund offered yesterday to buy a Canadian rival, Manalta Coal Income Trust, for $543.3 million (Canadian), or $364.3 million (United States). The combination would create North America's sixth-biggest coal producer. Together, the companies would have output of 41 million metric tons a year and revenue of $850 million (Canadian). The bid values Manalta at 12 percent more than its equity's closing price on Tuesday. The security, called installment receipts, has lost two-thirds of its value in 10 months. Manalta sold the receipts in a September public offering. Company officials were not available to comment on the bid.

title: OAKWOOD HOMES SHARES SLUMP ON 3D-QUARTER CHARGES
description: The stock of the Oakwood Homes Corporation tumbled yesterday after the Greensboro, N.C., company took charges in its third quarter to write down the value of its interests in mortgage securities. Oakwood, the nation's fifth-largest maker of manufactured homes, fell $10.0625 a share, to $20.9375. The charges, which caused earnings to plunge 78 percent for the quarter that ended June 30, come as the manufactured-home industry flourishes. It is the second straight quarter in which Oakwood has taken charges, this time totaling $35 million, for higher-than-expected prepayments and defaults on loans made to consumers that were later packaged as securities and sold to investors. Excluding the charges, earnings rose 17 percent in the quarter.

title: Wiping a Smile On Your Face
description: Ever have those mornings when you wish the first face you saw wasn't yours? Koo Koo, a two-year-old Vancover-based towel maker, has created Happy Face -- the towel. ''I was trying to think of something that would be nice to wake up to, that would make you smile,'' said Stephen Senini, 32, Koo Koo's designer. ''So many people wake up grumpy.'' Happy Face, 100 percent cotton terry cloth, comes in white and beige in sizes from face-cloth mitt ($12) to bath sheet ($50). Details, a new shop at 347 Bleecker Street (West 10th Street), stocks the towels; it is open from 1 to 11 P.M. Towels are also available from Koo Koo, (604) 844-7445. WILLIAM L. HAMILTON

title: Corbett Monica, 68, Comedian; Toured With Big-Name Singers
description: Corbett Monica, the durable comedian whose gentle jokes went down so well for so long that he spent more than 40 years touring as the opening act for Frank Sinatra and other big name singers, died yesterday at his home in North Miami, Fla. He was 68 and best recalled by television audiences as Joey Bishop's best friend on the 1960's ''Joey Bishop Show.''

title: Freshening Up Brooks Brothers
description: Brooks Brothers, the quintessentially preppy haberdashery, which was founded in 1818 and introduced the all-American sack suit in 1895, has been thought of as irredeemably stodgy. But Brooks Brothers -- known as ''B squared'' and patronized by Abraham Lincoln, Nelson A. Rockefeller, John F. Kennedy and Jacqueline Kennedy -- is getting ready to burnish its brand name. In September, a men's luxury collection will open on the redesigned sixth floor of the Madison Avenue shop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIR, HENRY J.
description: LEIR-Henry J. The Board of Trustees, the President, the Administration, and the Faculty and Staff of Clark University mourn the passing of their friend and supporter of many projects of mutual interest in Luxembourg. Through his generous support of CECIL (The Clark European Center in Luxembourg) Henry Leir enabled Clark faculty and students to study and teach in Luxembourg, the country which provided him with refuge from Nazi Germany in 1933 and the opportunities to become an international industrialist and philanthropist. The many Clark students and faculty who have been touched by Henry Leir's generousity and wisdom will always remember him and his special contribution to Clark University. Richard P. Traina, President Thomas Massey, Dean Walter Schatzberg, Professor and Director of CECIL

title: Failure's Hard But Success Can Be Worse
description: Making music after recovering from a failure or scandal can be very difficult, but it's even harder to make a record after recovering from a great success. For some musicians, it can be hard to write songs knowing that every word and every note will be scrutinized and held up for comparison against their previous work. Living with fame may be tough, but living up to high expectations is one of an artist's greatest challenges.

title: Starting on a Big Scale And Ending on a Small One
description: For 15 years, D. R. Miller was a millwork contractor, making cabinets and furniture for designers and architects for places like the Cub Room restaurant and the Savoy, both in SoHo. Now, he is designing trays and making them by hand. ''Inspired by Japanese architecture,'' as he puts it, the trays are machine cut from maple, ash and cherry, then assembled and finished by hand. For trays with a natural finish, $160 (15 1/2 by 21 inches) and $180 (17 by 25 inches); for trays with an ebonized finish (above), $175 and $195. At Bahay, 24 Ninth Avenue (13th Street); (212) 989-9412.

title: DuPont Profit Fell by 12% In 2d Quarter
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company reported a decline in profit of 12 percent for the second quarter today and said similar results were also likely for the current quarter. It had warned earlier this month that a decline could be expected.

title: UNITED VIDEO DROPS OFFER FOR GEMSTAR INTERNATIONAL
description: United Video Satellite Group Inc. dropped its $2 billion cash bid yesterday for Gemstar International Group Ltd. and said it would develop its own interactive program guide for digital cable television. Last week, Gemstar, of Pasadena, Calif., rejected the $45-a-share offer as too low and said it wanted remain independent. United Video, which is controlled by affiliates of Tele-Communications Inc., wanted to use Gemstar's technology to develop an on-screen programming service under the TV Guide brand. United Video recently agreed to buy TV Guide from the News Corporation. Shares of United Video, which is based in Tulsa, Okla., rose $1.3125 yesterday, to $33.75, while Gemstar fell $1.0625, to $38.6865.

title: A New Indictment Is Issued In the Columbia/HCA Case

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUNSON, CHARLES SHERWOOD (''SHERRY'')
description: MUNSON - Charles Sherwood (''Sherry''). Died at his home in Hobe Sound, FL. on Tuesday, July 21, 1998, in his 86th year. Beloved husband of Celia Deming Munson. Father of Marjorie Smith Munson and Jane Rust Munson Harrison, stepfather of Sharon Harts Wick and Deanne Harts Mallory, and grandfather of Timothy Laurel and Chauncey Rachael Sherwood Harrison. Mr. Munson was educated at the Taft School, after which he graduated with a BA from Yale. While at Yale, he was captain of the golf team, member of St. Elmo and President of the Intercollegiate Golf Association of America. In 1938 he attended Cambridge University and was a member of the Hawk's Club. From 1939-1944, he served as a Lt. Commander in the United States Navy during WW II in the Pacific, Atlantic and Caribbean theaters. Upon his return to the US, he worked at Vanadium Corp. as the assistant to the president until 1949 when he contracted polio. Although the wheelchair was the first thing that you saw, it was the last thing that you remembered. He faced this challenge head-on and remained fully active and committed to whatever he chose to accomplish. In 1953, he became a director of American European Securities Co., one of the first funds to combine European and American equity holdings. At that time, he was also a director at Reinsurance Corp. of America. In 1952, he was elected director of the Westport Bank and Trust, and the Connecticut New York Broadcasting Corp. In 1954, he was made a director at Baldwin-United Corporation. In 1959, he was promoted to the position of president of American European Securities, a post he held until 1972 when the company was sold. He also served as a director of the Eaton Corporation (1963-1981), Marine Midland Bank (1970-1982), Michigan Gas Utilities Co., and Baxter International, Inc. (1979-1990). In his retirement, Mr. Munson was the treasurer of the Hobe Sound Community Chest, a beloved volunteer teacher at the Hobe Sound Elementary School and a member of the board of directors of Planned Parenthood of the Palm Beach and Treasure Coast area. He was a member of The Links, Jupiter Island Club and past president of the Hobe Sound Yacht Club and The Country Club of Fairfield. His many published letters to newspaper editors served as a lesson to us all -''When we disagree, we should let it be known.'' A private memorial service will be held on July 24th, in Southport with burial in Woodbury, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Munson Fund No. 1134, The New York Community Trust, 2 Park Avenue, New York, New York 10016.

description: ''Computer, on'' and ''Computer, off'' may work on the Starship Enterprise, but other people still have to go through the motions of turning on their computers. Now a new product may turn logging on to a computer and protecting its data a hands-free operation.

title: A Place for Cell Phones?
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Transit and Traffic Changes in Midtown Today
description: SUBWAYS -- Trains will run on normal schedules, but the 42d Street subway station for the B and D lines will be accessible only through the 40th Street entrance. The entrance to the Times Square subway station at 43d Street and Broadway will be closed, but other entrances will be open.

title: Battle for Kosovo Town Grew in the Telling
description: Refugee families, their children looking stunned and exhausted, continued to arrive in this ethnic Albanian town today with detailed accounts of the terrors they say they survived in a battle between rebels and Government forces in Orahovac.

title: Serving Up a Smorgasbord of Choreography
description: Hungry theatergoers visiting the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival can find a restaurant, a pub and a snack bar on the grounds. But anyone who arrived on Tuesday night would also have discovered an artistically delectable treat inside the Ted Shawn Theater: a choreographic smorgasbord served up by the Miami City Ballet.

title: Public Eye; Passenger as Pilot: Navigating the Seat
description: EVERY time I board an airplane, economy-class ticket in hand, I experience what I think of as the Goldilocks syndrome. I work my way down the crowded aisle past the jumbo Papa Bear seats in first class, the more modest Mama Bear seats in business class and back to the little bitty Baby Bear seats in coach. Here the parallel with the fairy tale ends; no one in coach would ever declare that these tightly packed seats were ''just right.''

title: Mr. Secretary, Perhaps, and Ms. Ambassador
description: THE sign outside Kati Marton's Bridgehampton shingle house reads like the name of a big media law firm: ''Marton Holbrooke Jennings.''

title: 51 Years Later, Aliens Finally Get Tableware
description: What do you call this line of serving pieces? Flying Platters? Area 51? Actually, Wilton Armetale is calling it Roswell, after the town in New Mexico where aliens supposedly crash-landed 50 years ago last summer.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Mideast Peace Talks: Rumors Raise Hope
description: A flurry of diplomatic and political contacts and press leaks raised strong expectations today of a long-awaited break in the negotiating freeze between Israel and the Palestinians.

title: House Proud; Scaling Down the Space, but Not the Fantasy
description: AS the movers and shakers build 20,000-square-foot megamansions in the Hamptons and combine apartments on Park Avenue in Manhattan, the art dealer Holly Solomon is moving on down. Left behind: a nine-room apartment (plus maids' rooms and two storage rooms) on Sutton Place. Present home: a six-room apartment on the Upper East Side that seats six for dinner. That may seem more than adequate for most people, but Ms. Solomon used to give buffets for 100.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; At Computer Associates, Stock Option Plan Comes Home to Roost
description: An avalanche of selling hit the stock of Computer Associates International Inc. yesterday, after the company announced late Tuesday that unexpected tremors from the Asian economic crisis had reduced its sales expectations.

title: China's Chief Tells Army To Give Up Its Commerce
description: President Jiang Zemin ordered China's military to relinquish its sprawling multibillion-dollar commercial empire, saying it is the only way to combat an epidemic of smuggling, which the army dominates, the state news media reported today.

title: Despite Cutoff by U.S., Ethiopia and Eritrea Easily Buy Weapons
description: Two African countries that had seemed to be on the road to peace and the beginnings of prosperity are buying expensive weapons in preparation for a full-scale war that many officials fear will involve peasant armies and result in instability and another crisis in the Horn of Africa.

title: Woodworking Unplugged
description: ''EASY, fun and gorgeous.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDMAN, NATHAN
description: FREEDMAN-Nathan. Of Baltimore, MD. Survived by wife Helen B. Freedman, children Henry and Marianne Freedman, daughter-inlaw Helen E. Freedman and three grandchildren. Service, Thursday July 23 at 7 P.M., at the home of Henry Freedman.

title: Liverpool Journal; Britain's Shrine to the Beatles: It's Ever So Humble
description: The patterned brown sofa and armchair with the white linen antimacassars are where Paul McCartney and John Lennon, bending over their guitars and scribbling in a school notebook, wrote their first songs.

title: Steven Myers Acquisition
description: Steven Myers & Associates Inc. said today that it planned to acquire Decision-Science Applications Inc. for $30.9 million in stock and cash, to improve its technical services and nonmilitary business. Steven Myers helps companies, including the Lockheed Martin Corporation and the Boeing Company, write and secure contracts. The company said that if the merger was approved by Decision-Science shareholders, the addition of more than 230 scientists would almost triple its work force.

title: Health Care Hysteria, Part II
description: Politicians seem to think that Americans are clamoring for action on health care. This election year the debate has been redefined as voter anger at managed care plans. Democrats glimpse a winner, and Republicans scramble to cover themselves. Congress is rushing to regulate health maintenance organizations and to repeal existing legislation that shields health plans from high damages in lawsuits.

title: The Firestorm Cometh
description: Charles La Bella, who has been leading the Justice Department's campaign finance investigation, has now advised Attorney General Janet Reno that under both the mandatory and discretionary provisions of the Independent Counsel Act she must appoint an outside prosecutor to take over his inquiry. The other important figure of this investigation, Federal Bureau of Investigation Director Louis Freeh, has already recommended an independent counsel. Ms. Reno can give her usual runaround about being hard-headed, but she cannot hide from the meaning of this development.

title: Prices to Gargoyles: Co-ops Ranked on Web
description: WAKE up, you apartment fanatics!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, HERBERT
description: WOLF-Herbert. The Board of Governors and members of Tam O'Shanter Club are saddened by the passing of their member, Herbert Wolf. Our sincere condolences are extended to his wife Janice and the family. Robert Katz, President Donald Freedman, Secretary

title: Corrections
description: Two articles on Saturday about allegations of sexual misconduct among New York City police officers misstated the street number of what was said to be a brothel frequented by officers. It was at 335 West 39th Street, not 355 West 39th.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEE, AMANDA MERYL, DR.
description: SCHNEE-Amanda Meryl, Dr. Died on Sunday, July 19th, at the age of 52. She was born in North Berwick, Scotland, and completed a medical degree at St. Andrew's University in 1968. She began her career as a physician in Scotland and continued it in the United States, where she served as a civilian medical officer to the U.S. Air Force in Omaha, Nebraska, and as the Director of the Rice University Student Health Service for the last twenty years. She is survived by her husband Mark, her parents Daphne and Hamish MacNab, her four daughters, Samantha, Jicky, Pippa and Briony, and 4 siblings, Iain, Judy, Gavin, and Hamish, three of whom are physicians. Family and friends will gather for condolences at 9:00 AM, Thursday, July 23, 1998 at St. Anne Catholic Church at 2140 Westheimer at Shepherd. A Requiem Mass to celebrate her life will follow at 10:30AM. The family requests that, in lieu of flowers, donations be made to Rice University for the Dr. Amanda M. Schnee Student Health Service Memorial Fund (contact Stella Evenson at 713527-4032) or to the Texas Heart Institute in her name (contact Mark Mattsson at 713-791-3792) or to the Texas Heart Institute in her name (contact Mark Mattsson at 713791-3792). We hold the death of our wife, mother, daughter, sister, friend, physician and colleague deep in our hearts. Her legacy is one of joy, unbounded kindness, generosity and enduring love.

title: Neutral Experts Begin Studying Dispute Over Breast Implants
description: After 16 years of litigation and scientific controversy over the safety of silicone breast implants, a panel of independent experts today began its own inquiry into the dispute, which pits researchers who say there is no link between implants and disease against tens of thousands of women who say the devices made them sick.

title: NATIONAL PENN AGREES TO ADD ELVERSON NATIONAL BANK
description: National Penn Bancshares Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Elverson National Bank for around $104 million in stock. Under the deal, National Penn would exchange 1.175 shares for each Elverson share. Elverson's stock rose 75 cents a share, to $26.50, before the deal was announced and did not trade afterward, while National Penn was down $1.25 a share, to $32. National Penn, based in Boyertown, Pa., is a bank holding company with assets of $1.6 billion and 52 offices in southeastern Pennsylvania. Elverson, based in Elverson, Pa., has assets of $300 million and operates nine community banking offices. Separately, National Penn rescinded its buyback program, which had authorized the repurchase of up to 530,000 shares.

title: IRAN SAID TO TEST MISSILE ABLE TO HIT ISRAEL AND SAUDIS
description: Iran successfully tested a medium-range missile today, a senior Administration official said tonight. The weapon, with a range of about 800 miles, is capable of hitting Israel and Saudi Arabia, he said, and thus has the potential to alter the political and military balance of power in the Middle East.

title: A Strange Times Square
description: First off, it doesn't sound right. Silence in mid-city alerts the senses the way a loud noise unnerves people in the country. Here we are at the center of the universe, or more precisely at the center of our universe, and there are no cars lurching, no taxis honking, nobody begging quarters or selling cut-rate silk ties or chanting ''excuse me'' while shouldering through the tourists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALOFF, RUBIN
description: MALOFF-Rubin. On July 22, 1998. Devoted husband of Marilyn, beloved father of Lawrence, loving brother of Nathan, Aaron and Saul. Outstanding educator and trusted friend. Service Friday 11AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Prodigy Opens On-Line Classes To Teach Software Programs
description: Prodigy Internet has established an on-line learning center, offering training classes for popular applications from Microsoft, Adobe, Lotus and others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKERMAN, BEATRICE
description: ZUCKERMAN-Beatrice. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of its long time member and mother of our member, Jeffrey Zuckerman. May her entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob J. Schacter, Rabbi Samuel Goldman, President Elza Weinman, Sisterhood

title: Korean Union Defers Strike Set for Today
description: South Korea's second-largest union group said it would postpone a general strike scheduled to start today in an effort to clinch an agreement with the Government on layoffs and benefits. ''We decided to delay the planned strike as our talks with the Government are going smoothly,'' said Kim Yoo Jin, a director of the Korea Confederation of Trade Unions.

title: LIBRARY/GRAMMAR TUTORS; Grammar Aid for Those Who/Whom Need It
description: IN the mythical Golden Days, everyone had Miss Thistlebottom for eighth-grade English. (She was almost always Miss. Only in rare incarnations could she be spoken to as Miss T., though she was always spoken about that way.) She was an imposing woman with hair in a steel-gray bun and a formidable grasp of the minutiae of English grammar. Through force of will, and occasionally, according to legend, through force of ruler across knuckles, she was able to impart understanding of gerunds and infinitives to students by the cowering roomful.

title: Can Bioengineers Feed the Planet?
description: To the Editor:

title: International Briefs; Aerospatiale to Buy A Lagardere Unit
description: Aerospatiale, the big aerospace company, said yesterday that it would buy Lagardere S.C.A.'s military unit and that it planned to sell a fifth of the new company on the stock market before January. With the Lagardere unit, Matra Hautes Technologies, the company will have sales of about 80 billion francs ($13.3 billion) and estimated market value of 50 billion francs. It will rival British Aerospace P.L.C. as Europe's No. 1 military contractor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEUER, BERNARD
description: FEUER-Bernard. Dear Bernie, our loving friend, thanks for all the good times and for the breath of fresh air you were. May God grant you the eternal peace you so deserve. We will surely miss you. We wish to send heartfelt condolences to Marcia and the family. Jack, Rosalie, Carey, Billy and ''your girls'' Linda and Pat. Dobosh & Co.

title: Iran's Missile Test
description: Iran's test of a missile that can reach Israel, Saudi Arabia and Turkey is a disturbing and dangerous development. Testing such an advanced weapons system, potentially capable of carrying biological, chemical and nuclear as well as conventional weapons to targets 800 miles away, heightens anxieties in an already tense Middle East. It also raises new doubts about whether Iran, despite the encouraging words of its moderate President, Mohammad Khatami, is actually turning away from threatening its neighbors and from developing weapons of mass destruction, two conditions for improved relations with the United States.

title: Toxic Chemicals From 1970's Still Pollute Hudson, Study Says
description: A Federal environmental study has found that ''hot spots'' of PCB contamination in the upper Hudson River are not being buried in protective layers of silt, as some scientists have contended, but instead are disgorging fresh streams of the industrial PCB pollutants into the water, where they could accumulate in fish and pose a cancer threat to people who eat the fish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHARNEY, RUTH S.
description: CHARNEY-Ruth S. July 20,1998. Loving wife of the late Herman Charney. Dear sister of Martha, aunt of Joann, Michael and Peter. In lieu of flowers, contribution may be made to her favorite charity: New York Public Library, 42 St., Manhattan, in her name.

title: Are Teachers the Problem With Our Schools?
description: To the Editor:

title: Publicis Executive To Move to Lowe
description: Robert A. Kantor, chairman and chief executive at the New York office of Publicis, said yesterday that he would leave the agency after almost four years to join Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York as president for United States operations, effective Aug. 15.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: At the Movies; 'Ryan' Headed For an Oscar?
description: Is the Oscar race already over?

title: A Disheartening Turn In a Journey to Times Sq.
description: Steve Chang's journey to Times Square has taken him across three continents. Along the way, he has sold ice cream and corned beef sandwiches and golf equipment. Always, he looked ahead to the day he could open his own restaurant. And when that time came, it never occurred to him to look up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAURA, ANTONIO
description: SAURA-Antonio. In Cuenca Spain, on Wednesday, July 22, after a long bout with leukemia. Leaves his wife Mercedes, his daughter Marina, his brother Carlos, and his sister. Antonio Saura was a talented painter and his humanism and his modesty were known to all who knew him. Services private. His Friends in New York

title: By Appealing to Rebels, U.N. Chief Makes Peace With Mexico
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan of the United Nations has delicately defused a diplomatic crisis with the Mexican Government during a visit here by calling on the Zapatista rebels to return to the negotiating table to resolve the smoldering conflict in the state of Chiapas.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: International Briefs; ICI Shares Plunge On Earnings Report
description: The shares of Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. had their biggest one-day decline this decade, after the concern, Britain's biggest chemical company, posted lower-than-expected earnings and warned that worse was to come. The shares fell 131 pence, to 780, after ICI said net income in the second quarter rose 52 percent, to $:76 million ($125 million), from $:50 million a year ago, before exceptional items and good will. Analysts had been expecting a 62 percent rise.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKERMAN, BEATRICE
description: ZUCKERMAN-Beatrice. The Natinal Jewish Outreach Program mourns the passing of Beatrice Zuckerman, beloved mother of NJOP President, Jeffrey (Miriam) Zuckerman. Sincere condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Ephraim Z. Buchwald, Dir.

title: Investigation Widens in Tour Drug Scandal
description: Even as the race rested for its single day off, the drug scandal enveloping professional bicycle racing and the Tour de France widened today as three more officials and nine riders of a French team were taken into judicial custody and four officials of a Dutch team were being questioned by the police.

title: Antiques; Over the Top With Design In Everything
description: For our great-grandfathers, the concept of commissioning a house or a room in a single, coordinated style was novel. For them, art meant painting and sculpture.

title: Collapse in Times Sq. Hurts Fortunes of Four Hit Shows
description: While New Yorkers continued to cope with the disruption caused by the collapse of an elevator tower on Tuesday in Times Square, four major theater productions, including the popular ''Cabaret,'' were coping with more: financially onerous shutdowns of successful shows.

title: Married Marlowe and a Stretched Chandler
description: To expand on the work of Raymond Chandler, who succeeded in making literature out of the hard-boiled detective novel, undoubtedly takes the sort of nerve that Chandler endowed upon his proud, lonely philosopher-king of a gumshoe, Philip Marlowe. Nine years ago, Robert B. Parker took such a gamble by finishing a last Marlowe novel that Chandler, who died in 1959 at 70, had laid aside after only a tentative start. The result, ''Poodle Springs,'' was a defying-the-odds delight, a homage to Chandler and his ideas about personal integrity that artfully avoided parody.

title: Metro Business; Power Plant Expansion
description: Sithe Energies Inc., one of the largest builders and operators of power plants in the United States, said yesterday that it was planning a $400 million expansion at a power plant in upstate New York.

title: 91 Accused of Running Stolen Parts Network
description: Ninety-one people were arrested yesterday on charges that they operated a stolen auto parts network, based in Brooklyn, that had links to the Gambino and Lucchese organized crime families.

title: Observer; Strange Change Of Venue
description: I am amazed to learn that Art Buchwald, dean of American humor columnists, has moved to New York. Buchwald's home base has been Washington ever since the British burned the White House. They would have gone ahead and burned Georgetown too, he wrote, but it was teatime.

title: Boeing Earnings News Disappoints Investors
description: The Boeing Company stunned investors yesterday with news of a steep drop in second-quarter earnings and an even more unexpected warning that results for both this year and next will be about 40 percent below Wall Street estimates.

title: Inside Art; Selling Icons Of Modern Art
description: While much of the art world slows down in the summer, for auction house experts it's one of the busiest times of the year. July and August are when they travel the world, trying to get property to sell for the big auctions in November. And when a house obtains an important collection to sell, it is generally announced as soon as possible to encourage other sellers to follow.

title: Elusive Bombing Fugitive Divides a Town
description: There is a part of this town that is rooting for Eric Robert Rudolph to elude the camouflaged G-men and their droopy-eared bloodhounds, and not just because the six-month search for Mr. Rudolph, the accused abortion clinic bomber, has been good for business.

title: Political Briefing; Basking in a Golden Glow, State Legislators Welcome More Responsibility
description: The 1,200 state legislators who gathered in this desert gambling mecca this week for the annual meeting of the National Conference of State Legislatures had the look of winners.

title: TOP REPUBLICANS IN SENATE REJECT BIG TAX-CUT PUSH
description: Republican leaders in the Senate have decided that it would be futile to push for a big tax cut this year, infuriating conservatives in the House and the Senate who had hoped the prospect of huge Federal budget surpluses would lead to swift passage of sweeping tax reductions, members of Congress and aides said today.

title: Pepsico Studies Possible Conversion of Bottling Operations
description: Pepsico yesterday made its second major move this week to become a fiercer competitor to the Coca-Cola Company, saying it was studying the possible conversion of some bottling operations into a separate publicly traded company.

title: CAPITAL AUTOMOTIVE TO BUY 67 AUTO DEALER PROPERTIES
description: Capital Automotive REIT continued a series of acquisitions when it agreed yesterday to buy 67 auto dealership properties for about $334.5 million in cash and partnership units from Automotive Realty Trust of America. Terms of the purchase were not released. Capital Automotive, based in McLean, Va., has bought properties worth about $560 million since completing its $300 million initial public offering in February. It is the first real estate investment trust, or REIT, to focus on auto-dealership properties. Automotive Realty, based in Dallas, had expected to become the second auto dealership REIT and had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in April to raise $152 million in an initial offering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRECO, EDMUND
description: GRECO-Edmund. We mourn the loss of our dear and longtime friend and offer our deep condolences to his wife and family. Algernon Miller Constance Miller

title: Accounts
description: * Desert Glory, San Antonio, to Richards Group, Dallas, as the first agency to handle advertising for the marketer of Nature Sweet tomatoes. Billings were estimated at $3 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVER, SIMON
description: SILVER-Simon. We are diminished by the loss of our devoted, dedicated past President, who was a most important influence and help to us for over 40 years. Condolences to his life partner, Ethel, his sons, sisters and all the family. East End Temple Helene Spring, President Deborah A. Hirsch, Rabbi Fran Kolin, Sisterhood Pres

title: Chance and Fate at Play In 10 Modern Moral Tales
description: ''The Decalogue'' was shown at the Walter Reade Theater in 1996. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 8, 1996. The 10 films, directed by Krzysztof Kieslowski, who died in 1996, will play at the Walter Reade, 165 West 65th Street at Lincoln Center, today through Thursday. Schedule information: (212) 875-5600.

title: In the Forbidden City, a Tale Of Dissidence and Desire
description: Were it just that this is an independent film from China, where the Government has long intruded on the production and release of motion pictures, ''East Palace, West Palace'' would be noteworthy.

title: Louisiana Seizes Management Of Privately Run Youth Prison
description: Louisiana officials have taken over temporary management of a troubled, privately run juvenile prison after the warden resigned following a lawsuit, critical reports by Federal investigators and several disturbances by inmates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, HAROLD
description: LEVINE-Harold. Died July 14, 1998 in Plainview, N.Y. at age 82 after a long illness. Beloved husband of Sophie. Devoted father of Norman and Robert. Devoted grandfather of Karen and Eva. Chairman of English at Richmond Hill H.S. and Benjamin Cardozo H.S. Executive Assistant for English in the High School Division at the NYC Board of Education. Author of The Joy of Vocabulary, Vocabulary for the College-Bound Student, English: A Comprehensive Course and many other AMSCO School Publications.

title: SPARE TIMES: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Vogue's Untimely Cover Heralds the New Tower
description: The August issue of Vogue is just beginning to show up in subscribers' mailboxes and on newsstands. Its cover features a model, Carolyn Murphy, in elegant ivory evening wear atop none other than Conde Nast's future home at 4 Times Square.

title: Brady Competing for his Job and Contract
description: Finally, with a stable Jets team in his life, Kyle Brady is at his most uncertain since his rookie days.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the foreign news media's coverage of the race for Prime Minister of Japan misattributed a response to a Foreign Ministry official's statement about foreign journalists' relying too often on the same commentators to explain Japanese politics. It was Robert Neff, the president of the Foreign Correspondents Club of Japan, not John F. Neuffer, a political analyst, who said he regarded the comment as unfair criticism.

title: Pop and Jazz Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

description: Vehicles and pedestrians will not be allowed from 42d Street to 45th Street between Avenue of the Americas and Broadway. The following traffic changes will be in effect:

title: Once Again, Brawley Declines to Testify
description: More than a decade after she frustrated investigators by refusing to testify about her allegations of abduction and rape, Tawana Brawley failed to appear in court today.

title: Jury Convicts Man in Scheme To Set a Bomb In the Subway
description: A Palestinian immigrant who testified that he had wanted to kill as many Jews as possible in a suicide attack was convicted yesterday of plotting to explode a powerful pipe bomb in the New York City subway.

title: Tinkering With Nature
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Stripper Reveals Herself, in a Memoir
description: SHERRY BRITTON, the onetime striptease star who at age 80 has taken to calling herself Stripteasaurus Sex, has not been following Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's attempts to clean up the city's sex clubs. She's been too busy, working on her memoirs. (''One thousand pages; think I need an editor?'' she asks cheerfully.)

title: International Briefs; Nestle Sales Rose 12.4% In Second Quarter
description: Nestle S.A.'s implied second-quarter sales rose 12.4 percent, short of most analysts' forecasts, as sluggish sales in Japan and Brazil and a stronger Swiss franc partly offset growth in other markets. The world's biggest food company's implied sales in the three months through June rose to 18.1 billion francs ($12 billion) from 16.1 billion in the corresponding period of 1997. The company's stock fell 124 Swiss francs, to 3,312, its biggest one-day loss in nine months.

title: Outcry Erupts Over Palestinians' Statements on Holocaust
description: American Jewish organizations and Holocaust scholars are calling on Yasir Arafat to reprimand Palestinian officials and journalists who have recently made statements that appear to distort the history of the Holocaust or deny its existence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAIRD, ROBERT B.
description: BAIRD-Robert B. The Board of Directors of Central Suffolk Hospital mourn the passing of our colleague, Robert B. Baird. His valuable insight regarding the well being of the residents of our community, as well as his candor and humor will be remembered forever. Jesse R. Goodale, III, Chairman Joseph F. Turner, Jr. President and CEO

title: Pope Tightens Grip by Rome On Its Bishops
description: Seeking to curb the independence of bishops, Pope John Paul II issued an apostolic letter today that tightens Rome's control over 108 bishops' conferences around the world.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Technology; Net-Savvy Car Takes Computer For a Ride
description: WHAT'S the next big thing? To judge from many of the concept cars at this year's auto shows, it is an on-board computer that would allow a driver or passenger to log onto the Internet to read or send E-mail, check stock quotes or get traffic reports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALOFF, RUBIN
description: MALOFF-Rubin. On July 22, 1998. Devoted husband of Marilyn, beloved father of Lawrence, loving brother of Nathan, Aaron and Saul. Outstanding educator and trusted friend. Service Friday 11AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Protecting Digital Copyrights
description: Traditional copyright concepts that have served this nation well for centuries should guide the debate on copyright in the digital universe. As Congress fashions ways to protect commercial interests in the digital realm, it must be careful also to protect the larger public interest in broad access to information.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, LEWIS LOFSKY
description: SMITH-Lewis Lofsky. Of Great Neck, New York. Died peacefully at his home on Tuesday, July 21, 1998. Beloved husband of Beth Pearlman Smith; caring and loving father of Ethan Lofsky Smith and Rachel Lofsky Smith; son-in-law of Alexander W. Pearlman; brotherin-law of Deborah Pearlman and Ellyn Shander; uncle of Eytan Shander; dear friend of Kathryn Goodman. Lewis was a dedicated astronomer in the Research Department at Grumman Aerospace Corporation for 33 years. He held a Ph.D. in electrophysics. He was a consummate teacher, who shared his knowledge and humor with everyone he encountered. May his star shine on forever.

title: In the Park With Masur: Humidity and Mussorgsky
description: High temperatures, humidity, an afternoon storm and the threat of another did not deter picnickers and music fans on Tuesday evening, when the New York Philharmonic opened its 34th annual series of free outdoor concerts with a performance on the Great Lawn of Central Park.

title: New Spokesman Heeds Hard Lesson From 1988
description: As he recalls it a decade later, that summer of 1988 taught Joseph Lockhart a lesson he would never forget.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-11

title: Large Surplus For Transit Could Mean More Service
description: For the second year in a row, New York City's mass transit system is on its way to running up a large surplus that, if it holds up, will probably be used to add bus and subway service, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday.

title: Israel Cites Its Warnings on Iran but Sees No Missile Peril Now
description: Israel today treated Iran's test of a medium-range missile as confirmation of its insistent warnings over many months about Iran's efforts to develop a long-distance strategic threat.

title: World News Briefs; Russian Tax Problem For Johnson & Johnson
description: Tax authorities say that a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson, the world's fifth-largest drug maker, owes them almost $19 million in back taxes and that they have begun criminal cases against two of the company's managers here.

title: Senate Puts Aside Bill to Punish Nations That Persecute Religion
description: Legislation to require the United States Government to punish foreign countries that permit or endorse religious persecution was put off indefinitely today by a Senate committee because Republicans were deeply divided over the issue.

title: HBO Tribute to Ruth Is the 'Most Wonderful' One
description: She celebrated her 81st birthday last week, but when Julia Ruth Stevens reminisces about her father, she sounds 18. She smiles in a dreamy way about Babe Ruth and clasps her hands over her heart when she speaks of ''Daddy.'' There were tears in her eyes as she looked out at an audience that had been invited to screen HBO's ''Babe Ruth'' documentary Wednesday in Manhattan.

title: Juice-Poisoning Case Brings Guilty Plea and a Huge Fine
description: In what Federal officials say is the first criminal conviction in a large-scale food-poisoning outbreak, Odwalla Inc. pleaded guilty today to violating Federal food safety laws and agreed to pay a $1.5 million fine for selling tainted apple juice that killed a 16-month-old girl and sickened 70 other people in several states in 1996.

title: A Tribute To a Master Who Swings
description: The Jazz in July series at the 92d Street Y is special because the music, organized by Dick Hyman, generally has a sense of loveliness and humor that comes from another place and time: it is unhurried and gentle. On Tuesday night, opening the series, Mr. Hyman led a number of bass players and other musicians through a tribute to the 88-year-old bassist Milt Hinton.

title: AT&T Ad Filmed in Vietnam Was a Long Time Coming
description: A television commercial begins with a man in his 20's riding in a boat on a river. He disembarks, asks directions, reaches the top of a mountain and pensively looks around. ''My dad was here,'' he says. ''He never talked about it much. He said we had to be there. Here I am.''

title: The Taste of Cool

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRISTOPHERSON, DONOVAN R.
description: CHRISTOPHERSON-Donovan R. (''Dick''), 65, of Scottsdale, died on July 14, 1998. He was born in Ostrander, MN. on November 22, 1932. He graduated form St. John's University in Collegeville, MN in 1954, served as an officer in the U.S. Navy, and went on to earn his Master of Business Administration degree from the University of Minnesota. He worked for The Pillsbury Company & subsidiaries for twenty-three years, eventually holding the position of Chief Financial Officer of Burger King Corporation in Miami, Florida. From 1981 to 1994, he was a senior financial executive with Pepsico, Inc. in Purchase, NY. In 1994, he and his wife Mary retired to Scottsdale. They built their dream home in the desert surrounded by mountains, coyotes, javelinas and beautiful sunsets. Dick was a devoted husband, father, and grandfather. He is survived by his daughter, Mary Hoff, and her husband, Gene of Plymouth, MN; his son, Tom, and his wife, Judith of Schlossborn, Germany; his son, Jim, and his wife, Susan of Scottsdale, AZ; his daughter, Anne Christopherson of Corcoran, MN, and his grandchildren, Jan-Constantin and Nils-Frederick, both of Schlossborn, Germany, whom he dearly loved. His sister, Betty Wagner, and his brothers Robert, William, David, and Michael also survive Dick. A memorial Service will be held on Monday, July 27, 1998, at 2:00 PM at Messinger Mortuary & Chapel, 7601 E. Indian School Road, Scottsdale, AZ 85251. Memorial donations may be made to the Donovan R. Christopherson Scholarship Fund, in care of St. John's University, Collegeville, MN, 56321. Rest well, Papa.

description: GOLDMAN-David E. Loving husband and best friend of Jeanne, devoted father and role model to son James and daughter-in-law Elizabeth, and greatly beloved grandfather to Julie and Matthew. title: White House Says Veto of 'Patient Protection' Bill Is Likely
description: The White House said tonight that President Clinton would probably veto the version of ''patient protection'' legislation that Republican leaders plan to take up in the House of Representatives on Friday.

description: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation reported a $130 million second-quarter loss yesterday from the effects of the strong dollar on overseas cigarette sales, weakness in the company's food business and tobacco-litigation settlement costs.

title: Microsoft Describes a Successful Year and Talks of More
description: Confident Microsoft executives today outlined for industry analysts a string of successes suggesting momentum throughout the computer industry in markets as diverse as home computers, business desktop machines, engineering work stations and the giant computers that connect entire corporations and serve up World Wide Web sites on the Internet.

title: Closing Arguments Heard in 2d Trial for Officer's 1976 Murder
description: Hobbled by a 22-year gap between the crime and the courtroom, lawyers in the murder trial of Vincent James Landano delivered their closing arguments today, sending one of New Jersey's longest-running judicial dramas to a jury, which is scheduled to begin deliberations on Monday.

title: Quietly, New York City Backs Kennedy Rail Line
description: Three months after threatening to oppose a plan by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to build a rail line to Kennedy International Airport, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has quietly joined other officials in signing an agreement to support the project, city officials said yesterday.

title: International Briefs; ABB Posts 15% Rise In 2d-Quarter Profit
description: ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd., the world's largest electrical-engineering company, said yesterday that its second-quarter profit rose 15 percent as it reduced costs and benefited from growth in Europe and the United States. Net income in the three months through June rose to $380 million from $331 million a year earlier, in line with expectations. Orders, however, fell 9 percent, to $8.9 billion from $9.8 billion, suggesting the company, a maker of power stations and robots, will struggle to maintain the pace of profit growth.

title: Sheldon Silver Caves
description: After a do-nothing legislative session that ended last month, the New York State Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, has now called his house back to Albany to do something foolish. He wants the members to pass a sham parole bill called ''Jenna's law'' that is being pushed by the Republican Senate and Gov. George Pataki.

title: Mayor Faults Offer of Aid For Victims of Collapse
description: As the long-term costs of the Times Square construction site collapse became a sobering reality -- with at least 600 people left homeless and Broadway productions and local businesses shut down indefinitely -- Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday dismissed as inadequate a $50,000 compensation offer made by the owner and builder of the troubled Conde Nast building.

title: Waiting for Their Role In a Make-Believe World
description: Like a late-20th-century Atget, the British-born photographer Michael Kenna insists on seeing the quietly luminous in landscapes molded by the human hand. Atget had a gift for evoking the human presence in his photographs of Paris without showing a single soul. And Mr. Kenna, too, suggests the human presence in pictures taken at night or in the early morning -- at the Rouge steel plant in Dearborn, Mich., for instance, or at the gardens in France designed by Andre le Notre, the great 17th-century French landscape architect -- when there is no one around.

title: DELUXE TO CLOSE PRODUCTION AND DISTRIBUTION OUTLETS
description: The Deluxe Corporation, the nation's largest check printer, said yesterday that it planned to close three facilities in the United States during the coming year, affecting 400 jobs, as it looked to trim costs. The company, which is based in Shoreview, Minn., said it planned to close production facilities in Atlanta and Seattle and a distribution center in West Caldwell, N.J., by the middle of 1999. A spokesman, Stuart Alexander, said the company would try to relocate employees. Banking consolidation has led to increased price competition among check printers in the last year, and the company said it lost an undisclosed big bank as a client earlier this year. Deluxe had $1.92 billion in sales in 1997.

title: Hernandez May Switch To Bullpen to Fill Void

title: Sending Up (and Down) Mafia Movies
description: ''Mafia!'' makes an offer you could probably refuse. But its Mad-style, hit-or-miss humor has enough hits, pardon the expression, to keep it breezy and reasonably bright. This time Jim Abrahams, once part of the ''Airplane!'' team and since then the auteur behind the ''Hot Shots!'' parodies, directs his antic enthusiasm to the ''Godfather'' genre and comes up with anything from canned meatballs by Spalding to a turn-of-the-century Sicilian village with a ''Got vino?'' advertising campaign.

title: A Walk on Manhattan's Wild Side
description: As darkness falls, a burly man lugging a boom box heads into Inwood Hill Park followed by a group of others. Your heart could sink at the prospect of Manhattan's last stand of real forest, tucked away in the northwestern corner of the borough, being desecrated by loud music. But hold on. The fellow in front is Michael Feller, the parks department's senior naturalist. He is leading a nocturnal tour of the 190-acre park. What happens next is, to say the least, not typical of Manhattan night life.

title: Antic Dolts and Schemers? Must Be Screwball Comedy
description: The sharpest wit to have been overlooked by the American Film Institute's recent Top-100 list would have been 100 years old in August, and for the next two weeks the Film Forum will be celebrating his too-brief career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUTLER, JOHN F.
description: BUTLER-John F. Longtime enthusiast of thoroughbred racing and a director of the National Horse Show Association of America, died July 22 at age 90 in his Manhattan home after a three year illness following a stroke. Mr Butler, born in New York City on September 2, 1907, graduated Georgetown University, served as Commander U.S. Navy World War II, and in Naval Reserve, retired in 1963 with permanent rank of Commander. Survivors include his wife Marion Donovan, his nieces Mary and Amy Betancourt, step children Christine, Sharon, and Dr. James Donovan. Memorial service will be announced later.

title: Grievance Filed on Lockout
description: The players association filed an unfair labor practice charge with the National Labor Relations Board yesterday, challenging the National Basketball Association's owner-imposed lockout as unlawful. The union is requesting that the labor board seek an injunction ordering the owners to end the lockout immediately.

title: Hawaii at Home: Outrigger Races
description: To the bikers, bladers and joggers cruising along the path next to the West Side Highway, it had to look like a scene from the Elvis film ''Blue Hawaii,'' as directed by Fellini. More than 200 paddlers in bikinis or baggy print shorts, sandals and shades milled about a flotilla of 45-foot outrigger canoes on Pier 25, which juts into the Hudson River in the shadow of the World Trade Center. A fiberglass iguana, as big as an outrigger and mounted to a trailer where a Brazilian artist sculptures the wood pilings he finds floating in the Hudson, stares ominously over the West Side Highway.

title: Man in the News; Pushing the Boundaries of Reproductive Biology
description: He is nearly 70, an age when many have retired. He works on the windowless second floor of a converted warehouse in Honolulu, shut off from the island paradise. And he can hardly tear himself away.

title: BASEBALL: Managing His Future; Torre, Thrilled by Great '98, Has Threads of Doubt About '99
description: There are moments, private and public, when Joe Torre ponders the future and wonders if he wants to manage the Yankees next season. The thoughts flash by swiftly because Torre is too busy orchestrating what has been an amazing season and is still trying to insure that it finishes with a flourish in October.

title: Family Fare; Coming of Age In America
description: When Josephine Baldizzi Esposito died last spring, she left no journal of her life. But that didn't prevent her admirers at City Lights Youth Theater from creating one. The result is ''Caro Diario: The Story of Josephine Baldizzi,'' a play whose title means ''Dear Diary'' in Italian. Set on the Lower East Side in the 1930's, it details Mrs. Esposito's girlhood as the daughter of poor immigrants.

title: Pailin Journal; Come and Meet the Nonexistent Khmer Rouge
description: The world doesn't understand Pol Pot, Col. Seng Narin said as he leaned back on his front stoop, slipping his feet comfortably in and out of his sandals.

description: Tom Hanks's 12-part HBO mini-series, ''From the Earth to the Moon,'' earned the most Emmy Award nominations of any program, with 17, and NBC earned the most of any network, with 86, when nominations for the 1997-98 television season were announced here today.

title: Britain Reveals Elaborate Plots to Kill Hitler as War Neared End
description: British agents planned a series of bizarre plots to assassinate Adolf Hitler during the last months of World War II, according to wartime papers made public today by the Public Records Office.

title: Global Warming Is Our Friend
description: Once again, while the worst heat wave in years kills people right and left (more than 130 at last count) and the residents of much of the country shrivel like sausages, conservative economists have come forward to explain that what we thought was bad for us is in fact very good for us indeed.

title: Old West Tale: Gold, Gore And a Singing Cannibal
description: Try to arrive a few minutes late for ''Cannibal: The Musical.'' That way you'll miss the revolting sight of bloody, amputated body parts, the trademarks of Troma, the filmmakers who gave the world ''The Toxic Avenger'' and ''Surf Nazis Must Die!'' After the gory first scene, the movie is not completely appalling.

title: TEL-SAVE IN TALKS TO BE BOUGHT BY AN INTERNET COMPANY
description: Tel-Save Holdings Inc., which is based in New Hope, Pa., said yesterday that it was in talks to be acquired by an Internet company. Daniel M. Borislow, the chairman and chief executive of Tel-Save, would not name the suitor or say how soon he expected an agreement. The company's president, Gary McCullough, said the unnamed Internet company was attracted to Tel-Save, which sells long-distance phone services to subscribers to America Online Inc., because of Tel-Save's experience on the Internet. Tel-Save's stock fell $1.125, to $15.9375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: No Mistaking Times Square For Tokyo
description: WHILE Times Square stumbled through one more chaotic day, thoughts turned yesterday to another moment of urban breakdown. That was 14 years ago in Tokyo, where a fire in an underground tunnel destroyed a telephone exchange, wiping out service for more than 800,000 residents in a part of the city called Setagaya.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDER, RUTH

title: Lessons in Poetry, Science and History From the Age of Goethe
description: There is at the Frick Collection a loan show of drawings that is just the thing for high summer. Entitled ''Fuseli to Menzel,'' it is small (80 items in all) and mostly downstairs. Everything in it speaks for Germany in what is called ''the age of Goethe.'' The age in question can be elasticized, but basically it spans the first half of the 19th century.

title: Metro Business; Cablevision Acquires 'Scarlet Pimpernel'

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FROST, WINSTON HENRY
description: FROST-Winston Henry. Of Middleburg, VA, 85, died in West Palm Beach July 22 after a long illness. Mr. Frost, an attorney, was associated with Appleton, Rice, & Perrin in NYC. An avid sportsman, he excelled in polo and court tennis. Graduated from Harvard University ('35) and University of Virginia Law School, he was a Lieutenant Commander in the Navy during W.W. II. He is survived by his wife, Margaret Lawrance Frost of Southampton and Dora Frost of Bridgehampton. Services are to be announced later.

title: Clinton Bodyguard and an Adviser Testify
description: President Clinton's chief bodyguard, Larry L. Cockell, and Harold M. Ickes, a former senior White House aide, testified today before the Federal grand jury that is investigating the Monica S. Lewinsky matter.

title: Psychodrama That's Rooted In Complex Dreams and Rage
description: Tricky is an artist of the backward flow, dedicated to the path that veers in unforeseen directions. The composer-performer, who appeared at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Tuesday night, grounds his music in a reversal; he turns the intensity of hip-hop, pop's most potent forum for boasts and tall tales, into a means for deep introversion.

title: Playful Deconstructor of Urban Space
description: Although his visionary feats of architectural deconstruction exist only in murky photographs and films, Gordon Matta-Clark, who died 20 years ago at age 35, continues to be a figure of reverence for followers of avant-gardism. Last year's Documenta X in Kassel, Germany, included him among the forefathers of contemporary Conceptualism. Now an extensive exhibition of his works on paper, organized by the Generali Foundation of Vienna and on view at P.S. 1 in Long Island City, shows that Matta-Clark did a lot of drawing, much of it fairly engaging. But hardly anything he did on paper conveys how boldly innovative an artist he was.

title: Panoramic and Personal Visions of War's Anguish

title: FESTIVAL REVIEW/Theater; Goethe's Password? A Classic Tale Retold
description: Remember how smitten you were, how bowled over and enchanted, by your first foreign film? The experience was in every sense an eye-opener: the exotic words from the lips of heavy-lidded actors, the voluptuous camera work, the smoky, seemingly unrestrained carnality. Well, sitting through ''F@ust, Version 3.0,'' the live, multimedia piece by the Barcelona theater company La Fura dels Baus, is the opposite of that. A compression of the epic verse play that took Goethe a lifetime to compose, ''F@ust, Version 3.0'' is a disenchantment that manages to close the mind in an economical 100 minutes. It's as muddled and gratuitously profane as a particularly juvenile effort by a group of first-year film students.

title: Not the People's Choice in Japan
description: At a time when Japanese voters and world markets demand bold action against recession, Japan's largest party yesterday chose a man with an unbroken 35-year record of political timidity as the country's almost certain next prime minister. Keizo Obuchi was the public's least favorite contender and had to overcome a rare open revolt by discontented younger party members. Yet as the leader of the Liberal Democratic Party's largest faction, he won handily. The hope is that he can rise to the challenges now facing Japan and push through the large tax cuts, emergency spending increases and consolidations of failing banks he endorsed during his brief campaign. But already he seems to be edging away from those commitments.

PEI, based in Huntsville, Ala., a former division of the Chrysler Corporation, employs 370 and has projected annual sales of more than $50 million. Chrysler sold PEI, which develops inspection and test equipment for United States and foreign defense agencies, about five years ago. This is the latest defense acquisition for Veritas, which has spent $2.5 billion over seven years to acquire companies that work with the military.
