title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIMAN, ARTHUR A.
description: GIMAN-Arthur A. A prominent Long Island businessman and the founder and CEO of Jomart Inc., died at his home in Jericho, NY on July 23, 1998. The cause of death was complications due to cancer. Mr. Giman founded Jomart Inc. in Manhattan in 1963, and built it into a leading regional printing and packaging company. Jomart moved from Hudson Street to its current location in Islandia New York in 1996. Mr. Giman was born in Brussels Belgium on January 15, 1932. A refugee from the Holocaust, he was one of only 2,000 Jews to safely leave Vichy France during World War II. He arrived in New York on June 30, 1942 on the SS Guniea, the last ship to leave Europe carrying refugees. He quickly acclimated himself to America and developed a lifelong love of baseball. Mr. Giman was a devoted & loving husband, father, grandfather, brother and a loyal friend to all. He is survived by Evelyn, his wife of 47 years; daughters Randi Woltmann and Debbie Batterson; Grandchildren Michael and Alyssa Woltmann and Robert Batterson; Sons-in-law Walter Woltmann and Peter Batterson; and by his brother Sam; and many loyal friends. Mr. Giman was a member of the Jewish War Veterans Association, The Knights of Pythias, and a charter member of the National Holocaust Museum. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Services will be held at ''Guttermans Funeral Chapel'' on Sunday at Twelve O'clock Noon. 8000 Jericho Tpke. Woodbury, New York. Donations may be made to City of Hope; Hospice of Nassau; and American Diabetes Association.

The shutdown of two television-screen lines and one computer-monitor- screen line was made in an effort to bring inventory levels in line with demand, the company said yesterday. The lines are expected to be idled for most of the third quarter, but the actual length of the shutdown will depend on customer order levels, the company said. BMC, based in Minneapolis, has been hurt by soft market conditions and pricing pressures that have reduced demand for television and computer-monitor mask products.

K-C Aviation, based in Neenah, Wis., with additional operations in Texas and Massachusetts, completes the interiors of newly manufactured planes and provides maintenance. It had sales in 1997 of about $200 million. Kimberly-Clark, based in Dallas, is a consumer products company whose brands include Kleenex tissues and Huggies diapers. title: Making Times Square Safe
description: Four days is a long time to close down the heart of New York City. Since a high-rise construction accident on Tuesday morning at the Conde Nast building, Manhattan has been rerouted around its center. Most New Yorkers merely suffered a loss of time, the irritations of jammed traffic or clogged crosswalks. For those under the site, however, the deprivations are more tangible. Steve Chang, for example, made the fateful choice two weeks ago of opening a new restaurant in the shadow of the Conde Nast tower. Another victim, who left his apartment for a jog Tuesday morning, has spent the rest of the week borrowing clothes, money and living space. Then there are the pets, left behind in the sealed buildings and surely suffering the limits of survival time without food and water.

title: As the Streets Clog Up, Cars Hit the Sidewalks
description: Enmeshed last May in a two-and-a-half-hour traffic jam on his way to a Moscow airport, the driver of a city bus decided to save his passengers some time by taking a short cut through the park.

title: House Passes a Patients Bill; Veto Is Likely
description: Turning to a popular election-year issue, the House today passed a contentious Republican bill that would expand the rights of millions of patients who are dissatisfied with their medical care.

title: The Congo Massacres: The U.N. Steps Aside
description: An investigation into massacres in Congo, an issue that rights groups consider critical to the credibility of United Nations human rights operations, has been virtually shelved.

title: Man Carrying Fake Dynamite Spreads Panic in Newark
description: A man dressed partly in military fatigues carried what appeared to be seven sticks of dynamite attached to a timer into a downtown office building this morning, causing widespread panic and confusion. Although the device turned out to be fake, it was so realistic that it fooled police dogs trained to detect explosives.

title: Old Secret to Success: Staying Out of Trouble
description: For someone who has been plying the treacherous waters of Japanese politics since 1963, Keizo Obuchi has made scarcely a ripple. He is not identified with any major Government policies, has no memorable personality traits and has not been tarred by any scandal.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about an apostolic letter by Pope John Paul II tightening Rome's control over bishops' conferences misstated the kind of document that must be sent to Rome for approval even if it is passed by an overwhelming majority. The ruling applies to documents on doctrinal matters, not nondoctrinal matters.

title: Prospect of $195 Million Prize Draws Crowds to Connecticut
description: The usual Friday beach backup on Interstate 95 turned into a Powerball jam today as New Yorkers sat in traffic for hours so they could buy a dream of $195 million, a dollar at a time.

title: Rescued by a Megabyte, Pulsipher Remains a Met
description: Omar Minaya, the Mets' assistant general manager, called it an oversight. A front-office blunder was more like it. And General Manager Steve Phillips took full responsibility.

title: Grateful to Be Heard, 'Silicone Survivors' Take Fight Over Implants to Capital
description: They came in wheelchairs and leaning on canes, with violet-colored ribbons pinned to their lapels. Tearfully, they disclosed their symptoms: chronic fatigue, mysterious fevers, bizarre rashes, painful joints.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CECIL, EILEEN MARGARET DAVIS
description: CECIL-Eileen Margaret Davis. On July 22, 1998, at Heron Point Retirement Community, Chestertown, MD, formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Beloved wife of Dr. Jack Turner Cecil. Also survived by many cousins. A funeral liturgy will be held Wednesday, July 29th, at 10 AM, at Sacred Heart R. C. Church in Chestertown, MD.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Old Baptist Church, Women And All, Is Set to Leave Fold
description: Mabel Claire Maddrey, who was 13 when the 19th Amendment gave women the right to vote, stared at her television set in bewilderment in June as female delegates to the Southern Baptist Convention raised their hands in support of a declaration that asked them to submit graciously to their husbands' leadership.

title: 55-Month Jail Term in Citibank Fraud
description: A former vice president in Citibank's private-banking section was sentenced yesterday to 55 months in prison for defrauding the bank of $47 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHWATSKY, ROSE
description: CHWATSKY-Rose. Beloved wife of the late Hyman. Mother of Howard and Ann, Morton and Harriet. Grandmother of Marc Schulz and Joan Kaplan, Julie and Steven Hatfield, Amy and Rob Feinblatt, Lynn and Jory Siegel. Great-grandmother of Jacob Schulz and Carly Feinblatt. Services Sunday July 26th. At Gutterman's Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, 1:30 P.M.

title: Pataki and Giuliani, Party Rivals for 2000, Start Spreading the News
description: In back-to-back presentations brimming with unspoken rivalry and national ambition, Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani went before an audience of national Republican leaders yesterday and sought to claim credit for the recent rise in New York's fortunes, which each man would like to ride to higher office.

title: Japan Lets Itself Down -- Again
description: On the day of Japan's Upper House election earlier this month, a housewife said on the radio, ''I went to vote -- for anyone who didn't belong to the Liberal Democratic Party.''

title: Drugs Seen as a European Problem
description: American cyclists here for the Goodwill Games did not seem surprised at yesterday's drug-related developments in the Tour de France. The consensus was that while some bike riders who compete in this country might use illegal performance-enhancing drugs, the sport's drug problems involved Europe rather than the United States, road racing rather than velodrome and men rather than women.

title: Lawyers in Brawley Case Discuss Charge to Jury
description: Lawyers in the final stage of the Tawana Brawley defamation case spent about two hours yesterday working out details in the judge's charge to jurors, who are expected to decide next week what, if any, damages Steven A. Pagones should receive.

title: Beams Studied In Collapse At Times Sq.
description: Investigators looking into the causes of the buckling of a giant construction scaffold in Times Square on Tuesday are focusing on whether critical support beams at the 21st floor were disconnected by workers just days before the accident.

title: Wall Street Stumbles
description: It has not paid to have a sense of history on Wall Street for the past couple of years. Those who believed that traditional indicators of value mattered have sold stocks, only to see the stock market roar ahead. But this week Wall Street stumbled. Even with a mild recovery yesterday afternoon, the Dow Jones industrial average ended the week down more than 4 percent from the record level of just a week earlier.

title: Bridge; Best-Laid Expert Traps Fail When Foes Ignore the Bait
description: At the start of the American Contract Bridge League's Summer National Championships, a squad from the New York area has reached the semifinal of the Grand National Team Championship, which began eight months ago.

title: Have Book, Won't Travel
description: You try to give the interviewer a suitably provocative response. ''To be sure, publishers by definition live off their betters. . . .''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNPHY, DON
description: DUNPHY-Don ''The Voice of Boxing'' of Manhasset, NY, July 22, 1998. Beloved husband of Muriel. Proud father of sons, Don Jr. and Bob. Loving father-in-law of Sheila & Sharon. Devoted grandfather to Deirdre, Tara, Don III, Bobby and Christine. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel 1570 Northern Blvd. Manhasset, NY, Saturday & Sunday 3-5 & 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Monday 9:45 A.M., St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I have an 18-year-old daughter, and how could I look at her and tell her that her opinion does not mean as much as some man's?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKER, HENRY L.
description: ZUCKER-Henry L. The Officers, Trustees & staff of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee express their deep sorrow at the loss of Henry L. Zucker, a long time Honorary member of the JDC Board & a leader in American Jewry. Henry served JDC overseas after World War II and conducted the first International Survey of Operations for JDC. In addition to his JDC activities, he was the Executive Director of the Jewish Community Federation of Cleveland for 27 years, and will be remembered as one of the most influential and effective Jewish leaders of his generation. A man who brilliantly and creatively pursued the objective of a more humane, more effective, a more supportive society, his loss will be deeply felt. Our condolences to his family and to his wife Ellen. Jonathan W. Kolker, President Michael Schneider, Executive Vice President Ambassador Milton A. Wolf, Chairman of the Board

title: States Threaten Airlines With Antitrust Steps
description: Attorneys General from 25 states voiced their support yesterday for a Clinton Administration proposal to promote more competition in the airline industry. If the initiative fails, however, the states may file an antitrust suit against the major carriers, the leader of the group said.

title: Muzz Patrick, 83, a Ranger On 1940 Stanley Cup Team
description: Murray Patrick, who was raised in a legendary family of professional hockey players and builders in the middle decades of the century and became a player, coach and general manager of the Rangers, died Thursday at his home in Riverside, Conn. He was 83.

title: Gunman Invades Capitol, Killing 2 Guards
description: A gunman who had been investigated by the Secret Service burst into the Capitol this afternoon, officials said, and killed two police officers in a corridor shootout that left a tourist and the gunman lying wounded as terrified bystanders darted for cover.

title: A Limping Strawberry Eases Into His Home Run Trot, Twice
description: Joe Torre does not often ask Darryl Strawberry how his left knee feels anymore, and Strawberry probably would never volunteer to his manager all the sensations in the joint, whether it is pain or weakness or both. Don't ask, don't tell. Ignore the heavy limp and the possibility his knee may never get better, watch the ball fly off his bat.

title: N.B.A. and Union to Resume Talks
description: Amid the backdrop of two legal actions taken by the players association, the league and the union will resume bargaining on Aug. 6 in an effort to move closer to resolving the disputes that have left the National Basketball Association in a lockout for more than three weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HARRIS, HELEN
description: HARRIS-Helen. July 25, 1996. Always in our hearts. Larry, Jill, Seth and Erik

title: International Briefs; Italian Phone Gear Giant To Cut Staff by a Third
description: Telecom Italia S.p.A. and Siemens A.G. plan to cut the staff of Italtel, Italy's biggest maker of telephone equipment, by almost one-third and sell its system-installation business to offset declining revenue, according to union officials briefed by management. Up to 1,300 employees will be dismissed, and 3,300 will be transferred to outside suppliers, according to a cost-cutting plan presented to unions on Thursday by Italtel's chief executive, Giovanni Barbieri.

title: Religion Led to Rift Among Mothers of Feminism
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, SYLVIA GREENBLATT
description: NEWMAN-Sylvia Greenblatt. On July 22nd, 1998 in her 90th year. Beloved daughter, sister, aunt and great-aunt.

title: Uncovered Short Positions Are 3.7% Higher on Nasdaq
description: In a short sale, an investor borrows shares from a brokerage firm and sells them, hoping to buy them back at lower prices and make a profit. If the shares rise in price, the short-seller faces a loss. Uncovered short sales, or those with open positions, are those shares that have been borrowed and sold but not yet covered by repurchase.

title: Jurevicius Is a No-Show And Fassel Is Troubled
description: Acquiring a tall, physical wide receiver to boost an anemic offense was a priority of the Giants during the off season. It is the reason they used their second-round draft pick to take 6-foot-5-inch, 230-pound Joe Jurevicius, a wide receiver from Penn State.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPPENHEIMER, DONALD R.
description: OPPENHEIMER-Donald R. Sr. On July 22, 1998. Husband of Miriam (nee London) Oppenheimer of Weston Florida, formerly of 70 Minna Street, Brooklyn, New York. Private memorial services. Trustee and longtime member of Union Temple, Brooklyn, NY. Also survived by two sons, D. Robert Jr. of Reading, PA and John D. of Aptos, CA. Donations may be made to Union Temple, Brooklyn.

title: Topics of The Times; A Spinner's Unmerited Praise
description: Here is a proposition. Departing White House press secretaries get praised according to how well they organized reporters' travel needs rather than how well they served the information needs of the people who paid their salaries. Mike McCurry, who is resigning in a leisurely way, kept the White House press corps happy. He protected President Clinton's political interests. He has managed the not inconsiderable trick of leaving this White House without having been subpoenaed.

title: A Bowery Life With a 2d Act And a Twist
description: NEVER mind that Jack Ryan was dead. Everyone agreed he looked sharp. ''This is the best dressed Jack's been in a long time,'' said Keith Haskins, who helps run a center for the elderly on Delancey Street where John D. Ryan used to pass his days. ''He wouldn't spend a penny on himself.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

description: To the Editor:

title: WILLIAMS SCOTSMAN AND SPACE MASTER TO MERGE
description: Williams Scotsman Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Space Master International Inc., a privately held lessor of mobile-office units, for about $270 million. Williams Scotsman, based in Baltimore, is a mobile-office leasing concern with annual revenue of $235 million last year and a fleet of 48,000 units. It is a unit of Scotsman Holdings Inc. Williams Scotsman said it would pay for the acquisition with bank debt and equity investments from Cypress Merchant Banking Partners L.P., and Keystone Inc., which together own a majority of Williams Scotsman, and Odyssey Investment Partners Fund L.P., which holds a minority stake.

title: Bomb Scare Paralyzes a Metro-North Line
description: A worn suitcase filled with cans of dog food and abandoned at the New Rochelle train station caused a bomb scare that brought the Metro-North Railroad's New Haven line to a halt during the afternoon rush yesterday, railroad officials said. About 20,000 riders were delayed for up to two hours.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELSON, HENRY
description: ADELSON-Henry. On July 23, 1998. Beloved husband of Loretta. Devoted and loving father of Beth & Stewart. Officer in the Army Air Corp in World War II, past faculty member in the NYU & Columbia Schools of Dentistry, Past President of the 2nd District Dental Society. Funeral services to be held Sunday, July 26, at 12:15PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76 Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUSMAN, JUDY
description: HAUSMAN-Judy. The Board of Directors, the residents and staff of 465 West End Avenue mourn the passing of our dear friend Judy Hausman-concerned neighbor, loyal board member, and gracious hostess. We extend heartfelt condolences to her family. We shall all miss her. John Miller, President

title: Sweeps Come at Right Time For the Re-energized Mets
description: In the first game, a 32-year-old right-hander who had not pitched in the major leagues in over a year tossed eight shutout innings. In the second one, the Mets rallied for seven runs in the final four innings to erase a pair of one-run deficits.

title: Marking a Puerto Rican Anniversary
description: In his 35 years with the Puerto Rico Telephone Company, Guillermo de la Paz has gone on strike more than 10 times, but the latest strike has been different. Strangers bring him coffee and honk their horns when they pass the picket line, he says. Buckets fill up with cash donations.

title: Franco Loses Battle With Hill and Then the Game
description: Even though the Mets had swept a doubleheader here on Friday, John Franco said this morning that today's game was the most important of this four-game weekend series.

title: An Opponent Of Kohl Puts Taboo Topic Into Election
description: Just nine weeks before national elections, a political insurgent moving back to Germany from New York has injected a question into the campaign that some thought taboo: should Germany abandon its project to build a huge memorial to the Holocaust on the ruins of Hitler's Third Reich?

title: TELEVISION; Selling Anything, Enthusiastically, at 3 A.M.
description: LIKE most addictions, this one began innocently. Late on a sleepless night more than a decade ago, I turned on the television, hoping for an old movie or maybe one of those ''Victory at Sea'' documentaries. Instead, I got what appeared to be a cooking demonstration.

title: Commercial Property/Kingston, N.Y.; Making an Old I.B.M. Complex a High-Tech Center
description: THE HUDSON VALLEY as the next Silicon Valley? The area is better known as a recreational and scenic backyard for New York than as a hotbed of technology and entrepreneurship. But the area is also the home of I.B.M., which knows something about silicon, information technology and developing businesses.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: WHY GEESE DON'T GET OBESE

title: Release the Hound
description: Dog Days

title: In Melville's Traces
description: STORY LINE

title: Priorities in the National Parks
description: MORE than 270 million visitors pass through the gates of the national parks each year -- as if every man, woman and child in the country visited at least one park a year. The number has grown more than 10 percent in the past decade, and the boom has brought chronic headaches to the National Park Service.

title: A Dog's Best Friend
description: Linda Lasky has given cardiopulmonary resuscitation to a chihuahua. (''You can go as small as a gerbil,'' she says.) A critical-care veterinary technician by day, Lasky moonlights as a canine CPR instructor for Fast Response, an American Heart Association Training Center in Berkeley, Calif. Fast Response is the driving force behind ''Pet First Aid and CPR,'' a five-hour course.

title: Book Clubs Spring Up, Encouraging Sales
description: ''ABSOLUTELY tremendous,'' Patrick Corcoran, owner of the Arcade bookstore in Rye, said when asked about the impact book clubs have had on his business. ''They're helping booksellers, publishers and authors alike. Anything that encourages people to read is terrific.''

title: Theater; Songs That Make You Say 'I Sound So Good'
description: WHY do some songs make people want to sing them -- and not only in the shower? For answers, The New York Times asked five women, all stars of Jerry Herman's shows. Why women? Read on.

title: Beach Reads and Pool Books: Long Island in Hardcover; Playing Soda Jerk For Little Leaguers
description: ''Wait Till Next Year'' by the Pulitzer Prize-winning author Doris Kearns Goodwin is a memoir of a childhood that revolved around an utter devotion to the Brooklyn Dodgers. But even Yankee fans will appreciate her descriptions of the way of life, now vanished, that she found in her Rockville Centre neighborhood in the early postwar years.

title: Backtalk; Lifesaving Drug Can Be Deadly When Misused
description: For patients suffering from anemia caused by kidney disease, use of the synthetic hormone erythropoietin, or EPO, can be a lifesaver because it stimulates the production of red blood cells. For endurance athletes, the increased oxygen-carrying capacity provided by EPO has made it an alluring, performance-enhancing drug, albeit one that is banned and that can leave athletes at risk of strokes, heart attacks and even death.

title: Habitats/Vestry Street; Southerner Heads North
description: WHERE Mary McCulley Wheaton comes from, the mountainous border of Georgia and North Carolina, home buyers get a lot for their money.

title: The Rural Life; Keeping the New World New
description: In late April, a neighbor harrowed and seeded my pasture with a mixture of orchard grass, bird's-foot trefoil, clover and rye. For weeks, I looked out on a field that was uniformly brown, all its undulations exposed to view. In the silence that fell when planting was finished, I imagined a flock of starlings -- a soot-storm of birds -- landing on that newly planted soil and devouring every seed. That did not happen. But as days passed and the bare earth remained bare, I began to imagine that I had neglected some vital organic precondition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, ANNA
description: GOLD-Anna. Devoted wife of the late Leon. Beloved sister of the late Harry Feldman. Adored aunt, great aunt and great-great aunt. Services held on Sunday, July 26.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/

title: Overheard Between Floors
description: What is it about an elevator? Everyone knows that it's impossible not to overhear or be overheard in what is really just a walk-in closet with wanderlust. But on any given workday you might hear all or part of some extraordinary conversations on the office elevator: bizarre tales, stunning revelations, head-scratching non sequiturs. Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: You, Too, Can Own A Bad Bank Loan
description: Wall Street saw a darker strain of trickle-down economics last week as several companies with little to no direct exposure to the Asian malaise warned that their businesses were beginning to suffer.

title: July 19-25; Pepsico Buys Tropicana
description: Expanding the cola wars to the breakfast table, Pepsico announced that it was buying the Tropicana juice business from the Seagram Company. Pepsi will be in direct competition with its archrival, the Coca-Cola Company, when it comes to orange juice as well as colas, since Coke owns Minute Maid, another large purveyor of breakfast drinks.

title: In Need of Editing
description: To the Editor:

title: Searchers Say They Have Found Elusive Hull of Pirate Ship
description: For nearly two decades, Barry Clifford has looked for the remains of the Whydah, a fabled pirate ship sailed by Black Sam Bellamy. Caught in a fierce storm off Cape Cod, Mass., in 1717, it sank, supposedly laden with up to five tons of gold and silver.

title: FAST TALK
description: Officer Dominick Andrews writes 400 speeding tickets a month on the Interstates around Macon, Ga., so he hears excuses. In fact, he has heard enough to fill a book, just out, called ''What's Your Excuse?'' A city patrolman, former marine and longtime bodybuilder, Andrews remains ''emotionless'' during traffic stops and is known locally as ''the traffic Nazi,'' but he'll sometimes skip the ticket if an excuse makes him laugh. Among his favorites: ''I accidentally stuck my eye with my eyeliner brush,'' (57 miles per hour in a 35-m.p.h. zone); ''I was trying to get home for the 'Andy Griffith' marathon'' (68 in a 45), and (82 in a 55): ''My wife found out I was at a strip club -- if I'm not home in 10 minutes, she's going to shoot my truck.''

title: Hearty Italian, Comfortable Prices
description: ITALIAN family-style eating can mean enormous quantities of mediocre food, shoveled out of a production-line kitchen and slapped down in bare bones, less-than-charming surroundings, or it can be like Mary Jane's Restaurant in East Hampton. There (128 North Main Street, 324-8008), in a library-like setting of book-filled shelves, fireplaces, plush carpeting, blond paneling, traditional Italian art, antique hutches, a white grandfather clock and the warm glow of wall lanterns, quality and quantity walk hand in hand.

title: The High School At the End Of the Road
description: Alex Kotlowitz's '' High School at the End of the Road''(July 5) describes an experiment in social adjustment to which education has been added with dubious results. As such, it should be recommended to penologists as an alter-native to prison rather than a model for educators.

title: Best Books Lists Creates Readerships; Banned Volumes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBURG, ARTHUR JAY
description: GINSBURG-Arthur Jay. Beloved husband of Ellin and cherished father of Ann, brother of Marvin and Viviene. Founding law partner of Frankfurt, Garbus, Klein & Selz. Dear uncle, loving friend. A man of love, kindness, brilliance, honor and integrity. You will be in our hearts forever. Funeral held at Park Avenue Synagogue, New York, July 21, burial in Chicago. Rest in peace and know our eternal love. May you be in our hearts and watch over us forever more.

title: Lisa Summers and Daniel Haas
description: Lisa Rose Summers and Daniel Haas were married by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani on Friday in the Governor's Room at City Hall in New York.

title: Theater; Help Wanted: Adventurous U.S. Theatergoers
description: AS you watch the gorgeous new production of ''Twelfth Night'' at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, you may find your emotions tested in ways never intended by Shakespeare, Nicholas Hytner (the man who directed it) or Lincoln Center Theater (which staged the play as its own contribution to the theatrical portion of Lincoln Center Festival '98). The Hytner production charms, maddens, surprises and disappoints. You have to keep adjusting to it as if it were the signal of a riveting but wandering FM broadcast.

title: Awful! Terrible! Excruciatingly Bad!
description: RED LOBSTER, WHITE TRASH, AND THE BLUE LAGOON Joe Queenan's America. By Joe Queenan. 194 pp. New York: Hyperion. $21.95.

title: A Garden to Delight the Mind and Eye
description: PEOPLE once went to Garden in the Woods seeking nothing more than a stroll through the forest. In springtime in the mid-1980's, the parking lot was filled by families who descended into clouds of azaleas bedded with carpets of phlox, walking with Virginia bluebells and poppy celandine lapping at their ankles.

title: No Surprise
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  D'AVIGNON, MARY FLORENCE
description: D'AVIGNON-Mary Florence. Died peacefully at home June 28, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Edmond, mother of Mary Auletta, grandmother of Kelli and Kimberlee and mother-in-law of Richard. A memorial service will be held at All Saints Church, 230 East 60 Street, Monday, July 27 at 6:30PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Glaucoma Foundation, 33 Maiden Lane, New York, New York 10038.

title: Correspondence/Burying Abiola; One False Step Betrays The Desperation of Nigeria
description: THE day, sultry beneath low clouds, had long been pregnant with violence. Gathered within the high walls of the mansion, the crowd heaved this way and that, screaming abuse at the soldiers outside, waiting for the body. In their eyes lay anger and anguish and a frenzied desperation.

title: Ideas & Trends: Southern Curse; Why America's Murder Rate Is So High
description: MURDER in the United States has been dropping dramatically for years, to the lowest level since the modern crime wave began in the 1960's. But this encouraging decline has masked a fundamental fact -- that there is no such thing as an American murder rate.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Strawberry Tries to Hobble Into One More Post-Season
description: Darryl Strawberry has a noticeable hobble whenever he chugs around the bases or even moves through the clubhouse, a serious limp that makes his future with the Yankees seem very suspect no matter how many homers his body still produces. Strawberry's weak left knee may be from arthritis, a complication that Joe Torre does not wish to contend with during a tense October. The manager cannot afford to.

title: Separate Fates for Two Hispanic Cultural Centers
description: Last week brought news as grim as a death sentence to one imperiled Hispanic cultural center and a reprieve to another. The Charas/El Bohio Cultural and Community Center and the Clemente Soto Velez Cultural Center both occupy buildings that the city planned to sell at an auction last Monday. But on auction day, only the Charas building, at Avenue B and East Ninth Street, was sold, to a buyer who was not immediately identified, for $3.15 million. The Clemente Soto Velez Cultural Center, on Suffolk and Rivington Streets, was taken off the block.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 28 of The Times Magazine today, about the underground storage of nuclear waste, contains an outdated reference to the deadline for a Federal judge's ruling on the Energy Department's plans to bury plutonium waste at a New Mexico site. After the article went to press, the ruling was postponed indefinitely, from its original deadline of Aug. 14.

title: Palette to Palate
description: The art dealers who pulled up stakes in SoHo for new galleries in deserted west Chelsea don't miss the throngs of tourists, but they are nostalgic for one thing: good food. Rather than wait for an enterprising restaurateur to discover their up-and-coming art district, a group of dealers took matters into their own hands. They invested $10,000 each in Bottino, a low-key but stylish trattoria in a former hardware store at 246 10th Avenue (24th Street).

title: Police Say Woman, 21, Is Killed by Ex-Husband
description: A woman was shot and killed by her ex-husband on the steps of a J-train mezzanine in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: The Heart of the Heart of a Shore Community
description: THE seat of Ocean Grove's musical kingdom is a sacred space made of wood. Do not, however, conjure an isolated log cabin with bearded sage. Think of a huge auditorium seating 6,000, with an organ console and spans of organ pipes, visible and invisible.

title: Toxic
description: In your profile, Bruce Babbitt attempts yet again to portray himself in the Wrong Man Scenario, an innocent bystander caught in the crossfire of Washington's political turf battles.

title: Education Ends Welfare
description: To the Editor:

title: Wrapped To Go
description: The sarong, a couple of yards of fabric wrapped around the waist, is a genuine summer trend on the streets, at outdoor concerts and at evening parties, where the idea is to dress comfortably and look cool. Last week at a party at the Museum of the City of New York, the sarong, historically worn by both sexes, was in full flower, predominately on women, though one couple, left, wore kekoi sarongs they had bought in Mombasa, Kenya. The trend gained momentum last month from men at the Gay and Lesbian Pride March. The women's version is all about colorful prints in lengths from mini to ankle.

title: Charbroiled at the Beach
description: Bill and Luella Perhacs are at it again, providing charbroiled treats at Mr. Bill's, where the regular customers outnumber the newcomers even though the luncheonette is in the middle of the tourist town of Belmar.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEVINE, JAMES PHILLIPS
description: DEVINE-James Phillips, Jr. On July 24, 1998 of Port Washington. Beloved husband of Joan Graeber Devine. Dear father of James, Judith, John and Jeremy. Grandfather of Kathryn, Kenneth, Jennifer, Julie, Holly and Margaret. In respose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, Monday 3:00-5:00 PM and 7:00-9:00 PM. Funeral Service Tuesday 10:30 AM at St. Stephens Church, 9 Carlton Avenue, Port Washington. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to St. Stephens Church or the American Red Cross.

title: What Companies Need to Know Is in the Pizza Dough
description: AS empires crumble and technology pushes ever forward, some things remain unavoidable.

title: . . . And Lifeguards Return To Englewood's Pools
description: A protest by lifeguards that caused the temporary closing of two municipal swimming pools in Englewood last week (''Beach Patrols Confront a Declining Number of Lifeguards,'' July 19) has been resolved by increasing the number of lifeguards on duty and the hours they remain on duty.

title: Grappa, Cards and Istria
description: When Ivan Jakovcic, a member of the Croatian Parliament, was in New York recently, he did what diplomats from his part of the country often do. He left the glitz of Manhattan and made a pilgrimage to a gritty block in Astoria that is home to the United Miners (Rudar) Social Club.

title: As Cable Rates Rise, So Do Local Frustrations
description: EDWARD SIEGMANN, an advocate for the elderly who lives in Mattituck, went to the telephone after rates for basic cable television service more than doubled last winter.

title: In Camden, Always a Black-and-White Affair on This Island
description: A few years ago, the gardens surrounding the former estate of the financier Hamilton Q. Twombly, now on Fairleigh Dickinson University's Florham-Madison campus, were overgrown. It was difficult to see any remnant of the gardens that once drew admirers from around the globe -- such as the Emperor Meiji of Japan, who, in 1904, sent his gardener to the estate to learn the proper care of chrysanthemums. Then local residents decided to form Friends of Florham, a group of 25 led by Emma Joy Dana, dedicated to the restoration of the estate. The group's most recent accomplishment was the renovation and dedication of the Italian gardens this spring. Richard C. Simon, a novice historian and a member of Friends of Florham, and Mrs. Dana talked about the project. The garden and the 100-room Georgian revival mansion are opene for tours by appointment (973) 443-8921.

title: Lives; The Makeup Artist
description: My mother, who is beautiful and takes beauty seriously, was appalled at my sister's final make-over. The people at the funeral home had made her face pumpkiny orange, the lipstick too big on her downturned mouth. Breast heaving, my mother gazed into the coffin and announced to the mortuary cosmetologist, ''That's not my daughter in there.'' She held out her hand. ''Give me that sponge.'' The startled funeral director and staff watched as my mother redid my sister's face herself. So two weeks later I'm explaining to friends: ''My mother has gotten a job. . . .''

title: Buying Cheap in Asia, Betting on Recovery
description: THESE days, when a money manager tells an investment conference that he has almost half his portfolio in Asian stocks, his listeners are apt to snap to attention. Asian markets have been a minefield since the currency crisis began last summer. The market indexes for the region, excluding Japan, have fallen an average of 44.9 percent for the past year, and many investors are keeping their money elsewhere.

title: A Vote for the Hired Guns of Rock-and-Roll
description: EVER since the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame gave itself the ticklish job of anointing a rock-and-roll pantheon, one of its stated goals has been to salute not only rock's celebrities but the genre's lesser-known heroes too. But when the Hall of Fame announces its 14th annual class of inductees this fall -- the selection process began earlier this month -- it's a sure bet that Earl Palmer won't be among them.

title: Helping Disheartened Singles Take Heart
description: CONNECTING at 30 or 40 or 50 is not easy. And smart people make a lot of dumb relationship mistakes. Sandra Powers, a twice-divorced 55-year-old mother of four, knows it. She also realizes that people feel more comfortable in a homelike atmosphere.

title: Going Where A Lot of Other Dudes With Really Great Equipment Have Gone Before
description: Peary became aware of a wooden feeling in his feet. When Henson ripped off the sealskin boots he saw that the explorer's legs were bloodless white to the knee. As he tore off the undershoes, two or three toes from each foot clung to the hide and snapped off at the joint.

title: Concerts by Bronx Arts Ensemble
description: THE Bronx Arts Ensemble begins its annual series of free Summer Music concerts today with the pianist-conductor Pablo Zinger offering tangos from Argentina and dances from other Latin American countries. August begins with two more light-listening programs: next Sunday, Kenneth Cooper conducts a program of Silks and Rags, with the soprano Josephine Mongiardo, and on Aug. 9, it will be Big Band Jazz, with the trombonist Jack Gale at the helm. The classics return at the final two events, the soprano Cristina Arsuaga featured in Italian opera favorites on Aug. 16 and Irina Rees presiding at the harpsichord for a Baroque celebration on Aug. 23.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANUGUERRA, MATTEO
description: MANUGUERRA-Matteo. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of our beloved colleague, Matteo Manuguerra. An uncommonly eloquent interpreter of the great baritone roles in the Italian and French repertory, he sang 127 performances of 15 roles with the company following his debut as Enrico in ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' in 1971. An actor of great versatility, he will be remembered with admiration for his powerful Rigoletto & his malevolent Barnaba in ''La Gioconda'' as well as many vivid interpretations of the major Verdi roles. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Michelle and his three children. Joseph Volpe, General Manager James Levine, Artistic Director

title: July 19-25; Why They Invented Cliff's Notes
description: James Joyce's ''Ulysses,'' voted the best English-language novel of the century by a panel of experts last week, is hard to read. ''It is not the best novel,'' said John Kidd, director of the James Joyce Research Center at Boston University, who is preparing a new edition of the book. ''It is simply the most influential novel.''

title: Easing the Trials of Life as Usual, Through Jazz

But in June, at the JVC Jazz Festival in Manhattan, it was clear that his troubles have only enriched his music as he took the stage in a wheelchair and let them escape through the bell of his trombone.

description: MANY stock fund portfolios seem sorely lacking in dividends these days. With the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index paying an aggregate yield of just 1.24 percent, even funds that bill themselves as growth-and-income offerings seem far more weighted toward growth than income.

title: July 19-25; In Scientific Leap, Dozens of Mice Are Cloned
description: Scientists from the University of Hawaii announced that they had made dozens of mouse clones and had even cloned some of the clones. The announcement stunned biologists because it meant that cloning is advancing much more rapidly than had been expected. Just last year, the first clone of an adult animal, Dolly the sheep, was announced in Scotland.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Francois Latapie; He Also Serves Who Chats
description: FOR a July night, the tables were unusually jammed at La Goulue, the French bistro that is one of the kiss-kiss capitals of the Upper East Side. Francois Latapie, an owner and the host, couldn't figure it out. ''You know, no one has an answer -- why are they here?'' he asked, leaning against the mahogany bar last Wednesday around 9:30 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKER, HENRY L.
description: ZUCKER-Henry L. The American Friends of The Hebrew University of Jerusalem mourn with great sorrow the passing of Henry L. Zucker of Cleveland, Ohio, an Honorary Governor of The Hebrew University and member of AFHU's Council of Trustees. In 1989, he was the recipient of the Scopus Award, the highest honor given by the American Friends, when the Henry L. Zucker Fellowship Program for Graduate Study in Social Work was established at The Hebrew University. To his wife, Ellen, and the entire family we extend our deepest condolences. The Hebrew University of Jerusalem Professor Menachem Magidor, President The American Friends of The Hebrew University Keith L. Sachs, President Fred S. Lafer, Chairman of the Board Adam B. Kahan, Executive Vice President

title: Beach Reads and Pool Books: Long Island in Hardcover; The End of the Road At the End of the Island
description: ''A World Away'' is Stewart O'Nan's novel of Anne and James, a couple whose oldest son, Rennie, goes missing in action in the Pacific in World War II. Their struggle is compounded by having to deal with caring for James's aged father in his Hampton Bays home and their infidelity to each other. In this excerpt Anne travels to Montauk, intending to break off the affair with Martin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIGGES LA TOUCHE, WILLIAM O.
description: DIGGES LA TOUCHE-William O. on Monday, July 13 at the age of 55. A resident of Lambertville, New Jersey, he is survived by his brothers, Pendar and David, his sister, Phyllis Rawlins, his newphew, Kit, and his uncle, Oliver Pendar. A memorial service will be held at 2:00 PM, on Saturday, August 1st, at Solebury Friends Meeting House in Solebury, PA.

But to walk the streets of this capital on a gloomy morning after Mr. Obuchi's election is to conclude that Japan's kingmakers live in a parallel universe.

title: Taking a Vacation? Take Out Insurance
description: THERE is no safe place to take a vacation. Stick a pin in the map of the world, and you hit either empty ocean or a country with serious troubles of a political, social, medical or gastronomic nature, and most probably all four. Coups and revolutions, fundamentalists fighting battles left over from the Middle Ages, horrible diseases, incomprehensible languages and disgusting food are par for the course. Some nations don't even have ketchup.

title: Big Ship With a Message Visits Port Newark
description: Regina Maersk, a cargo ship about as long as the Chrysler Building is tall, visited New York Harbor last week. At 1,043 feet, the Danish ship is the biggest ever to visit the United States. It unloaded 492 containers of toys, Christmas decorations, furniture and clothing at Port Newark. It also delivered a message: such superships will soon be the norm, and the harbor must provide channels deep enough and docks modern enough to accommodate them, the shipping company said.

description: ANYONE driving in the city lately has probably muttered a silent blessing to the great god of air-conditioning.

title: Theater; Celebrating His Music And Precious Life Itself

The 66-year-old composer-lyricist for such huge successes as ''Hello, Dolly!,'' ''Mame'' and ''La Cage Aux Folles'' -- a Broadway figure who is both a symbol of a golden era and an undervalued songwriter -- was found to have H.I.V. 13 years ago and watched his health decline.

title: FROM THE DESK OF; Tact Can Seal A Global Deal . . . But a Little Spunk Works Best in New York
description: WE live in an exceedingly casual society. We believe that addressing strangers by their first names makes them feel like part of the family. In the global marketplace, however, this presumption of instant friendship may be a liability.

description: Melons are the borderline personality of fruit. Go to the bin where last summer you bought a pale green watermelon shaped like a football, and this summer it might be a dark green soccer ball with chartreuse pin stripes.

title: In America; Health Care Denied
description: Advocates for the disabled want to know why it is taking the Clinton Administration so long to right a wrongheaded and potentially very dangerous ruling by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: Rules on Occupancy In a Co-op
description: Q: The co-op in which I live is a Housing Development Fund Corporation (H.D.F.C.) building and we have severe resale restrictions. One shareholder sublet his apartment for the maximum allowable term of two years and now, rather than move back into the building, he seems interested in keeping the apartment empty in the hope that he will someday be able to sell it for full market value. Although there is nothing in our proprietary lease that requires continued use of the apartment as a primary residence, there is such a requirement in the H.D.F.C. regulations. Can he legally just leave it empty? . . . Eve Harmon, Manhattan.

title: History Lessons and the Law of Averages
description: Joe Torre all but covers his ears when others recite the Yankees' place in history, how they compare with the 1902 Pittsburgh Pirates or the '27 Yankees. The manager does not want to know anything about it, he says, because then he will start thinking about the law of averages, which the Yankees have blatantly defied.

title: What's So Wrong With This Picture?
description: I first saw ''Christina's World'' several years ago at MOMA (''What's So Wrong With This Picture?'' by Vance Muse, July 5). As I stood looking at the painting, two girls came up behind me, and one said, in hushed voice: ''Look at her. Something terrible must have happened in that house.'' It had never occurred to me that Christina might be moving from and not toward the building. Since that day, I have not been able to look at the painting in the same way.

title: For the Record: Enough Is Enough
description: THIS is a public-service announcement: Would everyone please stop generating history immediately? We have way more letters, notes, ceramic pots, battlefields, recordings, old buildings and large pieces of obsolete military hardware than we can keep up with.

title: Trying to Save an Old Way of Life From Progress
description: OLD Order Amish families hold church services in their homes. They rarely invite outsiders to attend. But you can't drive more than a mile through Lancaster County's rolling farmland without thinking you've already entered one of the world's great sacred spaces, a landscape consecrated over the centuries to a peaceful way of life. If this view is no more than a day-tripper's idle projection, it is not alien to a place that was settled in the 17th century in William Penn's spirit of religious tolerance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONEHILL, NORMA LIEBLING
description: STONEHILL - Norma Liebling. Died on July 24, 1998 at age 89 in New York City. Beloved wife of the late Harold Stonehill for 59 years. Sister of the late A.J. Liebling and daughter of Joseph and Anna Liebling. Devoted mother of Arthur, John, and Robert Stonehill. Friend and mother-in-law of Kari, Judith, and Carlyn Stonehill. Loving grandmother of Robert, Jr., Jeffrey, Alexandra, and David Stonehill and Inger Crumpton. Great grandmother of Kristen and Colton Stonehill and Ivana Crumpton. Norma Stonehill lived in retirement for 22 years with her husband in Bordighera, Italy where she will be remembered for her beautiful garden and the children's library that she founded. She was a serious linguist, an avid reader, and a great admirer and supporter of educational and literary endeavors. Funeral services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st Street on Monday, July 27, 1998 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Connecticut College, New London, CT 06320, where she was a member of the Class of 1930.

title: Columbia St.: Emerging Gem With Some Rough Facets
description: Pity poor Columbia Street. Before Robert Moses' Brooklyn-Queens Expressway cleaved it from the rest of the borough, its 13 blocks between Atlantic and Hamilton Avenues were one of New York's liveliest shopping thoroughfares. In the 1960's, the state condemned dozens of buildings along the street in anticipation of a huge Port Authority container port that never quite materialized. The final insult, after hundreds of residents were driven away by drugs, crime and arson, was a huge sewer project in the late 1970's that turned Columbia Street into an open pit.

The porterhouse served at the Assembly Steak House and Seafood Grill, the former Manhattan landmark that reopened in New Jersey in February, satisfies that desire. Jack Koumbis Jr., the owner and executive chef, begins with a three-pound loin cut of prime beef, which he cooks until the outside is crisp and the inside rare and juicy. Served on the bone with slightly more fat (and therefore more flavor) than a fillet, it is the kind of steak you long to eat in a less civilized setting.
