title: Site for Sore Eyes
description: Cassandra Saulter, a makeup artist, considers ''For Your Eyes Only'' a necessity. It's not the song she's talking about; it's the name of the treatment for the area around the eyes that she gets regularly at Haven, a spa at 150 Mercer Street (Houston and Prince Streets) in SoHo. ''I look at people's eyes all day long, and it's an area where people hold stress,'' she said. ''I never leave the house without makeup, but after this treatment I felt like all the age and the stress and the puffiness just melted away.'' The 45-minute procedure includes three types of massage around the eyes -- shiatsu, European massage and manual lymphatic drainage -- as well as a skin peel and herbal moisturizers. Gabrielle Ophals and Audra Senkus opened Haven two months ago to focus on facial treatments. ''American women are finally considering a facial part of regular maintenance, and along with this growing trend women want specialty treatments,'' Ms. Ophals said. For $50, it's an eye-opener. KIMBERLY STEVENS

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the economic prospects of middle-income workers misstated the affiliation of John Schwarz, a political science professor who calculated the wage needed to achieve a minimally adequate standard of living. He teaches at the University of Arizona, not Arizona State University.

title: Ideas & Trends; Medicine Lags Against Addiction
description: MAYOR RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI'S pronouncement last week that New York City should abolish methadone treatment for heroin addicts by the year 2000 drew fire from many drug-abuse experts. They insist that methadone is the best tool they have to help addicts reduce heroin use, stay out of jail and get back to work. In fact, some said, they wished they had something like it to treat cocaine addiction.

title: Women Entrepreneurs Attract New Financing
description: CELESTE M. JOHNSON had a dream of making gardening and landscaping products out of mixed recycled plastics. Raising the capital, however, has been a nightmare.

title: Ship Shape
description: When Le Corbusier declared the house to be ''a machine for living,'' he meant that as a good thing. The pioneering modern architect believed that houses should be as streamlined and efficient as the airplane, the automobile or the ocean liner.

title: Not for Teen-Agers
description: To the Editor:

title: Exploring Careers At Dance Academy
description: THE classes in sculpture, dance and drama looked, at first glance, not unlike other summer programs devoted to the visual and performing arts. Students transformed a pile of broken glass into mosaics and collages, fashioned life-size figures from plaster and wire and explored the dance possibilities of Beethoven's Fifth Symphony.

title: July 19-25; Justice Aide Urges Independent Counsel
description: The uproar over Attorney General Janet Reno's refusal to seek an independent prosecutor to investigate the financing of President Clinton's reelection intensified when the outgoing head of the Justice Department's fund-raising inquiry wrote that he believed an independent prosecutor should be appointed.

title: Corrections
description: A headline last Sunday on a Neighborhood Report about the testing of a proposed park bench misstated the location of the test. It is Battery Park, not Battery Park City.

title: Corrections
description: A music listing in the Guide on page 39 of today's Arts and Leisure section misstates the starting time for several concerts by Howard Jones, who will be performing with Culture Club and Human League. The concerts -- on Thursday at Radio City Music Hall, on Saturday at Jones Beach and next Sunday at PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J.. -- begin at 7:30 P.M., not 8.

title: Two Shows on the Farm in America
description: MUSEUM exhibitions often have pendant displays, but the situation here is one in which the tail wags the dog. Having assembled 141 photographs for the show ''American Farm,'' the Candace Perich Gallery presents roughly one-third of them at home base and the rest at the John Jay Homestead, a few miles away on Route 22.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, PETER W.
description: STONE-Peter W., Jr. Of Los Angeles, formerly of Irvington, NY. Beloved son of Dorothy and Dr. Peter W. Stone. Dear brother of Paul and Philip. Visiting Sunday 2-4 PM only, Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave. (Exit 17 Saw Mill), Dobbs Ferry. Funeral Monday, 10 AM, St. Barnabas Episcopal Church, N. Broadway, Irvington, NY. Contributions may be made to the Church of St. Barnabas, N. Broadway, Irvington, NY 10533, or the Tarrytown YMCA, 62 Main St., Tarrytown, NY 10591 appreciated.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There's an ache-in-the-heart feeling because of what happened yesterday. The morbid curiosity in everyone would like the tour guide to say something about what happened -- it could give an emotional closing. But it's better to carry on.''

title: The Techniques for Creating Textured Surfaces
description: MANY do-it-yourselfers overdo texturing and create wall surfaces that look like cake frosting. The key to creating a pleasing textured surface is to use restraint and subtlety.

title: At the Casinos
description: Atlantic City Hilton

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELSON, HENRY
description: ADELSON-Henry. On July 23, 1998. Beloved husband of Loretta. Devoted and loving father of Beth & Stewart. Officer in the Army Air Corp in World War II, past faculty member in the NYU & Columbia Schools of Dentistry, Past President of the 2nd District Dental Society. Funeral services to be held Sunday, July 26, at 12:15PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76 Street.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Reviving Main Streets by Historic Preservation
description: THE two-story building at 17 Second Avenue, half a block off Main Street, looks nothing like the graceful firehouse capped by a 50-foot tower that it was when it served this South Shore community from 1887 to 1914.

title: A Merger Nightmare on Fashion Street
description: CORPORATE mergers are all the rage, what with Daimler-Benz buying Chrysler, Bertelsmann swallowing Random House, and other high-stakes marriages in banking, pharmaceuticals and telecommunications. In the fashion industry, unions of famous labels have long seemed highly unlikely, given that designers consider themselves brilliant originals, whose artistic visions could not possibly be merged into one entity.

title: A Duet Of Wit And Love
description: NOEL COWARD (played by James Warwick) is reminiscing. And reading (his words). In the background, a scratchy recording of his song ''Someday, I'll Find You'' is playing, and the sounds of a marvelous party are heard. He speaks of Gertrude Lawrence, ''her magic imperishable'' (from the obituary he wrote.)

title: Stupid Inc.
description: Long before ''South Park'' became the national phenomenon that it is today, David Zucker had approached its creators -- Trey Parker and Matt Stone -- with ''Baseketball,'' the first film he had written in seven years. Back in 1980, Zucker and his brother Jerry, outsiders in Hollywood, had become something of a sensation with their first movie, ''Airplane!'' -- a classic, with its memorably offensive one-liners and ridiculous sight gags. Over the years since, Zucker had grown frustrated by a climate that seemed increasingly afraid of the outrageous, taboo-busting humor that made ''Airplane!'' so fresh and funny. He sat out much of the 90's before finally writing ''Baseketball,'' a goofy comedy that aspired to be a satire about our national sports culture.

title: Control of Browns Up to N.F.L.
description: There is a perception around the National Football League that the group made up of the banker Alfred Lerner, the former San Francisco 49ers president Carmen Policy and the former quarterback Bernie Kosar is leading the pack to buy the expansion Cleveland Browns team, which begins play next year.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Silhouettes at Boscobel

title: Flake Preaches Conservative Themes to a G.O.P. Choir
description: The Rev. Floyd H. Flake turned up at the summer meeting of the Republican National Committee yesterday morning, preaching capitalism, competition for public schools and individual responsibility to an audience of Republicans that practically glowed in the symbolism of the moment. The speech at the Plaza Hotel suggested Mr. Flake's emerging status as an iconoclast in New York politics.

title: The 'Buys' Have It: Beware the Pollyanna Message From Brokers
description: BROKERS are to stocks what Will Rogers was to people. Hardly ever do brokers meet a stock they don't like.

title: FROM THE DESK OF; Tact Can Seal A Global Deal . . . But a Little Spunk Works Best in New York
description: A CLIENT of mine, a marketing executive in Atlanta, recently made a rare trip to the Big Apple. The last time he had visited, he was a callow 17-year-old from a small town in North Carolina, getting some easy high school credit by joining a class trip. (Two highlights, he said, were when he dropped a can of pineapple from the roof of the Times Square Hotel and when he was jostled on the subway at 1 A.M.)

title: For Every Puerto Rican, a Political Rally
description: Tens of thousands of Puerto Ricans came to this coastal town today, some to celebrate, others to condemn the landing of American troops here 100 years ago, while thousands more traveled to a historic fortress in San Juan to pay homage to the political status that has defined Puerto Rico's relationship to the United States for nearly half a century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONNER, EDITH (NEE FAB
description: DONNER-Edith (nee Fab). Wife of the late Jacob. Beloved mother of Anita Johnston and Cynthia and Edward Brodsky. Loving grandmother of Laurie Andresakis, John Greenberg, Jill Greenberg, Peter Brodsky, William Brodsky and James Brodsky. Great-grandmother of James Andresakis, Michael Andresakis, Leah Greenberg, Sarah Greenberg and Beth Lester. Graveside services today, 2 PM, at Mt. Ararat Cemetery.

title: Keeping the Faith
description: The opening of THE CRUSADES (1935), a Cecil B. DeMille spectacular, is a terrific scene of two mighty armies slamming together. This is one DeMille lolla-palooza that really moves. There's no waiting around for the next commandment - from that fade-in to the climax, a barbarian walled city is unders siege by the Christmas. And tucked away within all the commotion between infidels and Christians is the appealing love story of Richard the Lion Hearted (Henry Wilcoxon) and his golden-haired princess-bride (Loretta Young). Ian Keither is effective as the wily Saracen, and so, more briefly, is Katherine DeMille (the director's daughter and the first Mrs. Anthony Quinn) - MONDAY at 8 A.M. on American Movie Classics.

title: No Time for Losers
description: Does anyone still remember the economic summit meeting that Bill Clinton convened in December 1992? Politically, it was another universe -- one in which the President-elect's personal hijinks were behind him, in which fundamental health-care reform was a vote-winner, in which Ira Magaziner was a genius and Newt Gingrich a comical figure. (Well, some things never change.) The central theme of the conference was the urgent need for America to get its act together to cope with powerful competition from other advanced countries -- above all, that economic juggernaut, Japan. And the heroes who were going to save us were the visionaries of high technology -- most prominent among them the lead speaker, John Sculley, the chief executive of Apple Computer.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Dose of Yesterday, Epitome of the Cool 90's
description: THE Red/Bar Brasserie, Southampton's newest restaurant, is the epitome of cool, crisp, 1990's Hamptons' dining yet simultaneously smiles sweetly at yesterday. For more than 60 years, this cottage on Hampton Road had been Balzarini's, a mainstay Italian spot. The new owners have exposed the original hardwood floors and whole walls of multi-paned windows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, BERTHA FRIEDLAND
description: GROSSMAN-Bertha Friedland. September 24, 1906-July 23, 1998. Last of Bessie and Morris Levinson's eleven children. Widow of Edward Friedland and Jacob Grossman. Mother of Susan Friedland and the late Corinne Schube. Grandmother of Ann (Paul) Katzenstein, Edward (Diane), & Peter (Lee) Schube. Great grandmother of Sarah and Andrew Katzenstein, Samuel, William and Benjamin Schube, stepmother & grandmother of Micki (Herbert), Suzi and Lee Goldberger, and Jeffrey Fisher. Services on Sunday, 11:30AM at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam.

title: Ideas & Trends; The N.E.A. Tries A Little Self-Help
description: FOR an agency that spends less than 0.01 percent of the Federal budget, the National Endowment for the Arts gets a lot of attention from Congress, particularly negative attacks from conservatives. But last week the House of Representatives overwhelmingly approved the agency's money for next year.

title: Mara Raphael, James Wilcox
description: Mara Buell Raphael, a Washington-based producer for CNN, was married yesterday to James Wightman Wilcox, who was until last week the press secretary to Representative Bill Archer, Republican of Texas. The Rev. Andrew Osmun officiated at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Middlebury, Vt.

title: Best Books Lists Creates Readerships; Outdated Perspective
description: To the Editor:

title: Coutts Is Racing Again, but Isn't Celebrating Yet
description: It was as if Russell Coutts were running on empty. His eyelids looked heavy, and his conversation lacked spark. But Coutts, New Zealand's America's Cup skipper, was on the mend after having been laid up for nearly a month with mononucleosis, a temporary but fatiguing malady.

title: Katherine Alberg, Joshua Anderson
description: Katherine Anne Alberg and Joshua Paul Anderson were married yesterday near Duvall, Wash. Judge M. Margaret McKeown of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in Seattle officiated in a field owned by the bride's grandfather Thomas Alberg.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ERDHEIM, BARBARA
description: ERDHEIM-Barbara. July 3rd, 1943-July 26th, 1996. I love and miss you. Lynn Merrill Unger

title: Miss Criscola And Mr. Theall
description: Kimberley Beth Criscola, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank F. Criscola of Watchung, N.J., is to be married this afternoon to John Stephen Theall, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Theall of Norwalk, Conn. The Rev. Chester H. Carina is to perform the ceremony at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Bernardsville, N.J.

title: Tangled System Decides Pensions For Firefighters Disabled on Job
description: The first time he hurt his back, William Guidal says, he was fighting a fire in an electronics store on East 86th Street in Manhattan. Something heavy fell on him. It might have been a television, but it was too dark and smoky to tell.

title: Ms. Weymouth And Mr. Scully
description: Katharine Bouchage Weymouth, a daughter of Elizabeth Graham Weymouth of New York and Yann Weymouth of Miami, was married last evening to Richard Alan Scully, the son of Bernice and Richard T. Scully of Washington. The Rev. Francis Geer, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the bride's mother's house in Southampton, N.Y.

title: Farrah Jarmel, Aaron Zabar
description: Farrah Ame Jarmel, a daughter of Dean and Arlene Jarmel of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married last evening to Aaron Zabar, the son of Carole and Saul Zabar of Manhattan. Rabbi Charles Davidson officiated at Moran's restaurant in Manhattan.

title: Missile Defense Plan Ignores Real Threat; Any Risk Is Too Big
description: To the Editor:

title: Assessor Is Overruled In Elderly Tax Review
description: NINE elderly Greenburgh homeowners have won an immediate reduction in their school taxes, leaving open the possibility that 50 others -- but maybe hundreds -- could also qualify.

title: Baby, It's Hot Outside for Child Care Companies
description: FINGER paint, macaroni jewelry and circle time are among the fundamental building blocks that fill the days of preschoolers at child care centers.

title: The Hippocratic Wars
description: Ellen Ruppel Shell's article on The New England Journal of Medicine and The Journal of the American Medical Association (''The Hippocratic Wars,'' June 28) depicted the two as subordinating their high purposes in a scramble for media publicity to garner advertising dollars. To tar both journals with the same brush, she presented them as essentially identical, despite real and important differences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPOPORT, MITCHELL
description: RAPOPORT-Mitchell. Good night, sweet prince, may flights of angels sing thee to thy rest! Know that we loved you and miss you. Uncle Carl and Aunt Florence Uncle Bernard and Aunt Robbie and Cousins all.

title: Air Cooling Can Provoke Hot Tempers
description: Zinno is known for Italian food and free nightly jazz at the bar. But for people living behind the restaurant, it is known mostly for really noisy air conditioners.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Minding the Store

title: Battering, Metrocards, Squatters; Homicides Aren't So Rare In Domestic Violence Cases
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCELROY, JAMES W.
description: McELROY-James W. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of James W. McElroy, associated with The Times from 1962, until retiring in 1984.

title: Beach Reads and Pool Books: Long Island in Hardcover; Keeping a Scary Eye On a Woman of Words
description: Victoria Gotti's suspense novel ''I'll Be Watching You'' is about Rose, a successful novelist living in a mansion in Brookville, who has a stalker named Billy.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.; Second Eyeglass Store in Brooklyn
description: Seven years ago, Mary and Bob Kane opened Eyes On Avenue U, an eyeglass store, at Avenue U and East 15th Street in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn. Eyes On U Too opened last week in Brooklyn Heights at 306 Henry Street, at Atlantic Avenue. The store, which will soon have an optometrist, sells high-end merchandise (Calvin Klein frames begin at $229). Because it is ''family-oriented,'' said Ms. Kane, there are also less costly frames. REBEKAH COLEMAN

title: Rescuing Swimmers, a Nonpartisan Effort
description: THE Suffolk County Legislature will never drown in bureaucracy, says its presiding officer, Steve Hackeling. He should know. Mr. Hackeling is a lifeguard. When he's not trying to save the county, he's saving lives at Robert Moses State Park. And he is not alone. Paul Tonna (Republican of West Hills) is also a summer lifeguard at Robert Moses. ''He has more seniority than I,'' Mr. Hackeling said. ''So he gets the main stand.''

title: No End of Restaurants On a Second Ave. Block
description: Strollers on the west side of Second Avenue from 74th Street to 75th Street can choose almost any food they want. The street has had a plethora of restaurants for years, but it has been a solid block of eateries ever since New World Coffee and Bagels opened this month at 1421 Second Avenue (at 74th Street).

title: Getting to the Heart of Sardinia
description: TO know Sardinia intimately, residents say, you must visit the interior of the island. Only tourists cling to the coast, along with pirates and conquerors and other sailors of blemished repute. If you are in quest of the Sardinian spirit, you must go where the earth turns brown and dry, the cork oak raises its battered silhouette against the horizon, and the winds whistle across the hills.

title: Plastic Surgeon Questions
description: To Sunday Styles:

title: SOAPBOX; Unsolved Mystery, Part 2
description: LAST month (Soapbox, June 14), I told the story of the century-old murder of my great-grandfather, Edwin Renner (pictured at right), a 28-year-old father of three found near Verona Lake with pistol-shot wounds through his brain and heart, and his head cut off with a knife. Based on newspaper articles of the day, I also spoke of the strong suspicion that the killer was a man named Henry Spangler, co-owner with my great-grandfather of a tourist boat at Lake Hopatcong. But Mr. Spangler, who left suicide notes for the police in Manhattan and Newark, was never found, dead or alive.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEIN, FELIX
description: KLEIN-Felix. January 17, 1911July 26, 1994. His love and wisdom still inspire and strengthen us. Founder of the National Society for Graphology, headquartered in Manhattan. His teaching legacy endures through the newly established Felix Klein Academy for Gestalt Graphology. In devoted remembrance, Janice

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIMAN, ARTHUR
description: GIMAN-Arthur. The Board of Directors and membership of Glen Head Country Club announce with profound sorrow the untimely passing of our esteemed member Arthur Giman. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. Martin Scheman, President

title: MetroStars Beat Chicago
description: Using the same players with consistency, the MetroStars are getting progressively better game by game. They are becoming more productive offensively and allow fewer goals defensively. As a result, they have been near the top of the Eastern Conference all season, and they appear to be ready to contend for the title in Major League Soccer.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; In Danbury, 931 Housing Units Rising or Approved
description: A 40-UNIT condominium project with a 128-slip marina is rising at the rim of a small inlet of Candlewood Lake here. The project, called Crystal Bay, replaces the old Anchor Marina, built when the 11-mile-long lake was created as a hydroelectric power resource in 1926.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, HERBERT SELIG
description: WOLF-Herbert Selig. On July 20, 1998, after a long illness. Survived by his wife, two children and two grandchildren. Mr. Wolf was Vice President and CFO of Accent Supply Company. Donations may be sent to the Brain Tumor Society, Boston, MA., or National Cancer Institute, Bethesda, MD.

title: Tribal Windfall: A Chance to Reopen History
description: THE month of July on B. Kliban's 1998 cat calendar: Three cats row a dinghy to the beach. A tribe of mice innocently paddles its teacups out to meet them. The lead cat raises a paw: an ominous hello. The first contact between Indians and Europeans at Plymouth was most likely that friendly. The cat-and-mouse encounter that swiftly followed, however, has shaped the American mind right down to its taste in kitsch.

title: A Feast of a Picnic With Chicken Wiener Schnitzel and Salads
description: WHEN some friends suggested that we celebrate the Fourth of July with a picnic and a Ray Charles concert at Tanglewood, it seemed like a great idea. We arrived early, but the lawn was already crowded despite the threat of rain. We found an empty spot near the front and, feeling lucky, settled ourselves down and spread out our feast.

title: In Port Washington, an Eyesore Becomes a Golfer's Delight
description: FOR more than a century, the Port Washington sand pits provided the raw material for the cement that helped build Manhattan skyscrapers. Its canyons served as desert backdrops for filmmakers. Now a new sports complex has risen from the sands, turning an abandoned eyesore into an oasis.

title: U.S. Cancels Plans For Raid on Bosnia To Capture 2 Serbs
description: After spending more than two years and tens of millions of dollars preparing missions, training commandos and gathering intelligence, the United States has dropped its secret plans to arrest Bosnia's two most wanted men accused of war crimes, senior Administration officials say.

title: Getting the Most From Water Usage
description: The recent In the Garden column, ''Bidding Adieu to the Always-Green Lawn'' (June 14), underscored two facts: Long Islanders use a lot of water to irrigate lawns, gardens and shrubs during the warmer months and as the column pointed out, homeowners have many opportunities to use water more efficiently.

title: High Tech for Elderly
description: SOME graduates at the Fairview Greenburgh Community Center are seniors in more ways than one. They are older than 55 and members of Seniornet, a national nonprofit computer training organization that teaches computer technology and the Internet to more than 23,000 older people a year. But like graduates everywhere, each has a different reason for choosing to take the 8-week, 16-hour course at the center.

title: The Honeymooners Mambo on The Web
description: When John Katsigeorgis first saw ''The Honeymooners,'' the television show starring Jackie Gleason as Ralph Kramden, the blustering bus driver from Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, and Art Carney as his pal, Ed Norton, the unflappable sewer worker, Mr. Katsigeorgis was 4 years old. ''All I remember is Norton dancing around and I just started laughing,'' said Mr. Katsigeorgis, now 25 and living in Astoria, Queens.

title: New Parks From The Grass Roots
description: THE idea of a national park as a wilderness set aside for recreation for everyone began with Yellowstone in 1872, before there was a National Park Service. Now, 126 years later, the service has jurisdiction over 376 places -- memorials and monuments, land and houses, historic sites and the like -- embracing over 83 million acres. But in the last 15 years, in an ''ambitious experiment,'' as the Park Service calls it, Congress has given the service a vastly different task: Helping grass-roots groups preserve history, landscape, canals and rivers or anything else that seems to them to embody the special qualities of where they live and work.

title: An Inn's Classic Fare, a Bit of Attitude, Too
description: SOME restaurants make their reputations by the culinary equivalent of bungee jumping: taking risks with innovative food. Others, like the Inn at Ridgefield, produce a steady diet of familiar dishes that rarely soar but rarely crash either.

title: With Determined Pride, Visitors Tour as Usual
description: Eric Driessen trained his video camera on the expanse of the Capitol's Great Rotunda. He was not really listening to the official tour guide, who spoke cheerily of the building's architecture and history but made no mention of the bloody shootout on Friday in which two Capitol police officers were killed.

title: A Picnic Fit for Making Memories
description: WHEN some friends suggested that we celebrate the Fourth of July with a picnic and a Ray Charles concert at Tanglewood, it seemed like a great idea. It was not an elaborate picnic, but it drew stares from our immediate neighbors. An Austrian friend, Ingeborg Hecht, made wiener schnitzel, using pounded chicken breasts instead of veal. We had salads of chopped tomatoes mixed with red onion and kernels of corn and waxy Yukon gold potatoes tossed in a mustard vinaigrette with tarragon and hard-boiled eggs. This was followed by bread and cheese. For dessert, there were cherries, slices of melon, a bowl of strawberries and blueberries tossed with a little sugar, and chocolate-chip cookies.

title: Where Rivers of Ice Flowed
description: TONIGHT the air is teal blue, so vivid it seems a Venetian heaven concocted by Tintoretto. Above the mirroring lake, white peaks and serrated ridges are lit by alpenglow. This is no dream. The wooden stoop is splintery. My feet rest on grass. Behind the screen door, my companion calls me to bed, but I will stay until the hotel's yellow lights blink out. I will wait for stars to emerge, watch trout rise, hear the flutter of ducks in the winging silence.

title: Charles Mann Jr., 68, Authority on Hemingway
description: Prof. Charles William Mann Jr., a sleuth of the unpublished Hemingway and the keeper of rare books at Pennsylvania State University for the last four decades, died on July 17 at his home in Baltimore. He was 68 and also lived in State College, Pa.

title: How Much Of a Bargain?
description: Someone got a bargain at a city real estate auction on Monday. Or did they?

title: LOOKING BACK; What Was With the Weather
description: Although New York is prone to neither hurricanes, nor tornadoes, nor earthquakes, nor floods, it has seen its fair share of eventful weather, which has occasionally influenced the course of the city's history:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GARFUNKEL, CARRIE (WEIL
description: GARFUNKEL-Carrie (Weil). We miss you more each year. In loving memory, your children and grandchildren

title: SIGNOFF; Coulda Been Contenders, And Now They Can
description: Could that be the movie reviewer Gene Siskel swinging around his longtime pal Roger Ebert, helicopter style, by his stock-and-trade thumb? It could indeed.

title: Carting Renewal
description: Rye Brook plans to renew its contract with Suburban Carting, despite the fact that the Mamaroneck-based trash hauler pleaded guilty last year to Federal racketeering and fraud charges and was assessed millions of dollars in fines.

title: Sports of the Times; Taking One Last Leap on Two Steady Feet
description: JACKIE JOYNER-KERSEE took the final long jump of her brilliant 15-year career here last night. There is talk of some overseas farewell. But in Joyner-Kersee's mind, and in the minds of those who have followed her, the curtain finally fell.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about living in Whitestone, Queens, misstated the name of the developer of the Wildflower Estate condominiums. It is Kiska Development, not Kisko.

title: The View From/Litchfield; New at the White Memorial Museum
description: SOMETIMES the greatest treasures sit quietly in your own neighborhood, visited by out-of-towners, largely ignored by the local populace. The White Memorial Conservation Center in Litchfield isn't necessarily like that; lots of people from Litchfield County are among the 30,000 or so visitors who find their way there to hike the trails that traverse 4,000 acres.

title: Libya and Lockerbie
description: To the Editor:

title: Down East
description: Cordelia Underwood

title: July 19-25; Panel, Challenging Integrity, Rejects Air Force Nominee
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee rejected President Clinton's choice to be the next Secretary of the Air Force, challenging the nominee's truthfulness and integrity.

title: Famine: The Man-Made Disaster
description: The pictures from the Sudan are heartbreakingly familiar -- the sunken cheeks and spindly legs of famine, which could kill half a million people this year. In the past few years the world has improved its ability to spot famine and feed the starving. But in the Sudan and North Korea those efforts are not enough to prevent widespread death from hunger and its related diseases.

title: Deruta Ceramics
description: To the Editor: Elaine Sciolino renews for me a trip my husband and I took in 1970 in search of Deruta and the Grazia Pottery Works (''In Umbria, a World of Pottery,'' July 5). Some friends had commissioned us to find missing pieces of their dinner set; we were unable to resist buying many items for ourselves.

title: Alone in the Badlands
description: THE official National Park Service map of South Dakota's Badlands National Park makes no mention of the Cuny Cafe. This is a significant omission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWITZ, NORMA S.
description: BERKOWITZ-Norma S. Wife of the late Sidney (Sam). Mass of the Resurrection will be Monday, at 10 AM, from St. Columba Church, 313 W. 25th St, NYC. Burial to follow in Calvary Cemetery. For information call Horne and Dannecker Funeral Home, 212-242-5250.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WOLF, TONY
description: WOLF-Tony. July 26, 1982. ''That is the land of lost content, I see it shining plain, The happy highways where I went And cannot come again.'' In love and sorrow, Mom and Sasha

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAZURE, ROBERTA C.
description: MAZURE-Roberta C. On July 23, 1998. Beloved wife of David. Loving mother of Lisa and Caren. Adoring grandmother of Sara and Harris. Daughter of Jean. Sister of Eileen. Aunt of Michael. Her strong will, warm heart and great generosity will always be remembered. Visiting Saturday, 7-9PM. Services Sunday, 10AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions to the National Tuberous Sclerosis Association, 8181 Professional Place, Suite 110, Landover, MD 20785-2226 in memory of Roberta Mazure.

title: Strong Office Market
description: A combination of business expansions and relocations by local companies resulted in a strong office market in Westchester during the first half of the year, the Insignia/ESG Midyear Office Market shows. Leasing activity was up 43 percent over the same period a year ago. The county's availability rate for commercial real estate dropped almost 3 percentage points to 14.2 percent.

title: Republican Whip Details Shootout in Offices
description: Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the Republican whip, was talking business on Friday with two staff members in his Capitol Hill office when he heard the shots.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANTON, EDWIN J.

Mr. Vasulka is a media artist, combining video, computer technology and traditional machinery in his work. It had taken him months to put everything together and relatively little time to take it apart. Something was amiss, but Mr. Vasulka appeared calm.

title: The Nation; Good Times Are Bad For Interest Groups
description: IN the past few years the Federal Government and private researchers have issued a number of reports depicting dramatic improvement in the quality of life for America's black population. High school completion rates have reached parity with those of whites. Birth rates among single black women have hit a 40-year low. Homicide rates have declined to the levels of the 1960's. Poverty rates have dipped below 30 percent of black households for the first time in the country's history. The home ownership rate is up. The jobless rate is down.

title: Distinctive Voices Past and Present

It's amazing how difficult it can be to recognize the voices of even famous tenors like Carlo Bergonzi or Giuseppe di Stefano. A voice may be great without being that distinctive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, JANICE
description: JOHNSON-Janice. Age forty-five, passed away on July 3rd. A professional artist at the peak of her career with representation with Margulies/Taplin Gallery in Coral Gables, Florida and Woodward Gallery in New York City. The highly educated Johnson specialized in the ancient technique of encaustic (wax) paintings from which she received international recognition. Johnson enjoyed the tremendous success of her most recent exhibition this Spring at Woodward Gallery, Soho, where she displayed contemporary encaustics as an homage to Manet's last still life flowers. Her work is featured in collections throughout the world. Though the art community is greatly diminished by this loss, her friends, collectors and family derive strength from the memory of her creativity and vitality.

title: ARTS/ARTIFACTS; Drivers Beware: Bumps Ahead
description: AS a teen-ager growing up near San Francisco in the 1960's, Peter Foster would occasionally steal his parents' car in the middle of the night and drive down to Playland at the Beach in search of an after-hours bumper-car fix. These days, to satisfy that urge, Mr. Foster, 43, doesn't have to go any farther than the Exxon station he owns in Petaluma, Calif. He keeps some of the three dozen bumper cars he owns at the station so that he, his employees and his customers, who come from as far as 300 miles away, can whizz around an impromptu track set up on the station grounds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANDEN, EDITH
description: STANDEN-Edith. The Trustees and Staff of the Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn with affection and deep sadnees the passing of their respected colleague and friend, Edith Standen, who was Curator Emeritus of the Department of European Sculpture and Decorative Arts, and a renowned and prolific tapestry historian. She was in charge of the Textile Study Room from 1949 until her retirement in 1970, and continued to devote herself to her research on tapestries of the Renaissance and later periods, arriving at the Museum early each morninginto her 93rd year-to work in the Watson Library. She was a familiar and respected presence, and a determined and prolific scholar who will be greatly missed. Philippe de Montebello, Director

title: The Precarious Future of the Baltic Mill
description: SINCE the looms producing cotton fell silent in 1967, the capacious floors of the Baltic Mill in the town of Sprague have echoed with little but the sound of rain and wind sluicing through its leaking roof or cracked windows -- and speculation about the future of the old mill on the Shetucket River.

title: Long-Delayed Lessons About Fathers and a War
description: IN the late afternoon of an autumn day in 1962, a comrade in arms and I were flat on our bellies in a foxhole, peering out from under olive-drab infantry helmets across a field of tall grass turned brown and brittle with the season. Rifles at the ready, we were watching for German troop movements in a stand of maples and oaks some 50 yards off, ignoring as best we could the headlight beams blasting through the naked trees from the Chevy Bel Airs and Ford Fairlanes and Rambler Americans passing by.

title: Kayaks Off Chelsea? Not This Summer. Too Many Waves.
description: It would have made for quite a summer scene: dozens of kayaks sailing the Hudson off Pier 64, at the end of West 24th Street in Chelsea. But a plan to launch the small boats from just south of the pier has been scuttled, at least for now, by a divided Community Board 4.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HART, LAURA
description: HART-Laura. Widow of Ralph A. Hart. Died at her home in Palm Beach, Florida on July 19, at the age of 92. Born in Saskatchewan, Canada, she moved with her husband & daughter Gay from Toronto to Bombay to Sydney and Paris before coming to Short Hills, New Jersey in 1954. She and Mr. Hart later moved to Hartford, Connecticut where her husband was Chairman and CEO of the Heublein Company. They retired to Florida in 1974. She will be greatly missed by her two surviving daughters Gay Hart Gaines of Palm Beach, Florida, & Wilma Purdy Warriner of Winnipeg, Canada, her six grandchildren and eight greatgrandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held at a future date to be announced.

title: My Boris
description: As one of the few remaining people with frequent access to the increasingly volcanic President of Russia, Valentin Yumashev knows when to step lightly. So it was with careful planning -- and a slightly queasy stomach -- that the Kremlin chief of staff decided to present an important document to Boris Yeltsin one day this spring.

title: Republican Infighting
description: People who wondered what the Republican Party would use for an agenda once the Contract With America faded into the history of political flapdoodle may now have their answer. The party's two historical wings -- the corporate pro-business faction and the populist social conservatives -- seem inclined to spend eternity canceling out each other's proposals. Voter pressures make that unwise. But it makes for a good show.

title: Multilingual Students Help Budapest Tourists
description: Hungary has become an increasingly attractive place for tourists -- interesting, still relatively unknown, not too expensive and not too much of a trek. But in the last several years, along with some other Central and Eastern European destinations, Hungary has given visitors some unwelcome experiences.

title: A McCartney Home Is Opening for Tours
description: The house in Liverpool where Paul McCartney and his family lived in the 1950's and 60's has been acquired by the National Trust and will open to the public on Wednesday. Paul was 13 in 1955 when the family moved to 20 Forthlin Road, a small three-bedroom house, where the Beatles practiced and wrote their earliest songs. It was rented from the Liverpool City Council by Jim and Mary McCartney, who lived there with Paul and his younger brother, Michael.

title: Stripper Screening
description: Earlier this summer, Citizenship and Immigration Canada -- the Canadian Government's border guard -- started making it more red-tapish for exotic dancers from outside Canada to do their thing in the Great White North. It used to be that non-Canadian strippers hoping to work in Canada only needed an intent-to-hire letter from a Canadian strip club and a modest fee for a work permit. Under rules just recently put into place, most strippers from overseas have to check in with the C.I.C. and be prepared to show proof that they are, in fact, pros.

title: Abraham I. Katsh, 92, Scholar And Researcher of Judaica
description: Abraham I. Katsh, a scholar of Judaica and Hebrew studies who introduced modern Hebrew to American university classrooms, and a relentless researcher who persuaded the Soviet authorities to allow him to reproduce thousands of Jewish documents in their custody at the height of the cold war, died on Tuesday at DeWitt Nursing Home in Manhattan.

title: On the Road to Utopia in a Fractious France
description: MANUEL POIRIER'S movie career got off to a slow start. He was 40 by the time his first film was released, and even then, forced to act as his own producer, he could afford only one print. Yet, somehow, the right people saw it and liked it and the doors that Mr. Poirier had been knocking on for years suddenly opened. Within two years he had made three more movies, and the last of these, ''Western,'' won the Grand Jury Prize at the 1997 Cannes International Film Festival.

title: Clarice Olinger and Victor Lindner
description: AT 72, Clarice K. Olinger is anything but stereotypical. Her hair is naturally black and curly and she drives very, very fast, zooming up her long driveway like a teen-ager. She runs a mile every day, takes aerobics classes and appears to have none of the usual fears that come with age: neither extra-spicy food nor loneliness concern her at all.

title: All-Weather Setting in Bedford Village

On temperate summer evenings, however, one can dine outdoors on this restaurant's patio, which seems, almost as an afterthought, carved into a spectacular garden. The heady fragrance of lofty trumpet lilies even wafts through the enclosed dining porch, which affords a panoramic view of double hollyhocks, phlox, riots of pansies, pots of shameless-pink bougainvillea and giant floral snowballs of blue and white.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Reconstructing Soutine
description: Sleek museum halls may represent, in effect, the rich and complex fruits of an artist's life arranged into neatly hung and clearly labeled rows. An Expressionist in Paris: The Paintings of Chaim Soutine (Prestel/Te Neues, $65) goes far to do the reverse; it attempts to return the artist and his work to their vital place in history. Born in 1893 to poor Orthodox Jews in a village near Minsk, Soutine came of age while pogroms swept Russia. From the age of 20, when he arrived in Paris on the eve of World War I, to his death in 1943 while hiding from Nazi forces in an occupied France, he practiced a particularly frenetic and unsettlingly morbid breed of Expressionism: landscapes so laden with paint the canvases themselves seem overgrown, portraits in which the subjects' faces seem to dissolve, still lifes with sides of beef dripping with blood. Yet the focus of the 10 essays in this book rests not so much on Soutine's paintings as on how little else he left behind. He did not sketch; he left few photographs and even fewer letters. The achievement of ''An Expressionist in Paris'' ultimately lies in its elegant manipulation of the various forms of secondhand testimony with which we can make up for that dearth -- the criticism, the myths, the anecdotes, the sales and exhibition records. Through such meticulously researched works of scholarship as Kenneth E. Silver's informative profile of the artistic, critical, religious and political climates during Soutine's career and Colette Giraudon's exhaustive delineation of Soutine's market, the painter himself remains a silent, phantasmal figure that must be reconstituted from the fragments. And the image that does resolve itself inevitably brings with it a sense of irretrievable loss. Christina Cho

title: Little Pitchers
description: Want to buy a football? That's what 21 recent third grade graduates would like you to do, and they can be very persuasive. Their persuasiveness takes the form of a television commercial they made at Three Bridges School in Hunterdon County. They had help, from Barbara Perchaluk, an executive at the Gianettino & Meredith advertising agency in Short Hills, who is the aunt of James Sullivan, one of the students. She guided the students in conceiving an imaginary product -- a big football containing two smaller ones -- and forming groups to handle such tasks as copywriting, wardrobe, story board production and painting backgrounds. The result, finished last month, is an upbeat minute of children tossing a football around the world (with plenty of special effects) and a catchy jingle. The project was meant to illustrate logical thinking, communication and teamwork. What the student's didn't need was an introduction to the main concept. ''Kids,'' said Ms. Perchaluk, ''know all about commercials.''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Too Late to Live
description: In a sharp break from the wry humor of her best-selling Adrian Mole diaries, Sue Townsend's novel GHOST CHILDREN (Soho, $22) uses an obsessive, desperate romance to address such complex issues as abortion and child abuse. In a macabre early scene, Christopher Moore -- middle-aged, unemployed and socially isolated -- discovers a dumped bag of aborted fetuses and, like a demented Silas Marner, takes one home until it decomposes. This strange act prompts him to search out Angela Lowood, nee Carr, with whom he had a youthful love affair until she aborted their out-of-wedlock child. His obsession with this lost child casts a foreboding shadow over his attempts to win Angela back, and also colors his chance dealings with Crackle and Tamara, a grubby young couple who live in a housing project, and their infant daughter, Storme. What Christopher hardly suspects, and Townsend unflinchingly depicts, is the cycle of abuse that will put Storme in the hospital even as Christopher is re-establishing his relationship with Angela. Now morbidly obese and married to a cold, class-conscious and sexually frustrated businessman named Gregory, Angela is also haunted by the past. And her daydreams -- sometimes near-hallucinations -- of a perfect daughter only sharpen the poignancy of the wasted years as she tries to change her life. Never casting judgment on Angela and Gregory or Crackle and Tamara, Townsend moves with assurance and cold irony from the gentle satire of her previous books into grim social drama. Even at its bleakest, ''Ghost Children'' displays her talent for getting inside her characters' minds -- though they are far less pleasant to inhabit than young Adrian Mole's. Allen Lincoln

title: Making the Case for an Overlooked Swing Pianist

The honor belongs to Mel Powell, who won in 1990 for a two-piano concerto called ''Duplicates.'' To be sure, the composer of ''Duplicates'' had long since stopped playing jazz by the time he collected his prize. But Powell, who worked with Benny Goodman and Glenn Miller in the 1940's, was for a brief time among the best-known big-band sidemen in America, and when he died on April 24, jazz connoisseurs mourned him not as a relatively obscure composer of nontonal classical music, but as one of the most underrated pianists of the swing era.

Lueken died in 1995, and her followers split into factions that feuded over control. One, headed by her husband, Arthur, won a court battle and kept the Lueken name. The other -- a larger group, St. Michael's World Apostolate -- scored its own coup when city parks officials granted it a permit to use the Queens site on June 18. The Luekenites planned to show up too, creating a tense situation. Here's what happened that day.

title: The Hippocratic Wars
description: ''The Hippocratic Wars'' seriously misrepresents the impact of the Ingelfinger rule, whereby respected scientific journals will not accept previously published material. If there were no rule, any researcher with interesting results and half a brain would publish first in the mass media. The lengthy, rigorous process of peer review at a prestigious medical journal could come later. But if that peer review revealed the work to be scientifically invalid, could we always count on the media to retract the earlier ''news''? The public health implications are serious. Supporters of the rule include physicians, scientists and public health advocates who are concerned about the proliferation of ''junk science'' in the mass media and on the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PREY, HERMANN
description: PREY-Hermann. The 92nd Street YM-YWHA Board of Directors & Staff deeply mourn the passing of preeminent German baritone Hermann Prey. His tireless work as creator and artistic director of the Y's landmark Schubertiade (1987-1997), the first event of its kind in the U.S., made it one of the most acclaimed music programs of the past decade. This unprecedented celebration of the life and work of composter Franz Schubert was blessed with Mr. Prey's unyielding moral & musical support. His 15 year association with the Y also featured numerous solo performances, including his celebrated March 11, 1998 Schubertiade post - script, Schubert's Last Lieder, exploring the final chapter of the composer's prolific career. In a sad irony, the concert, which would be his last New York appearance, included Schwanengesang (Swan Song), Schubert's final song cycle. Paul Griffiths of the New York Times described this extraordinary performance as ''a reminder of (Prey's) powers (that also) had an impressive candor that was of the moment. He was singing of himself.'' Hermann Prey's devotion & contributions to classical music at the 92nd Street Y will be greatly missed by us all. We extend our profound sympathy to his wife, Barbara and his family. Philip L. Milstein, President Joseph N. Leff, Chairman Sol Adler, Executive Director

title: Message On a Can
description: Since last month, Miller Lite has been sold in seven different cans that invite the guzzler to establish a meaningful relationship with his beer. One can has a Cal-O-Meter on it, a scale to show the calories consumed, from zero ounces (zero calories) to 12 ounces (128 calories). Another can has a space where a drinker can write his name, address and phone number -- in case the can gets lost. Some cans note, ''Not every can of Miller Lite contains the same number of bubbles.'' The arch labeling is pitched to the postcollegiate crowd, beer-drinkers weaned on Lettermanesque humor. It is the Miller Brewing Company's response to a flatness in sales, said Gina Shaffer, marketing communications manager for Miller Lite in Milwaukee. She said the labeling is ''focused on 21- to 28-year-olds.'' Miller Lite, introduced in 1975, had its peak year in 1990, said Eric Shepard, executive editor of Beer Marketers Insight, an industry newsletter. A six-pack of 12-ounce cans is $4.50. ELAINE LOUIE

title: The Hippocratic Wars

title: Riders Get Up Off Couch and Head for the Alps
description: If teams had psychologists instead of sports doctors, they might say the Tour de France was in a state of denial today. The 147 riders still in the race continued rolling toward the Alps, stalwart in their vow not to further discuss the doping problems that have become the focus of this year's event -- at least not until they sit down with officials of the Tour and the International Cycling Union this autumn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTFIELD, HELEN
description: BARTFIELD-Helen. Died on July 25. Deeply beloved wife of Ira. Caring daughter of Theresa. Devoted mother of Ross, Scott and Geoffrey. Loving sister of Shirley. Cherished grandmother of Talia and Oliva. A Board Certified diplomate psychotherapist. She was a graduate of Columbia Unviversity School of Social Work, was a clinical supervisor for After-Care at S.E.N.G.C. on Long Island and was associated with the Brooklyn Center for Psychotherapy. Her permeating warmth, infectious optimism and uncompromising insistence on living life to the fullest, despite a dark prognosis since 1980, will always be an unforgettable inspiration to family, friends, patients and all whose lives were enriched by her. Services will be held 9:45 AM, Monday, July 27, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St.and Asmterdam Ave.

David Wells is the epitome of sloppiness on a diamond. The pitcher wears the illustrious pinstripes like an oversized $29 suit, he has a bouncer's style and a boorish image.

title: Op-Art
Critic's Notebook; Listening For Ideology in the Commotion of TV News
description: Is television news infected by a liberal virus or is it infested with right-wing vermin? Recent eruptions confirm that this much-chewed argument doesn't go away but continues to stir ideological juices on all sides. Journalists' claims of objectivity are perhaps imperfectly realized; even so, the hard-line critics protest too much.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALDEN, JOAN WILLIAMS
description: MALDEN-Joan Williams. Of Massapequa, NY. Died on July 22, 1998. Beloved daughter of Myrtle and Sidney Siegel. She is survived by her sister Marjorie Ewald; her five children: Marc Chasnov, Robin Antila, Debra Viniar, David Chasnov, and Kristine Malden; and her eight grandchildren. Joan was a passionate pediataric physical therapist in private practice for over thirty years. Her gift for healing changed the lives of thousands of children. An avid pilot, traveler, and educator, Joan will be remembered for her spirit of adventure, her sense of humor, and above all her strength. She will be deeply missed. For more information, call the Claude R. Boyd-Spencer Funeral Home at 516-669-2400.

title: Compressed Data; Band of Angels Invests in Sendmail

Last week the software, Sendmail, drew $6 million in financing for its owner, Sendmail Inc. of Emeryville, Calif. Nearly all of the money came from the prestigious Band of Angels, a loosely organized group of investors that includes Mark Porat, the founder of Avanti Capital, and Dean Morton, the retired chief operating officer of Hewlett-Packard.

title: A Weak International Court

It was an important moment for those who longed to put some teeth into international law. More than 100 nations have now created an institution to prosecute people who commit international crimes. But the court's weaknesses will allow many of the worst criminals to escape trial.

description: In a stunning triumph of optimism over simple arithmetic, Americans tapped their savings, choked sidewalks and interstate highways and blissfully endured hours in the summer sun today as they lined up by the millions for a 1-in-80-million shot at a quarter-billion dollars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLER, RABBI H. LEONARD
description: POLLER-Rabbi H. Leonard. Larchmont Temple-Har Chayim records with deep sorrow the death of our beloved Rabbi Emeritus, H. Leonard Poller. Rabbi Poller served as the Senior Rabbi of Larchmont Temple-Har Chayim from 1972 to 1994. Rabbi Poller was ordained at Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion (HUC-JIR) on May 25, 1957. He was the Chairman of the Task Force for the Creation of the New Central Conference of American Rabbis (CCAR) Prayerbook for the 21st Century, and was the CoEditor of On the Doorposts of Your House, a CCAR prayerbook. Rabbi Poller was a critic of religious affairs for CBS-TV ''Would You Believe'' from 1967 to 1972. In 1982 Rabbi Poller was awarded a Doctorate of Divinity Honoris Causa from HUC-JIR. In 1990 he received the Distinguished Service Award from the Synagogue Council of America. We will miss his warmth and compassion, his spiritual leadership, his scholarly efforts, and the rich contributions he made to the lives of all of his congregants. To his family and loved ones, we express our profound sympathy. Kenneth Gordon, President Jeffrey J. Sirkman, Rabbi

title: USA Official Puts It Together
description: Craig Masback completed his first year as USA Track and Field's chief executive with his first major accomplishment: putting on a successful major international meet from scratch in only five weeks.

title: Police Investigate Death Of Girl Found in Queens
description: Detectives in Queens have begun an investigation after paramedics responding to a 911 call about an unconscious child found a 5-year-old girl dead in her home early yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Recovering And Guarding Her Privacy
description: Angela M. Dickerson, the woman wounded in the shooting at the Capitol last Friday, was recovering quietly at her home in Chantilly, Va., today, well enough to talk to family and friends but determined to guard her privacy.

title: Defying Bitter Past, Cambodians Vote Peacefully
description: The crush at the door of the tiny schoolhouse here was so thick today that when the voters burst in, one by one, they were sweating and laughing from the exertion.

title: Forget Bang; Fall TV Lineup Barely Musters A Whimper
description: At a time when the television networks are ever more battered by viewer defections, with ratings this summer hitting unexpected new lows, the need for exciting new shows to bring the audience back has never been greater. But few broadcast executives expect the new fall season to produce the comeback the networks need.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUPIN, NATHAN
description: KUPIN-Nathan. The loving family of Nathan Kupin express with deepest sorrow the loss of a truly great human being. His love will always be in our hearts. Services will be held at Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY, at 10 AM, Tuesday, July 28.

title: In Latest Tobacco Negotiations, States Lack Clear Health Goals
description: As a new round of tobacco settlement talks starts today in New York, state attorneys general are more in agreement about money than about specific public health goals.

description: That the American wrestlers beat the Russians yesterday to win the Goodwill Games gold medal was no surprise. But how they did it was: on the strength of the lighter wrestlers.

description: Putting the singer Regina Belle in a small club like the Blue Note is a bit like trying to fit a thunderstorm in a suburban living room; it doesn't really work.

title: Belmont Meet Ends With 'Saratoga' in Front
description: As racing fans sat on lawn chairs strategically placed underneath television monitors, and children played among picnic tables covered with coolers and programs, there was a definite Saratoga feel in the tree-shaded backyard at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: Circling Back To a Time Of Mystery And Wonder
description: While much of the rest of the world was savoring one of John Williams's latest film scores on Saturday evening, in Steven Spielberg's new drama, ''Saving Private Ryan,'' Mr. Williams and 8,000 or so listeners were attending to another, much more delicate of his new creations here at the Tanglewood Festival. Mr. Williams conducted the Boston Symphony Orchestra in the premiere of a lovely orchestral song cycle, ''Seven for Luck,'' with Cynthia Haymon as the soprano soloist.

title: Political Notebook; This Race, in Theory, Is No Longer Safe Bet
description: Six months ago it looked as if Paul Cellucci, who became Acting Governor of Massachusetts when Gov. William F. Weld was nominated for an ambassadorship, might win the job in his own right in this fall's election.

title: Paris Journal; The Mystery of Racism As a Tale for the Young
description: Tahar Ben Jelloun knew he was touching a delicate subject when he recently wrote a book on racism. But the Moroccan poet and novelist, who lives in Paris, never imagined how much his life would be changed by his latest work, a slim volume called ''Racism, as Explained to My Daughter.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, RALPH G.
description: NEWMAN-Ralph G. Age 86. An internationally recognized book dealer, author, and Lincoln scholar. Died July 23 at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. Mr. Newman was the former owner of a famous Chicago bookstore devoted to Lincoln which he ran in various locations for 62 years. He co-founded the Civil War Round Table, a discussion group of history lovers that now has more than 300 chapters around the world. He wrote or edited more than 20 books including Lincoln For The Ages and The American Illiad. Mr. Newman was Chairman of the Illinois Commission for the 1964-65 New York World's Fair, Chairman of the Illinois Sesquicentennial Commission, and President of the Chicago Public Library Board for more than ten years. He was the husband of Patricia; father of Maxine Brandenburg of Burlington, VT and Carol Parry Fox of New York City; stepfather of Scott Simon of Washington, DC; grandfather of Suzanne Brandenburg and Cynthia Brandenburg; greatgrandfather of Kurt Oleson, Maria Vespa, Sarah Vespa; former husband to Estelle Newman. Memorial service 2 PM, Sunday, August 2, at Chicago Cultural Center, 78 East Washington Street, Chicago. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to: Ralph G. Newman Chair, Lincoln College, 300 Keokuk Drive, Lincoln, Illinois 62656 or Civil War Round Table Chicago, 601 South LaSalle Building, Suite 81C, Chicago, Illinois 60605.

title: Editorial Observer; Cabbies, Passengers and a Collision of Interests
description: The bullet-proof partitions between the front and back seats of most medallion taxis appear to have done wonders for New York's cab drivers. Serious crime against them has plummeted from the 1993 high of 7 murders and 723 robberies.

description: Officials Are Now Vague On Reopening Times Sq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKINSON, ALEX
description: JACKINSON-Alex. The longtime head of the Alex Jackinson Literary Agency died on July 14, 1998, at age 93. He was also an author and poet. He is survived by his niece June Schnur and his nephew Murray Jacobson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, HERBERT
description: GREENBERG-Herbert. Of Great Neck, New York on Saturday, July 25, 1998. Beloved husband of Rosalie ''Mickey'' Brown; loving father of Edward ''Woody'', Betsy Feinberg (Robert), Amy Poster (Robert), and Susan Piper (Gordon); adored grandfather of Cara Feinberg, Guy Greenberg, and Joanna, Tracy and Michael Piper; devoted son of the late Charles and Jennie Greenberg; brother of Gladys Goldstein (Murray), the late Leo Greenberg, and the late Rose Rabbino; loving uncle and dear friend. Former Chairman and CEO of Charles Greenberg & Sons, Inc.; Captain in the U.S. Army during World War II; dedicated and active leader of many philanthropic and community organizations. Funeral will be held at Temple Beth El of Great Neck, NY on Monday, July 27 at 1:30 PM.

description: Cell phone junkies, beware. A wake-up call is coming from Gary Hustwit, the 33-year-old founder of Incommunicado Press, who wants ''to bring danger back into books.''

description: Steven T. Florio, the chief executive of Conde Nast, has had a troublesome month. Tina Brown, the popular editor of The New Yorker, resigned to start her own venture. And Fortune published a company profile with the theme: ''In Florio's hands, truth is a fungible commodity.''

description: Four tires or just two? That was pertinent question at today's Pennsylvania 500.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLARD, ROSALIND
description: GALLARD-Rosalind. Wife of the late F. Edmund Gallard. Mother of Don Gallard of Denver, CO; Lorraine Gallard of Bethesda, MD; and Ken Gallard of Taos, NM. Sister of Walter Abrams of Valley Stream, NY. Grandmother of Dewey Gallard and Solomon Kuckelman. Lifelong friend of Roz and Murray Martin. She will be remembered for her deep love of family, her strength, her intelligence, her elegance. Despite advancing illness, she continued to be a loving inspiration to her children. Graveside services at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ, on Monday, July 27, at 11 AM. Memorial contributions in her name may be made to Jewish Heritage for the Blind, Brooklyn, NY, or Alzheimer's Association. Date of passing, July 25, 1998.

title: Belichick Helps Build For Jets' Future and His
description: The man who figures to be the Jets' next head coach presided over his beloved defense today, his usual quiet demeanor punctuated occasionally by a high-pitched voice trying to fuse a mostly ordinary bunch into a group making extraordinary plays.

description: The Yankees are not going to trade Chuck Knoblauch for Baltimore's Roberto Alomar, but they at least considered the idea earlier this month, according to an American League executive.

description: Congress prepared today to pay tribute to two slain police officers with an honor usually reserved for former Presidents and heroes of grand military campaigns.

description: Who would want to visit a museum dedicated to the seemingly arcane topic of tort law?

description: Sportswear may be fashion's preference for fall, but for summer many women prefer the ease of a dress that bares the arms and neck.

title: Jurevicius Signs For $1.408 Million
description: ALBANY, July 27 -- Giants wide receiver Joe Jurevicius ended his three-day holdout today, reporting to training camp after signing a three-year contract worth $1.408 million, including a $516,000 signing bonus.

title: Asia Crisis Hurts Union Carbide Profit
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said today that its profit declined 37 percent in the second quarter as falling prices, weak Asian markets and the strong dollar outweighed lower raw-material costs.

title: Man Faces Charges In Fake Bomb Threat
description: A man who the police say forced the evacuation of 1,000 people from downtown Newark on Friday with a fake bomb was ordered held on $200,000 bail yesterday after pleading not guilty to all 11 charges against him.

title: When Medicine Goes Too Far in the Pursuit of Normality
description: I REALIZED recently that I suffer from a genetic condition. Although I have not actually had my genome screened, all the anatomical signs of Double-X Syndrome are there. And while I could probably handle the myriad physiological disorders associated with my condition -- bouts of pain and bleeding coming and going for decades, hair growth patterns that obviously differ from ''normal'' people's -- the social downsides associated with it are troubling.

title: Indonesia Agrees To Loan Guarantees
description: Indonesia and 21 domestic banks signed an agreement yesterday providing for Government guarantees on loans to exporters in an effort to kick-start the country's moribund economy. Finance Minister Bambang Subianto said the loans would be made at ''normal'' rates, but details of the plan, including how much would be lent, were not provided.

title: Mayor's Methadone Stance Risks Addicts' Health
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Is Asked to Rule On Candidate's 2d Race
description: State Attorney General Peter Verniero asked a Superior Court judge yesterday to decide whether a candidate for the House of Representatives who lost a primary in one district could run as an independent in another.

title: HARCOURT UNIT BUYING GARTNER TECHNOLOGY TRAINING UNIT
description: The Harcourt Brace unit of Harcourt General Inc. agreed to buy Gartner Group's information technology training unit and will merge it into its NETg operating unit. Harcourt said Gartner Group would receive an 8 percent equity interest in the combined entity, plus other considerations, though it did not disclose the purchase price. The combined company will have revenue of more than $100 million in the fiscal year 1999, Harcourt said. Gartner Group, in Stamford, Conn., is a management consulting firm. Harcourt General, of Chestnut Hill, Mass., is a multimedia publisher and service provider.

title: State Presses Inquiry Into Corruption In Broadway Ticket Sales
description: The New York State Attorney General's office is close to wrapping up an investigation of what officials say are rampant kickbacks and price-gouging practices involving the biggest theaters on Broadway and the most powerful entertainment and sports venues in the city, officials said yesterday.

title: Accounts
description: * Decibel Instruments Inc., Fremont, Calif., to Goldberg Moser O'Neill, San Francisco, to handle advertising for the maker of Intune Hearing Solutions hearing devices, which had been handled by Lois/EJL, New York, part of Lois/U.S.A. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $7 million.

title: China Moves to Untie the Knots Between Military and Industries
description: China's broad array of military-run and military-related enterprises are undergoing a deep transformation that is intended to yield a fighting force that is more professional, less distracted by nonmilitary business and, above all, better controlled by generals allied with President Jiang Zemin.

title: U.S. Sues to Block Citicorp-Gtech Deal
description: The Justice Department filed suit today against Citicorp and the Gtech Holdings Corporation seeking to block Citicorp's $11.5 million acquisition from Gtech of assets and contracts for electronically transferring benefits.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Little Rain Forest That Could
description: It's not often you get to walk through one of the world's greatest rain forests at treetop level. It's not everywhere you can look one of the rarest monkeys on earth, the golden-headed lion tamarin, in the eye as he jumps from tree to tree. It's not your average Sunday when you share a path with a caravan of leaf-cutter ants carting away chunks of leaves to their anthill the size of a pitcher's mound. It's not often you see termite nests as big as pumpkins, hanging from rubber trees dripping with natural latex. It is not every forest where a single hectare of land contains as many as 450 different tree species, all wrestling for sunlight.

title: Democrats Cast Wary Eye on One of Their Own
description: After an unbroken 22-year streak of Republican governors here in Illinois, some prominent Democrats are lamenting that Republican views will prevail yet again in this year's race -- even if the Democratic candidate wins.

title: Critics of Bus Rerouting Assail Transit Agency and Trump
description: A group of residents from the Upper West Side are objecting to a proposed change in a bus route that would extend service to a new luxury apartment complex being built by Donald J. Trump, and they contend that transit officials are willing to inconvenience them in order to appease him.

title: Lawsuit Is Reinstated In Worker's Death
description: The State Supreme Court reinstated a lawsuit yesterday against several oil and chemical companies filed by the widow of a Newark man who died of cancer after working 26 years for a defunct barrel-cleaning firm.

title: TENNIS: ROUNDUP
description: MERCEDES-BENZ CUP

title: Scientists Gain Access to the Navy's 'Deep Ears' on the Oceans
description: THE NAVY, after years of delay, has agreed to let civilian scientists routinely use its ''deep ears,'' which were built at a cost of $16 billion in the cold war to pinpoint the locations of enemy ships and submarines by tracking their machinery noises.

title: Board Expels Ron Carey From Teamsters for Life
description: A court-appointed review board expelled Ron Carey, the teamsters president, from the union yesterday, apparently ending the career of a labor leader who once seemed destined to clean up one of the nation's largest but most corrupt unions.

title: As Suspect Recovers, Congress Prepares to Honor Officers
description: With the nation preparing to pay extraordinary tribute on Tuesday in the Capitol's Great Rotunda to the two police officers killed on Friday in a House corridor shootout, the father of the man being held expressed his sorrow for his son's violent rampage.

title: A Taste for Flowers Helped Beetles Conquer the World; In Evolutionary Biology, Diet is Destiny
description: SWARMING the world in a dazzling array of shapes, colors and sizes from gargantuan Goliath beetles to jewel-like tortoise beetles to dearly familiar ladybugs, beetles, with more species than any other plant or animal group on earth, are the undeniable rulers of the planet.

title: Can President Be Prosecuted? No One Knows for Sure
description: By issuing a subpoena to President Clinton to testify before a grand jury that is investigating him for possible Federal crimes, Kenneth W. Starr has made urgent and concrete the theoretical question that has hovered at the margins of the independent counsel's four-year-old investigation: can a sitting President be subject to criminal prosecution?

title: Forecast: Cloudy
description: Q. When weather forecasters say there is a 50 percent chance of rain tomorrow, what does that mean? And how far ahead can a reliable forecast be made?

title: Spielberg's War
description: Gradually, each generation grows into the news its elders could not quite impart. But war is news that lies hidden even within the generation that experiences it. Men who have survived combat find that what they knew in that irretrievable now is something they will always know. But they can barely tell each other what it was. If nothing else, their silence is a kind of respect for the dead, whose understanding -- though it is a metaphor to call it that -- surpasses explanation.

title: Shell Projects in Malaysia
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said today that two Malaysian units would invest 12 billion ringgit ($2.8 billion) in oilfield and exploration projects over the next five years. Sarawak Shell and Sabah Shell Petroleum will spend 7.2 billion ringgit on oil exploration projects in Sarawak and Sabah and 4.8 billion ringgit on operating expenditures.

title: Stranded Pets Retrieved
description: After absorbing days of panicked pleas from pet owners and animal lovers, city officials managed yesterday to pluck a menagerie of beloved pets from apartments near the Conde Nast building.

title: Henri Ziegler, Aviation Figure, Is Dead at 91
description: Henri Ziegler, a trained pilot and commander of the Free French Air Force in World War II who helped start some of Europe's most ambitious postwar aviation projects, including the Concorde supersonic jetliner and the Airbus civilian airliner program, died at a nursing home in Paris on July 23. He was 91.

title: Peterborough Journal; In a New Museum, Canoes Glide Into Mythology
description: Like other men who have dipped paddles into dark, clear waters and felt the soulful satisfaction of gliding through perfect silence, John Jennings has been captivated by canoes. He has been that way since he was a boy, and he can think of few things better than to enter the northern wilderness with four weeks of supplies in a 16-foot canoe and simply disappear.

title: Discovery to Buy 50% Stake In CBS Eye on People Channel
description: CBS, citing ''significant losses,'' announced yesterday that it would cede management of the Eye on People cable channel to Discovery Communications, which will acquire a 50 percent interest in what will become a joint venture.

title: A Display of Color, Light, Life--and 'Rare Beauty'
description: The curators note that one day the photographs may be all that is left. But the ominous tone seems a stark contrast to the vivid display of color, light and life lining a dead-end hallway in the American Museum of Natural History. The 41 photographs of the exhibit, ''Rare Beauty: America's Endangered Plants,'' capture in brilliant natural light the species that Federal authorities believe are in danger of extinction, often because of habitat destruction, other man-made factors or disease. The United States Fish and Wildlife Service now lists 669 plants as endangered or threatened; Hawaii has 263 of those, the most in the nation. Scientists are concerned about vanishing plants because of their untapped potential for use in life-saving medicines, their breeding potential and their possibly unique genetic qualities like hardiness or disease resistance. The exhibit runs through Oct. 4.

title: For Yanks, Winning the Series Is the Only Thing
description: The Yankees have already won so many games with such numbing efficiency that two-game losing streaks qualify as mild surprises. It is not even August, but the Yankees address questions about competing in the post-season because the players realize it is silly to act as if they will not make it. That is what happens when a team has the chance to break a 92-year-old record for regular-season victories.

title: Bridge Victory Is a Squeaker
description: The Life Master Pair Championship ended here Sunday night in the second-closest finish in the 69-year history of the event. Playing at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, Geoff Hampson of Fenton, Mich., and Eric Greco of Annandale, Va., won the title over a father-and-son-combination by a margin of less than one match point after three days of play.

title: Keeping Enemy Missiles at Bay
description: As one of the nine members of the bipartisan commission that assessed the ballistic missile threat to the United States, I am alarmed that some have interpreted our findings as providing support for a new national missile defense system.

title: Cambodians Counting Votes Amid Measured Optimism
description: International observers voiced cautious optimism today over the conduct of Cambodia's parliamentary election as villagers and townspeople in 11,699 polling places painstakingly tallied Sunday's ballots.

title: To Our Readers
description: Because of computer problems, some pages that normally have color pictures are limited to black and white ones today.

title: A Fistful Of Hostility Is Found In Women
description: In the old Punch and Judy shows of the last century, Punch would batter Judy under the stage while the audience roared. But now it seems likely that in their private moments together Judy gave Punch back a bit of his own.

title: 2d Trial in Killing of Officer Ends With Acquittal
description: Vincent James Landano, who paid dearly for a crime he steadfastly denied committing for 22 years, won the battle of his life today when a jury here acquitted him in his second trial for the 1976 murder of a Newark police officer.

title: Telephone Mergers: A Heated Game of Musical Chairs
description: It would be a stretch to say that the Bell Atlantic Corporation and the GTE Corporation, two of the nation's biggest local phone companies, have agreed to a $52.8 billion merger out of fear. But not much of a stretch.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A big Nasdaq penalty in an old bugaboo: delayed trade reports.
description: CRACKING down on the Nasdaq stock market's old cheatin' ways has generated more than $1 billion in penalties from the well-known market maker Merrill Lynch to Charles Schwab & Company's market-making subsidiary, Mayer & Schweitzer. Yesterday, the collection plate went around again, with a million dollars or so more dropped into it.
