description: New York Shows in Flux

title: Malaysia Postpones $2 Billion Bond Sale
description: Malaysia said today that it had postponed an international sale of $2 billion in bonds because two credit-rating agencies lowered their assessment of the country last week.

description: Two directors of Copley Pharmaceutical Inc. have resigned.

title: Alone at the Top: Pantani Conquers the Alps
description: Climbing with startling power in heavy rain, Marco Pantani shook up the Tour de France today as he finished alone in the Alps and soared from fourth place over all into the leader's yellow jersey by nearly four minutes.

title: EXPLORING DEAL, LEWINSKY TALKS TO PROSECUTORS
description: Prosecutors met for five hours at an undisclosed place in midtown Manhattan today with Monica S. Lewinsky, the woman at the heart of the White House sex and perjury inquiry, in a possible prelude to an immunity deal.

title: Loss of 3,000 Mexican Steel Jobs Has an Asia Connection
description: Despite considerable nervousness about the impact of the Asian crisis on Mexico and other Latin American countries, until last week the main effects had been confined to the financial markets, with only limited repercussions for the broad economy.

title: Stocks Plunge, And Russia Moves to Sell Energy Stake
description: Russian stock prices plummeted again today, a clear indication that investors still doubt whether the Government can make good on a pledge to climb out of its seemingly bottomless hole of domestic and international debt.

title: Elaine Aiken, 71, Taught Acting and Founded Actors Conservatory
description: Elaine Aiken, a Method acting teacher, former member of the Actors Studio and a founder and director of Actors Conservatory in Manhattan, died on July 12 at her home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. She was 71.

title: Justice Dept. Refuses to Let Panel See 2 Memos
description: The Justice Department refused today to let a House committee see two internal memorandums in which the F.B.I. Director and another high-ranking official urged appointment of an independent counsel to investigate fund-raising abuses in President Clinton's re-election campaign.

title: Albright Rebukes Chinese On Arrest of Dissidents
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright protested to the Chinese Foreign Minister today over the arrest of several political dissidents since President Clinton's visit to China, a development that other Administration officials said had alarmed and embarrassed the United States.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Weekend on Friday with a film review of ''Billy's Hollywood Screen Kiss'' reversed the actors' names. Brad Rowe, who played Gabriel, appeared on the right, and Sean P. Hayes, who played Billy, on the left.

title: DRUG WHOLESALERS' STOCK SURGES ON COMMENTS BY JUDGE
description: Shares of the Amerisource Health Corporation and of the Bergen Brunswig Corporation surged to all-time highs as comments from a judge raised investor hopes that he would permit acquisitions of the two drug wholesalers. Amerisource, of Valley Forge, Pa., closed up $9.25, to $76.75, after reaching as high as $80.75. Bergen, based in Orange, Calif., rose $3.625, to $55.50, after touching $62.25. The Federal Trade Commission is challenging the purchase of Bergen by Cardinal Health Inc. and the acquisition of Amerisource by the McKesson Corporation. As closing arguments ended late Friday in Federal District Court in Washington, Judge Stanley Sporkin said he did not share the F.T.C.'s fears that the companies would raise prices and that other companies could not enter the $94 billion drug distribution market. A decision is expected this week.

title: For Kasparov's Challenger, Coming In Last Is a Fiasco
description: The Sparkassen International Tournament in Dortmund, Germany, June 26 to July 5, was the occasion of a glaring embarrassment for the Spanish grandmaster Alexei Shirov. The challenger for Garry Kasparov's world championship, Shirov finished last in a field of 10. The player he defeated handily in the candidates match that earned him the challenger's status, Vladimir Kramnik of Russia, took first place in Dortmund on tiebreak over Michael Adams of England and Peter Svidler of Russia.

title: Athena Awards To Be Revived
description: The Newspaper Association of America said that after a seven-year hiatus, it would revive the Athena Awards, honoring the most creative advertising in newspapers.

title: Judge Rules Clothing Maker Is Liable in Workers' Lawsuit
description: In a decision that lawyers for workers said could help end sweatshop conditions in the garment district, a Federal judge in Manhattan has ruled that an apparel maker may be held responsible for a contractor's failure to pay overtime to its employees.

title: Asians, Reliant on Japan, React Gloomily to Leadership Choice
description: Japanese voters are not the only people who reacted tepidly to the election of Keizo Obuchi as the leader of Japan's governing party. The choice of Mr. Obuchi has deflated many in the rest of Asia, who were hoping that a forceful new leader would step up to recharge Japan's weak economy and repair its faltering financial system.

title: A DEAL IS STRUCK FOR COLISEUM SITE
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is expected to approve the sale tomorrow of the New York Coliseum, one of the most treasured and star-crossed development sites in Manhattan, to Time Warner and the Related Companies for a hotel and residential complex that will also include a world headquarters and digital television studio for Time Warner.

title: The Mets Save Worst For N.L. Least Teams
description: Some people in baseball have this misguided notion about how some teams should beat other teams. A contending team, for example, should beat expansion teams, they believe. But the idea must be misguided because Bobby Valentine thinks it is.

title: Alfonzo Bothered By Lack Of Output
description: If there was one certainty about the Mets' offense this season, from the front office on down, it was that Edgardo Alfonzo was headed for stardom.

title: Onstage Magic With Water; 'Twelfth Night' Designer Creates a Wonder World
description: The setting for ''Twelfth Night'' is an Oriental fantasy of the mind. As far as the eye can see, there is a road winding through water. At the front of the Vivian Beaumont stage, actors are lolling sybaritically, surrounded by burning candles and incense. Nearby is a pool for swimming and dunking. Later in the play there will be a rainstorm. In Bob Crowley's enchanting scenic design for Nicholas Hytner's production, water is the central motif -- more than 10,000 gallons at every performance.

title: Going Out on a Beam With the Picture Guy
description: WHEN the scaffolding at 4 Times Square gave way last Tuesday, showering tons of orange-painted steel onto the streets below, Gerard J. Suarez had a view most people would envy, until they thought about it for a second.

title: HEALTH WATCH; Driven by Ego
description: Two psychologists who set out to explore the relationship between self-esteem and aggressive behavior have discovered the ties may be minimal. Narcissism is a better predictor of aggression.

title: Lewis Is Hopeful For Holyfield Bout
description: Lennox Lewis was in Manhattan yesterday to promote his World Boxing Council title fight with Zeljko Mavrovic in Connecticut on Sept. 26. But as has been the case since last December, Evander Holyfield was the main topic of conversation.

title: Must Guns Be Our No. 1 Right?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Battle of the Sexes, Sung and Danced to Bartok
description: Bela Bartok's ''Bluebeard's Castle'' is two characters in search of an opera. Bartok and his librettist, Bela Balazs, succeed in filling the inner lives of their characters, one the homicidal lord, the other the curious bride.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Negotiators in G.M. Strike Press On as Arbitration Nears
description: Negotiators, seeking to resolve strikes at two General Motors parts factories here, continued to put in long hours today, as union officials, in particular, had an incentive to settle before an arbitration ruling on the strikes' legality that could come as soon as Wednesday.

title: Clinton Subpoena Usurps Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: HICKS, MUSE UNITS IN $148 MILLION RADIO AND TV DEALS
description: Two deals worth $148 million and involving two affiliates of the buyout group Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst of Dallas were announced yesterday. The Chancellor Media Corporation, whose leading shareholder is Hicks, Muse, agreed to buy Puerto Rico's No. 1 radio broadcaster, the closely held Primedia Broadcast Group, for about $75 million. Chancellor, of Irving, Tex., said the deal would add eight FM stations to its group of 108. Chancellor said Primedia, which is expected to have $16.8 million in revenue this year, would immediately add to earnings. Chancellor seeks to attract more advertising dollars by controlling a larger chunk of the Latino market. Chancellor agreed this month to acquire 50 percent of Grupo Radio Centro S.A., Mexico's largest radio broadcaster, for $237 million. Chancellor shares fell $2 yesterday, to $51. In the second deal, a television broadcasting affiliate of Hicks, Muse, the Sunrise Television Corporation in St. Petersburg, Fla., agreed to buy WUPW-TV, the Fox Television network affiliate in Toledo, Ohio, for $73 million from Raycom Media Inc. After the acquisition, Sunrise will own and operate 14 television stations in 7 states.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALLIANCE DATA SYSTEMS, Dallas, a provider of account management and data base services to retailers, bought the privately held Loyalty Management Group Canada Inc., a data base services and marketing company, for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: A CONVERSATION: With Dr. Marvin Minsky; Why Isn't Artificial Intelligence More Like the Real Thing?
description: DR. MARVIN MINSKY, 71, a rumpled-looking man who wears shirts mended with masking tape, is Toshiba professor of media arts and sciences and professor of electrical engineering and computer sciences at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and one of the world's leading theorists of artificial intelligence. In the late 1950's, Dr. Minsky and John McCarthy, a professor of computer science at Stanford University, founded a research program that would evolve into the MIT Artificial Intelligence Laboratory. In addition to inventing and building thinking machines, Dr. Minsky wrote the classic ''The Society of Mind,'' (Simon & Schuster, 1986) in which he tries to show how intelligence works ''by the particular way the agents in the brain have evolved to interact.'' ''The Turing Option,'' (Warner Books, 1992) a novel by Dr. Minsky and Harry Harrison, is about superintelligence in not-too-far-off 2023.

title: GOLF: Raised To Be A Champion; Father's Firm Push Sent Pak To the Top of Women's Golf
description: In South Korea, golf is a game primarily for the wealthy, with annual membership in country clubs costing $200,000 to $1 million. Se Ri Pak's family was not on that level. Her background was considered middle class, and her father had a reputation of being in the Korean underworld.

title: Clinton Subpoena Usurps Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: Weston May Have Sought To Attack the White House
description: Federal law-enforcement officers are investigating whether Russell E. Weston Jr. first sought to attack the White House on Friday morning before shifting his focus to the Capitol, officials said today.

title: The Toronto-based Wolf Group acquires shop after shop in its quest to meet twin goals.
description: WHO is Larry Wolf, to paraphrase the title of a rather obscure Dustin Hoffman movie from 1971, and why is Madison Avenue saying all those things about him?

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There'll be the Pinto with the exploding gas tank, flammable pajamas, asbestos and breast implants, the whole history of medical malpractice, and of course the more recent toxic pollution, like Love Canal.''

title: Times Square Is Reopened to Traffic
description: Times Square was reopened to traffic at dawn yesterday, but optimism at the pace of work on the damaged scaffolding at the Conde Nast building gave way to renewed safety concerns in the afternoon when gusty winds apparently sent a 15-foot-long aluminum pipe falling more than 400 feet to the roof of a theater next door.

title: It's Slash-and-Burn Flamenco
description: Noche Flamenca has operated for five years on the timeless principle of fighting heat with heat. What better way to forget high summer temperatures than to be swept into the passion of Spanish dance and music? Intimacy and family feeling are other factors in the success of Noche Flamenca, which drew repeated standing ovations from its capacity audience on Saturday night at Theater 80.

title: New Analysis of Fossils May Muddy Accepted Path of Human Evolution
description: AN analysis of African fossils, including a few new specimens, has revealed a puzzling anatomical difference between two major species of the early human family, one from southern and the other from eastern Africa. The discoverers of the difference suggest that the evolution of the human body thus was more complicated than previously understood, possibly requiring some rearrangement of branches on the family tree.

title: Police Are Allowed to Test Evidence in Widow's Disappearance
description: Dismissing protests from defense lawyers, a judge granted law enforcement officials permission yesterday to perform tests on a .22-caliber pistol and other new evidence found last week in a gym bag belonging to the suspects in the disappearance of an Upper East Side widow.

title: Shooting Rattles Neighbors of a 'Nice Guy' on the Beat
description: The lights on Post Street went on like a wildfire spreading Sunday night, as word passed that Gerard Carter, an officer with the housing police on Staten Island, had been shot. Officer Carter has spent most of his 28 years on this street in Mariners Harbor, where he lives with his mother, Martha, and his 26-year-old brother, Keith, in a two-story house with a swimming pool.

title: FESTIVAL REVIEW/Music; Bach as Mountain Range
description: The idea was so preposterous that it hadn't even occurred: What do you do for an encore after playing virtually all the organ works of Bach? If you are Christopher Herrick (and not many other people would try such a thing), you play two pieces again, and two of the grandest.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: The Ice Mass Goeth?

title: Valderrama's Walkout Won't Go Unpunished
description: The league and the Miami Fusion will take action against Carlos Valderrama, one of the league's superstars, for walking out of practice last Friday when he learned that Miami had changed coaches. Valderrama, who is from Colombia, was unhappy with the team's decision to dismiss Carlos Cordoba of Argentina and hire the Brazilian Ivo Wortmann.

title: Marijuana and Stroke
description: THE medical use of marijuana is controversial for a simple, obvious reason: In addition to the benefits, like relief for cancer-related nausea, patients get high. But one marijuana ingredient may have significant therapeutic value without the psychoactive effect, according to a study by Government neuroscientists, among them a Nobel laureate.

title: Girls Are the Victims In Thai Sex Industry
description: One after another, the girls, looking even younger than they are despite the painted lips and cheeks, tell similar stories of being lured or coerced from their homes in Burmese hill towns to the cubicles of Thailand, where they were rented out as virgins two or three or more times before settling into the practiced prostitute's life.

title: Continental A.G. in $1.93 Billion Deal
description: Continental A.G., which makes Uniroyal and General tires, said today that it had agreed to buy ITT Industries' brake and chassis business for $1.93 billion.

title: The Return, Almost, of Times Square
description: The blare of traffic is back. Sidewalks along Broadway are full -- the usual mass of people buying, selling, gawking, pushing, all at different speeds and in different directions. A small ark of animals has been rescued from a building on 44th Street, including 12 cats, 2 illegal ferrets, several goldfish, one cockatiel, a guinea pig, a gerbil and a hamster. Except for those areas in the shadow of the Conde Nast building, where loose scaffolding caused part of an elevator tower to break away a week ago, crashing into a residential hotel and killing an elderly woman, Times Square is almost back to normal.

title: Mayor's Methadone Stance Risks Addicts' Health
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Ruling on Denial of Lawyer-Client Privilege
description: Following are excerpts from the decision today by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit on attorney-client privilege in the case of the independent counsel's subpoena of Bruce Lindsey, a deputy White House counsel, to testify before the grand jury investigating the case of Monica S. Lewinsky. The decision, which was redacted by the court, was not signed but was supported by Judges A. Raymond Randolph and Judith W. Rogers. Judge David S. Tatel dissented in the main part of the decision.

title: Of Canada, In Slow Motion But Not On Ice
description: Just how Canadian is the Tragically Hip? Well, the band started its set on Thursday night at Wetlands with ''Fireworks,'' in which the singer is astonished to meet a girl who couldn't care less about hockey. ''I never saw someone say that before,'' he marvels.

title: At American Express, Profit Rises by 11%
description: The American Express Company reported yesterday that second-quarter net income rose 11 percent as spending by card users rose, and investors bought record amounts of mutual funds.

title: Critic's Notebook; 19th-Century Novelists, Stop Spinning in Your Graves
description: With all due respect to Arthur Schlesinger Jr., A. S. Byatt, William Styron and the others who, acting at the behest of the Modern Library, produced a list of the 100 greatest English-language novels of the century, the truth is that the entire endeavor is so drenched in caprice as to be close to silly. You might be able scientifically to pick the 100 best-ever baseball players, because there would be a certain statistical basis to rely on. The same is not the case with works of the imagination. Still, the purpose of the exercise was to provoke discussion, always a good thing.

title: Clinton Is No Ordinary Witness
description: The power of Kenneth Starr, the independent counsel, to call President Clinton before a grand jury inevitably follows from two principles. The first is that we are a government of laws, not men. The second is that ''the public has a right to every man's evidence,'' as the Supreme Court wrote in 1974 when it turned back President Richard Nixon's effort to withhold the White House tapes.

title: For Whitman, A Setback On Gas Tax
description: Democrats in the Assembly announced today that they would not support Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's proposed gasoline tax increase. This prompted the Assembly Speaker, Jack Collins, to say that he would not put it up for a vote.

title: Must Guns Be Our No. 1 Right?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Mayor Pleads Guilty To Defrauding Clients
description: A former Mayor of Montville pleaded guilty yesterday to Federal charges that he defrauded his law clients of more than $500,000 in insurance settlements, the United States Attorney's office said.

title: Clinton May Use Wall Street To Ease Social Security Ills
description: President Clinton said today that he was seriously considering relying on the financial markets to help solve Social Security's long-term problems but said he had not made up his mind about any of the details.

title: Toll of U.N.'s Civilian Workers Overtakes the Military Deaths
description: An expert in famine relief with more than 25 years' experience in Africa was killed on Thursday in Burundi, the latest victim in series of violent deaths among United Nations officials.

title: Spirits Council Names Bozell
description: The Distilled Spirits Council of the United States in Washington, an association that represents liquor marketers like Brown-Forman and Seagram Americas, said yesterday that it had named Bozell Worldwide in New York as the first agency to handle its account.

title: Must Guns Be Our No. 1 Right?
description: To the Editor:

title: Schizophrenic Indicted in Fiancee's Death
description: A Yale Law School graduate whose struggle to overcome schizophrenia gained him national attention was indicted today by the Westchester County District Attorney's office in connection with the stabbing death of his pregnant fiancee in June in their apartment in Hastings-on-Hudson.

title: Both Parents Charged In Death of Girl, 5
description: The parents of a 5-year-old girl who was found dead in their Queens home on Sunday were arrested yesterday on charges of murder and endangering the welfare of a child, the police said.

title: Another Game, Another Gold for U.S.
description: In an intensely played match that saw five yellow cards and countless hard tackles, a pair of goals by forward Mia Hamm in the 66th and 87th minutes gave the United States a 2-0 victory over China tonight for the women's gold medal in soccer at the Goodwill Games.

title: Life Re Agrees To Be Bought By Swiss Re
description: Furthering a consolidation that has recently accelerated in the reinsurance industry, the Swiss Reinsurance Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Life Re Corporation for $95 a share, or about $1.8 billion, in cash.

title: Treatment Can Be Illusion for Violent Mentally Ill
description: Russell E. Weston Jr., the suspect in the fatal shootings of two police officers in the nation's Capitol, may have chosen an unusually public place to explode. But his history of mental illness has much in common with other delusional mentally ill people who become violent, illustrating both the cracks in the nation's mental-health system and its difficulty in compelling treatment, even for those at risk of becoming violent.

title: Must Guns Be Our No. 1 Right?
description: To the Editor:

title: Belden Associates To Media Advisors
description: Media Advisors International, a media research company in Dallas, said yesterday that it had acquired Belden Associates in Dallas, a newspaper research and strategy company, from the VNU/USA Marketing Information Services Inc. unit of VNU N.V. Terms were not disclosed.

title: TELEFONOS DE MEXICO TO BUY STAKE IN PRODIGY SERVICES
description: Telefonos de Mexico S.A., or Telmex, Mexico's largest telephone operator and largest Internet service provider, said it planned to buy a 20 percent stake in the Prodigy Services Corporation for $49 million to secure a presence in the United States Internet service provider market. The investment would be carried out by injecting new capital in Prodigy, the on-line service company, and by buying minority stakes from Prodigy's shareholders. Prodigy, controlled by Carso Global Telecom S.A. of Mexico, is the fourth-largest Internet service provider in the United States with 450,000 customers. Carso Global also owns a 15 percent stake in Telmex.

title: American Express Earnings Help Push Dow Past 9,000
description: An earnings report that was stronger than expected lifted stocks out of the doldrums yesterday as most major market indexes closed higher.

title: Let Children Ride Free
description: To the Editor:

title: What About a Bill of Rights for the Uninsured?
description: For the past two weeks, Republicans and Democrats have been touting their separate bills to overhaul managed care, while sniping at the other party's legislation. Last week, House Republicans passed their bill, which the White House said President Clinton would probably veto because it ''falls far short of insuring Americans the quality care they need and deserve.''

title: Still a Puny Military Force By the World's Standards
description: China's locomotivelike economic growth and its brittle public face have helped foment a perception overseas that it poses a growing military threat to its neighbors. In the next century, some experts have predicted, China could even clash militarily with the United States.

title: Serbs Advance in Kosovo, Imperiling Diplomatic Effort
description: Yugoslav Government forces continued their intensive attacks against separatist guerrillas across Kosovo Province today, officials said. The soldiers have retaken stretches of major roads that were held by the rebels, the officials added, and are beginning to confine the rebels to two areas of the province.

title: Alternate Excused From Brawley Case
description: For more than eight months, Dale Hollmen was forbidden to read a newspaper, listen to radio reports or speak to a single uninitiated soul about the central fact in her life -- the Tawana Brawley defamation case.

title: MERRILL LYNCH SELLS HSBC 4% OF BEZEQ FOR $102.5 MILLION
description: HSBC Investment Bank, an arm of HSBC Holdings P.L.C. of London, said yesterday that it had bought 4.15 percent of Bezeq Ltd., Israel's state-run telephone company, for $102.5 million from Merrill Lynch & Company. HSBC also sold Cable and Wireless P.L.C., the British telephone company, the right to buy the stake at $3.30 a share from Aug. 20, 1999, Cable and Wireless said. Cable and Wireless now owns 12.75 percent in the company. Merrill, which will cut its stake in Bezeq to 2.27 percent, bought 12.4 percent of Bezeq from Israel's Government for $250 million a year ago. At the time, Merrill said it intended to resell the stake to clients.

title: Floribunda! The Business Of Blooms Consolidates; A Mixed Bouquet of Acquisitions Has Built U.S.A. Floral Products
description: The scene at 5 A.M. in the Miami International Airport cargo area hasn't changed much over the years. Refrigerated trucks with logos of companies like Atlantic Bouquet, CFX (''The Cut Flower Experts'') and Continental Farms still rumble through the security gates, back up to the loading docks and fill their trailers with boxes of roses, lilies, chrysanthemums, baby's breath, bird of paradise and dozens of other kinds of flowers.

title: Attica's Ghost In the Shadow Of Pataki Veto
description: DAVID C. LEVEN did not wear a jacket to work yesterday, partly because it was hot and partly because, he figured, why bother when no clients would be showing up at his office near City Hall. It has been very slow lately at Prisoners' Legal Services, where he is executive director.

title: Metro Business; Company Is Accused Of an Ad Monopoly
description: Transit Displays Inc., which sells much of the advertising space on billboards, telephone kiosks, buses and trains throughout New York City, has been sued by a small public relations and advertising company that accuses it of monopolizing the market for transit ads.

title: TWO PHONE GIANTS REPORTED MERGING IN $52 BILLION DEAL
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation, which dominates the local telephone business from Maine to Virginia, has agreed to acquire the GTE Corporation, the nation's largest independent local and long-distance company, for $52.8 billion in stock, executives close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Wondrin' What's Behind Those Great Melodies
description: RICHARD RODGERS

title: Style Aside, Cheap PC May Fit Best
description: FOR all the attention paid to sizzling microprocessors speeds, dazzling multimedia technologies and snazzy styling, the z's that are most common in personal computers today are the ones that occur while the computer is waiting for something to do.

title: BRANDYWINE TO BUY AXINN PROPERTIES FOR $103.5 MILLION
description: Brandywine Realty Trust said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the privately held Donald E. Axinn Companies for $103.5 million. Brandywine, which is based in Newtown Square, Pa., owns 179 commercial and industrial properties in the mid-Atlantic region with 12 million square feet of rentable space. Axinn, in Jericho, N.Y., owns 29 office and industrial properties in northern New Jersey and Long Island with 1.3 million square feet of rentable space.

title: Rising Stress of Raising a Grandchild
description: HAVING grandchildren is supposed to be a storybook experience: snapshots of laughter and hugs, the license to indulge the little ones with gifts and extra helpings of dessert before returning them to Mom and Dad. But for growing numbers of grandparents, joyful dates with the grandchildren have been replaced by the responsibility of full-time child care. And doctors and other health care professionals are just now beginning to see that the demands are taking a toll on many grandparents' health.

title: INSIDE
description: Times Square Reopens

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: WHEAT AT 7-YEAR LOW. Wheat fell 1.8 percent after Egypt bought 250,000 tons from France, raising speculation that U.S. offers had been spurned. The July contract fell 4.75 cents a bushel, to $2.605, the lowest since July 1991.

title: Yet Another Reason to Fight the Fat
description: DO you know your triglyceride level? New evidence strongly suggests that it is time to add triglycerides to the substances in the blood that influence your chances of developing heart disease.

title: This Frazier Show Is Not Must-See TV
description: Walt Frazier thesaurizes so pestiferously on Knicks radio games that Peter Roget must wail lachrymosely in lexicography heaven. Evidently, no producer has forcefully persuaded Frazier that his silly wordplay hurts his credibility and overwhelms the insight that his partisans say he possesses.

title: Group Wants Pesticide Companies to End Testing on Humans
description: Pesticide companies have conducted tests on humans and told the Government that they expect to do more, saying the tests may provide more reliable data than animal tests and might justify less stringent rules on pesticides.

title: SEALED AIR TO CUT 750 JOBS AND TAKE $112 MILLION CHARGE
description: The Sealed Air Corporation said it expected to eliminate 750 jobs, reducing its work force to about 13,750, in a reorganization related to its $4.9 billion purchase of the Cryovac operations of W. R. Grace & Company in March. It also said it would take a third-quarter charge of $112 million to $122 million and post a separate charge of $23 million related to earnings of units not considered permanently invested in its business. Sealed Air, which is based in Saddle Brook, N.J., makes specialty and protective packaging material such as bubble cushioning and absorbent meat pads. Its shares rose $3.0625, to $39.9375.

title: Justice in Cambodia
description: To the Editor:

title: Sweepstakes Pit Gullibility and Fine Print
description: Optimistically, Dorothy Edouart recites her mantra. ''I haven't won yet, but I've got the letters saying I won and I'll be getting my winnings very soon,'' she says outside the airy dining room of the retirement center where she lives. ''All I have to do is send in my entries and my checks.''

title: Wilkinson Leading the U.S. Toward a Diving Comeback
description: Until the 1980's, the world's best divers usually came from the United States and its college and club systems. Then the Chinese discovered and developed the sport, the Russians made a resurgence, the great American champion Greg Louganis retired and American diving struggled.

title: U.S. Sprinter and Shot-Putter Accused of Drug Use
description: Another drug scandal rocked international sports yesterday when track and field's world governing body announced that two of America's top athletes, the sprinter Dennis Mitchell and the 1996 Olympic shot-put champion Randy Barnes, had been suspended for possible doping offenses.

title: Sanyo Buys Access to Technology From I.B.M.
description: The Sanyo Electric Company, struggling to emerge from the shadows cast by bigger competitors like Sony and Matsushita, has bought access to some of the most advanced semiconductor technology to use in its consumer electronics.

title: Candidates Are Attacked Over Tobacco Money
description: G. Oliver Koppell, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for state attorney general, attacked two of his rivals yesterday for accepting campaign contributions from members of the Tisch family, which controls the Lorillard Tobacco Company.

title: Hip-Hop With a Message Instead of Just a Boast
description: The third annual Smokin' Grooves tour, which came to the PNC Bank Arts Center here tonight, might as well have been called the Hip-Hop Holdouts tour. It assembled groups that insist, against the commercial tide, that hip-hop isn't exclusively about ''playas'' who brag about their wealth, their women, their brand-name possessions and their unsavory pasts while borrowing the melodies of pop hits.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: TYSON FOODS TO TAKE $200 MILLION CHARGE TO CUT COSTS
description: Tyson Foods Inc., the world's largest poultry company, said it would take a pretax charge of about $200 million in its fiscal fourth quarter to cover the expense of a cost-cutting plan that could include closing plants, laying off workers or selling businesses. Tyson also said third-quarter earnings beat analysts' forecasts by a penny, rising 3.1 percent, to $46.6 million, or 20 cents a diluted share, from $45.2 million, or 21 cents, in the similar period a year earlier. Revenue rose 23 percent, to $1.95 billion from $1.59 billion. Shares of Tyson, which is based in Springdale, Ark., slipped 6.25 cents, to $22.5625.

title: Green Denounces D'Amato As Being an 'Opportunist'
description: Mark Green, a Democratic candidate for the Senate, attacked Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato yesterday as an ''election-year opportunist and a shakedown artist,'' delivering the kind of blistering assault on Mr. D'Amato's ethics that Mr. Green said his Democratic opponents were unwilling to make.

title: Lure of High Speeds Makes Races a Threat to Fans, Too
description: Experiencing the speed of race cars up close is, without a doubt, what attracts fans to the track. But that is just the problem.

title: Suspect Arrested After Armed Standoff in Officer's Shooting
description: A 17-year-old ex-convict accused of shooting a police officer was captured during an armed standoff on Staten Island yesterday morning, and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani seized on the suspect's criminal record as yet another example of why the state's parole system needs to be overhauled.

title: No Answer in Past To Urgent Question
description: As the independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, pushes to have President Clinton testify before a Federal grand jury investigating him for possible crimes, this question is becoming urgent: can a sitting President be subject to criminal prosecution?

title: Keeping the Capitol Safe
description: When tragedy strikes, it is natural for people to ask themselves if there was any way it could have been averted. That is even more true when the awful event takes place at a site as familiar and freighted with symbolic import as the Capitol in Washington. Since a gunman opened fire there last week, members of Congress have offered suggestions for improving security that range from requiring guards to wear bulletproof vests to building an underground entrance where the public could be screened for weapons. Fencing off the Capitol grounds is another frequently mentioned option.

title: Sharpton Lawyer Asks Leniency as Jury Weighs Damages
description: Fighting back tears as he delivered his closing statement today, the lawyer for the Rev. Al Sharpton pleaded with the jurors in the Tawana Brawley defamation case not to punish Mr. Sharpton with a large damage award, which he compared to a financial death sentence.

title: Tal Farlow, 77, Jazz Guitarist Rooted in Bop
description: Tal Farlow, one of jazz's best-known guitarists, died on Saturday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 77 and lived in Sea Bright, N.J., and Manhattan.

title: Mayor's Methadone Stance Risks Addicts' Health
description: To the Editor:

title: Hallucinations About Iraq
description: Awash with money from Congress for covertly promoting Iraqi opposition to Saddam Hussein, the Clinton Administration is once again dreaming about engineering his ouster. The only problem is that no one in Washington has figured out how to do so. Instead the Administration is preparing to renew its courtship with Massoud Barzani, a Kurdish factional leader who betrayed Washington and other opposition groups by forming a temporary military alliance with Baghdad in 1996.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sunday about a subpoena issued to President Clinton misstated the source and the nature of a subpoena to President Thomas Jefferson in the treason trial of Aaron Burr in 1807. The subpoena was ordered by Chief Justice John Marshall, sitting as a Federal trial court judge in Richmond in the Burr trial, not by a Congressional committee. The subpoena was for documents, not for the President's personal appearance.

title: Guardians on the Streets of Despair; New Jersey Task Force Focuses on Crimes Against Prostitutes
description: The woman known as Soft Touch stood barefoot on the sidewalk by her house in the Central Ward and watched the customized van glide gently to the curb. At 9 o'clock on a Friday night, it could mean only one thing -- another ''date.''

title: Suddenly, Lewinsky Is Dealing
description: Since January, the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr has insisted that prosecutors would not grant immunity to Monica S. Lewinsky unless they first met with her and judged her credibility for themselves. ''There is no substitute for looking a witness in the eye,'' Mr. Starr has said. .

title: Soldini Wins In Record Time
description: Giovanni Soldini, the Italian long-distance sailor who lost a friend at sea four months ago, sailed to victory yesterday in the Atlantic Alone, a 3,700-mile race from England to Charleston, S.C. Soldini's time of 21 days 17 hours surpassed by seven days a pace set four years ago by Yves Parlier of France in the same race.

title: Clinton Subpoena Usurps Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: Nuclear Suspicions Cling To Iraq in Latest Report
description: Seven years after Iraq pledged to dismantle its nuclear weapons program, international inspectors still suspect that it may be hiding the documents, equipment and material needed to make an atomic weapon.

title: Patience Pays Off as Pair Join Rush to Consolidate
description: Ivan G. Seidenberg, the chief executive of the Bell Atlantic Corporation, may be the most patient executive in corporate America.

title: Sports of The Times; A Pioneer In Her Sport And Beyond
description: THE choice was reaching people or saving lives. Julie Foudy decided there is too big a world out there to confine herself to a single residency. She junked medical school, choosing the life of an explorer over one as a healer.

title: Parole System On Defensive In Legislature
description: New York's parole system has long been viewed as a powerful tool for both encouraging good behavior in prison and reintroducing inmates into society once they are deemed rehabilitated.

title: Marking Time for the Millennium
description: Here's an idea from a couture house this season: at the dawning of the new millennium, we'll either be partying (thus wearing tinsels, pompoms, streamers and confetti) or be victims of mass destruction (thus wearing clothes shaped by the atom bomb). There are two clues that the concept isn't from a top couturier, but from an upstart house, Viktor & Rolf. The first clue is that its difficult to imagine Nan Kempner and Anne Bass in mushroom-shaped togs. But the second is that it's an idea. And ideas are something that top couturiers are seemingly waiting until the millennium to share.

title: Greens Hope for Place in the Sun When Germans Vote
description: When Germans choose a Prime Minister in September, Joschka Fischer will not be even close to winning the job. But that does not mean he'll be unhappy.

title: TV Ads Nominated For Emmy Awards
description: Five commercials have been nominated for 1997 Emmy Awards by the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences. The winner will be announced in September.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: ROUNDUP
description: Cuban Cyclist Is Reported Missing

title: Second Lodi Officer Arrested in Inquiry
description: The Bergen County Prosecutor yesterday announced that a second Lodi police officer had been arrested in an investigation of the department that began on July 16.

title: Pentagon to Tighten Army's Fraternizing Ban
description: The Department of Defense plans to order the Army to adopt strict new prohibitions on dating, sexual intimacy and other close relationships between officers and enlisted personnel, officials say.

title: Jets-Packers Connection Helps Out Both Teams
description: They winter a few houses apart in Florida, but today Ron Wolf and Bill Parcells stood a few feet apart and appraised the Jets on the practice field.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Mice Say 'Cheese,' Find Nest in Jersey

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Sunday about a German politician's comments on a project to build a memorial to the Holocaust in Berlin misspelled the surname of an American finalist in a competition to design it. He is Peter Eisenman, not Eisenmann.

title: Sehorn and Barber Touting Skills for Returning Kicks
description: It was a simple kickoff return, one of many practiced last weekend at the Giants' training camp, but it stirred the attending fans like nothing else to date at this year's workouts.

title: Whose Rights are Right?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, RUTH

title: Bill Clinton's 29 Months
description: The White House spin that Kenneth Starr is a combination of Javert and Clouseau played well on ''Meet the Press,'' but in the end it probably harmed President Clinton by lulling him. Mr. Starr, with his tacky polo shirts and low poll ratings, spent the first dreamy days of summer stumbling through a series of legal reverses. And because the independent counsel seemed such a klutz, Mr. Clinton spent those days -- well, dreaming. His attention turned to the Hamptons rather than to the huge task of repairing the reputation of his Presidency.

title: A Veto That Buoyed the Bureaucrats
description: There was a time in America when the education of a child was a family responsibility. Communities rushed to the polls to elect a school board; parents came after school; grandparents helped with homework and chaperoned school trips. Somehow through the years, it was decided that education was now the province of bureaucrats and of everyone but parents, families and communities.

title: When a Nice Guy Holds Someone Hostage
description: In a twist on the Hitchcockian maxim, ''The Negotiator'' places two extraordinary actors, Samuel L. Jackson and Kevin Spacey, in the midst of surprisingly ordinary circumstances. And considering how well-known they are for delivering wildly colorful dialogue with deadpan panache, it is no less unexpected to find them cast as blandly nice guys. Though the film has its basis in an actual event that took place in St. Louis, it takes on the homogeneous look of many other thrillers in which an emergency escalates into a paramilitary operation. Lots of close-ups, exaggeratedly tense moments and blue-lighted nighttime scenes guarantee that ''The Negotiator'' will be right at home on video some day.

title: ROPER INDUSTRIES TO PAY $125 MILLION FOR LEACH HOLDING
description: Roper Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the privately held Leach Holding Corporation for $125 million in stock, plus $10 million in assumed debt. Leach Holding operates one business that supplies power management controls and components, and a second business that makes instrumentation for medical diagnostics and other analytical markets. It had revenue of $144 million in the year ended March 31. Roper, based in Bogart, Ga., manufactures fluid handling, industrial control and analytical instrumentation products. It had revenue of $186 million in the six months ended April 30.

description: Glenn Foley's eyes grew wide when he imagined how the Jets' offense would perform this season.

title: QUESTAR TO PAY $157.5 MILLION FOR ITS RIVAL'S BUSINESS
description: HS Resources Inc., the oil and natural gas explorer based in San Francisco, agreed yesterday to sell its HSRTW Inc. unit for $157.5 million in cash to the rival Questar Corporation to reduce bank debt and focus its exploration efforts on the Rocky Mountains and Gulf Coast. The subsidiary has stakes in properties in Arkansas, Louisiana, Oklahoma and Texas with reserves totaling about 200 billion cubic feet of natural-gas equivalent. This represents about 17 percent of HS Resources' total reserves. The Salt Lake City-based Questar, with $1.9 billion in assets, will roll HSRTW into its Universal Resources unit.

title: Whitney Museum Appoints A Director

Mr. Anderson, who has spent three years in that post, succeeds David A. Ross, who resigned in March to become director of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art.

description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation agreed today to pay the Defense Department up to $75 million if failures continue in tests of an antimissile system, Lockheed and the Government said.

title: NETWORK ASSOCIATES IN CASH DEAL FOR SOFTWARE MAKER
description: Network Associates Inc., a top antivirus and security-software maker, agreed yesterday to buy Cybermedia Inc. for $130.2 million in cash to add programs that monitor computer crashes and fix outdated software. Network Associates, based in Santa Clara, Calif., will offer $9.50 for each of Cybermedia's 13.7 million outstanding shares. Cybermedia closed up $1.6563 at $9.2188, while Network Associates fell $1.0625, to $48.875. Cybermedia has about 270 employees worldwide. It reported a second-quarter net loss of $11.9 million, compared with a net loss of $6.7 million in the corresponding period a year earlier.

title: Supreme Court Denies Sex Shops' Plea to Halt New York Law
description: The United States Supreme Court rejected a last-ditch effort yesterday by a coalition of sex shops that had sought to block New York City from enforcing a new zoning law against X-rated businesses.

title: Journal; This Way Lies Madness
description: The Capitol police officers Jacob Chestnut and John Gibson had hardly been declared dead when Senator Robert Torricelli, the New Jersey Democrat, sent out a press release arguing that tighter gun control could have prevented the tragedy. Not missing a beat, Trent Lott was soon arguing that a $125 million bunker-barricade camouflaged as a visitors' center would repel future assailants. But in a city where most politicians are so ignorant about mental illness that they still think Whitewater, not the disease of depression, drove Vincent Foster to suicide, no one said the obvious: It is the gaping cracks in American mental-health care, not in Capitol security or gun-control laws, that most clearly delivered Russell Weston Jr. to his rendezvous with history.

title: Business Travel; Business Air Fares Are Holding Steady
description: Don't look now, but typical business air fares finally appear to be holding steady. The reasons why are a matter of some dispute. But after having to contend with steadily rising fares from 1995 through 1997, as the airline industry struggled to return to financial health after its $14 billion hemorrhage in the first half of the decade, business travelers are likely to welcome any leveling off, whatever the reasons.

title: DQE DROPS OUT OF ALLEGHENY ENERGY'S PROPOSED BUYOUT
description: DQE Inc. said yesterday that it would not go through with plans for a buyout by Allegheny Energy Inc. because of conditions imposed on the buyout by Pennsylvania regulators. Allegheny said in April 1997 that it would buy DQE for $2.5 billion in stock and $1.7 billion in assumed debt. In a statement yesterday, DQE said that the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission's April 30 ruling on the buyout did not let Allegheny refinance enough debt after the state deregulates its electricity market over the next few years. Without refinancing more, DQE said, Allegheny will not be able to compete in a deregulated market. Shares of DQE rose 56.25 cents, to $36, while Allegheny slipped $62.5 cents, to $27.6875.

title: Corrections

It is not the construction manager; that position is held by Tishman Construction Corporation, an operating unit of Tishman Realty and Construction.

title: In Connecticut, the Check Is in the Mailbox, and Many Are Blase

As he delivered to homes in this blue-collar city, a few people went to their mailboxes to see how much money they were getting back in the first tax rebate ever offered by the State of Connecticut. And although some were excited, others were not exactly rushing to the bank.

title: THE FINE PRINT: A close look at consumer regulation; Last-Minute Amendment Seeks to Delay Rules on Combustible Upholstered Furniture
description: For nearly four years, the Federal Government's top consumer agency has been working to fashion regulations to make upholstered furniture more fire resistant. The agency, the Consumer Product Safety Commission, acted after a group of fire marshals filed a petition in 1994 that said fires from upholstered furniture accounted for hundreds of household fire deaths in the nation each year, many of them children.

title: EASYJET TO BUY UP TO 30 BOEING PLANES WORTH $1.2 BILLION
description: The Easyjet Airline Company said yesterday that it would buy as many as 30 Boeing Company planes worth $1.2 billion, potentially doubling its fleet as the British no-frills carrier seeks to beat rivals into Europe's low-fare market. The carrier, based at Luton Airport north of London, will buy 15 737-700's and take options for another 15. With seven planes in its all-Boeing fleet and 12 more ordered last year, Easyjet will have 49 if all options are used. Deliveries are set to begin in October 2000 and continue through February 2003. Easyjet's rapid expansion comes after British Airways started its own low-cost carrier, Go.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNDERHILL, CELESTE H.
description: UNDERHILL-Celeste H. At the age of 98 at San Simeon by the Sound in Greenport, New York on July 26. A 65-year resident of Shelter Island Heights, New York, she was born in New York City on April 14, 1900 and was a graduate of Erasmus Hall. A descendant of Benjamin Mendez Seixas, a lieutenant in the New York Militia, she was inducted into the Fort Greene chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution in 1925. After marrying Marvin Shiebler in 1929 and moving to Shelter Island in 1930, she organized & became a charter member of the Shelter Island chapter of the D.A.R., serving as Regent for many years. After the death of Mr. Shiebler in 1944, she took over his real estate and insurance business, running it alone and sucessfully for almost four decades. For over 40 years she served the Suffolk County Taxpayers Association in various capacities. An active parishioner of Our Lady of the Isle Roman Catholic Church, she also supported St. Gabriel's Monastery. She was an enthusiastic supporter and Honorary Member of the Shelter Island Heights Volunteer Fire Department and a lifetime member of the Shelter Island Historical Society, instrumental in restoring five rooms of its landmark headquarters, the Havens House, and serving on the Board of Directors for many years. In 1945, she married Henry Underhill, who died in 1969. Her son, Andrew Shiebler, was born in 1938 and died in 1971. She is mourned by her nephew Edward Furey, her grand nephew Edward Furey, Jr. & his wife Jane, her great grand-niece Elizabeth Furey & her many friends on Shelter Island. Reposing at DeFreist's Funeral Home on Shelter Island, Wednesday 7-9 P.M. Mass at Our Lady of the Isle 10 A.M. Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAIRD, ROBERT B.
description: BAIRD-Robert B. II of Quogue, N.Y., passed away on Wednesday, July 22, while on vacation in Spain. He was born on January 1,1923 in Brooklyn, N.Y. and grew up in both Brooklyn and Quogue. His wife, Barbara Arnold Baird, survives him. He is also survived by 15 children, Margaret M. Baird, Barbara B. Zeman, Camille R. Baird, Robert L. Baird, Esther S. Baird, Mary E. Baird, Belinda B. Fremont, Cynthia Baird Goode, William T. Baird, David T. Baird, Catherine Bennett, Andrew H. Baird, Dr. Susan Arnold, Margaret Arnold and James Arnold. He also leaves behind 20 grandchildren and one great-grandchild. He is predeceased by his first wife, Esther S. Baird. Mr. Baird was owner and C.E.O. of Polyesther Corporation, which imports and exports specialty chemicals for the cosmetics industry, and Robert B. Baird Division, which imports crude rubber. Mr. Baird was a graduate of Polytechnic Preparatory Country Day School in Brooklyn where he enjoyed an illustrious wrestling and track career, winning three national championships, which he carried on to Lehigh University winning medals and trophies in virtually every sport he participated in. During W.W.II he served in the U.S. Army Air Corps. Mr. Baird was a member of The Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, the Quogue Field Club, Quogue Beach Club, the Shinnecock Yacht Club, Westhampton Yacht Squadron, the New York Yacht Club, the Princeton Club, India House, the Southampton Club, the V.F.W. in Quogue and the Circumnavigators Club. Mr. Baird was also very active in the community. He was a founder of the South Street Seaport Museum. He served on the Board of Directors of Good Samaritan Hospital in West Islip, Southampton Hospital and Central Suffolk Hospital in Riverhead and is a former Director of the Suffolk County Red Cross. He served on the Planning Board of the Village of Quogue, was a Village Trustee for 11 years and had terms as Quogue Fire Commissioner and Acting Police Commissioner. He was also instrumental in the establishment of the Quogue Wildlife Refuge Nature Center as well as being Director of the Southampton Wildfowl Association. Some of his other activities include serving on the Board of Directors at the Lincoln Savings Bank, serving on the Board of Directors of several schools, and being assistant director of the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton. A memorial service will be held at Saint Mark's Church in Westhampton Beach, New York, at 11 A.M. on Friday, July 31, with a reception afterwards at the Quogue Field Club. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Polytechnic Prep School, 92nd Street and 7th Ave., Brooklyn, N.Y. 11228 or to the Southampton Township Wildfowl Association, Box 492, Quogue, New York 11959.

title: CISCO SYSTEMS IS IN $116 MILLION DEAL FOR SUMMA FOUR
description: Cisco Systems Inc., the No. 1 maker of equipment that links computers, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Summa Four Inc., a maker of switches used to direct telephone calls, for about $116 million in stock. Cisco will exchange 0.179 share for each Summa Four share, valuing Summa Four at $17.36. Summa Four closed at $16.375, up $3, while Cisco, which is based in San Jose, Calif., fell $1.50, to $96. The purchase of Summa Four, based in Manchester, N.H., would give Cisco another product to offer in its battle with the phone-equipment makers Lucent Technologies Inc. and Northern Telecom Ltd. for sales to telephone carriers. Cisco said it expected to take a charge of 4 cents to 9 cents a share in the first half of fiscal 1999 to pay for the purchase.

Canadian Natural is one of the country's biggest oil and gas producers. The site it will acquire is Remington's Buick Creek natural gas property.

title: George Orwell's List

The British were reminded last month just how engaged he was, when excerpts from his diaries were published there. Though Orwell's disputes with fellow leftists were legendary, there was some surprise at new evidence that the creator of Big Brother had informed for the British Government in the late 1940's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LATSEY, VAN PETER
description: LATSEY-Van Peter. A prominent gynecologist/obstetrician passed away on July 28, 1998. Dr. Latsey graduated from Medical School at the University of Athens and trained at Boston City Hospital and St. Luke's Hospital in New York City. He remained on staff at St. Luke's and served as Chief of the Clinic at Women's Hospital, until his retirement in 1980. He was a member of the teaching staff of Columbia University Medical School, Diplomate of the Obstetrics and Gynecology Board, and Member of the Medical Society of New York State. Dr. Latsey was a respected and active member of the Greek community and the Greek Orthodox Church, having the title Archon Aktouarios conferred upon him in 1979 by His Eminence Archbishop Iakovos. He served as Vice President of St. Michael's Home for the Aged, Member of the Board of Trustees of the Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, and Member of the Order of Orthodox Crusaders of the All-Holy Tomb of Christ. He is remembered as a loving husband, a kind gentleman, and a mentor and generous friend to many. His wife, Angelika, and nephews and nieces, in Athens, Washington, Boston and New York survive him. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 81st and Madison Ave., New York on July 30th from 6PM-9PM. Funeral services will be held at the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74th Street, New York City, on July 31st at 10AM. Interment Pinelawn Memorial Park. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. Michael's Home for the Aged, 3 Lehman Terrace, Yonkers, NY 10705, in memory of Dr. Latsey, will be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RATTNER, GABRIEL (GEORGE)
description: RATTNER - Gabriel (George). Passed away peacefully July 26, 1998 at age 76 after a courageous struggle with ALS. Before contracting the disease in 1998, he jogged, skied and played the piano and led an active life with his loved ones. He brought energy and discipline to everything he did. He reached out to help others all through his life. His wisdom, vision and concern touched many people. He worked for over 50 years in the steel distribution industry & founded Dover Tubular Alloys, Inc., where he continued to work until shortly before his death. He was predeceased by his loving wife of 50 years, Hilda, and his daughter Sandy. He is survived by his children, Mark of Morristown, NJ, Joe of Ridgewood, NJ and Cheryl Rattner-Price of San Diego, California, and their respective spouses, Lenore, Amy & Michael Price. Also surviving are son-inlaw Robert Pelican (husband to Sandy) and grandchildren Jamie, David, Justin, Ellen, Eric & Emily. Services were held at GuttermanMusicant, corner Passaic and Park Streets, Hackensack, New Jersey. Contributions to Eleanor and Lou Gehrig ALS/MDA Research Center Neurological Institute, C/O Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, N.Y.C. He is jogging again.

Shares of Compdent rose $3.25, or 24 percent, to $16.75. The Atlanta-based company said shareholders would be offered $18 a share in cash but that an undisclosed number of shares held by management would be exempt. Based on the total number of shares outstanding as of April 30, the acquisition could be worth as much as $182 million before the company's long-term debt is refinanced. The acquiring investment group includes TA Associates Inc., NMS Capital Partners and Golder, Thoma, Cressey, Rauner Inc.

description: MORSE-Howard R. Beloved brother of Marjorie Stolzar. Loving uncle of Peter and Joanna, Michael and Karen, and Andrew and Joan. Beloved great uncle of Sam, David, Matt, Lauren and Scott. Special friend of Monte Morgan. Services Friday, 11:15 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', corner of 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Plaintiff Is Awarded $345,000 In Brawley Defamation Case
description: After an acrimonious eight-month trial that revived the racially divisive Tawana Brawley case, Steven A. Pagones was awarded $345,000 in damages today by a Dutchess County jury that had found that the Rev. Al Sharpton and two other men had defamed the white former prosecutor by accusing him of abducting and raping the black teen-ager.

title: DOBSON COMMUNICATIONS AGREES TO BUY SYGNET WIRELESS
description: The Dobson Communications Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Sygnet Wireless Inc., a closely held provider of wireless services, for $337.5 million in cash, or $34.41 a share, and to assume $310 million in debt. Dobson, which is based in Oklahoma City, offers a range of phone services and is also closely held. Sygnet, of Canfield, Ohio, provides cellular services under the Cellular One and Wilcom Cellular brands in areas of Ohio, Pennsylvania and New York. After the acquisition, Dobson will have 258,000 subscribers in 10 states.

title: Inquiry Inflicts Lasting Damage on Presidency; Contrite Felons?
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I have come here today, not in anger or to anger, though my mere presence has been sufficient, obviously, to anger some. Nor have I come to defend my views, but rather to assert my right to think for myself, to refuse to have my ideas assigned to me as though I was an intellectual slave because I'm black.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, BELLE LASDAY.
description: COHEN-Belle Lasday. Of Pittsburgh died on July 28th at age 94; beloved wife of the late Ithiel A. Cohen; devoted mother of Maxine Cohen Davidoff and son-in-law Richard Davidoff of New York City & Mark I. Cohen & daughterin-law Nilda Cohen of Southampton, MA; loving sister of Gertrude Ratner of Pittsburgh, adored grandmother of Dawn Margolin of Piedmont, CA., Wendy Cohen of New York City, Dr. Andrew Davidoff of Memphis, TN, and Jennifer Davidoff Cook of New York City; survived also by eight great grandchildren. For further information contact Ralph Schugar, Inc of Pittsburgh, PA, 1-888-621-8282.

title: Where Fathers Can Go for Help
description: FOR a proud first-time father -- one too proud, perhaps, to ask his partner or own parents about such tricks of the trade as eliciting the perfect burp -- the shelves of any bookstore can offer a stack of road maps, yet few written for anyone other than the mother.

title: NBC Executive In Polygram Bid
description: Neil S. Braun has resigned as president of the NBC television network to submit a bid today for one of Europe's largest film distributors, the movie business of Polygram N.V.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, JEROME
description: ROBBINS-Jerome. Peter Martins, Ballet Master in Chief, Howard Solomon, Chairman of the Board, Robert I. Lipp, President of the Board of Directors, and the entire New York City Ballet family profoundly mourn the passing of CoFounding Choreographer Jerome Robbins, our teacher, mentor, colleague and cherished friend. After more than five decades with New York City Ballet, he created nearly 60 ballets, some of which became the most enduring and beloved works of the twentieth century. Considered America's greatest classical choreographer, his ballets were notable for their diversity, brilliance, lyric beauty and humor. He had the uncanny ability to make the most complex movement appear effortless, and totally reflective of the musical score. Jerry's artistic vision, commitment, dedication and passion on each and every project in which he was involved, sought and strove for the very best in all of us. We watched him, we listened to him, we worked with him, we learned from him and we danced for him. His extraordinary life in musical theatre and dance and the prolific gifts of his genius brought immeasurable pleasure & delight to the world. His incomparable legacy to generations of performers will never be forgotten.

title: Paying Attention
description: To the Editor:

title: Fixes Are Elusive For a Security Gap
description: A serious security flaw in recent versions of Microsoft Outlook 98, Outlook Express and Netscape Mail -- three of the four most widely used Internet electronic mail programs -- is proving more difficult to fix than initially thought. Programmers at Microsoft and Netscape were scrambling last night to devise solutions to the flaw, which could allow rogue programmers to damage or steal data from a user's computer by sending a seemingly normal E-mail message.

title: Johnson Talks Are Still Going
description: The Yankees continue to talk with the Seattle Mariners about Randy Johnson as Friday's midnight trade deadline draws near, but their bid may ultimately hinge on whether Johnson agrees to a contract extension.

title: Angels Show Hernandez A Quick Exit
description: The Yankees win so often that their losses are generally forgotten.

title: Using E-Mail Ship to Shore
description: Q. My brother wishes to meet a writing deadline via E-mail while crossing the Atlantic Ocean by ship. How is this best done from a laptop, and what are the expected costs?

title: LG&E DISCONTINUES ITS BUSINESS IN TRADING OF ELECTRICITY
description: The LG&E Energy Corporation, Kentucky's largest electric utility, said that because of the recent volatility in the power market and its own current portfolio of energy-marketing contracts, it had discontinued trading electricity. It said it would record an after-tax loss of $225 million in the second quarter on the disposition of the operations. It also took a charge of $53.8 million, or 42 cents a share, related to its purchase of the Kansas City Power and Light Company. LG&E, which is based in Louisville, reported a second-quarter loss yesterday of $231.8 million, or $1.79 a diluted share, compared with net income of $33.7 million, or 26 cents a diluted share, in the second quarter of 1997.

title: Flaw in E-Mail Programs Points to an Industrywide Problem
description: The security flaw reported this week in E-mail programs produced by two highly respected software companies points to an industrywide problem -- the danger of programming languages whose greatest strength is also their greatest weakness.

title: Anti-Smoking Zeal Is Hazardous to Your Freedom
description: FOR YOUR OWN GOOD

title: Art CD-ROM's Hard to Find
description: To the Editor:

title: Cendant Shares Up 8% After Sweeping Board Room Changes
description: The Cendant Corporation, which is struggling to emerge from an accounting scandal that erupted in April, saw its shares rise by more than 8 percent in heavy trading yesterday, as investors reacted to sweeping board room changes announced after the market had closed on Tuesday.

title: Gay Policy in San Francisco Draws Penalty in the House
description: The House tonight narrowly passed a measure that would deny Federal housing money to San Francisco because of that city's policies supporting live-in homosexual partners.

title: On Blaming the Police
description: To the Editor:

title: Binnie Barnes, 95, Actress Known for Her Feisty Roles
description: Binnie Barnes, an English actress who was lured to Hollywood after her role as Catherine Howard in ''The Private Life of Henry VIII,'' the 1933 film starring Charles Laughton, died on Monday at her home in Beverly Hills. She was 95.

title: BOEING GETS ORDER WORTH $1.29 BILLION FROM BOULLIOUN
description: The Boeing Company won an order yesterday for 30 updated 737 jetliners, valued at $1.29 billion, from Boullioun Aviation Services Inc., an aircraft-leasing company. Boullioun, which is based in Bellevue, Wash., is a unit of the Sumitomo Trust and Banking Company. Boullioun also took options to buy 30 more planes, which could bring the total value to $2.6 billion, Boeing said. The announcement is Boeing's second major order this week, following yesterday's contract with the London-based Easyjet Airline Company.

title: An Appointment With Truth?
description: President Clinton and the independent counsel, Kenneth Starr, have reached a reasonable compromise in the deal to have Mr. Clinton testify at the White House rather than before a grand jury. That is a significant step in maintaining the dignity of the Presidency. But his videotaped testimony, on Aug. 17, should be only a preliminary to the more essential steps of telling the truth and explaining his conduct to the American people.

title: Saratoga Opens to Surprise by Call Me Up
description: From the steeplechasers who opened Saratoga's season this afternoon, to the 2-year-old fillies seeking stakes status in the Grade II Schuylerville, the depth of today's card served as a reminder of why Saratoga is racing's best known and most prestigious meet.

title: A Ghanaian-American Called to Lead His Tribe
description: Can an American human resources executive and basketball fan transform himself into a tribal chieftain in Ghana? Such is the decision facing Sule Issifu who after 25 years in the United States is summoned back on the death of his father to the family village of Nalerigu. His relatives, an extended clan, are demanding that he keep power over the 250,000-member Mamprusi tribe.

title: ITT PLANS $1.1 BILLION STOCK BUYBACK AFTER SALE OF UNITS
description: ITT Industries said yesterday that it planned to buy back $1.1 billion of its stock as a first step toward spending expected proceeds from the sale of two auto-parts units. On Monday, Continental A.G., the German tire maker, agreed to buy ITT's brake and chassis unit for $1.93 billion in cash. And ITT said last month that it would sell its electrical auto-parts unit to France's Valeo S.A. for $1.7 billion as it moves away from the auto-parts business to focus on its more profitable pumps and electronics operations. Shares of ITT, which is based in White Plains, rose $1.0625, to $33.5625. Based on that price, the company would repurchase about 32.8 million shares, or 28 percent of its 118.45 million shares outstanding as of yesterday. The buyback is contingent on the receipt of $2.6 billion expected from the sale of both units after taxes.

title: Sprinklers Fit for a Sculpture Garden
description: IN ''Knoxville: Summer 1915,'' James Agee's lyric celebration of the ''great order of noises'' on a Tennessee night, he wrote of fathers watering the lawn, adjusting the nozzles of hoses to produce an ''intense hiss of the stream,'' a spray that was a ''compromise between distance and tenderness.'' Joni Mitchell called her 1975 album ''The Hissing of Summer Lawns.''

title: Akzo Nobel Shares Slide on Profit News
description: Shares of Akzo Nobel N.V. dropped 14 percent after company, the world's biggest paint maker and the largest Dutch chemicals concern, posted lower-than-expected second-quarter earnings. Net income at Akzo, which makes the world's best-selling birth-control pill, Marvelon, rose 5 percent, to 483 million guilders ($242 million), from 459 million guilders. Analysts polled by Bloomberg News had expected a 14 percent rise.

title: Fans Boo Rojas and Valentine Boos Fans
description: Bobby Valentine's office was almost empty. The television cameramen and most of the reporters had dispersed to the clubhouse. Only a few people watched the testy manager get even testier than he had been a few seconds earlier when he discussed how the fans berated Mel Rojas before the reliever threw his first pitch. Obviously, the noise was based on Rojas's previous performances.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits last Thursday about art CD-ROM's misspelled the surname of the founder of Lucid Design, a multimedia development company. She is Nina Tovish, not Tovich.

title: Sports of the Times; N.B.A. Stay-at-Homes Don't Get It
description: FROM his old friend, Chris Webber has received the following advice regarding his trade to the Sacramento Kings, a team he is reportedly not overjoyed about playing for: show up, suit up and shut up.

title: Ctrl+Alt+Del? Or F2? Books to the Rescue
description: ABOUT 20 years ago, when America was awakening to its puppy love for personal computers, there was much talk about how digitized data would start to replace books. Anyone remember the paperless office?

title: Medical Examiner Says Girl Died in Homicide
description: The City Medical Examiner's office determined yesterday that Rosario Ladino, the 5-year-old girl found dead in her Queens home last weekend, died of ''fatal child abuse syndrome'' and declared her death a homicide.

title: A Time-Delay Virus Skips Catastrophe Date
description: Another computer virus did not cause the sky to fall this week, despite warnings to the contrary. On July 26, the CIH virus was supposed to affect computers running Windows 95 and 98, stopping some machines, keeping others from starting and wiping out files on yet others.

title: Goldman, Sachs Tries to Soothe Limited Partners
description: The top executives of Goldman, Sachs & Company have promised that when the firm, Wall Street's premier private investment bank, sells shares to the public, everyone at the firm, from general partners to janitors, will get a share of the multibillion-dollar payoff.

title: Bagel With Coffee? 2 Chains Make Deal
description: New World Coffee and Bagels Inc. will expand both its size and menu by buying the bankrupt Manhattan Bagel Corporation, its chief executive, Ramin Kamfar, said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARX, ERNEST J.
description: MARX-Ernest J. Age 78 on July 28, 1998. Beloved by wife of fiftyone years Helga, daughters Evie and Susan and son-in-law Barry Helfmann. Adoring and adored Opa of Loryn. Cherished brother of Ilse Gruen and uncle of Peter and Roger Gruen. Services on Thursday 1 P.M., at Riverdale Temple, Independence Avenue. Memorial donations to National Kidney Foundation.

description: Nothing, White House aides insist, could be as bad as late January, when the Lewinsky accusations first crashed over them.

description: LITERATURE has certainly come a long way since it really mattered.

title: A Haven From the Roar of the Street And Flying Gum Balls
description: BALLS of blue paint sail and splatter. The players catch marshmallows in their mouths and spew colored gum balls onto the stage. At the Astor Place Theater in New York, during a typical Blue Man Group performance, it's art as a kind of graduate-level kindergarten. But when the head Blue Man, Chris Wink, gets home, the scene changes markedly.
