description: AUTO RACING

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLER, LEONARD H., RABBI.
description: POLLER-Leonard H., Rabbi. The New York Association of Reform Rabbis mourns the passing of its Past President. The membership joins in extending sincere condolences to Priscilla, Judith, Sharon and Elyse and their extended families.

title: GOODWILL GAMES: ROUNDUP
description: BOXING

title: Four Indicted In Assaults Videotaped At Texas Jail
description: A mock riot staged for a training video for guards, in which prisoners were hit, kicked, shocked with a stun gun and bitten by police dogs, has led to the indictment of four jailers on Federal charges of violating three of the inmates' civil rights.

title: Amid the Crush of Fame, Pak Takes the Hoopla in Stride
description: A few months ago, Se Ri Pak never imagined that she would be overwhelmed with interview requests. Or that phone calls to her hotel room would have to be screened. Or that dozens of charitable organizations would want her to make appearances or donations. Or that her presence at an L.P.G.A. tournament would mean more fans and more news media.

title: SHARES JUMP IN ATL AFTER PHILIPS AGREES TO ACQUIRE IT
description: Shares of ATL Ultrasound Inc. jumped 19 percent yesterday after Royal Philips Electronics N.V. said it had agreed to acquire ATL, a maker of medical diagnostic equipment, for $50.50 a share, or a total of $800 million. ATL, based in Bothell, Wash., closed at $50, up $7.9375. The company had sales of $111.7 million in the six months that ended June 30. Philips is one of the world's largest consumer electronics companies. The acquisition of ATL will give Philips a presence in the ultrasound sector, the only area of the diagnostic imaging market in which it does not currently operate, Philips said.

title: MCCAW FAMILY EXERCISES AN OPTION FOR SHARES IN NEXTEL
description: Nextel Communications Inc., which provides wireless services, said the cellular phone pioneer Craig McCaw and his family had exercised an option to buy about 10 million shares in the company in a cashless transaction. The McCaws had two stock options in Nextel, which is based in McLean, Va., one to acquire 15 million shares at $16 each and the other for 10 million shares at $18 each. The options were to expire yesterday. Craig McCaw, co-chief executive of the closely held Teledesic L.L.C., built the wireless phone company McCaw Cellular Communications before selling it to the AT&T Corporation for $11.5 billion in 1994.

title: Senate Deadlocked on Rules for Health Bill Debate
description: Senate Republican and Democratic leaders deadlocked on patients' rights legislation today, all but guaranteeing that the Senate would not debate the contentious but politically popular issue until September, if then.

title: Gingerly, Urmanov Returns To the Ice
description: For the first time in 16 months, Aleksei Urmanov of Russia returned to Olympic-style figure skating tonight at the Goodwill Games. The 1994 Olympic champion was not trying to reclaim his past as much as he was seeking confirmation of the possibilities for a healthy future.

title: Relay Sinks American Men Against Germans
description: When the Goodwill Games swimming began Tuesday night and the United States women's team routed China, an American sweep seemed viable -- three dual-meet victories by the American women and three by the men.

title: Modern Idioms Via Brazil
description: Bahia Ballet, from Salvador, Brazil, is neither a folk ensemble nor a classical ballet troupe. Yet its polished dancers take daily ballet class, and the company's choreography occasionally draws upon traditional inspiration and movement idioms. Bahia Ballet is very much a modern-dance company with a Brazilian accent.

title: Poverty Plays Role in South's Murder Rate
description: To the Editor:

title: Meditation and Decoration: Om for the Home
description: ''YOU don't need a separate room for meditation,'' the designer Diane Von Furstenberg was saying. ''I meditate every morning in my bed for a half-hour before I get up.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about people flocking to Greenwich, Conn., to buy Powerball tickets misstated one of the ways the jackpot is paid. Winners who choose to play for the full prize amount receive an initial payment at the time they win and then receive payments for 24 more years. The payments are not made over 20 years.

title: THE POP LIFE/The Big Hit That Wasn't: A Band Takes Stock; Expectations Betray Smashing Pumpkins
description: When the Smashing Pumpkins performed at the Universal Amphitheater here on July 1, Billy Corgan, the band's bald singer and guitarist, made a strange comment. He called the group's latest record, ''Adore'' (Virgin), ''the most misunderstood album since 'Gish.' '' (Gish was the band's first record, released in 1991.) Coming from the mouth of the leader of one of the biggest alternative-rock bands of the decade, the singer of lines like ''I'm forever broken,'' the sentiment may not have been a huge surprise. But behind it was the frustration not just of an artist who feels his work has been misjudged, but of a man who feels the music world -- his world -- has willfully turned its back on him as well.

title: Excerpts From Speech by Justice Thomas
description: Following are excerpts from the speech yesterday by Justice Clarence Thomas to the annual convention of the National Bar Association in Memphis. The speech was made available by the C-Span cable network on its Internet site.

title: Broadcasters Vow to Keep Affirmative Action
description: Some of the nation's biggest broadcasters, including the four major networks and several of the largest owners of radio stations, have agreed to continue following the Federal Communications Commission's affirmative action guidelines, even though they are no longer required to do so under a recent court decision, the industry's chief regulator said today.

title: MetroStars Beat Fatigue and Kansas City
description: Major League Soccer's All-Star Game on Sunday in Orlando, Fla., could not come at a better time for the MetroStars. Playing their fourth game in 10 days, the MetroStars scored a 3-2 shootout victory over the Kansas City Wizards at Giants Stadium tonight, but it seemed they were ready for a rest.

title: Dartmouth Gives iMac A Stamp of Approval
description: The Apple iMac, to be released Aug. 15, got a vote of approval from Dartmouth College, which placed the computer on its recommended list for incoming students.

title: Deal Struck on Antitrust Bill
description: In baseball parlance, the Senate Judiciary Committee for the first time yesterday moved into scoring position with a bill that would alter the antitrust exemption Major League Baseball has enjoyed since 1922.

title: Swinging Through The Night
description: The best dance bands from the Americas have the unstoppable forward motion of a loaded freight train moving quickly down a mountain. Regardless of style or country, they have a swing that keeps dancers going, and at Lincoln Center's Fountain Plaza on Friday night Marce et Tumpak, a small, rocking group from Martinique, went right at that swing and stayed there for an hour.

title: Sale of Coliseum Site Receives Approval
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority approved the sale of the New York Coliseum site yesterday for $345 million, the first step in a three-year, $1.3 billion project that will alter the face of the Columbus Circle area.

title: Looking Closely
description: APPLE-GREEN paint fascinates John R. Stilgoe, the professor of landscape history at Harvard. He sometimes finds it inside the cupboards or broom closets of old kitchens, a token of the 1920's, a time when that color was thought to be soothing to the soul. Public schools wore that green; its relative survives in too many halls under the name ''landlord green.''

title: Russia Fails to Free Iraq From Intrusive Inspections
description: Russia tried and failed to get Security Council action today on a resolution declaring that Iraq had complied with demands to destroy its nuclear weapons program and was ready to move away from intrusive inspections to long-term monitoring,

description: The State Treasurer yesterday asked the State Attorney General whether the Treasurer is legally allowed to delay a contract to install a new statewide auto emissions testing system after the lone bidder had been notified the job was his, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUFER, SIMON
description: LAUFER-Simon. We are deeply saddened by the passing of Simon Laufer. His cheerful dispositon and extraordinary benevolence will be missed by all. Beloved and devoted husband to Fran, our dynamic founding President. Together they helped establish and nurture our organization as they did with countless other institutions. To Fran, and to the entire family, we offer our heartfelt sympathy. May the Almighty console you among the other mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rivkah Laufer Bikur Cholim

title: Theater as Juice, Dream and Cattle Prod
description: It's not likely that the theater of the future will exactly mirror the antics of the crazed Argentine ectomorphs whizzing around like window washers on amphetamines in the former bank building between Toys ''R'' Us and Starbucks across from Union Square.

title: Mother's Legal Vulnerability Is Seen as Motive for Lewinsky
description: When Monica S. Lewinsky's legal troubles began last January, her first phone call was to her mother, Marcia Lewis. The two, by all accounts, are extremely close. So close, it seems, that when Federal prosecutors granted Ms. Lewinsky full immunity from prosecution on Tuesday, a similar deal was given Ms. Lewis, Ms. Lewinsky's shopping partner, roommate and, perhaps most relevant, her confidante.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MUELLER INDUSTRIES, Memphis, a maker of copper, brass and aluminum fixtures for plumbing systems, agreed to acquire B&K Industries, Elk Grove Village, Ill., a privately held import distributor, for $33.5 million in cash and stock.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. A day after Japan's currency rose as Kiichi Miyazawa, a well-regarded former Premier, was asked to be Finance Minister, it dropped on fear that he would be ineffective. The dollar rose to 142.35 yen from 141.35.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Conflict Over Conflicts; Class-Action Lawyers Defend Their Political Contributions
description: Leonard Barrack, a prominent fund-raiser for Democratic causes and the finance chairman of the Democratic National Committee, has been a generous contributor to the campaigns of Mayor Ed Rendell in Philadelphia and H. Carl McCall, the State Comptroller in New York.

title: Sony's Quarterly Profit Up 18%, Buoyed by Sales of Video Games
description: The Sony Corporation said today that earnings rose 18 percent in the first quarter, lifted by strong sales of games for its Playstation video game machine and by demand for digital camcorders and flat-screen television sets.

title: Business Improvement District At Grand Central Is Dissolved
description: After a year of mounting acrimony between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and several of Manhattan's business improvement districts, senior city officials said yesterday that they were putting the Grand Central Partnership, one of the largest and by far the most combative of the districts, out of business.

title: After Search for Debris, Rockaway Beach Reopens
description: Rockaway Beach was opened to swimmers yesterday morning after high tide was found to be free of the syringes and vials that had washed up in the five previous days.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Confirmation

title: The Tour de France Faces Its Worst Crisis
description: The Tour de France, already in turmoil because of investigations into the use of illegal performance-enhancing drugs by cyclists, was stopped twice today by riders protesting police methods, and for the first time in its 95-year history faced a premature end.

title: Gun Doesn't Link 2 to a Slaying
description: The .22-caliber pistol found in a gym bag belonging to the suspects in the disappearance of an Upper East Side widow was not the gun used to kill a Los Angeles businessman earlier this year, investigators said yesterday.

title: Telefonica Names Alcatel as Supplier
description: The Spanish telecommunications operator Telefonica S.A. said yesterday that it had selected Alcatel S.A. of France as its primary supplier for wireless telecommunications equipment. Alcatel said the equipment supply contract covers Spain, Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Peru.

title: A Plane's Engine Fails, And Smoke Fills Another
description: A Contintental Air Lines flight leaving Newark International Airport last night was forced to land after an engine failed during takeoff, airline officials said.

title: VERIO BUYING HIWAY TO EXPAND ITS WEB SITE OPERATIONS
description: Verio Inc., a provider of Internet services, said yesterday that it would buy the closely held Hiway Technologies Inc. for $329.7 million in cash and stock to expand its business of operating Web sites. Verio will pay $101 million in cash and issue 8.67 million common shares for Hiway's outstanding shares. Its shares rose $2.625 yesterday, to $29. Shareholders of Hiway, which is based in Boca Raton, Fla., and employs 275 people, will own about 19 percent of the combined company. With the acquisition of Hiway, Verio, based in Englewood, Colo., will operate more than 150,000 Web sites.

title: Pharmacia & Upjohn Has First Quarterly Earnings Gain in a Year
description: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. said today that profit before a charge rose 5 percent in the second quarter, its first quarterly earnings gain in more than a year, lifted by the sale of new drugs. Reflecting the charge, net income declined 18 percent.

title: Cambodia's Voters Have Spoken, but Silence Doesn't Reign

Robert Hearn through hundreds of pages, getting to know all his real and psychological limnings, before coming to this sentence: ''A half-hour later, Lieutenant Hearn was killed by a machine-gun bullet which passed through his chest.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, BLANCHE W.

Dear mother-in-law of Marc Kalech, Managing Editor of the New York Post. Adoring Grammy of Margot and Max. Devoted sister of Robert Weiner and Evelyn Leshin. Service on Thursday 1 P.M., at Temple Israel 27 Pierce Street, Greenfield, Mass. Contribution in her memory to Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center.

title: Papers in Capitol Shootings Show More Ammunition Was Found

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHN, NOEL
description: BEHN-Noel. Novelist, screenwriter and theatrical producer, died on July 27 at Beth Israel Hospital in New York City. He was 70 years old & lived in Manhattan. Mr. Behn succumbed to a heart attack after a battle with cancer. A member of New York's theater community for more than fifty years, Mr. Behn was at the forefront of the creation of the off-Broadway theater movement as the Producing Director of the legendary Cherry Lane Theater. He was the author of seven books, including ''Seven Silent Men'' and ''The Shadowboxer''. Of his remaining work, two were made into feature films and one is still in development. In 1970, Mr. Behn's novel, ''The Kremlin Letter'', was released as a motion picture directed by John Houston and starring Orson Welles. ''The Brink's Job'', a 1978 movie starring Peter Falk and Peter Boyle, was adapted from Mr. Behn's non-fiction book, ''The Big Stick-Up at Brink's''. His latest book, a study of the kidnapping of the Lindbergh baby entitled ''Lindbergh'', is currently in development as a feature film. As a friend of Woody Allen, Mr. Behn also appeared in Mr. Allen's films ''Another Woman'' and as Doug Orkin in 1980's ''Stardust Memories''. In addition to his work in film and theater, Mr. Behn has extensive television credits. He wrote for Tattingers, and, for seven seasons, served as creative consultant on NBC's critically acclaimed series ''Homicide: Life on the Street''. During that time, Mr. Behn wrote or co-wrote more than six episodes and was writing his seventh at the time of his death. His script ''A Many Splendored Thing'' was nominated for the 1994 Writer's Guild Award for Outstanding Writing for a Drama Series. Mr. Behn was also a much loved denizen of Elaine's, New York's legendary watering hole. A veteran of the U.S. Army's Counterintelligence Corps, Mr. Behn, who was divorced, is survived by his mother, Dorothy, of Miami Lakes, Florida, where a funeral service will be held today. There will be a memorial service for Mr. Behn in Manhattan, with further details to be announced.

Conoco will use the proceeds from the stock sale, along with cash on hand, to repay part of a $7.5 billion promissory note issued to DuPont on July 20, according to the S.E.C. filing. Analysts have estimated that the public offering could raise $3 billion to $5 billion through the sale of a 20 percent stake in Conoco.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, JEROME
description: ROBBINS-Jerome. Peter Martins, Ballet Master in Chief, Howard Solomon, Chairman of the Board, Robert I. Lipp, President of the Board of Directors, and the entire New York City Ballet family profoundly mourn the passing of CoFounding Choreographer Jerome Robbins, our teacher, mentor, colleague and cherished friend. After more than five decades with New York City Ballet, he created nearly 60 ballets, some of which became the most enduring and beloved works of the twentieth century. Considered America's greatest classical choreographer, his ballets were notable for their diversity, brilliance, lyric beauty and humor. He had the uncanny ability to make the most complex movement appear effortless, and totally reflective of the musical score. Jerry's artistic vision, commitment, dedication and passion on each and every project in which he was involved, sought and strove for the very best in all of us. We watched him, we listened to him, we worked with him, we learned from him and we danced for him. His extraordinary life in musical theatre and dance and the prolific gifts of his genius brought immeasurable pleasure & delight to the world. His incomparable legacy to generations of performers will never be forgotten.

Prior to joining ''Project Renewal'' Dr. Roff was Deputy Director at Altro, Inc. and previously was a senior level administrator at the New York City Department of Mental Health, Mental Retardation and Alcoholism Services. Dr. Seriff was an exceptional physician who impressed all who knew him with his intellect, his kindness and his unwavering love for the profession he practiced so brilliantly. description: WPP Group P.L.C. in London, which owns agencies including Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide and the J. Walter Thompson Company, is negotiating to acquire a stake in Asatsu Inc. in Tokyo, Japan's third-largest agency company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHMUD, DR. FAIQ,
description: MAHMUD-Dr. Faiq, 34, of New York City, was struck by an auto and killed in Beaumont, Texas on July 23rd. Services were held July 27th at the Islamic Center of New York in Manhattan. Interment was at Washington Memorial Park in Coram, NY. Dr. Mahmud was a graduate of Columbia University Medical School. His residency in orthopaedic surgery was served at New York Orthopaedic Hospital. At the time of his death, Dr. Mahmud was practicing at the Beaumont Bone and Joint Institute in Texas. Dr. Mahmud is survived by his mother and father, Gulshan and Husain Mahmud of New York City, brother, Urooj Mahmud of Chicago, sisters, Naila Mahmud of Great Neck, New York, and Arfa Mahmud of New York City.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a hearing on breast implants misidentified a defendant in a class-action lawsuit filed by the Toxic Discovery Network, a group that represents women who say implants made them sick, and misstated the office of Dr. C. Lin Puckett, who defended implant safety. The defendant is the American Society of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgeons, not the American Society for Aesthetic Plastic Surgery; Dr. Puckett is vice president of the group, not its president.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VONA, DANIEL D.
description: VONA-Daniel D. On July 25, 1998. Longtime servant of the Democratic Party, the late Commissioner of Records NYS & W.W. I Veteran. Beloved husband of the late Helen. Loving father of Marie Ingram, Daniel & Angela. Cherished grandfather of Susanna, Patrick, Clarissa, Alexander, Daniel, Leal and Andrew. Devoted greatgrandfather of Jessica, Joshua, Samuel, Elizabeth, Matthew, Rebecca, Daniel, Edward and Peter. Dear brother of the late Edward. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (cor 20th Street), NYC, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Immaculate Conception Church, Saturday 10 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Top Bridge Teams Still Prevail in Chicago
description: All the topranked teams prevailed here Wednesday night in the Spingold Knockout Team Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, but several had to fight hard to survive.

title: Casino Official Resigns, Citing Financial Pressure
description: Bradford S. Smith, chairman of the New Jersey Casino Control Commission, announced yesterday that he would leave his position as the state's top casino regulator on Sept. 4 and seek a job in the private sector.

title: Irvan Wins Pole In Record Time
description: Ernie Irvan won the pole for tomorrow's Brickyard 400 for a second straight year yesterday, breaking his own track record with a speed of 179.394 miles an hour at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway after a rain delay of nearly four hours.

title: A.I.G. Will Put $1.35 Billion Into Blackstone
description: American International Group Inc. said yesterday that it would invest $1.35 billion in the Blackstone Group, a private New York merchant bank, raising the prospect of considerable future cooperation between the two companies as the traditional barriers between insurance and investment banking continue to erode.

title: Softly, Softly: A Seduction With Songs of Schumann
description: Singing is not a better form of speaking. Singing is a better form of whispering, according to the way the German baritone Matthias Goerne sang his Schumann recital for the Mostly Mozart Festival at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night.

title: City Can Eject Homeless From Shelters, Court Says
description: The Giuliani administration can eject homeless people from shelters if they violate a variety of rules, including failing to participate in drug treatment and job training programs, a state appeals court ruled yesterday.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Troubled Health Plan's Stock Price Ills
description: Is it time for investors to stick a toe in? The stock of Oxford Health Plans, the troubled managed-care company, has long been down and out, after plunging last year when the company told investors to expect an enormous loss. Now, the stock has again fallen precipitously, losing nearly half its sharply reduced value in the last few weeks.

title: Labor Costs Rose Slightly In the Spring
description: Despite signs that economic growth is slowing sharply, wages and benefits are climbing a bit faster than a year ago.

title: Ideas on Life's Start And Southpaw Way
description: Two new scientific papers attempt to trace the story of life from a cloud in deep space to vents in the deep ocean. Australian astronomers have suggested that the quality of light in the nebula from which the Sun and planets formed may explain a fundamental mystery about chemical life on Earth. Organic molecules can have a right- or left-handed form, but key molecules in living creatures exist only in left-handed forms. Stellar radiation may have erased the oppositely handed forms of such molecules before the Earth was formed.

title: A River Park Grows in Manhattan
description: New Yorkers who fought for 14 years to create a park along the Hudson River had every reason to throw themselves a party the other night. They started with what seemed an irresistible vision, to reclaim the waterfront for New York City's citizens by replacing two miles of rotting piers and decaying warehouses below 59th Street with an inviting mix of open space and modest commercial development. They encountered endless obstacles, including inert politicians, but on the last day of the legislative session in Albany in June they got what they wanted -- a bill officially establishing the park, defining its borders and setting up an administrative mechanism to run it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINON, MARTIN P.
description: SINON-Martin P. Beloved husband of Frances. Devoted father of Marie and John McHale, Jean Anne & Dan Valance, Rosemary & Patrick Quirke, John and Gina, and Martin and Joanne. Also survived by seven grandchildren, brother, Denis, and mother-in-law, Mrs. Vincent Simeti. Reposing at the James Romanelli-Stephen Funeral Home, 89-01 Rockaway Blvd., Ozone Park, until Monday, 8:45 AM. Mass of the Resurrection at St. Brendan's R.C. Church (Bronx), 10 AM. Entombment Woodlawn Cemetery. Chapel hours 2-5 and 7-10 PM.

title: House Bars Use of Funds to Move Highway
description: In a slight to Donald J. Trump, the House of Representatives voted late Wednesday against the use of Federal highway funds to move a stretch of the West Side Highway that is next to Mr. Trump's luxury condominium project, now being built on the Upper West Side.

title: Briton Hanged in 1953 Is Finally Exonerated
description: For 46 years the relatives of Derek Bentley, hanged at 19 for his role in the murder of a police officer, told anyone who would listen that he was the victim of a terrible miscarriage of justice.

title: At the Movies; This Summer, Noise Matters
description: If there is one outstanding feature of the movies released this summer, especially the big special-effects pictures, it is that they are among the noisiest films ever made. ''Armageddon'' and ''Godzilla,'' and even the serious drama ''Saving Private Ryan,'' have cranked up the aural effects, leaving some people thrilled and others with headaches.

title: Observer; Toads and Wonders
description: We truly live in wonderful times, but now and then when Old Devil Skeptic jumps on my back, he starts me asking myself questions. Here are several I asked just this morning.

title: The Master of Broadway and Ballet
description: Lights dimmed for a moment last night on Broadway, the theater world's way of honoring Jerome Robbins, one of the century's great choreographers. Mr. Robbins, who died in Manhattan Wednesday at age 79, left his legendary imprint on every Broadway show he touched, on every ballet he crafted and on audiences who felt his untethered genius behind the athletic rumble in ''West Side Story'' or in ''Watermill,'' a ballet executed with such exacting slowness that George Balanchine described it as being without time.

title: France to Sell Up to 30% Of Thomson Multimedia
description: The French Government agreed today to sell as much as 30 percent of Thomson Multimedia, one of Europe's largest consumer electronics makers, to industrial partners including the Microsoft Corporation, which is expected to use the investment to expand its push into delivering Internet services via television.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Take the A Train'

title: No Helpless, Wimpy Waif Filling This Glass Slipper
description: Sooner or later Cinderella was bound to be reinvented as a resourceful young woman whose ascent from rags to riches depended on her own pluck and not on the magical intercession of a fairy godmother. Andy Tennant's bland, sappy costume comedy ''Ever After: A Cinderella Story,'' portrays the most popular of all fairy-tale characters as a kind of 16th-century Olympic hopeful going for the gold on several fronts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICHMAN, MARCUS
description: REICHMAN - Marcus. Beloved husband of Shirley. Devoted father of Lawrence (Michelle) Richman and Robert (Denise). Adoring grandfather of Molly and Alanna. He was much loved and will be greatly missed.

title: UNITED PLACES BILLION-DOLLAR ORDER WITH AIRBUS
description: United Airlines approved the purchase yesterday of 22 Airbus Industrie planes worth up to $1.05 billion, completing a plan to build up the airline's fleet and giving Airbus, the European aircraft maker, another victory over the Boeing Company. The Chicago-based United, a unit of the UAL Corporation, ordered 12 Airbus A320's and 10 A319's for delivery in 2000 and 2001. The planes, designed for flights within the United States, seat about 150 passengers. In March, United ordered 30 Airbus planes, and in April it bought 23 Boeing jets in an order worth up to $3.2 billion.

description: FOR CHILDREN

title: MCI Reports a Decline of 30% In Net Income for the 2d Quarter
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said today that profit before special items fell 27 percent in the second quarter, less than expected, as a surge in data services helped to produce the strongest revenue growth since 1996. Net income decreased 30 percent.

title: Home Video; Sturges at 100: Reeling Back
description: In the early and middle 1940's, Preston Sturges wrote and directed a string of perhaps the wittiest, most sophisticated comedies ever made for the American screen. In the late 30's, though, he wrote before he directed. ''This is him seeing what directors were doing and saying to himself, 'Wait a minute, I can do that,' '' said his son Tom Sturges.

description: BASEBALL

title: A Detective Is Allowed To Resign
description: After fending off police investigators and Federal prosecutors for more than five years, Detective John K. Wrynn has resigned rather than face a departmental trial on charges that he leaked top-secret information about undercover detectives and confidential informers to organized crime associates in the Bronx, police officials said yesterday.

title: You Gotta Believe! 13's the Lucky Number
description: Long before today, they called themselves the Lucky 13.

title: Columbia/HCA to Pay $2.5 Million Penalty
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation will pay a $2.5 million civil penalty to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it did not move quickly enough to sell hospitals in Utah and Florida.

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD ASKS 2,400 MANAGERS TO TAKE PAY CUT
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company is asking about 2,400 mid- to upper-level managers worldwide to take a 5 percent cut in pay for three months as the company, the third-largest computer maker, tries to cut costs as sales slump. Hewlett-Packard also said yesterday that it planned to close offices worldwide for four days in late December. The moves are part of an effort by the chief executive, Lewis E. Platt, to cut expenses, which have hurt earnings in recent quarters. Last week, the company warned that third-quarter profit would not meet analysts' expectations because of slowing sales, mostly in Asia.

description: Halifax P.L.C., Britain's largest mortgage lender, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Birmingham Midshires Building Society for $:750 million ($1.23 billion) to expand its mortgage business, even though its first-half profit showed mortgages might be a problem area.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: OFFICIAL'S COMMENTS HURT YEN. Japan's currency dropped sharply after Kiichi Miyazawa, the new Finance Minister, suggested there would be no intervention to defend the yen. The dollar rose to 143.66 yen from 142.35.

title: Sampras to Be Busy Before Title Quest
description: Pete Sampras will be keeping busy in the weeks leading to the United States Open, when he will be seeking to tie Roy Emerson's men's record of 12 Grand Slam singles titles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, WILLIAM MCCHESNEY, JR.
description: MARTIN-William McChesney, Jr. The Board of Directors of The New York Stock Exchange mourns the death of our former President, esteemed colleague and friend, William McChesney Martin, Jr. He served as the first full-time paid President of the Exchange from June 30, 1938 until April 16, 1941. He returned to conduct a study of the Exchange in 1971 where his insight and initiative led to changes in the governance of the Exchange. His dedication and commitment to the Exchange and the securities industry will endure. Richard A. Grasso, Chairman and C E O, New York Stock Exchange, Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, EMANUEL
description: HALPERN-Emanuel. On July 30, 1998 at home. Beloved husband of Dorothy, loving father of Dr. Steven Halpern and Dr Janis Kritzer. Beloved grandfather of Beverly and Dana Halpern, Adam, Daniel and Benjamin Kritzer. Relatives and friends are invited to attend services today at Bloomfield Cooper Jewish Chapels, Manalapan, New Jersey. Shiva will be observed at Stevens home, 46 High Street Summit, New Jersey.

Theresa Melican, Ann Lynch, John Melican & Sr. Regina Anne, O.P. Also survived by several nieces and nephews and grand nieces and grand nephews. Friends may call at the Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Ave, Scarsdale, Saturday 2-4 and 7-9PM. Mass of the Eucharist Sunday, 7:30PM at Saint Pius X Church. Funeral Mass Monday, 10:30AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Saint Pius X School in his memory.

title: Sex and the City's Tiny, Tiny Apartments
description: IT seems a good time to drop in on Candace Bushnell, the sex columnist who spawned what this summer has become one of HBO's best-rated sitcoms: ''Sex and the City,'' starring Sarah Jessica Parker, a journey into Ms. Bushnell's 1990's Manhattan demimonde of models, investment bankers, designer G-strings and threesomes. Actually, any time is an amusing time to drop in on Ms. Bushnell, but as it happens there are developments in her life.

title: Profit Off 20% at Glaxo but Up 19% at Astra
description: Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C. said yesterday that net income fell 20 percent in the first half, less than expected, as sales growth for newer drugs offset declines in revenue from the ulcer medication Zantac and development costs decreased. Its shares rose sharply.

title: State's Top Court Voids Death Sentence
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court yesterday overturned the death sentence of a woman who admitted to killing a Haddon Heights police officer and an investigator from the Camden County Prosecutor's office in 1995, ruling that crucial information was never shown to the jury.

title: STOCK OF USA NETWORKS UP 11.3% AS LOSSES NARROW
description: Shares of USA Networks Inc. rose 11.3 percent yesterday after the company said that its second-quarter loss narrowed more than expected and that it planned to buy back as many as 10 million shares in the next year. It had a pro forma loss of $1.3 million, or 1 cent a diluted share, compared with $10.5 million, or 8 cents, a year earlier. Revenue rose 15 percent, to $689.9 million from $601.1 million. USA Networks attributed the improvement to higher advertising revenue at its cable-television networks, and stronger sales and lower returns at its electronic-retailing business, which includes the Home Shopping Network. Shares of USA Networks, which is based in New York, rose $3.09375, to $30.50.

title: Hercules to Buy BetzDearborn In $2.4 Billion Chemical Deal
description: Hercules Inc. agreed yesterday to buy BetzDearborn Inc. for $2.4 billion in cash and $700 million in assumed debt, creating one of the world's biggest makers of chemicals used in paper-making, water-treatment and other industrial processes.

description: The Procter & Gamble Company said today that profit rose 12 percent in the fiscal fourth quarter, aided by strong sales of Pampers diapers and higher prices for tissues and towels.

title: Times Sq. Vagabonds Hurry Home With New Sense of Grace
description: It is a gift rarely granted: to walk in another's shoes, to feel the familiar road suddenly drop away, to know how sore your feet get after wearing the same wingtips or high heels for 10 days straight.

title: Pedaling Pleasures, En Masse vs. Solo
description: Early on a sultry summer morning, a caravan of recreational bicyclists pulls out of a parking lot at Brookdale College in Lincroft, N.J., for a 25-mile ride through the country lanes of Monmouth County. We are a dozen people, ages 30 to 60, men and women -- including one couple on a tandem -- heading out to Holmdel, Colts Neck, Marlboro and Freehold for a marvelous workout, camaraderie, tips on bike handling and the consuming power that comes from riding together.

title: Northwest and Pilots Reach An Impasse in Negotiations
description: Federal mediators have declared an impasse in contract negotiations between Northwest Airlines and its pilots, setting the stage for a possible strike as early as next month.

title: Investments in Stock Funds Slow, But Remain Ahead of '97 Pace
description: Exhibiting their usual skittishness in a period of stock market turmoil, mutual fund investors slowed their purchases of equity funds in the second half of July, fund companies and industry analysts said yesterday.

title: Thompson New York was looking for a savior, and Bob Jeffrey intends to succeed at the job.
description: BOB JEFFREY describes himself as someone who ''loves challenges.'' He has certainly come to the right place.

title: Microsoft Co-Founder to Buy 90% of Big Cable Company
description: The billionaire investor Paul Allen expanded his holdings in the cable business yesterday by agreeing to buy more than 90 percent of Charter Communications, the nation's 10th- largest cable operator, for $4.5 billion.

description: Douglas Gordon, the 32-year-old film and video artist from Glasgow who won the prestigious Turner Prize two years ago, has captured another award. On Wednesday night, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum announced that Mr. Gordon was this year's winner of the Hugo Boss Prize.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITEHEAD, O.Z. (ZEBBY),
description: WHITEHEAD-O.Z. (Zebby), age 87. Died on July 29, 1998, Dublin, Ireland. After a short illness. Attended St. Marks School '30 and Harvard. Actor in Hollywood, in ''Grapes of Wrath, ''The Lion in Winter'', ''Ulysses'' & many other films and television productions. He worked with Henry Fonda, Katharine Hepburn and Spencer Tracy. In 1950's joined Baha'i faith and moved to Ireland in 1963. In 1972 he was elected to the newly formed Baha'i National Assembly in Ireland and served until 1987. Author of books and essays on Baha'i faith and biography of Gish sisters. He sponsored an annual playwright competition in Ireland, and in 1965 received the Actor's Church Union Award for the Best Actor in the Dublin Theatre Festival for his performance in Eugene O'Neill's ''Hughie''. Member, Kildare Street Club in Dublin and other clubs. Baha'i funeral service and burial in Ireland on July 30.

title: Hernandez Focuses On Some Adjustments
description: Yankee Manager Joe Torre welcomed Orlando Hernandez into his office today and talked about pitching in general -- a fair topic, following the beating Hernandez took Wednesday night in the Yankees' 10-5 loss to Anaheim.

description: Cambodia's leader, Hun Sen, offered today to form a coalition government with his chief rivals as additional returns in the parliamentary election on Sunday appeared to confirm his predictions of victory.

description: English pikemen gird for battle, at left, in the 17th-century civil war that pitted Parliament against the Crown, a scene from the eight-part series ''War and Civilization,'' which begins Sunday night at 9 on the Learning Channel.

title: Shaker Style: An Elegance Beyond Time
description: Marybeth Keene, a partner in Wayne Pratt Antiques of Woodbury, Conn., recently interviewed 60 antiques dealers so she could compile a list of what's in and what's out of fashion among collectors. She concluded that Shaker is currently out.

title: Metro Business; Luxury Hotel at Kennedy
description: The first luxury hotel to be built in 20 years at Kennedy International Airport, the Four Points Sheraton, will hold its official opening on Tuesday.

title: Capturing Images and Passion in a Turbulent World
description: Our world is so overrun with photographic images that it's amazing to realize that the art of photography is barely 150 years old. Who would have thought, until it had been done, that it was possible to capture and freeze a moment of time on a piece of paper? Sandra Goldbacher's ravishingly handsome film ''The Governess'' takes us back to the spooky moment when the pioneers of photography discovered how to create a lasting photographic image. That the inventors in her film -- a gentleman scientist named Charles Cavendish and his daughter's governess, Rosina da Silva (Minnie Driver) -- are fictional characters gives her a metaphoric license that sticking to the facts couldn't have allowed.

description: In one of the nation's most ambitious efforts to preserve vanishing farmland and woodlands, the New Jersey Legislature passed a ballot measure today that will ask voters in November to approve borrowing $1 billion to protect half of the state's remaining two million acres of undeveloped land over the next 10 years.

title: Long Island Town Astir Over Clinton's Fund-Raising Getaway
description: No one here begrudges President Clinton a weekend getaway, what with that nettlesome Lewinsky matter back in Washington. But of all places, why would he choose a Long Island town that becomes a parking lot in the summer for people who consider themselves plugged-in and beautiful, as well as for those who attend to their many needs?

Don't be put off by that misleading title: Manuel Poirier's road movie is actually set in western France, where two funny and hapless outsiders wind up joining forces and embarking on a wonderfully droll journey.

title: In the Eye of the Collector: Seeking the Innate Order or Chaos
description: The instinct to preserve, strong in most people, can run especially deep in artists. Their desire to leave a record of their beliefs, lives, times or inner states has been in effect at least since the time of the Lascaux cave paintings, to the great benefit of the world's cultures.

title: House Wades Toward a Vote on Campaign Finance Legislation
description: The House today picked up the pace on its campaign finance debate and began making its way through more than three dozen amendments to bipartisan legislation that would cut back on money in politics.

title: Attention, Sports Fans: These Dudes Got Game
description: Maybe, just maybe, through sheer overkill, ''Baseketball,'' will put an end to the use of the word ''dude'' as an all-purpose comic term of endearment shouted in each other's faces by hormonally rampant, eternally adolescent movie pals. Should it do so, the flourishing genre of acne-challenged, gonad-driven buddy comedy that came into its own with ''Wayne's World'' could find itself facing a major identity crisis. What, after all, could possibly replace ''dude?'' ''Darling?''

title: Mother Sues Over Bomb Inquiry

title: An Admirer of Giuliani Feels His Wrath
description: It was only a few years ago that Daniel A. Biederman was so in tune with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's thinking that he was chosen to be on the Mayor's 1993 transition team, helping to select city officials. Even yesterday, having been sent sprawling by Mr. Giuliani's wrath, Mr. Biederman claimed to be an enormous admirer of the man who is dismantling his career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RALSTON, BRUCE L., MD,
description: RALSTON-Bruce L., MD, 73. Of Tuxedo Park, New York, died on Wednesday July 29, 1998 at Valley Hospital, Ridgewood, New Jersey. Dr. Ralston was a Neurosurgeon in Middletown, NY who retired in 1985. He was born in Brooklyn, NY to Miriam Levey Hoffer & the late Harry Ralston. He was married to Shirley Wadhams Ralston. Besides his wife & mother Dr. Ralston is survived by 1 son, Lowell Ralston, Ph.D. of Virginia; two daughters, Betsy Collins of Mass. & Diana Horvath, Ph.D. of New York; five grandchildren, a brother, Donald Ralston, of White Plains, NY and one niece and a nephew. Funeral services will be held on Saturday, August 1, 1998, 11 AM in St. Mary's in the Park Church, Tuxedo Park, New York. Burial to follow at the St. Mary's in the Park Cemetery, Tuxedo, NY. Friends are invited to call at the Wanamaker & Carlough Funeral Home, 41 Eagle Valley Road, Sloatsburg, New York on Friday July 31 from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9PM. Memorial contributions may be sent to Lown Cardio Vascular Foundation, 21 Longwood Avenue, Brookline, Massachusetts 02446.

title: Metro Business; Prestigious Law Firm Extends Its Lease
description: The law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy agreed yesterday to a 15-year, 270,000-square-foot lease extension and renegotiation that is believed to be the largest such deal for a law firm in the United States this year.

title: A Neighborhood Outing With Brassy Fanfare
description: The second leg of the New York Philharmonic's tour of parks in and around New York City got under way on Tuesday evening at Van Cortlandt Park, in the Bronx. Kurt Masur has ceded the podium of the traveling Carlos Moseley Pavilion to a newcomer, Roberto Minczuk, a young Brazilian conductor, whose calling cards included some fluff (John Williams's ''Summon the Heroes''), a dash of Brazilian color (Lorenzo Fernandez's ''Batuque'') and two more substantial works (Tchaikovsky's Serenade and Dvorak's Eighth Symphony).

title: PROSECUTORS SEEK TESTING FOR DNA IN LEWINSKY DRESS
description: Prosecutors are seeking genetic testing of a dress belonging to Monica S. Lewinsky that she says contains physical evidence of a sexual encounter with President Clinton, lawyers close to the case say.

title: Russians Test American Fighters
description: The United States boxing team figured its toughest competition in the Goodwill Games would come from Cuba and Russia. During the quarterfinals, the United States held its own against Cuba. Last night, in the semifinals at The Theater at Madison Square Garden, United States boxers were 4-2 against Russian boxers.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Brian Clarke

title: In Heat Wave, Thirsty Trees Stir a Call for Helping Hands
description: This month's heat wave may be hard on people, but it is particularly troublesome for the city's five million trees, according to a warning yesterday by the Parks Department.

title: Revisiting a Dangerous Obsession
description: As a screenwriter, Vladimir Nabokov was a great novelist. Mere traces of his awkward, overlong screenplay for ''Lolita'' are evident in Stanley Kubrick's 1962 film (bizarre and dated in its own right), but the script survives in published form. In one of his least cinematic touches, Nabokov envisioned an on-camera prologue featuring Dr. John Ray Jr., the tongue-in-cheek character who framed the novel, a psychiatrist purporting to have edited Humbert Humbert's memoir about his affair with a 12-year-old nymphet.

title: Art Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Summer hours vary for galleries and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Cameraless Pictures, Rippling With Color
description: The camera often sees a great deal that the human eye doesn't. For Adam Fuss, cameraless photography sees even more. In his photograms -- images created by placing objects on large sheets of photographic paper and exposing them to light -- the simplest things are transformed into abstractions of startling beauty.

title: Queens Man Accused of Critically Injuring Girl, 3
description: A 27-year-old bodybuilder from Queens was arrested yesterday and accused of critically wounding his live-in girlfriend's 3-year-old daughter by beating her with a weight lifter's belt and then throwing her headfirst into a wall, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIRENBLATT, FLORENCE MAZO,
description: NIRENBLATT-Florence Mazo, 87. Of Charleston, SC, widow of Bernard Nirenblatt, died July 30, 1998. Graveside services will be held at 2 P.M., Friday, July 31, 1998, in Emanu-el Cemetery, directed by J. Henry Stuhr, Inc, Downtown Chapel. Mrs. Nirenblatt was born March 6, 1911 in Charleston, S.C. A daughter of Elihu Mazo and Anastasia Tandit Mazo. She was a member of Synagogue Emanu-el. She is survived by one son Norman Nirenblatt of Charleston, SC, one daughter Marilyn N. Hoffman of Charleston, SC, five grandchildren, five great grandchildren, five sisters, Mary M. Bodne of New York, Celie M. Weisman of New York, Annie M. Rabin, Minnie M. Meislin and Norma Mazo all of Charleston, SC. Memorials may be made to Synagogue Emanu-el, 5 Windsor Dr, Charleston, S.C. 29407 or The Charleston Jewish Federation, 1645 Raoul Wallenberg Blvd, Charleston, S.C. 29407.

title: Giving Unequal Treatment to the Halls of Fame
description: The ceremony to induct Mike Singletary, Anthony Munoz, Dwight Stephenson, Paul Krause and Tommy McDonald into the Pro Football Hall of Fame tomorrow will be carried live on ESPN2 from noon to 2 P.M. That's live. For two hours.

title: TV Weekend; Battles and Bloodshed Over Millenniums
description: John Keegan, the popular British military historian, lends scholarship to ''War and Civilization,'' the eight-part history of mayhem that begins Sunday night on the Learning Channel. Walter Cronkite, America's narrator for all occasions, lends his portentous baritone. And the producers lay on plenty of effects -- smoke, bodies, slow motion, fleeting images -- intended to represent the most momentous clashes of the centuries.

title: World News Briefs; Turkey's Premier Plans A Visit to Israel
description: In a move that is expected to strengthen the close ties that have developed between Turkey and Israel over the last year, Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz is to visit Israel in early September, according to a diplomat involved in planning the trip.

title: Friendly Crowd Greets Clinton in South
description: President Clinton appeared today before friendly crowds in North Carolina, never mentioning the sex and perjury inquiries as he pressed his environmental programs and helped raise money for John Edwards, a Democratic candidate for the Senate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARNER, MARY MOSHER.
description: WARNER-Mary Mosher. On June 22, 1998 at her residence in Upper Nyack. She was a former teacher. Survived by her husband, Charles H. Warner Jr., son Mark, daughter-in-law Susan, two grandchildren: Mark Jr., Amy. Predeceased by a son, Peter. Funeral services were held in Nyack, July 11, 1998.

title: High Road Is Only Road G.O.P. Takes
description: The House of Representatives begins its session most days with a period for one-minute speeches that members can devote to any topic they please. Often, representatives use these speeches to address the news of the day.

title: Something Old, Something New in Japan Chief's Cabinet
description: Keizo Obuchi took office on Thursday as Prime Minister and named a Cabinet which, while it largely reflects his loyalty to factions of the governing Liberal Democratic Party that insured his election, also made a nod to younger members pushing for change.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR RISES 3.8 PERCENT. After languishing near 11-year lows, sugar rallied when Indonesia said it would buy 700,000 tons, helped by an international aid package. The October contract rose 0.32 cent, to 8.84 cents a pound.

title: Beverly Hills Journal; Once Again, Tinseltown Brings Down the House
description: The big Tudor house on the corner was not exactly the old Granville place in ''It's a Wonderful Life,'' and the man who lived there for nearly 50 years until he died last summer was named James Stewart, not George Bailey. But 918 North Roxbury Drive, with its towering trees, wide lawn and walled English garden, was a landmark on a leafy street where the neighbors included Lucille Ball, Jack Benny and Ira Gershwin.

title: Pearson Faces New Scrutiny In Its Simon & Schuster Bid
description: The British media group Pearson P.L.C. is facing a new round of scrutiny from Federal antitrust regulators in its bid to become the world's biggest educational publisher with the purchase of most of Simon & Schuster.

title: Lottery Fever: States Feed It, And Catch It
description: WHEN a Bronx waiter is so overcome by Powerball fever that he plunks down $3,000 that should have gone for his trade-school tuition, when presumably solid citizens waste hours standing in line to buy a pipe dream, when ill will flows likes a river outside overburdened lottery shops in Greenwich, Conn., some people question the wisdom and even morality of government turning itself into a numbers runner.

title: On a Tightrope, Finding Her Dream
description: What is it about the Goodspeed Opera House and musicals involving plucky, pint-size redheads who melt hearts and minister to troubled adults? From the theater where ''Annie'' was born 22 years ago now comes ''Mirette,'' with music and lyrics by ''The Fantasticks'' team of Harvey Schmidt and Tom Jones. It is adapted from the prize-winning children's book ''Mirette on the High Wire,'' the story of a little girl's dream of becoming a tightrope walker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUS, WILLIAM
description: STRAUS-William. Age 96, of Lauderhill, Florida, passed away July 30, 1998. Mr. Strauss is survived by his loving wife, Celia Topf Straus; devoted son, Robert H. Straus acting Justice New York State Supreme Court, adored daughter-in-law Bobbi Straus and cherished grandson Matthew Robert Straus. Funeral services will be held today, Friday July 31 at 11 AM, Washington Cemetery, Brooklyn, New York. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Sarah L. Straus Alumni Scholarship Fund, c/o Seward Park High School, 350 Grand Street, New York, NY 10002

Paid Notice: Deaths  DONAHUE, ROBERT F.
description: DONAHUE-Robert F. The officers, directors, and employees of Hoenig & Co., Inc., mourn the passing of our dear friend and colleague. Bob played an important role at Hoenig during his twentyfour years and served as a director from 1987 until 1997. We appreciate his many contributions during his years with the Hoenig organization.

title: Hollywood Entertainment to Buy Reel.Com
description: The Hollywood Entertainment Corporation, the second-largest chain of video rental shops, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Reel.Com Inc., the largest service selling videos over the Internet. The price is $100 million, of which $30 million is in cash and the remainder in stock.

title: On My Mind; 'What Did You Do To Us?'
description: Twenty-five years ago an editor on The New York Times, decently paid and with a good future, diverted money from the newspaper to himself -- less than $1,000. He did it in a way that made it inevitable that the paper would soon find out.

title: Wounded Tourist Says Shootings Have Left Some Emotional Scars
description: Angela Dickerson, who was wounded in last week's shootings at the Capitol, said today that she would carry no deep scars, except perhaps emotional ones.

title: Stellar Hint at Radiation's Role in Life
description: The left-handed molecules that led to the creation of life on earth may have been singled out for their eventual role in biology by a type of radiation astronomers have discovered in a star-forming cloud some 1,500 light-years away.

title: Coffers Full, Massachusetts Slashes Taxes
description: How is this as a measure of the monetary euphoria sweeping statehouses across the country lately? Even here, in the state derided not so long ago as Taxachusetts, Acting Gov. Argeo Paul Cellucci signed a $19.5 billion budget today that incorporated part of a brand new, multiyear, $770 million tax cut, the largest in the state's history.

title: Laver's Strength? No Weakness
description: IT seemed a perfect nickname: Rocket. For when Rod Laver was playing top-flight tennis, and dominating his sport as few others have -- he is the only player to win the Grand Slam twice, sweeping all four major tournaments in 1962 and 1969 -- he looked like the rocket's red glare. Swift, sure, relatively small, at 5 feet 8 1/2 inches and 150 pounds, with a patch of red hair that resembled a rooster's comb when in flight, a profusion of freckles, a beaklike nose, bandy legs, left-handed and a will to reach and whack back every shot at every conceivable angle on the court, the spectator saw a scarlet blur.

description: Hail to the Chief

title: Ferraro Stresses Status as Only Woman in Race
description: Asserting that Congress has suffered because of the scarcity of women in its ranks, Geraldine A. Ferraro said yesterday that she should be elected to the Senate because she could, as a woman, bring a perspective to a variety of issues, from child care to the economy, that her male competitors could not match.

description: To the Editor:

title: $62 Billion Bank Bailout Plan in Mexico Incites Outrage as Critics Say It Helps the Rich
description: If there is anyone who personifies what Mexicans distrust about their banking system, it is Angel Isidoro Rodriguez Saez.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: JACOBS ENGINEERING GROUP INC., -- Pasadena, Calif., said its Rocky Flats Closure Site Services had received a $225 million contract from Kaiser-Hill Co., Denver, to provide support services for a cleanup of the defunct Rocky Flats nuclear-weapons plant in Colorado.

title: OMNICARE TO BUY PHARMACY BUSINESS FROM EXTENDICARE
description: Omnicare Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the pharmacy operations of Extendicare Health Services Inc. of Canada for $264 million in cash and stock. Omnicare, based in Covington, Ky., provides pharmacy and related consulting services for nursing homes and other long-term care operations. Extendicare Health, a unit of Extendicare Inc. in Markham, Ontario, operates 312 long-term-care operations in Canada, the United States and Britain. Extendicare Health's pharmacy business, which operates under the name United Professional Companies, provides services to 550 facilities in 12 states. Shares of Omnicare rose $1.125 yesterday, to $38.625.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OURMAN, HOWARD
description: OURMAN-Howard. On July 30, 1998. Devoted father of Stanley and David. Graveside service on Friday 11:00 A.M., at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont.

title: Cabaret Guide
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Sharpton Claims Victory, and Vows to Appeal Defamation Verdict
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton claimed victory yesterday, a day after a jury in Dutchess County ordered him to pay $65,000 to a white former prosecutor whom he had accused of kidnapping and raping a black teen-ager 10 years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOYLE, JOHN (JACK),
description: DOYLE-John (Jack), Detective Lieutenant/Commander, Manhattan North Homicide Squad, 41 years with N.Y.C.P.D., of Garden City, New York, on July 29, 1998. Beloved husband of Patricia M. (Nee Duffy). Devoted father of John P., Ann M. Doyle, Maureen Stuhlman, Kevin P., Peter D. and Patrick J. Doyle. Father-in-law of Gerard, Grace and Claire. Also survived by six grandchildren. Dear brother of Thomas & James Doyle and Mary Geelan. Reposing at Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 125 Hillside Avenue, New Hyde Park, New York. Funeral Mass Saturday, 10:15 AM, at St. Anne's Church, Garden City. Interment at Calvary Cemetery, Long Island City, NY. Visiting hours Friday 2-5 & 7-9:30 PM. In Lieu of Flowers, donations to Rice High School (1-212-369-4100), Chaminade High School (1-516-742-5555), or Adults & Children with Learning and Developmental Disabilities, Inc. (1-516-352-5904), appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODLIFFE, STANLEY GEORGE.
description: WOODLIFFE-Stanley George. On July 29, 1998. Survived by his sister, Iris W. Kramer; cousin, Margaret Davey; nephew, Richard B. Kramer; grand nephew, Michael W. Kramer; and grand niece, Laurie J. Kramer. Employee of Trinity Church, 74 Trinity Place, NYC for forty years until retirement. Funeral service, Trinity Church, All Saints Chapel, Saturday, 1PM.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on July 3 about a plan by the Japanese Government to clear away the nation's bad debts referred incorrectly to the timing of the plan. Government officials have not indicated when the plan might be completed; they did not say they hoped it would take two to five years.

title: Time Bandit Wins Sanford Stakes
description: If it's Saratoga, it must be 2-year-olds, and if it's 2-year-olds, it must be the trainer D. Wayne Lukas.

title: Business District Vows to Fight City's Order to Shut It Down
description: Setting the stage for a legal battle over the rules governing business improvement districts in New York City, the Grand Central Partnership said yesterday that it would seek a court order to block the seizure of its assets and financial records by the city.

title: Metro Business; Firing at Laser Mortgage
description: Laser Mortgage Management Inc.'s board fired Michael Smirlock, its founder, chairman and chief executive, yesterday and said it was hiring an adviser to evaluate ''strategic alternatives'' and boost the stock price.

title: Elusive Prey in a Courtly Paradise
description: The branch of the Metropolitan Museum known as the Cloisters is, in every sense, one of the high points of art in New York City. An impressive jumble of Romanesque scraps and American prewar masonry, and a monument to American philanthropy, it sits atop a rocky outcrop over the Hudson near the upper tip of Manhattan. The island's last stand of virgin forest is just to the north beyond a geological fault line; to the south the terrain gradually descends toward midtown.

title: LOUISIANA COMPANY ORDERS 3 GENERATORS FROM CBS UNIT
description: Westinghouse Power Generation of Orlando, Fla., said yesterday that it had received a contract valued at more than $75 million from the Cleco Corporation for three combustion turbine-generators. Westinghouse Power, a unit of the CBS Corporation, said Cleco, based in Pineville, La., would use three Westinghouse combustion turbine-generators to replace steam turbines at its plant in St. Landry, La. Cleco provides electrical service to 238,000 customers in Louisiana.

title: E.D.S. Posts 25% Gain but Issues Warning
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation said today that its second-quarter profit rose 25 percent, beating estimates, but it warned that earnings for the rest of the year would be hurt by labor problems at General Motors.

title: Universal Care, Yes, but Patient's Rights First; Paying for Lobbyists
description: To the Editor:

title: Messages in the Media: Varied Perceptions of Factuality
description: Guys Jackson Pollock, Mark Rothko, Barnett Newman, Ad Reinhardt -- made Abstract Expressionism. Other guys -- Robert Rauschenberg, Jasper Johns, Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein, James Rosenquist -- made proto-Pop and Pop Art, and still other guys made Minimalism, Conceptualism and the various isms of the 1960's. But girls made post-modernism.

title: Broken Record: Wheatley is Hurt
description: For Tyrone Wheatley, no Giants season has ever been without controversy or injury. Or both.

title: Plumbing the Subconscious to Reach Marital Equilibrium
description: Hypnotism and feng shui (the Eastern philosophy involving the strategic placement of buildings and their contents to achieve a greater harmony with nature) are forces that impinge powerfully on the marriage of Mathilde (Sandrine Kiberlain), a neurotic 29-year-old Parisian, and her 39-year-old husband, Nico (Vincent Lindon), a successful orthopedic surgeon. In Benoit Jacquot's eerie, exquisitely subtle film ''Seventh Heaven,'' which opens today at the Quad Cinema, both are crucial elements of what might be described as a psychological mystery that exudes a faint undertone of menace.

title: A Union Vote Sows Bitterness in California Strawberry Fields
description: Tension and fear hover over the strawberry fields of the Coastal Berry Company here like the morning fog.

description: The ''On Stage and Off'' column will resume with the new theater season in the fall.

title: Reforming Welfare With Education
description: An important amendment approved by the Senate to the bill reauthorizing the Higher Education Act would give states the option of allowing welfare recipients to enroll in postsecondary education or vocational training for two years without losing their welfare benefits. The provision, sponsored by Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota, should be retained in the final bill.

title: Noel Behn, 70, Novelist, Producer and Screenwriter
description: Noel Behn, a novelist, screenwriter, theatrical producer and celebrated raconteur who held court nightly at Elaine's, the Upper East Side watering hole, died on Monday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. He was 70 and lived in Manhattan.

description: Japan Seeks a Balance

description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 10.

title: AFTER EARNINGS FALL SHORT, ORION PLANS TO SELL A UNIT
description: The Orion Capital Corporation, a specialty property and casualty insurer in Farmington, Conn., plans to sell its Colorado Casualty unit after disappointing second-quarter earnings. Orion said yesterday that second-quarter profit -- excluding gains on the sale of securities -- rose 15 percent, to $23.4 million, or 83 cents a diluted share, from $20.3 million, or 73 cents, in the quarter a year ago. Analysts had forecast 85 cents. Orion stock fell $1.6875, to $48. The earnings shortfall prompted Orion management to step up plans to exit the increasingly competitive business of insuring cars and trucks for companies, as well as put the Colorado Casualty unit up for sale. Colorado Casualty sells business and general liability insurance in rural areas, with annual premiums of about $55 million.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHLOSSER, H. ARTHUR.
description: SCHLOSSER-H. Arthur. Papa, it's your 80th birthday and we miss you and love you as much as ever. You were our shining star and still are. Judy, Gary, Irene, Rich, Max, Ken and children.
